en: CHAPTER I.
vi: Chapter 1
tr: First chapter
es: Chapter 1

en: The studio was filled with the rich odour of roses, and when the light summer wind stirred amidst the trees of the garden, there came through the open door the heavy scent of the lilac, or the more delicate perfume of the pink-flowering thorn.
vi: The studio was filled with the fragrance of roses, and when the gentle summer breeze stirred among the trees in the garden, the scent of lilacs wafted through the open door, mingling with the more delicate aroma of blooming wild peach blossoms.
tr: The studio was filled with the languid scent of roses; when a light summer breeze wandered among the trees in the garden, the heavy fragrance of lilacs or the more delicate perfume of pink-flowered thorn trees wafted in through the open door.
es: The intense perfume of the roses embalmed the studio, and when the light breeze stirred the trees in the garden, an intense scent of lilacs or the more delicate aroma of the pink flowers of the hawthorns entered through the open door.

en: From the corner of the divan of Persian saddle-bags on which he was lying, smoking, as was his custom, innumerable cigarettes, Lord Henry Wotton could just catch the gleam of the honey-sweet and honey-coloured blossoms of a laburnum, whose tremulous branches seemed hardly able to bear the burden of a beauty so flamelike as theirs; and now and then the fantastic shadows of birds in flight flitted across the long tussore-silk curtains that were stretched in front of the huge window, producing a kind of momentary Japanese effect, and making him think of those pallid, jade-faced painters of Tokyo who, through the medium of an art that is necessarily immobile, seek to convey the sense of swiftness and motion. The sullen murmur of the bees shouldering their way through the long unmown grass, or circling with monotonous insistence round the dusty gilt horns of the straggling woodbine, seemed to make the stillness more oppressive. The dim roar of London was like the bourdon note of a distant organ.
vi: From the corner of the Persian camel saddlebag-patterned divan on which he habitually lay smoking countless cigarettes, Lord Henry Wotton could only faintly see the honey-sweet and honey-colored blossoms of a laburnum tree whose trembling branches seemed to struggle under the weight of such a blazing beauty; and occasionally, the strange shadows of birds in flight would flicker across the long tussore silk curtains drawn before the wide window, evoking a sensation somewhat akin to a fleeting Japanese impression, and making him think of the green-faced, yellow-fanged artists in Tokyo, who, through the medium of an inherently static art, had attempted to convey a sense of swiftness and movement. The mournful hum of bees threading through the long, uncut grass, or circling with monotonous persistence around the golden-tipped horns of the overgrown honeysuckle, seemed to make the stillness even more oppressive. The distant roar of London was like the pedal note of a far-off organ.
tr: Lord Henry Wotton, who was lying in the corner of the divan adorned with Iranian saddlebags, smoking countless cigarettes as was his habit, could make out the honey-colored, honey-sweet flowers of the yellow wisteria tree from where he was. The tree's trembling branches seemed to struggle under the burden of such flame-like beauty. Occasionally, the shadows of birds, like dreams, would fall upon the long, silken curtains stretched in front of the large window. At first glance, these curtains, which evoked a Japanese atmosphere, reminded Lord Henry of the pale, emerald-faced painters of Tokyo; painters who tried to convey movement and speed through the necessarily static medium of art. The dull hum of bees, either trying to make their way through the tall, uncut grass or circling monotonously around the dusty, gilded horns of the sprawling French marigolds, seemed to make the tranquility of the surroundings all the more tedious. The faint hum of London resembled the bass notes of a distant organ melody.
es: Lord Henry Wotton, who had already consumed, as was his custom, innumerable cigarettes, glimpsed, from the end of the sofa where he was lying —upholstered in the style of Persian carpets—, the glow of the blossoms of a broom, sweet and honey-colored, whose trembling branches barely seemed capable of bearing the weight of such dazzling beauty as theirs; and, from time to time, the fantastic shadows of birds in flight slid over the long Indian silk curtains hanging in front of the immense windows, producing something like a Japanese effect, which made him think of the painters of Tokyo, with faces as pale as jade, who, through a necessarily motionless art, try to convey the sensation of speed and movement. The obstinate buzzing of bees, making their way through the tall unmown grass, or circling with monotonous insistence around the dusty golden horns of the disordered honeysuckles, seemed to make the stillness more oppressive, while the confused noises of London were like the deep notes of a distant organ.

en: In the centre of the room, clamped to an upright easel, stood the full-length portrait of a young man of extraordinary personal beauty, and in front of it, some little distance away, was sitting the artist himself, Basil Hallward, whose sudden disappearance some years ago caused, at the time, such public excitement and gave rise to so many strange conjectures.
vi: In the middle of the room, clamped tightly onto an upright easel, was a full-length portrait of a young man with extraordinary personal beauty, and sitting in front of it, a little further away, was the artist himself, Basil Hallward, whose sudden disappearance a few years ago had caused, at that time, an overwhelming public sensation and generated a myriad of strange speculations.
tr: In the very center of the room, on a standing canvas, stood a portrait of an extraordinarily beautiful young man. In front of it, a little further away, sat the painter of the portrait: Basil Hallward, who had caused quite a stir a few years ago by suddenly disappearing and giving rise to a host of strange speculations.
es: In the center of the room, on a straight easel, rested the full-length portrait of a young man of extraordinary beauty; and, in front, at a certain distance, sat the artist himself, Basil Hallward, whose sudden disappearance a few years ago so moved society and gave rise to such strange suppositions.

en: As the painter looked at the gracious and comely form he had so skilfully mirrored in his art, a smile of pleasure passed across his face, and seemed about to linger there. But he suddenly started up, and closing his eyes, placed his fingers upon the lids, as though he sought to imprison within his brain some curious dream from which he feared he might awake.
vi: As the artist gazed at the elegant and beautiful figure that he had skillfully captured with his art, a contented smile briefly crossed his face and seemed about to linger there. But he suddenly stood up and, closing his eyes, placed his fingers on his eyelids, as if trying to imprison in his mind a strange dream from which he feared he might awaken.
tr: As he gazed at the elegant and handsome figure reflected in the artist's work, a smile of pleasure spread across his face, and it seemed as if he wanted to linger there for a while. However, he suddenly started and straightened up, closing his eyes and pressing his fingertips against his eyelids as if trying to trap a strange dream in his mind that he feared losing upon waking.
es: Upon contemplating the handsome and elegant figure that he had so skillfully depicted thanks to his art, a smile of satisfaction, which perhaps could have lasted longer, illuminated his face. But the artist abruptly stood up and, closing his eyes, covered his eyelids with his fingers, as if trying to capture in his mind some strange dream from which he feared to awaken.

en: “It is your best work, Basil, the best thing you have ever done,” said Lord Henry languidly. “You must certainly send it next year to the Grosvenor. The Academy is too large and too vulgar. Whenever I have gone there, there have been either so many people that I have not been able to see the pictures, which was dreadful, or so many pictures that I have not been able to see the people, which was worse. The Grosvenor is really the only place.”
vi: "That is your most beautiful work, Basil, the most beautiful thing you have ever created," Lord Henry said languidly. "Next year you must certainly send it to the Grosvenor. The Academy is too large and too vulgar. Every time I go there, it is either so crowded that I cannot see the paintings, which are dreadful, or there are so many paintings that I cannot see the people, which is even worse. The Grosvenor is really the only place."
tr: Lord Henry said in a lazy voice, "This is your best work, Basil, the finest thing you have done." "You must send it to the Grosvenor Gallery next year, without a doubt. The Academy is too large, too vulgar. Whenever I went there, I either couldn't see the paintings because of the crowd, which is a terrible thing, or I couldn't see the people because of the multitude of paintings, which is even worse. Believe me, the only option is the Grosvenor Gallery."
es: —It is your best work, Basil —said Lord Henry with a languid tone—, the best you have done. Be sure to send it to the Grosvenor Gallery next year. The Academy is too large and too vulgar. Every time I go there, either there are so many people that I can't see the paintings, which is horrible, or there are so many paintings that I can't see the people, which is even worse. The Grosvenor Gallery is the right place.

en: “I don’t think I shall send it anywhere,” he answered, tossing his head back in that odd way that used to make his friends laugh at him at Oxford. “No, I won’t send it anywhere.”
vi: “I don't think I'll send it anywhere,” he replied, tossing his head back in that peculiar way that often made his friends laugh at him in Oxford. “No: I won't send it anywhere.”
tr: The painter replied, "I don't think I'll send this anywhere," throwing his head back with that strange motion that had always amused his friends when he was in Oxford. "No, I won't send it anywhere."
es: —I don't think I'll send it anywhere —replied the artist, throwing his head back in that curious way that always made his friends from Oxford laugh—. No; I won't send the portrait anywhere.

en: Lord Henry elevated his eyebrows and looked at him in amazement through the thin blue wreaths of smoke that curled up in such fanciful whorls from his heavy, opium-tainted cigarette. “Not send it anywhere? My dear fellow, why? Have you any reason? What odd chaps you painters are! You do anything in the world to gain a reputation. As soon as you have one, you seem to want to throw it away. It is silly of you, for there is only one thing in the world worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about. A portrait like this would set you far above all the young men in England, and make the old men quite jealous, if old men are ever capable of any emotion.”
vi: Lord Henry raised an eyebrow and looked at him in astonishment through the thin blue smoke curling into surreal spirals from his opium-laden cigarette. “Not sending it anywhere? My friend, why? Do you have any reason? You artists are truly peculiar creatures! You do everything in the world to gain fame. Yet the moment you have it, it seems you want to throw it away. That is your folly, for there is only one thing in this world worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about. A portrait like this would place you above all the young men in England, and make the old ones seethe with envy, if those old men are still capable of feeling any emotion.”
tr: Lord Henry raised his eyebrows; he looked at his friend in astonishment through the thin, blue rings of smoke spiraling up from the thick, opium-laced cigarette he was smoking. “Aren't you going to send it anywhere? My dear friend, why? Do you have a reason? You painters are such strange people! You do everything to gain fame. And as soon as you gain it, you want to squander it! What you're doing is nonsense, because if there's anything worse in this world than being talked about, it's not being talked about. Such a portrait would place you higher than all the young painters in England and make the old ones die of envy; though I don't know if the old ones have any feelings left.”
es: Lord Henry raised his eyebrows and looked at him with astonishment through the thin curls of smoke that, emerging from his opium-laced cigarette, twisted into strange shapes. —Aren't you going to send it anywhere? Why, my dear friend? What reason could you give? Why are you painters such strange people? You do anything to earn a reputation, but as soon as you have it, it seems you don't want it anymore. It's foolish, because in the world there's only one thing worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about. A portrait like that would place you far above all the young English painters and would arouse the jealousy of the old ones, if the old ones are still capable of emotions.

en: “I know you will laugh at me,” he replied, “but I really can’t exhibit it. I have put too much of myself into it.”
vi: “I know you will laugh at me,” he replied, “but I really can't display it. I've put too much of myself into it already.”
tr: Painter Hallward said, "I know you will mock me, but still, I really can't exhibit this painting." "I have put so much of myself into it."
es: —I know you're going to laugh at me —replied Hallward—, but I can't exhibit that portrait. I've put too much of myself into it.

en: Lord Henry stretched himself out on the divan and laughed.
vi: Lord Henry stretched out on the couch and laughed.
tr: Lord Henry lay full length on the divan and laughed.
es: Lord Henry, stretching out on the sofa, let out a laugh.

en: “Yes, I knew you would; but it is quite true, all the same.”
vi: “Yes, I know you will; but nevertheless, it is entirely true.”
tr: "Yes, I knew you would laugh, but I'm still telling the truth, no matter what you say.""
es: —Yes, Harry, I knew you were going to laugh, but, anyway, it's nothing but the truth.

en: “Too much of yourself in it! Upon my word, Basil, I didn’t know you were so vain; and I really can’t see any resemblance between you, with your rugged strong face and your coal-black hair, and this young Adonis, who looks as if he was made out of ivory and rose-leaves. Why, my dear Basil, he is a Narcissus, and you—well, of course you have an intellectual expression and all that. But beauty, real beauty, ends where an intellectual expression begins. Intellect is in itself a mode of exaggeration, and destroys the harmony of any face. The moment one sits down to think, one becomes all nose, or all forehead, or something horrid. Look at the successful men in any of the learned professions. How perfectly hideous they are! Except, of course, in the Church. But then in the Church they don’t think. A bishop keeps on saying at the age of eighty what he was told to say when he was a boy of eighteen, and as a natural consequence he always looks absolutely delightful. Your mysterious young friend, whose name you have never told me, but whose picture really fascinates me, never thinks. I feel quite sure of that. He is some brainless beautiful creature who should be always here in winter when we have no flowers to look at, and always here in summer when we want something to chill our intelligence. Don’t flatter yourself, Basil: you are not in the least like him.”
vi: “Too much of yourself in it! It’s really odd, Basil, I didn’t know you were so vain; and I really can’t see any resemblance between you, with your rugged strong face and coal-black hair, and this young Adonis, who looks as if he were made out of ivory and rose leaves. Why, my dear Basil, he is a Narcissus, and you — oh, of course you have an intellectual expression and all that. But beauty, real beauty, ends where an intellectual expression begins. Intellect in itself is a mode of exaggeration, and destroys the harmony of any face. The moment one sits down to think, one becomes all nose, or all forehead, or something horrid. Look at the successful men in any of the learned professions. How perfectly hideous they are! Except, of course, in the Church. But then in the Church they don’t think. A bishop keeps on saying at the age of eighty what he was told to say when he was a boy of eighteen, and as a natural consequence, he always looks absolutely delightful. Your mysterious young friend, whose name you have never told me, but whose picture really fascinates me, never thinks. I am quite sure of that. He is some brainless, beautiful creature, who should always be here in winter when we have no flowers to look at, and always here in summer when we want something to chill our intelligence. Don’t flatter yourself, Basil: you are not in the least like him.”
tr: “You added a lot of yourself, huh! God bless you, Basil, I never knew you were so arrogant. I can't see any resemblance between your coal-black hair, your harsh-lined, swarthy face and this young Adonis; believe me, this young man looks like he's made of ivory and rose petals. A perfect Adonis, dear Basil, while you... Yes, you do have an intellectual expression, and so on, but beauty, true beauty, ends where the intellectual expression begins. The mind is a kind of exaggeration in itself, it disrupts the harmony of the face it enters. The moment a person starts to think, they become all nose, all forehead, or something equally dreadful. Just look at the men who have succeeded in intellectual professions. How utterly ugly they are from head to toe! Only the church is an exception to this, naturally. However, those who have made the church their profession do not think either. A bishop will say at eighty what he was taught to say at eighteen, and as a result, he always appears charming. As for that mysterious young friend of yours whose name you haven't mentioned but whose portrait truly fascinates me, I don't think he thinks at all. I can bet on it. A brainless, beautiful creature; he should be here in winter when we have no flowers to look at, and in summer when we need something to cool our minds. Don't flatter yourself, Basil, you don't resemble him in the slightest.”
es: "Too much of yourself!" "By my faith, Basil, I didn't know you were so vain; I don't see the slightest resemblance between you, with your well-defined and somewhat harsh features and your hair as black as coal, and that young Adonis, who seems to be made of ivory and rose petals." "Come now, my dear Basil, that boy is a Narcissus, and you... well, you have, of course, an intellectual air and all that." "But beauty, true beauty, ends where the intellectual air begins." "Intellect is, in itself, a form of exaggeration, and it destroys the harmony of any face." "The moment someone starts to think, they become all nose or forehead or something dreadful." "Look at those who succeed in any learned profession." "They are absolutely impossible." "With the exception, of course, of the Church." "But it happens that in the Church one does not think." "A bishop continues to say at eighty what he was told to say at eighteen, and the logical consequence is that he always looks delightful." "Your mysterious young friend, whose name you have never revealed to me, but whose portrait truly fascinates me, never thinks." "I am completely sure of it." "He is a beautiful, brainless creature, who should always be here in winter, when we have no flowers to look at, and also in summer, when we seek something to cool our intelligence." "Don't delude yourself, Basil: you are nothing like him at all."

en: “You don’t understand me, Harry,” answered the artist. “Of course I am not like him. I know that perfectly well. Indeed, I should be sorry to look like him. You shrug your shoulders? I am telling you the truth. There is a fatality about all physical and intellectual distinction, the sort of fatality that seems to dog through history the faltering steps of kings. It is better not to be different from one’s fellows. The ugly and the stupid have the best of it in this world. They can sit at their ease and gape at the play. If they know nothing of victory, they are at least spared the knowledge of defeat. They live as we all should live—undisturbed, indifferent, and without disquiet. They neither bring ruin upon others, nor ever receive it from alien hands. Your rank and wealth, Harry; my brains, such as they are—my art, whatever it may be worth; Dorian Gray’s good looks—we shall all suffer for what the gods have given us, suffer terribly.”
vi: “You don't understand me, Harry,” the artist replied. “Of course, I am not like him. I know that very well. Indeed, I should be sad if I looked like him. You shrug? I am telling you the truth. There is a destiny for all physical and intellectual excellence, a kind of destiny that seems to follow the faltering steps of kings throughout history. It is better not to be different from your friends. Ugliness and ignorance are always the most advantageous in this world. They can sit comfortably and yawn at the game. If they know nothing of victory, at least they do not have to know defeat. They live as we all should live, peacefully, indifferently, without worry. They do not bring trouble to others nor receive it from anyone else. Your status and wealth, Harry; my intellect, as it is — my art, whatever it may be worth; the beauty of Dorian Gray — we all must bear what the gods give us, bear it miserably.”
tr: The painter replied, "You don't understand me, Harry." "Of course, I don't resemble him. I know this very well. In fact, I would be upset if I resembled him. Are you shrugging your shoulders? I'm telling you the truth. In my opinion, there is a curse in all physical and mental excellence, the kind of curse that has followed the faltering steps of kings throughout history. It is better not to be different from our other human brothers. I think the luckiest ones in this world are the ugly and the foolish. They can lie back and watch the game called life with their mouths open. Even if they don't know what victory is, at least they don't taste defeat either. They actually live as we all should live, carefree, indifferent, and without turmoil. They do not cause the ruin of others, nor do they become victims at the hands of others. Your title and wealth, Harry; my mind and intellect, however limited; if my art has any value; Dorian Gray's beauty... We will all suffer because of these gifts from God, and suffer greatly."
es: —You don't understand me, Harry —replied the artist—. I'm not like him, of course. I know that perfectly well. In fact, I would regret resembling him. Are you shrugging your shoulders? I'm telling you the truth. There is an adverse fate tied to bodily or intellectual superiority, the adverse fate that throughout history follows the faltering steps of kings. It is much better not to be different from the majority. The ugly and the stupid are the ones who have the best time in the world. They can sit comfortably and watch the show with their mouths open. Even if they know nothing of triumph, at least they are spared the disappointments of defeat. They live as we all should live, calmly, carelessly, impassively. They neither cause the ruin of others, nor receive it from others. Your social status and your wealth, Harry; my brain, whatever it may be; my art, whatever its value; the handsomeness of Dorian Gray: we are all going to suffer for what the gods have given us, and suffer terribly.

en: “Dorian Gray? Is that his name?” asked Lord Henry, walking across the studio towards Basil Hallward.
vi: “Dorian Gray? Is that his name?” Lord Henry asked as he walked across the studio towards Basil Hallward.
tr: Lord Henry walked towards Basil Hallward, who was sitting on the other side of the studio, and said, "Dorian Gray?" "Is that his name?"
es: "Dorian Gray? Is that his name?" asked Lord Henry, crossing the studio towards Basil Hallward.

en: “Yes, that is his name. I didn’t intend to tell it to you.”
vi: “Yes, that's his name. I didn't intend to tell you that.”
tr: “Yes, that's the name. I had no intention of telling you.”
es: —Yes; that's what it's called. I didn't intend to tell you.

en: “But why not?”
vi: “But why not?”
tr: “Why, then?”
es: —But, why not?

en: “Oh, I can’t explain. When I like people immensely, I never tell their names to any one. It is like surrendering a part of them. I have grown to love secrecy. It seems to be the one thing that can make modern life mysterious or marvellous to us. The commonest thing is delightful if one only hides it. When I leave town now I never tell my people where I am going. If I did, I would lose all my pleasure. It is a silly habit, I dare say, but somehow it seems to bring a great deal of romance into one’s life. I suppose you think me awfully foolish about it?”
vi: “Oh, I can't explain. When I really like someone, I never tell anyone their name. Doing so is like giving away a part of them. I've gradually come to cherish secrecy. It seems to be something that can make modern life mysterious or extraordinary for us. The most trivial thing becomes interesting if we just hide it away. Now, whenever I leave the city, I never tell my family where I’m going. If I did, I would lose all my joy. It's a silly habit, I'm sure, but somehow it seems to bring a lot of romance to our lives. I bet you think I'm extremely foolish about this, don't you?”
tr: “Oh, I can't explain it! If I like someone a lot, I never tell anyone their name. It feels like handing over a piece of their identity to someone else. Over time, I grew to love secrecy. It seems to me that this is the only thing that can make modern life appear mysterious and magical to us. If you keep it secret, even the most ordinary thing can become sweet and enjoyable. These days, when I leave the city, I don't tell anyone where I'm going. If I did, all the fun would be ruined. It might be a childish habit, but it seems to add a lot of romance to one's life. You probably think I'm really stupid because of this, don't you?”
es: —I can't explain it to you. When I like someone very much, I never tell anyone their name. It's like giving away a part of that person. Over time, I have come to love the secret. It seems to be the only thing capable of making modern life mysterious or wonderful. Just hiding the most ordinary thing makes it delightful. When I leave London now, I never tell my people where I am going. If I did, it would stop being pleasurable for me. It's a silly habit, I admit, but for some reason, it seems to imbue life with romance. I suppose I seem terribly ridiculous to you, don't I?

en: “Not at all,” answered Lord Henry, “not at all, my dear Basil. You seem to forget that I am married, and the one charm of marriage is that it makes a life of deception absolutely necessary for both parties. I never know where my wife is, and my wife never knows what I am doing. When we meet—we do meet occasionally, when we dine out together, or go down to the Duke’s—we tell each other the most absurd stories with the most serious faces. My wife is very good at it—much better, in fact, than I am. She never gets confused over her dates, and I always do. But when she does find me out, she makes no row at all. I sometimes wish she would; but she merely laughs at me.”
vi: "Absolutely not," Lord Henry replied, "absolutely not, my dear Basil. You seem to forget that I am married, and one of the charms of marriage is that it makes living a lie absolutely necessary for both parties. I never know where my wife is, and my wife never knows what I am doing. When we meet — we occasionally meet, when we dine out together, or go down to the Duke's — we tell each other the most absurd stories with the most serious faces. My wife is very good at that — in fact, much better than I am. She never gets the dates wrong, while I often do. But when she catches me out, she never makes a fuss. Sometimes I wish she would; but she only laughs at me."
tr: “Not at all,” replied Lord Henry. “Dear Basil, not at all. You forget that I am a married man; the only attractive aspect of marriage is that it makes a life of deception necessary for both parties. I have no idea where my wife is in the world, and my wife has no idea what I am up to. When we meet – which we occasionally do, when we are invited to a dinner together or go to see the duke – we tell each other the most ridiculous lies without batting an eye. My wife is very skilled at this, much more skilled than I am, to be honest. She never gets the dates wrong, whereas I always do. But when my wife catches my lie, she never makes a fuss. Sometimes I wish she would, but she just laughs it off.”
es: —Absolutely not —replied Lord Henry—; nothing of the sort, my dear Basil. You seem to forget that I am married, and the only charm of marriage is that it requires both parties to practice deception assiduously. I never know where my wife is, and my wife never knows what I am doing. When we do meet, which sometimes happens because we go out to dinner together or visit the Duke's house, we tell each other with tremendous seriousness the most absurd stories about our respective activities. My wife does it very well; much better than I do, in fact. She never gets the dates wrong and I always do. But when she catches me, she doesn't get angry. Sometimes I wish she would, but she just laughs at me.

en: “I hate the way you talk about your married life, Harry,” said Basil Hallward, strolling towards the door that led into the garden. “I believe that you are really a very good husband, but that you are thoroughly ashamed of your own virtues. You are an extraordinary fellow. You never say a moral thing, and you never do a wrong thing. Your cynicism is simply a pose.”
vi: “I hate the way you talk about your family life, Harry,” Basil Hallward said, strolling towards the door leading to the garden. “I believe you are truly a very good husband, but you are very embarrassed by your own virtues. You are an extremely peculiar person. You never say anything moral, and you never do anything wrong. Your mockery is simply for show.”
tr: Basil Hallward walked slowly towards the door leading to the garden and said, "I hate the way you talk about your marriage, Harry." "I believe that you are actually a very good husband, but you are ashamed of your own virtues. You are a unique fellow, indeed. You never say anything moral, nor do you ever do anything immoral. Your cynical attitude is nothing but an affectation."
es: —I don't like at all how you talk about your married life, Harry —said Basil Hallward, heading towards the door that led to the garden—. I think you are actually an excellent husband, but you are ashamed of your virtues. You are an extraordinary person. You never give moral lessons and you never do anything wrong. Your cynicism is nothing but affectation.

en: “Being natural is simply a pose, and the most irritating pose I know,” cried Lord Henry, laughing; and the two young men went out into the garden together and ensconced themselves on a long bamboo seat that stood in the shade of a tall laurel bush. The sunlight slipped over the polished leaves. In the grass, white daisies were tremulous.
vi: “Living in harmony with nature is just for show, and it's the most annoying kind of showmanship I've ever known,” Lord Henry shouted, laughing; and the two young men walked into the garden, then settled on a long bamboo bench placed in the shade of a tall laurel bush. Sunlight glided through the glossy leaves. On the grass, daisies swayed.
tr: Lord Henry laughed and said, "Being natural is just another pose, and the most irritating one at that, in my opinion." Two young men went out to the garden together and sat on the long bamboo bench in the shade of a tall laurel tree. The sun was sliding down the polished leaves. The white daisies among the grass were trembling.
es: —Naturalness is also affectation, and the most irritating one I know —exclaimed Lord Henry, bursting into laughter. The two young people went out together to the garden, settling on a wide bamboo bench placed in the shade of a laurel tree. The sunlight slid over the waxed leaves. White daisies trembled on the grass.

en: After a pause, Lord Henry pulled out his watch. “I am afraid I must be going, Basil,” he murmured, “and before I go, I insist on your answering a question I put to you some time ago.”
vi: After a brief pause, Lord Henry took out his watch. “I’m afraid I must be going now, Basil,” he muttered, “and before I go, I implore you to answer the question I posed to you earlier.”
tr: After a pause, Lord Henry took out his pocket watch. “I'm sorry, but I have to go, Basil,” he murmured. “But before I go, I will insist that you answer one question. I asked you some time ago as well.”
es: After a silence, Lord Henry took out his pocket watch. —I am very much afraid that I must leave, Basil —he murmured—, but before I go, I insist that you answer the question I asked you a while ago.

en: “What is that?” said the painter, keeping his eyes fixed on the ground.
vi: “What is it?” the artist said, still staring at the ground.
tr: Without lifting his eyes from the ground, the painter asked, "What is it?"
es: —Which one was it? —said the painter, without lifting his eyes from the ground.

en: “You know quite well.”
vi: "You know very well."
tr: “You know it very well.”
es: —You know it perfectly well.

en: “I do not, Harry.”
vi: “I don't know, Harry.”
tr: “I don't know, Harry.”
es: —I don't know, Harry.

en: “Well, I will tell you what it is. I want you to explain to me why you won’t exhibit Dorian Gray’s picture. I want the real reason.”
vi: “Alright, I will tell you what it is. I want you to explain to me why you are not displaying the portrait of Dorian Gray. I want to know the real reason.”
tr: "Well then, let me tell you. I want you to explain why you don't want to exhibit Dorian Gray's portrait." “I told you, the real reason.”
es: —Well, then I will tell you. I want you to explain to me why you are not going to exhibit the portrait of Dorian Gray. I want the real reason.

en: “I told you the real reason.”
vi: “I already told you the real reason.””
tr: “I told you, the real reason.”
es: —I have given it to you.

en: “No, you did not. You said it was because there was too much of yourself in it. Now, that is childish.”
vi: “No, you haven't told me yet. You said it was because there were too many things about yourself in it. Come on, that sounds very childish.”
tr: “No, you didn't say that. You said, I put too much of myself into this painting. My friend, this is childhood.”
es: —No, you haven't. You told me that there is too much of you in that portrait. And that's childish.

en: “Harry,” said Basil Hallward, looking him straight in the face, “every portrait that is painted with feeling is a portrait of the artist, not of the sitter. The sitter is merely the accident, the occasion. It is not he who is revealed by the painter; it is rather the painter who, on the coloured canvas, reveals himself. The reason I will not exhibit this picture is that I am afraid that I have shown in it the secret of my own soul.”
vi: “Harry,” Basil Hallward said while looking straight at him, “every portrait that is painted with feeling is a portrait of the artist, not of the sitter. The sitter is merely the accident, the occasion. It is not he who is revealed by the painter; it is rather the painter who, on the colored canvas, reveals himself. The reason I will not exhibit this painting is that I am afraid that I have shown in it the secret of my own soul.”
tr: Looking into his friend's eyes, Basil Hallward said, "Harry." "Every portrait that is painted with feeling is a portrait of the artist, not of the sitter. The sitter is merely the accident, the occasion. It is not he who is revealed by the painter; it is rather the painter who, on the colored canvas, reveals himself. That is the reason I will not exhibit this picture: I am afraid that I have shown in it the secret of my own soul."
es: —Harry—said Basil Hallward, looking him directly in the eyes—, every portrait that is painted with feeling is a portrait of the artist, not of the sitter. The model is merely an accident, the occasion. It is not the subject that the painter reveals; rather, it is the painter who, on the colored canvas, reveals himself. The reason I will not exhibit the picture is that I am afraid I have shown the secret of my own soul.

en: Lord Henry laughed. “And what is that?” he asked.
vi: Lord Henry laughed. "And what is it?" he asked.
tr: Lord Henry laughed. “What could this mystery be?” he asked.
es: Lord Henry laughed. — And, what is ...? —he asked.

en: “I will tell you,” said Hallward; but an expression of perplexity came over his face.
vi: “I will tell you,” Hallward said; but a look of confusion crossed his face.
tr: Hallward said, "I will tell you," but a look of astonishment had appeared on his face.
es: —I am going to tell you —replied Hallward; but what appeared on his face was an expression of perplexity.

en: “I am all expectation, Basil,” continued his companion, glancing at him.
vi: "I am eagerly looking forward to it, Basil," his friend continued, glancing at him.
tr: His friend glanced at him and said, "I'm waiting, Basil."
es: —I am all ears, Basil —insisted his companion, glancing at him sideways.

en: “Oh, there is really very little to tell, Harry,” answered the painter; “and I am afraid you will hardly understand it. Perhaps you will hardly believe it.”
vi: “Oh, there really isn't much to tell, Harry,” the artist replied; “and I'm afraid you will find it hard to understand. You might find it hard to believe.”
tr: The painter replied, "There isn't much to tell." "I'm afraid you won't understand it properly. Maybe you won't want to believe it."
es: —In reality, there is very little to tell, Harry —replied the painter—, and I am afraid you would hardly understand it. Perhaps you wouldn't believe it either.

en: Lord Henry smiled, and leaning down, plucked a pink-petalled daisy from the grass and examined it. “I am quite sure I shall understand it,” he replied, gazing intently at the little golden, white-feathered disk, “and as for believing things, I can believe anything, provided that it is quite incredible.”
vi: Lord Henry smiled and bent down to pluck a pink-petaled daisy from the grass, examining it. “I am sure I can understand it,” he replied, staring intently at the small yellow center covered with white fuzz, “and as for the believable things, I can believe anything, as long as it is utterly unbelievable.”
tr: Lord Henry smiled and bent down, plucked a pink daisy from the grass, and began to examine it. Looking carefully at this small round flower with a golden eye in his hand, he said, "I have no doubt that I will understand." "As for believing; I can believe anything, as long as it is something utterly unbelievable."
es: Lord Henry smiled and, bending down, plucked a pink-petaled daisy from the grass and began to examine it. —I am sure I will understand it —he replied, staring intently at the small golden disc with white feathers—; and as for believing things, I can believe anything as long as it is totally unbelievable.

en: The wind shook some blossoms from the trees, and the heavy lilac-blooms, with their clustering stars, moved to and fro in the languid air. A grasshopper began to chirrup by the wall, and like a blue thread a long thin dragon-fly floated past on its brown gauze wings. Lord Henry felt as if he could hear Basil Hallward’s heart beating, and wondered what was coming.
vi: The wind brushed a few flowers off the tree, and the heavy lilac clusters, with their star-shaped blooms, swayed lazily in the air. A grasshopper began chirping incessantly by the wall, and like a blue thread, a slender dragonfly drifted past on its brown gauzy wings. Lord Henry felt as if he could hear Basil Hallward's heartbeat and wondered what was coming.
tr: The breeze scattered a few sprigs of flowers from the fruit trees; large lilacs, resembling clusters of stars, swayed in the languid air. A cricket began to chirp by the wall; a slender, long dragonfly, with its brown gauzy wings, flew past like a blue silk thread. Lord Henry felt as if he could hear his friend's heartbeat and wondered what he was going to say.
es: The air tore some flowers from the trees, and the heavy lilac blooms, with their clusters of stars, swayed languidly. A grasshopper began to sing next to the fence, and a dragonfly, long and slender like a blue thread, floated by on its brown gauze wings. Lord Henry had the impression of hearing the heartbeat of Basil Hallward, and wondered what was going to happen.

en: “The story is simply this,” said the painter after some time. “Two months ago I went to a crush at Lady Brandon’s. You know we poor artists have to show ourselves in society from time to time, just to remind the public that we are not savages. With an evening coat and a white tie, as you told me once, anybody, even a stock-broker, can gain a reputation for being civilized. Well, after I had been in the room about ten minutes, talking to huge overdressed dowagers and tedious academicians, I suddenly became conscious that some one was looking at me. I turned half-way round and saw Dorian Gray for the first time. When our eyes met, I felt that I was growing pale. A curious sensation of terror came over me. I knew that I had come face to face with some one whose mere personality was so fascinating that, if I allowed it to do so, it would absorb my whole nature, my whole soul, my very art itself. I did not want any external influence in my life. You know yourself, Harry, how independent I am by nature. I have always been my own master; had at least always been so, till I met Dorian Gray. Then—but I don’t know how to explain it to you. Something seemed to tell me that I was on the verge of a terrible crisis in my life. I had a strange feeling that fate had in store for me exquisite joys and exquisite sorrows. I grew afraid and turned to quit the room. It was not conscience that made me do so: it was a sort of cowardice. I take no credit to myself for trying to escape.”
vi: “That's all there is to it,” the artist said after a while. “Two months ago I attended a crowded gathering at Mrs. Brandon's place. You know, we poor artists sometimes have to show ourselves in society, just to remind the public that we are not barbarians. Wearing a dress coat and a white tie, as you once told me, anyone, even a stockbroker, can gain the reputation of being civilized. So, after I had been in the room for about ten minutes, talking to overly ostentatious fat widows and dull academicians, I suddenly realized that someone was looking at me. I turned halfway around and saw Dorian Gray for the first time. When our eyes met, I felt that I was turning pale. A dreadful sense of curiosity took hold of me. I knew that I was face to face with someone whose mere personality was so fascinating that, if I allowed it to do so, it would absorb my whole nature, my whole soul, and even my very art. I did not want any external influence in my life. You know yourself, Harry, how independent I am by nature. I have always been able to control myself; and at least it had always been so until I met Dorian Gray. Then — but I don't know how to explain it to you. Something seemed to tell me that I was on the verge of a terrible crisis in my life. I had a strange feeling that Fate had in store for me exquisite joys and exquisite sorrows. I gradually became afraid, and turned to leave the room. It wasn't conscience that made me do so; it was something akin to cowardice. I felt no glory in trying to escape.”
tr: After a pause, the painter said, "It all comes down to this." "Two months ago, I attended one of Lady Brandon's gatherings. You know, we poor artists occasionally have to show up in high society, just to remind everyone that we are not complete savages. Once, you told me; as long as one wears an evening coat and a white tie, anyone, even a stockbroker, can gain a reputation as a civilized person. Anyway, I had been in the room for about ten minutes. I was chatting with those large, overly adorned, elderly noblewomen and those tedious academy members when suddenly, I felt someone was looking at me. When I turned around, I saw Dorian Gray. I didn't know him at all. When our eyes met, I felt my face turn pale. A strange unease enveloped me. The mere presence of this person I was facing was so captivating that, if I allowed it, he could take over my entire being, my soul, even my art. I realized this immediately. Yet, I did not want any external interference in my life. You know how independent I am by nature, Harry. I have always been my own master. That is, until I met Dorian Gray. At that moment... But I don't know how to explain it to you. It was as if a voice was telling me that I was on the brink of a terrible crisis. I had a premonition that fate had prepared unparalleled joys and unparalleled sorrows for me. I got scared, turned around, and walked to the door with the intention of going outside. It wasn't the voice of my conscience that made me do this, it was a kind of cowardice. I'm not giving myself any credit for trying to escape.”
es: —It's a very simple story —said the painter after some time—. Two months ago, I attended one of those parties thrown by Lady Brandon, which so many people go to. You know that we poor artists have to appear in society from time to time to remind the public that we are not savages. Dressed in formal attire and with a white tie, as you once told me, anyone, even a stockbroker, can earn a reputation for being civilized. Well, when I had been in the room for about ten minutes, chatting with imposing widows overly adorned with jewelry and tedious academics, I suddenly noticed that someone was looking at me. When I turned around, I saw Dorian Gray for the first time. When our eyes met, I felt myself turn pale. A strange sensation of terror took hold of me. I knew that I had before me someone with such a fascinating personality that, if I allowed it, he would absorb my entire existence, my whole soul, even my art. I did not want any external influence in my life. You know perfectly well how independent I am by nature. I have always done what I wanted; at least, until I met Dorian Gray. Then... although I don't know how to explain it to you. Something seemed to tell me that I was on the verge of a terrible crisis. I had the strange feeling that Fate had exquisite joys and terrible sufferings in store for me. I got scared and turned around to leave the room. It wasn't conscience that drove me to do it: rather something akin to cowardice. I don't attribute any merit to myself for having tried to escape.

en: “Conscience and cowardice are really the same things, Basil. Conscience is the trade-name of the firm. That is all.”
vi: “Conscience and cowardice are really the same thing, Basil. Conscience is the trade name of the firm. That is all.”
tr: “Conscience and cowardice are really the same thing, Basil. Conscience is just the trade name of the firm, that's all.”
es: —Conscience and cowardice are really the same thing, Basil. Conscience is the trade name of the firm. That is all.

en: “I don’t believe that, Harry, and I don’t believe you do either. However, whatever was my motive—and it may have been pride, for I used to be very proud—I certainly struggled to the door. There, of course, I stumbled against Lady Brandon. ‘You are not going to run away so soon, Mr. Hallward?’ she screamed out. You know her curiously shrill voice?”
vi: “I don't believe that, Harry, and I don't believe you would either. However, regardless of my motive — and it could be pride, as I am often very proud — I still resolutely made my way to the door. There, of course, I encountered Mrs. Brandon again. ‘Don't leave so early, Mr. Hallward?’ she exclaimed. Surely you know her strange, shrill voice?”
tr: “I don't believe this, Harry; I don't believe you think this way either. Anyway, whatever it was that made me act this way... maybe it was pride, I used to be very proud once... The truth is, I made my way through the crowd towards the door. But there, I naturally collided with Lady Brandon. Lady Brandon exclaimed, ‘Mr. Hallward, are you running away so early?’ You know how oddly high-pitched her voice is!”
es: —I don't believe it, Harry, and it seems to me that you don't believe it either. Whatever my motive was, and perhaps it was pride, because I have always been very proud, I managed to barely make it to the door. But there, of course, I ran into Lady Brandon. «You're not leaving so soon, Mr. Hallward?», she shouted at me. Do you remember the peculiarly shrill voice she has?

en: “Yes; she is a peacock in everything but beauty,” said Lord Henry, pulling the daisy to bits with his long nervous fingers.
vi: "Yes; she is a peacock in everything but beauty," said Lord Henry, tearing a daisy into pieces with his long, restless fingers.
tr: Lord Henry, plucking the daisy with his long, sensitive fingers, said, "Yes, he is a peacock in everything but beauty."
es: —Yes; he is a peacock in everything except beauty —said Lord Henry, undoing the daisy with his long, nervous fingers.

en: “I could not get rid of her. She brought me up to royalties, and people with stars and garters, and elderly ladies with gigantic tiaras and parrot noses. She spoke of me as her dearest friend. I had only met her once before, but she took it into her head to lionize me. I believe some picture of mine had made a great success at the time, at least had been chattered about in the penny newspapers, which is the nineteenth-century standard of immortality. Suddenly I found myself face to face with the young man whose personality had so strangely stirred me. We were quite close, almost touching. Our eyes met again. It was reckless of me, but I asked Lady Brandon to introduce me to him. Perhaps it was not so reckless, after all. It was simply inevitable. We would have spoken to each other without any introduction. I am sure of that. Dorian told me so afterwards. He, too, felt that we were destined to know each other.”
vi: "I couldn't escape her. She took me to meet the princes and those wearing stars and Garter badges, then the elderly ladies with enormous tiaras and parrot-like noses. She spoke about me as if I were her closest friend. I had only met her once before, but she internalized that encounter to treat me like a celebrity. I believe there was some painting of mine that once achieved great success, at least it was mentioned in the penny papers which were the nineteenth-century standard of immortality. Suddenly I found myself face to face with the young man whose personality had strangely intrigued me so. We were very close, almost touching. Our eyes met again. It was due to my recklessness, but I asked Mrs. Brandon to introduce me to him. Perhaps it wasn't too reckless after all, in the end. It was simply unavoidable. We could have talked to each other without any introduction at all. I'm certain of that. Dorian later told me so. He also felt that it was our fate to meet."
tr: “I couldn't escape from her. She introduced me to people of royal lineage, to those with titles and decorations, to hook-nosed individuals with enormous crowns, and to elderly ladies. She would refer to me as her very dear friend. Although we had only met once before, she was determined to take me under her wing. I suppose one of my paintings had gained some fame at that time, or rather, it had been written about in the colorful boulevard newspapers, which is the measure of immortality in the nineteenth century. I came face to face with the young man who had stirred such strange emotions within me. Our eyes met. It was a reckless move, I know, but I asked Lady Brandon to introduce us. Perhaps it wasn't recklessness, who knows. Maybe it was inevitable. Even if we hadn't been introduced, we would have spoken to each other. I'm sure of it. Later, Dorian said the same thing. He also felt that it was written in our fate to know each other.”
es: —I couldn't get rid of her. She introduced me to royal highnesses, military officers and aristocrats, and elderly ladies with gigantic tiaras and parrot noses. She spoke of me as her dearest friend. I had only been with her once, but she got it into her head to make me the celebrity of the evening. I believe that around that time one of my paintings had great success or at least was talked about in the sensationalist newspapers, which are the measure of immorality in the 19th century. Suddenly, I found myself face to face with the young man whose personality had affected me so strangely. We were very close, almost touching. Our gazes crossed again. It was reckless of me, but I asked Lady Brandon to introduce us. Perhaps it wasn't recklessness, but something simply inevitable. We would have spoken to each other without the need for an introduction. I'm sure of it. Dorian confirmed it to me later. He also felt that we were destined to meet.

en: “And how did Lady Brandon describe this wonderful young man?” asked his companion. “I know she goes in for giving a rapid précis of all her guests. I remember her bringing me up to a truculent and red-faced old gentleman covered all over with orders and ribbons, and hissing into my ear, in a tragic whisper which must have been perfectly audible to everybody in the room, the most astounding details. I simply fled. I like to find out people for myself. But Lady Brandon treats her guests exactly as an auctioneer treats his goods. She either explains them entirely away, or tells one everything about them except what one wants to know.”
vi: “And how did Mrs. Brandon describe this wonderful young man?” his friend asked. “I know she usually gives a quick summary to all her guests. I remember she once introduced me to an aggressive elderly gentleman with a flushed face covered in medals and ribbons, and she whispered in my ear, in a tragically audible voice to everyone in the room, the most astonishing details. I made a quick escape. I prefer to learn about people on my own. But Mrs. Brandon treats her guests no differently than an auctioneer treats his items. She either explains everything about them or tells people everything except what they actually want to know.”
tr: Lord Henry asked, "Well, how did Lady Brandon describe this wonderful young man?" "I know she is excellent at giving quick summaries of all her guests. I remember once she took me to a red-faced, grumpy old man covered in medals and ribbons; then she leaned over and began to whisper tragic details into my ear, which I'm sure everyone there could clearly hear. Lady Brandon treats her guests the way auctioneers view the items they sell. She either dismisses them with a single remark or reveals everything about them, except what one actually wants to know."
es: —And how did Lady Brandon describe that wonderful young man? —asked his friend—. I know she likes to give a quick summary of all her guests. I remember she introduced me to an elderly gentleman with a red face, covered with all imaginable decorations, and confided in my ear, in a tragic whisper that everyone present must have perfectly heard, the most astonishing details. I simply fled. I prefer to unmask people myself. But Lady Brandon treats her guests exactly like an auctioneer treats his goods. She either explains them completely backwards or tells everything except what one wants to know.

en: “Poor Lady Brandon! You are hard on her, Harry!” said Hallward listlessly.
vi: "Poor Mrs. Brandon! You were too harsh on her, Harry!" Hallward said, absent-mindedly.
tr: The painter spoke with a bit of boredom, "Poor Lady Brandon! You are not showing her any mercy, Harry!"
es: —Poor Lady Brandon! You are very hard on her, Harry! —said Hallward languidly.

en: “My dear fellow, she tried to found a salon, and only succeeded in opening a restaurant. How could I admire her? But tell me, what did she say about Mr. Dorian Gray?”
vi: “My friend, she tried to establish a salon, but only succeeded in opening a restaurant. How can I admire her? But tell me, what did she say about Mr. Dorian Gray?”
tr: “My dear friend, this woman attempted to establish a salon but only managed to set up a restaurant. How can I admire her? But you tell me, what did she say about Mr. Dorian Gray?”
es: —My dear friend, that good lady was trying to establish a salon, but she has only managed to open a restaurant. How do you expect me to admire her? But, tell me, what did she tell you about Mr. Dorian Gray?

en: “Oh, something like, ‘Charming boy—poor dear mother and I absolutely inseparable. Quite forget what he does—afraid he—doesn’t do anything—oh, yes, plays the piano—or is it the violin, dear Mr. Gray?’ Neither of us could help laughing, and we became friends at once.”
vi: 1 Salon: a meeting place for artists. “Oh, some things like, ‘a handsome young man — his poor mother and I can never be apart for a moment. Completely forget what he does — afraid that he — does nothing at all — oh, yes, plays the piano — or is it the violin, Mr. Gray?’ Both of us couldn't help but laugh, and we became friends immediately.”
tr: “He mumbled something like: a lovely child... We were inseparable with his poor mother. I can't remember what Dorian was doing... I'm afraid he's doing nothing... Ah, yes, he plays the piano, doesn't he... Or was it the violin, dear Mr. Gray?.. We both couldn't help but laugh, and we immediately hit it off.”
es: —Something like "charming young man, his poor mother and I absolutely inseparable. I've completely forgotten what he does, I'm afraid that..., he does nothing... Yes, yes, he plays the piano, or is it the violin, my dear Mr. Gray?" Neither of us could avoid laughing, and we became friends instantly.

en: “Laughter is not at all a bad beginning for a friendship, and it is far the best ending for one,” said the young lord, plucking another daisy.
vi: “Laughing is certainly not a bad beginning for a friendship, and it is far better as an ending for it,” the young gentleman said as he plucked another daisy.
tr: The Young Lord plucked another daisy and said, "Laughter is not a bad start for friendship; it is the best way to end it."
es: —Laughter is not a bad beginning for a friendship, and certainly it is the best way to end it —said the young lord, plucking another daisy.

en: Hallward shook his head. “You don’t understand what friendship is, Harry,” he murmured—“or what enmity is, for that matter. You like every one; that is to say, you are indifferent to every one.”
vi: Hallward shook his head. "You don't understand what friendship is, Harry," he muttered, "nor what enmity is, either." You like everyone; that means you are indifferent to everyone."
tr: Hallward shook his head, "Harry, you don't understand what friendship means," he said. "Nor do you know the meaning of enmity. You love everyone, which means you are indifferent to everyone."
es: Hallward shook his head. —You don't understand what friendship is, Harry —he murmured—; nor enmity, for that matter. You like everyone; that is to say, everyone leaves you indifferent.

en: “How horribly unjust of you!” cried Lord Henry, tilting his hat back and looking up at the little clouds that, like ravelled skeins of glossy white silk, were drifting across the hollowed turquoise of the summer sky. “Yes; horribly unjust of you. I make a great difference between people. I choose my friends for their good looks, my acquaintances for their good characters, and my enemies for their good intellects. A man cannot be too careful in the choice of his enemies. I have not got one who is a fool. They are all men of some intellectual power, and consequently they all appreciate me. Is that very vain of me? I think it is rather vain.”
vi: “You are terribly unfair!” Lord Henry shouted, flipping his hat back and looking up at the small clouds, like tangled, shiny white silk threads, drifting across the deep turquoise of the summer sky. “Yes; you are terribly unfair. I understand very well the great difference between people. I choose friends because they are beautiful, acquaintances because they are good, and enemies because they are talented. No matter how skilled one is, it is never excessive in the selection of enemies. I have not chosen a single fool as an enemy. They are all people with considerable intellectual abilities, and therefore they all appreciate me. Is that too conceited of me? I think it is quite conceited indeed.”
tr: Lord Henry, "What a terrible injustice you do to me!" he said, pushing his hat back; he looked at the clouds flying like unraveled bright silk skeins over the turquoise dome of the summer sky. "Yes, you do me a terrible injustice. In fact, I do distinguish between people. I choose my friends for their beauty, my acquaintances for the solidity of their character, and my enemies for their sharp intellect. One cannot be too careful in choosing one's enemies. I do not have a single foolish enemy. All my enemies have strong mental faculties, and therefore they appreciate my worth. Do you find me very arrogant? Yes, I am quite arrogant."
es: —How horribly unfair you are to me! —exclaimed Lord Henry, tipping his hat back to look at the little clouds that, like tangled skeins of bright white silk, wandered through the turquoise hollow of the summer sky—. Yes; horribly unfair. Of course I distinguish between people. I choose my friends for their good looks, my acquaintances for their good reputation, and my enemies for their intelligence. One cannot be too careful in choosing one's enemies. I don't have a single stupid one. They are all people of some intellectual stature and, consequently, they appreciate me. Do you think that's too much vanity on my part? I think it is.

en: “I should think it was, Harry. But according to your category I must be merely an acquaintance.”
vi: “I think so too, Harry. But according to your ranking, I'm probably just an acquaintance.”
tr: “I think so too, Harry. But according to your classification, I am merely an acquaintance in your eyes.”
es: —I agree with you on that. But according to your categories, I must be nothing more than an acquaintance.

en: “My dear old Basil, you are much more than an acquaintance.”
vi: “My dear old friend Basil, you are far superior to mere acquaintances.”
tr: “My very dear friend Basil, you are much more than an acquaintance.”
es: —My dear Basil: you are much more than an acquaintance.

en: “And much less than a friend. A sort of brother, I suppose?”
vi: "And definitely lost to you. A kind of brother, I suppose?"
tr: “But far from being just a friend. Am I a kind of sibling, I wonder?”
es: —And much less than a friend. Something like a brother, isn't that right?

en: “Oh, brothers! I don’t care for brothers. My elder brother won’t die, and my younger brothers seem never to do anything else.”
vi: “Oh, my brothers! I don't care about my brothers. My brother will not die, and my younger brothers seem to never do anything else at all.”
tr: “Oh, don't call me brother! I don't like that word at all. My older brother doesn't seem to know how to die; and my younger siblings don't seem to know anything but dying.”
es: —Ah, siblings! I don't like siblings. My older brother never dies, and the younger ones never do anything else.

en: “Harry!” exclaimed Hallward, frowning.
vi: “Harry!” Hallward shouted, frowning.
tr: Basil Hallward frowned and said, "Harry!"
es: —Harry! —exclaimed Hallward, frowning.

en: “My dear fellow, I am not quite serious. But I can’t help detesting my relations. I suppose it comes from the fact that none of us can stand other people having the same faults as ourselves. I quite sympathize with the rage of the English democracy against what they call the vices of the upper orders. The masses feel that drunkenness, stupidity, and immorality should be their own special property, and that if any one of us makes an ass of himself, he is poaching on their preserves. When poor Southwark got into the divorce court, their indignation was quite magnificent. And yet I don’t suppose that ten per cent of the proletariat live correctly.”
vi: "My friend, I am not very serious. But I cannot help but hate my relationships. I suppose it is because none of us can tolerate others having the same faults as we do. I fully sympathize with the wrath of British democracy against what they call the vices of the upper class. The masses feel that alcoholism, stupidity, and depravity should be their own characteristics, and that if any of us make a fool of ourselves, we have encroached on their territory. When poor Southwark went to court to divorce his wife, their indignation was truly remarkable. However, I do not think that even ten percent of the lower class live properly."
tr: “My friend, I'm joking. Still, I can't help but hate my relatives. It's probably because none of us can stand seeing our own flaws in others. I understand very well the British democracy's grudge against what they call the bad traits of the upper classes. The masses want drunkenness, stupidity, and immorality to be exclusive to them! When one of us disgraces themselves, it's as if their private property has been violated: The public's outrage was truly remarkable when poor little Southwark found himself in the divorce court. Yet, I don't think even one-tenth of the proletariat lives a flawless life.”
es: —I'm not entirely serious. But it is impossible for me not to detest my family. I imagine it is because no one can stand people who have the same flaws as they do. I perfectly understand the indignation of English democracy at what it calls the vices of the upper classes. The masses believe that drunkenness, stupidity, and immorality should be their exclusive domain, and when one of us makes a fool of ourselves, they see us as poachers on their land. When poor Southwark had to appear in the Divorce Court, the indignation of the masses was truly magnificent. And yet, I don't think ten percent of the proletariat lives correctly.

en: “I don’t agree with a single word that you have said, and, what is more, Harry, I feel sure you don’t either.”
vi: “I do not agree with even a single word you say, and, moreover, Harry, I feel certain that you don't either.”
tr: “Harry, I don't believe a single word you're saying. Moreover, I'm sure you don't believe it either.”
es: —I don't agree with a single word of what you have said and, what's more, I'm sure you feel the same way.

en: Lord Henry stroked his pointed brown beard and tapped the toe of his patent-leather boot with a tasselled ebony cane. “How English you are Basil! That is the second time you have made that observation. If one puts forward an idea to a true Englishman—always a rash thing to do—he never dreams of considering whether the idea is right or wrong. The only thing he considers of any importance is whether one believes it oneself. Now, the value of an idea has nothing whatsoever to do with the sincerity of the man who expresses it. Indeed, the probabilities are that the more insincere the man is, the more purely intellectual will the idea be, as in that case it will not be coloured by either his wants, his desires, or his prejudices. However, I don’t propose to discuss politics, sociology, or metaphysics with you. I like persons better than principles, and I like persons with no principles better than anything else in the world. Tell me more about Mr. Dorian Gray. How often do you see him?”
vi: Lord Henry stroked his sharp brown beard, tapping the glossy black cane with a tassel on the tip of his polished leather boot. “You really are an Englishman, Basil! This is the second time you've made that remark. If someone proposes an idea to a true Englishman — always a risky endeavor — he never dreams of considering whether the idea is right or wrong. The only thing of any significance that he considers is whether the other person believes in it or not. For the value of an idea has nothing to do with the sincerity of the person expressing it. Indeed, it is very likely that the less sincere a person is, the more purely intellectual the idea will be, as in that case it will not be colored by his own needs, desires, or prejudices. However, I do not intend to discuss politics, sociology, or metaphysics with you. I prefer people to principles, and I prefer those without principles to anything else in the world. Tell me more about Mr. Dorian Gray. Do you see him often?”
tr: Lord Henry was stroking his sharp, chestnut-colored beard and kept tapping his patent leather shoes with his tasseled ebony cane. “How typically English you are, Basil! You are stating the same opinion for the second time. When a person presents an idea to a true Englishman... Which is already a dangerous task... He never even considers whether the idea is right or wrong. The only thing he deems important is whether he himself believes in it. Now, there is no connection between the value of an idea and the sincerity of the person presenting it. To be honest, most likely, the less sincere a person is, the purer the intellectual value of the idea will be, because it will not be tainted by that person's needs, desires, and prejudices. However, I have no intention of discussing politics, sociology, or metaphysics with you. I love people more than principles. Tell me a bit more about this Mr. Dorian Gray. Do you see him often?”
es: Lord Henry stroked his sharp brown beard and tapped the tip of a patent leather boot with his mahogany cane. —How English you are, Basil! It's the second time today that you've made that observation. If an idea is presented to a genuine Englishman (which is always imprudent), it never occurs to him, even remotely, to stop and think whether the idea is true or false. The only thing he considers important is whether the person believes what they are saying. Now, the value of an idea has nothing to do with the sincerity of the person expressing it. In fact, it is likely that the more insincere the person, the more purely intellectual the idea, since in that case it will not be colored by their needs, desires, or prejudices. However, I do not intend to discuss politics, sociology, or metaphysics with you. I like people more than principles, and I like people without principles more than anything in the world. Tell me more about Dorian Gray. Do you see him often?

en: “Every day. I couldn’t be happy if I didn’t see him every day. He is absolutely necessary to me.”
vi: “We meet every day. I can't be happy without seeing him every day. I really need him.”
tr: “Every day. If I don't see him every day, I can't be happy! I can't do without him anymore.”
es: —Every day. I wouldn't be happy if I didn't see him every day. It's absolutely necessary for me.

en: “How extraordinary! I thought you would never care for anything but your art.”
vi: "Strange! I thought you didn't pay attention to anything except your art."
tr: “An unusual thing, indeed! I thought you didn't care about anything other than art.”
es: —Extraordinary! I thought you were only interested in art.

en: “He is all my art to me now,” said the painter gravely. “I sometimes think, Harry, that there are only two eras of any importance in the world’s history. The first is the appearance of a new medium for art, and the second is the appearance of a new personality for art also. What the invention of oil-painting was to the Venetians, the face of Antinous was to late Greek sculpture, and the face of Dorian Gray will some day be to me. It is not merely that I paint from him, draw from him, sketch from him. Of course, I have done all that. But he is much more to me than a model or a sitter. I won’t tell you that I am dissatisfied with what I have done of him, or that his beauty is such that art cannot express it. There is nothing that art cannot express, and I know that the work I have done, since I met Dorian Gray, is good work, is the best work of my life. But in some curious way—I wonder will you understand me?—his personality has suggested to me an entirely new manner in art, an entirely new mode of style. I see things differently, I think of them differently. I can now recreate life in a way that was hidden from me before. ‘A dream of form in days of thought’—who is it who says that? I forget; but it is what Dorian Gray has been to me. The merely visible presence of this lad—for he seems to me little more than a lad, though he is really over twenty—his merely visible presence—ah! I wonder can you realize all that that means? Unconsciously he defines for me the lines of a fresh school, a school that is to have in it all the passion of the romantic spirit, all the perfection of the spirit that is Greek. The harmony of soul and body—how much that is! We in our madness have separated the two, and have invented a realism that is vulgar, an ideality that is void. Harry! if you only knew what Dorian Gray is to me! You remember that landscape of mine, for which Agnew offered me such a huge price but which I would not part with? It is one of the best things I have ever done. And why is it so? Because, while I was painting it, Dorian Gray sat beside me. Some subtle influence passed from him to me, and for the first time in my life I saw in the plain woodland the wonder I had always looked for and always missed.”
vi: “He is all my art to me now,” the artist said, very seriously. “Sometimes I think, Harry, that there are only two periods that have any significance in the history of the world. The first is the appearance of a new medium for art, and the second is the appearance of a new personality also for art. The things that the invention of oil painting brought to the Venetians, the face of Antinoüs brought to later Greek sculpture, and the face of Dorian Gray will bring to me one day. It’s not simply that I paint from him, draw from him, sketch from him. Of course, I have done all that. But he means more to me than just a model or a sitter. I won’t tell you that I am not satisfied with what I have done about him, or that his beauty is so marvelous that Art cannot express it. There is nothing that Art cannot express, and I know that the work I have done since I met Dorian Gray is good work, the best work of my life. But in some strange way — I wonder if you understand me? — his personality has stirred in me a completely new manner of art, a completely new mode of style. I see things differently, I think of them differently. Now I can recreate life in a way that was hidden from me before. ‘A dream of form in days of thought,’ — who said that? I forget; but that is what Dorian Gray has brought to me. Just his mere presence — for to me he seems little more than a boy, though he is really over twenty — just his mere presence — oh! I wonder if you can realize all that that means? Unconsciously, he defines for me the limits of a fresh school, a school that has in it all the passion of the romantic spirit, all the perfection of the spirit that belongs to Greece. The harmony of soul and body — how much that is! In our madness, we have separated the two, and have invented a realism that is vulgar, an ideality that is void. Harry! If you only knew what Dorian Gray means to me! Do you remember that landscape of mine, for which Agnew offered me such a large price, but which I could not part with? It is one of the best things I have ever done. Why is that? Because while I was painting it, Dorian Gray sat beside me. Some subtle influence passed from him to me, and for the first time in my life, I saw in the plain woodland the wonder I had always looked for, and always missed.”
tr: The painter replied seriously, "For me, my art means everything now." "Harry, sometimes I think there are only two periods in world history that can be considered important, in my opinion. The first is the emergence of a new art environment, and the second is the appearance of a new personality for art. The invention of oil painting was to the Venetian painters what the face of Antinous was to the late Greek sculptors, and one day, Dorian Gray's face will hold that importance for me. I'm not just drawing and painting because of him. Of course, I am doing those things. Yet, in my eyes, he means much more than just a model. I'm not going to tell you that I'm not satisfied with the paintings I made inspired by him, or that art cannot capture his beauty. There is nothing that art cannot express; I know that the works I've done since I met Dorian Gray are good products, the best I've ever produced. Still, how strange... I wonder if you'll understand me?.. Thanks to his personality, I feel as if there's a completely new style in art. A completely new style. I see everything differently, I perceive everything differently now. Nowadays, I can create life in a completely new form that I didn't know or see before. 'A form dreamt of in the days of thought.' Who said that? I can't remember, but that's what Dorian Gray is to me. The mere visible presence of this boy... Actually, he's over twenty, but I always see him as a child... Yes, even his mere visible presence... Oh, I don't know if you can grasp the full meaning of all this? Without even knowing it, this boy seems to define the lines of a completely new art school: a school that will combine all the fire of the romantic school with all the perfection of the ancient Greek school. The harmony of body and soul... How important this is! We, in our stupidity, have separated them, invented a crude realism, an empty idealism. Oh, Harry, if only you could understand what Dorian Gray symbolizes to me! You know that landscape of mine, Agnew offered a fortune for it, but I didn't let it go. It's one of my best works. And why, do you think? Because while I was painting it, Dorian Gray was sitting beside me. There must have been an intangible influence from him to me, because for the first time in my life, I found the magic I had always sought but never caught in the ordinary forest in front of me."
es: —Dorian is all my art —said the painter gravely—. Sometimes I think, Harry, that the history of the world has only known two important eras. The first is the one that sees the emergence of a new artistic technique. The second, the one that witnesses the emergence of a new personality, also for art. What the invention of oil painting was for the Venetians, or the face of Antinous for the last Greek sculptors, the face of Dorian Gray will be for me someday. It's not just that I use him as a model to paint, to draw, to make sketches. I've done all that, of course. But for me, he is much more than a model or a subject. I'm not going to tell you that I'm dissatisfied with what I've achieved, nor that his beauty is such that art cannot express it. There is nothing that art cannot express, and I know that what I've done since I met Dorian Gray is good, it's the best I've ever done. But, in some curious way (I don't know if you'll understand me), his personality has suggested to me a completely new way, a new style. I see things differently, I think of them differently. Now I am able to recreate life in a way I didn't know before. «A dream of beauty in days of meditation». Who said that? I don't remember; but that has been Dorian Gray for me. The mere presence of that boy, because he seems little more than a teenager to me, although he is over twenty, his mere presence... Ah! I wonder if you can realize what it means.
