Unconsciously, he defines for me the outlines of a new school, a school that has all the passion of the romantic spirit and all the perfection of the Greek. The harmony of soul and body, what a marvel! In our madness, we have separated the two things, and we have invented a realism that is vulgar, and a hollow idealism. Harry! If you knew what Dorian is to me! Do you remember that landscape of mine, for which Agnew offered me so much money, but which I didn't want to part with? It is one of the best things I've ever done. And, why? Because while I was painting it, Dorian Gray was by my side. He transmitted some subtle influence to me and for the first time in my life I saw in a simple forest the wonder I had always sought and that had always eluded me.

en: “Basil, this is extraordinary! I must see Dorian Gray.”
vi: “Basil, this is so strange! I must meet Dorian Gray.”
tr: "Basil, this is unheard of! I absolutely must see Dorian Gray."
es: —What you're telling me is extraordinary! I must see Dorian Gray.

en: Hallward got up from the seat and walked up and down the garden. After some time he came back. “Harry,” he said, “Dorian Gray is to me simply a motive in art. You might see nothing in him. I see everything in him. He is never more present in my work than when no image of him is there. He is a suggestion, as I have said, of a new manner. I find him in the curves of certain lines, in the loveliness and subtleties of certain colours. That is all.”
vi: Hallward got up from his seat and paced back and forth in the garden. A moment later, he returned. “Harry,” he said, “Dorian Gray is just an artistic motif to me. You will never see anything in him. I see everything in him. He is never more present in my work than when his image is not there. He is a suggestion, as I have said, of a new style. I see him in the curves of certain lines, in the grace and subtlety of certain colors. That's all.”
tr: Hallward stood up and began pacing back and forth in the garden. A little later, he came back again. “Harry,” he said. “Dorian Gray is merely a motive that drives me to creativity. I find everything in him. You may find nothing. The times when he is most present in my works are also the times when his image is not seen. As I said, he is the intuition of a completely new style. I find him in the curve of some lines, in the beauty of certain colors, in their indescribable delicacy. That's all.”
es: Hallward got up from his seat and began to walk around the garden. After a few moments, he returned. —Harry —he said—, Dorian Gray is nothing more to me than an artistic inspiration. Perhaps you see nothing in him. I see everything. He is never more present in my work than when he does not appear in what I paint. He is the suggestion, as I have said, of a new manner. I find him in the curves of certain lines, in the charm and subtlety of certain colors. That is all.

en: “Then why won’t you exhibit his portrait?” asked Lord Henry.
vi: “Then why don't you display his portrait?” Lord Henry asked.
tr: Lord Henry asked, "Then why don't you exhibit his portrait?"
es: —Then, why do you refuse to exhibit his portrait? —asked Lord Henry.

en: “Because, without intending it, I have put into it some expression of all this curious artistic idolatry, of which, of course, I have never cared to speak to him. He knows nothing about it. He shall never know anything about it. But the world might guess it, and I will not bare my soul to their shallow prying eyes. My heart shall never be put under their microscope. There is too much of myself in the thing, Harry—too much of myself!”
vi: “Because, although unintentionally, I have imbued it with some expression of this strange idolatry in art, an idolatry that, of course, I never wanted to discuss with him. He knows nothing about it. He will never know anything about it. But the world might guess it; and I will not expose my soul to their shallow, prying eyes. My heart will never be placed under their microscope. There is too much of myself in that thing, Harry — too much of myself!”
tr: “It is because I have unconsciously reflected in that portrait the strange artistic idolatry I have heard of. I never spoke to him about these feelings, naturally. Dorian Gray has no idea about it. Nor will he ever. However, others might sense it; and I have no intention of exposing my soul to their shallow, curious eyes. I will never lay my heart under their microscopes. There is too much of myself in the portrait, Harry, far too much!”
es: —Because, without intending to, I have put in that painting the expression of my strange idolatry as an artist, which, of course, I have never wanted to talk to him about. He knows nothing. He will never know. But perhaps the world will guess it; and I do not want to bare my soul before its intrusive and superficial gaze. I will never place my heart under its microscope. There is too much of myself in that painting, Harry, too much of myself!

en: “Poets are not so scrupulous as you are. They know how useful passion is for publication. Nowadays a broken heart will run to many editions.”
vi: “Poets do not deliberate as much as you do. They know how useful passion is for publishing. These days, a broken heart will make it into many prints.”
tr: “Poets do not split hairs as much as you do. They know that passion is something useful to publish. Nowadays, a burning heart can make countless impressions.”
es: —Poets are not as scrupulous as you. They know how useful passion is when they think about publishing. In our days, a broken heart can lead to many editions.

en: “I hate them for it,” cried Hallward. “An artist should create beautiful things, but should put nothing of his own life into them. We live in an age when men treat art as if it were meant to be a form of autobiography. We have lost the abstract sense of beauty. Some day I will show the world what it is; and for that reason the world shall never see my portrait of Dorian Gray.”
vi: “I hate them for that,” Hallward exclaimed. “An artist should create beautiful things, but should not put anything of his own life into them. We live in an age where people treat art as if it were some kind of autobiography. We have lost the ability to abstractly appreciate beauty. One day I will show the world what it is; and for that reason, the world will never see my portrait of Dorian Gray.”
tr: The painter shouted, "I despise them for this very reason!" "An artist should create beautiful things, but should not put anything of his own life into them. We live in an age where everyone looks at art as a kind of autobiography. We have lost the sense of abstract beauty. One day I will show the world what it is; that is why the world will never see my portrait of Dorian Gray."
es: —I detest them for that —exclaimed Hallward—. An artist should create beautiful things, but without putting anything of their own existence into them. We live in an age where art is treated as if it were a form of autobiography. We have lost the abstract sense of beauty. Someday I will show the world what that is; and that is the reason why the world must never see my portrait of Dorian Gray.

en: “I think you are wrong, Basil, but I won’t argue with you. It is only the intellectually lost who ever argue. Tell me, is Dorian Gray very fond of you?”
vi: “I think you are wrong, Basil, but I will not argue with you. Only fools argue. Tell me, does Dorian Gray like you very much?”
tr: “I think your attitude is wrong, Basil, but I'm not going to argue with you. If you ask me, those who go astray intellectually argue incessantly. Tell me, is Dorian Gray very attached to you?”
es: —I think you are mistaken, but I am not going to argue with you. Only those who are intellectually lost argue. Tell me, does Dorian Gray care about you a lot?

en: The painter considered for a few moments. “He likes me,” he answered after a pause; “I know he likes me. Of course I flatter him dreadfully. I find a strange pleasure in saying things to him that I know I shall be sorry for having said. As a rule, he is charming to me, and we sit in the studio and talk of a thousand things. Now and then, however, he is horribly thoughtless, and seems to take a real delight in giving me pain. Then I feel, Harry, that I have given away my whole soul to some one who treats it as if it were a flower to put in his coat, a bit of decoration to charm his vanity, an ornament for a summer’s day.”
vi: The artist pondered for a few seconds. "He likes me," he replied, after a slight hesitation; "I know he likes me. Of course, I flatter him excessively. I find a strange pleasure in telling him things that I know I will regret saying. As usual, he is very charming to me, we sit in the studio and talk about all sorts of things. However, sometimes he is terribly reckless, and seems to find real joy in hurting me. At those times, I feel, Harry, that I would give my soul to someone who knows how to treat it as if it were a flower to pin on his cloak, a small ornament to beautify his vanity, a decoration for a summer's day."
tr: The painter thought for a while. After a pause, he replied, "She likes me." "I know, she likes me. Of course, I also flatter her immensely. I take a strange pleasure in telling her a lot of things that I know I will definitely regret later. She generally behaves very sweetly and charmingly towards me. We sit in the studio and talk about a thousand different topics. However, sometimes she acts incredibly thoughtlessly, as if she takes real pleasure in causing me pain. Harry, at those times, it feels to me as if I have given my entire soul to someone who treats it like a flower to be pinned to their lapel; she treats my soul like an ornament to flatter her vanity, an ornament to be used and discarded on a summer day."
es: The painter reflected for a few moments. —He is fond of me —he replied, after a pause—; I know he is fond of me. It is true, on the other hand, that I flatter him terribly. I find a strange pleasure in telling him things that I know I will regret later. Generally, he is charming with me, and we sit in the study and talk about a thousand things. From time to time, however, he is terribly inconsiderate, and he seems to enjoy making me suffer. Then I feel that I have given my whole soul to someone who treats it as if it were a flower to put in his buttonhole, a decoration that delights his vanity, an ornament for a summer's day.

en: “Days in summer, Basil, are apt to linger,” murmured Lord Henry. “Perhaps you will tire sooner than he will. It is a sad thing to think of, but there is no doubt that genius lasts longer than beauty. That accounts for the fact that we all take such pains to over-educate ourselves. In the wild struggle for existence, we want to have something that endures, and so we fill our minds with rubbish and facts, in the silly hope of keeping our place. The thoroughly well-informed man—that is the modern ideal. And the mind of the thoroughly well-informed man is a dreadful thing. It is like a bric-à-brac shop, all monsters and dust, with everything priced above its proper value. I think you will tire first, all the same. Some day you will look at your friend, and he will seem to you to be a little out of drawing, or you won’t like his tone of colour, or something. You will bitterly reproach him in your own heart, and seriously think that he has behaved very badly to you. The next time he calls, you will be perfectly cold and indifferent. It will be a great pity, for it will alter you. What you have told me is quite a romance, a romance of art one might call it, and the worst of having a romance of any kind is that it leaves one so unromantic.”
vi: “Summer days, Basil, tend to linger,” Lord Henry murmured. “You might grow bored with him sooner than he with you. It is sad to think about, but Talent undoubtedly lasts longer than Beauty. That explains why we all put so much effort into refining ourselves over and over. In the mad struggle for survival, we want something enduring, so we fill our memories with rubbish and facts, with the naive hope of maintaining our place. The know-it-all — that is the ideal of our time. And the intellect of the know-it-all is a terrible thing. It is like a curiosity shop, full of monsters and dust, with everything priced higher than its true worth. I think you will grow bored first, no matter what. One day you will look at your friend, and you will see that he seems slightly misdrawn, or you will dislike his tone, or something. You will bitterly resent him in your heart, and seriously think that he has treated you very badly. The next time he visits, you will be cold and indifferent as if nothing happened. That will be a great pity, for it will change you. What you have told me is indeed a romantic story, a romantic story about art as one might call it, and the worst thing about having any kind of romantic story is that it makes one become exceedingly ordinary.”
tr: Lord Henry murmured, “Summer days are long, Basil.”“Perhaps you will tire of it before it does. A sad thought, yes, but genius undoubtedly lasts longer than beauty. That is why we all go to such lengths to educate ourselves excessively. In this mad, fierce struggle for life, we all want to possess something durable, so we fill our heads with trivia, with facts, to maintain our place in the struggle. The man with complete knowledge: This is the contemporary ideal. Yet the mind of a man with complete knowledge is a terrifying thing. Like a shop selling second-hand crockery, full of dust and misshapen objects, monsters. Everything is priced above its real value. Yes, it seems to me that you will be the first to grow weary. One day you will look at your friend, and his features will seem somewhat out of proportion to you, or you will not like the tone of his color, or something like that. Inwardly, you will bitterly reproach him, thinking he has treated you very badly. When he comes to your door again, you will behave entirely coldly and indifferently towards him. It will be a great pity, really, because it will change you. The story you told me is a thoroughly romantic one, a romance of art, we might say. The worst part of living such a romantic story is that when it ends, it completely alienates a person from romanticism.”
es: —In summer, the days are usually long, Basil —murmured Lord Henry—. Perhaps you will tire before he does. It's sad to think about, but undoubtedly genius lasts longer than beauty. That explains why we strive so hard to cultivate ourselves. In the fierce struggle for existence, we want to have something that lasts, and we fill our heads with trash and data, with the foolish hope of maintaining our position. The person who knows everything: that is the modern ideal. And the mind of that person who knows everything is a terrible thing, a junk shop, all monsters and dust, and always with prices above their true value. I think you will tire first, anyway. Someday you will look at your friend, and he will seem a bit blurred, or you won't like the tone of his complexion, or something else. You will reproach him bitterly, and you will think, very seriously, that he has treated you badly. The next time he visits you, you will show yourself perfectly cold and indifferent. It will be a shame, because it will change you. What you have told me is a love story, it should be called an aesthetic love story, and the worst thing about any love story is that afterward one feels very little romantic.

en: “Harry, don’t talk like that. As long as I live, the personality of Dorian Gray will dominate me. You can’t feel what I feel. You change too often.”
vi: "Harry, don't talk like that. As long as I live, the personality of Dorian Gray will dominate me. You cannot feel what I feel. You change too often."
tr: "Harry, don't talk like that. As long as I exist, the influence of Dorian Gray will dominate me. You can't feel what I feel! You are someone who is constantly changing."
es: —Harry, don't talk like that. As long as I live, the personality of Dorian Gray will dominate me. You can't feel what I feel. You change too often.

en: “Ah, my dear Basil, that is exactly why I can feel it. Those who are faithful know only the trivial side of love: it is the faithless who know love’s tragedies.” And Lord Henry struck a light on a dainty silver case and began to smoke a cigarette with a self-conscious and satisfied air, as if he had summed up the world in a phrase. There was a rustle of chirruping sparrows in the green lacquer leaves of the ivy, and the blue cloud-shadows chased themselves across the grass like swallows. How pleasant it was in the garden! And how delightful other people’s emotions were!—much more delightful than their ideas, it seemed to him. One’s own soul, and the passions of one’s friends—those were the fascinating things in life. He pictured to himself with silent amusement the tedious luncheon that he had missed by staying so long with Basil Hallward. Had he gone to his aunt’s, he would have been sure to have met Lord Goodbody there, and the whole conversation would have been about the feeding of the poor and the necessity for model lodging-houses. Each class would have preached the importance of those virtues, for whose exercise there was no necessity in their own lives. The rich would have spoken on the value of thrift, and the idle grown eloquent over the dignity of labour. It was charming to have escaped all that! As he thought of his aunt, an idea seemed to strike him. He turned to Hallward and said, “My dear fellow, I have just remembered.”
vi: “Oh, my dear Basil, that is exactly why I feel it. Those who are faithful know only the trivial side of love; it is the faithless who know the tragedies of love.” And Lord Henry lit a cigarette from a dainty silver box, then began to smoke with a cautious and satisfied air, as if he had just summarized the entire world in a single sentence. Somewhere, there was the rustling sound of sparrows chirping among the glossy green ivy leaves, while blue shadows flitted across the lawn like swallows. How pleasant it was in the garden! And how interesting other people's emotions were! — much more pleasant than their ideas, — it seemed to him. The soul of a man, and the passions of his friends — those were the fascinating things in life. He silently relished the thought of the dull luncheon he had missed by lingering too long with Basil Hallward. If he had gone to his aunt's, he would have met Lord Goodbody there, and the whole conversation would have been about feeding the poor and the necessity of model lodging houses. Each class would expound on the importance of virtues that they themselves did not need to practice in their own lives. The rich would talk about the value of thrift, while the unemployed would wax eloquent about the true worth of labor. How fortunate he was to have escaped all that! As he thought of his aunt, an idea seemed to suddenly occur to him. He turned to Hallward and said, “My dear fellow, I have just remembered.”
tr: “Ah, dear Basil, that is precisely why I can feel these things. Those who are faithful in love only know the trivial aspects of love; those who know its tragedies are unfaithful.” Lord Henry began to puff on his cigarette, which he had lit with an elegant silver lighter, with a self-aware and self-satisfied air; you would think he had summarized the world in a single sentence. There was the rustling of sparrows chirping among the polished leaves of the ivy, and blue cloud shadows were flying over the grass like swallows. How beautiful it was to be in this garden! How delightful were the feelings of others! Lord Henry found people's feelings much more delightful than their thoughts. One's own soul and the feelings of friends: these were the matters that enveloped a person in life. Lord Henry thought with a secret smile about the tedious dinner invitation he had avoided by lingering so long beside Basil Hallward. If he had gone to his aunt's invitation, he would have undoubtedly encountered Lord Goodbody, and the entire conversation would have been about the necessity of feeding the poor and building model housing. Every class would be prattling about the importance of virtues that were not a necessity for their own lives. The rich would extol the value of thrift, and the lazy would praise the nobility of labor to the skies. It had been so sweet to escape from these! As Lord Henry thought of his aunt, something seemed to occur to him. Turning to the painter, he said, “It just came to my mind.”
es: —Ah, my dear Basil, precisely because of that I am able to feel it! Those who are faithful only know the trivial side of love: it is the unfaithful who know its tragedies. Lord Henry struck a match on a delicate silver case and began to smoke a cigarette with an air so self-satisfied and so pleased with himself as if he had summarized the world in a phrase. The sparrows were chattering among the lacquered leaves of the vine, and the blue shadows of the clouds chased each other over the lawn like swallows. How pleasant it was to be in the garden! And how delightful the emotions of other people! Much more so than their ideas, in lord Henry's opinion. Our soul and the passions of our friends: those are the fascinating things in life. He amused himself by silently recalling the tedious lunch he had missed by staying so long with Basil Hallward. If he had gone to his aunt's house, he would undoubtedly have encountered lord Goodboy, and they would have only talked about feeding the poor and the need to build model housing. All the diners would have emphasized the importance of the virtues that their situation in life exempted them from practicing. The rich would speak of the value of thrift, and the idle would eloquently expound on the dignity of work. It was delightful to have escaped all that! While thinking about his aunt, something seemed to surprise him. Turning to Hallward, he said:

en: “Remembered what, Harry?”
vi: “Remember what, Harry?”
tr: “What comes to your mind, Harry?”
es: —I just remembered. —Remember what, Harry?

en: “Where I heard the name of Dorian Gray.”
vi: “The place where I heard the name of Dorian Gray.”
tr: "Where I might have heard the name Dorian Gray.""
es: —Where have I heard the name Dorian Gray.

en: “Where was it?” asked Hallward, with a slight frown.
vi: “Where was that?” Hallward asked, frowning slightly.
tr: Hallward, faintly wrinkling his face, asked, "Where?"
es: "Where?" asked Hallward, frowning slightly.

en: “Don’t look so angry, Basil. It was at my aunt, Lady Agatha’s. She told me she had discovered a wonderful young man who was going to help her in the East End, and that his name was Dorian Gray. I am bound to state that she never told me he was good-looking. Women have no appreciation of good looks; at least, good women have not. She said that he was very earnest and had a beautiful nature. I at once pictured to myself a creature with spectacles and lank hair, horribly freckled, and tramping about on huge feet. I wish I had known it was your friend.”
vi: “Don't look so angry, Basil. It was at my aunt's place, Lady Agatha's. She told me that she had discovered a wonderful young man who was going to help her in the East End, and that his name was Dorian Gray. I must say, she never mentioned to me that he was very handsome. Women don't appreciate physical beauty; at least, decent women don't. She said that he was very earnest and had a good nature. I immediately pictured a creature with spectacles and lank hair, freckles galore, and walking around on huge feet. If only I had known he was your friend.”
tr: "Basil, don't get so angry. I had heard it from my aunt Lady Agatha. My aunt told me that she had discovered a wonderful young man, that this young man would help her in the East End, and that his name was Dorian Gray. I must also point out that my aunt never mentioned that this boy was handsome. Women don't understand beauty anyway, or rather, respectable women don't. My aunt told me that this young man was very serious, honest, and well-mannered. In my mind, I immediately pictured someone with greasy hair, glasses, and terrible freckles, wandering around with huge feet. I wish I had known that this young man was the person you were talking about."
es: —There is no need for you to get angry. It was at my aunt's house, Lady Agatha. She told me that she had discovered a wonderful young man who was going to help her in the East End and that his name was Dorian Gray. I have to confess that she never told me he was good-looking. Women do not appreciate beauty; at least, honest women don't. She told me he was very serious and very well-disposed. Immediately, I imagined a creature with glasses and straight hair, horribly covered in freckles and with enormous flat feet. I wish I had known he was your friend.

en: “I am very glad you didn’t, Harry.”
vi: “I am very glad you don't know, Harry.”
tr: "I'm very glad you didn't know, Harry."
es: —I'm very glad it wasn't like that, Harry.

en: “Why?”
vi: "Why?"
tr: “Why?”
es: —Why?

en: “I don’t want you to meet him.”
vi: “I don't want you to meet him.”
tr: “That's because I don't want you to know him.”
es: —I don't want you to meet him.

en: “You don’t want me to meet him?”
vi: “Don't you want me to meet him?”
tr: "You don't want me to know him, huh?""
es: —Don't you want me to meet him?

en: “No.”
vi: "No."
tr: "I don't want to.""
es: —No.

en: “Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio, sir,” said the butler, coming into the garden.
vi: "Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio, sir," the butler said as he walked into the garden.
tr: "Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio, sir." The male servant had appeared in the garden.
es: —Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio —announced the butler, entering the garden.

en: “You must introduce me now,” cried Lord Henry, laughing.
vi: “You must introduce me at once,” Lord Henry exclaimed and laughed heartily.
tr: Lord Henry laughed, "Now you have to introduce me!" he said.
es: —Now you have to introduce him to me —exclaimed Lord Henry, laughing.

en: The painter turned to his servant, who stood blinking in the sunlight. “Ask Mr. Gray to wait, Parker: I shall be in in a few moments.” The man bowed and went up the walk.
vi: The painter turned to the servant who was standing and blinking in the sunlight. "Tell Mr. Gray to wait, Parker: I will be there in a few seconds." The servant bowed and hurried away.
tr: The painter looked at his servant who was standing in the sun, blinking his eyes. “Parker, please tell Mr. Gray to wait. I am coming in a few minutes.” Adam bent down, then walked towards the house.
es: The painter turned to his servant, who was forced to blink by the sunlight. —Tell Mr. Gray to wait, Parker. I will meet with him in a moment. The butler bowed and withdrew.

en: Then he looked at Lord Henry. “Dorian Gray is my dearest friend,” he said. “He has a simple and a beautiful nature. Your aunt was quite right in what she said of him. Don’t spoil him. Don’t try to influence him. Your influence would be bad. The world is wide, and has many marvellous people in it. Don’t take away from me the one person who gives to my art whatever charm it possesses: my life as an artist depends on him. Mind, Harry, I trust you.” He spoke very slowly, and the words seemed wrung out of him almost against his will.
vi: Then he looked at Lord Henry. “Dorian Gray is my closest friend,” he said. “His nature is simple and kind. Your aunt was absolutely right about him. Do not spoil him. Do not try to influence him. Your influence would be disastrous. The world is vast, and it contains many extraordinary people. Do not take away from me the person who has given my art all the charm it possesses; my personal life as an artist depends entirely on him. Mark my words, Harry, I trust you.” He spoke very slowly, and the words seemed to be dragged out of him almost against his will.
tr: Then the painter looked at Lord Henry. "Dorian Gray is my most precious friend," he said. "He has a simple, beautiful personality. Your aunt has described him very accurately. Do not spoil his purity. Do not try to influence him. Your influence will be bad. The world is vast. There are many wonderful people in it. Do not take away the only person who adds a touch of charm to my art, Harry. My life as an artist depends on Dorian Gray. Remember, I trust you, Harry." He spoke slowly; it was as if a force beyond his will was pulling the words out of him.
es: Hallward then turned to Lord Henry. —Dorian Gray is my dearest friend —he said—. He is a simple and kind person. Your aunt was right in describing him. Do not spoil him. Do not try to influence him. Your influence would be bad. The world is very large and contains many wonderful people. Do not take away from me the only person who gives my art all the charm it possesses: my life as an artist depends on him. Keep that in mind, Harry, I trust you —he spoke very slowly, and the words seemed to come out of his mouth almost against his will.

en: “What nonsense you talk!” said Lord Henry, smiling, and taking Hallward by the arm, he almost led him into the house.
vi: "What nonsense are you talking about!" Lord Henry interrupted, smiling, and, taking Hallward's arm, almost led him into the house.
tr: Lord Henry smiled and said, "What nonsense are you talking about!" and, grabbing Basil Hallward by the arm, dragged him into the house.
es: —What nonsense you speak! —responded Lord Henry, with a smile. Then, taking Hallward by the arm, he almost led him towards the house.

en: CHAPTER II.
vi: Chapter 2
tr: Second chapter
es: Chapter 2

en: As they entered they saw Dorian Gray. He was seated at the piano, with his back to them, turning over the pages of a volume of Schumann’s “Forest Scenes.” “You must lend me these, Basil,” he cried. “I want to learn them. They are perfectly charming.”
vi: When they entered, they saw Dorian Gray. He was sitting by the piano, his back turned to them, flipping through the pages of Schumann's Forest Scenes. "You must lend these to me, Basil," he exclaimed. "I want to learn them. They are beautiful."
tr: They saw Dorian Gray as they entered. The young man was sitting at the piano with his back turned, leafing through the pages of Schumann's Forest Scenes. “Basil, lend these to me!” he called out. “I want to learn. They are very exquisite things.”
es: Upon entering, they saw Dorian Gray. He was seated at the piano, with his back to them, turning the pages of Schumann's Forest Scenes. —You have to lend it to me, Basil —he exclaimed—. I want to learn them by heart. They are delightful.

en: “That entirely depends on how you sit to-day, Dorian.”
vi: "That entirely depends on how well you sit for the modeling today, Dorian."
tr: "Everything depends on the modeling you will do for me today, Dorian."
es: —That depends on how you pose today, Dorian.

en: “Oh, I am tired of sitting, and I don’t want a life-sized portrait of myself,” answered the lad, swinging round on the music-stool in a wilful, petulant manner. When he caught sight of Lord Henry, a faint blush coloured his cheeks for a moment, and he started up. “I beg your pardon, Basil, but I didn’t know you had any one with you.”
vi: “Oh, I'm tired of sitting, and I don't want a life-sized portrait of myself,” the young man replied, spinning on the piano stool, showing a stubborn, sulky demeanor. When he saw Lord Henry, a slight blush appeared on his cheeks for a moment, and he stood up. “I'm sorry, Basil, but I didn't know you had a guest with you.”
tr: The young man, "Ugh, I'm tired of modeling, I don't want any full-length portraits either," he said grumpily, with a stubborn expression, turning to those who had come while sitting on the piano stool. When he saw Lord Henry, a slight color spread across his cheeks for a moment as he stood up. "I'm sorry, Basil, I didn't know you had someone with you."
es: —I am tired of posing, and I don't want a full-body portrait —replied the young man, turning on the piano stool with a capricious and sullen gesture. Upon seeing Lord Henry, his cheeks colored for a moment and he proceeded to stand up—. Forgive me, Basil, but I didn't know you were accompanied.

en: “This is Lord Henry Wotton, Dorian, an old Oxford friend of mine. I have just been telling him what a capital sitter you were, and now you have spoiled everything.”
vi: "This is Lord Henry Wotton, Dorian, an old friend of mine from Oxford. I was just telling him what a perfect model you are, and now you've ruined everything."
tr: “Dorian, this is Lord Henry Wotton, an old friend of mine from Oxford. I was just telling him what an exceptional model you are, and you ruined everything.”
es: —I present to you Lord Henry Wotton, Dorian, an old friend of mine from Oxford. I was telling him that you are a very disciplined model, and you have just ruined everything.

en: “You have not spoiled my pleasure in meeting you, Mr. Gray,” said Lord Henry, stepping forward and extending his hand. “My aunt has often spoken to me about you. You are one of her favourites, and, I am afraid, one of her victims also.”
vi: “You haven't spoiled my pleasure in meeting you, Mr. Gray,” Lord Henry said, stepping forward and extending his hand. “My aunt often talks to me about you. You are one of her most admired people, and, I fear, also one of her victims.”
tr: “You did not spoil the pleasure I felt in meeting you at all, Mr. Gray,” said Lord Henry, stepping forward and extending his hand. “My aunt spoke to me about you. You are one of her favorites. I fear you are one of her victims.”
es: —Except for the pleasure of meeting you, Mr. Gray —said Lord Henry, stepping forward and extending his hand—. My aunt has often spoken of you. You are one of her favorites and, I much fear, also one of her victims.

en: “I am in Lady Agatha’s black books at present,” answered Dorian with a funny look of penitence. “I promised to go to a club in Whitechapel with her last Tuesday, and I really forgot all about it. We were to have played a duet together—three duets, I believe. I don’t know what she will say to me. I am far too frightened to call.”
vi: “I am in Mrs. Agatha's black book,” Dorian replied, with a comically apologetic look. “I promised to go to a club in Whitechapel with her last Tuesday, and I completely forgot about it. We were supposed to play a duet together — three duets, I think. I don't know what she will say to me. I'm so scared that I don't dare to visit her.”
tr: Dorian said with a ridiculous expression of regret, "At the moment, I am on Lady Agatha's blacklist." "I promised to go with her to a club in Whitechapel last Tuesday, but I completely forgot. We were supposed to play a duet together, three duets, if I'm not mistaken. Who knows what she will say to me! I am too afraid to go."
es: —At the moment, I am on Lady Agatha's blacklist —replied Dorian with an amused expression of remorse—. I promised to go with her on Tuesday to a club in Whitechapel and completely forgot about it. We were going to play a duet together..., or rather three, I believe. I don't know what she will say. I'm afraid to visit her.

en: “Oh, I will make your peace with my aunt. She is quite devoted to you. And I don’t think it really matters about your not being there. The audience probably thought it was a duet. When Aunt Agatha sits down to the piano, she makes quite enough noise for two people.”
vi: “Oh, I will reconcile you with my aunt. She is very devoted to you. And I don't think there's really any serious issue with you not going there. The audience probably thought it was a duet. Whenever Aunt Agatha sits down at the piano, she usually makes enough noise for two people.”
tr: “I will mediate between you. My aunt likes you very much. I don't think your not going to the club would have changed anything. Those present there probably thought it was a duet anyway. When my Aunt Agatha sits at the piano, she makes a racket for two.”
es: —I will take care of reconciling him with her. She feels true devotion for you. And I don't think it would matter if you didn't go. The audience probably thought it was a duet. When Aunt Agatha sits at the piano, she makes enough noise for two people.

en: “That is very horrid to her, and not very nice to me,” answered Dorian, laughing.
vi: “Saying that would be too harsh on her, and not very nice for me either,” Dorian laughed, responding.
tr: Dorian laughed, "That's an insult to your aunt, and not much of a compliment to me," he said.
es: —That is an insinuation against her and it doesn't leave me in a very good position either —replied Dorian, laughing.

en: Lord Henry looked at him. Yes, he was certainly wonderfully handsome, with his finely curved scarlet lips, his frank blue eyes, his crisp gold hair. There was something in his face that made one trust him at once. All the candour of youth was there, as well as all youth’s passionate purity. One felt that he had kept himself unspotted from the world. No wonder Basil Hallward worshipped him.
vi: Lord Henry looked at him. Yes, he was truly extremely handsome, with perfectly curved red lips, honest blue eyes, and golden curly hair. There was something about his face that made people trust him immediately. All the carefree youthfulness was there, as well as all the earnest purity of youth. One felt that he had kept himself untainted by the world. No wonder Basil Hallward worshipped him.
tr: Lord Henry looked at him. Yes, this boy was indeed extraordinarily handsome, with his delicately curved bright red lips, open-hearted blue eyes, and vibrant golden hair. There was something in his face that immediately won one's trust. Alongside the passionate innocence of youth, there was also an openness in this countenance. It seemed as if he could protect himself from the world's corruption. It was no wonder Basil Hallward adored him.
es: Lord Henry stared at him. Yes; there was no doubt that he was extraordinarily handsome, with properly arched very red lips, blue eyes full of frankness, and curly blond hair. There was something in his face that inspired immediate trust. All the candor of youth was present there, as well as all its passionate purity. One felt that this young man had not allowed himself to be tainted by the world. It was no wonder that Basil Hallward felt veneration for him.

en: “You are too charming to go in for philanthropy, Mr. Gray—far too charming.” And Lord Henry flung himself down on the divan and opened his cigarette-case.
vi: “You are too charming to do charity work, Mr. Gray — far too charming.” And Lord Henry threw himself onto the couch, then opened his cigarette case.
tr: "You are too charming to devote yourself to charity, Mr. Gray, far too charming for such things." Saying this, Lord Henry threw himself onto the sofa and opened the cigarette case.
es: —Without a doubt, you are too charming to devote yourself to philanthropy, Mr. Gray —Lord Henry dropped onto the divan and opened the cigarette case.

en: The painter had been busy mixing his colours and getting his brushes ready. He was looking worried, and when he heard Lord Henry’s last remark, he glanced at him, hesitated for a moment, and then said, “Harry, I want to finish this picture to-day. Would you think it awfully rude of me if I asked you to go away?”
vi: The painter is busy mixing colors and preparing brushes. He looks anxious, and when he hears Lord Henry's last remark, he glances at him, hesitates for a moment, then says, "Harry, I want to finish this painting today. Do you think it would be too rude of me to ask you to leave?"
tr: The painter, in the meantime, was mixing his paints and preparing his brushes. His face was anxious, especially after hearing these last words, he glanced towards Henry, hesitated for a moment, then said, "Harry, I want to finish this painting today." "Would it be too rude if I asked you to leave?"
es: The painter had been busy mixing colors and preparing the brushes. He seemed worried and, upon hearing Lord Henry's last remark, looked at him, hesitated for a moment, and then said: —Harry, I want to finish this portrait today. Would you think me terribly rude if I asked you to leave?

en: Lord Henry smiled and looked at Dorian Gray. “Am I to go, Mr. Gray?” he asked.
vi: Lord Henry smiled, looking at Dorian Gray. "Shall I go, Mr. Gray?" he asked.
tr: Lord Henry smiled as he looked at Dorian Gray. "Do I have to go, Mr. Gray?" he asked.
es: Lord Henry smiled and looked at Dorian Gray. —Do I have to leave, Mr. Gray? —he asked.

en: “Oh, please don’t, Lord Henry. I see that Basil is in one of his sulky moods, and I can’t bear him when he sulks. Besides, I want you to tell me why I should not go in for philanthropy.”
vi: “Oh, please don't, Lord Henry. I see that Basil is just in a sulky mood; and I can't stand him when he's sulking. Besides, I want you to tell me why I shouldn't continue doing charity work.”
tr: “Ah, my dear, don't go, Lord Henry. I can see it, Basil is in a bad mood; I can't stand him when he sulks. Besides, I want you to tell me why I shouldn't be interested in charitable works?”
es: —No, please, Lord Henry. I can see that Basil is in a bad mood today, and I can't stand him when he sulks. Besides, I want you to explain to me why I shouldn't devote myself to philanthropy.

en: “I don’t know that I shall tell you that, Mr. Gray. It is so tedious a subject that one would have to talk seriously about it. But I certainly shall not run away, now that you have asked me to stop. You don’t really mind, Basil, do you? You have often told me that you liked your sitters to have some one to chat to.”
vi: “I didn't know I had to talk to you about that matter, Mr. Gray. It is such a tedious topic that one has to speak seriously about it. But I surely don't have to run outside, since you have asked me to stay. You really don't mind, Basil, do you? You often tell me that you like your models to have someone to talk to.”
tr: “I don't really think I will tell you this, Mr. Gray. Charity work is such a boring subject that it forces one to become serious. On the other hand, I won't run away, since you want me to stay. Basil, you aren't really angry with me, are you? You've said many times that your models like having someone to chat with beside them.”
es: —I'm not sure I should tell you, Mr. Gray. It's such a tedious matter that it would require serious discussion. But, of course, I won't run away after you've told me to stay. You don't mind too much, do you, Basil? You've told me many times that you like your sisters to have someone to chat with.

en: Hallward bit his lip. “If Dorian wishes it, of course you must stay. Dorian’s whims are laws to everybody, except himself.”
vi: Hallward bit his lip. "If Dorian wants it that way, then of course you can stay. Dorian's whims are law for everyone, except for himself."
tr: Hallward bit his lip, "If Dorian wants it, of course you will stay. Dorian's whims are considered law for everyone except himself."
es: Hallward bit his lips. —If Dorian wishes, of course you can stay. Dorian's whims are laws for everyone, except for himself.

en: Lord Henry took up his hat and gloves. “You are very pressing, Basil, but I am afraid I must go. I have promised to meet a man at the Orleans. Good-bye, Mr. Gray. Come and see me some afternoon in Curzon Street. I am nearly always at home at five o’clock. Write to me when you are coming. I should be sorry to miss you.”
vi: Lord Henry picked up his hat and gloves. "You are very persistent, Basil, but I'm afraid I must go. I have promised to meet someone in Orleans. Goodbye, Mr. Gray. Do come and see me some afternoon on Curzon Street. I am almost always at home at five o'clock. Write to me beforehand when you are coming. I would be very sorry to miss you."
tr: Lord Henry took his hat and gloves in his hand. “You insist too much, but unfortunately, I have to go, Basil. I have an appointment with someone in Orleans. Goodbye, Mr. Gray. Come to Curzon Street one afternoon so we can meet. I am usually home at five in the evening almost every day. Write to me the day you will come. I would like to see you when you arrive.”
es: Lord Henry picked up his hat and gloves. —You are very insistent, Basil, but unfortunately, I must go. I promised to meet someone at the Orleans. Goodbye, Mr. Gray. Come see me some afternoon on Curzon Street. I am almost always home at five. Write to me when you decide to come, I would hate to miss your visit.

en: “Basil,” cried Dorian Gray, “if Lord Henry Wotton goes, I shall go, too. You never open your lips while you are painting, and it is horribly dull standing on a platform and trying to look pleasant. Ask him to stay. I insist upon it.”
vi: "Basil," Dorian Gray exclaimed, "if Lord Henry Wotton leaves, then I will also leave. You never speak while you are painting, and it is terribly boring to stand on the platform and try to look cheerful. Please ask him to stay. I beg you."
tr: Dorian Gray said, "Basil!" "If Lord Henry Wotton leaves, I will leave too. You don't open your mouth while you draw; standing on the platform trying to look cheerful is driving me crazy. Ask him to stay. What I say goes."
es: —Basil —exclaimed Dorian Gray—, if Lord Henry Wotton leaves, I will leave too. You never part your lips when you paint, and it is very boring to stand on a platform and try to look happy. Ask him to stay. I insist.

en: “Stay, Harry, to oblige Dorian, and to oblige me,” said Hallward, gazing intently at his picture. “It is quite true, I never talk when I am working, and never listen either, and it must be dreadfully tedious for my unfortunate sitters. I beg you to stay.”
vi: “Stay, Harry, to do a favor for Dorian, and to do a favor for me,” Hallward said while intently looking at his painting. “Really, I never talk when I am working, and I never listen either, and that must be terribly boring for my unfortunate models. I beg you to stay.”
tr: Hallward, with his eyes fixed intently on the picture he was drawing, said, "Stay, Harry, stay and cheer up Dorian, and make me happy too." "It's very true, I never talk while I'm working, nor do I listen to what's being said. It must be terribly boring for my poor models. I beg you to stay."
es: —Stay, Harry, to please Dorian and to please me —said Hallward, without taking his eyes off the painting—. It is very true that I never talk when I am working, and I do not listen either, which must be incredibly tedious for my poor models. I beg you to stay.

en: “But what about my man at the Orleans?”
vi: "What about my man in Orleans?"
tr: “So, what will happen to the man in Orleans?”
es: —And what will become of the gentleman who is waiting for me in Orleans?

en: The painter laughed. “I don’t think there will be any difficulty about that. Sit down again, Harry. And now, Dorian, get up on the platform, and don’t move about too much, or pay any attention to what Lord Henry says. He has a very bad influence over all his friends, with the single exception of myself.”
vi: The artist laughed. "I don't think there will be any difficulty with that." “Now sit down again, Harry. Now then, Dorian, get on the platform, and don't move too much, or pay attention to what Lord Henry says. He has a very bad influence on all his friends, except for me.”
tr: The painter laughed. "I don't think this will cause any trouble. Sit down, Harry. And you, Dorian, get up on that platform. Try not to move too much; and don't pay attention to what Lord Henry says. He has a very bad influence on all his friends except me."
es: The painter burst out laughing. —I don't think that will be a problem. Sit down again, Harry. And now, Dorian, get on the platform and don't move too much or pay attention to what Lord Henry says. He has a terrible influence on all my friends, with no exception but me.

en: Dorian Gray stepped up on the dais with the air of a young Greek martyr, and made a little moue of discontent to Lord Henry, to whom he had rather taken a fancy. He was so unlike Basil. They made a delightful contrast. And he had such a beautiful voice. After a few moments he said to him, “Have you really a very bad influence, Lord Henry? As bad as Basil says?”
vi: Dorian Gray stepped onto the platform with the demeanor of a Greek youth martyred, and made a slight grimace to show his displeasure before Lord Henry, whom he had come to quite admire. He was entirely different from Basil. They created an interesting contrast. And he had such a wonderful voice. After a few seconds, he said to him, "Are you really a bad influence, Lord Henry? As bad as Basil says?"
tr: Dorian Gray stepped onto the platform with the air of a young saint from ancient Greece, looking towards Lord Henry and slightly wrinkling his face with a hint of complaint. He had taken quite a liking to Lord Henry. This man was so different from Basil. The two friends formed a very delightful contrast. Lord Henry's voice was also beautiful. A few minutes later, Dorian asked him: “Do you really have such a bad influence on your friends, Lord Henry? Is it as bad as Basil says?”
es: Dorian Gray ascended the platform with the appearance of a young Greek martyr, and made a slight grimace of discontent directed at Lord Henry, who already inspired in him a great sympathy. He was so different from Basil! They produced a very pleasant contrast. And he had a very beautiful voice. —Is it true that you exert a terrible influence, Lord Henry? —he asked after a few moments—. As bad as Basil says?

en: “There is no such thing as a good influence, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral—immoral from the scientific point of view.”
vi: “There is nothing like a good influence, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral — immoral from the scientific point of view.”
tr: “There is no such thing as a good influence, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral – immoral from the scientific point of view.”
es: —Good influences do not exist, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral; immoral from a scientific point of view.

en: “Why?”
vi: "Why?"
tr: “Why?”
es: —Why?

en: “Because to influence a person is to give him one’s own soul. He does not think his natural thoughts, or burn with his natural passions. His virtues are not real to him. His sins, if there are such things as sins, are borrowed. He becomes an echo of some one else’s music, an actor of a part that has not been written for him. The aim of life is self-development. To realize one’s nature perfectly—that is what each of us is here for. People are afraid of themselves, nowadays. They have forgotten the highest of all duties, the duty that one owes to one’s self. Of course, they are charitable. They feed the hungry and clothe the beggar. But their own souls starve, and are naked. Courage has gone out of our race. Perhaps we never really had it. The terror of society, which is the basis of morals, the terror of God, which is the secret of religion—these are the two things that govern us. And yet—”
vi: “To influence a person is to give him one's own soul. He does not think his natural thoughts, or burn with his natural passions. His virtues are not real to him anymore. His sins, if there is such a thing as sins, are borrowed. He becomes an echo of someone else's music, an actor of a part that has not been written for him. The aim of life is self-development. To realize one's nature perfectly — that is what each of us is here for. Nowadays people are afraid of themselves. They have forgotten the highest of all duties, the duty that one owes to oneself. Of course they are charitable. They feed the hungry and clothe the beggar. But their own souls are starving and naked. Courage has left our race. Perhaps we never really had it. Fear of society, which is the basis of morality, fear of God, which is the secret of religion — these are the two things that govern us. And yet…”
tr: “To influence someone means to give them your own soul. This person no longer thinks with their own natural thoughts, no longer burns with their own natural passions. Their virtues are not genuine. Their sins – if there is such a thing as sin – are borrowed. This person becomes a reflection of someone else's music, an actor playing a role not written for them. The purpose of life is for a person to develop themselves. To perfectly realize the requirements of our nature: That is why each of us is here. Yet nowadays people are afraid of their own true selves. They have forgotten the highest duty, which is the duty to one's own true self. There is nothing to say against their charity. They feed the hungry, clothe the beggars. But their own souls are hungry, naked. There is no courage left in our kind. Perhaps there never was. Fear of society – which is the basis of morality – and fear of God, which is the secret of religion: These are the two things that govern us. On the other hand, still...”
es: —To influence a person is to give them one's own soul. That person stops thinking their own thoughts and burning with their own passions. Their virtues cease to be real. Their sins, if sins exist, are borrowed. They become an echo of someone else's music, an actor playing a role that was not written for them. The purpose of life is self-development. To realize one's nature perfectly—that is what we are here for. Nowadays people are afraid of themselves. They have forgotten the highest of all duties, the duty that one owes to oneself. Of course, they are charitable. They feed the hungry and clothe the naked. But their own souls starve, and they themselves are naked. Our race has ceased to have courage. Perhaps it has never had it. The fear of society, which is the basis of morality; the fear of God, which is the secret of religion: these are the two things that govern us. And yet...

en: “Just turn your head a little more to the right, Dorian, like a good boy,” said the painter, deep in his work and conscious only that a look had come into the lad’s face that he had never seen there before.
vi: “Please turn your head a little to the right, Dorian, please,” the artist said, immersed in his work, and only noticed that a certain feature he had never seen before had just appeared on the young man's face.
tr: The painter said, "Dorian, turn your head a little more to the right, please." He was deeply engrossed in his work, yet he noticed that an expression he had never seen before appeared on the young man's face.
es: —Turn your head a little more to the right, Dorian, like a good boy —said the painter, engrossed in his work, only aware that a completely new expression had appeared on the boy's face.

en: “And yet,” continued Lord Henry, in his low, musical voice, and with that graceful wave of the hand that was always so characteristic of him, and that he had even in his Eton days, “I believe that if one man were to live out his life fully and completely, were to give form to every feeling, expression to every thought, reality to every dream—I believe that the world would gain such a fresh impulse of joy that we would forget all the maladies of mediævalism, and return to the Hellenic ideal—to something finer, richer than the Hellenic ideal, it may be. But the bravest man amongst us is afraid of himself. The mutilation of the savage has its tragic survival in the self-denial that mars our lives. We are punished for our refusals. Every impulse that we strive to strangle broods in the mind and poisons us. The body sins once, and has done with its sin, for action is a mode of purification. Nothing remains then but the recollection of a pleasure, or the luxury of a regret. The only way to get rid of a temptation is to yield to it. Resist it, and your soul grows sick with longing for the things it has forbidden to itself, with desire for what its monstrous laws have made monstrous and unlawful. It has been said that the great events of the world take place in the brain. It is in the brain, and the brain only, that the great sins of the world take place also. You, Mr. Gray, you yourself, with your rose-red youth and your rose-white boyhood, you have had passions that have made you afraid, thoughts that have filled you with terror, day-dreams and sleeping dreams whose mere memory might stain your cheek with shame—”
vi: “And yet,” Lord Henry continued, in a soft, melodious voice, and with the graceful wave of the hand that was always so characteristic of him, and which he had even used in his days at Eton, “I believe that if one were to live out their life fully and completely, to shape every emotion, to express every thought, to realize every dream — I believe the world would gain such a fresh, joyous impulse that we would forget all the maladies of medieval spirit, and return to the Greek ideal — perhaps to something higher, more precious than the Greek ideal. But the bravest among us is afraid of himself. The barbaric custom of mutilation leaves its tragic remnants in the chastity that is corrupting our lives. We are punished for our own refusals. Every impulse we strangle broods in the mind, and poisons us. The body sins once, and has done with its sin, for action is a mode of purification. There is nothing left after that but the recollection of a pleasure, or the luxury of a regret. The only way to get rid of a temptation is to yield to it. Resist it, and your soul grows sick with longing for the things it has forbidden to itself, with desire for what its monstrous laws have made monstrous and unlawful. It has been said that the greatest events of the world take place in the brain. It is in the brain, and the brain only, that the great sins of the world take place also. You, Mr. Gray, you yourself, with your rose-red youth and your rose-white boyhood, you have had passions that have made you afraid, thoughts that have filled you with terror, day-dreams and sleeping dreams whose mere memory might stain your cheeks with shame…”
tr: Lord Henry continued speaking with that low, melodious voice of his, and with the graceful gesture of his hand that had been characteristic of him since his school days at Eton, "I believe that if a man were to live his life fully and completely, give form to every feeling, express every thought, and realize every dream... I think our world would be so refreshed with joy that mankind would forget all the maladies inherited from the Middle Ages and return to the Hellenistic ideal... Perhaps to something even nobler and more splendid than the Hellenistic ideal. However, even the bravest of us are afraid of ourselves. The cutting away of the wild part of us turns into a tragic life struggle with self-denial that casts a shadow over our lives. Every impulse we try to strangle broods in the mind and poisons us. The body sins once, and the relationship with sin is severed, for action is a form of purification. After the action, all that remains is the memory of a pleasure or the luxury of a regret. The only way to get rid of a temptation is to yield to it. If resisted, the soul grows sick with longing for the things it has forbidden to itself, with desire for what its monstrous laws have made monstrous and unlawful. There are those who say that the great events of the world take place in the brain. The great sins of the world also take place in the brain, only in the brain. You, Mr. Gray, with your rose-red youth and rose-white boyhood, you have had passionate feelings that made you afraid of yourself, thoughts that filled you with terror, dreams that you have seen at night or daydreamed about that merely recalling them might make your face blush with shame..."
es: —And yet —continued Lord Henry, with his grave and musical voice, and with the peculiar hand movement that was so characteristic of him, and that already distinguished him even in the days of Eton—, I believe that if a man were to live his life fully and completely, if he were to give form to every feeling, expression to every thought, reality to every dream..., I believe the world would receive such a wave of joy that we would forget all the diseases of medievalism and return to the Hellenic ideal; perhaps even to something more delicate, richer than the Hellenic ideal. But even the bravest of us is afraid of himself. The mutilation of the savage finds its tragic survival in the self-denial that disfigures our lives. We are punished for our refusals. All the impulses we strive to strangle multiply in the mind and poison us. Let the body sin once, and it will be freed from its sin, because action is a mode of purification. Afterwards, nothing remains except the memory of a pleasure or the voluptuousness of a remorse. The only way to get rid of temptation is to yield to it. If one resists it, the soul grows sick, longing for what it has forbidden to itself, desiring what its monstrous laws have made monstrous and unlawful. It has been said that the great events of the world take place in the brain. It is also in the brain, and only in the brain, that the great sins are committed. You, Mr. Gray, you yourself, still with the red roses of youth and the white ones of childhood, have had passions that made you afraid, thoughts that filled you with terror, dreams and moments of wakefulness whose mere memory can stain your cheeks with shame...

en: “Stop!” faltered Dorian Gray, “stop! you bewilder me. I don’t know what to say. There is some answer to you, but I cannot find it. Don’t speak. Let me think. Or, rather, let me try not to think.”
vi: "Stop!" Dorian Gray stammered, "stop! You are confusing me too much. I don't know what to say anymore. There must be some answer for you, but I can't find it. Don't speak anymore. Let me think. Or rather, let me try not to think anymore."
tr: “Enough!” said Dorian Gray in a trembling voice. “Be quiet! You are confusing me. I don't know what to say. There is an answer to give you, but I can't find it. Don't speak. Let me think. Or rather, let me try not to think.”
es: —Enough! —stammered Dorian Gray—; enough! You bewilder me. I don't know what to say. There is a way to respond to you, but I can't find it. Don't speak. Let me think. Or, rather, let me try to think.

en: For nearly ten minutes he stood there, motionless, with parted lips and eyes strangely bright. He was dimly conscious that entirely fresh influences were at work within him. Yet they seemed to him to have come really from himself. The few words that Basil’s friend had said to him—words spoken by chance, no doubt, and with wilful paradox in them—had touched some secret chord that had never been touched before, but that he felt was now vibrating and throbbing to curious pulses.
vi: For nearly ten minutes, he stood there, motionless, with slightly parted lips and strangely bright eyes. He vaguely realized that entirely new influences were stirring within him. Yet he felt as if they truly came from inside him. A few words that Basil's friend had just said to him — words spoken casually, undoubtedly, with intentional paradox within them — had touched some secret chord that had never been touched before, but now he felt it vibrating and beating with curious rhythms.
tr: He stood there almost motionless for about ten minutes, his lips parted, a strange brightness in his eyes. He vaguely sensed the brand-new stirrings within him, yet they seemed to have come from within himself. The few words Basil's friend had spoken –words said at random, undoubtedly filled with deliberate contradictions– had touched a hidden chord within the young man. Dorian now felt this chord, which had remained untouched until now, vibrating with a strange pulse.
es: For about ten minutes he remained there, motionless, his lips parted and a strange gleam in his eyes. He was vaguely aware that completely new influences were at work within him, although, it seemed to him, they actually came from himself. The few words that Basil's friend had said to him, words thrown out at random, no doubt, and whimsically paradoxical, had touched some secret chord, never before struck, but which he now felt vibrating and throbbing with peculiar tremors.

en: Music had stirred him like that. Music had troubled him many times. But music was not articulate. It was not a new world, but rather another chaos, that it created in us. Words! Mere words! How terrible they were! How clear, and vivid, and cruel! One could not escape from them. And yet what a subtle magic there was in them! They seemed to be able to give a plastic form to formless things, and to have a music of their own as sweet as that of viol or of lute. Mere words! Was there anything so real as words?
vi: Music once moved you like that. Music once tormented you many times. But music does not speak clearly. It is not a new world, but rather another chaos, the one created within us. Words! Just words! How terrifying they are! How pure, vivid, and cruel! One cannot escape from them. And what an enchanting magic they possess! They seem to have the ability to shape the shapeless, and possess a music of their own as sweet as that of the violin and the lute. Just words! Is there anything as real as words?
tr: Music also excited him like this. There were many times when music made him uneasy. However, music does not speak with words. What it creates within us is not a new world but a new chaos. Words! Simple, ordinary words! How terrifying they were! How clear, vivid, and ruthless! One could not escape from them. Yet how intangible their magic was! They seemed to have the ability to give a flexible form to immaterial things, as if they had their own music, sweet like a viola, like a flute. Everyday words, ha! Was there anything more real than words?
es: The music affected him in the same way. The music had moved him many times. But the music was not directly intelligible. It was not a new world, but rather another chaos created within us. Words! Simple words! How terrible they were! How clear, and how sharp and cruel! It was not possible to escape. And yet, what subtle magic there was in them! They seemed to have the virtue of giving a plastic form to shapeless things and possessing a music of their own as sweet as that of a viola or a lute. Simple words! Was there anything as real as words?

en: Yes; there had been things in his boyhood that he had not understood. He understood them now. Life suddenly became fiery-coloured to him. It seemed to him that he had been walking in fire. Why had he not known it?
vi: Yes; there are things from your youth that you didn't understand. Now you understand them. Life suddenly becomes vivid and colorful for you. You feel as if you are walking through fire. Why had you never known this before?
tr: Yes; there had been things in his youth that he did not understand. Dorian understood them now. Life had suddenly turned fiery red in his eyes. It was as if he had walked through flames. Why hadn't he known this before?
es: Yes; there were things in his childhood that he never understood, but now he did. Life, suddenly, took on a bright red color in his eyes. It seemed to him that he had been walking on fire. Why hadn't he known it before?

en: With his subtle smile, Lord Henry watched him. He knew the precise psychological moment when to say nothing. He felt intensely interested. He was amazed at the sudden impression that his words had produced, and, remembering a book that he had read when he was sixteen, a book which had revealed to him much that he had not known before, he wondered whether Dorian Gray was passing through a similar experience. He had merely shot an arrow into the air. Had it hit the mark? How fascinating the lad was!
vi: With a subtle smile, Lord Henry observed the boy. He knew well the precise psychological moment when nothing needed to be said. He found it extremely amusing. He was astonished by the sudden impression his words had made, and, recalling a book he had read when he was sixteen, a book that had opened up many things to him that he had not known before, he wondered if Dorian Gray was going through a similar experience. He had merely shot an arrow into the air at random. Did it hit the target? How charming this young man was!
tr: Lord Henry was scrutinizing the young man with that meaningful smile. He knew well that psychological moment when nothing should be said. He felt a deep interest. The sudden effect of his words had surprised him, bringing to mind a book he had read when he was six years old, a book that explained many things he hadn't known before. He wondered if Dorian Gray was going through a similar experience. What he had done was nothing more than shooting an arrow into the air. Had the arrow hit the target? How fascinating this boy was!
es: With a subtle smile, Lord Henry watched him. He knew the psychological moment when nothing should be said. He was extremely interested. Surprised by the impression his words had made, and recalling a book he had read at sixteen, a book that revealed many things to him that he hadn't known before, he wondered if Dorian Gray was having a similar experience. He had merely shot an arrow into the air. Had it hit the mark? How fascinating that boy was!

en: Hallward painted away with that marvellous bold touch of his, that had the true refinement and perfect delicacy that in art, at any rate comes only from strength. He was unconscious of the silence.
vi: Hallward painted diligently with an extraordinarily bold technique, containing precise elegance and perfect finesse that, in art, no matter what, always originates from inner strength. He did not notice the silence.
tr: Hallward was working with those magnificent, bold strokes of his brush. These brush strokes – at least in art – possessed that true maturity and perfect subtlety that only comes from strength. The painter had not noticed the silence that had settled over the room.
es: Hallward painted tirelessly with those wonderful and bold brushstrokes of his that had the true refinement and perfect delicacy that, at least in art, come solely from strength. He had not noticed the silence.

en: “Basil, I am tired of standing,” cried Dorian Gray suddenly. “I must go out and sit in the garden. The air is stifling here.”
vi: “Basil, I'm tired of standing,” Dorian Gray suddenly exclaimed. “I must go out and sit in the garden. The air here is too stuffy.”
tr: Dorian Gray suddenly complained, "Basil, I'm tired of standing!" "I want to go and sit in the garden. The air here is suffocating."
es: —Basil, I'm tired of standing —exclaimed Gray suddenly—. I want to go out to the garden and sit down. The air here is suffocating.

en: “My dear fellow, I am so sorry. When I am painting, I can’t think of anything else. But you never sat better. You were perfectly still. And I have caught the effect I wanted—the half-parted lips and the bright look in the eyes. I don’t know what Harry has been saying to you, but he has certainly made you have the most wonderful expression. I suppose he has been paying you compliments. You mustn’t believe a word that he says.”
vi: "My dear, I'm sorry. When I draw, I can't think about anything else. But you've never sat as a better model. You were perfectly still. And I captured the impression I wanted — the slightly parted lips, the radiance in the eyes. I don't know what Harry said to you, but he certainly brought out the best expression in you. I suppose he complimented you. You shouldn't believe a single word he says."
tr: “My dear child, I am very sorry. When I am painting, I can't think of anything else. But you have never posed so beautifully for me. You stood completely still. I captured exactly the expression I wanted: glowing eyes with slightly parted lips. I don't know what Harry told you, but he certainly managed to give your face a wonderful expression. He must have paid you compliments. Don't believe a word he says.”
es: —You will have to forgive me. When I paint, I forget everything else. But you have never posed better. You have been completely still. And I have captured the effect I wanted: the slightly parted lips, and the sparkle in the eyes. I don't know what Harry might have told you to achieve this wonderful expression. I imagine he was flattering your vanity. You must not believe a single word he says.

en: “He has certainly not been paying me compliments. Perhaps that is the reason that I don’t believe anything he has told me.”
vi: “He definitely does not compliment me. Perhaps that is the reason why I do not believe anything he tells me.”
tr: “He never complimented me. Maybe that's why I don't believe any of his words.”
es: —Of course, it didn't flatter my vanity. Perhaps that's why I haven't believed anything he told me.

en: “You know you believe it all,” said Lord Henry, looking at him with his dreamy languorous eyes. “I will go out to the garden with you. It is horribly hot in the studio. Basil, let us have something iced to drink, something with strawberries in it.”
vi: "You know you believe it all," Lord Henry said, looking at him with dreamy, languid eyes. "I will go to the garden with you. It's terribly hot in the studio. Basil, give us something cold to drink, something with strawberries in it."
tr: Lord Henry looked at the young man with dreamy, wistful eyes and said, "I know full well that you believe in all of it." "I'm coming to the garden with you too. The studio is terribly hot. Basil, let's have something iced, with strawberries."
es: —Admit that you believed it all —said Lord Henry, giving him a dreamy and languid look—. I'll go out to the garden with you. It's horribly hot in the studio. Basil, offer us something cold to drink, something with strawberries.

en: “Certainly, Harry. Just touch the bell, and when Parker comes I will tell him what you want. I have got to work up this background, so I will join you later on. Don’t keep Dorian too long. I have never been in better form for painting than I am to-day. This is going to be my masterpiece. It is my masterpiece as it stands.”
vi: “Of course, Harry. Just ring the bell, and when Parker comes, I'll tell him what you want. I have to get started on this background, so I'll join you later. Don't keep Dorian too long. I've never been more excited about painting than today. This will be my masterpiece. It already is my masterpiece even now.”
tr: “Hey hey, Harry; pull that bell, I'll tell Parker what you want when he comes. I need to finish working on this background, I'll join you later. Don't keep Dorian too long. I've never been in such good form for painting as I am today. This will be my masterpiece. Even in its current state, it's my masterpiece.”
es: —Of course, Harry. Just call; as soon as Parker comes, I'll tell him what you want. I have to work on the background; I'll join you afterwards. Don't keep Dorian too long. I've never felt so ready to paint as I do today. It's going to be my masterpiece. It already is, just as it is now.

en: Lord Henry went out to the garden and found Dorian Gray burying his face in the great cool lilac-blossoms, feverishly drinking in their perfume as if it had been wine. He came close to him and put his hand upon his shoulder. “You are quite right to do that,” he murmured. “Nothing can cure the soul but the senses, just as nothing can cure the senses but the soul.”
vi: Lord Henry stepped out into the garden and saw Dorian Gray burying his face in the large, cool lilacs, awkwardly drinking in their fragrance as if it were wine. He approached him and placed a hand on his shoulder. "You are doing the right thing," he whispered. "Nothing can cure the soul but the senses, just as nothing can cure the senses but the soul."
tr: When Lord Henry stepped into the garden, he found Dorian Gray with his face buried in the lush, cool lilac flowers, drinking in their scent as if it were wine. He approached and placed his hand on the young man's shoulder. “You are doing very right,” he murmured. “Only the senses can take the pain of the soul, just as the only thing that can take the pain of the senses is the soul.”
es: Lord Henry went out into the garden and found Dorian Gray with his face buried in the large lilac flowers, feverishly drinking in their fresh scent as if it were wine. He approached him and placed a hand on his shoulder. —You are right to do that —he murmured—. Nothing, except the senses, can cure the soul, just as nothing, except the soul, can cure the senses.

en: The lad started and drew back. He was bareheaded, and the leaves had tossed his rebellious curls and tangled all their gilded threads. There was a look of fear in his eyes, such as people have when they are suddenly awakened. His finely chiselled nostrils quivered, and some hidden nerve shook the scarlet of his lips and left them trembling.
vi: The young man was startled and stepped back. He was bareheaded, with leaves tossing his unruly curls and tangling their golden threads. There was a look of fear in his eyes, as people often have when they suddenly wake up. His finely chiseled nostrils quivered, some hidden nerve lightly tugged at his crimson lips, leaving them trembling.
tr: The young man recoiled in shock. His head was bare, the leaves of the tree had tousled his curls and tangled his golden hair strands. There was a fearful look in his eyes, like the eyes of someone suddenly awakened from sleep. His thin, well-defined nostrils were twitching, as if a hidden nerve had drained the color from his lips and made them tremble.
es: The boy started, stepping back. His head was uncovered, and the leaves of the bush had tousled his hair, tangling the golden strands. There was fear in his eyes, as happens when someone is suddenly awakened. His nostrils flared and some hidden nerve twitched the red of his lips, making them tremble.

en: “Yes,” continued Lord Henry, “that is one of the great secrets of life—to cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul. You are a wonderful creation. You know more than you think you know, just as you know less than you want to know.”
vi: “Yes,” Lord Henry continued, “that is one of the great secrets of life — to heal the soul by means of the senses, and to heal the senses by means of the soul. You are a wonderful creation. You know more than you think you know, just as you know less than you want to know.”
tr: Lord Henry continued his speech, "Yes," he said. "It is one of the great mysteries of life: to cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul. You are a wonderful creation. You know more than you think you do; on the other hand, you know less than you want to know."
es: —Yes —continued Lord Henry—; that is one of the great secrets of life: to cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul. You are an astonishing creature. You know more than you think you know, but less than you want to.

en: Dorian Gray frowned and turned his head away. He could not help liking the tall, graceful young man who was standing by him. His romantic, olive-coloured face and worn expression interested him. There was something in his low languid voice that was absolutely fascinating. His cool, white, flowerlike hands, even, had a curious charm. They moved, as he spoke, like music, and seemed to have a language of their own. But he felt afraid of him, and ashamed of being afraid. Why had it been left for a stranger to reveal him to himself? He had known Basil Hallward for months, but the friendship between them had never altered him. Suddenly there had come some one across his life who seemed to have disclosed to him life’s mystery. And, yet, what was there to be afraid of? He was not a schoolboy or a girl. It was absurd to be frightened.
vi: Dorian Gray frowned and turned his head away. He couldn't help but like the tall, young, elegant man standing beside him. The dreamy olive face and the weariness of the man made him take notice.
