There was something in his languid, soft voice that had an absolute allure. Even his cool, white hands, like flowers, had a strange charm. They moved, when he spoke, like music, and seemed to have their own language. But he was afraid of him, and ashamed of being afraid. Why let a stranger expose him to himself? He had known Basil Hallward for months, but their friendship had never changed him. Suddenly, someone had casually entered his life and seemed to reveal to him the mysteries of existence. And, after all, what was there to fear? He was neither a schoolboy nor a young girl. There was nothing to fear.
tr: Dorian Gray slightly frowned and turned his head to the other side. He couldn't help but dislike this tall, elegant young man standing next to him. The romantic dark face and worn expression of this man intrigued him. There was something utterly mesmerizing in Lord Henry's low, sleepy voice. Even those cool, white, flower-like hands had a strange charm. As the man spoke, these hands, moving like music, seemed to have a language of their own. Yet Dorian was afraid of him, and he was ashamed of his fear. How had a stranger analyzed him so thoroughly? He had known Basil Hallward for months, but their friendship had not changed Dorian. Then suddenly, someone who had entered his life had seemingly revealed the secret of life to him. What was there to be afraid of? He was neither a schoolboy nor a young girl. Fear was a ridiculous thing.
es: Dorian Gray frowned and turned his head away. It was impossible for him to stop looking favorably upon that tall and elegant young man beside him. His dark and romantic face and his weary air interested him. There was something in his voice, deep and languid, that was absolutely fascinating. His white, calm hands, which even had something of flowers, possessed a curious charm. They moved, when Lord Henry spoke, in a musical manner, and seemed to possess a language of their own. But Lord Henry frightened him, and he was ashamed to feel fear. How was it that a stranger had made him discover himself? He had known Hallward for months, but the friendship between them had not changed him. Suddenly, however, he had come across someone who seemed to reveal to him the mystery of existence. Although, in any case, what reason was there to feel fear? He was neither a schoolboy nor a little girl. It was absurd to be frightened.

en: “Let us go and sit in the shade,” said Lord Henry. “Parker has brought out the drinks, and if you stay any longer in this glare, you will be quite spoiled, and Basil will never paint you again. You really must not allow yourself to become sunburnt. It would be unbecoming.”
vi: “Let's sit in the shade,” Lord Henry said. “Parker has brought out the drinks, and if you stay any longer in this glaring light, you'll lose much of your charm, and Basil will never paint you again. You really shouldn't let yourself get tanned. It wouldn't suit you.”
tr: Lord Henry said, "Come on, let's sit in the shade." "Parker has brought our drinks. If you stay in this sun any longer, your beauty will fade, and Basil will never paint your picture again. Indeed, you must be very careful not to get sunburned. It wouldn't suit you at all."
es: —Let's sit in the shade —said Lord Henry—. Parker has brought us the drinks, and if you stay any longer under this blazing sun, your complexion will be ruined and Basil will never paint you again. You must not let the sun burn you. It would be very unflattering.

en: “What can it matter?” cried Dorian Gray, laughing, as he sat down on the seat at the end of the garden.
vi: “What does that matter anyway?” Dorian Gray exclaimed with a laugh as he sat down on the chair at the end of the garden.
tr: Dorian Gray, laughing, sat on the bench at the end of the garden and said, "What does it matter?"
es: —What importance does that have? —exclaimed Dorian Gray, laughing, as he sat on a bench at the back of the garden.

en: “It should matter everything to you, Mr. Gray.”
vi: “That matter is of utmost importance to you, Mr. Gray.”
tr: “Everything is of utmost importance to you, Mr. Gray.”
es: —All the importance in the world, Mr. Gray.

en: “Why?”
vi: “Why?”
tr: "Why?"
es: —Why?

en: “Because you have the most marvellous youth, and youth is the one thing worth having.”
vi: “Because you are in the most wonderful period of youth, and youth is something valuable.”
tr: “Because you are wonderfully young. The only thing worth holding onto in this world is youth.”
es: —Because you possess the most wonderful youth, and youth is the most precious thing one can possess.

en: “I don’t feel that, Lord Henry.”
vi: “I don't see it that way, Lord Henry.”
tr: "It doesn't feel that way to me at all, Lord Henry."
es: —I don't feel that way, Lord Henry.

en: “No, you don’t feel it now. Some day, when you are old and wrinkled and ugly, when thought has seared your forehead with its lines, and passion branded your lips with its hideous fires, you will feel it, you will feel it terribly. Now, wherever you go, you charm the world. Will it always be so? ... You have a wonderfully beautiful face, Mr. Gray. Don’t frown. You have. And beauty is a form of genius—is higher, indeed, than genius, as it needs no explanation. It is of the great facts of the world, like sunlight, or spring-time, or the reflection in dark waters of that silver shell we call the moon. It cannot be questioned. It has its divine right of sovereignty. It makes princes of those who have it. You smile? Ah! when you have lost it you won’t smile.... People say sometimes that beauty is only superficial. That may be so, but at least it is not so superficial as thought is. To me, beauty is the wonder of wonders. It is only shallow people who do not judge by appearances. The true mystery of the world is the visible, not the invisible.... Yes, Mr. Gray, the gods have been good to you. But what the gods give they quickly take away. You have only a few years in which to live really, perfectly, and fully. When your youth goes, your beauty will go with it, and then you will suddenly discover that there are no triumphs left for you, or have to content yourself with those mean triumphs that the memory of your past will make more bitter than defeats. Every month as it wanes brings you nearer to something dreadful. Time is jealous of you, and wars against your lilies and your roses. You will become sallow, and hollow-cheeked, and dull-eyed. You will suffer horribly.... Ah! realize your youth while you have it. Don’t squander the gold of your days, listening to the tedious, trying to improve the hopeless failure, or giving away your life to the ignorant, the common, and the vulgar. These are the sickly aims, the false ideals, of our age. Live! Live the wonderful life that is in you! Let nothing be lost upon you. Be always searching for new sensations. Be afraid of nothing.... A new Hedonism—that is what our century wants. You might be its visible symbol. With your personality there is nothing you could not do. The world belongs to you for a season.... The moment I met you I saw that you were quite unconscious of what you really are, of what you really might be. There was so much in you that charmed me that I felt I must tell you something about yourself. I thought how tragic it would be if you were wasted. For there is such a little time that your youth will last—such a little time. The common hill-flowers wither, but they blossom again. The laburnum will be as yellow next June as it is now. In a month there will be purple stars on the clematis, and year after year the green night of its leaves will hold its purple stars. But we never get back our youth. The pulse of joy that beats in us at twenty becomes sluggish. Our limbs fail, our senses rot. We degenerate into hideous puppets, haunted by the memory of the passions of which we were too much afraid, and the exquisite temptations that we had not the courage to yield to. Youth! Youth! There is absolutely nothing in the world but youth!”
vi: "No, you won't see it right now. One day, when you are old, wrinkled, and ugly, when thought has furrowed your forehead with its plows, and passion has scorched your lips with its hideous flames, you will see it, you will find it unbearable. Now, wherever you go, you enchant the world. Will it always be like that?... You have a beautiful face, Mr. Gray. Don't frown. You do. And Beauty is a form of Genius — actually, it is above Genius because it needs no explanation. It is one of the greatest truths of the world, like sunlight, spring, or the reflection in dark water of that silver shell we call the moon. It is indisputable. It has the supreme divine right of sovereignty. It transforms those who possess it into kings. You laugh? Oh! When you lose it, you won't be able to laugh... Sometimes people say that beauty is only superficial. It may be so. But at least it is not as superficial as Thought. To me, Beauty is the wonder of wonders. Only shallow people do not judge by appearances. The true mystery of the world is the visible, not the invisible. Yes, Mr. Gray, the gods have been very good to you. But what the gods give, they quickly take away. You have only a few years to live truly, live perfectly, live fully. When your youth goes, your beauty will go with it, and then you will suddenly discover that there are no triumphs left for you, or have to be content with those pitiful victories that the memory of your past will make more bitter than defeats. Each waning moon brings you closer to something dreadful. Time is jealous of you, and wars against your lilies and your roses. You will become sallow, hollow-cheeked, dull-eyed. You will suffer horribly... Oh! Realize your youth while you have it. Don't squander the gold of your days, don't listen to the tedious, don't try to improve the hopeless failures, or give your life to the ignorant, the common, and the vulgar. These are the sickly aims, the false ideals, of our age. Live! Live the wonderful life that is in you! Let nothing be lost upon you. Always search for new sensations. Be afraid of nothing... A new Hedonism — that is what our century needs. You might be its visible symbol. With your personality, there is nothing you could not do. The world belongs to you for a season... The moment I met you, I saw that you were quite unconscious of what you really are, of what you really might be. There was so much in you that charmed me that I felt I must tell you something about yourself. I thought how tragic it would be if you were wasted. For there is such a little time that your youth will last — such a little time. The common hill-flowers wither, but they blossom again. The laburnum will be as yellow next June as it is now. In a month there will be purple stars on the clematis, and year after year, the green night of its leaves will hold its purple stars. But we never get back our youth. The pulse of joy that beats in us at twenty becomes sluggish. Our limbs fail, our senses rot. We degenerate into hideous puppets, haunted by the memory of the passions we were too much afraid to yield to, and the exquisite temptations we had not the courage to yield to. Youth! Youth! There is absolutely nothing in the world but youth!”
tr: “No, it won't seem like that now. But one day it will, when you are old and wrinkled, when you have become ugly; when thoughts have left marks on your forehead, when the terrible fire of lust has stamped your lips, it will seem like that to you too, and it will be bitter. Now, wherever you go, you win everyone's heart. Will it always be like this?.. You have an extraordinarily beautiful face, Mr. Gray. Don't frown. I'm telling the truth. Beauty is a kind of genius, even higher than genius because it needs no explanation. Beauty is one of the great facts of the world, like sunlight, like springtime, like the reflection of that silver shell we call the moon in dark waters. Its greatness cannot be questioned. Sovereignty is its divine right. It bestows princeliness on those who possess it. You're smiling, huh? Well, you won't be smiling when you lose your beauty. Sometimes people say that beauty is superficial. But at least beauty is not as superficial as thought. In my eyes, beauty is the miracle of miracles. Those who do not judge by appearances are only shallow people. The true mystery of the world is the visible, not the invisible... Yes, Mr. Gray, the gods have been generous to you. But the gods take back what they give very quickly. Truly, you have only a few years to live fully and perfectly. When your youth goes, your beauty will go too, and then you will suddenly see that there are no more victories to be won. Or you will have to be content with some petty victories, which the memories of the past will make more bitter than defeat for you. Every month that nears its end wages war against your roses and lilies out of envy. In time, you will become sallow, hollow-cheeked, and dull-eyed. You will suffer terribly... Ah, value your youth while you have it! Don't waste the gold of your days listening to tedious people, trying to improve the worthless; don't squander your life on the ignorant, the common, and the vulgar. Live! Live the wonderful life that is in you! Let nothing be lost. Seek new sensations always. Fear nothing... A new hedonism: that is what our century needs. You could be its visible symbol. There is nothing you cannot do with your presence. The world is yours for a season... When I first saw you, I realized that you were unaware of what you really are, of what you could really be. There were so many things in you that won my heart that I felt the need to tell you something about yourself. How tragic it would be if you were wasted, I thought. Your youth will last so short, so short. The simplest wildflowers wither, but then they bloom again. This laburnum will be just as yellow next June as it is now. In a month, purple stars will bloom on these clematis branches, and every year, God's green night will harbor purple stars in its leaves. But our youth will never come back again. The joy that pulses in our veins at twenty will fade over time. Our legs will fail, our senses will decay. We will turn into hideous puppets. The memory of the passions we were afraid to indulge, the exquisite sins we dared not taste, will haunt us and make us suffer. Ah, youth! Youth! There is nothing in the world but youth!”
es: —No; he does not feel it now. But someday, when he is old and ugly and full of wrinkles, when thoughts have marked his forehead with their folds and passion has burned his lips with its hateful embers, he will feel it, and he will feel it terribly. Now, wherever he goes, he seduces everyone. Will it always be like this?...You have an extraordinarily handsome face, Mr. Gray. Do not frown. It is true. And beauty is a manifestation of genius; it is even above genius, since it needs no explanation. It is one of the great gifts of nature, like sunlight, or spring, or the reflection in dark waters of that silver shell we call the moon. It admits no argument. It has a divine right of sovereignty. It makes princes of those who possess it. Are you smiling? Ah! When you have lost it, you will not smile...People sometimes say that beauty is only superficial. Perhaps. But at least it is not as superficial as thought. To me, beauty is the wonder of wonders. Only shallow people do not judge by appearances. The true mystery of the world is the visible, not the unseen...Yes, Mr. Gray, the gods have been good to you. But what the gods give, they also take away, and very soon. You only have a few years in which to live truly, perfectly, and fully. When your youth goes, your beauty will go with it, and then you will suddenly discover that there are no more triumphs left for you, or you will have to be content with those mean triumphs that the memory of your past splendor will make more bitter than defeats. Every month that passes brings you closer to something dreadful. Time is jealous of you, and fights against your lilies and your roses. You will become sallow, your cheeks will sink in, and your eyes will lose their brightness. You will suffer horribly... Ah! Enjoy your youth while you have it. Do not squander the gold of your days listening to the tedious, trying to improve the hopeless failure, or giving your life to the ignorant, the common, and the vulgar. These are the sickly aims, the false ideals of our age. Live! Live the wonderful life that is in you! Let nothing be lost upon you. Be always searching for new sensations. Be afraid of nothing...A new hedonism: that is what our century wants. You might be its visible symbol. With your personality, there is nothing you could not do. The world belongs to you for a season...The moment I met you, I saw that you did not realize what you really are, what you really could be. There was so much in you that charmed me that I felt I must tell you something about yourself. I thought of the tragedy of your wasting what you have. For youth is the one thing worth having, and it is too short, too short indeed. The simple flowers of the field wither, but they bloom again. The gorse will be as yellow next June as it is now. In a month, there will be purple stars on the clematis, and year after year, the green night of its leaves will hold its purple stars. But we never get back our youth. The pulse of joy that beats in us at twenty becomes sluggish. Our limbs fail, our senses rot. We degenerate into hideous puppets, haunted by the memory of the passions we were too afraid to yield to, and the exquisite temptations we had not the courage to yield to. Youth! Youth! There is absolutely nothing in the world but youth!

en: Dorian Gray listened, open-eyed and wondering. The spray of lilac fell from his hand upon the gravel. A furry bee came and buzzed round it for a moment. Then it began to scramble all over the oval stellated globe of the tiny blossoms. He watched it with that strange interest in trivial things that we try to develop when things of high import make us afraid, or when we are stirred by some new emotion for which we cannot find expression, or when some thought that terrifies us lays sudden siege to the brain and calls on us to yield. After a time the bee flew away. He saw it creeping into the stained trumpet of a Tyrian convolvulus. The flower seemed to quiver, and then swayed gently to and fro.
vi: Dorian Gray listened, his eyes wide with astonishment. The lilac branch fell from his hand onto the grass. A fuzzy bee flew over and buzzed around for a moment. Then it began to crawl all over the star-speckled oval gourd. He watched it with that strange fascination we often show for trivial things when important matters frighten us, or when we are distracted by some new emotion we cannot find words to express, or when some terrifying idea suddenly besieges our mind and calls for our surrender. A moment later, the bee flew away. He watched it crawl into the tarnished trumpet of a royal purple morning glory. The flower seemed to tremble, then gently sway.
tr: Dorian opened his eyes, listening in a dazed and bewildered manner. The lilac in his hand fell onto the pebbles on the ground. A fuzzy bee came and buzzed over the lilac for a moment. Then it climbed onto the tuft of star-shaped tiny flowers. Dorian watched the bee with that strange interest we try to feel towards insignificant things when important things frighten us, when a brand-new feeling we cannot name stirs within us, or when a thought that terrifies us suddenly besieges our mind and calls for our surrender. He saw the bee burrow into the bright-colored trumpet of a purple laughing flower. The flower seemed to shiver slightly, then began to gently sway back and forth.
es: Dorian Gray listened, his eyes wide open, astonished. The bouquet of lilacs fell to the ground. A silky bee buzzed around him for a moment. Then it began to climb laboriously over the star-shaped globes of each flower. Dorian Gray watched it with the strange interest in trivial things that we try to cultivate when the more important ones frighten us, or when we are overwhelmed by some new emotion that we do not know how to express, or when some idea that terrifies us suddenly besieges the mind and demands our surrender. After some time, the bee took flight. Dorian Gray saw it enter the bell of a vine flower. The flower seemed to shudder and then gently swayed back and forth.

en: Suddenly the painter appeared at the door of the studio and made staccato signs for them to come in. They turned to each other and smiled.
vi: Suddenly, the artist appeared at the entrance to the studio and gestured silently to invite them inside. They turned to each other and laughed.
tr: Suddenly, the painter appeared at the studio door and waved them inside. Dorian and Lord Henry looked at each other and smiled.
es: Suddenly, the painter appeared at the studio door and, with brusque gestures, indicated that they should enter the house. Dorian Gray and Lord Henry looked at each other and smiled.

en: “I am waiting,” he cried. “Do come in. The light is quite perfect, and you can bring your drinks.”
vi: “I'm waiting here,” he shouted. “Come on in. The light is perfect, and you can bring your drinks along.”
tr: The painter called out, "I'm waiting." "My dear, come on. The light is perfect right now. Bring your drinks too."
es: —I am waiting —exclaimed Hallward—. Come, please. The light is perfect; bring the glasses.

en: They rose up and sauntered down the walk together. Two green-and-white butterflies fluttered past them, and in the pear-tree at the corner of the garden a thrush began to sing.
vi: “They stood up, wandering together. Two blue-and-white butterflies fluttered past them, and, on the pear tree in the corner of the garden, a thrush sang.
tr: They stood up and started walking side by side on the road. Two butterflies, green and white, fluttered past them; a bird began to sing in the pear tree at the corner of the garden.
es: They got up and walked the path together. Two green and white butterflies crossed their path, and in the pear tree that occupied a corner of the garden, a blackbird began to sing.

en: “You are glad you have met me, Mr. Gray,” said Lord Henry, looking at him.
vi: “Are you happy to see me, Mr. Gray,” Lord Henry said, looking at him.
tr: Lord Henry looked at the young man and said, "You are glad to have met me, Mr. Gray."
es: —He is glad to have met me, Mr. Gray—said Lord Henry, looking at him.

en: “Yes, I am glad now. I wonder shall I always be glad?”
vi: “Yes, I am happy. I wonder if I will always be happy?”
tr: “Yes, now I am happy. Will I always be this happy, I wonder?”
es: —Yes, now I do. I wonder if I will always be happy.

en: “Always! That is a dreadful word. It makes me shudder when I hear it. Women are so fond of using it. They spoil every romance by trying to make it last for ever. It is a meaningless word, too. The only difference between a caprice and a lifelong passion is that the caprice lasts a little longer.”
vi: “Forever!” “That is a terrible word. It makes me shudder every time I hear it. Women love to use it. They ruin every romantic affair by trying to make it last forever. It is also a meaningless word. The only difference between a whim and a lifelong passion is that a whim lasts a little longer.”
tr: “Always! It's a very ugly expression. As soon as I hear it, my blood freezes. Women love to use it. They ruin every love by trying to make it last forever. As a word, it is also meaningless. The only difference between a whim and an eternal love is that the whim lasts a little longer.”
es: —Always! Terrible word. It makes me shudder when I hear it. Women are so fond of using it. They ruin all love stories by trying to make them last forever. It is, moreover, a meaningless word. The only difference between a whim and a lifelong passion is that the whim lasts a little longer.

en: As they entered the studio, Dorian Gray put his hand upon Lord Henry’s arm. “In that case, let our friendship be a caprice,” he murmured, flushing at his own boldness, then stepped up on the platform and resumed his pose.
vi: When they entered the studio, Dorian Gray placed his hand on Lord Henry's arm. "If so, let our friendship be a whim," he whispered, blushing at his own boldness, then stepped onto the platform and resumed his modeling pose.
tr: As they entered the studio, Dorian Gray placed his hand on Lord Henry's arm. "Then let our friendship be a whim," he said, and his face turned crimson at his own audacity. Then he stepped onto the platform and resumed his previous pose.
es: Upon entering the study, Dorian Gray placed a hand on Lord Henry's arm. —In that case, let our friendship be a whim —she murmured, blushing at her own audacity; then she stepped onto the stage and resumed posing.

en: Lord Henry flung himself into a large wicker arm-chair and watched him. The sweep and dash of the brush on the canvas made the only sound that broke the stillness, except when, now and then, Hallward stepped back to look at his work from a distance. In the slanting beams that streamed through the open doorway the dust danced and was golden. The heavy scent of the roses seemed to brood over everything.
vi: Lord Henry dropped himself into the spacious wicker armchair and observed him. The strokes and brush marks on the canvas created the only sound breaking the silence, except for the occasional moments when Hallward stepped back to view his work from a distance. In the slanting beams of light streaming through the open window, dust danced and turned golden. The fragrant scent of roses seemed to envelop everything.
tr: Lord Henry, dropping himself into a wide wicker chair, began to gaze at him. The strokes and glides of the brush on the canvas were the only sounds breaking the silence. Occasionally, Hall would step back a bit to look at his work from a distance. Golden-colored dust danced in the slanting rays of light coming through the door. The heavy scent of roses had permeated everything.
es: Lord Henry dropped into a large wicker armchair and watched him. The brush's stroke on the canvas was the only noise disturbing the stillness, except when, from time to time, Hallward stepped back to examine his work from a distance. In the slanting rays that penetrated through the open door, the dust danced, turned into gold. The intense fragrance of the roses seemed to envelop everything.

en: After about a quarter of an hour Hallward stopped painting, looked for a long time at Dorian Gray, and then for a long time at the picture, biting the end of one of his huge brushes and frowning. “It is quite finished,” he cried at last, and stooping down he wrote his name in long vermilion letters on the left-hand corner of the canvas.
vi: After about a quarter of an hour, Hallward stopped painting, gazed at Dorian Gray for a long time, then looked at the painting for a long time, biting the end of one of his huge paintbrushes, frowning. "It's all done," he finally exclaimed and bent down to write his name in long red letters on the bottom left corner of the canvas.
tr: About a quarter of an hour later, Hallward put down the brush. For a long time, he looked at Dorian Gray, then, biting the tip of his large brush, he frowned at his work. Finally, "Finished, finally!" he shouted, bending over, and wrote his name in long, red letters in the left corner of the canvas.
es: After a quarter of an hour, Hallward stopped painting, looked at Dorian Gray for a long time, and then at the painting for another long time while biting the end of one of his large brushes and frowning. —It's finished —he exclaimed at last; bending down, he signed with large red strokes in the bottom left corner of the canvas.

en: Lord Henry came over and examined the picture. It was certainly a wonderful work of art, and a wonderful likeness as well.
vi: Lord Henry approached and examined the painting closely. It was indeed an extraordinary piece of art, and the resemblance was also remarkable.
tr: Lord Henry arrived and examined the portrait. Without a doubt, it was an extraordinary work of art, exactly like the model.
es: Lord Henry approached to examine the portrait. It was, without a doubt, a splendid work of art, and the likeness was excellent.

en: “My dear fellow, I congratulate you most warmly,” he said. “It is the finest portrait of modern times. Mr. Gray, come over and look at yourself.”
vi: “Dear friend, I warmly congratulate you,” he said. “This is the most beautiful portrait of the time. Mr. Gray, come here and look at yourself.”
tr: "My dear friend, I congratulate you with all my heart." "This is the finest portrait of the contemporary era! Mr. Gray, come and see yourself.""
es: —My dear friend —he said—, I congratulate you with all my heart. It is the best portrait of our time. Mr. Gray, come and see for yourself.

en: The lad started, as if awakened from some dream.
vi: The young man was startled, as if waking up from some dream.
tr: The young man jolted as if waking from a dream.
es: The boy started, as if waking from a dream.

en: “Is it really finished?” he murmured, stepping down from the platform.
vi: "Is it really over?" he whispered, stepping down from the platform.
tr: “Is it really over?” he said, stepping down from the platform.
es: —Really finished? —he murmured, stepping down from the platform.

en: “Quite finished,” said the painter. “And you have sat splendidly to-day. I am awfully obliged to you.”
vi: "It's completely done," the artist said. "And today you posed wonderfully. I am extremely grateful to you."
tr: “It's truly finished,” said the painter. “You posed beautifully today. I sincerely thank you.”
es: —Absolutely —said the painter—. And today you have posed better than ever. I am very grateful to you.

en: “That is entirely due to me,” broke in Lord Henry. “Isn’t it, Mr. Gray?”
vi: "It's all my doing," Lord Henry interrupted. "Isn't that right, Mr. Gray?"
tr: Lord Henry said, "It was entirely thanks to me." "Isn't that right, Mr. Gray?"
es: —You owe that entirely to me —interjected Lord Henry—. Isn't that right, Mr. Gray?

en: Dorian made no answer, but passed listlessly in front of his picture and turned towards it. When he saw it he drew back, and his cheeks flushed for a moment with pleasure. A look of joy came into his eyes, as if he had recognized himself for the first time. He stood there motionless and in wonder, dimly conscious that Hallward was speaking to him, but not catching the meaning of his words. The sense of his own beauty came on him like a revelation. He had never felt it before. Basil Hallward’s compliments had seemed to him to be merely the charming exaggeration of friendship. He had listened to them, laughed at them, forgotten them. They had not influenced his nature. Then had come Lord Henry Wotton with his strange panegyric on youth, his terrible warning of its brevity. That had stirred him at the time, and now, as he stood gazing at the shadow of his own loveliness, the full reality of the description flashed across him. Yes, there would be a day when his face would be wrinkled and wizen, his eyes dim and colourless, the grace of his figure broken and deformed. The scarlet would pass away from his lips and the gold steal from his hair. The life that was to make his soul would mar his body. He would become dreadful, hideous, and uncouth.
vi: Dorian did not respond, but indifferently walked past his painting, then turned towards it. When he saw it, he stepped back, and his cheeks flushed for a moment with joy. A look of delight appeared in his eyes, as if he recognized himself for the first time. He stood motionless in astonishment, vaguely aware that Hallward was speaking to him, but unable to grasp the meaning of his words. The awareness of his own beauty came to him like an enlightenment. He had never felt that before. Basil Hallward's praises seemed to him merely the charming exaggerations of friendship. He had heard them, laughed at them, and forgotten them. They did not affect his nature. Then Lord Henry Wotton came with his strange eulogy of youth, with his terrible warning of its brevity. That had unsettled him at the time, and now, as he stood staring at the image of his own beauty, the full reality of that description flashed across him. Yes, there would come a day when his face would be wrinkled and withered, his eyes would dim, and his graceful figure would become bloated and deformed. The crimson would fade from his lips, the gold would flee from his hair. The life that had made his soul would also mar his body. He would become dreadful, hideous, and coarse.
tr: Dorian, without responding, reluctantly moved forward and turned towards his portrait. He recoiled when he saw the portrait, his cheeks momentarily flushed with pride. As if recognizing himself for the first time, a joy sparkled in his eyes. He stood there motionless, as if in a trance. Though he vaguely noticed Hallward saying something to him, he couldn't grasp the meaning of the words. He had become aware of his own beauty, as if a sacred truth had been revealed. He had never felt this before. He had considered Basil Hallward's praises as sweet exaggerations of friendship. He had listened, laughed, and forgotten. These praises had not affected his nature. Then Lord Henry had appeared, with that strange ode to youth and his alarming warnings about its brevity. The meaning of these words, which had impressed the young man while listening, suddenly struck him with full clarity as he looked at the reflection of his own beauty in the portrait. Yes, the day would come when his face would wrinkle and sag, the light and color of his eyes would fade, the delicate harmony of his form would become distorted and misshapen. The redness of his lips would pale, the golden sheen of his hair would vanish. The life that would develop his soul would disfigure his body. He would become something dreadful, repulsive, and cumbersome.
es: Dorian, without responding, advanced slowly with his back to the painting and then turned towards it. Upon seeing it, he stepped back, his cheeks flushed with pleasure for a moment. A gleam of joy lit up in his eyes, as if he recognized himself for the first time. He remained motionless and amazed, barely aware that Hallward was speaking to him and without grasping the meaning of his words. The awareness of his own beauty struck him like a revelation. It was the first time. Basil Hallward's compliments had seemed to him until then mere pleasant exaggerations, products of friendship. He listened to them, laughed at them, and forgot them. They did not influence him. Then Lord Henry Wotton had appeared with his strange panegyric on youth, his terrible warning about its brevity. That had moved him and now, as he gazed intently at the image of his beauty, he grasped the whole truth with blinding clarity. Yes, on a not too distant day his face would wrinkle and wither, his eyes would lose color and brightness, the harmony of his figure would break. The scarlet red of his lips and the gold of his hair would disappear. The life that was to shape his soul would deform his body. He would become a horrible, hateful, grotesque being.

en: As he thought of it, a sharp pang of pain struck through him like a knife and made each delicate fibre of his nature quiver. His eyes deepened into amethyst, and across them came a mist of tears. He felt as if a hand of ice had been laid upon his heart.
vi: While he was thinking about it, a sharp pain pierced through him like a knife, making every soft fiber of his being tremble. His eyes were a deep amethyst color, and across them — a veil of blurred tears. He felt as if an icy hand had just been placed on his heart.
tr: The sharp pain that pierced the young man's soul like a knife made the delicate fibers of his being quiver one by one. His eyes darkened and turned into amethyst purple, shrouded in a mist of tears. It was as if an icy hand had squeezed his heart.
es: Thinking about it, a very sharp pain pierced him like a knife, making all the fibers of his being tremble. The blue of his eyes darkened with a veil of tears. He felt as if an icy hand had settled on his heart.

en: “Don’t you like it?” cried Hallward at last, stung a little by the lad’s silence, not understanding what it meant.
vi: “You don't like it?” Hallward finally exclaimed, a bit distressed by the young man's silence, not understanding what it meant.
tr: The painter, slightly offended by the young man's silence which he couldn't understand, finally burst out, "Didn't you like it?"
es: —Don't you like it? —Hallward finally exclaimed, somewhat hurt by the boy's silence, not understanding its meaning.

en: “Of course he likes it,” said Lord Henry. “Who wouldn’t like it? It is one of the greatest things in modern art. I will give you anything you like to ask for it. I must have it.”
vi: “Of course he likes it,” said Lord Henry. “Who wouldn't like it? It is one of the greatest works of modern art. I will give you anything you want for it. I must have it.”
tr: Lord Henry said, "Of course he liked it." "Who wouldn't like this? It's one of the greatest works of contemporary art. I'll give you whatever you want in exchange for this painting. It must be mine."
es: —Of course he likes it —said Lord Henry—. Who could not like it? It is one of the great works of modern art. I will give you whatever you want for it. It must be mine.

en: “It is not my property, Harry.”
vi: “It does not belong to me, Harry.”
tr: “The painting doesn't belong to me, Harry.”
es: —I am not its owner, Harry.

en: “Whose property is it?”
vi: "So, who owns it?"
tr: "Whose is it?"
es: —Who is the owner?

en: “Dorian’s, of course,” answered the painter.
vi: “Dorian's, of course,” the artist replied.
tr: “Of course to Dorian,” replied the painter.
es: —Dorian, of course —replied the painter.

en: “He is a very lucky fellow.”
vi: “He is a very lucky young man.”
tr: “He was a very lucky child.”
es: —He is very fortunate.

en: “How sad it is!” murmured Dorian Gray with his eyes still fixed upon his own portrait. “How sad it is! I shall grow old, and horrible, and dreadful. But this picture will remain always young. It will never be older than this particular day of June.... If it were only the other way! If it were I who was to be always young, and the picture that was to grow old! For that—for that—I would give everything! Yes, there is nothing in the whole world I would not give! I would give my soul for that!”
vi: “How sad it is!” Dorian Gray whispered, his eyes still fixed on the portrait of himself. “How sad it is! I will gradually grow old, ugly, and horrible. But this picture will remain young forever. It will never be older than this particular day in June… If only there were another way! If only I could stay young and the picture would grow old! For that — for that — I would give everything! Yes, there is nothing in the whole world that I would not give! I would give my soul for that!”
tr: Dorian Gray murmured, "How sad!" without taking his eyes off his own portrait. "How sad it is! I will grow old and become ugly, I will be hideous. Yet this picture will remain young forever. It will never be older than this June day... If only it could be the other way around! If I could remain young forever, and this picture would grow old! For that... I would give everything for that! Yes, there is nothing in the whole world I wouldn't give! I would even sell my soul for that!"
es: —How sad it is! —murmured Dorian Gray, his eyes still fixed on the portrait—. I will grow old, horrible, dreadful. But this picture will always remain young. It will never be older than this particular day of June... If it were only the other way around! If I could always stay young and the picture grow old! I would give..., I would give anything for that! I would give my soul!

en: “You would hardly care for such an arrangement, Basil,” cried Lord Henry, laughing. “It would be rather hard lines on your work.”
vi: "You will hardly be able to arrange such a setup, Basil," Lord Henry exclaimed, laughing. "It will become a misfortune in your work."
tr: Lord Henry laughed and said, "Basil, such a bargain would not suit you." "It would be unfair to your work."
es: —I don't think you would like that solution very much, Basil —exclaimed Lord Henry, laughing—. It would be quite unkind to your work.

en: “I should object very strongly, Harry,” said Hallward.
vi: "I will probably oppose it to the end, Harry," Hallward said.
tr: The painter replied, "I would have already opposed it with all my might, Harry."
es: —I would oppose it with the greatest possible energy, Harry —said Hallward.

en: Dorian Gray turned and looked at him. “I believe you would, Basil. You like your art better than your friends. I am no more to you than a green bronze figure. Hardly as much, I dare say.”
vi: Dorian Gray turned to look at him. "I believe you will, Basil. You love your art more than your friends. You see me as nothing more than a bronze statue turning green. It's hard to match that, I dare say."
tr: Dorian Gray turned and looked at him. "I believe it, Basil. You value your art above your friends. In your eyes, I am no different from a bronze statue. I am not even worth that much!"
es: Dorian Gray turned to look at him. —I am sure you would. Your art matters more to you than friends. To you, I am nothing more than a little bronze figurine. Not even that, I would dare to say.

en: The painter stared in amazement. It was so unlike Dorian to speak like that. What had happened? He seemed quite angry. His face was flushed and his cheeks burning.
vi: The artist stared in astonishment. It did not seem like Dorian had said that. What had happened? You seemed quite angry. Your face was flushed and your cheeks were glowing.
tr: The painter was left staring in astonishment. Such a conversation was something completely unexpected from Dorian Gray. What had happened? The young man looked quite angry. Blood had rushed to his face, and his cheeks were burning.
es: The painter stared at him, astonished. Dorian never spoke like that. What had happened? He seemed very angry. His face was flushed and his cheeks were burning.

en: “Yes,” he continued, “I am less to you than your ivory Hermes or your silver Faun. You will like them always. How long will you like me? Till I have my first wrinkle, I suppose. I know, now, that when one loses one’s good looks, whatever they may be, one loses everything. Your picture has taught me that. Lord Henry Wotton is perfectly right. Youth is the only thing worth having. When I find that I am growing old, I shall kill myself.”
vi: “Yes,” he continued, “You regard me as less than your ivory Hermes or your silver Faun. You will always like them. How long will you like me? Until I get my first wrinkle, I suppose. Now I know that when one loses their beauty, whatever it may be, they lose everything. Your painting taught me that. Lord Henry Wotton was absolutely right. Youth is the only thing worth having. When I see myself growing old, I will kill myself.”
tr: “Yes,” he continued speaking. “In your eyes, I am even less important than that ivory Hermes, that silver Faun. You will love them for a lifetime. How long will you love me? Probably until the first wrinkle appears on my face. Now I have learned: When a person loses their beauty, they lose everything. Your portrait taught me that. Lord Henry Wotton is absolutely right. The only thing worth having is youth. When I see that I am starting to age, I will kill myself.”
es: —Yes —continued the young man—: to you, I am less than your ivory Hermes or your silver faun. Those you will always like. How long will you like me? Until I get my first wrinkle. Now I know that when beauty is lost, whether much or little, everything is lost. Your painting has taught me that. Lord Henry Wotton is right. Youth is the only thing worth having. When I discover that I am aging, I will kill myself.

en: Hallward turned pale and caught his hand. “Dorian! Dorian!” he cried, “don’t talk like that. I have never had such a friend as you, and I shall never have such another. You are not jealous of material things, are you?—you who are finer than any of them!”
vi: Hallward turned pale, grasping his hand. "Dorian! Dorian!" he cried, "don't say that. I've never had a friend like you, and I never will have another like that. You're not jealous of those tangible things, are you? — you're more beautiful than any of them!”
tr: Hallward turned pale and grasped the young man's hand. “Dorian!” he cried. “Dorian, don't talk like that. I've never had a friend like you before, and I never will again. You're not trying to envy material, worldly things, are you? You are above all of them.”
es: Hallward paled and took his hand. —Dorian! Dorian! —he exclaimed—, don't speak like that. I've never had a friend like you, nor will I ever have another. Don't tell me you're jealous of material things. You are above all of them!

en: “I am jealous of everything whose beauty does not die. I am jealous of the portrait you have painted of me. Why should it keep what I must lose? Every moment that passes takes something from me and gives something to it. Oh, if it were only the other way! If the picture could change, and I could be always what I am now! Why did you paint it? It will mock me some day—mock me horribly!” The hot tears welled into his eyes; he tore his hand away and, flinging himself on the divan, he buried his face in the cushions, as though he was praying.
vi: “I am jealous of everything that has immortal beauty. I am jealous of the portrait you painted of me. Why can it retain what I must lose? Every passing moment takes something from me and gives something to it. Oh, if only there were another way! If the painting could change, and I could remain as I am now! Why did you paint it? One day it will mock me — mock me terribly!” Hot tears welled up in his eyes; he pulled his hand away, and, throwing himself onto the couch, he buried his face in the cushion, as if in prayer.
tr: “I envy everything whose beauty does not die. I envy the portrait you drew. Why should it keep what I have lost! Every passing minute takes something away from me while adding something to it. Ah, if only it could be the other way around! If only the picture changed and I could remain as I am! Why did you do this? One day this picture will mock me, mock me terribly!” Tears filled his eyes. He pulled his hand away as if tearing it off, threw himself onto the couch, and buried his face in the pillows as if praying.
es: —I am jealous of everything whose beauty does not die. I am jealous of my portrait. Why should it keep what I am going to lose? Every moment that passes takes something from me to give it to him. Ah, if it were the other way around! If the painting could change and I could always remain as I am now! Why did you paint it? It will mock me someday, it will mock me mercilessly! His eyes filled with burning tears; he abruptly withdrew his hand and, throwing himself onto the divan, buried his face among the cushions, as if he were praying.

en: “This is your doing, Harry,” said the painter bitterly.
vi: "This is your doing, Harry," the artist said bitterly.
tr: The painter bitterly said, "This is your doing, Harry!"
es: —This is your doing, Harry —said the painter bitterly.

en: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. “It is the real Dorian Gray—that is all.”
vi: Lord Henry shrugged. "That is Dorian Gray — that's all."
tr: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. “The real Dorian Gray before us... That's all.”
es: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. —It is the real Dorian Gray, that's all.

en: “It is not.”
vi: "No."
tr: “It is not!”
es: —It is not.

en: “If it is not, what have I to do with it?”
vi: “If not, then what do I have to do with it?”
tr: “If not, then what?”
es: —If it isn't, what do I have to do with that?

en: “You should have gone away when I asked you,” he muttered.
vi: “You should have left when I asked you,” he muttered.
tr: The painter muttered, "You were supposed to leave when I asked."
es: —You should have left when I asked you to —he murmured.

en: “I stayed when you asked me,” was Lord Henry’s answer.
vi: “I stayed when you asked me,” was Lord Henry's reply.
tr: Lord Henry replied, "I stayed when you asked."
es: —I stayed when you asked me to —was Lord Henry's reply.

en: “Harry, I can’t quarrel with my two best friends at once, but between you both you have made me hate the finest piece of work I have ever done, and I will destroy it. What is it but canvas and colour? I will not let it come across our three lives and mar them.”
vi: "Harry, I can't argue with my two best friends at the same time, but just between the two of you, you have made me hate the most beautiful work I have ever created, and I will destroy it. What is it but canvas and paint? I will not let it interfere with our three lives and ruin them."
tr: “Harry, I can't get into a fight with both of my best friends at once, but you two have teamed up and made me lose my passion for my best work; so I will destroy this painting. But after all, isn't it just canvas and paint? I can't allow it to cast a shadow and wound all three of our lives.”
es: —Harry, I can't fight with my two best friends at the same time, but between the two of you, you have made me hate the most perfect of my works, and I am going to destroy it. What is it, after all, except canvas and color? I will not allow a portrait to come between us.

en: Dorian Gray lifted his golden head from the pillow, and with pallid face and tear-stained eyes, looked at him as he walked over to the deal painting-table that was set beneath the high curtained window. What was he doing there? His fingers were straying about among the litter of tin tubes and dry brushes, seeking for something. Yes, it was for the long palette-knife, with its thin blade of lithe steel. He had found it at last. He was going to rip up the canvas.
vi: Dorian Gray lifted his golden head from the pillow, and, with a pale face and tear-stained eyes, looked at him, while he walked to the pine drawing table under the tall, curtained window. What was he doing there? His fingers wandered among the clutter of tin tubes and dry brushes, searching for something. Yes, searching for the long palette knife, with its thin, soft steel blade. At last he found it. He would slash the canvas.
tr: Dorian Gray lifted his golden head from the pillow and watched with his pale face and tearful eyes as Basil walked towards the pine easel standing by the window. What was the painter doing there? His fingers were moving around, searching for something among the tangled tin tubes and dry brushes. Yes, he was looking for that long palette knife made of flexible, thin steel. There, he had finally found it. He was going to cut and slice the canvas.
es: Dorian Gray lifted his blond head from the cushion and, with a pale face and eyes red from tears, looked at him as Hallward walked towards the wooden table situated under the high curtained window. What had he gone there to do? His fingers got lost among the jumble of tin tubes and dry brushes, searching for something. Yes, the long palette knife, with its thin, flexible steel blade. . Once found, he was about to slash the canvas.

en: With a stifled sob the lad leaped from the couch, and, rushing over to Hallward, tore the knife out of his hand, and flung it to the end of the studio. “Don’t, Basil, don’t!” he cried. “It would be murder!”
vi: With a sobbing cry, the young man jumped off the couch, and, rushing to Hallward, snatched the knife from his hand, throwing it to the other side of the studio. "Don't, Basil, don't!" he shouted. "That's murder!"
tr: Dorian sprang up with a choked sob, leaping onto Hallward and snatching the knife from his hand, then hurling it to the opposite corner of the studio. "Don't do it, Basil, don't do it!" he was shouting. "This would be murder!"
es: Stifling a groan, the boy jumped off the divan and, running towards Hallward, snatched the knife from his hand, throwing it to the other end of the studio. —No, Basil, don't do it! —he exclaimed—. It would be murder!

en: “I am glad you appreciate my work at last, Dorian,” said the painter coldly when he had recovered from his surprise. “I never thought you would.”
vi: "I am glad that you have finally appreciated my work, Dorian," the artist said coldly, as he calmed down after the surprise. "I never thought you would."
tr: When the painter's astonishment passed, he said coldly, "I'm glad you finally appreciate the value of the painting I made, Dorian." "I thought you would never know.""
es: —I'm glad that you finally appreciate my work, Dorian —said the painter coldly, once he had recovered from the surprise—. I had lost hope.

en: “Appreciate it? I am in love with it, Basil. It is part of myself. I feel that.”
vi: "Appreciate it? I am in love with it, Basil. It is a part of myself. That's how I feel."
tr: "Appreciate its value? I'm infatuated with this painting, Basil. It's a part of my existence. That's how it feels to me. "
es: —Appreciate it? It fascinates me. It's part of myself. I notice it.

en: “Well, as soon as you are dry, you shall be varnished, and framed, and sent home. Then you can do what you like with yourself.” And he walked across the room and rang the bell for tea. “You will have tea, of course, Dorian? And so will you, Harry? Or do you object to such simple pleasures?”
vi: "Alright, as soon as you are dry, you will be varnished, framed, and sent home. After that, you can do whatever you like with yourself." And he walked across the room and rang the bell for tea. "Will you have some tea, Dorian? And you too, Harry? Or do you object to even such simple pleasures?"
tr: “Well then, as soon as my paints dry, I will apply a varnish over it, then frame it and send it to your home. Then you can do whatever you want with it.” Saying this, the painter walked towards the door and rang the bell to ask for tea. “You will stay for tea, won't you, Dorian? Will you stay too, Harry? Or do you object to such small pleasures?”
es: —Alright; as soon as you are dry, you will be varnished and framed and sent to your home. Once there, you can do with yourself whatever you want —crossing the room, he rang the bell to order tea—. Will you have tea, as is logical, Dorian? And you too, Harry? Or are you against such simple pleasures?

en: “I adore simple pleasures,” said Lord Henry. “They are the last refuge of the complex. But I don’t like scenes, except on the stage. What absurd fellows you are, both of you! I wonder who it was defined man as a rational animal. It was the most premature definition ever given. Man is many things, but he is not rational. I am glad he is not, after all—though I wish you chaps would not squabble over the picture. You had much better let me have it, Basil. This silly boy doesn’t really want it, and I really do.”
vi: “I admire simple pleasures,” Lord Henry said. “They are the last refuge of the complex. But I do not like scenes, except on the stage. How ridiculous you both are! I wonder who defined man as a rational animal. It was the most hasty definition ever given. Man is many things, but he is not rational. I am glad he is not, after all: though I wish you two would not quarrel over the picture. You had better let me have it, Basil. This silly boy doesn’t really want it, and I really do.”
tr: “I adore small pleasures,” said Lord Henry. “They are the last refuge of complex souls. But I do not like theater scenes played offstage. How ridiculous you both are! I wonder who first called man a rational animal? It is the most premature definition ever given. Man can be many things, but rational is not one of them. And I am glad he is not; still, I do not want you quarreling over this painting. Basil, you better give it to me. He does not actually want this silly portrait, whereas I truly do.”
es: —I adore simple pleasures —said Lord Henry—. They are the last refuge of complex souls. But I do not like scenes, except in the theater. How absurd you both are! I wonder who defined man as a rational animal. It was the most premature definition ever given. Man is many things, but not rational. And I am glad of it after all: although I would like you not to fight over the painting. It would be much better if you gave it to me, Basil. This poor boy doesn't really want it, and I do.

en: “If you let any one have it but me, Basil, I shall never forgive you!” cried Dorian Gray; “and I don’t allow people to call me a silly boy.”
vi: “If you let anyone else have it besides me, Basil, I will never forgive you!” Dorian Gray exclaimed; “and I do not allow people to call me a foolish boy.”
tr: Dorian Gray shouted, "Basil, if you give this to anyone else, I will never forgive you in this world!" "I also won't allow anyone to call me a fool!"
es: —If you give it to another person, I will never forgive you! —exclaimed Dorian Gray—; and I do not allow anyone to call me poor boy.

en: “You know the picture is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it existed.”
vi: "You know the painting is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it even existed."
tr: "This painting is yours, Dorian, you know that. I gave it to you before it even existed."
es: —You know that the painting is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it even existed.

en: “And you know you have been a little silly, Mr. Gray, and that you don’t really object to being reminded that you are extremely young.”
vi: “And you know you used to be a naive boy, Mr. Gray, and that you don't really feel upset about being reminded that you are extremely young.”
tr: “You also know that you are acting a bit silly, Mr. Gray. You actually have no objection to the emphasis on your youth.”
es: —And you also know, Mr. Gray, that you have let yourself be carried away by your feelings and that, in reality, you do not mind being reminded of how young you are.

en: “I should have objected very strongly this morning, Lord Henry.”
vi: "I should have felt extremely uncomfortable this morning, Lord Henry."
tr: “If it were this morning, I would strongly object, Lord Henry.”
es: —It would have seemed frankly wrong to me this morning, Lord Henry.

en: “Ah! this morning! You have lived since then.”
vi: "Oh! This morning! You lived through that moment."
tr: “Ha! This morning! You have lived a lifetime since then.”
es: —Ah, this morning! You have lived a lot since then.

en: There came a knock at the door, and the butler entered with a laden tea-tray and set it down upon a small Japanese table. There was a rattle of cups and saucers and the hissing of a fluted Georgian urn. Two globe-shaped china dishes were brought in by a page. Dorian Gray went over and poured out the tea. The two men sauntered languidly to the table and examined what was under the covers.
vi: There was a knock on the door, the butler entered with a heavy tray of tea and placed it on the small Japanese table. There was the clinking of cups and the whistling of the antique George-era grooved teapot. Two spherical porcelain bowls were brought in by a young servant. Dorian Gray approached and poured the tea. The two of them wandered closer to the table and looked to see what was under the lid.
tr: There was a knock at the door, the servant entered with a full tea tray in his hand, and placed the tray on a small Japanese table. There was the clinking of a cup and saucer, and the whistle of an antique grooved teapot was heard. A young servant's assistant brought two porcelain plates. They had dome-shaped covers on them. Dorian took his place at the tray and poured the tea. The two men approached the table with lazy steps and looked at what was under the covers.
es: The door was heard knocking, the butler entered with the tea tray and placed it on a Japanese table. The clinking of cups and saucers and the whistle of a Georgian teapot were heard. A page entered carrying two globe-shaped dishes. Dorian Gray approached the table and served the tea. The other two approached languidly and examined what was under the covers.

en: “Let us go to the theatre to-night,” said Lord Henry. “There is sure to be something on, somewhere. I have promised to dine at White’s, but it is only with an old friend, so I can send him a wire to say that I am ill, or that I am prevented from coming in consequence of a subsequent engagement. I think that would be a rather nice excuse: it would have all the surprise of candour.”
vi: “Let's go watch a play tonight,” Lord Henry said. “There must be something showing, somewhere. I had promised to have dinner at White's, but it's just with an old friend, so I can send him a telegram saying that I'm ill, or that I'm prevented from coming due to a later invitation. I think that would be a rather good excuse: it will have all the straightforward surprise.”
tr: Lord Henry said, "Let's go to the theater tonight." "There must be something going on somewhere. I have a dinner appointment at White's with a very old friend. I'll tell him that I'm sick or that something came up. It would be very pleasant to offer such an excuse, I think: It creates the surprise of candor."
es: —Let's go to the theater tonight —proposed Lord Henry—. There will be something to see somewhere. I have a dinner appointment at White's, but it's just with an old friend, so I can send him a telegram saying that I'm sick or that I can't go due to a prior commitment. I think it would be a rather nice excuse, as it would come with the surprise of sincerity.

en: “It is such a bore putting on one’s dress-clothes,” muttered Hallward. “And, when one has them on, they are so horrid.”
vi: “It is really tedious to have to wear formal attire,” Hallward muttered. “And, when people put them on, they look so dreadful.”
tr: Hallward grumbled, "Wearing formal attire is so annoying!" "And it looks so bad when you put it on."
es: —It's so boring to dress formally! —murmured Hallward—. And, once you've done it, you look so awful!

en: “Yes,” answered Lord Henry dreamily, “the costume of the nineteenth century is detestable. It is so sombre, so depressing. Sin is the only real colour-element left in modern life.”
vi: “That's right,” Lord Henry said dreamily, “nineteenth-century clothing is truly disgusting. It is too gloomy, too dreary. Sin is the only real color left in modern life.”
tr: Lord Henry replied absentmindedly, "Yes." "The attire of the nineteenth century is truly disgusting. So dreary, so gloomy! The only thing that adds color to today's life is sin."
es: —Yes —replied Lord Henry distractedly—, the clothing of the 19th century is detestable. So gloomy, so depressing. Sin is the only element of color left in modern life.

en: “You really must not say things like that before Dorian, Harry.”
vi: "You really shouldn't say things like that in front of Dorian, Harry."
tr: “Harry, you shouldn't talk like that in front of Dorian, I'm serious.”
es: —You shouldn't say things like that in front of Dorian, Harry.

en: “Before which Dorian? The one who is pouring out tea for us, or the one in the picture?”
vi: “Which Dorian are you talking about? The one pouring tea for us, or the one in the painting?”
tr: “In front of which Dorian? The one who served our tea, or the one in the portrait?”
es: —In front of which Dorian? The one serving us tea or the one in the painting?

en: “Before either.”
vi: "In front of both of them."
tr: "Both of them.""
es: —Neither of them.

en: “I should like to come to the theatre with you, Lord Henry,” said the lad.
vi: “I would like to go see the play with you, Lord Henry,” the young man said.
tr: The young man said, "I want to go to the theater with you, Lord Henry."
es: —I would like to go to the theater with you, Lord Henry —said the boy.

en: “Then you shall come; and you will come, too, Basil, won’t you?”
vi: “Then you just go; and you will go too, Basil, won't you?”
tr: “Come then. You will come too, won't you, Basil?”
es: —Come, then; and you too, Basil.

en: “I can’t, really. I would sooner not. I have a lot of work to do.”
vi: “I really can't. I prefer staying at home. I have too much work to do.”
tr: “Believe me, I can't come. I don't feel like it. I have a lot of work.”
es: —The truth is that I can't. It would be better not to. I have a lot of work.

en: “Well, then, you and I will go alone, Mr. Gray.”
vi: “Is that so? Then you and I will go separately, Mr. Gray.”
tr: "Well then. You and I are going alone, Mr. Gray."
es: —Well; in that case, you and I will go, Mr. Gray.

en: “I should like that awfully.”
vi: “I like it extremely.”
tr: "I would be so happy!""
es: —Delighted.

en: The painter bit his lip and walked over, cup in hand, to the picture. “I shall stay with the real Dorian,” he said, sadly.
vi: The painter bit his lip and walked, with a cup in hand, towards the painting. "I will stay with Dorian indeed," he said, sorrowfully.
tr: The painter, biting his lip, went to the painting with a tea glass in his hand. In a sad voice, he said, "I am also staying with the real Dorian Gray."
es: The painter bit his lip and, with the cup in his hand, approached the painting. —I will stay with the real Dorian —he said sadly.

en: “Is it the real Dorian?” cried the original of the portrait, strolling across to him. “Am I really like that?”
vi: “Is that really Dorian?” the original of the portrait exclaimed, strolling past him. “Do I really look like that?”
tr: The model for the portrait walked towards the painter, asking, "Is this the real Dorian Gray?" "Is this really how I am?"
es: —Is that the real Dorian? —exclaimed the original of the portrait, approaching Hallward—. Am I really like that?

en: “Yes; you are just like that.”
vi: “Yes; you look exactly like that.”
tr: “Yes, you are just like this.”
es: —Yes; exactly like that.

en: “How wonderful, Basil!”
vi: "Wonderful, Basil!"
tr: "This is wonderful, Basil!"
es: —Marvelous, Basil!

en: “At least you are like it in appearance. But it will never alter,” sighed Hallward. “That is something.”
vi: "At least you resemble it on the outside. But it will never change," Hallward sighed. "That's what makes it precious."
tr: Hallward, "So this is how you look. And this picture will never change," he sighed. "That's something."
es: —You at least look the same. But he won't change —sighed Hallward—. That's something.

en: “What a fuss people make about fidelity!” exclaimed Lord Henry. “Why, even in love it is purely a question for physiology. It has nothing to do with our own will. Young men want to be faithful, and are not; old men want to be faithless, and cannot: that is all one can say.”
vi: “People make too much of loyalty!” “Why, even in love, it is merely a matter of physiology. It has nothing to do with our will. The young want to be faithful but can't; the old want to be unfaithful but can't: that's all there is to say.”
tr: Lord Henry murmured, "How people exaggerate the matter of loyalty!" "Even love is merely a physiological issue. It has nothing to do with our own will. Young people want to be faithful, but they cannot; old people want to be unfaithful, but they cannot. That's all there is to say."
es: —What an obsession people have with fidelity! —exclaimed Lord Henry—. Even love is simply a matter of physiology. It has nothing to do with the will. Young people want to be faithful and are not; old people want to be unfaithful and cannot: that is all there is to say.

en: “Don’t go to the theatre to-night, Dorian,” said Hallward. “Stop and dine with me.”
vi: “Don't go to the theater tonight, Dorian,” Hallward said. “Stay and have dinner with me.”
tr: “Dorian, don't go to the theater tonight,” said Hallward. “Stay and have dinner with me.”
es: —Don't go to the theater tonight, Dorian —said Hallward—. Stay and have dinner with me.

en: “I can’t, Basil.”
vi: "I can't, Basil."
tr: “My pen, Basil.””
es: —I can't, Basil.

en: “Why?”
vi: "Why?"
tr: “Why?”
es: —Why not?

en: “Because I have promised Lord Henry Wotton to go with him.”
vi: “Because I promised Lord Henry Wotton that I would go with him.”
tr: “I promised to go with Lord Henry Wotton, that's why.”
es: —Because I have promised Lord Henry Wotton to go with him.

en: “He won’t like you the better for keeping your promises. He always breaks his own. I beg you not to go.”
vi: "He doesn't like you more because you keep your promises. He always breaks his promises. I beg you not to go."
tr: “She won't love you more just because you kept your word. She always breaks her promises. I beg you, don't go.”
es: —His opinion of you won't improve just because you keep your promises. He always breaks his. I beg you not to go.

en: Dorian Gray laughed and shook his head.
vi: Dorian Gray smiled and shook his head.
tr: Dorian Gray shook his head with a laugh, indicating no.
es: Dorian Gray laughed and shook his head.

en: “I entreat you.”
vi: “I beg you.”
tr: “I am pleading from the heart.”
es: —I beg you.

en: The lad hesitated, and looked over at Lord Henry, who was watching them from the tea-table with an amused smile.
vi: The young man hesitated and glanced at Lord Henry, who was watching them from the tea table with a delighted smile.
tr: The young man hesitated; he looked at Lord Henry, who was watching them from the head of the tea table with a sly smile.
es: The boy hesitated and looked towards Lord Henry, who was watching them from the tea table with an amused smile.

en: “I must go, Basil,” he answered.
vi: “I have to go, Basil,” he replied.
tr: "I must go, Basil.""
es: —I have to go, Basil —replied the young man.

en: “Very well,” said Hallward, and he went over and laid down his cup on the tray. “It is rather late, and, as you have to dress, you had better lose no time. Good-bye, Harry. Good-bye, Dorian. Come and see me soon. Come to-morrow.”
vi: “Alright,” Hallward said; then he approached and placed the cup on the tray. “It's quite late, and since you have to change clothes, it's best not to waste any more time. Goodbye, Harry. Goodbye, Dorian. Come see me soon. Come tomorrow.”
tr: “Well, then,” said Hallward. He went and placed the teacup on the tray. “It's getting late; since you still have to change your outfit, it would be best not to waste too much time. Goodbye, Harry. Goodbye, Dorian. Do come again; don't take too long. Come tomorrow.”
es: —Very well —said Hallward; and, stepping away, he placed his cup on the tray—. It is quite late and, since you have to get dressed, it would be best if you didn't waste any more time. Goodbye, Harry. Goodbye, Dorian. Come see me soon. Tomorrow.

en: “Certainly.”
vi: "Of course."
tr: “There there.”
es: —Of course.

en: “You won’t forget?”
vi: “You won't forget, right?”
tr: “You won't forget, right?”
es: —Will you not forget it?

en: “No, of course not,” cried Dorian.
vi: “No, of course not,” Dorian exclaimed.
tr: Dorian replied, "What do you mean, of course I won't forget."
es: —No, of course not! —exclaimed Dorian.

en: “And ... Harry!”
vi: "Ah... Harry!"
tr: "You too, Harry..."
es: —And..., Harry!

en: “Yes, Basil?”
vi: "Yes, Basil?"
tr: "Sir, Basil?"
es: —Yes, Basil?

en: “Remember what I asked you, when we were in the garden this morning.”
vi: "Remember what I asked you, when we were in the garden this morning."
tr: "Don't forget the thing I asked of you in the garden this morning.""
es: —Remember what I asked you when we were in the garden this morning.

en: “I have forgotten it.”
vi: “I have already forgotten.”
tr: "I forgot, it's gone.""
es: —I have forgotten it.

en: “I trust you.”
vi: "I believe you."
tr: "I trust you."
es: —I trust you.

en: “I wish I could trust myself,” said Lord Henry, laughing. “Come, Mr. Gray, my hansom is outside, and I can drop you at your own place. Good-bye, Basil. It has been a most interesting afternoon.”
vi: “I wish I could trust myself,” Lord Henry said with a laugh. “Now, Mr. Gray, my hansom cab is outside, and I can drop you off at your place. Goodbye, Basil. It has been an extremely delightful afternoon.”
tr: Lord Henry said, "I wish I could trust myself!" laughing. "Come on, Mr. Gray, my carriage is outside. I can take you home. Goodbye, Basil. We had a very interesting afternoon, indeed."
es: —I wish I could trust myself —said Lord Henry, laughing—. Come on, Mr. Gray, my carriage is outside, I can take you home. Goodbye, Basil. It has been a very interesting afternoon.

en: As the door closed behind them, the painter flung himself down on a sofa, and a look of pain came into his face.
vi: When the door closed behind them, the artist sank onto the sofa, and a look of pain appeared on his face.
tr: When the door closed behind the guests, the painter let himself fall onto a couch, a pained expression appearing on his face.
es: When the door closed behind them, the painter let himself fall onto a sofa, and an expression of suffering appeared on his face.

en: CHAPTER III.
vi: Chapter 3
tr: Third chapter
es: Chapter 3

en: At half-past twelve next day Lord Henry Wotton strolled from Curzon Street over to the Albany to call on his uncle, Lord Fermor, a genial if somewhat rough-mannered old bachelor, whom the outside world called selfish because it derived no particular benefit from him, but who was considered generous by Society as he fed the people who amused him. His father had been our ambassador at Madrid when Isabella was young and Prim unthought of, but had retired from the diplomatic service in a capricious moment of annoyance on not being offered the Embassy at Paris, a post to which he considered that he was fully entitled by reason of his birth, his indolence, the good English of his dispatches, and his inordinate passion for pleasure. The son, who had been his father’s secretary, had resigned along with his chief, somewhat foolishly as was thought at the time, and on succeeding some months later to the title, had set himself to the serious study of the great aristocratic art of doing absolutely nothing. He had two large town houses, but preferred to live in chambers as it was less trouble, and took most of his meals at his club. He paid some attention to the management of his collieries in the Midland counties, excusing himself for this taint of industry on the ground that the one advantage of having coal was that it enabled a gentleman to afford the decency of burning wood on his own hearth. In politics he was a Tory, except when the Tories were in office, during which period he roundly abused them for being a pack of Radicals. He was a hero to his valet, who bullied him, and a terror to most of his relations, whom he bullied in turn. Only England could have produced him, and he always said that the country was going to the dogs. His principles were out of date, but there was a good deal to be said for his prejudices.
vi: At half-past twelve the next day, Lord Henry Wotton leisurely walked from Curzon Street through Albany to visit his uncle, Lord Fermor, a cheerful old bachelor despite his somewhat rude manners. The outside world considered him selfish because they couldn't gain any exceptional benefits from him, but the upper class viewed him as very generous because he supported those who entertained him. His father had been our ambassador in Madrid when Isabella was young, and Prim was not yet thought of, but he had left the diplomatic service in a fit of pique over not being invited to be the ambassador in Paris, a position he believed he was entirely entitled to because of his lineage, his laziness, his perfect English in his dispatches, and his excessive passion for pleasure. The son, who had been his father's secretary, also resigned along with his boss, a move that was considered somewhat foolish at the time, and when he inherited the title a few months later, he devoted himself to the serious study of the great aristocratic art of doing absolutely nothing. He had two large houses in town but preferred to live in a furnished bachelor apartment to avoid inconvenience and mostly dined at his club. He also paid some attention to managing his coal mines in the Midlands, justifying this industrial stain on the grounds that one advantage of having coal was that it allowed a gentleman to afford to burn wood in his fireplace. In politics, he was a Conservative, except when the Conservatives were in power, during which time he openly insulted them for turning into Radicals. He was a hero to his valet, who bullied him, and a terror to most of his relatives, whom he bullied in turn. Only England could have produced him, and he always said that the country was going to the dogs. His principles were outdated, but there was much to be said in favor of his prejudices.
tr: The next day at half-past twelve, Lord Henry Wotton left Curzon Street and headed towards the Albany Hotel to visit his uncle, Lord Fermor. The world, which could not derive any benefit from Lord Fermor, who was a cheerful, talkative, and friendly old man despite some of his blunt behaviors, accused him of selfishness. However, society considered him generous because Lord Fermor would feed those who entertained him. His father had been the Ambassador to Madrid during Isabella's youth, long before Prim was even thought of, but he had quit the diplomatic profession in a fit of anger when he was not made Ambassador to Paris. Lord Fermor believed he fully deserved this position due to his lineage, mischief, the reports he prepared, his eloquence, and his excessive love of pleasure and luxury. His son, who was acting as his secretary, had also submitted his resignation along with him. It was thought that he had been a bit foolish at the time. A few months later, the new Lord Fermor, who inherited his father's title, dedicated himself to seriously studying that magnificent art of aristocracy, namely the art of doing absolutely nothing. He had two huge houses in the city, but preferred to stay in a hotel suite because it was less troublesome, and usually had his meals there as well. He took a slight interest in managing the coal mines he owned around the Midlands, and to excuse the stain on his honor for making this effort, he would say, "There is only one benefit of coal: it provides the upper class with the privilege of burning wood in their own fireplaces!" Politically, he was a Tory, except when the Tories were in power. During such times, Lord Fermor would denounce them as a "pack of Radicals" and condemn them vehemently. In the eyes of his personal valet, who managed him with an overbearing authority, Lord Fermor was a hero, while to his relatives, whom he managed with the same overbearing authority, he was a tyrant. Only England could have produced him, and he was always saying that the country was going to the dogs. His principles might have been somewhat outdated, but there was no denying his prejudices.
es: At half past twelve the next day, Lord Henry Wotton walked from Curzon Street to Albany to visit his uncle, Lord Fermor, an old bachelor, cordial but somewhat brusque, who was generally considered selfish because the world gained no benefit from him, but whom good society deemed generous because he fed people who amused him. His father had been an ambassador in Madrid when Isabel II was young and no one had yet thought of General Prim, but he capriciously abandoned his diplomatic career out of spite when he saw that he was not offered the embassy in Paris, a position he believed he had full right to due to his birth, his indolence, the excellent English of his dispatches, and his excessive passion for pleasures. The son, who had been his father's secretary and who also resigned, a gesture that was considered somewhat reckless at the time, succeeded his father in the title a few months later, and dedicated himself seriously to cultivating the great aristocratic art of doing absolutely nothing.
