Although he owned two large houses in London, he preferred to live in rented rooms, which caused him fewer inconveniences, and he took most of his meals at his club. He was somewhat concerned with the management of his coal mines in the Midlands, and excused that contact with industry by claiming that owning coal mines granted a gentleman the privilege of burning wood in his own fireplace. In politics, he was a conservative, except when the conservatives were in power, at which time he systematically insulted them, accusing them of being a bunch of radicals. He was a hero to his valet, who tyrannized him, and a terrifying figure to most of his relatives, whom he, in turn, tyrannized. He was a person who could only have been born in England, and he always claimed that the country was going to ruin. His principles were outdated, but much could be said in favor of his prejudices.

en: When Lord Henry entered the room, he found his uncle sitting in a rough shooting-coat, smoking a cheroot and grumbling over The Times. “Well, Harry,” said the old gentleman, “what brings you out so early? I thought you dandies never got up till two, and were not visible till five.”
vi: When Lord Henry entered the room, he saw his uncle sitting, wearing a coarse hunting jacket, smoking a cigar cut at both ends, and grumbling over The Times, "Ah, Harry," the old man said, "what brings you out so early? I thought you dandies never got up before two and never appeared before five."
tr: When Lord Henry entered, he found his uncle grumbling while reading the Times newspaper, puffing on a leaf cigar, and wearing a sports jacket. "Well, Harry," said the old man. "What are you doing here so early? I thought you high-society fops wouldn't get out of bed before two and wouldn't show your faces before five."
es: When Lord Henry entered his uncle's room, he found him dressed in a coarse hunting jacket, smoking a Havana cigar, and grumbling while reading The Times. —Well, Harry —said the elderly gentleman—, what has made you leave the house so early? I thought dandies didn't get up until two and didn't appear in public until five.

en: “Pure family affection, I assure you, Uncle George. I want to get something out of you.”
vi: “It's just pure family affection, I assure you of that, Uncle George.” “I want to ask you for this favor.”
tr: “Believe me, Uncle George, it is purely familial love that brought me here. I want to get something from you!”
es: —Pure familial affection, Uncle George, I assure you. I want to ask you something.

en: “Money, I suppose,” said Lord Fermor, making a wry face. “Well, sit down and tell me all about it. Young people, nowadays, imagine that money is everything.”
vi: "Money, you think so," Lord Fermor said, making a face. "Now, sit down and tell me all about it. Young people today think money is everything."
tr: Lord Fermor grimaced, "It must be about money," he said. "Anyway, sit down and tell me about it. Young people these days think that money is everything in life."
es: —Money, I imagine —responded Lord Fermor, twisting his expression—. Well; sit down and tell me everything. These days, young people imagine that money is everything.

en: “Yes,” murmured Lord Henry, settling his button-hole in his coat; “and when they grow older they know it. But I don’t want money. It is only people who pay their bills who want that, Uncle George, and I never pay mine. Credit is the capital of a younger son, and one lives charmingly upon it. Besides, I always deal with Dartmoor’s tradesmen, and consequently they never bother me. What I want is information: not useful information, of course; useless information.”
vi: “Yes,” Lord Henry whispered, adjusting the flower in his buttonhole; “and when they grow old, they know it is true. But you don't need money. Only those who have bills to pay need it, Uncle George, and I never have to pay mine. Credit is the capital of the second son, and he lives comfortably on it. Besides, I always deal with the merchants of Dartmoor, so they never bother me. What I want is information; not useful information, of course; but useless information.”
tr: Lord Henry murmured, "Yes." "They know this to be true even when they grow old. However, what I want is not money. Only those who pay their debts want money, dear Uncle George, whereas I never pay my debts. The capital of the younger sons of nobles is credit, and one can live quite pleasantly with this credit. Besides, I always do business with the Dartmoor tradesmen, so they never bother me. No, what I want is knowledge. Not useful knowledge, of course, but useless knowledge."
es: —Yes —murmured Lord Henry, adjusting the flower in his jacket's buttonhole—; and when they grow old, they don't imagine it: they know it. But I don't want money. Only people who pay their bills need money, Uncle George, and I never pay mine. Credit is the capital of a second son, and one lives pleasantly with it. Besides, I always deal with the suppliers from Dartmoor and, consequently, they never bother me. What I want is information: not useful information, of course; perfectly useless information.

en: “Well, I can tell you anything that is in an English Blue Book, Harry, although those fellows nowadays write a lot of nonsense. When I was in the Diplomatic, things were much better. But I hear they let them in now by examination. What can you expect? Examinations, sir, are pure humbug from beginning to end. If a man is a gentleman, he knows quite enough, and if he is not a gentleman, whatever he knows is bad for him.”
vi: "Yes, I can tell you everything in the British Blue Book, Harry, although these days they write a lot of nonsense. When I was in the diplomatic service, things were much better. But I hear now they let them in through exams. What else can you expect? Exams, my boy, are just a fraud from start to finish. If a man is a gentleman, he will know enough, and if he is not a gentleman, then all he knows will only harm him."
tr: "Well, Harry, I can relay to you any information you want from the Blue Book of England. Although, nowadays, the guys who write it have gone crazy. When I was in the diplomatic service, things were more orderly. But now, from what I hear, they even hire people there through exams. That thing called an exam, my friend, is nonsense from start to finish. If a person is a gentleman from the polite society, what he knows is more than enough for him. If he's not a gentleman, everything he knows is harmful to him."
es: —I can tell you everything that any official report contains, although those who write them nowadays write a lot of nonsense. When I was in the diplomatic corps, things were much better. But, as I understand it, now they have to take an entrance exam. Should we be surprised at the result? Exams, my dear sir, are pure lies from beginning to end. If a person is a gentleman, he knows more than enough, and if he is not, everything he knows is bad for him.

en: “Mr. Dorian Gray does not belong to Blue Books, Uncle George,” said Lord Henry languidly.
vi: "Mr. Dorian Gray has nothing to do with the Blue Book, Uncle George," Lord Henry said languidly.
tr: Lord Henry said in his lazy voice, "Mr. Dorian Gray has no place in the Blue Book, Uncle George."
es: —Mr. Dorian Gray has nothing to do with the world of official reports, Uncle George —said Lord Henry languidly.

en: “Mr. Dorian Gray? Who is he?” asked Lord Fermor, knitting his bushy white eyebrows.
vi: “Mr. Dorian Gray? Who is he?” Lord Fermor asked, furrowing his thick white eyebrows.
tr: Lord Fermor furrowed his bushy white eyebrows and asked, "Dorian Gray?" "Who is he?"
es: —Mr. Dorian Gray? Who is he? —asked Lord Fermor, furrowing his thick gray brow.

en: “That is what I have come to learn, Uncle George. Or rather, I know who he is. He is the last Lord Kelso’s grandson. His mother was a Devereux, Lady Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about his mother. What was she like? Whom did she marry? You have known nearly everybody in your time, so you might have known her. I am very much interested in Mr. Gray at present. I have only just met him.”
vi: “That is what I came to hear, Uncle George. Or rather, I already know who he is. He is the grandson of the last Lord Kelso. His mother was a Devereux; Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about his mother. What was she like? Whom did she marry? You know almost everyone of that time, so you might know her. At present, I am very interested in Mr. Gray. I have just met him.
tr: "That's exactly what I came to learn, Uncle George. Or rather, I don't know who he is. The grandson of the late Lord Kelso. His mother was from the Devereux family, Lady Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about her. What kind of woman was she? Whom did she marry? You've known almost everyone in your time; perhaps you knew her too. I'm currently very interested in Mr. Gray. We just met recently."
es: —That is what I have come to find out, Uncle George. I should rather say, I know who he is. He is the grandson of the last Lord Kelso. His mother was a Devereux, Lady Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about his mother. What was she like? Whom did she marry? You practically dealt with everyone in your time, so perhaps you knew her. At the present moment, I am very interested in Mr. Gray. He has just been introduced to me.

en: “Kelso’s grandson!” echoed the old gentleman. “Kelso’s grandson! ... Of course.... I knew his mother intimately. I believe I was at her christening. She was an extraordinarily beautiful girl, Margaret Devereux, and made all the men frantic by running away with a penniless young fellow—a mere nobody, sir, a subaltern in a foot regiment, or something of that kind. Certainly. I remember the whole thing as if it happened yesterday. The poor chap was killed in a duel at Spa a few months after the marriage. There was an ugly story about it. They said Kelso got some rascally adventurer, some Belgian brute, to insult his son-in-law in public—paid him, sir, to do it, paid him—and that the fellow spitted his man as if he had been a pigeon. The thing was hushed up, but, egad, Kelso ate his chop alone at the club for some time afterwards. He brought his daughter back with him, I was told, and she never spoke to him again. Oh, yes; it was a bad business. The girl died, too, died within a year. So she left a son, did she? I had forgotten that. What sort of boy is he? If he is like his mother, he must be a good-looking chap.”
vi: “Kelso's grandson!” the old man repeated — “Kelso's grandson!… That's right… I knew his mother very well. I believe I attended her baptism. She was a beautiful woman, Margaret Devereux; and she drove all the men crazy by eloping with a penniless young man; a nobody, my dear, a lieutenant in the infantry regiment, or something like that. Absolutely. I remember the whole thing as if it happened yesterday. The poor young man was killed in a duel at Spa, a few months after the wedding. There's a dreadful story about it. They say Kelso hired some thug, a brutal Belgian, to insult his son-in-law in public; paid him, my dear, to do it, paid him; and that fellow skewered his victim as if he were a pigeon. The matter was hushed up, but, oh dear, Kelso ate his chops alone at the club for quite a long time afterward. He took his daughter back, I heard, and she never spoke to him again. Yes, indeed; it was a very bad business. The girl died too; died within a year. So she left a son, did she? I had forgotten that. What sort of boy is he? If he takes after his mother, he must be a very handsome young man.”
tr: The old Lord repeated his nephew's words, "Kelso's grandson!" "Kelso's grandson!.. Of course... I knew his mother very well. I was present at her christening, if I'm not mistaken. She was an extraordinarily beautiful girl, this Margaret Devereux. Then she eloped with a penniless young man, driving all her admirers crazy. The young man she eloped with was a nobody, sir, a sergeant in an infantry regiment or something like that. Of course. It's all as clear as if it were yesterday. Poor boy, he died in a duel in Spa a few months after the wedding. There was an ugly rumor about it. They said Kelso had hired a lowlife to insult his son-in-law in public. The guy was a Belgian brute. Apparently, Kelso paid this guy; literally paid him, and the Belgian shot his prey like a sitting duck. The incident was covered up, sir, but after that, no one at the club would go near Kelso. I heard he brought his daughter back, but she never spoke to him again. Yes, it was a dirty business, to be honest. The girl died too, within a year she was dead. So she left behind a son? I had forgotten that. What does the boy look like? If he looks like his mother, he must be handsome.”
es: —Grandson of Kelso! —repeated the elderly gentleman—. The grandson of Kelso... Of course... I knew his mother very well. I believe I attended his christening. She was an extraordinarily beautiful young woman, Margaret Devereux, and she drove everyone mad by running off with a young man who didn't have a penny, a nobody, sir, a non-commissioned infantry officer or something like that. Indeed. I remember it all as if it had happened yesterday. The poor fellow was killed in a duel in Spa a few months after the wedding. A very ugly story. They said Kelso hired an unscrupulous adventurer, a Belgian brute, to publicly insult his son-in-law; he paid him, sir, to do it; he paid him and then that individual skewered the non-commissioned officer like a pigeon. They covered up the matter, but, good heavens, Kelso dined alone at the club for some time after that. He took his daughter in, so I was told, but the girl never spoke to him again. Yes, yes, a very ugly affair. Margaret also died, in less than a year. So she left a son, didn't she? I had forgotten. What is the boy like? If he is like his mother, he must be quite handsome.

en: “He is very good-looking,” assented Lord Henry.
vi: “He is very beautiful,” Lord Henry agreed.
tr: Lord Henry, "Very handsome," he confirmed his uncle.
es: —He is quite handsome —agreed Lord Henry.

en: “I hope he will fall into proper hands,” continued the old man. “He should have a pot of money waiting for him if Kelso did the right thing by him. His mother had money, too. All the Selby property came to her, through her grandfather. Her grandfather hated Kelso, thought him a mean dog. He was, too. Came to Madrid once when I was there. Egad, I was ashamed of him. The Queen used to ask me about the English noble who was always quarrelling with the cabmen about their fares. They made quite a story of it. I didn’t dare show my face at Court for a month. I hope he treated his grandson better than he did the jarvies.”
vi: “I hope it falls into the right hands,” the old man continued. “It would have had a pile of money waiting if Kelso had done the right thing for it. Its mother also has money. All the Selby family assets were transferred to her, through her grandfather. Her grandfather hated Kelso, thought he was a despicable scoundrel. He was just the same. Came to Madrid once while I was there. Oh my, I was so embarrassed by him. The Queen often asked me about an English nobleman who frequently argued with the coachmen over fares. They made up a whole story about that incident. I didn't dare show my face at the Palace for a whole month. I hope he treats his grandchild better than he treated those hired drivers.”
tr: The old Lord continued, "I hope he falls into the right hands," he said. "If Kelso has done what is necessary, the child should come into a pot of money. His mother was wealthy too. She had inherited all the Selbys' property from her grandfather. This grandfather hated Kelso, called him a treacherous animal. And indeed he was. He had come to Madrid once, while I was there. He had humiliated me. The Queen would always ask me about the English nobleman who got into fights with the coachmen over fares. The coachmen would embellish the stories. I couldn't show my face at the palace for a whole month. I hope he didn't do to his grandson what he did to the coachmen."
es: —I hope it falls into good hands —continued the old man—. He will inherit a lot of money if Kelso has treated him well. His mother also had money. She received all the Selby properties through her grandfather. His grandfather hated Kelso, he considered him a very stingy man. And he was not wrong. He went to Madrid once when I was there. Good heavens, he made me ashamed of him. The queen asked me who the English nobleman was who always argued with the coachmen over the fare. What a story. I spent a month without appearing at the Court. I trust he treated his grandson better than the hired coachmen.

en: “I don’t know,” answered Lord Henry. “I fancy that the boy will be well off. He is not of age yet. He has Selby, I know. He told me so. And ... his mother was very beautiful?”
vi: “I don't know,” Lord Henry replied. “I suppose that boy will be very rich. He is not of age yet. He will inherit Selby, you know. He told me so. And… his mother is very beautiful, isn't she?”
tr: “I don't know,” said Lord Henry. “I don't think the child will be left without money. He hasn't even reached adolescence yet. Selby is looking after him. I know, he told me himself. So... His mother was very beautiful, huh?”
es: —I don't know —responded Lord Henry—. I imagine the boy will want for nothing. He is still not of age. I know Selby is his: I know because he told me so. And... was his mother very beautiful then?

en: “Margaret Devereux was one of the loveliest creatures I ever saw, Harry. What on earth induced her to behave as she did, I never could understand. She could have married anybody she chose. Carlington was mad after her. She was romantic, though. All the women of that family were. The men were a poor lot, but, egad! the women were wonderful. Carlington went on his knees to her. Told me so himself. She laughed at him, and there wasn’t a girl in London at the time who wasn’t after him. And by the way, Harry, talking about silly marriages, what is this humbug your father tells me about Dartmoor wanting to marry an American? Ain’t English girls good enough for him?”
vi: “Margaret Devereux was one of the most delightful creatures I have ever seen, Harry. What on earth could have induced her to behave as she did, I can never understand. She could have married anyone she chose. Carlington was madly in love with her. She was dreamy, that's it. All the women in that family are. The men are a poor lot, but, my God! the women are wonderful. Carlington crawled on his knees to her. He himself told me so. She laughed at him, yet there wasn't a girl in London at that time who wouldn't have pursued him. By the way, Harry, speaking of foolish marriages, what is this nonsense your father told me about Dartmoor wanting to marry an American? Isn't an English girl good enough for him?”
tr: “Harry, Margaret Devereux was one of the most beautiful creatures I have ever seen. What possessed her to get involved in such things, I will never know. She could have married anyone she wanted. Carlington was madly in love with her. But the girl was romantic. All the women in that family were romantic. The men were useless, but the women were truly magnificent! Carlington had knelt down and begged Margaret, he himself told me. Margaret just laughed it off, even though at that time every girl in London was after Carlington. Oh, now that I remember, Harry... We were talking about unsuitable marriages... From what I heard from your father, Dartmoor wants to marry some American, what is this scandal? What’s wrong with English girls?”
es: —Margaret Devereux was one of the most charming creatures I have ever seen, Harry. What drove her to behave as she did is something I will never understand. She could have married anyone she wanted. Carlington was madly in love with her. But she was a romantic. All the women in that family have been. The men were worthless, but, good heavens, the women were wonderful. Carlington proposed on his knees. He told me so himself. Margaret Devereux laughed at him, and there wasn't a girl in London at the time who didn't want to catch him. And, by the way, Harry, speaking of foolish marriages, what is that nonsense your father tells me about Dartmoor wanting to marry an American? Are English girls not good enough for him?

en: “It is rather fashionable to marry Americans just now, Uncle George.”
vi: “Marrying an American is quite fashionable nowadays, Uncle George.”
tr: "Uncle George, marrying Americans has become a bit of a trend these days.""
es: —Now it's quite fashionable to marry American women, Uncle George.

en: “I’ll back English women against the world, Harry,” said Lord Fermor, striking the table with his fist.
vi: “I would bet on English women against the whole world, Harry,” Lord Fermor said, pounding his fist on the table.
tr: Lord Fermor slammed his fist on the table and said, "Harry, I think English women are one thing, and the world is another."
es: —I support English women against the whole world, Harry —said Lord Fermor, hitting the table with his fist.

en: “The betting is on the Americans.”
vi: “The bets are pouring in on the American women's side.”
tr: “But Americans are favorites.”
es: —Everyone bets on the Americans.

en: “They don’t last, I am told,” muttered his uncle.
vi: “They won't last, I heard,” he grumbled.
tr: “I hear they are not durable,””
es: —They don't last, so I've been told —murmured his uncle.

en: “A long engagement exhausts them, but they are capital at a steeplechase. They take things flying. I don’t think Dartmoor has a chance.”
vi: “The long-term binding exhausts them, but they excel in the steeplechase. They soar over the obstacles. I don't think Dartmoor stands a chance.”
tr: "If the match lasts long, they get tired and exhausted, but when it comes to straight running, there's no one better than them. It's as if they're flying! I don't give Dartmoor any chance at all."
es: —Long-distance races wear them out, but they are unmatched in obstacle races. They jump over everything without blinking. I don't think Dartmoor has the slightest chance.

en: “Who are her people?” grumbled the old gentleman. “Has she got any?”
vi: "Who is her family?" the old man grumbled. "Does she have anyone?"
tr: The old Lord grumbled, "Who are his family?" he asked. "Or rather, does he even have a family?"
es: —Who are your parents? —grumbled the old man—. Do you even have any?

en: Lord Henry shook his head. “American girls are as clever at concealing their parents, as English women are at concealing their past,” he said, rising to go.
vi: Lord Henry shook his head. "American girls are just as good at hiding things from their parents as English women are at hiding their past," he said as he stood up to leave.
tr: Lord Henry nodded his head. “While English women are adept at hiding their pasts, American girls are equally cunning at hiding their parents,” he said, standing up to leave.
es: Lord Henry shook his head. —American young women are as clever at hiding things from their parents as English women are at concealing their past —said Lord Henry, getting up to leave.

en: “They are pork-packers, I suppose?”
vi: “They are pork traders, don't you think so?”
tr: “They must be working at a pig slaughterhouse or something, isn't that right?”
es: —They must be butchers, I suppose.

en: “I hope so, Uncle George, for Dartmoor’s sake. I am told that pork-packing is the most lucrative profession in America, after politics.”
vi: “I hope so, Uncle George, for the sake of Dartmoor. I've heard that pork trading is the most profitable business in America, second only to politics.”
tr: "I hope so, Uncle George, for Dartmoor's sake, I hope so." "They say that after politics, the most profitable profession in America is pig slaughtering.""
es: —I hope so, Uncle George, for Dartmoor's sake. They tell me that butchery is one of the most lucrative professions in the United States, after politics.

en: “Is she pretty?”
vi: “Is she pretty?”
tr: “Is the girl at least beautiful?”
es: —Is that girl pretty?

en: “She behaves as if she was beautiful. Most American women do. It is the secret of their charm.”
vi: “She acts as if she is very beautiful. Most American women do that. That is the secret of their charm.”
tr: "As if it's beautiful in the weather. Most American women are like this. The secret of their charm is this."
es: —She behaves as if she were beautiful. Most American women do. It's the secret of their charm.

en: “Why can’t these American women stay in their own country? They are always telling us that it is the paradise for women.”
vi: “Why can't those American women stay in their own country? They always tell us that it is a paradise for women.”
tr: “Can't these American women stay in their own country? They keep bragging that it's a paradise for women there.”
es: —Why don't they stay in their country? They are always telling us that it is a paradise for women.

en: “It is. That is the reason why, like Eve, they are so excessively anxious to get out of it,” said Lord Henry. “Good-bye, Uncle George. I shall be late for lunch, if I stop any longer. Thanks for giving me the information I wanted. I always like to know everything about my new friends, and nothing about my old ones.”
vi: “It is indeed so. That is why, like Eve, they are so eager to escape from it,” said Lord Henry. “Goodbye, Uncle George. I will be late for lunch if I stay any longer. Thank you for giving me the information I needed. I always want to know everything about new friends, and everything about old friends.”
tr: “America is really like that. And that's why American women, just like Eve, are eager to escape from there!” said Lord Henry. “Goodbye, Uncle George. If I linger a bit more, I'll be late for dinner. Thank you for giving me the information I wanted. I've always wanted to know everything about my new friends, but nothing about my old friends...”
es: —It is. That is the reason why, like Eve, they are so excessively anxious to leave it —said Lord Henry—. Goodbye, Uncle George. Thank you for giving me the information I wanted. I like to know everything about my new friends and nothing about the old ones.

en: “Where are you lunching, Harry?”
vi: "Where did you have lunch, Harry?"
tr: “Where do you eat, Harry?”
es: —Where are you having lunch today, Harry?

en: “At Aunt Agatha’s. I have asked myself and Mr. Gray. He is her latest protégé.”
vi: "At Aunt Agatha's place." "I requested for myself and Mr. Gray. He is her latest protégé." 1 Sponsored person.
tr: “Agatha is at my aunt's. I invited myself, and also Mr. Gray. Mr. Gray is my aunt's latest protégé.”
es: —At Aunt Agatha's house. I have arranged for her to invite me, along with Mr. Gray, who is her latest protégé.

en: “Humph! tell your Aunt Agatha, Harry, not to bother me any more with her charity appeals. I am sick of them. Why, the good woman thinks that I have nothing to do but to write cheques for her silly fads.”
vi: “Hmph! Tell your Aunt Agatha, Harry, not to bother me any more with her charity appeals. I'm sick of them. Why does that good woman think I have nothing better to do than write checks for her whimsical nonsense.”
tr: “Let them love! Harry, tell Aunt Agatha to stop bothering me with donation requests. I've had it up to here. Good grief, the poor woman thinks I have nothing better to do than write checks for her silly obsessions!”
es: —Hmm! Tell your Aunt Agatha, Harry, not to bother me anymore with her charitable enterprises. I'm fed up. Goodness, the good woman thinks I have nothing better to do than write checks for her stupid whims.

en: “All right, Uncle George, I’ll tell her, but it won’t have any effect. Philanthropic people lose all sense of humanity. It is their distinguishing characteristic.”
vi: “Alright, Uncle George, I will tell her, but it won't make any difference. Kind-hearted people often lose all sense of humanity. That is their most prominent characteristic.”
tr: “Well, uncle, I will tell them, but it will have no effect. People who are involved in charity work lose all their humanity. You can distinguish them by this characteristic.”
es: —Alright, Uncle George, I'll tell him, but it won't have any effect. Philanthropic people lose all sense of humanity. They are recognized by that.

en: The old gentleman growled approvingly and rang the bell for his servant. Lord Henry passed up the low arcade into Burlington Street and turned his steps in the direction of Berkeley Square.
vi: The old man muttered in agreement and rang the bell to call the servant. Lord Henry walked through the low-arched passage leading to Burlington Street, then turned towards Berkeley Square.
tr: The old Lord let out a grunt of approval and rang the bell to call his servant. Lord Henry passed under the low arch and stepped out onto Burlington Street, from where he directed his steps towards Berkeley Square.
es: The elderly gentleman grunted approvingly and called for his servant to come in. Lord Henry crossed some low arcades to reach Burlington Street, and made his way towards Berkeley Square.

en: So that was the story of Dorian Gray’s parentage. Crudely as it had been told to him, it had yet stirred him by its suggestion of a strange, almost modern romance. A beautiful woman risking everything for a mad passion. A few wild weeks of happiness cut short by a hideous, treacherous crime. Months of voiceless agony, and then a child born in pain. The mother snatched away by death, the boy left to solitude and the tyranny of an old and loveless man. Yes; it was an interesting background. It posed the lad, made him more perfect, as it were. Behind every exquisite thing that existed, there was something tragic. Worlds had to be in travail, that the meanest flower might blow.... And how charming he had been at dinner the night before, as with startled eyes and lips parted in frightened pleasure he had sat opposite to him at the club, the red candleshades staining to a richer rose the wakening wonder of his face. Talking to him was like playing upon an exquisite violin. He answered to every touch and thrill of the bow.... There was something terribly enthralling in the exercise of influence. No other activity was like it. To project one’s soul into some gracious form, and let it tarry there for a moment; to hear one’s own intellectual views echoed back to one with all the added music of passion and youth; to convey one’s temperament into another as though it were a subtle fluid or a strange perfume: there was a real joy in that—perhaps the most satisfying joy left to us in an age so limited and vulgar as our own, an age grossly carnal in its pleasures, and grossly common in its aims.... He was a marvellous type, too, this lad, whom by so curious a chance he had met in Basil’s studio, or could be fashioned into a marvellous type, at any rate. Grace was his, and the white purity of boyhood, and beauty such as old Greek marbles kept for us. There was nothing that one could not do with him. He could be made a Titan or a toy. What a pity it was that such beauty was destined to fade! ... And Basil? From a psychological point of view, how interesting he was! The new manner in art, the fresh mode of looking at life, suggested so strangely by the merely visible presence of one who was unconscious of it all; the silent spirit that dwelt in dim woodland, and walked unseen in open field, suddenly showing herself, Dryadlike and not afraid, because in his soul who sought for her there had been wakened that wonderful vision to which alone are wonderful things revealed; the mere shapes and patterns of things becoming, as it were, refined, and gaining a kind of symbolical value, as though they were themselves patterns of some other and more perfect form whose shadow they made real: how strange it all was! He remembered something like it in history. Was it not Plato, that artist in thought, who had first analyzed it? Was it not Buonarotti who had carved it in the coloured marbles of a sonnet-sequence? But in our own century it was strange.... Yes; he would try to be to Dorian Gray what, without knowing it, the lad was to the painter who had fashioned the wonderful portrait. He would seek to dominate him—had already, indeed, half done so. He would make that wonderful spirit his own. There was something fascinating in this son of love and death.
vi: So that is the story of Dorian Gray's lineage. As blunt as it was told to him, it stirred his heart with the suggestion of a strange, almost modern romance. A beautiful woman had risked everything for her mad passion. A few weeks of wild happiness cut short by a hideous, deceitful crime. Months of silent suffering, then a child born in pain. The mother kidnapped by death, the boy left in loneliness and the cruelty of a heartless old man. Yes; it was an interesting background. It elevated the young man, made him seem more perfect. Behind everything beautiful that has ever existed, there must be something tragic. The world must endure the pain of childbirth, so that even the most ordinary flower can bloom… And how enchanting he was at dinner the night before, when, with frightened eyes and lips parted in dreadful joy, he sat opposite him in the club, the red lampshade casting a deeper crimson on his awakened astonishment. Talking to him was like playing on a finely tuned violin. He responded to every touch and vibration of the bow… There was something irresistibly fascinating about exerting influence. No other activity was quite like it. To project one's soul into a graceful form, and let it linger there for a while; to hear one's own intellectual views echoed back with all the added music of passion and youth; to transmit one's temperament through another as if it were some magical fluid or strange perfume; there was a very real pleasure in it — perhaps the most satisfying pleasure left to us in an age as limited and coarse as ours, an age utterly mundane in its pleasures, utterly mediocre in its aims… He, the young man whom by a strange chance he had met in Basil's studio, was also an extraordinary model; or could be made into an extraordinary model, in any case. Grace was his, along with the pure innocence of youth, and beauty like that which the ancient Greek marble statues have preserved for us. There was nothing that could not be done with him. He could be crafted into a giant or a toy. How tragic it was that such beauty should be destined to fade!... And Basil? How interesting he was from a psychological perspective! A fresh artistic style, a new outlook on life, strangely inspired merely by the visible presence of someone completely unaware of it; a quiet soul still dwelling in the dim forest, still walking invisibly in the open field, suddenly revealing itself, like a fearless forest goddess, because in his soul, the one who sought her there, had awakened the extraordinary imagination that before only it could reveal the extraordinary; the mere form and pattern of those things had, so to speak, become essential, and achieved a kind of symbolic value, even though they were models of a different and more perfect form whose shadow they had made real: how strange all this was! He recalled something similar in history. Was it Plato, that artist of thought, who first analyzed it? Was it Buonarotti, who carved it into the colored marble of a sonnet sequence? But in our century, it was truly strange… Yes; he would try to become, to Dorian Gray, what that young man, unknowingly, had become to the artist who created that marvelous portrait. He would seek to dominate him — in fact, he had almost done so already. He would make that extraordinary soul his own. There was something truly enchanting about this child of Love and Death.
tr: So, this was the story of Dorian Gray's parents. Despite being told in broad strokes, this story had excited him by evoking a strange, contemporary romanticism. A beautiful woman who sacrificed everything for a mad passion. A few weeks of wild happiness ending in a vile, treacherous murder. Months of silent suffering, then a child born in pain. The mother being taken by death, the child left alone in the hands of an old, loveless man. Yes, an interesting background. It formed a backdrop for Dorian, making him seem even more perfect. Behind every perfect thing, there was hidden pain. It was as if the world had to suffer for the most ordinary flower to bloom... The boy had sat across from Lord Henry at the dinner they had at the club the previous night, with startled eyes and lips parted with timid pleasure, as the red shades of the candelabras painted the slowly awakening consciousness on his face a deeper rose color, how sweet he had been. Talking to him was like playing a fine violin. The boy responded to every touch, every pull of the bow... There was something immensely enveloping about wielding one's influence in this way. No other occupation could compare to this. To transfer one's own soul into a separate, beautiful form and hold it there for a while, to have one's thoughts echoed, to add the music of youth and excitement to it, and to transmit one's own temperament and attitude, like a slippery liquid, a mysterious scent, to another. There was a true joy in this...Perhaps in an era as limited and crude as ours, with pleasures roughly sensual and goals roughly vulgar, this was the most fulfilling joy left to us... Then, by a strange coincidence, this boy he had met in Basil's studio had a wonderful personality; or at least his personality could be shaped into a wonderful form. He had elegance, the pure clarity of youth, and the beauty that ancient Greek marbles had preserved for us. There was no shape that could not be given to this boy. He could be made into a titan or a toy. But how sad it was that such beauty was destined to fade away...And Basil? How interesting he was from a psychological standpoint! A new art method, a completely different perspective on life... The mere visible presence of the young man had evoked these in the painter, while the young man was completely unaware of them. That silent, feminine spirit living in dim groves, wandering unseen in the open fields, suddenly revealed itself, fearless, like the forest goddesses. A marvelous eye had opened in the painter's own soul, and marvelous things could only be seen by this eye. Thus, the simplest lines and forms of objects had become refined and exalted, gaining a symbolic value, as if they were examples of a completely different and more perfect form, and these forms made their shadows real. How strange all this was! Lord Henry seemed to recall something similar in history. Was it not Plato, that painter of thoughts, who first examined this? Was it not Buonarroti who first carved this into the colorful marbles of a sonnet? Yet in our current age, such a thing was startling. Yes, just as Dorian Gray had unknowingly symbolized something to the painter who drew that wonderful portrait, Lord Henry would try to make Dorian Gray symbolize it to him. He would try to dominate him, and he was already halfway there, even now. He would claim that beautiful soul for himself. There was an enchanting allure in this child of love and death.
es: That was, therefore, the family history of Dorian Gray. Despite the schematic nature of the story, it had impressed him because it made one think of a strange, almost modern love story. A beautiful woman who risks everything for a mad passion. A few weeks of boundless happiness cut short by a heinous crime, by a betrayal. Months of silent suffering, and then a child born in pain. The mother snatched away by death, the child abandoned to loneliness and the tyranny of a heartless old man. Yes; some interesting antecedents, which placed the boy, which added a new perfection to him, so to speak. Behind all exquisite things, there is something tragic. For the humblest of flowers to bloom, the effort of worlds is needed...And, how charming he had been during dinner the night before, when, with surprise in his eyes and lips parted in pleasure and fear, he had sat across from him at the club, the red screens of the lamps enhancing the blush awakened in his face by astonishment! Talking to him was like playing the most delicate of violins. Dorian responded to every touch and vibration of the bow...There was something terribly captivating about influencing someone. There was no other activity like it. Projecting the soul onto a pleasing form, pausing for a moment; emitting one's own ideas to be echoed back, accompanied by the music of youthful passion; transmitting one's own sensitivity to another as if it were a subtle fluid or a strange perfume; there lay the source of true joy, perhaps the most satisfying that such a mean and vulgar age as ours still allows, an age crudely carnal in its pleasures and enormously vulgar in its goals...That boy whom he had met by a strange chance in Basil's studio also embodied a wonderful model or, at least, could be turned into a wonderful being. His was the charm, and the immaculate purity of adolescence, along with a beauty that only ancient Greek marbles preserve for us. There was nothing that could not be done with him. He could be turned into a titan or a toy. What a pity that such beauty was destined to wither!... And Basil? From a psychological point of view, how interesting he was! A new artistic style, a new way of seeing life, all suggested so strangely by the mere presence of someone who was all that unconsciously; the silent spirit that dwells in shadowy forests and walks unseen through open fields, suddenly revealing itself like a dryad, and without fear, because in the soul that seeks it, that singular capacity has already awakened, to which the revelation of wonderful things corresponds; the simple forms, the simple contours of things that were stylized, so to speak, acquiring something akin to symbolic value, as if they were in turn the sketch of another more perfect form, whose shadow endowed them with reality: how strange it all was! He remembered something similar in the history of thought. Was it not Plato, that artist of ideas, who had analyzed it for the first time? Was it not Buonarotti who sculpted it in the multicolored marble of a succession of sonnets? But in our century it was strange...Yes; he would try to be for Dorian Gray what he, unknowingly, had been for the author of that wonderful portrait. He would try to dominate him; in reality, he had already done so halfway. He would make that wonderful spirit his own. There was something fascinating about that child of Love and Death.

en: Suddenly he stopped and glanced up at the houses. He found that he had passed his aunt’s some distance, and, smiling to himself, turned back. When he entered the somewhat sombre hall, the butler told him that they had gone in to lunch. He gave one of the footmen his hat and stick and passed into the dining-room.
vi: Suddenly, he stopped and looked up at the houses. He realized that he had walked past his aunt's house by several blocks, and, smiling to himself, turned back. When he stepped into the somewhat gloomy hall, the butler informed him that they had already gone to eat. He handed his hat and cane to a servant, then went into the dining room.
tr: Suddenly, Lord Henry stopped and looked at the houses beside him. Seeing that he had passed his aunt's house by quite a bit, he turned back with a smile to himself. When he entered the somewhat gloomy hall, the head butler informed him that dinner had started. Lord Henry handed his hat and cane to one of the footmen and entered the dining room.
es: Suddenly, Lord Henry stopped and contemplated the houses that surrounded him. He realized that he had passed his aunt's house and, smiling, retraced his steps. When he entered the somewhat gloomy hall, the butler informed him that the diners had already sat down at the table. He handed his hat and cane to one of the footmen and proceeded to the dining room.

en: “Late as usual, Harry,” cried his aunt, shaking her head at him.
vi: “Late again as always, Harry,” his aunt yelled, shaking her head at him.
tr: His aunt looked at him, shaking her head, and shouted, "You're late, Harry!" "As always."
es: —Late as usual —exclaimed his aunt, reprimanding him with a shake of her head.

en: He invented a facile excuse, and having taken the vacant seat next to her, looked round to see who was there. Dorian bowed to him shyly from the end of the table, a flush of pleasure stealing into his cheek. Opposite was the Duchess of Harley, a lady of admirable good-nature and good temper, much liked by every one who knew her, and of those ample architectural proportions that in women who are not duchesses are described by contemporary historians as stoutness. Next to her sat, on her right, Sir Thomas Burdon, a Radical member of Parliament, who followed his leader in public life and in private life followed the best cooks, dining with the Tories and thinking with the Liberals, in accordance with a wise and well-known rule. The post on her left was occupied by Mr. Erskine of Treadley, an old gentleman of considerable charm and culture, who had fallen, however, into bad habits of silence, having, as he explained once to Lady Agatha, said everything that he had to say before he was thirty. His own neighbour was Mrs. Vandeleur, one of his aunt’s oldest friends, a perfect saint amongst women, but so dreadfully dowdy that she reminded one of a badly bound hymn-book. Fortunately for him she had on the other side Lord Faudel, a most intelligent middle-aged mediocrity, as bald as a ministerial statement in the House of Commons, with whom she was conversing in that intensely earnest manner which is the one unpardonable error, as he remarked once himself, that all really good people fall into, and from which none of them ever quite escape.
vi: Y came up with a plausible excuse to justify himself, and sat down in the empty seat next to his aunt, looking around to see who was there. Dorian shyly bowed his head in greeting from the other end of the table, a slight flush of joy creeping up his cheeks. Opposite him was the Duchess of Harley; a kind-hearted and good-natured lady, esteemed by all her acquaintances, and possessing a fertile architectural symmetry that in women who are not duchesses is still described by contemporary historians with the word "obese". Sitting next to her, on her right, was Sir Thomas Burdon, a member of the Radical Party, a Member of Parliament, who followed his leader in public life, but in private life followed the best chefs, dined with Conservatives, thought with Liberals, adhering to a wise and famous rule. The position on her left was occupied by Mr. Erskine of Treadley, a rather charming and cultured elderly gentleman, who nevertheless had acquired the bad habit of silence because, as he once explained to Mrs. Agatha, he had said everything he needed to say before he was thirty. Next to him was Lady Vandeleur, one of his aunt's oldest friends, a perfect angel among women, but dressed so terribly that she reminded people of a poorly bound hymn book. Fortunately for him, sitting on the other side of her was Lord Faudel, an extraordinarily intelligent middle-aged man, as bald as a minister's speech in the House of Commons, with whom she conversed in that eager, lively manner that, as he once noted to himself, was an unforgivable fault that all truly kind-hearted people fell into and from which none of them ever fully escaped.
tr: Lord Henry uttered the first excuse that came to his tongue, and, sitting in the empty seat next to his aunt, looked around to see who was present at the table. Dorian, sitting at the far end of the table, looked at him shyly and smiled, a joyful color spreading across his face. Opposite him was Duchess Harley, whose good nature and kind heart were greatly admired, and who was loved by all her acquaintances. Modern historians, when they encounter the architectural proportions of this lady in women who are not duchesses, describe them as "stout." To her right sat Sir Thomas Burdon, a radical member of Parliament. He adhered to a well-known, wise rule by following his leader in public life and the most skilled chefs in private life, dining with the Tories and thinking with the Liberals... On his right sat Mr. Erskine of Treadley. This elderly gentleman, who possessed considerable charm and culture, unfortunately had acquired the bad habit of silence, because, as he once explained to Lady Agatha, he believed he had said everything he had to say before the age of thirty. Next to Lord Henry was Ms. Vandeleur, one of his aunt's oldest friends: An angelic woman, yet so dowdy and shabby that she reminded one of a poorly bound prayer book. Lord Henry was fortunate that on the other side of the woman sat Lord Faudel, an extremely intelligent, middle-aged, and mediocre person. Lord Faudel had a completely bald head, like a wasted ministerial promise in the House of Commons. Ms. Vandeleur was speaking to him with utmost sincere honesty. As Lord Henry once said, this sincere honesty was the only unforgivable mistake that all truly good people fell into and from which none could entirely escape.
es: Lord Henry invented a trivial excuse and, after settling into the empty seat next to Lady Agatha, looked around to see the guests. Dorian Gray gave him a timid nod from the end of the table, a blush of satisfaction appearing on his cheeks. Opposite him was the Duchess of Harley, a lady with admirable character and courage, much loved by all who knew her, and with the ample architectural proportions that contemporary historians, when not referring to duchesses, call corpulence. To his right sat Sir Thomas Burdon, a radical member of Parliament, who followed his leader in public life and the best chefs in private, dining with the conservatives and thinking with the liberals, according to a rule as prudent as it was well-known. The seat to the left of the Duchess was occupied by Mr. Erskine of Treadley, an elderly gentleman of considerable charm and culture, who had nevertheless fallen into the bad habit of keeping silent, since, as he once explained to Lady Agatha, everything he had to say he had said before he turned thirty. To the left of Lord Henry sat Mrs. Vandeleur, one of his aunt's oldest friends, saintly among women, but so terribly unattractive that she made one think of a poorly bound hymnal. Fortunately for him, Mrs. Vandeleur had on her other side Lord Faudel—a very intelligent mediocrity, over forty years old and as bald as a ministerial statement in the House of Commons—with whom she conversed in that intensely serious manner that is the only unforgivable error, as he himself had once pointed out, that all truly good people fall into and from which none of them entirely escape.

en: “We are talking about poor Dartmoor, Lord Henry,” cried the duchess, nodding pleasantly to him across the table. “Do you think he will really marry this fascinating young person?”
vi: “We are talking about poor Dartmoor, Lord Henry,” the duchess exclaimed, nodding warmly at him across the table. “Do you think he will really marry this charming young girl?”
tr: The Duchess, laughing and nodding her head from the other side of the table, said, "We were talking about poor Dartmoor, Lord Henry." "Do you think Dartmoor will really marry this charming young girl?"
es: —We are talking about poor Dartmoor, Lord Henry —exclaimed the duchess, giving him a friendly nod from across the table—. Do you think he will really marry that fascinating young woman?

en: “I believe she has made up her mind to propose to him, Duchess.”
vi: “I believe she has decided to propose to him, Your Grace.”
tr: “I think the girl was determined to propose to him, Duchess.”
es: —I believe the young woman is determined to ask for her hand, Duchess.

en: “How dreadful!” exclaimed Lady Agatha. “Really, some one should interfere.”
vi: “How terrifying!” Mrs. Agatha exclaimed. “Someone really should intervene.”
tr: Lady Agatha shouted, "What have I done!" "Someone must stop this."
es: —What a fright! —exclaimed Lady Agatha—. Someone should take action on this matter.

en: “I am told, on excellent authority, that her father keeps an American dry-goods store,” said Sir Thomas Burdon, looking supercilious.
vi: "I heard, according to a very reliable source, that her father manages a grocery store in America," said Mr. Thomas Burdon, looking disdainful.
tr: Sir Thomas Burdon said with a haughty expression, "I have heard from a reliable source that the girl's father runs a dry goods store in America."
es: —I have been reliably informed that his father owns a gravel warehouse —said Sir Thomas Burdon disdainfully.

en: “My uncle has already suggested pork-packing, Sir Thomas.”
vi: “My uncle hypothesized that it was pork trading, Sir Thomas.”
tr: Sir Thomas Burdon said with a haughty expression, "I have heard from a reliable source that the girl's father runs a dry goods store in America."
es: —My uncle has suggested that it is about charcuterie, Sir Thomas.

en: “Dry-goods! What are American dry-goods?” asked the duchess, raising her large hands in wonder and accentuating the verb.
vi: “General store! What is an American general store?” the duchess asked, raising her large hands in surprise, and emphasizing the verb.
tr: The Duchess, opening her large hands in astonishment, "Fabric! What is American fabric?" she asked.
es: —Arid goods! What kind of merchandise is that? —asked the duchess, raising her large hands in a gesture of astonishment and heavily emphasizing the verb.

en: “American novels,” answered Lord Henry, helping himself to some quail.
vi: “American novels,” Lord Henry replied, helping himself to a bit of quail.
tr: Lord Henry, taking some quail onto his plate, responded, "American novels."
es: —American novels —replied Lord Henry, while serving himself a quail.

en: The duchess looked puzzled.
vi: The duchess seemed confused.
tr: The Duchess seemed to understand nothing.
es: The duchess seemed bewildered.

en: “Don’t mind him, my dear,” whispered Lady Agatha. “He never means anything that he says.”
vi: "Don't pay attention to it, my friend," whispered Mrs. Agatha. "It is never serious about what it says."
tr: Lady Agatha whispered, "Don't pay attention to her, darling." "You shouldn't take any of her words seriously."
es: —Don't pay attention to him, dear —whispered Lady Agatha—. My nephew never speaks seriously.

en: “When America was discovered,” said the Radical member—and he began to give some wearisome facts. Like all people who try to exhaust a subject, he exhausted his listeners. The duchess sighed and exercised her privilege of interruption. “I wish to goodness it never had been discovered at all!” she exclaimed. “Really, our girls have no chance nowadays. It is most unfair.”
vi: “When America was discovered,” the member of the Radical party said, and he began to present some tedious facts. Like anyone who tries to exhaust a topic, he also exhausted his listeners. The Duchess sighed and used her privilege to interrupt. “I only wish it had never been discovered at all!” she exclaimed. “Truly, our girls nowadays have no chance. It is so terribly unfair.”
tr: The Radical Parliament member began his speech with, "When America was discovered," and proceeded to list a series of tedious facts. Like all people who try to exhaust a topic, he eventually exhausted the patience of his listeners. The Duchess sighed and used the interruption to cut off the person in front of her: "I wish it had never been discovered!" she exclaimed softly. "God knows, our daughters have no chance anymore. This is a great injustice."
es: —When America was discovered... —intervened the radical member of the House of Commons, proceeding to enumerate some extremely boring facts. Like all people who try to exhaust a topic, he succeeded in exhausting his listeners. The duchess sighed and used her privileged position to interrupt. —I wish they had never discovered it! —he exclaimed—. To tell the truth, our young women don't have the slightest chance now. It's a great injustice.

en: “Perhaps, after all, America never has been discovered,” said Mr. Erskine; “I myself would say that it had merely been detected.”
vi: “Perhaps in the end, America was never actually discovered,” Mr. Erskine said. “I always say it was merely recognized.”
tr: Mr. Erskine said, "Perhaps America was never actually discovered." "If you ask me, it was only revealed."
es: —Perhaps, after all, America was never truly discovered —said Mr. Erskine—; I would rather say it was merely detected.

en: “Oh! but I have seen specimens of the inhabitants,” answered the duchess vaguely. “I must confess that most of them are extremely pretty. And they dress well, too. They get all their dresses in Paris. I wish I could afford to do the same.”
vi: “Oh! But I have seen a few of those types of people,” the duchess replied, very carelessly. “I must admit that most of them are extremely charming. And they dress well too. They buy all their clothes in Paris. I wish I could afford to do that.”
tr: The Duchess said, "Ha! But I have seen examples of the natives from there." "To be honest, most of them are quite attractive. They also dress well. They get all their outfits from Paris. I wish my situation allowed for that!"
es: —Yes, yes, but I have seen specimens of its inhabitants —the duchess responded vaguely—. I must confess that most of the women are extraordinarily beautiful. And they also dress well. They buy all their clothes in Paris. I would like to be able to afford it.

en: “They say that when good Americans die they go to Paris,” chuckled Sir Thomas, who had a large wardrobe of Humour’s cast-off clothes.
vi: “They say that when good Americans die, they go to Paris,” Sir Thomas chuckled, he had a large wardrobe full of discarded Humor.
tr: Sir Thomas chuckled, "They say that good Americans go to Paris when they die." His wardrobe was filled with Humour's second-hand clothes.
es: —They say that when good Americans die, they go to Paris —chuckled Sir Thomas, who had a large wardrobe of discarded witty phrases.

en: “Really! And where do bad Americans go to when they die?” inquired the duchess.
vi: “Really! So where do bad Americans go when they die?” the duchess inquired.
tr: The Duchess said, "Don't say that!" "Well, where do bad Americans go when they die?"
es: —Really? And, where do the bad ones go? —the duchess wanted to know.

en: “They go to America,” murmured Lord Henry.
vi: “They go to America,” Lord Henry whispered.
tr: Lord Henry murmured, "To America."
es: —They are going to the United States —murmured Lord Henry.

en: Sir Thomas frowned. “I am afraid that your nephew is prejudiced against that great country,” he said to Lady Agatha. “I have travelled all over it in cars provided by the directors, who, in such matters, are extremely civil. I assure you that it is an education to visit it.”
vi: Sir Thomas frowned. “I’m afraid your grandson has a prejudice against that great country,” he said to Mrs. Agatha. “I have traveled everywhere there, in carriages meticulously arranged by directors, who, in such matters, are extremely polite. I assure you that visiting that place is an education in itself.”
tr: Sir Thomas frowned. He said to Lady Agatha, "I am afraid your nephew has a prejudice against this great country." "I have traveled every inch of this country with the carriages provided by the administrators, who are extremely kind in these matters. Believe me, this journey in itself is an education.""
es: Sir Thomas frowned. —I am afraid your nephew has prejudices against that great country —he said to Lady Agatha—. I have traveled all over the territory, in cars provided by the directors, who are extraordinarily hospitable in these matters. I assure you it is very instructive to visit the United States.

en: “But must we really see Chicago in order to be educated?” asked Mr. Erskine plaintively. “I don’t feel up to the journey.”
vi: “But do we really need to see Chicago to be educated?” Mr. Erskine asked again, gloomily. “I don't feel up to that journey.”
tr: Mr. Erskine complained, "But do we really have to go to Chicago to get an education?" "Personally, I can't take such a risk."
es: —Do we really have to see Chicago to be well-educated? —asked Mr. Erskine querulously—. I don't feel capable of undertaking that trip.

en: Sir Thomas waved his hand. “Mr. Erskine of Treadley has the world on his shelves. We practical men like to see things, not to read about them. The Americans are an extremely interesting people. They are absolutely reasonable. I think that is their distinguishing characteristic. Yes, Mr. Erskine, an absolutely reasonable people. I assure you there is no nonsense about the Americans.”
vi: Sir Thomas waved his hand. "Mr. Erskine of Treadley has the whole world on his bookshelf. Practical people like us prefer to see things rather than just read about them. Americans are an extremely interesting people. They are absolutely rational. I think that is their most prominent characteristic. Yes, Mr. Erskine, an absolutely rational people. I assure you there is nothing irrational about Americans at all."
tr: Sir Thomas waved his hand. “The world is hidden on the bookshelves for Mr. Erskine with his Treadley. But we practical people prefer to see things in the world rather than read about them. Americans are an extremely interesting people. Completely rational individuals. I think that is their distinguishing characteristic. Yes, Mr. Erskine, a completely rational, logical society. Rest assured. There is nothing nonsensical about Americans.”
es: Sir Thomas waved his hand. —Mr. Erskine of Treadley has the world on the shelves of his library. We, practical men, like to see things, not read their descriptions. Americans are a very interesting people. And totally reasonable. I think that is the characteristic that distinguishes them. Yes, Mr. Erskine, a totally reasonable people. I assure you that Americans do not beat around the bush.

en: “How dreadful!” cried Lord Henry. “I can stand brute force, but brute reason is quite unbearable. There is something unfair about its use. It is hitting below the intellect.”
vi: “How terrifying!” exclaimed Lord Henry. “I can resist brute force, but brute reason is truly unbearable. There is something deceitful in its use. It strikes below the intellect.”
tr: Lord Henry, "I didn't do it!" he said. "I can endure absolute power, but absolute logic is unbearable. I find an injustice in the use of such a thing. I consider it a blow below the belt."
es: —Terrible! —exclaimed Lord Henry—. I do not like brute force, but brute reason is absolutely unbearable. It is not right to use it. It is like hitting below the intellect.

en: “I do not understand you,” said Sir Thomas, growing rather red.
vi: “I don't understand you,” Mr. Thomas said, his face becoming quite red.
tr: Sir Thomas, with his face slightly reddening, said, "I don't understand you."
es: —I don't understand you —said Sir Thomas, blushing considerably.

en: “I do, Lord Henry,” murmured Mr. Erskine, with a smile.
vi: “I understand, Lord Henry,” Mr. Erskine muttered, with a smile.
tr: Mr. Erskine murmured with a smile, "I understand."
es: —I do, Lord Henry —murmured Mr. Erskine with a smile.

en: “Paradoxes are all very well in their way....” rejoined the baronet.
vi: “Paradoxes are all very interesting in their own way…” the young baron replied.
tr: Sir Thomas began to speak, "A contradiction is endured in its time, but..."
es: —Paradoxes are all well and good in their own way... —interjected the baronet.

en: “Was that a paradox?” asked Mr. Erskine. “I did not think so. Perhaps it was. Well, the way of paradoxes is the way of truth. To test reality we must see it on the tight rope. When the verities become acrobats, we can judge them.”
vi: “Is that a paradox?” Mr. Erskine asked. “I don't think so. Maybe it is. Well, the path of paradox is the path of truth. To test Reality, we must see it on a tightrope. When Truths become acrobats, then we can judge them.”
tr: Mr. Erskine asked, "Was this a contradiction?" "It didn't seem so to me. But maybe it was. Well, the path to truth passes through contradiction. If we want to test the truth, we must first see it on the tightrope. We can only measure truths when they become acrobats."
es: —Was that a paradox? —asked Mr. Erskine—. It didn't seem like it to me. Maybe it was. Well, the path of paradoxes is the path of truth. To test reality, we must see it on the tightrope. When truths become acrobats, we can judge them.

en: “Dear me!” said Lady Agatha, “how you men argue! I am sure I never can make out what you are talking about. Oh! Harry, I am quite vexed with you. Why do you try to persuade our nice Mr. Dorian Gray to give up the East End? I assure you he would be quite invaluable. They would love his playing.”
vi: "Oh my God!" said Mrs. Agatha, "you men love to argue so much! I'm sure I'll never be able to understand what you are talking about. Ah! Harry, I am quite displeased with you. Why are you trying to persuade our handsome Mr. Dorian Gray to leave East End? I assure you he will be truly invaluable. They really enjoy having him play."
tr: Lady Agatha said, "Look here!" "You men just love to argue. I can never understand what you're talking about, honestly. Oh, Harry, I'm very angry with you. What's the point of trying to dissuade our dear Mr. Dorian Gray from going to the East End? It will be extremely beneficial for us, believe me. Everyone will love his piano playing."
es: —Good heavens! —said Lady Agatha—, how you men argue! I'm sure I'll never know what you're talking about. By the way, Harry, I am very angry with you. Why are you trying to convince our Dorian Gray, such a charming person, to give up the East End? I assure you it would be invaluable. Our regulars would have loved to hear him play.

en: “I want him to play to me,” cried Lord Henry, smiling, and he looked down the table and caught a bright answering glance.
vi: “I want him to play for me,” Lord Henry exclaimed, laughing, then he looked down to the other end of the table and met a bright, responsive gaze.
tr: Lord Henry smiled and said, "I want him to play the piano for me." He looked to the other end of the table and caught a sparkling smile that answered his own.
es: —I want you to play for me —exclaimed Lord Henry, smiling. When he looked towards the end of the table, he caught a gleam in Dorian's eyes as a response.

en: “But they are so unhappy in Whitechapel,” continued Lady Agatha.
vi: “But they are very miserable in Whitechapel,” Mrs. Agatha continued.
tr: Lady Agatha continued, "But the ones in Whitechapel are so unhappy!"
es: —But in Whitechapel, people are very unfortunate —protested Lady Agatha.

en: “I can sympathize with everything except suffering,” said Lord Henry, shrugging his shoulders. “I cannot sympathize with that. It is too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid in the modern sympathy with pain. One should sympathize with the colour, the beauty, the joy of life. The less said about life’s sores, the better.”
vi: “I can sympathize with everything except suffering,” said Lord Henry, shrugging his shoulders. “I cannot sympathize with that. It is too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid about modern sympathy with pain. One should sympathize with color, beauty, the joy of life. The less said about the sorrows and woes of life, the better.”
tr: Lord Henry shrugged, "I can sympathize with everything in the world except suffering," he said. "That is something I cannot sympathize with. It is excessively ugly, tragic, and distressing. There is something extremely morbid in our age's affinity for pain. One should show affinity for the color, beauty, and joy of life. The less we talk about life's festering wounds, the better, in my opinion."
es: —I can sympathize with anything except suffering —said Lord Henry, shrugging his shoulders—. I can't go that far. It's too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid about our era's sympathy for pain. We should be interested in colors, in beauty, in the joy of living. The less we talk about the miseries of life, the better.

en: “Still, the East End is a very important problem,” remarked Sir Thomas with a grave shake of the head.
vi: “However, the East End is a serious matter,” Sir Thomas remarked, with a solemn shake of his head.
tr: Sir Thomas shook his head seriously and said, "Nevertheless, the East End is a very important issue."
es: —In any case, the East End is a very important problem —remarked Sir Thomas, with a grave nod of his head.

en: “Quite so,” answered the young lord. “It is the problem of slavery, and we try to solve it by amusing the slaves.”
vi: “That's right,” the young lord replied. “It's a matter of slavery, and we try to solve it by entertaining the slaves.”
tr: The Young Lord said, "Indeed, very much so!" "East End is a slavery problem, and we are trying to solve it by entertaining the slaves."
es: —Very true —replied the young lord—. It is the problem of slavery, and we try to solve it by entertaining the slaves.

en: The politician looked at him keenly. “What change do you propose, then?” he asked.
vi: The politician looked at him sharply. "So what changes do you propose, huh?" he asked.
tr: The politician squinted his eyes and looked at him. “So, what kind of change are you proposing?” he asked.
es: The politician looked at him with great interest. —What change do you propose, in that case? —he asked.

en: Lord Henry laughed. “I don’t desire to change anything in England except the weather,” he answered. “I am quite content with philosophic contemplation. But, as the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt through an over-expenditure of sympathy, I would suggest that we should appeal to science to put us straight. The advantage of the emotions is that they lead us astray, and the advantage of science is that it is not emotional.”
vi: Lord Henry laughed. “I do not wish to change anything in England except the weather,” he replied. “I am quite satisfied with philosophical contemplation. But, as the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt from overspending on sympathy, I suggest that we should appeal to Science to bring us back to the right path. The advantage of emotions is that they lead us astray, while the advantage of Science is that it has no emotions.”
tr: Lord Henry laughed. “There is nothing I want to change in England except the weather,” he replied. “Delving into philosophical thoughts is enough for me. The fact is, since the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt due to our reckless squandering of understanding and compassion, my suggestion is that we turn to science to correct us. The advantage of emotions is that they lead us astray; the advantage of science is that it is not emotional.”
es: Lord Henry laughed. —I do not wish to change anything in England, except the weather —he replied—. I am more than satisfied with philosophical contemplation. But since the 19th century has been ruined by an excessive expenditure of sympathy, I suggest turning to science to solve it. The advantage of emotions is that they lead us astray, and the advantage of science is that it excludes emotion.

en: “But we have such grave responsibilities,” ventured Mrs. Vandeleur timidly.
vi: “But I bear very grave responsibilities,” Mrs. Vandeleur ventured, shyly.
tr: Ms. Vandeleur hesitantly suggested, "But we bear such heavy and serious responsibilities!"
es: —But we have very serious responsibilities —ventured Mrs. Uandeleur timidly.

en: “Terribly grave,” echoed Lady Agatha.
vi: "Terribly serious," Mrs. Agatha repeated.
tr: “Extremely serious and grave,” Lady Agatha repeated his words.
es: —Extremely serious - echoed Lady Agatha.

en: Lord Henry looked over at Mr. Erskine. “Humanity takes itself too seriously. It is the world’s original sin. If the caveman had known how to laugh, history would have been different.”
vi: Lord Henry glanced at Mr. Erskine. "Human beings consider themselves too important. That is the original sin of the world. If the cave dwellers had known how to laugh, history would have been different."
tr: Lord Henry looked towards Mr. Erskine. "Man takes himself too seriously. This is the first sin the world committed. If the caveman knew how to laugh, history would be very different."
es: Lord Henry looked intently at Mr. Erskine. —Humanity takes itself too seriously. It is the original sin of the world. If the cavemen had known how to laugh, history would have been different.

en: “You are really very comforting,” warbled the duchess. “I have always felt rather guilty when I came to see your dear aunt, for I take no interest at all in the East End. For the future I shall be able to look her in the face without a blush.”
vi: “You really know how to comfort someone,” the duchess whispered. “I always feel quite guilty whenever I visit your aunt, because I don't care at all about the East End. From now on, I can look her in the eye without blushing.”
tr: The Duchess said in a cheerful voice, “You put my mind at ease.” “I always feel guilty when I come to see your dear aunt, because the East End doesn't interest me in the slightest. From now on, I won't blush with shame when I look at your aunt's face.”
es: —You don't know how much it comforts me to hear you —chirped the duchess—. I always feel very guilty when I come to see your dear aunt, because I am not at all interested in the East End. In the future, I will be able to look her in the face without blushing.

en: “A blush is very becoming, Duchess,” remarked Lord Henry.
vi: “Blushing suits you very well too, madam duchess,” Lord Henry remarked.
tr: Lord Henry, "Blushing becomes a person, Duchess," he opined.
es: —Blushing is very becoming, Duchess —remarked Lord Henry.

en: “Only when one is young,” she answered. “When an old woman like myself blushes, it is a very bad sign. Ah! Lord Henry, I wish you would tell me how to become young again.”
vi: “Only when one is still young,” she replied. “When an old lady like me blushes, it is a very bad sign. Ah, Lord Henry, I wish you could show me how to become young again.”
tr: The Duchess said, "But only for the young." "For an old woman like me, blushing is a bad sign. Oh, Lord Henry, I wish you could show me how to be young again!"
es: —Only when one is young —she replied—. When an old woman like me blushes, it's a very bad sign. Ah, I wish you could tell me how to be young again!

en: He thought for a moment. “Can you remember any great error that you committed in your early days, Duchess?” he asked, looking at her across the table.
vi: He thought for a moment. “Can you remember any major mistake you made in the early days, Duchess?” he asked, looking at her across the table.
tr: Lord Henry thought for a moment. Then, looking at the woman in front of him, he asked, "Can you recall a great mistake you made in your old days, Duchess?"
es: Lord Henry pondered for a moment. —Do you remember any big mistake you made in your early days, Duchess? —he asked, looking at her from the other side of the table.

en: “A great many, I fear,” she cried.
vi: “A lot, I'm afraid so,” she exclaimed.
tr: “I'm afraid quite a lot!””
es: —Many, unfortunately —she exclaimed.

en: “Then commit them over again,” he said gravely. “To get back one’s youth, one has merely to repeat one’s follies.”
vi: "Then commit them again," he said, solemnly. "To return to youth, one only needs to repeat their own follies."
tr: Lord Henry replied seriously, "Then do them again." "To regain one's youth, one only needs to repeat one's follies."
es: —Well, commit them again —he said gravely—. To regain youth, it is enough to repeat the same follies.

en: “A delightful theory!” she exclaimed. “I must put it into practice.”
vi: “An interesting theory!” she exclaimed. “I must apply it in practice.”
tr: The Duchess said, "A wonderful theory." "I must apply it immediately."
es: —Delicious theory! —she exclaimed—. I must put it into practice.

en: “A dangerous theory!” came from Sir Thomas’s tight lips. Lady Agatha shook her head, but could not help being amused. Mr. Erskine listened.
vi: "A dangerous theory!" came from the tightly pressed lips of Mr. Thomas. Mrs. Agatha shook her head but couldn't help laughing. Mr. Erskine listened.
tr: Sir Thomas spoke with pursed lips, "A dangerous theory!" Lady Agatha nodded her head but couldn't help feeling amused. Mr. Erskine was all ears.
es: —A dangerous theory! —said Sir Thomas, his mouth tense. Lady Agatha shook her head disapprovingly, but the idea still seemed amusing to her. Mr. Erskine was listening.

en: “Yes,” he continued, “that is one of the great secrets of life. Nowadays most people die of a sort of creeping common sense, and discover when it is too late that the only things one never regrets are one’s mistakes.”
vi: “Yes,” he continued, “that is one of the greatest secrets of life. Nowadays most people die of a creeping common sense, and discover too late that the only things one never regrets are one's mistakes.”
tr: Lord Henry added, "Yes." "It is one of the great mysteries of life. Nowadays, most people die of a sort of creeping common sense. They realize too late that the only things one never regrets are one's mistakes."
es: —Yes —continued the young lord—; it is one of the great secrets of life. Nowadays, most people die of an indigestion of common sense and discover when it is already too late that the only things we never regret are our mistakes.

en: A laugh ran round the table.
vi: A burst of laughter ran around the table.
tr: Laughter circulated around the table.
es: Laughter was heard around the table.

en: He played with the idea and grew wilful; tossed it into the air and transformed it; let it escape and recaptured it; made it iridescent with fancy and winged it with paradox. The praise of folly, as he went on, soared into a philosophy, and philosophy herself became young, and catching the mad music of pleasure, wearing, one might fancy, her wine-stained robe and wreath of ivy, danced like a Bacchante over the hills of life, and mocked the slow Silenus for being sober. Facts fled before her like frightened forest things. Her white feet trod the huge press at which wise Omar sits, till the seething grape-juice rose round her bare limbs in waves of purple bubbles, or crawled in red foam over the vat’s black, dripping, sloping sides. It was an extraordinary improvisation. He felt that the eyes of Dorian Gray were fixed on him, and the consciousness that amongst his audience there was one whose temperament he wished to fascinate seemed to give his wit keenness and to lend colour to his imagination. He was brilliant, fantastic, irresponsible. He charmed his listeners out of themselves, and they followed his pipe, laughing. Dorian Gray never took his gaze off him, but sat like one under a spell, smiles chasing each other over his lips and wonder growing grave in his darkening eyes.
vi: He toyed with that idea, and gradually became obstinate; tossing it into the air and transforming it; letting it escape and then catching it again; making it shine brilliantly with imagination, then giving it wings with paradox. The praise of madness, as he continued, soared to the heights of philosophy, while Philosophy itself became youthful, catching the frenzied music of Pleasure, wearing, we might imagine, a wine-stained robe, crowned with ivy, dancing like a Bacchante across the hills of life, mocking the slow old god Silenus for not being drunk. Truths rushed past her like frightened wild animals.
