Her pure white feet trampled the enormous press on which wise Omar sat, until the fermenting grape juice rose around her bare limbs in waves of purple bubbles, or crawled in red foam over the steep, black, drenched sides of the vat. It was an extraordinary improvisation. He felt that Dorian Gray's eyes were fixed on him, and the awareness that among his audience there was someone possessing the temperament he wished to mesmerize seemed to sharpen his intellect and add color to his imagination. He was talented, eccentric, irresponsible. He lured his listeners out of themselves, and they followed his pipe laughing. Dorian Gray never took his eyes off him, but sat like one enchanted, smiles chasing each other on his lips, and wonder slowly turning to solemnity in his darkening eyes.
tr: Lord Henry became more and more excited as he toyed with this idea. He tossed the idea into the air, transforming it, letting it slip away only to catch it again, adorning it with fantasies and making it iridescent, attaching wings of contradiction to it. The praise he lavished on madness soon turned into a philosophy. Now the philosophy itself had rejuvenated, aligning with the wild music of pleasure and revelry; it seemed as though, dressed in a wine-stained garment and crowned with a laurel wreath, it danced like a Bacchus follower over the hills of life, mocking the slow Silenus for being sober. Truths fled before him, like timid forest animals. As his white feet trampled the grapes in wise Omar’s vat, the frothy grape juice rose around his bare legs in waves of purple bubbles, spilling over the wet, sloping, black edge of the vat as a flood of crimson foam. It was an astonishing improvisation! Lord Henry sensed that Dorian Gray’s eyes were fixed upon him, and knowing that there was someone among the listeners whom he wanted to dazzle seemed to sharpen his sense of humor and add color to his imagination. His speech was brilliant, incredible, and irresponsible. Enchanting his listeners, it was as if he drew them out of themselves, and they followed him merrily to the tune of his pipe. Dorian Gray sat there as if mesmerized, never taking his eyes off him, smiles chasing each other on his lips, and the astonishment and admiration in his increasingly darkening eyes deepening.
es: Lord Henry played with the idea, becoming more and more animated; he tossed it into the air and transformed it; he let it escape and recaptured it; he adorned it with all the fires of fantasy and gave it wings with paradox. The praise of folly, as Lord Henry continued, rose to the heights of philosophy, and philosophy itself became young and, infected by the unrestrained music of pleasure, dressed, one might imagine, in its wine-stained robe and an ivy garland, danced like a bacchante over the hills of life and mocked the placid Silenus for his sobriety. Facts fled before it like frightened little animals of the forest. Its alabaster feet trod the enormous winepress where the wise Omar holds court, until the rosy juice of the vine rose around its bare limbs in waves of purple bubbles, or slid in foam down the black sloping walls of the vat. It was an extraordinary improvisation. Lord Henry felt Dorian Gray's eyes fixed on him, and knowing that among those listening there was someone he wished to fascinate seemed to sharpen his wit and lend brighter colors to his imagination. He was brilliant, fantastic, irresponsible. He enchanted his listeners, making them forget themselves, and follow, laughing, the melody of his pipe. Dorian Gray never took his eyes off him, and remained motionless as if he were enchanted, smiles succeeding one another on his lips, while the astonishment in the depths of his eyes took on a thoughtful gravity.

en: At last, liveried in the costume of the age, reality entered the room in the shape of a servant to tell the duchess that her carriage was waiting. She wrung her hands in mock despair. “How annoying!” she cried. “I must go. I have to call for my husband at the club, to take him to some absurd meeting at Willis’s Rooms, where he is going to be in the chair. If I am late he is sure to be furious, and I couldn’t have a scene in this bonnet. It is far too fragile. A harsh word would ruin it. No, I must go, dear Agatha. Good-bye, Lord Henry, you are quite delightful and dreadfully demoralizing. I am sure I don’t know what to say about your views. You must come and dine with us some night. Tuesday? Are you disengaged Tuesday?”
vi: Finally, wearing the uniform of the era, Reality stepped into the room disguised as a servant to inform the duchess that her carriage was waiting. She twisted her hands, pretending to be disappointed. “How boring!” she exclaimed. “I have to go. I have to drop by to meet my husband at the club to take him to some silly meeting at Willis's rooms, where he will be presiding. If I am late, he will surely be furious, and I can't argue while wearing this beret. It's too delicate. A harsh word could ruin it. No, I must go, dear Agatha. Goodbye, Lord Henry, you are truly amusing, and so very decadent. I certainly don't know what to say about your views. You must come to dine with us some evening. Tuesday? Are you free on Tuesday?”
tr: In the end, reality, dressed in the uniform of the age, entered the room in the guise of a servant and informed the duchess that her carriage was waiting. The duchess, rubbing her hands with feigned helplessness, exclaimed, "How annoying!" "I have to go. I have to pick up my husband from the club and take him to a ridiculous meeting at Willis's house. He is to preside over the meeting. If I'm late, he will surely be angry. And I can't come to a quarrel with this hat on my head. It's a very delicate hat. It could be ruined by a harsh word. No, I must go, dear Agatha. Goodbye, Lord Henry, you are very sweet and demoralizing. I don't know what to say about your views. I invite you to dinner at our place one evening. How about Tuesday? Do you have any plans for Tuesday evening?"
es: Finally, covered in the livery of the time, reality entered the room in the form of a footman to announce that the duchess's carriage was waiting for her. The noble lady wrung her hands in feigned despair. —What a nuisance! —she exclaimed—. I have to leave. I have to pick up my husband at the club to take him to Willis's Rooms, where he has to preside over some absurd meeting. If I arrive late, he will undoubtedly be furious, and I can't risk a scene with this hat. It is too fragile. A harsh word would destroy it. No, I must go, my dear Agatha. Goodbye, Lord Henry, you are absolutely delightful and terribly demoralizing. Of course, I wouldn't know what to say about your ideas. You must come to dinner with us one of these nights. Tuesday? Are you free on Tuesday?

en: “For you I would throw over anybody, Duchess,” said Lord Henry with a bow.
vi: "For you, I could abandon anyone, Your Grace," Lord Henry said, with a bow.
tr: Lord Henry leaned in and said, "I would renounce all my words for you, Duchess."
es: —For you, Duchess, whom would I not do without? —replied Lord Henry, with a nod of his head.

en: “Ah! that is very nice, and very wrong of you,” she cried; “so mind you come”; and she swept out of the room, followed by Lady Agatha and the other ladies.
vi: "Ah! That is very charming and also very wrong on your part," she exclaimed; "so remember that;" and she quickly glided out of the room, followed by Mrs. Agatha and the other ladies.
tr: The Duchess said, "Oh, very sweet, very shameful!" "I am waiting, then." With that, he left the room with all his fuss. Lady Agatha and the other ladies followed him.
es: —Ah! Very kind and very cruel of you! —exclaimed the Duchess—; but don't forget to come —and she left the room followed by Lady Agatha and the other ladies.

en: When Lord Henry had sat down again, Mr. Erskine moved round, and taking a chair close to him, placed his hand upon his arm.
vi: When Lord Henry sat down again, Mr. Erskine walked around, brought a chair close to him, and placed his hand on his arm.
tr: When Lord Henry sat down, Mr. Erskine turned, sat close to him, and placed his hand on his arm.
es: When Lord Henry had sat down again, Mr. Erskine, walking around the table, and placing himself beside him, put a hand on his arm.

en: “You talk books away,” he said; “why don’t you write one?”
vi: “You say books fall short,” he said; “why don't you write one?”
tr: “You overshadow books with your words,” he said. “Why don't you sit down and write a book?”
es: —You talk a lot about books —he said—; why don't you write one?

en: “I am too fond of reading books to care to write them, Mr. Erskine. I should like to write a novel certainly, a novel that would be as lovely as a Persian carpet and as unreal. But there is no literary public in England for anything except newspapers, primers, and encyclopaedias. Of all people in the world the English have the least sense of the beauty of literature.”
vi: “I am too fond of reading books to care about writing them, Mr. Erskine. I like writing novels, of course; a novel as lovely as a Persian carpet, and just as unreal. But there is no literary market in England for anything except newspapers, primers, and encyclopedias. Of all the peoples in the world, the English have the least ability to appreciate the beauty of literature.”
tr: “Mr. Erskine, my love for books is so great that it prevents me from writing one. Although I would love to write a novel, as beautiful as a Persian carpet, and just as fictitious. However, in England, people read nothing but daily newspapers and encyclopedias! Among the peoples of the world, the English are the ones who understand the beauty of literature the least.”
es: —I like reading them too much to bother writing them, Mr. Erskine. Of course, I would like to write a novel, a novel that would be as charming and unreal as a Persian carpet. But in England, there is an audience only for newspapers, textbooks, and encyclopedias. There are no people in the whole world with less sense of literary beauty than the English.

en: “I fear you are right,” answered Mr. Erskine. “I myself used to have literary ambitions, but I gave them up long ago. And now, my dear young friend, if you will allow me to call you so, may I ask if you really meant all that you said to us at lunch?”
vi: “I'm afraid you are right,” Mr. Erskine replied. “I once had literary aspirations myself, but I set them aside long ago. And now, my dear young friend, if you will allow me to call you that, may I ask if you were truly serious about everything you said to us at lunch?”
tr: Mr. Erskine said, "I'm afraid you're right." "I once had literary ambitions myself, but I gave them up years ago. And now... If you allow me to call you my young friend... Were you serious about everything you said at dinner?"
es: —I am afraid you are right —replied Mr. Erskine—. I myself had literary ambitions, but I abandoned them long ago. And now, my young and dear friend, if you allow me to call you that, may I ask if you stand by everything you told us during lunch?

en: “I quite forget what I said,” smiled Lord Henry. “Was it all very bad?”
vi: “I have completely forgotten what I said,” Lord Henry laughed. “Were they all bad?”
tr: Lord Henry smiled, "I have completely forgotten what I said." "Did I say very bad things?"
es: —I have completely forgotten what I said —smiled Lord Henry—. Was it so immoral?

en: “Very bad indeed. In fact I consider you extremely dangerous, and if anything happens to our good duchess, we shall all look on you as being primarily responsible. But I should like to talk to you about life. The generation into which I was born was tedious. Some day, when you are tired of London, come down to Treadley and expound to me your philosophy of pleasure over some admirable Burgundy I am fortunate enough to possess.”
vi: “Very bad indeed. In fact, I consider you extremely dangerous, and if anything happens to our kind duchess, we will all look at you as the main person responsible. But I want to discuss life with you. The generation in which I was born is very boring. One day, when you are tired of London, come down to Treadley and explain to me your philosophy of pleasure while enjoying some excellent Burgundy wine that I am fortunate to possess.”
tr: “And very bad indeed. To be honest, in my eyes, you are a very dangerous person. If anything happens to our dear duchess, we will all see you as the main culprit. But I would like to talk to you about life. Our generation turned out to be quite boring. One day, when you get tired of London, come to Treadley. By chance, I have some very exquisite Burgundy wine. While sipping it, you can explain to me in detail this ‘philosophy of pleasure’ of yours.”
es: —Extremely immoral. In fact, I consider him extraordinarily dangerous, and if anything happens to our good duchess, we will hold him directly responsible. But I would like to talk to you about life. The generation I am part of is frankly boring. Someday, when you tire of London, come to Treadley, explain to me your philosophy of pleasure while we enjoy an excellent Burgundy that I am fortunate enough to possess.

en: “I shall be charmed. A visit to Treadley would be a great privilege. It has a perfect host, and a perfect library.”
vi: "I will be very delighted." "A visit to Treadley must be a great privilege." "A place with a perfect host, and a perfect library."
tr: "I would be very happy. I would consider it a great honor to come and see Treadley. He is a perfect host, and he has a perfect library."
es: —I will love it. A visit to Treadley will be a great privilege. It boasts a perfect host and an equally perfect library.

en: “You will complete it,” answered the old gentleman with a courteous bow. “And now I must bid good-bye to your excellent aunt. I am due at the Athenaeum. It is the hour when we sleep there.”
vi: “I will complete it to make it perfect,” the old man replied, with a polite bow. “And now I must say goodbye to your wonderful aunt. I have to go to the literary club. This is the time when we sleep there.”
tr: The elderly gentleman, with a polite bow, said, "You will complete Treadley." "Now I must bid farewell to your esteemed aunt. They are waiting for me at the Athenaeum Club. It is the time we sleep there now."
es: —Your presence will add a new charm —replied the elderly gentleman, with a courteous bow—. And now I must take my leave of your excellent aunt. I am expected at the Atheneum. It is the hour when we sleep there.

en: “All of you, Mr. Erskine?”
vi: “All of you, Mr. Erskine?”
tr: “All of you, Mr. Erskine?”
es: —All of them, Mr. Erskine?

en: “Forty of us, in forty arm-chairs. We are practising for an English Academy of Letters.”
vi: “Forty of us, in forty armchairs. We are training to establish a British Academy of Literature.”
tr: "Forty of us, all at forty seats. We are trying to establish an English literature academy."
es: —Forty, in forty armchairs. We are doing exercises for an English Academy of Letters.

en: Lord Henry laughed and rose. “I am going to the park,” he cried.
vi: Lord Henry laughed and stood up. "I'm going to the park," he exclaimed.
tr: Lord Henry stood up laughing. "I am going to the park," he said.
es: Lord Henry laughed, standing up. —I'm going to the park —he exclaimed.

en: As he was passing out of the door, Dorian Gray touched him on the arm. “Let me come with you,” he murmured.
vi: As he walked past the door, Dorian Gray touched his arm. "Let me go with you," he whispered.
tr: As he was leaving through the door, Dorian Gray touched his arm. "Allow me to come with you," he murmured.
es: As he passed through the door, Dorian Gray touched him on the arm. —Allow me to go with you —he murmured.

en: “But I thought you had promised Basil Hallward to go and see him,” answered Lord Henry.
vi: “But I thought you promised Basil Hallward to go see him,” Lord Henry replied.
tr: Lord Henry, "But I thought you promised to go see Basil Hallward," he said.
es: —I thought you had promised Basil Hallward that you would go see him —replied Lord Henry.

en: “I would sooner come with you; yes, I feel I must come with you. Do let me. And you will promise to talk to me all the time? No one talks so wonderfully as you do.”
vi: “I prefer to go with you; yes, I feel I must go with you. Please allow me. And will you promise to talk to me all the time? No one speaks as well as you.”
tr: “I would prefer to come with you. Yes, I feel like being with you. My dear, let me come with you. And promise me that you will talk to me without stopping. No one can talk as wonderfully as you.”
es: —I prefer to go with you; yes, I feel that I must go with you. Allow me. And promise to talk to me all the time. Nobody does it as well as you do.

en: “Ah! I have talked quite enough for to-day,” said Lord Henry, smiling. “All I want now is to look at life. You may come and look at it with me, if you care to.”
vi: "Ah! I've said quite enough for today already," Lord Henry said with a laugh. "All I want now is to observe life. You can come and observe it with me, if you like."
tr: Lord Henry smiled and said, "No, I've talked enough for today." "Now, my only desire is to watch life. If you want, you can come and watch it with me." 1. The general term used for the period's social guide (like a phone directory) is street slang.
es: —Ah! I have already spoken more than enough for today —said Lord Henry, smiling—. All I want now is to watch life. You can come and watch it with me, if you please.

en: CHAPTER IV.
vi: Chapter 4
tr: (Ç. N.) 2. One of Dionysus's drunken followers in Greek mythology, an ally of the satyrs. (Ç. N.) Fourth Chapter
es: Chapter 4

en: One afternoon, a month later, Dorian Gray was reclining in a luxurious arm-chair, in the little library of Lord Henry’s house in Mayfair. It was, in its way, a very charming room, with its high panelled wainscoting of olive-stained oak, its cream-coloured frieze and ceiling of raised plasterwork, and its brickdust felt carpet strewn with silk, long-fringed Persian rugs. On a tiny satinwood table stood a statuette by Clodion, and beside it lay a copy of Les Cent Nouvelles, bound for Margaret of Valois by Clovis Eve and powdered with the gilt daisies that Queen had selected for her device. Some large blue china jars and parrot-tulips were ranged on the mantelshelf, and through the small leaded panes of the window streamed the apricot-coloured light of a summer day in London.
vi: One afternoon, a month later, Dorian Gray sat resting on a luxurious armchair in the small library at Lord Henry's house in Mayfair. It was a very charming room, in its own way, with wainscoting of olive-stained oak panels, cream-colored pilasters, and a ceiling adorned with plaster reliefs, while the dusty-brick colored carpet was covered with long-fringed Persian silk rugs. On the tiny lacquered table stood a small Clodion statue, and next to it lay a copy of Les Cent Nouvelles, bound by Clovis Eve for Margaret of Valois, decorated with gilded daisies that the Queen herself had chosen for her emblem. Several large blue porcelain vases with parrot tulips lined the mantelpiece, and through the tiny leaded panes of the window streamed the ripe-apricot light of a London summer day.
tr: One afternoon, a month later, Dorian Gray was sitting, sunk into an extremely comfortable chair, in the small library of Lord Henry's house in Mayfair. This room, paneled with oak painted in olive color, with cream-colored cornices and ceiling decorations, and scattered with long-tasseled silk Persian prayer rugs on a brick-red carpet that covered the floor wall-to-wall, had a unique charm of its own. On a tiny table made of yellow Indian wood stood a small statue by Clodion, and next to it, a copy of Les Cent Nouvelles (The One Hundred New Stories). This book had been bound by Clovis Eve for Margaret of Valois, with gilded daisies chosen by the Queen herself scattered over it. On the mantelpiece, large vases of blue porcelain held tulips of various colors; the apricot-colored light of a summer day in London filtered through the small leaded panes of the window.
es: One afternoon, a month later, Dorian Gray was reclining in a luxurious armchair in the small library of Lord Henry's house in Mayfair. It was, in its style, a very pleasant room, with high olive-colored oak paneling, a cream-colored frieze, a plaster ceiling, and a brick-colored felt carpet, over which smaller silk Persian rugs with long fringes had been spread. On a tiny satinwood table, there was a statuette by Clodion and, next to it, a copy of Les Cent Nouvelles, bound for Marguerite de Valois by Clovis Eve and adorned with the daisies that the queen had chosen as her emblem. Some large blue porcelain vases with multicolored tulips occupied the mantelpiece, and through the leaded glass rectangles of the window, the apricot-colored light of a summer day in London poured in.

en: Lord Henry had not yet come in. He was always late on principle, his principle being that punctuality is the thief of time. So the lad was looking rather sulky, as with listless fingers he turned over the pages of an elaborately illustrated edition of Manon Lescaut that he had found in one of the book-cases. The formal monotonous ticking of the Louis Quatorze clock annoyed him. Once or twice he thought of going away.
vi: The lord has not yet returned. He is always late by principle, his principle being that punctuality is the thief of time. As a result, the young man seemed quite sulky, while he used his indifferent fingers to flip through the pages of an elaborately illustrated edition of Manon Lescaut that he found on one of the bookshelves. The monotonous ticking of the Louis XIV clock annoyed him. A couple of times he thought about leaving.
tr: Lord Henry had not arrived yet. He was deliberately late everywhere, as it was his principle to consider punctuality a theft of time. Therefore, Dorian Gray was sulking quite a bit as he reluctantly flipped through a very intricately illustrated copy of Manon Lescaut he found on one of the shelves. The monotonous ticking of the Louis Quatorze clock was also getting on his nerves. A couple of times, he even considered getting up and leaving.
es: Lord Henry had not returned yet. He was always late on principle, as, in his opinion, punctuality is the thief of time. So the boy seemed quite sulky as he distractedly flipped through the pages of a sumptuously illustrated edition of Manon Lescaut that he had found on one of the shelves. The solemn and monotonous ticking of the Louis XIV clock bothered him. Once or twice he thought about leaving.

en: At last he heard a step outside, and the door opened. “How late you are, Harry!” he murmured.
vi: Finally, he heard footsteps outside, and the door opened. "Why are you so late, Harry!" he muttered.
tr: Finally, he heard footsteps outside; the door opened. Dorian complained, "But you're late, Harry!"
es: Finally, he heard footsteps outside and the door opened. —How late you arrive, Harry! —he murmured.

en: “I am afraid it is not Harry, Mr. Gray,” answered a shrill voice.
vi: “I'm afraid it's not Harry, Mr. Gray,” a shrill voice replied.
tr: “Unfortunately, not Harry, Mr. Gray,” replied a shrill voice.
es: —I'm afraid it is not about Harry, Mr. Gray —responded a very sharp voice.

en: He glanced quickly round and rose to his feet. “I beg your pardon. I thought—”
vi: He quickly looked around and sat up. "I'm sorry. I thought..."
tr: The young man quickly turned his head and stood up. “I apologize. I didn't mean to...”
es: Dorian quickly turned, standing up. —I beg your pardon. I thought...

en: “You thought it was my husband. It is only his wife. You must let me introduce myself. I know you quite well by your photographs. I think my husband has got seventeen of them.”
vi: “You thought I was my husband. But I am just his wife. You should let me introduce myself. I know you quite well from your photos. I think my husband has seventeen of them in total.”
tr: "You thought I was my husband. But I'm only his wife! Allow me to introduce myself. I know you very well, from your photographs. I believe my husband has seventeen pictures of you."
es: —You thought he was my husband. I am only his wife. Allow me to introduce myself. I know you well from your photographs. I think my husband has seventeen.

en: “Not seventeen, Lady Henry?”
vi: “Isn't it seventeen, Miss Henry?”
tr: “There cannot be seventeen, Lady Henry!”
es: —No, Lady Wotton, not seventeen!

en: “Well, eighteen, then. And I saw you with him the other night at the opera.” She laughed nervously as she spoke, and watched him with her vague forget-me-not eyes. She was a curious woman, whose dresses always looked as if they had been designed in a rage and put on in a tempest. She was usually in love with somebody, and, as her passion was never returned, she had kept all her illusions. She tried to look picturesque, but only succeeded in being untidy. Her name was Victoria, and she had a perfect mania for going to church.
vi: “Ah, eighteen, that's it. And I saw you with him the other night at the opera house.” She laughed nervously as she spoke, and looked at him with absent-minded glassy eyes. She was a curious woman, her clothes always looked as if they were designed in a frenzy and worn in a storm. She often fell in love with someone, and, since her affections were never reciprocated, she retained all her illusions. She tried to appear impressive, but only succeeded in becoming shabby and unkempt. Her name was Victoria, and she was insanely addicted to going to church.
tr: “Eighteen, then.” “I saw you next to him at the opera last night.” The woman laughed nervously as she spoke, scrutinizing the young man with her azure, cloudy eyes. Her clothes always looked as if they had been designed during a fit of rage and worn amidst a whirlwind. She was always infatuated with someone, but since her love was never reciprocated, she never lost her dreams. She tried to appear different and striking, but unfortunately, she only managed to look disheveled. Her name was Victoria, and she had an irrepressible passion for going to church.
es: —Eighteen, then. And I saw them together the other night at the opera —she laughed nervously as she spoke, gazing at him with her blue, somewhat vague, forget-me-not eyes. She was a curious woman, whose dresses always gave the impression of having been designed in anger and worn in a storm. Ordinarily, she was in love with someone, and since her passion was never reciprocated, she had preserved all her illusions. She tried to achieve a picturesque appearance, but only managed to give an impression of untidiness. Her name was Victoria and she had the persistent obsession of going to church.

en: “That was at Lohengrin, Lady Henry, I think?”
vi: “I think it was at the Lohengrin performance, wasn't it, Miss Henry?”
tr: "It must be in Lohengrin, right, Lady Henry?"
es: —It was Lohengrin, if I remember correctly.

en: “Yes; it was at dear Lohengrin. I like Wagner’s music better than anybody’s. It is so loud that one can talk the whole time without other people hearing what one says. That is a great advantage, don’t you think so, Mr. Gray?”
vi: “Yes; it is because of dear Lohengrin. I prefer Wagner's music over anyone else's. It is so loud that we can talk the whole time without anyone else hearing what we say. That is a great advantage of it: don't you think so, Mr. Gray?”
tr: “Yes, dear, at Lohengrin. I love Wagner's music the most. It's so loud that one can talk from start to finish without others hearing what they say. Isn't that a great privilege, don't you think, Mr. Gray?”
es: —Yes, it was my dear Lohengrin. I like Wagner's music more than any other. It is so loud that you can talk all the time without other people hearing what is being said. That is a great advantage, don't you think, Mr. Gray?

en: The same nervous staccato laugh broke from her thin lips, and her fingers began to play with a long tortoise-shell paper-knife.
vi: The same nervous, abrupt laugh escaped from her thin lips, and her fingers began to play with a long paper knife made of tortoiseshell.
tr: From her thin lips once again spilled that abrupt, nervous laugh, and she began to play with a long, three-colored letter opener.
es: The same laugh, nervous and intermittent, escaped from the thin lips, and their fingers began to play with a tortoiseshell letter opener.

en: Dorian smiled and shook his head: “I am afraid I don’t think so, Lady Henry. I never talk during music—at least, during good music. If one hears bad music, it is one’s duty to drown it in conversation.”
vi: Dorin smiled and shook his head: "I'm afraid I don't think so, Miss Henry." "I never talk while listening to music, at least not when the music is good." "If someone has to listen to bad music, it's their duty to drown it out with conversation."
tr: Dorian shook his head with a smile. “I'm sorry, but I don't think so, Lady Henry. I never talk while listening to music. I mean, while listening to good music. When we hear bad music, it is our duty to drown it out by talking.”
es: Dorian smiled and shook his head. —I'm afraid I don't agree, Lady Wotton. I never speak when music is playing; at least, if it's good music. If the music is bad, it is our duty to drown it out with conversation.

en: “Ah! that is one of Harry’s views, isn’t it, Mr. Gray? I always hear Harry’s views from his friends. It is the only way I get to know of them. But you must not think I don’t like good music. I adore it, but I am afraid of it. It makes me too romantic. I have simply worshipped pianists—two at a time, sometimes, Harry tells me. I don’t know what it is about them. Perhaps it is that they are foreigners. They all are, ain’t they? Even those that are born in England become foreigners after a time, don’t they? It is so clever of them, and such a compliment to art. Makes it quite cosmopolitan, doesn’t it? You have never been to any of my parties, have you, Mr. Gray? You must come. I can’t afford orchids, but I spare no expense in foreigners. They make one’s rooms look so picturesque. But here is Harry! Harry, I came in to look for you, to ask you something—I forget what it was—and I found Mr. Gray here. We have had such a pleasant chat about music. We have quite the same ideas. No; I think our ideas are quite different. But he has been most pleasant. I am so glad I’ve seen him.”
vi: “Aha! That is one of Harry's views, isn't it, Mr. Gray? I always hear Harry's views from his friends. That's the only way I am familiar with them. But you shouldn't think that I don't like good music. I love it, but I fear it. It makes me too dreamy. I just adore pianists — two at a time, sometimes, that's what Harry tells me. I don't know what it is about them. Perhaps it's because they are foreigners. They all are, aren't they? Even those born in England become foreigners after a while, don't they? That is very wise of them, and quite a compliment to the art. Making it belong to the whole world, right? You have never attended any of my parties, have you, Mr. Gray? You should come. I can't afford orchids, but I don't mind spending on foreigners. They make the room look as pretty as a picture. But here is Harry! — Harry, I came to find you, to ask you something — I forgot what it was — and I found Mr. Gray here. We have been having a delightful conversation about music. We have exactly the same ideas. No; I think our ideas are completely different. But he is extremely pleasant. I am so glad I met him.”
tr: “Ha, this is one of Harry's views, isn't it, Mr. Gray? I always hear Harry's views from his friends. They only reach my ears this way. Don't think that I don't like good music. I love it but I also fear it. It gives me an excessive romanticism. There have been times when I literally worshipped pianists, sometimes even two pianists at once, according to Harry. I don't know what it is about pianists. Maybe it's their foreignness. They are all foreigners, aren't they? Even those born in England become foreigners after a while, don't they? They become very skillful, and this is always the skill of art. Art gains a cosmopolitan quality in this way... Mr. Gray, you have never come to my gatherings, have you? You should come. I don't have money to buy orchids, but when it comes to gathering foreigners in my salon, I spare no expense. They add such a picturesque atmosphere to the salons... Here comes Harry!.. Harry, I was looking for you, I wanted to ask you something but I forgot what it was, and here I found Mr. Gray. We had such a sweet chat about music. Our thoughts are almost identical. No, our thoughts seem quite opposite. But he is very charming. I'm so glad we met!”
es: —Ah! That is one of Harry's ideas, isn't it, Mr. Gray? I always hear Harry's ideas from the lips of his friends. That's how I find out they exist. But you mustn't think I don't like good music. I adore it, but it scares me. It makes me too romantic. I simply worship pianists; two at a time, on some occasions, Harry tells me. I don't know what it is about them. Perhaps it's that they are foreigners. They all are, aren't they? Even those born in England become foreigners over time, don't you think? What skill they have! And for art, what an excellent compliment! It makes it extremely cosmopolitan, doesn't it? Have you never been to one of my parties, Mr. Gray? You must come. I can't afford orchids, but I spare no expense with foreigners. They make the house look so picturesque! But here is Harry! Harry, I came looking for you to ask you something, I don't remember what, and I found Mr. Gray. We've had a very pleasant conversation about music. We have exactly the same ideas. No; I think our ideas are completely different. But he has been the epitome of kindness. And I am very glad to have met him.

en: “I am charmed, my love, quite charmed,” said Lord Henry, elevating his dark, crescent-shaped eyebrows and looking at them both with an amused smile. “So sorry I am late, Dorian. I went to look after a piece of old brocade in Wardour Street and had to bargain for hours for it. Nowadays people know the price of everything and the value of nothing.”
vi: “I am very delighted, my love, very delighted,” Lord Henry said, raising his crescent-shaped black eyebrows and looking at both of them with a joyful smile. “I am very sorry for being late, Dorian. I went to see an old gold-embroidered tapestry on Wardour Street, and had to bargain for a few hours for it. Nowadays people know the price of everything but the value of nothing.”
tr: Lord Henry raised his crescent-shaped dark eyebrows and, gazing at both with a pleasant smile, said, "I am very glad too, my dear, very glad." "Dorian, I am so sorry for being late. I went to Wardour Street to look at an old brocade and had to bargain for hours. Nowadays people know the price of everything but the value of nothing."
es: —Splendid, my love, splendid —said Lord Henry, raising the dark double crescent of his eyebrows and gazing at both with an amused smile. —I'm sorry for being late, Dorian. I went looking for a piece of antique brocade on Wardour Street, and I had to haggle for hours to get it. These days, people know the price of everything and the value of nothing.

en: “I am afraid I must be going,” exclaimed Lady Henry, breaking an awkward silence with her silly sudden laugh. “I have promised to drive with the duchess. Good-bye, Mr. Gray. Good-bye, Harry. You are dining out, I suppose? So am I. Perhaps I shall see you at Lady Thornbury’s.”
vi: "I'm afraid I have to go," Miss Henry exclaimed, breaking the awkward silence with her sudden silly laughter. "I promised to ride with the duchess." "Goodbye, Mr. Gray. Goodbye, Harry. I think you're going out to eat, aren't you? So am I." "Maybe I'll see you at Mrs. Thornbury's."
tr: Lady Henry broke the tense silence with her abrupt, meaningless laugh, saying, "It's a pity that I have to go!" "I promised the Duchess to go for a carriage ride. Goodbye, Mr. Gray. Goodbye, Harry. I suppose you are dining out tonight, aren't you? So am I. Perhaps we'll meet at Lady Thornbury's."
es: —I'm afraid I must be going —exclaimed Lady Wotton, breaking an awkward silence with her sudden senseless laughter—. I have promised to go out in the carriage with the Duchess. Goodbye, Mr. Gray. See you later, Harry. I imagine you are dining out. So am I. Perhaps I'll see you at Lady Thornbury's.

en: “I dare say, my dear,” said Lord Henry, shutting the door behind her as, looking like a bird of paradise that had been out all night in the rain, she flitted out of the room, leaving a faint odour of frangipanni. Then he lit a cigarette and flung himself down on the sofa.
vi: “Probably, my dear,” Lord Henry said, closing the door behind her, as she, looking like a bird of paradise that had spent the whole night in the rain, darted out of the room, leaving behind a faint scent of frangipani. After that, he lit a cigarette and sank into the sofa.
tr: Lord Henry said, "Maybe, my dear," and closed the door behind her. The woman, with the appearance of a Phoenix that had been in the rain all night, glided out of the room, leaving behind a faint scent of frangipani. Her husband lit a cigarette and threw himself onto a couch.
es: —I imagine so, my dear - Lord Henry closed the door behind her, when, looking like a bird of paradise that had spent the whole night in the rain, she fluttered out of the room, leaving a faint scent of almond cake; then he lit a cigarette and sank into the sofa.

en: “Never marry a woman with straw-coloured hair, Dorian,” he said after a few puffs.
vi: "Never marry a woman with straw-colored hair, Dorian," he said, after a few short breaths.
tr: After taking a few puffs from his cigarette, he said, "Dorian, never marry a woman with strawberry-colored hair!"
es: —Never marry a woman with straw-colored hair, Dorian —he said after blowing a few puffs of smoke.

en: “Why, Harry?”
vi: "Why is that, Harry?"
tr: “Why is that, Harry?”
es: —Why, Harry?

en: “Because they are so sentimental.”
vi: "Because they are very sentimental."
tr: “They become very emotional, that's why.”
es: —Because they are very sentimental.

en: “But I like sentimental people.”
vi: “But I like sentimental people.”
tr: “But I love emotional people!”
es: —But I like sentimental people.

en: “Never marry at all, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women, because they are curious: both are disappointed.”
vi: "Don't get married at all, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women because they are curious; both are disappointed."
tr: “Never marry, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired, women because they are curious. Both are disappointed.”
es: —Don't get married, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women, because they are curious: both end up disappointed.

en: “I don’t think I am likely to marry, Harry. I am too much in love. That is one of your aphorisms. I am putting it into practice, as I do everything that you say.”
vi: "I don't think I could ever get married, Henry. I am too heavily in love. That is one of your maxims. I have practiced it, as I always do with everything you say."
tr: “I have almost no chance of getting married, Harry. Because I am in love to the extent that I won't get married. Here is one of your aphorisms. Since I never go against your words, I am putting this into practice in my real life.”
es: —I don't think it's likely that I'll get married, Harry. I'm too much in love. That's one of your aphorisms. I'm putting it into practice, and I'm doing everything you recommend.

en: “Who are you in love with?” asked Lord Henry after a pause.
vi: "Who do you love?" Lord Henry asked, after a moment of silence.
tr: After a pause, Lord Henry asked, "Who are you in love with?"
es: —Who have you fallen in love with? —asked Lord Henry, after a pause.

en: “With an actress,” said Dorian Gray, blushing.
vi: “An actress,” Dorian Gray said, blushing.
tr: Dorian Gray blushingly replied, "To an actress."
es: —From an actress —said Dorian Gray, blushing.

en: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. “That is a rather commonplace début.”
vi: Lord Henry shrugged. "That was a rather mediocre début."
tr: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. "This is a very conventional beginning."
es: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. —It's a rather ordinary debut.

en: “You would not say so if you saw her, Harry.”
vi: "You probably wouldn't say that if you had seen her, Harry."
tr: "If you saw him, you wouldn't say that, Harry.""
es: —You wouldn't say that if you saw her, Harry.

en: “Who is she?”
vi: "Who is she?"
tr: "Who is this girl?"
es: —Who is it?

en: “Her name is Sibyl Vane.”
vi: "Her name is Sibyl Vane."
tr: “Her name is Sibyl Vane.”
es: —Her name is Sibyl Vane.

en: “Never heard of her.”
vi: “Never heard of her.”
tr: “I have never heard of it.”
es: —I've never heard of her.

en: “No one has. People will some day, however. She is a genius.”
vi: “No one ever has. But everyone will, one day. She is a genius.”
tr: “No one has heard. But when the day comes, everyone will hear. The girl is very talented.”
es: —No one has heard. But everyone will hear someday. He is a genius.

en: “My dear boy, no woman is a genius. Women are a decorative sex. They never have anything to say, but they say it charmingly. Women represent the triumph of matter over mind, just as men represent the triumph of mind over morals.”
vi: “My dear boy, there are no girls who are geniuses. Girls are the gender meant for display. They never have anything to say, but they speak very charmingly. Girls represent the triumph of matter over spirit, just as boys represent the triumph of spirit over morality.”
tr: “My dear child, no woman can be a great talent. Women are a gender created for adornment. They never have anything to say, but they say it very sweetly. Women symbolize the triumph of the physical over the mind, just as men symbolize the triumph of the mind over morality.”
es: —My dear boy, no woman is a genius. Women are a decorative sex. They never have anything to say, but they say it charmingly. They represent the triumph of matter over mind, in the same way that men represent the triumph of mind over morals.

en: “Harry, how can you?”
vi: "Harry, how could you?"
tr: “Harry, how can you talk like that?”
es: —How can you say such a thing, Harry?

en: “My dear Dorian, it is quite true. I am analysing women at present, so I ought to know. The subject is not so abstruse as I thought it was. I find that, ultimately, there are only two kinds of women, the plain and the coloured. The plain women are very useful. If you want to gain a reputation for respectability, you have merely to take them down to supper. The other women are very charming. They commit one mistake, however. They paint in order to try and look young. Our grandmothers painted in order to try and talk brilliantly. Rouge and esprit used to go together. That is all over now. As long as a woman can look ten years younger than her own daughter, she is perfectly satisfied. As for conversation, there are only five women in London worth talking to, and two of these can’t be admitted into decent society. However, tell me about your genius. How long have you known her?”
vi: “My dear Dorian, it is indeed so. I am analyzing women, so I should know. The subject is not as difficult to understand as I thought. I have discovered that, ultimately, there are only two kinds of women, monochromatic and polychromatic. Monochromatic women are very useful. If you want to appear respectable, you just need to take them out to dinner. The other type of women are very charming. However, they make one mistake. They wear makeup to try to look youthful. Our grandmothers wore makeup to try to speak well. Powder and wit used to go together. Now that is a thing of the past. As long as a woman can look ten years younger than her daughter, she is content. For conversation, there are only five women in London worth talking to, and two of them cannot be admitted into polite society. However, tell me about your genius. Have you known her long?”
tr: “Dear Dorian, it is very true, that's why. These days I am always studying women, so I should know. The subject is not as obscure as I thought. Now I see that there are two types of women, colorful and colorless. Colorless women are very useful. If you want to be known as honorable and decent, just take one of them out to dinner, that's enough. The other women are very attractive. However, they have one single flaw. They paint themselves in an effort to look young. Our grandmothers used to paint themselves in an effort to make bright speeches. Blush and humor went hand in hand in those days. But now that era is over. A woman is happy as long as she can look ten years younger than her own daughter. When it comes to conversation; there are only five women in London worth talking to... and you can't introduce two of them into your family circle. Anyway, tell me about your highly talented girl.” “Oh, Harry, your ideas terrify me.”
es: —My dear Dorian, it is nothing but the truth. I am analyzing women at the moment, so I must know. It is not as abstruse a subject as I thought. I find that, ultimately, there are only two kinds of women, the plain ones and those who paint themselves. The former are very useful. If you want to gain a reputation as a respectable person, just invite them to dinner. The other women are extremely charming. But they make a mistake. They paint themselves to look young. Our grandmothers painted themselves to try to speak brilliantly. Rouge and esprit used to go together. Now that is over. As long as a woman can look ten years younger than her daughters, she will be perfectly satisfied. As for conversation, there are only five women in London worth talking to, and two of them are not received by good society. Anyway, tell me about your genius. How long have you known her?

en: “Ah! Harry, your views terrify me.”
vi: “Oh! Harry, your perspective frightens me.”
tr: “Oh, Harry, your ideas terrify me.”
es: —Harry, Harry! Your opinions terrify me.

en: “Never mind that. How long have you known her?”
vi: "Don't pay attention to it." "Have you known her for long?"
tr: "Never mind now. How long have you known him?"
es: —Don't worry about that. How long have you known her?

en: “About three weeks.”
vi: "About three weeks."
tr: “It has been about three weeks.”
es: —About three weeks.

en: “And where did you come across her?”
vi: "And where did you run into her?"
tr: "Where did you meet?"
es: —And, how did you run into her?

en: “I will tell you, Harry, but you mustn’t be unsympathetic about it. After all, it never would have happened if I had not met you. You filled me with a wild desire to know everything about life. For days after I met you, something seemed to throb in my veins. As I lounged in the park, or strolled down Piccadilly, I used to look at every one who passed me and wonder, with a mad curiosity, what sort of lives they led. Some of them fascinated me. Others filled me with terror. There was an exquisite poison in the air. I had a passion for sensations.... Well, one evening about seven o’clock, I determined to go out in search of some adventure. I felt that this grey monstrous London of ours, with its myriads of people, its sordid sinners, and its splendid sins, as you once phrased it, must have something in store for me. I fancied a thousand things. The mere danger gave me a sense of delight. I remembered what you had said to me on that wonderful evening when we first dined together, about the search for beauty being the real secret of life. I don’t know what I expected, but I went out and wandered eastward, soon losing my way in a labyrinth of grimy streets and black grassless squares. About half-past eight I passed by an absurd little theatre, with great flaring gas-jets and gaudy play-bills. A hideous Jew, in the most amazing waistcoat I ever beheld in my life, was standing at the entrance, smoking a vile cigar. He had greasy ringlets, and an enormous diamond blazed in the centre of a soiled shirt. ‘Have a box, my Lord?’ he said, when he saw me, and he took off his hat with an air of gorgeous servility. There was something about him, Harry, that amused me. He was such a monster. You will laugh at me, I know, but I really went in and paid a whole guinea for the stage-box. To the present day I can’t make out why I did so; and yet if I hadn’t—my dear Harry, if I hadn’t—I should have missed the greatest romance of my life. I see you are laughing. It is horrid of you!”
vi: “I will tell you, Harry; but you must not be prejudiced against it. After all, it probably would never have happened if I hadn't met you. You made me feel a longing to know everything about life. For many days after I met you, something seemed to be throbbing in my veins. When I wandered aimlessly in the Park, or strolled down Piccadilly, I often looked at each person who passed me by, and wondered, with a mad curiosity, what kind of life they were living. Some of them fascinated me. Others made me feel afraid. There was some subtle poison in the air. I was enamored with strong emotions... So, one evening, around seven o'clock, I decided to go out and seek some adventure. I felt that our gray, gigantic city of London, with its myriad people, with its petty criminals, with its enthralling sins, as you once put it, must have something in store for me. I imagined a thousand things. The mere danger gave me a sense of delight. I remembered what you had said to me on that marvelous afternoon when we first dined together, that ‘the search for beauty is the true secret of life.’ I didn't know what I was waiting for, but I went out and wandered eastward, soon getting lost in a maze of grimy streets and dark squares without a blade of grass. Around half-past eight, I passed a ridiculous little theater, with great blazing gas lamps and gaudy posters. A hideous Jew, wearing the most astonishing waistcoat I had ever seen in my life, was standing at the entrance, smoking a vile cigar. He had greasy ringlets and a huge diamond blazing in the center of his soiled shirt. “Take a box, my lord?” he said, when he saw me, and took off his hat with a florid servility. There was something about him, Harry, that amused me. He was indeed a monster. You will laugh at me, I know, but I actually went in and paid a whole guinea for a box near the stage. To this day I cannot understand why I did it; yet if I hadn't — My dear Harry, if I hadn't, I would have missed the greatest romance of my life. I see you laughing. You are outrageous.
tr: “I will tell you, Harry. Just don't be negative about it. If I hadn't met you, I would never have met him either. You instilled in me a crazy desire to learn everything about living. After meeting you, it felt like my veins were beating like a heart for days. When I lingered in the park, walked down Piccadilly, I looked at everyone passing by, wondering what kind of life they were leading, with a mad curiosity. Some seemed to enchant me, some filled me with horror. There was a delicious poison in the air. I couldn't get enough of the excitement...Anyway, one evening around seven o'clock, I decided to go out and look for an adventure. I felt that London, as you once said; our gray, monstrous London with its disgusting sinners and magnificent sins, surely had something to offer me. I remembered what you told me on that wonderful night when we had our first dinner together: You said that the real secret of life is to pursue beauty. I don't know what I was expecting now. I went out and headed east. Soon I got lost among the intertwined filthy streets and dark, grassless areas. Around half-past eight, I passed in front of a tiny, ridiculous theater. There were huge flaming gas torches and flashy posters at its entrance. A Jew wearing the most astonishing waistcoat I had ever seen was standing at the entrance, puffing on a filthy leaf cigarette. His curly hair was greasy, and a diamond sparkled on the front of his dirty shirt. When he saw me, he took off his hat with magnificent obsequiousness and said, "Would you like a box, my lord?"Harry, there was something about this man that amused me. He was so grotesque! I know you'll mock me, but I went in, paid a full guinea for a first-class box. Why I did it, I still can't figure out today. But if I hadn't gone in...Dear Harry, if I hadn't gone in, I would have missed the greatest love adventure of my life. There, you're laughing. You're so wicked, Harry!”
es: —I'm going to tell you, Harry; but you have to be understanding. After all, it wouldn't have happened if I hadn't met you. You made me feel a tremendous desire to know everything about life. For several days after meeting you, something special was pulsing through my veins. While I was in the park or walking through Piccadilly, I looked at all the people I passed, wondering with tremendous curiosity what their lives were like. Some people fascinated me. Others filled me with horror. Exquisite poisons floated in the air. I felt a passion for sensations... Well, one afternoon, around seven, I decided to go out in search of some adventure. I felt that this London of ours, so gray and so monstrous, with its myriads of people, its sordid sinners and its splendid sins, as you once said, had something in store for me. I imagined a thousand things. The mere sensation of danger filled me with joy. I remembered what you had told me that wonderful evening when we dined together for the first time, about the fact that the pursuit of beauty is the true secret of life. I don't know what I was expecting, but I went out into the street and headed east, soon losing myself in a labyrinth of grimy streets and dark, grassless squares. Around eight-thirty, I passed by a ridiculous little theater, with bright lights and garish posters. At the entrance, there was a horrid Jew, with the most exotic waistcoat I have ever seen in my life, smoking a foul-smelling cigar. His hair fell in greasy curls, and in the middle of a dirty shirt, a huge diamond sparkled. "A box, milord?" he said when he saw me, and he took off his hat with a fascinatingly servile air. There was something about him that amused me, Harry. He was so monstrous! You're going to laugh at me, I know, but I went in and paid no less than a guinea for a box next to the stage. To this day, I still don't know why I did it; but if I hadn't, my dear Harry, I would have missed the great love story of my life. I see you're laughing. How bad that seems to me!

en: “I am not laughing, Dorian; at least I am not laughing at you. But you should not say the greatest romance of your life. You should say the first romance of your life. You will always be loved, and you will always be in love with love. A grande passion is the privilege of people who have nothing to do. That is the one use of the idle classes of a country. Don’t be afraid. There are exquisite things in store for you. This is merely the beginning.”
vi: “I am not laughing, Dorian; at least I am not laughing at you. But you should not talk about the greatest romantic affair of your life. You should talk about the first romantic affair of your life. You will always be loved, and you will always fall in love with your lover. A grande passion1 is the privilege of those who have nothing to do. It is a benefit of the idle classes of a nation. 1 A great passion. Don't be afraid. There are wonderful things already prepared for you. This is just the beginning."
tr: “I'm not laughing, Dorian, I mean, I'm not laughing at you. It's just that you shouldn't say it's the greatest love adventure of my life. You should say it's the first love adventure of my life. You will always be loved, you will always live as someone in love with love. To experience a grande passion is the privilege of those who have nothing to do. This is the benefit of having idle classes in a country. Don't be afraid. Wonderful things await you. This is just the beginning.”
es: —I'm not laughing, Dorian; at least, I'm not laughing at you. But you shouldn't say it's the great love story of your life. You should say it's the first. They will always love you, and you will always be in love with love. A great passion is the privilege of those who have nothing to do. That is the only utility of the idle classes of a country. Don't be afraid. Exquisite adventures are reserved for you. This is just the beginning.

en: “Do you think my nature so shallow?” cried Dorian Gray angrily.
vi: "Do you think that I am very shallow by nature?" Dorian Gray shouted, angry.
tr: Dorian Gray shouted angrily, "Do you think my nature is that shallow?"
es: —Do you consider me that superficial? —exclaimed Dorian Gray, very hurt.

en: “No; I think your nature so deep.”
vi: “No; I think your nature is very secretive.”
tr: "Yo, I think your creation is just this profound."
es: —No; I think you're very profound.

en: “How do you mean?”
vi: “What do you mean?”
tr: “What do you mean?”
es: —What do you mean?

en: “My dear boy, the people who love only once in their lives are really the shallow people. What they call their loyalty, and their fidelity, I call either the lethargy of custom or their lack of imagination. Faithfulness is to the emotional life what consistency is to the life of the intellect—simply a confession of failure. Faithfulness! I must analyse it some day. The passion for property is in it. There are many things that we would throw away if we were not afraid that others might pick them up. But I don’t want to interrupt you. Go on with your story.”
vi: “My dear boy, the person who loves only once in their life is truly shallow. What they call fidelity and honesty, I call a state of habitual coma or a lack of imagination. Loyalty in the realm of emotions is akin to consistency in the realm of intellect — simply an admission of failure. Loyalty! I will have to analyze it someday. The desire for possession lies within it. There are many things we would surely discard if we were not afraid that others might pick them up. But I don't want to interrupt you. Continue with your story.”
tr: “My dear child, those who love only once in their lives are the truly shallow ones. What they call loyalty and fidelity, I attribute either to the comfort of habit or to the lack of imagination. For emotional life, loyalty is what consistency is for intellectual life: a simple admission of defeat. Loyalty! I need to examine this one day. The passion for possession also plays a part in this. There are many things we would have discarded long ago if we weren't afraid others would take them. But I don't want to interrupt your story. Continue with your narration.”
es: —My dear boy, people who only love once in their lives are really the superficial ones. What they call their loyalty and fidelity, I call it the lethargy of routine or lack of imagination. Fidelity is to the life of emotions what coherence is to the life of the intellect: simply a confession of failure. Fidelity! I have to analyze it someday. The passion for ownership is in it. There are many things we would get rid of if we weren't afraid that others would pick them up. But I don't want to interrupt you. Continue with your story.

en: “Well, I found myself seated in a horrid little private box, with a vulgar drop-scene staring me in the face. I looked out from behind the curtain and surveyed the house. It was a tawdry affair, all Cupids and cornucopias, like a third-rate wedding-cake. The gallery and pit were fairly full, but the two rows of dingy stalls were quite empty, and there was hardly a person in what I suppose they called the dress-circle. Women went about with oranges and ginger-beer, and there was a terrible consumption of nuts going on.”
vi: "Then I found myself sitting in a dreadfully small private box, with a crude curtain hanging blatantly in front of me. I peeked out from behind the curtain and observed the theater. It was a gaudy affair, full of cupids and goat horns adorned with fruits, like a third-rate wedding cake. The gallery and the second tier were quite full, but the two rows of drab seats in front of the stage were completely empty, and there was hardly anyone in what I think they call the balcony. Women were walking around with oranges and ginger beer, and there was an enormous consumption of nuts taking place."
tr: “Anyway, I found myself in a terribly small box, with a very mediocre stage curtain right in front of me. I looked around the hall from behind the curtain of the box. It was a miserable place. It was decorated with Cupids and strange things. It wasn't very full. Women were walking around selling oranges and drinks, and it seemed like everyone was eating nuts.”
es: —Well, I found myself sitting in a dreadful little box, with the most vulgar curtain in front of my eyes. From my discreet hiding place, I set about examining the room. It was a perfectly tacky place, all cupids and cornucopias, like a fourth-rate wedding cake. The gallery and the stalls were quite full, but the first two rows of faded seats were completely empty and there were hardly any people in the best seats of the amphitheater. There were women selling oranges and refreshments, and large quantities of nuts were being consumed.

en: “It must have been just like the palmy days of the British drama.”
vi: “Surely it is just like the glorious days of English Theatre.”
tr: “The Golden Age of English Theatre, you say.”
es: —It must have been like in the glorious days of British drama.

en: “Just like, I should fancy, and very depressing. I began to wonder what on earth I should do when I caught sight of the play-bill. What do you think the play was, Harry?”
vi: “Exactly the same, I think so, and very boring. When I started to wonder what the heck I should do, I suddenly saw the advertisement poster. What do you think the play was called, Harry?”
tr: “Probably; it was giving a sense of collapse inside a person. I was pondering deeply about what to do when my eyes caught the program. Guess what the play was, Harry?”
es: —Precisely, I think, and very depressing. I was beginning to wonder what the hell I was doing there when I noticed the program. What play do you think they were performing, Harry?

en: “I should think ‘The Idiot Boy’, or ‘Dumb but Innocent’. Our fathers used to like that sort of piece, I believe. The longer I live, Dorian, the more keenly I feel that whatever was good enough for our fathers is not good enough for us. In art, as in politics, les grandpères ont toujours tort.”
vi: “I think it is ‘The Foolish Boy, or Silly but Innocent.’ Our ancestors often liked this type of work, I believe so. The longer I live, Dorian, the more deeply I feel that whatever was good enough for our ancestors is not good enough for us. In art, as in politics, les grandpères ont toujours tort1." 1 A detail from Hamlet.
tr: “If you ask me, I would say foolish child or silly and innocent. Our fathers used to love such games, I believe. Dorian, with each passing day, I understand a bit more that our fathers didn't know anything better than us. In politics as in art, les grand-peres ont toujours tort. Grandfathers are always wrong.”
es: —I imagine The Young Idiot or Dumb but Innocent. Our parents liked that kind of plays, I believe. The older I get, Dorian, the more convinced I am that what was good enough for our parents is not good enough for us. In art, as in politics, les grand-péres ont toujours tort.

en: “This play was good enough for us, Harry. It was Romeo and Juliet. I must admit that I was rather annoyed at the idea of seeing Shakespeare done in such a wretched hole of a place. Still, I felt interested, in a sort of way. At any rate, I determined to wait for the first act. There was a dreadful orchestra, presided over by a young Hebrew who sat at a cracked piano, that nearly drove me away, but at last the drop-scene was drawn up and the play began. Romeo was a stout elderly gentleman, with corked eyebrows, a husky tragedy voice, and a figure like a beer-barrel. Mercutio was almost as bad. He was played by the low-comedian, who had introduced gags of his own and was on most friendly terms with the pit. They were both as grotesque as the scenery, and that looked as if it had come out of a country-booth. But Juliet! Harry, imagine a girl, hardly seventeen years of age, with a little, flowerlike face, a small Greek head with plaited coils of dark-brown hair, eyes that were violet wells of passion, lips that were like the petals of a rose. She was the loveliest thing I had ever seen in my life. You said to me once that pathos left you unmoved, but that beauty, mere beauty, could fill your eyes with tears. I tell you, Harry, I could hardly see this girl for the mist of tears that came across me. And her voice—I never heard such a voice. It was very low at first, with deep mellow notes that seemed to fall singly upon one’s ear. Then it became a little louder, and sounded like a flute or a distant hautboy. In the garden-scene it had all the tremulous ecstasy that one hears just before dawn when nightingales are singing. There were moments, later on, when it had the wild passion of violins. You know how a voice can stir one. Your voice and the voice of Sibyl Vane are two things that I shall never forget. When I close my eyes, I hear them, and each of them says something different. I don’t know which to follow. Why should I not love her? Harry, I do love her. She is everything to me in life. Night after night I go to see her play. One evening she is Rosalind, and the next evening she is Imogen. I have seen her die in the gloom of an Italian tomb, sucking the poison from her lover’s lips. I have watched her wandering through the forest of Arden, disguised as a pretty boy in hose and doublet and dainty cap. She has been mad, and has come into the presence of a guilty king, and given him rue to wear and bitter herbs to taste of. She has been innocent, and the black hands of jealousy have crushed her reedlike throat. I have seen her in every age and in every costume. Ordinary women never appeal to one’s imagination. They are limited to their century. No glamour ever transfigures them. One knows their minds as easily as one knows their bonnets. One can always find them. There is no mystery in any of them. They ride in the park in the morning and chatter at tea-parties in the afternoon. They have their stereotyped smile and their fashionable manner. They are quite obvious. But an actress! How different an actress is! Harry! why didn’t you tell me that the only thing worth loving is an actress?”
vi: “This play is good enough for me, Harry. It is Romeo and Juliet. I must confess that I was quite annoyed with the idea of watching Shakespeare performed in such a shabby, miserable nook. However, I still found it somewhat interesting. Anyway, I decided to wait for the first act. There was a dreadful band, kept in tune by a young Hebrew man sitting by a broken piano, which almost drove me away, but finally the curtain rose, and the play began. Romeo was a fat old man, with eyebrows blackened with burnt cork, a hoarse tragic voice, and a body like a beer barrel. Mercutio was almost as bad. He was played by a low comedian, who inserted his own jokes and had a very friendly relationship with the second-class audience. Both of them were as ridiculous as the scenery, which looked as if it had appeared in a country fair theater. But Juliet! Harry, imagine a girl, just seventeen years old, with a small face as fresh as a flower, a Greek-style head, with dark brown braided hair, eyes like wells of passionate violet, lips like rose petals. She is the most lovely creature I have ever seen in my life. You once told me that pathos does not move you, but that beauty, only beauty, could bring tears to your eyes. I tell you, Harry, I could hardly see this girl because of the veil of tears that came across me. And her voice — I have never heard a voice like that. At first it was very soft, with deep sweet notes, as if each one was being poured into your ear. Then it became a little louder, and sounded like a distant flute or oboe. In the garden scene, it echoed with all the trembling ecstasy one hears just before dawn when the nightingale sings. There were moments, later, when it had the wild passion of a violin. You know how a voice can stir one. Your voice and Sibyl Vane's voice are the two that I will never forget. When I close my eyes, I hear them, and each says something different. I do not know which to follow. How could I not love her? Harry, I have loved her. To me, she is the most important thing in the world. Night after night, I go to see her perform. One night she is Rosalind, the next night she is Imogen. I have seen her die in the dim darkness of an Italian tomb, after sucking the poison from her lover's lips. I have watched her wander through the forest of Arden, disguised as a pretty boy in long hose and doublet, wearing a dainty cap. She has been mad, and has come to a guilty king, giving him rosemary to use, and rue to taste. She has been innocent, and the black hand of jealousy has strangled her reed-like throat. I have seen her in every age and in every costume. Ordinary women never appeal to one's imagination. They are limited to their century. No mystical charm ever elevates them. We understand their minds as easily as we understand their bonnets. We always find them. There is no mystery in any of them. They ride in the park in the morning, chatter at tea-parties in the afternoon. They have stereotyped smiles and fashionable manners. They are quite obvious. But an actress! How different an actress is! Harry! Why did you not tell me that the only thing worth loving is an actress?”
tr: “This play was also to our liking, Harry. It was Romeo and Juliet. I must admit that the idea of watching Shakespeare in this dingy hole initially irritated me. Still, I felt a strange interest. I was determined to at least watch the first act. There was a terrible orchestra; at the forefront, a young Jew playing a cracked piano. The music almost drove me away, but finally, the curtain on the stage opened, and the play began. Romeo was an old man with eyebrows painted with mushroom, a hoarse voice suitable for tragedies, and a build resembling beer barrels. Mercutio was almost as bad as him. A very vulgar comedian played this role. He had sprinkled his own invented lines and was very chummy with the orchestra members. Both actors were as shapeless as the stage decor, which looked like it was taken from a village fair... But Juliet!.. Harry, imagine a girl who is barely seventeen, tiny, with a face like a flower, a small head like in ancient Greek paintings, dark chestnut ringlets, eyes like deep purple wells of passion, lips like rose petals. She was the most beautiful thing I had ever seen in my life. Once, you told me that touching things didn't affect you, yet that beauty, just that beauty, could even bring tears to your eyes. Believe me, Harry, I could barely see the girl properly because of the tears in my eyes. And her voice! I had never heard such a voice in my life! At first, it came out very slowly, like deep, soft notes dropping one by one into your ear. Then, as it rose a bit more, it resembled a flute or the sound of an oboe heard from afar. In the garden scene, this voice reflected that trembling excitement heard when nightingales sing before dawn. Later, at times, it resonated with the wild passion of a violin. You know how voices can affect a person at times. If there are two things I will never forget in my life, they are your voice and the voice of Sibyl Vane. When I closed my eyes, I could hear these voices; both were saying different things. I don't know which one to listen to. Why shouldn't I love her, Harry? I love her. She is everything to me in life. Every night, I go to the theater to watch her. One night she is Rosalind, the next night Imogen. I saw her die in the dimness of an Italian cemetery, sucking the poison from her lover's lips. I saw her wander in the Forest of Arden, dressed as a beautiful young man in long stockings, knee breeches, and an elegant cap. Once, she went mad, stood before a guilty king, and gave him bitter herbs to taste. Once, she was innocent, yet the black hands of jealousy squeezed and crushed her swan-like neck. I have seen her in every guise, in every era. Ordinary people cannot affect our imagination. They are limited by their times. There is no magic to pull them out of their molds. We know the insides of their heads as well as their hats. We can easily find them. There is no mystery in any of them. They ride horses in the park in the mornings, chatter at tea parties in the afternoons. Their laughter is clichéd, their behavior is tailored to fashion. They are easily readable. But an actress! A woman who is an actress is so different! Harry, why didn't you tell me that the only thing worth loving is an actress?”
es: —The play was good enough for us, Harry. It was Romeo and Juliet. I must admit that I wasn't too thrilled about the idea of seeing Shakespeare performed in a place like that. But I was interested, nonetheless. I decided to at least watch the first act. There was a dreadful orchestra, led by a young Jew sitting at an out-of-tune piano that almost drove me out of the theater; but finally the curtain rose and the play began. Romeo was a burly gentleman with many years behind him, eyebrows painted with cork black, a hoarse tragic voice, and the silhouette of a beer barrel. Mercutio was almost equally sinister. He was played by a traveling comedian who had added his own jokes to the text and maintained extremely friendly relations with the audience. Both were as grotesque as the set, which looked like it came from a fairground booth. But, Juliet! Imagine a little girl of barely seventeen, with a flower-like face, a Greek-like head with dark brown hair braided, eyes that were violet wells of passion, lips like rose petals. The most enchanting creature I had ever seen! Once you told me that pathos didn't move you at all, but that beauty, simple beauty, could fill your eyes with tears. I assure you, Harry, I could hardly see that girl because my eyes were always clouded with tears. And her voice! I've never heard a voice like it. Just a thread at first, with low, melodious notes that seemed to fall one by one into the ear. Then it grew in volume, and sounded like a flute or a distant oboe. In the garden scene, it had all the trembling joy of nightingales when they sing just before dawn. There were moments later when it reached the unrestrained passion of violins. You know perfectly well how much a voice can affect us. Your voice and Sibyl Vane's are two things I will never forget. When I close my eyes, I hear them, and each says something different. I don't know which to follow. Why shouldn't I love her? I love her, Harry. She means everything to me. I go to see her act day after day. One night she is Rosalind and the next Imogen. I've seen her die in the gloom of an Italian tomb, taking poison from her lover's lips. I've watched her cross the Forest of Arden, disguised as a boy, in breeches, doublet, and a delightful cap. She has been the madwoman who appears before a guilty king, giving him rue to wear and bitter herbs to taste. She has been innocent, and the black hands of jealousy have crushed her reed-like neck. I've seen her in all ages and in all costumes. Ordinary women don't stir our imagination. They are anchored in their century. Fascination never transfigures them. You know what's in their heads as easily as if it were their hat. You always find them. There's no mystery in any of them. They go for walks in the park in the morning and chat in the afternoon at tea parties. They have a stereotyped smile and the manners of the moment. They are transparent. But an actress! How different an actress is, Harry! Why didn't you tell me that the only thing worth loving is an actress?

en: “Because I have loved so many of them, Dorian.”
vi: “Because I have loved many of them already, Dorian.”
tr: “Because I loved so many actresses, Dorian!”
es: —Because I have loved too many, Dorian.

en: “Oh, yes, horrid people with dyed hair and painted faces.”
vi: “Oh, yes, those scary girls, with dyed hair and painted faces.”
tr: "Ha, yes, disgusting people with dyed hair and painted faces.""
es: —Yes, of course; horrible people with dyed hair and painted faces.

en: “Don’t run down dyed hair and painted faces. There is an extraordinary charm in them, sometimes,” said Lord Henry.
vi: “Don't criticize dyed hair and painted faces. There is sometimes a strange charm in them,” Lord Henry said.
tr: “Do not scorn painted hair and painted face,” said Lord Henry. “Sometimes they can be extraordinarily attractive.”
es: —Do not disdain dyed hair and painted faces. Sometimes they have an extraordinary charm —said Lord Henry.

en: “I wish now I had not told you about Sibyl Vane.”
vi: “Now I just wish I hadn't told you about Sibyl Vane.”
tr: "I wish I hadn't told you about Sibyl Vane."
es: —Now I wish I hadn't told you anything about Sybil Vane.

en: “You could not have helped telling me, Dorian. All through your life you will tell me everything you do.”
vi: "You can't not tell me, Dorian. For the rest of your life, you will tell me everything you do."
tr: “You can't help but tell, Dorian. You will tell me everything you do for the rest of your life.”
es: —You couldn't have avoided it, Dorian. Throughout your life, you will tell me everything you do.

en: “Yes, Harry, I believe that is true. I cannot help telling you things. You have a curious influence over me. If I ever did a crime, I would come and confess it to you. You would understand me.”
vi: “Yes, Harry, I believe that's true. I can't help but tell you everything. You have a strange influence on me. If I ever commit a crime, I would come to confess it to you. You would understand me.”
tr: "Yes, I think it will be so, Harry. I can't help but tell you everything. You have a strange effect on me. Even if I committed a serious crime one day, I would come and confess to you. You would understand me."
es: —You are right, Harry; I think you are correct. I can't help but tell you things. You have a curious influence over me. If I ever committed a crime, I would come to confess it to you. You would understand.

en: “People like you—the wilful sunbeams of life—don’t commit crimes, Dorian. But I am much obliged for the compliment, all the same. And now tell me—reach me the matches, like a good boy—thanks—what are your actual relations with Sibyl Vane?”
vi: “People like you — the stubborn rays of life — will not commit crimes, Dorian. But I still very much appreciate the compliment, nonetheless. Now tell me — pass me the matches, please, thank you: — what is your actual relationship with Sibyl Vane?”
tr: “People like you – the sunbeams of life – do not commit serious crimes, Dorian. Nevertheless, thank you very much for the compliment. Now tell me... Would you be so kind as to pass the match? Thank you... What is the nature of your relationship with Sibyl Vane?”
es: —People like you, the whimsical rays of sunshine in life, do not commit crimes. But, anyway, I am very grateful to you for that compliment. And now tell me... hand me the matches, like a good boy, thank you... What are your current relations with Sybil Vane?

en: Dorian Gray leaped to his feet, with flushed cheeks and burning eyes. “Harry! Sibyl Vane is sacred!”
vi: Dorian Gray jumped up, his cheeks red, his eyes blazing. "Harry! Sibyl Vane is sacred!"
tr: Dorian Gray blushed, his eyes blazing with anger as he jumped to his feet. "Harry! Sibyl Vane is sacred!"
