es: Dorian Gray jumped to his feet, his cheeks flushed and his eyes blazing. —Harry! Sybil Vane is sacred!

en: “It is only the sacred things that are worth touching, Dorian,” said Lord Henry, with a strange touch of pathos in his voice. “But why should you be annoyed? I suppose she will belong to you some day. When one is in love, one always begins by deceiving one’s self, and one always ends by deceiving others. That is what the world calls a romance. You know her, at any rate, I suppose?”
vi: “Only sacred things are worth touching, Dorian,” Lord Henry said, with a strange touch of excitement in his voice. “But why are you upset? I suppose she will belong to you one day. When we love, we always begin by deceiving ourselves, and we always end by deceiving others. That is what the world calls romance. You are already acquainted with her, anyway, I think, aren't you?”
tr: Lord Henry said, "Only sacred things are worth touching." There was a strange sadness in his voice. "Why are you angry? Surely the girl will be yours one day. When a person falls in love, they always start by deceiving themselves and end by deceiving others. This is what our world calls romance... I suppose you have at least met her, haven't you?"
es: —Only sacred things deserve to be touched, Dorian —said Lord Henry, with a strange note of pathos in his voice—. But why do you have to get angry? I suppose it will be yours someday. When you are in love, you start by deceiving yourself and end up deceiving others. That is what the world calls a love story. At least, you know her personally, I imagine.

en: “Of course I know her. On the first night I was at the theatre, the horrid old Jew came round to the box after the performance was over and offered to take me behind the scenes and introduce me to her. I was furious with him, and told him that Juliet had been dead for hundreds of years and that her body was lying in a marble tomb in Verona. I think, from his blank look of amazement, that he was under the impression that I had taken too much champagne, or something.”
vi: "Of course, I knew her. On the first night I was at the theater, that dreadful old Jew came by my box after the performance ended and offered to take me backstage and introduce me to her. I was furious with him, telling him that Juliet had been dead for hundreds of years, and that her body was lying in a marble tomb in Verona. From the stunned look on his face, I thought he had the impression that I had drunk too much champagne or was on something."
tr: “Of course I did. The first night I went to the theater, that old Jew came to my box at the end of the play and suggested taking me backstage to introduce me to her. I was very angry with him. I said, Juliet has been dead for hundreds of years, lying in a marble tomb in Verona. From the bewildered look on his face, I understood that he thought I had had too much champagne.”
es: —Of course I know her. The first night I was at the theater, the horrible old Jew came to the box after the performance ended and offered to take me backstage and introduce me to her. He managed to infuriate me, and I told him that Juliet had been dead for hundreds of years and that her body lay in Verona, in a marble tomb. From the look of astonishment he gave me, I think he got the impression that I had drunk too much champagne or something like that.

en: “I am not surprised.”
vi: “I am not surprised.”
tr: “I never waver.”
es: —It doesn't surprise me.

en: “Then he asked me if I wrote for any of the newspapers. I told him I never even read them. He seemed terribly disappointed at that, and confided to me that all the dramatic critics were in a conspiracy against him, and that they were every one of them to be bought.”
vi: “Then he asked me if I wrote for any newspaper. I told him that I had never even read them. He seemed terribly disappointed by that, and confided in me that all the theater critics were part of a conspiracy against him, and that they were all bought.”
tr: “Then he asked me if I was a journalist. I told him that I didn't read newspapers. When he heard this, he was very disappointed, obviously. He told me that all theater critics were conspiring against him, and that they were all, without exception, for sale.”
es: —Then he asked me if I wrote for any newspaper. I told him that I never read them. He seemed terribly disappointed to hear that, and he confessed to me that all the theater critics were hostile to him and that they could all be bought.

en: “I should not wonder if he was quite right there. But, on the other hand, judging from their appearance, most of them cannot be at all expensive.”
vi: “I wouldn't be surprised if he was completely right on this point. But, on the other hand, judging by their appearance, most of them probably aren't worth much either.”
tr: “If he is right in what he says, I wouldn't be surprised. But on the other hand, if you look at most of their appearances, they shouldn't be very expensive.”
es: —It wouldn't surprise me if you were right about that. But, on the other hand, judging by the way most of them look, they can't be too expensive.

en: “Well, he seemed to think they were beyond his means,” laughed Dorian. “By this time, however, the lights were being put out in the theatre, and I had to go. He wanted me to try some cigars that he strongly recommended. I declined. The next night, of course, I arrived at the place again. When he saw me, he made me a low bow and assured me that I was a munificent patron of art. He was a most offensive brute, though he had an extraordinary passion for Shakespeare. He told me once, with an air of pride, that his five bankruptcies were entirely due to ‘The Bard,’ as he insisted on calling him. He seemed to think it a distinction.”
vi: “Yes, he seems to think they are beyond his capability,” Dorian laughed. “However, by then the lights in the theater started to go out and I had to leave. He wanted me to try a few cigars that he enthusiastically recommended. I refused. The next night, of course, I went back there. When he saw me, he bowed deeply to greet me, and assured me that I was a generous patron of the arts. He was an extremely repulsive brute, yet he harbored a particular passion for Shakespeare. Once he told me, with a proud look, that his five bankruptcies were all due to the ‘Bard,’ as he insisted on calling him. He seemed to think it was a mark of respect.”
tr: Dorian laughed, "I don't know, I think he found those critics too expensive for his own pocket." "By the way, I left because the theater's lights were starting to be turned off. The Jew wanted to offer me a leaf cigarette, he strongly recommended this brand. I didn't take it. But the next night I returned there, naturally. When the Jew saw me, he bowed down to the ground and said that I was a generous patron of the arts. He was truly an annoying fellow, but he had an unprecedented passion for Shakespeare. Once, he proudly told me that he had gone bankrupt five times, and all five bankruptcies were because of Shakespeare. He seemed to view this as a privilege."
es: —Well; but he seems to think they are beyond his means —laughed Dorian—. By then, however, they were already turning off the theater lights and I had to leave. The Jew wanted me to try some cigars which he praised highly. But I declined his offer. The next night, I returned, of course. Upon seeing me, he made a deep bow and assured me that I was a munificent patron of the arts. He is an insufferable being, but Shakespeare is his passion. He has already told me, visibly proud, that his five bankruptcies were entirely due to "the Bard," as he insists on calling him. He seems to consider it a badge of honor.

en: “It was a distinction, my dear Dorian—a great distinction. Most people become bankrupt through having invested too heavily in the prose of life. To have ruined one’s self over poetry is an honour. But when did you first speak to Miss Sibyl Vane?”
vi: “It is an honor, my dear Dorian — a great honor. Most people go bankrupt from investing too heavily in the struggle for existence. Going bankrupt because of poetry is a distinction. But when did you first speak to Miss Sibyl Vane?”
tr: “It is a privilege, dear Dorian, a great privilege. Most people go bankrupt because they invest too much in the prose of life. To go bankrupt because of poetry is an honor... But when did you first speak to Miss Sibyl Vane?”
es: —It is, my dear Dorian; a true badge of glory. Most people ruin themselves by investing too much in the prose of life. To be ruined by poetry is an honor. When did you first speak with Miss Sybil Vane?

en: “The third night. She had been playing Rosalind. I could not help going round. I had thrown her some flowers, and she had looked at me—at least I fancied that she had. The old Jew was persistent. He seemed determined to take me behind, so I consented. It was curious my not wanting to know her, wasn’t it?”
vi: “The third night. At that time she was playing the role of Rosalind. I couldn't help but go around to the back. I threw her some flowers, and she looked at me; at least I imagined she did. The old Jew was very persistent. He seemed determined to follow me, so I agreed. Isn't it strange that I didn't want to get to know her?”
tr: “The third night. She was playing Rosalind. I couldn't stop myself from going backstage. I had thrown her a few flowers, and she had looked at me, or rather, it seemed to me that she had looked. The old Jew kept insisting. He was determined to take me backstage, and I yielded. Wasn't it strange that I didn't want to meet this girl, don't you think?”
es: —The third night. She had played Rosalind. It was impossible for me not to go see her. I had thrown some flowers to her and she looked at me; at least, I imagined she had. The old Jew insisted. He was determined to take me backstage, so I agreed. It's curious that I didn't want to meet her, don't you think?

en: “No; I don’t think so.”
vi: "No; I don't think so."
tr: “No, I don't think so.”
es: —No; it doesn't seem curious to me.

en: “My dear Harry, why?”
vi: “My dear Harry, why?”
tr: “Dear Harry, but why?”
es: —Why, my dear Harry?

en: “I will tell you some other time. Now I want to know about the girl.”
vi: “I will tell you another time. Now I want to know about this girl.”
tr: “I'll tell you another time. Now I want to learn about this girl.”
es: —I'll tell you some other time. Now I want to know more about that girl.

en: “Sibyl? Oh, she was so shy and so gentle. There is something of a child about her. Her eyes opened wide in exquisite wonder when I told her what I thought of her performance, and she seemed quite unconscious of her power. I think we were both rather nervous. The old Jew stood grinning at the doorway of the dusty greenroom, making elaborate speeches about us both, while we stood looking at each other like children. He would insist on calling me ‘My Lord,’ so I had to assure Sibyl that I was not anything of the kind. She said quite simply to me, ‘You look more like a prince. I must call you Prince Charming.’”
vi: “Sibyl? Oh, she is so very shy, so very gentle. There is something of a child in her. Her eyes opened wide in utter amazement when I told her what I thought of her performance, and she seemed completely unaware of her own talent. I think both of us were quite nervous. The old Jew stood grinning at the entrance to the dusty greenroom, uttering polished phrases about both of us, while we stood looking at each other like children. He insisted on calling me 'lord,' so I had to assure Sibyl that I had nothing to do with such people. She told me very simply, 'You look more like a prince. I should call you Prince Charming.'”
tr: “Sibyl, my dear? Ah, she is so shy, so gentle! She already has a childlike air about her. When I told her how much I liked her performance, her eyes opened wide with a delightful disbelief and pleasure. She seemed unaware of the power of her influence. I think we were both feeling a bit awkward. The old Jew stood at the door of that dusty dressing room, grinning from ear to ear, while he showered us with grandiose words, and we stood there like two children, looking at each other. The man kept insisting on calling me ‘My Lord.’ So I had to tell Sibyl that I wasn’t a lord at all. And with a completely unaffected simplicity, she said, ‘You look more like a prince than a lord; it would be fitting to call you Sweet Prince.’”
es: —Sybil? So shy and so kind! There is something childlike about her. She opened her eyes wide with the most sincere astonishment when I told her what I thought of her performance, and she seemed to have no awareness of her talent. I think we were both quite nervous. The old Jew smiled from the door of the dusty dressing room, saying elaborate phrases about the two of us, while Sybil and I looked at each other like children. The old man insisted on calling me "mylord," and I had to explain to Sybil that I was nothing of the sort. She said to me: "You rather look like a prince. I will call you Prince Charming."

en: “Upon my word, Dorian, Miss Sibyl knows how to pay compliments.”
vi: “I swear on my honor, Dorian, Miss Sibyl knows how to compliment very well.”
tr: "My goodness, Dorian, Miss Sibyl knows how to compliment.""
es: —By my faith, Dorian, Miss Sybil knows how to give compliments.

en: “You don’t understand her, Harry. She regarded me merely as a person in a play. She knows nothing of life. She lives with her mother, a faded tired woman who played Lady Capulet in a sort of magenta dressing-wrapper on the first night, and looks as if she had seen better days.”
vi: “You don't understand her, Harry. She sees me as just a character in a play. She knows nothing about life. She lives with her mother, a weary and withered woman, who plays Lady Capulet wearing a kind of dark crimson cloak on the first night, and looks as if she has seen better days.”
tr: “You can't understand him, Harry. He only saw me as a character in a play. He doesn't know life at all! He lives with his mother. His mother is an elderly, tired woman. The first night I went, she played Lady Capulet in a kimono-like purple garment. She seems to have been well-off but has now fallen on hard times.”
es: —You don't understand, Harry. She saw me only as a character in a play. She knows nothing about life. She lives with her mother, a worn-out and fatigued woman who, in a more or less crimson robe, played Lady Capulet on the first night; a woman who looks like she has seen better days.

en: “I know that look. It depresses me,” murmured Lord Henry, examining his rings.
vi: "I know this look. It discourages me," Lord Henry muttered, scrutinizing his rings.
tr: Lord Henry, examining the rings on his fingers, murmured, "I know those types, they bore me."
es: —I know that look. It depresses me —murmured Lord Henry, examining his rings.

en: “The Jew wanted to tell me her history, but I said it did not interest me.”
vi: “The old Jew wanted to tell me her background, but I told him I wasn't interested.”
tr: “The Jew wanted to tell me his life story, but I said, I'm not interested.”
es: —The Jew wanted to tell me his story, but I told him I wasn't interested.

en: “You were quite right. There is always something infinitely mean about other people’s tragedies.”
vi: “You are absolutely right. There is always something incredibly pathetic about other people's tragedies.”
tr: “You did the right thing. There is always something extremely ugly and bitter in the tragedies of others.”
es: —You were absolutely right. There is always something infinitely petty in the tragedies of others.

en: “Sibyl is the only thing I care about. What is it to me where she came from? From her little head to her little feet, she is absolutely and entirely divine. Every night of my life I go to see her act, and every night she is more marvellous.”
vi: “Sibyl is the only thing I care about. What does it matter to me where she comes from? From her small head to her tiny feet, she is absolutely and completely divine. Every night of my life, I go to see her performance, and each night she is more marvelous.”
tr: “The only thing I care about is Sibyl. I don't care about her lineage or background. From her tiny head to her tiny feet, she is entirely, utterly a marvelous creature. Every night of the week, I go to watch her on stage, and every night I find her more wonderful.”
es: —Sybil is the only thing that interests me. What do I care where she came from? From her little head to her tiny feet, she is absolutely and entirely divine. Night after night I go to see her perform, and each night she does better than the last.

en: “That is the reason, I suppose, that you never dine with me now. I thought you must have some curious romance on hand. You have; but it is not quite what I expected.”
vi: “I believe that is the reason why you never go out to dinner with me these days. I think you must have some strange romantic affair on your hands already. You did; but it was not what I expected.”
tr: “I suppose this is why you haven't been going out to eat with me lately. I had a feeling you were having an interesting romantic adventure. Indeed, it turned out to be true, but this adventure was different from what I had imagined.”
es: —I imagine that's the reason you never have dinner with me anymore. I thought, and I was right, that perhaps you had some curious love story on your hands. But it's not exactly what I imagined.

en: “My dear Harry, we either lunch or sup together every day, and I have been to the opera with you several times,” said Dorian, opening his blue eyes in wonder.
vi: “My dear Harry, we still have lunch or dinner together every day, and I have been to the opera with you a few times,” Dorian said, opening his wide blue eyes in astonishment.
tr: “Dear Harry, we have lunch or dinner together almost every day, and I have come to the opera with you many times,” Dorian Gray replied, opening his blue eyes in astonishment.
es: —My dear Harry, you and I have lunch or dinner together every day; and I have gone to the opera with you several times —said Dorian, opening his eyes wide to show his astonishment.

en: “You always come dreadfully late.”
vi: “You always arrive terribly late.”
tr: “You are always terribly late.”
es: —You always arrive terribly late.

en: “Well, I can’t help going to see Sibyl play,” he cried, “even if it is only for a single act. I get hungry for her presence; and when I think of the wonderful soul that is hidden away in that little ivory body, I am filled with awe.”
vi: “Yes, I cannot help but go see Sibyl perform,” he exclaimed, “even if it is just a single act. I crave her figure; and when I think of the wondrous soul hidden within that petite, exquisite body, my heart is filled with fear.”
tr: The young man shouted, "What should I do!" "I can't help but go to see Sibyl's play, even if it's just for a single act! I feel like I'm starving to see her. Especially when I think about the marvelous soul hidden in that ivory body, I feel a sense of awe."
es: —I can't stop watching Sybil perform —he exclaimed—, even if I only see the first act. I feel the need for her presence; and when I think of the marvelous soul hidden in that little ivory body, I am filled with wonder.

en: “You can dine with me to-night, Dorian, can’t you?”
vi: "Can you have dinner with me tonight, Dorian?"
tr: “You will come to dinner with me tonight, won't you, Dorian?”
es: —You're having dinner with me tonight, aren't you?

en: He shook his head. “To-night she is Imogen,” he answered, “and to-morrow night she will be Juliet.”
vi: He shook his head. "Tonight she is Imogen," he replied, "and tomorrow night she will be Juliet."
tr: Dorian nodded his head. "Tonight Sibyl is Imogen," he replied. "Tomorrow night she is Juliet."
es: Dorian Gray shook his head. —Today she plays Imogen —he replied—, and tomorrow night she will be Juliet.

en: “When is she Sibyl Vane?”
vi: “So when is she Sibyl Vane?”
tr: “When do I become Sibyl Vane?”
es: —When is Sybil Vane?

en: “Never.”
vi: "Never."
tr: “Never.”
es: —Never.

en: “I congratulate you.”
vi: "Congratulations to you."
tr: “Congratulations to you.”
es: —I congratulate you.

en: “How horrid you are! She is all the great heroines of the world in one. She is more than an individual. You laugh, but I tell you she has genius. I love her, and I must make her love me. You, who know all the secrets of life, tell me how to charm Sibyl Vane to love me! I want to make Romeo jealous. I want the dead lovers of the world to hear our laughter and grow sad. I want a breath of our passion to stir their dust into consciousness, to wake their ashes into pain. My God, Harry, how I worship her!” He was walking up and down the room as he spoke. Hectic spots of red burned on his cheeks. He was terribly excited.
vi: “Why are you so unreasonable! She is all the great heroines of the world combined into one. She is more than a single individual. You laugh, but I tell you: she is a genius. I love her, and I must make her love me. You, who know all the secrets of life, show me how to enchant Sibyl Vane so that she loves me! I want to make Romeo jealous. I want the past lovers of this world to hear our laughter and become sad. I want a breath of our passion to stir their dust into consciousness, to awaken their ashes in the realm of pain. God, Harry, why do I adore her so!” He paced back and forth in the room as he spoke. Feverish red spots burned on his cheeks. He was terribly agitated.
tr: “How disgusting you are, Harry! Sibyl is the combination of all the great female heroines of the world. She is something beyond the individual. You laugh, but I'm telling you, she is a great talent. I love her, and I must make her love me too. You, who know all the secrets of life, tell me, what spell should I cast to make Sibyl Vane love me? I want to make Romeo jealous. I want the dead lovers of history to hear our laughter and feel sorrow. I want a breath of our fire to give life to their soil, to awaken their ashes and make them suffer. My God, if you only knew how I worship her, Harry!” Dorian was pacing back and forth in the room while talking. Red spots, like the fever of a fever, were burning on his cheeks. The young man was extremely excited.
es: —How wicked you are! Sybil is all the great heroines of the world in one. She is more than a single person. You laugh, but I repeat to you that she is wonderful. I love her, and I must make her love me. You, who know all the secrets of life, tell me how to enchant Sybil Vane so that she loves me. I wish to make Romeo jealous. I want all the dead lovers to hear our laughter and be saddened. I want a breath of our passion to stir their dust, awaken their ashes, and make them suffer. Heavens, Harry, how I adore her! —he was moving from one side of the room to the other as he spoke. Red spots, like fever, burned on his cheeks. He was terribly excited.

en: Lord Henry watched him with a subtle sense of pleasure. How different he was now from the shy frightened boy he had met in Basil Hallward’s studio! His nature had developed like a flower, had borne blossoms of scarlet flame. Out of its secret hiding-place had crept his soul, and desire had come to meet it on the way.
vi: Lord Henry observed him with a subtle sense of satisfaction. How different he was now from the shy, frightened boy he had once met in Basil Hallward's studio! His nature had blossomed like a flower, had bloomed in vivid red. His soul had slipped out of its secret hiding place, and Desire was on its way to meet it.
tr: Lord Henry was watching him with a secret pleasure. How different this Dorian was from the shy, timid boy he had seen in Basil Hallward's studio! His personality had blossomed like a flower, with crimson flame buds. His soul had emerged from its hidden place, and desire had met it halfway.
es: Lord Henry felt a secret pleasure in watching him. How different he was already from the timid and frightened boy he had met in Basil Hallward's studio! He had matured, producing flowers of scarlet fire. From its secret hiding place, his soul had come out into the world, and Desire had come to meet it along the way.

en: “And what do you propose to do?” said Lord Henry at last.
vi: “And what do you intend to do?” Lord Henry said, finally.
tr: Lord Henry asked finally, "Well, what do you plan to do?"
es: —And, what do you intend to do? —said Lord Henry finally.

en: “I want you and Basil to come with me some night and see her act. I have not the slightest fear of the result. You are certain to acknowledge her genius. Then we must get her out of the Jew’s hands. She is bound to him for three years—at least for two years and eight months—from the present time. I shall have to pay him something, of course. When all that is settled, I shall take a West End theatre and bring her out properly. She will make the world as mad as she has made me.”
vi: “I want you and Basil to come with me one night to see her perform. I am not in the least bit afraid of the outcome. You will surely acknowledge her talent. After that, we must get her out of that Jew's hands. She is bound by a contract with him for three years — at least for two years and eight months — from now. I will have to pay him something, of course. When everything is settled, I will rent the West End theater and present her properly. She will drive the whole world crazy as she has done to me.”
tr: “Come one night with Basil, see his play, I want you to. I have no fear at all of the outcome. You will acknowledge his superior talent, this is certain. Then I must save him from that Jew’s hands. He is bound to him by a three-year contract, which means two years and eight months from today. I will have to pay the Jew something, naturally. Once these things are settled, I will rent a theater in West End and properly introduce Sibyl. She will enchant the whole world, just as she has enchanted me.”
es: —I want Basil and you to come with me some night to see her perform. I have no fear of the outcome. Without a doubt, you will recognize her genius. Then we must rescue her from the hands of that old Jew. She is bound to him for three years, at least two years and eight months from now. I will have to pay him something, of course. When everything is settled, I will bring her to some theater in the West End and present her as she deserves. She will drive the world mad as she has driven me mad.

en: “That would be impossible, my dear boy.”
vi: "That is impossible, my boy?"
tr: “This is unbelievable, my dear.”
es: —That is impossible, my friend!

en: “Yes, she will. She has not merely art, consummate art-instinct, in her, but she has personality also; and you have often told me that it is personalities, not principles, that move the age.”
vi: "Yes, she will be able to do it. She not only has art, an exquisite artistic inclination within her, but she also has personality; and he often tells me that it is personality, not principles, that moves the ages."
tr: “Yes, she will enchant. What Sibyl has is not only artistic talent, a perfect artistic instinct, but also personality. You have told me many times that it is not principles but personalities that influence the age.”
es: —She will do it. There is not only art in her, consummate art and instinct; she also has personality; and you have often told me that it is personalities, not principles, that move our age.

en: “Well, what night shall we go?”
vi: “Alright, so which night shall we go?”
tr: “So, which night are we going?”
es: —Alright; which night will we go?

en: “Let me see. To-day is Tuesday. Let us fix to-morrow. She plays Juliet to-morrow.”
vi: "Let me see. Today is Tuesday. Let's finalize it for tomorrow. Tomorrow you will play Juliet."
tr: “Wait a minute. Today is Tuesday. Let's say tomorrow. Sibyl is playing Juliet tomorrow.”
es: —Let me see. Today is Tuesday. Let's meet tomorrow. Tomorrow she plays Juliet.

en: “All right. The Bristol at eight o’clock; and I will get Basil.”
vi: “Alright. Bristol, at eight o'clock; and I will bring Basil along.”
tr: “Okay. At eight o'clock in Bristol. I'll pick up Basil.”
es: —Agreed. At the Bristol at eight; I will bring Basil.

en: “Not eight, Harry, please. Half-past six. We must be there before the curtain rises. You must see her in the first act, where she meets Romeo.”
vi: “Not eight o'clock, Harry, please. Six-thirty. I have to be there before the curtain rises. You have to see her in the first act, when she meets Romeo.”
tr: “Not eight, Harry, please, six-thirty. I must be there before the curtain rises. You have to see her in the first act, when she meets Romeo.”
es: —Not at eight, Harry, I beg you. At six-thirty. We have to be there before the curtain rises. You have to see her in the first act, when she meets Romeo.

en: “Half-past six! What an hour! It will be like having a meat-tea, or reading an English novel. It must be seven. No gentleman dines before seven. Shall you see Basil between this and then? Or shall I write to him?”
vi: “Six-thirty! What kind of time is this! It's no different than having meat tea or reading an English novel. It has to be seven o'clock. No decent person has dinner before seven o'clock. Will you meet Basil between this hour and the next? Or should I write to him?”
tr: “Half past six, ha! What a strange hour! It's like drinking broth instead of tea or reading an English novel. Let's make it seven. No gentleman dines before seven. Will you see Basil in the meantime, or should I write a note?”
es: —Six thirty! What a time! It would be like having a tea-dinner or reading an English novel. It has to be at seven. No gentleman dines before seven. Should I see Basil between now and tomorrow? Or will it be enough to write to him?

en: “Dear Basil! I have not laid eyes on him for a week. It is rather horrid of me, as he has sent me my portrait in the most wonderful frame, specially designed by himself, and, though I am a little jealous of the picture for being a whole month younger than I am, I must admit that I delight in it. Perhaps you had better write to him. I don’t want to see him alone. He says things that annoy me. He gives me good advice.”
vi: "Dear Basil! I haven't laid eyes on him all week." "It's a bit excessive on my part, as he sent me my portrait in a beautiful frame, specially designed by himself, and, although I'm a bit jealous of the painting for being a whole month younger than me, I must admit I am delighted with it." "Perhaps it's better if you write to him." "I don't want to meet him alone." "He will say things that annoy me." "He keeps giving me good advice."
tr: "Dear Basil! It has been a week since I last saw him. It was very rude of me because he sent me my portrait, in a wonderful frame that he designed himself. Although I am jealous because he is a month younger than me, I must admit that I love this portrait. Maybe it would be better if you wrote. I don't want to be alone with him. He always says things that irritate me: He gives me very appropriate advice."
es: —Good old Basil! I haven't laid eyes on him for a week. I'm very embarrassed because he sent me the painting with a magnificent frame, specially designed by him, and although I'm a bit jealous of the portrait for being a month younger than me, I must admit that it amazes me to see it. Maybe it's better if you write to him, I don't want to be alone with him. He says things that annoy me. He insists on giving me good advice.

en: Lord Henry smiled. “People are very fond of giving away what they need most themselves. It is what I call the depth of generosity.”
vi: Lord Henry laughed. "People love to give away what they need most themselves. That is what I call the height of generosity."
tr: Lord Henry smiled. “People love to get rid of the things they need. I call it the height of generosity.”
es: Lord Henry smiled. —People love to give away what they need the most. It is what I call the unfathomable abyss of generosity.

en: “Oh, Basil is the best of fellows, but he seems to me to be just a bit of a Philistine. Since I have known you, Harry, I have discovered that.”
vi: “Oh, Basil is the best friend, but to me, he seems a bit old-fashioned. Since I met you, Harry, I have realized that.”
tr: “No, Basil is a really good man, but he seems a bit unrefined to me. After getting to know you, I realized this, Harry.”
es: —No, no; Basil is the best of people, but somewhat prosaic. I discovered this after meeting you, Harry.

en: “Basil, my dear boy, puts everything that is charming in him into his work. The consequence is that he has nothing left for life but his prejudices, his principles, and his common sense. The only artists I have ever known who are personally delightful are bad artists. Good artists exist simply in what they make, and consequently are perfectly uninteresting in what they are. A great poet, a really great poet, is the most unpoetical of all creatures. But inferior poets are absolutely fascinating. The worse their rhymes are, the more picturesque they look. The mere fact of having published a book of second-rate sonnets makes a man quite irresistible. He lives the poetry that he cannot write. The others write the poetry that they dare not realize.”
vi: “Basil, my dear boy, has put all his charm into his work. As a result, he has nothing left to live on but prejudices, principles, and intellect. The only artists I have ever known who are personally delightful are bad artists. A good artist lives wholly in what he creates, and consequently has no life in anything else. A great poet, a really great poet, is the most unpoetical of all creatures. But inferior poets are absolutely fascinating. The worse their rhymes, the more picturesque they look. The mere fact of having published a second-rate sonnet makes a man quite irresistible. He lives the poetry that he cannot write. The others write the poetry that they dare not realize.”
tr: “Dear child, Basil channels all the charming aspects of his personality into his work. As a result, all that remains for his life are his prejudices, principles, and common sense. Among the artists I know, those who are charming in everyday life are only the bad artists. Good artists exist solely in their works, and as a result, their personalities remain dull. The great poet, the truly great poet, is the one who is the furthest from poetry among all creatures. However, third and fourth-rate poets are interesting. The worse their poetry, the more striking their appearance. Having published a second-rate sonnet book is enough to make a person utterly unbearable. This man lives the poetry he cannot write. The others, the real poets, write as poetry what they dare not achieve in life.”
es: —Basil, my dear boy, puts all his best qualities into his work. The consequence is that for life he is left with only prejudices, principles, and common sense. The only charming artists I know are bad artists. The good ones exist only in what they do and, consequently, are completely uninteresting as people. A great poet, a truly great poet, is the least poetic of all creatures. But the lesser poets are absolutely fascinating. The worse their rhymes, the more picturesque their appearance. The mere fact of having published a second-rate book of sonnets makes a man absolutely irresistible. He lives the poetry he is incapable of writing. The others write the poetry they do not dare to enact.

en: “I wonder is that really so, Harry?” said Dorian Gray, putting some perfume on his handkerchief out of a large, gold-topped bottle that stood on the table. “It must be, if you say it. And now I am off. Imogen is waiting for me. Don’t forget about to-morrow. Good-bye.”
vi: “I wonder if that is really true, Harry?” Dorian Gray said, dabbing some perfume on his handkerchief from a rather large gold-capped bottle that was still on the table. “It must be, if you say so. Now I must go. Imogen is waiting for me. Don't forget about tomorrow. Goodbye.”
tr: Dorian, "I don't know, Harry, is it really like that?" he said, applying some perfume from the large bottle with the golden stopper onto his handkerchief. "It must be, since you say so. Now I am leaving. Imogen is waiting. Don't forget about tomorrow, okay? Goodbye."
es: —I wonder if it is really so, Harry —said Dorian Gray, pouring a bit of perfume from a large bottle with a golden stopper that was on the table onto his handkerchief—. It must be, if you say so. And now I have to leave. Imogen is waiting for me. Don't forget about tomorrow. See you later.

en: As he left the room, Lord Henry’s heavy eyelids drooped, and he began to think. Certainly few people had ever interested him so much as Dorian Gray, and yet the lad’s mad adoration of some one else caused him not the slightest pang of annoyance or jealousy. He was pleased by it. It made him a more interesting study. He had been always enthralled by the methods of natural science, but the ordinary subject-matter of that science had seemed to him trivial and of no import. And so he had begun by vivisecting himself, as he had ended by vivisecting others. Human life—that appeared to him the one thing worth investigating. Compared to it there was nothing else of any value. It was true that as one watched life in its curious crucible of pain and pleasure, one could not wear over one’s face a mask of glass, nor keep the sulphurous fumes from troubling the brain and making the imagination turbid with monstrous fancies and misshapen dreams. There were poisons so subtle that to know their properties one had to sicken of them. There were maladies so strange that one had to pass through them if one sought to understand their nature. And, yet, what a great reward one received! How wonderful the whole world became to one! To note the curious hard logic of passion, and the emotional coloured life of the intellect—to observe where they met, and where they separated, at what point they were in unison, and at what point they were at discord—there was a delight in that! What matter what the cost was? One could never pay too high a price for any sensation.
vi: When he left the room, Lord Henry's heavy eyelids drooped, and he began to think. Surely, only a few people had ever interested him as much as Dorian Gray, yet the young man's mad adoration for someone else did not cause him the slightest pang of jealousy or distress. He was pleased with this. It made him a more interesting subject for study. He had always been fascinated by the methods of natural science, but the usual subjects of that science seemed to him trivial and unimportant. So he had begun with the vivisection of himself, as he had ended with the vivisection of others. Life — it appeared to him as something to be studied minutely. Nothing else seemed to be of any value in comparison. Indeed, when one looks at life in its strange crucible of pain and pleasure, one cannot wear a mask to shield the face, nor keep the fumes of sulfur from tormenting the brain, and clouding the imagination with monstrous fancies and distorted dreams. There are subtle poisons so exquisite that to know their properties one has to fall ill from them. There are strange maladies so bizarre that one has to go through them to understand their nature. Yet, how great the reward will be! How wonderful the world will become to us! To remember the strange, relentless logic of passion, and the multicolored life of the intellect — to observe where they meet, where they part, at what points they harmonize, at what points they are at odds — there is a pleasure in that! What does the cost matter? Perhaps we have never paid too high a price for any sensation.
tr: When Dorian went out, Lord Henry closed his heavy eyelids and began to ponder. The fact was that there were very few people who interested him as much as Dorian Gray did. Yet, the young lord felt not the slightest jealousy or annoyance that the boy was madly infatuated with someone else. On the contrary, he found it pleasing. This passion made Dorian Gray more interesting, more worthy of study. Lord Henry had always harbored a deep curiosity about the natural sciences, though he found their ordinary subjects trivial and insignificant. Thus, he began by examining himself under the microscope, eventually turning to dissect and study others. Human life: this was the only thing worth examining in Lord Henry's eyes. Nothing could be as valuable. Indeed, while the observer watched life in the test tube filled with a mixture of pains and joys, he could not wear a glass mask, nor could he prevent the poisonous vapors from affecting his brain, causing his imagination to throb with strange fantasies and shapeless dreams. There were such insidious poisons that one had to be poisoned by them to discern their qualities. Yet, in the end, how magnificent a reward this examination gave to a person! How marvelous the world became in one's eyes! To notice the strange, rigid logic of passion and the experiences of the mind tinged with sentimentality, to observe where these two converged, where they diverged, where they reconciled, and where they clashed... What a great delight was hidden in this! Who cared about the cost? No excitement's price was too high.
es: When Dorian Gray left the room, Lord Henry closed his eyes and began to think. Certainly, few people had interested him as much as Dorian Gray, although the boy's excessive adoration for another person did not cause him the slightest twinge of annoyance or jealousy. On the contrary, he liked it. It made him a more interesting object of study. He had always been fascinated by the methods of the natural sciences, but not by their usual subject matter, which seemed trivial and unimportant to him. So he had started by performing vivisection on himself and had ended up doing it to others. Human life was the only thing that seemed worthy of investigation to him. Compared to that, nothing else had the slightest value. Although if one contemplated life in its curious crucible of pain and pleasure, it was not possible to cover one's face with a crystal mask, nor to prevent the sulfurous vapors from altering the brain and clouding the imagination with monstrous fantasies and deformed dreams. There were poisons so subtle that to know their properties one had to fall ill with them. And diseases so strange that it was necessary to suffer from them to understand their nature. How great, however, was the reward received! How wonderful the whole world became! To perceive the peculiar inflexible logic of passion, and the life of the intellect emotionally colored; to observe where they met and where they separated, at what point they functioned in unison and at what point discordances arose: what great pleasure was thus obtained! What did the price matter? One never paid too much for sensations.

en: He was conscious—and the thought brought a gleam of pleasure into his brown agate eyes—that it was through certain words of his, musical words said with musical utterance, that Dorian Gray’s soul had turned to this white girl and bowed in worship before her. To a large extent the lad was his own creation. He had made him premature. That was something. Ordinary people waited till life disclosed to them its secrets, but to the few, to the elect, the mysteries of life were revealed before the veil was drawn away. Sometimes this was the effect of art, and chiefly of the art of literature, which dealt immediately with the passions and the intellect. But now and then a complex personality took the place and assumed the office of art, was indeed, in its way, a real work of art, life having its elaborate masterpieces, just as poetry has, or sculpture, or painting.
vi: He realized — and the thought brought a gleam of delight into his agate-brown eyes — that thanks to some words of his, melodious words spoken with a melodious accent, Dorian Gray's soul had turned towards this pure white girl and bowed reverently before her. To a very large extent, the young man was his own creation. He had fashioned him a bit prematurely. There was some rightness in that. Ordinary people would wait until life revealed its secrets to them, but for a few, for those chosen, the mysteries of life would unveil themselves before the veil was lifted. Sometimes it is the influence of art, and primarily of literary art, which has a direct connection with passion and intellect. But occasionally, a complex personality takes the place and assumes the role of art; for indeed, in its own way, being a true work of art, Life has its elaborate masterpieces, just as poetry, or sculpture, or painting does.
tr: Lord Henry was aware –and knowing this gave a gleam of pleasure to his agate-colored eyes– that because of some words he had said, words spoken in a melodious voice, Dorian Gray's soul had turned towards this lily-like girl, had bowed before her. The boy was largely his creation. Lord Henry had developed him early. That was something. Ordinary people waited for life to reveal its secrets to them. However, to a handful of select individuals, life's secrets were revealed before the curtain even rose. Sometimes this happened under the influence of art, especially literature; because literature deals directly with passions and the mind. Sometimes a complex personality would take the place of art, assuming its role, in short, becoming a true work of art in its own right. Life, just like poetry, sculpture, and painting, has its meticulously created masterpieces.
es: He knew perfectly well—and the idea produced a gleam of pleasure in his agate eyes—that thanks to certain words of his, musical words spoken in a musical manner, the soul of Dorian Gray had turned towards that white young girl and had bowed in adoration before her. To a great extent, that boy was his creation. He had accelerated his maturity, which was not insignificant. Ordinary people waited for life to unveil its secrets to them, but for a few, for the chosen ones, life revealed its mysteries before lifting the veil. This was sometimes a consequence of art, and especially of the art of literature, which deals immediately with passions and intelligence. But every now and then a complex personality took its place and assumed the functions of art, and was, in fact, in its own way, a true work of art, because, like poetry, sculpture, or painting, life has refined masterpieces.

en: Yes, the lad was premature. He was gathering his harvest while it was yet spring. The pulse and passion of youth were in him, but he was becoming self-conscious. It was delightful to watch him. With his beautiful face, and his beautiful soul, he was a thing to wonder at. It was no matter how it all ended, or was destined to end. He was like one of those gracious figures in a pageant or a play, whose joys seem to be remote from one, but whose sorrows stir one’s sense of beauty, and whose wounds are like red roses.
vi: Yes, the young man is a bit inexperienced. He harvested the winter crop while it was still spring. The pulse of youthful passion still beats within him, but he has begun to develop self-awareness. It is truly interesting to observe him. With a beautiful face and a beautiful soul, he is a creature of wonder. It doesn't matter how things end, or what fate has decreed for the end. He is like one of those compassionate characters in a magnificent procession or a play, whose joys seem very distant from us, yet whose sorrows evoke our capacity to appreciate beauty, and whose wounds are like roses.
tr: Yes, the young man had matured ahead of his time. He was reaping his harvest in the spring. He was filled with the speed and fire of youth and was beginning to become aware of his own existence. It was a great pleasure to observe him. That beautiful face, with his beautiful soul, the young man was truly something unbelievable. Who cares how the end will come, or what is written on his forehead? He resembled characters from a stage play, from a carnival: You know, their joys seem distant from us, their sorrows caress our sense of beauty, and their wounds bleed like red roses.
es: Yes; the teenager was precocious. He was harvesting still in spring. He had within him the heartbeat and passion of youth, but he was beginning to reflect on it all. It was delightful to watch him. With his beautiful face and equally beautiful soul, he was a source of wonder. It didn't matter how it all ended or how it was destined to end. He was like one of those charming figures in a parade or a play, whose joys seem very distant to us, but whose sorrows awaken our sense of beauty, and whose wounds are like red roses.

en: Soul and body, body and soul—how mysterious they were! There was animalism in the soul, and the body had its moments of spirituality. The senses could refine, and the intellect could degrade. Who could say where the fleshly impulse ceased, or the psychical impulse began? How shallow were the arbitrary definitions of ordinary psychologists! And yet how difficult to decide between the claims of the various schools! Was the soul a shadow seated in the house of sin? Or was the body really in the soul, as Giordano Bruno thought? The separation of spirit from matter was a mystery, and the union of spirit with matter was a mystery also.
vi: The soul and the body, the body and the soul — how mysterious they are! There is animal instinct in the soul, and the body has its moments of spirituality. Sensations can be refined, while intellect can degenerate. Who can say where the urge of lust ends, or the natural impulse begins? How shallow are the arbitrary definitions of mediocre psychologists! Yet, it is very difficult to choose between the assertions of different schools of thought! Is the soul the shadow sitting in the house of sin? Or is the body truly within the soul, as Giordano Bruno once thought? The separation of spirit from matter is a mystery, and the union of spirit with matter is just as much a mystery.
tr: Spirit and body, body and spirit: How mysterious they were! The spirit could become animalistic, and the body could at times become spirit. What the emotions exalted, the mind could disdain. Who could know where the physical impulse ended and the bodily impulse began? How shallow were the haphazard definitions of ordinary psychologists! On the other hand, how difficult it was to choose among the claims of various psychological schools! Was the spirit a shadow residing within the house of sin? Or was the body actually within the spirit, as Giardano Bruno thought? The separation of the spirit from matter was a mystery, just as the union of the spirit with matter was a mystery.
es: Soul and body, body and soul, how mysterious they were! There was animalism in the soul, and the body had its moments of spirituality. The senses could be refined and the intelligence degraded. Who could say where the carnal impulse ceased or the psychic one began? How superficial were the arbitrary definitions of ordinary psychologists! And yet, how difficult it was to take a stance between the assertions of the different schools! Was the soul a ghost that inhabited the house of sin? Or did the body truly merge with the soul, as Giordano Bruno thought? The separation between spirit and matter was a mystery, and the union of spirit with matter was also one.

en: He began to wonder whether we could ever make psychology so absolute a science that each little spring of life would be revealed to us. As it was, we always misunderstood ourselves and rarely understood others. Experience was of no ethical value. It was merely the name men gave to their mistakes. Moralists had, as a rule, regarded it as a mode of warning, had claimed for it a certain ethical efficacy in the formation of character, had praised it as something that taught us what to follow and showed us what to avoid. But there was no motive power in experience. It was as little of an active cause as conscience itself. All that it really demonstrated was that our future would be the same as our past, and that the sin we had done once, and with loathing, we would do many times, and with joy.
vi: Y began to wonder if it was possible to turn psychology into a pure science so that every small crack in life would be exposed before us. However, we always misunderstand ourselves and rarely understand others. Experience has no moral value at all. It is merely the name people give to their mistakes. Ethicists, as usual, see it as a warning method, demand a certain moral efficacy in character formation for it, and praise it as something that teaches us what to pursue and shows us what to avoid. But there is no motivation in experience. It has as little positive purpose as conscience itself. All it truly proves is that our future will be no different from our past, and the sin we once committed with disgust, we will continue to commit many times more, but with joy.
tr: Lord Henry had begun to wonder: Was it within our power to turn psychology into an absolutely precise and definitive science, thereby ensuring that even the smallest springs of life were laid bare? In that case, we were always misunderstanding ourselves and rarely understanding others. What was called experience had no ethical value. It was merely a name people gave to their mistakes. Moralists generally considered it a kind of warning, claimed it had an ethical benefit in the development of personality, and boasted that it was a sign of what to follow and what to avoid. However, there was no driving force in experience. The active role it played was as insignificant as the role of conscience. The only truth it revealed was that our future would be equal to our past; we would commit the sin we once committed with disgust many times in the future, and this time with pleasure.
es: He began to wonder if psychology would ever become such an exact science that it could reveal to us the very last spring of life. Meanwhile, we always make mistakes about ourselves and rarely understand others. Experience lacks ethical value. It is simply the name men give to their errors. Generally, moralists consider it a warning, claim for it some ethical efficacy in character formation, and praise it as something that teaches us which path to follow and which abysses to avoid. But experience lacks determining force. It has as little active cause as conscience itself. The only thing it really proves is that our future will be the same as our past, and that the sin we have committed once, and with bitterness, we will repeat many times, and with joy.

en: It was clear to him that the experimental method was the only method by which one could arrive at any scientific analysis of the passions; and certainly Dorian Gray was a subject made to his hand, and seemed to promise rich and fruitful results. His sudden mad love for Sibyl Vane was a psychological phenomenon of no small interest. There was no doubt that curiosity had much to do with it, curiosity and the desire for new experiences, yet it was not a simple, but rather a very complex passion. What there was in it of the purely sensuous instinct of boyhood had been transformed by the workings of the imagination, changed into something that seemed to the lad himself to be remote from sense, and was for that very reason all the more dangerous. It was the passions about whose origin we deceived ourselves that tyrannized most strongly over us. Our weakest motives were those of whose nature we were conscious. It often happened that when we thought we were experimenting on others we were really experimenting on ourselves.
vi: He saw clearly that the experimental method was the only method by which one could achieve any scientific analysis of passion; and certainly, Dorian Gray was a subject perfectly suited for him, and seemed to promise rich and useful results. His sudden mad love for Sybil Vane was a psychological phenomenon of little importance. It was certain that curiosity had a great deal to do with it, curiosity and the desire for new experiences; however, it was not a simple passion but rather a very complex one. What was actually in it was the sensual instinct of youth transformed by the activities of the imagination, turning into something that seemed to the young man himself to be very far removed from sensation, and for that very reason, it was even more dangerous. It is the passions that we deceive ourselves about their origins that torment us the most. Our weakest motives are those whose nature we are unaware of. Often when we think we are testing others, we are actually testing ourselves.
tr: Lord Henry could clearly see that the only way to lead a person to the scientific examination of passions was the experimental method. Dorian Gray was indeed a perfect subject for him, promising bright and fruitful results. This sudden mad passion he had developed for Sibyl Vane was an extraordinary psychological event, not to be underestimated in its peculiarity. There was no doubt that curiosity played a major role in this, curiosity and the desire for novelty. Yet it was not a simple passion; it was very complex. The lustful impulse derived from youth, altered by the influence of imagination, had transformed into a feeling that seemed far from logic and common sense to the boy himself, and thus all the more dangerous. It was the passions about whose origins we deceived ourselves that exerted the most relentless pressures on us. Our weakest impulses were those whose nature we knew. Often, when we thought we were experimenting on others, we were actually experimenting on ourselves.
es: He considered it evident that the experimental method was the only one that would lead him to the scientific analysis of passions; Dorian Gray, for his part, was the ideal subject, and seemed to promise abundant and precious results. His sudden and foolish love for Sybil Vane was a psychological phenomenon of no small interest. Undoubtedly, curiosity had much to do with it; curiosity and the desire for new experiences; it was not, however, a simple passion but a very complicated one. What there was in it of purely sensual adolescent instinct had been transformed thanks to the activity of the imagination, transformed into something that to the boy himself seemed far removed from the senses and which was, for that very reason, much more dangerous. The passions about whose origin one deceives oneself are the ones that most tyrannize. The motives that are best known have much less force. How many times it happened that, believing we are experimenting on others, we are actually experimenting on ourselves.

en: While Lord Henry sat dreaming on these things, a knock came to the door, and his valet entered and reminded him it was time to dress for dinner. He got up and looked out into the street. The sunset had smitten into scarlet gold the upper windows of the houses opposite. The panes glowed like plates of heated metal. The sky above was like a faded rose. He thought of his friend’s young fiery-coloured life and wondered how it was all going to end.
vi: While Lord Henry sat dreaming about these things, a knock touched the door, and his servant entered, reminding him that it was time to change clothes for dinner. He stood up and looked out onto the street. The sunset cast a deep golden-red hue on the upper windows of the houses opposite. The panes glowed like sheets of metal heated by fire. The sky above was like a withered rose. He thought about the fiery, youthful life of his friend and wondered how it would all end.
tr: While Lord Henry sat lost in these thoughts, there was a knock at the door, and his personal servant entered to inform him that it was time to dress for dinner. Lord Henry stood up and looked out the window at the street. The sunset had turned the upper floor windows of the houses across the street into crimson gold. The panes glowed like sheets of heated metal. Above, the sky resembled a faded rose. Lord Henry thought of his friend's fresh, fiery life and wondered what the outcome of all this would be.
es: A knock on the door brought Lord Henry out of that long reverie. His valet reminded him that he needed to dress for dinner. He stood up and looked towards the street. The sunset had turned the tall windows of the houses across the street into golden scarlets. The glass panes shone like sheets of red-hot metal. Above, the sky was like a withered rose. Lord Henry thought of his friend, of that life colored by all the fires of youth, and wondered how it would all end.

en: When he arrived home, about half-past twelve o’clock, he saw a telegram lying on the hall table. He opened it and found it was from Dorian Gray. It was to tell him that he was engaged to be married to Sibyl Vane.
vi: When he got home, around half past twelve, he found a telegram lying on the table in the hall. He opened it and saw that it was from Dorian Gray. It informed him that he was engaged to Sibyl Vane.
tr: When he returned home around half-past six, he found a telegram on the table in the hall. When he opened it, he realized it was from Dorian Gray. The telegram was informing that Dorian Gray had gotten engaged to marry Sibyl Vane.
es: When he returned home, around half past twelve, he saw a telegram on the vestibule table. Upon opening it, he discovered that it was from Dorian Gray. It announced that he had become engaged to Miss Sibyl Vane.

en: CHAPTER V.
vi: Chapter 5
tr: Fifth chapter
es: Chapter 5

en: “Mother, Mother, I am so happy!” whispered the girl, burying her face in the lap of the faded, tired-looking woman who, with back turned to the shrill intrusive light, was sitting in the one arm-chair that their dingy sitting-room contained. “I am so happy!” she repeated, “and you must be happy, too!”
vi: "Mom, mom, I'm so happy!" the girl whispered, burying her face into the lap of the tired, withered woman, her back turned to the glaring light that intruded, sitting on an armchair in their filthy living room. "I'm so happy!" she repeated, "and you must be happy too!"
tr: The girl whispered, "Mom, mommy, I am so happy!" as she buried her head in the lap of the tired, elderly-looking woman. The woman, with her back turned to the harsh, glaring light, was sitting in the only chair in that shabby room. The girl said, "I am so happy that you must be happy too!"
es: —How happy I am, mother! —whispered the girl, hiding her face in the lap of the withered woman, who looked tired, and who, with her back turned to the too-bright light from the window, was sitting in the only armchair that her sordid living room contained—. I am very happy —she repeated—, and you must be too!

en: Mrs. Vane winced and put her thin, bismuth-whitened hands on her daughter’s head. “Happy!” she echoed, “I am only happy, Sibyl, when I see you act. You must not think of anything but your acting. Mr. Isaacs has been very good to us, and we owe him money.”
vi: Mrs. Vane shrank back, placing her thin, discolored batiste hands on her daughter's head. “Happiness!” she repeated, “I am only happy, Sibyl, when I see you perform.” 1 Bismuth Oxychloride: A substance found in nature, used for makeup since ancient times. You should not think about anything other than your acting. Mr. Isaacs is very good to us, and we owe him money.”
tr: Ms. Vane shuddered slightly and placed her thin, bismuth-whitened hands on her daughter's head. "Did you say happy, Sibyl! I am only happy when I see you on stage. You should think of nothing but your profession. Mr. Isaacs has done us many favors. We owe him money."
es: Mrs. Vane winced in pain and placed her thin, makeup-whitened hands on her daughter's head. —Happy! —he repeated like an echo—. I am only happy when I see you perform. You should only think about your career. Mr. Isaacs has been very good to us, and we owe him money.

en: The girl looked up and pouted. “Money, Mother?” she cried, “what does money matter? Love is more than money.”
vi: The girl looked up and pouted. “Money, money?” she exclaimed, “what's so important about money? Love is more important than money.”
tr: The girl lifted her head and looked at her mother, pouting her lip. "Did you say money, mom?" she retorted. “Why should we care about money? Love is superior to money.”
es: The girl raised her head and pouted. —Money, mother? —he exclaimed—, what importance does money have? Love is more than money.

en: “Mr. Isaacs has advanced us fifty pounds to pay off our debts and to get a proper outfit for James. You must not forget that, Sibyl. Fifty pounds is a very large sum. Mr. Isaacs has been most considerate.”
vi: "Mr. Isaacs advanced me fifty pounds to pay off debts and to purchase suitable equipment for James. You should not forget that, Sibyl. Fifty pounds is a very large sum of money. Mr. Isaacs has been extremely considerate."
tr: “Let's pay our debts. Mr. Isaacs gave us fifty pounds so that we could also properly dress James. You must not forget this, Sibyl. Fifty pounds is a lot of money. Mr. Isaacs did us a great favor.”
es: —Mr. Isaacs has advanced us fifty pounds to pay our debts and to dress James properly. You must not forget it, Sibyl. Fifty pounds is a lot. Mr. Isaacs has been very considerate with us.

en: “He is not a gentleman, Mother, and I hate the way he talks to me,” said the girl, rising to her feet and going over to the window.
vi: “He is not a gentleman, mother, and I hate the way he talks to me,” the girl said, standing up and moving closer to the window.
tr: “Mr. Isaacs is not a gentleman, mother,” said the girl as she stood up and walked to the window. “I hate the way he talks to me.”
es: —He is not a gentleman, mother, and I greatly dislike the way he speaks to me —said the girl, standing up and approaching the window.

en: “I don’t know how we could manage without him,” answered the elder woman querulously.
vi: “I don't know how I would manage without him,” the older woman replied, irritably.
tr: Her mother, grumbling, said, "I don't know what we would do without him."
es: —I don't know how we could manage without him —replied the older woman in a whining tone.

en: Sibyl Vane tossed her head and laughed. “We don’t want him any more, Mother. Prince Charming rules life for us now.” Then she paused. A rose shook in her blood and shadowed her cheeks. Quick breath parted the petals of her lips. They trembled. Some southern wind of passion swept over her and stirred the dainty folds of her dress. “I love him,” she said simply.
vi: Sibyl Vane tossed her head back and laughed. “I don't need him anymore, mother. The Charming Prince will rule my life from now on.” Then she paused. A rose bloomed in her blood, casting a shadow on her cheek. Her breath quickened, parting the petals of her lips. They trembled. A certain passionate Southern wind swept over her, rustling her pretty dress. “I love him,” she said, simply.
tr: Sibyl shook her head and laughed. "We don't need him anymore, mother. Now we have the Sweet Prince with us." Sibyl paused. Her cheeks blushed as if a rose had been tossed in her blood. Her lips parted, trembling, as her breath caught. A warm breeze of passion swirled around the delicate folds of her dress. Sibyl said simply, "I love him."
es: Sibyl moved her head and started to laugh. —We no longer need it, mother. The prince charming now governs our lives —then she paused. A rose stirred in her blood, setting her cheeks ablaze. Her breath, quickened, parted the petals of her lips, which trembled. A southern wind of passion blew over her, moving the delicate folds of her dress—. I love him —she added simply.

en: “Foolish child! foolish child!” was the parrot-phrase flung in answer. The waving of crooked, false-jewelled fingers gave grotesqueness to the words.
vi: “The foolish girl! The foolish girl!” were the parroted scolding words. The waving of crooked fingers, adorned with fake jewels, added absurdity to the words.
tr: The response he received was a parrot-like repetition, "Stupid child! Stupid child!" The waving of the crooked fingers adorned with fake gemstone rings added an extra layer of oddity to the words.
es: —Stupid girl! Stupid girl! —was the parrot-like phrase that she received in response. The movement of some deformed fingers, covered in fake jewels, gave a grotesque character to those words.

en: The girl laughed again. The joy of a caged bird was in her voice. Her eyes caught the melody and echoed it in radiance, then closed for a moment, as though to hide their secret. When they opened, the mist of a dream had passed across them.
vi: The girl laughed again. The joy of a caged bird resonated in her voice. Her eyes caught the melody, reflecting it as a radiant glow; then closed for a moment, as if to hide their secret. When they opened, a dreamy mist drifted across them.
tr: The girl laughed again. There was the joy of a bird trapped in a cage in her voice. Her eyes also captured this melody and seemed to reflect it in the form of a sparkle, then closed for a moment as if to hide the secret within them. When they reopened, it was as if a mist of a dream had passed through them.
es: The girl laughed again. Her voice reflected the joy of a caged bird. Her eyes picked up the melody and echoed it with their brightness: then they closed for a moment, as if to hide their secret. When they opened again, they were veiled by the mist of a dream.

en: Thin-lipped wisdom spoke at her from the worn chair, hinted at prudence, quoted from that book of cowardice whose author apes the name of common sense. She did not listen. She was free in her prison of passion. Her prince, Prince Charming, was with her. She had called on memory to remake him. She had sent her soul to search for him, and it had brought him back. His kiss burned again upon her mouth. Her eyelids were warm with his breath.
vi: The wisdom of thin-lipped advice spoke to her from the worn chair, cautiously alluding, quoting from a book on cowardice whose author parodied the name of common sense. She did not listen. She was free in the prison of her passion. Her prince, Prince Charming, was with her. She had asked Memory to recreate him. She had sent her soul to find him, and it had brought him back. His kiss burned on her lips once more. Her eyelids were warm with his breath again.
tr: The cautious mind was raising its voice from that worn-out armchair, touching on the necessity of being careful, and quoting from the famous "cowardice" book that its author admired in the name of "common sense." The girl wasn't even listening to it. She was free within the prison of her passion. Her own fairy tale prince, Sweet Prince, was now right beside her. Sibyl had turned to memory so that it could bring her prince to life beside her. And memory had brought the prince to her. The prince's kiss was burning the young girl's lips again. His breath was warm on the girl's eyelids.
es: The wisdom of lips that were too thin spoke to her from the worn-out armchair, advising prudence, with quotes from that book on cowardice whose author disguises himself with the name of common sense. She did not listen. She was free in the prison of her passion. Her prince, the prince charming, was with her. She had called upon memory to reconstruct him. She sent her soul to find him, and her soul returned with him. His kiss burned her mouth again. His breath warmed her eyelids.

en: Then wisdom altered its method and spoke of espial and discovery. This young man might be rich. If so, marriage should be thought of. Against the shell of her ear broke the waves of worldly cunning. The arrows of craft shot by her. She saw the thin lips moving, and smiled.
vi: Then Wisdom changed its method and instructed about tracking and detection. This young man must be wealthy. If so, marriage is something to consider. On the rim of her ear, waves of worldly cunning shattered. Arrows of trickery grazed past her. She watched the thin lips move and smiled.
tr: Then the mind changed its method; it spoke of "probing" and "learning and understanding." This young man could be wealthy. If so, marriage should be considered. Waves of cunning began to crash upon the pearl of the girl's ear; arrows of deceit pierced her heart. The girl saw those thin lips moving and smiled.
es: Wisdom then changed its method and spoke of spying and discovering. That young man could be rich. If so, one had to think about marriage. Against Sibyl's ear, the waves of worldly prudence crashed. The arrows of cunning passed without touching her. She saw the thin lips move, and smiled.

en: Suddenly she felt the need to speak. The wordy silence troubled her. “Mother, Mother,” she cried, “why does he love me so much? I know why I love him. I love him because he is like what love himself should be. But what does he see in me? I am not worthy of him. And yet—why, I cannot tell—though I feel so much beneath him, I don’t feel humble. I feel proud, terribly proud. Mother, did you love my father as I love Prince Charming?”
vi: Suddenly she felt the need to speak. The loud silence bothered her. “Mother, mother,” she cried out, “why does he love me so much? I know why I love him. I love him because he is like what Love itself should become. But what does he see in me? I am not worthy of him. But — why, I cannot say — even though I feel so much inferior to him, I do not feel inferior. I feel proud, extremely proud. Mother, did you love my father as I love Prince Charming?”
tr: Suddenly, he felt the need to speak. This silence full of words was making him uneasy. “Mom, mom!” she said. “Why does this child love me so much? I know why I love him. I love him because he is like a living symbol of love itself. But what does he see in me? I am not worthy of him. Still... I don't know why... I feel that I am far below him, but I don't feel crushed. I feel proud, incredibly proud. Mom, did you love my father like this, the way I love my Sweet Prince?”
es: Suddenly, she felt the need to speak. The silence full of words unsettled her. —Mother, mother —she exclaimed—, why do you love me so much? I know that I love you. I love you because you are the image of what Love itself must be. But, what does he see in me? I am not worthy of him. And yet, although I see myself so far below him, I do not feel humility: I feel pride, a terrible pride, but I cannot explain why. Mother, did you love my father as I love the blue prince?

en: The elder woman grew pale beneath the coarse powder that daubed her cheeks, and her dry lips twitched with a spasm of pain. Sybil rushed to her, flung her arms round her neck, and kissed her. “Forgive me, Mother. I know it pains you to talk about our father. But it only pains you because you loved him so much. Don’t look so sad. I am as happy to-day as you were twenty years ago. Ah! let me be happy for ever!”
vi: The older woman turned pale under the coarse powder on her cheeks, and her dry lips twitched in pain. Sybyl rushed to her, wrapped her arms around her neck, and kissed her. "Forgive me, mother. I know talking about father causes you pain. But it only hurts because you loved him so much. Don't look so sad. Today, I am as happy as you were twenty years ago. Oh! Let me be happy forever!”
tr: Anne turned pale under the thick layer of powder smeared on her cheeks, a nerve twitched on her dry lips. Sibyl ran up to her, hugged her, and kissed her. “Forgive me, my dear mother. I know talking about my father upsets you. But if you are so upset, it is because you once loved him very much. Don't look so sad. Just as you were happy twenty years ago, I am happy today. Oh, please, let me be happy for a lifetime!”
es: —the older woman paled under the too-visible powders that smeared her cheeks, and her dry lips trembled in a spasm of pain. Sibyl ran to her, hugged her neck, and kissed her—. Forgive me, mother. I know that talking about my father makes you suffer. But you suffer because you loved him very much. Do not be sad. I am as happy today as you were twenty years ago. Ah, let me be happy forever!

en: “My child, you are far too young to think of falling in love. Besides, what do you know of this young man? You don’t even know his name. The whole thing is most inconvenient, and really, when James is going away to Australia, and I have so much to think of, I must say that you should have shown more consideration. However, as I said before, if he is rich ...”
vi: "My child, you are still too young to be thinking about being infatuated with love. Moreover, what do you know about this young man? You don't even know his name yet. This whole thing is extremely troublesome, and actually, with James about to leave for Australia, and me having too many things to think about, I must say that you should have shown more consideration. However, as I said earlier, if he were rich..."
tr: “My dear child, you are still very young, you are not at the age to think about falling in love. Besides, what do you know about this young man? You don't even know his name. From any angle, it’s a very inappropriate situation, very untimely. At a time when I have a world of problems to think about, especially with James going to Australia, I would have expected a bit more understanding from you, honestly. Anyway, as I said, if this boy is wealthy...”
es: —My dear daughter, you are too young to think about falling in love. Besides, what do you know about that young man? You don't even know his name. All of this is very inconvenient and, to be honest, when lames is about to go to Australia and I have so many worries, I must say that you could have shown a bit more consideration. However, as I have said before, in the case that he is rich... —Mother, mother!

en: “Ah! Mother, Mother, let me be happy!”
vi: "Oh! Mother, mother, please let me be happy!"
tr: “Mom, dear mom, please, let me be happy!”
es: Let me be happy!

en: Mrs. Vane glanced at her, and with one of those false theatrical gestures that so often become a mode of second nature to a stage-player, clasped her in her arms. At this moment, the door opened and a young lad with rough brown hair came into the room. He was thick-set of figure, and his hands and feet were large and somewhat clumsy in movement. He was not so finely bred as his sister. One would hardly have guessed the close relationship that existed between them. Mrs. Vane fixed her eyes on him and intensified her smile. She mentally elevated her son to the dignity of an audience. She felt sure that the tableau was interesting.
vi: Mrs. Vane glanced at her, and, with one of those theatrical, artificial gestures that often become a second nature to actors, hugged her tightly in her arms. At this moment, the door opened, and a young man with shaggy brown hair stepped into the room. He had a sturdy build, large limbs, and was somewhat clumsy. He was not as well-bred as his sister. It was hard to guess the close relationship that existed between them. Mrs. Vane fixed her eyes on him, smiling more deeply. She silently elevated her son to the level of an audience. She felt certain that the scene was very interesting.
tr: Ms. Vane looked at her daughter, then embraced her with one of those artificial gestures that become a second nature to actors and pressed her to her chest. At that very moment, the door opened and a young man with disheveled chestnut hair entered the room. He was stocky, with large hands and feet, and his movements were somewhat awkward. He lacked his sister's grace. One could never guess the close blood relation between them. Ms. Vane fixed her eyes on him, the smile on her lips widened. In her mind, she had elevated her son to the level of an "audience." She had no doubt about the interesting nature of the "scene" she had created.
es: Mrs. Vane stared at her and, with one of those false theatrical gestures that so often become almost second nature to an actor, embraced her.
