At that moment, the door opened, and a young man with coarse brown hair entered the room. He was rather stout, had large feet and hands, and moved with a certain clumsiness. He did not possess his sister's delicacy, and it was difficult to discern the close kinship between the two. Mrs. Vane fixed her eyes on him, and her smile intensified. Mentally, she elevated her son to the status of an audience. She was sure that the tableau was interesting.

en: “You might keep some of your kisses for me, Sibyl, I think,” said the lad with a good-natured grumble.
vi: "Can you save a few kisses for me, Sybil? I would really appreciate it," the young man said, with a gentle murmur.
tr: The young man said with a tender growl, "Sibyl, you can save some of your kisses for me too."
es: —You could save some of your kisses for me, Sibyl, I think —said the boy in a tone of gentle reproach.

en: “Ah! but you don’t like being kissed, Jim,” she cried. “You are a dreadful old bear.” And she ran across the room and hugged him.
vi: "Oh! But I don't like being kissed, Jim," she exclaimed. "I am a grumpy old bear." And she ran across the room to hug him tightly.
tr: Sibyl said, "But you don't like to be kissed, Jim!" “You know how to grumble like a bear!” she said, running up to him and hugging him tightly.
es: —But you don't like being kissed! —exclaimed her sister—. You've always been a prickly thistle. And she ran across the room to hug him.

en: James Vane looked into his sister’s face with tenderness. “I want you to come out with me for a walk, Sibyl. I don’t suppose I shall ever see this horrid London again. I am sure I don’t want to.”
vi: James Vane lovingly looked at his sister's face. "I want you to go for a walk with me, Sibyl. I don't believe I will ever see this dreadful city of London again. I am certain that I don't want to."
tr: James Vane looked at his sister's face with love. “I want you to come for a walk with me, Sibyl. I don't think I will see this dreadful city called London again. Nor do I want to see it.”
es: James Vane contemplated his sister's face with tenderness. —Come with me for a walk, Sibyl. I don't think I'll ever see this horrible London again. I'm sure I won't miss it.

en: “My son, don’t say such dreadful things,” murmured Mrs. Vane, taking up a tawdry theatrical dress, with a sigh, and beginning to patch it. She felt a little disappointed that he had not joined the group. It would have increased the theatrical picturesqueness of the situation.
vi: "My son, don't say such frightening things," Mrs. Vane murmured, picking up the gaudy costume with a sigh, and began to mend it. She felt a bit disappointed that he didn't join the group. That will increase the theatrical vividness of the situation.
tr: Ms. Vane murmured, "My son, don't say such things!" Sighing, she picked up an old, shabby, cheap stage costume and began to mend it. She was a bit disappointed that her son hadn't joined them. Had James joined them, a more striking scene would have emerged.
es: —Don't say such horrible things, my son —murmured Mrs. Vane, resuming, with a sigh, a tawdry piece of theatrical clothing that she began to mend. It saddened her somewhat that James had not joined the company, which would have increased the theatrical picturesque nature of the situation.

en: “Why not, Mother? I mean it.”
vi: “Why not, mom? I'm telling the truth.”
tr: "Why shouldn't I say it, mom? I'm speaking sincerely."
es: —Why not, mother? It's what I feel.

en: “You pain me, my son. I trust you will return from Australia in a position of affluence. I believe there is no society of any kind in the Colonies—nothing that I would call society—so when you have made your fortune, you must come back and assert yourself in London.”
vi: "You cause me pain, my son. I believe you will return from Australia with a wealthy status. I believe there is no upper class of any kind in the colonies, nothing that I can call the upper class; so when you have succeeded, you must come back and establish yourself in London."
tr: "You are upsetting me, my son. I believe that you will return from Australia as a wealthy and reputable man. I do not believe that there is such a thing as society in the colonies, at least not anything I would call society. Therefore, after you have made your fortune there, you must return here and make your mark in London."
es: —It hurts me that you say that, my son. I haven't lost hope that you will return from Australia after making a fortune. I believe that good society does not exist in the colonies; at least, nothing of what I consider good society; so when you have succeeded, you should return to London and become a well-known person here.

en: “Society!” muttered the lad. “I don’t want to know anything about that. I should like to make some money to take you and Sibyl off the stage. I hate it.”
vi: "The upper class!" the young man muttered. "I don't want to know anything about that. I just want to make some money to get mother and Sibyl off the stage. I hate it."
tr: The child muttered, “High society!” “I don't want to get involved with that at all. What I want is to make some money and take you and Sibyl away from the stage. I hate the stage life.”
es: —Good society! —murmured the boy—. I am not interested in good society at all. I would like to earn some money to get you and Sibyl off the stage. I abhor the life of the theater.

en: “Oh, Jim!” said Sibyl, laughing, “how unkind of you! But are you really going for a walk with me? That will be nice! I was afraid you were going to say good-bye to some of your friends—to Tom Hardy, who gave you that hideous pipe, or Ned Langton, who makes fun of you for smoking it. It is very sweet of you to let me have your last afternoon. Where shall we go? Let us go to the park.”
vi: "Oh, Jim!" Sibyl said with a laugh, "Why are you so mean! But will you really take a walk with me? That's great! I was afraid you were going to say goodbye to some of your friends — say goodbye to Tom Hardy, the guy who gave you that hideous pipe, or Ned Langton, the guy who teased you for smoking it. You are so sweet for letting me enjoy your last afternoon. Where shall we go? Let's go to the Park."
tr: Sibyl laughed, "Aman Jim, how cruel you are!" "Really, do you want to go for a walk with me? How nice. I thought you would be saying goodbye to your own friends: Tom Hardy, who gave you that dreadful pipe, and Ned Langton, who mocks you for smoking it. It's so sweet of you to spend your last afternoon with me. Where shall we go? Let's go to the park."
es: —Jim! —exclaimed Sibyl, laughing—, how unkind of you! Do you really want to take a walk with me? That's good! I was afraid you were going to say goodbye to some of your friends..., to Tom Hardy, who gave you that dreadful pipe, or to Ned Langton, who teases you by smoking it. It touches me that you are giving me your last afternoon. What shall we do? Shall we go to the park?

en: “I am too shabby,” he answered, frowning. “Only swell people go to the park.”
vi: "You look so messy," he replied, frowning. "Only those who are well-dressed go to the Park."
tr: His brother frowned and said, "I look so shabby." "Only high society people go to the park."
es: —I don't have suitable clothes —replied her brother, frowning—. Only elegant people go to the park.

en: “Nonsense, Jim,” she whispered, stroking the sleeve of his coat.
vi: "Too much nonsense, Jim," she whispered, stroking his sleeve.
tr: Sibyl, stroking the sleeve of his coat, said, "You're talking nonsense."
es: —Nonsense, Jim —whispered Sibyl, stroking the sleeve of his jacket.

en: He hesitated for a moment. “Very well,” he said at last, “but don’t be too long dressing.” She danced out of the door. One could hear her singing as she ran upstairs. Her little feet pattered overhead.
vi: He hesitated for a moment. "Alright," he finally said, "but don't take too long to change." She skipped out of the door. You could hear her singing as she ran upstairs. Her little feet pitter-pattered overhead.
tr: James paused for a moment. Finally, he said, "Alright." "But don't take too long getting dressed up." Sibyl exited the room as if dancing. They heard her singing upstairs. Her little feet were pattering on the ceiling.
es: James hesitated for a moment. —Alright —he finally said—, but don't take too long to get dressed. Sibyl took a few dance steps to the door. She was heard singing as she ran up the stairs and then the sound of her feet on the upper floor.

en: He walked up and down the room two or three times. Then he turned to the still figure in the chair. “Mother, are my things ready?” he asked.
vi: You paced back and forth in the room a few times. Then you turned to the silent figure on the chair. "Mom, is my stuff ready?" you asked.
tr: James paced back and forth in the room. Then he turned to the woman sitting motionless on the couch. “Mom, are my things ready?” he asked.
es: His brother paced the room two or three times before turning to the motionless figure in the armchair. —Are my things ready, mother? —he asked.

en: “Quite ready, James,” she answered, keeping her eyes on her work. For some months past she had felt ill at ease when she was alone with this rough stern son of hers. Her shallow secret nature was troubled when their eyes met. She used to wonder if he suspected anything. The silence, for he made no other observation, became intolerable to her. She began to complain. Women defend themselves by attacking, just as they attack by sudden and strange surrenders. “I hope you will be contented, James, with your sea-faring life,” she said. “You must remember that it is your own choice. You might have entered a solicitor’s office. Solicitors are a very respectable class, and in the country often dine with the best families.”
vi: “Everything is ready, James,” she replied, her eyes not leaving her work. For the past few months, she had felt uncomfortable whenever she was alone with her rude, cold son. Her shallow reserved nature found it difficult when their eyes met. She often wondered if he suspected anything. The silence, due to his lack of further comments, became unbearable for her. She began to complain. Women protect themselves by attacking, just as they attack with sudden and strange surrenders. “I hope you are satisfied, James, with your life at sea,” she said. “You should remember that it was your own choice. You could have joined a law office. Lawyers are a very respectable class, and in the province, they often dine with the wealthiest families.”
tr: The woman replied, "Everything is ready, James," without lifting her eyes from her work. In recent months, being alone with her straightforward, serious son had become a source of discomfort for her. Whenever their eyes met, her sly, shallow soul grew uneasy, wondering if her son suspected anything. Since her son did not say anything else, she could no longer bear the silence. She began to complain. Women defend themselves through attacks, and sometimes, they launch attacks through sudden, inexplicable surrenders. Ms. Vane said, "James, I hope the seafaring life gives you satisfaction." "You must never forget that you chose this yourself. You could have joined a lawyer's office. The legal profession is very respectable. Especially those in the countryside are often invited to dine with the best families."
es: —Everything is ready, James —replied Mrs. Vane without lifting her eyes from her work. For several months she had felt uncomfortable when she was alone with that coarse and severe son of hers. She feared revealing her secret frivolity whenever their gazes met. And she often wondered if James suspected anything. The silence, because her son made no further comment, became intolerable to her, and she began to complain. Women defend themselves by attacking, just as they attack through sudden and strange surrenders—. I hope you are satisfied with your life at sea —she said—. Remember that it was you who chose it. You could have joined a lawyer's office. Lawyers are very respectable people, and in the provinces, they often dine with the best families.

en: “I hate offices, and I hate clerks,” he replied. “But you are quite right. I have chosen my own life. All I say is, watch over Sibyl. Don’t let her come to any harm. Mother, you must watch over her.”
vi: “I hate the offices and I hate the clerks,” he replied. “But you are absolutely right. I have chosen my own life. All I need to say is, protect Sibyl. Don't let her be harmed. Mother, you must protect her.”
tr: His son replied to his mother, "I hate offices and clerks." "All I want to tell you is to keep an eye on Sibyl. Don't let any harm come to her. You must take care of her as if she were your own eyes, mother."
es: —I detest offices and office workers —replied his son—. But you are absolutely right. It is I who have chosen to live this way. I only ask that you take care of Sibyl. Do not let anything bad happen to her. You have to take care of her, mother.

en: “James, you really talk very strangely. Of course I watch over Sibyl.”
vi: “James, what you’re saying is really strange. Of course, I have to protect Sibyl.”
tr: “James, you are talking very strangely. Am I not looking after Sibyl?”
es: —You speak in a very strange manner, James. Of course, I will take care of Sibyl.

en: “I hear a gentleman comes every night to the theatre and goes behind to talk to her. Is that right? What about that?”
vi: "I heard that a noble person comes to the theater every night and goes backstage to talk to her. Is that true? What does that mean?"
tr: “I heard that a gentleman comes to the theater every evening and goes backstage to talk to you. Is there any truth to this? What do you say about this?”
es: —I have been told that there is a gentleman who goes to the theater every night and then chats with her backstage. Is it true? What about that?

en: “You are speaking about things you don’t understand, James. In the profession we are accustomed to receive a great deal of most gratifying attention. I myself used to receive many bouquets at one time. That was when acting was really understood. As for Sibyl, I do not know at present whether her attachment is serious or not. But there is no doubt that the young man in question is a perfect gentleman. He is always most polite to me. Besides, he has the appearance of being rich, and the flowers he sends are lovely.”
vi: “You are talking about things you don't understand, James. In this profession, we have become accustomed to receiving a lot of very pleasing attention. I myself have received many bouquets at the same time. That is when the performance is truly understood. As for Sibyl, I don't know if her affection is serious at the moment. But one thing is certain, the young man being talked about is a perfect gentleman. He is always very polite to me. Moreover, he has a wealthy lifestyle, and the flowers he sends are also very lovely.”
tr: “James, you are talking about things you don't understand. In this profession, we attract a lot of attention, our pride swells. There was a time when I used to receive bunches of flowers. People truly appreciated theater acting. As for Sibyl; I don't know if she has a serious commitment at the moment. But it is undeniable that the mentioned young man is a perfect gentleman. He always treats me with utmost respect. And he seems to be wealthy from his appearance. The flowers he sends are very beautiful.”
es: —You talk about things you don't understand, James. In our profession, we are used to receiving attentions. There was a time when I myself received many bouquets of flowers. Back then, the work of actors was truly appreciated. As for Sibyl, I don't know if her interest is serious at the moment or not. But there is no doubt that the young man you mention is a perfect gentleman. He treats me with extraordinary politeness. Moreover, he seems to be wealthy, and the flowers he sends are very beautiful.

en: “You don’t know his name, though,” said the lad harshly.
vi: “Mother doesn't even know its name yet, anyway,” the young man said, gruffly.
tr: The young man said harshly, "But you don't know her name."
es: —But you don't know what his name is —said the boy harshly.

en: “No,” answered his mother with a placid expression in her face. “He has not yet revealed his real name. I think it is quite romantic of him. He is probably a member of the aristocracy.”
vi: “Not yet,” his mother replied, with a calm expression on her face. “He hasn't revealed his real name yet. I think it's quite romantic of him. He must be a member of the nobility.”
tr: With a serene expression on her face, his mother said, "No." "He hasn't revealed his name yet. I think it's quite a romantic thing. He must be someone from the aristocracy."
es: —No —responded Mrs. Vane with a serene expression on her face—. He hasn't revealed his true name yet. And I find it very romantic. He is probably an aristocrat.

en: James Vane bit his lip. “Watch over Sibyl, Mother,” he cried, “watch over her.”
vi: James Vane bit his lip. "Protect Sibyl, mother," he cried, "protect her."
tr: James Vane bit his lip. Then, he said again, "Look after Sibyl, mother." "Protect her with your life!"
es: James Vane bit his lips. —Take care of Sibyl, mother —he exclaimed—. Take care of her!

en: “My son, you distress me very much. Sibyl is always under my special care. Of course, if this gentleman is wealthy, there is no reason why she should not contract an alliance with him. I trust he is one of the aristocracy. He has all the appearance of it, I must say. It might be a most brilliant marriage for Sibyl. They would make a charming couple. His good looks are really quite remarkable; everybody notices them.”
vi: “My son, you make me very sad. Sibyl has always received special care from me. Of course, if that gentleman is wealthy, there is no reason why your sister shouldn't associate with him. I believe he belongs to the aristocratic class. He exhibits all the outward signs of it, I must say. There will surely be a splendid wedding for Sibyl. They will make a stunning couple. His beauty is truly extraordinary; everyone notices him.”
tr: “My son, you are darkening my heart. I have always looked after Sibyl like the apple of my eye. If this gentleman is wealthy, there is no reason why Sibyl should not enter into a relationship with him. I believe he is an aristocrat. He completely looks the part, believe me. Thus, Sibyl can make a dazzling marriage. What a beautiful couple they would make: The boy is extraordinarily handsome. He attracts everyone's attention.”
es: —My son, your words hurt me deeply. I always take special care of Sibyl. Of course, if that gentleman is wealthy, there is no reason why she shouldn't marry him. I am sure he is an aristocrat. He has all the appearance, there is no doubt about it. It would be a very brilliant marriage for Sibyl. They would make a charming couple. He is a very handsome young man, everyone notices it.

en: The lad muttered something to himself and drummed on the window-pane with his coarse fingers. He had just turned round to say something when the door opened and Sibyl ran in.
vi: The young man muttered something to himself and tapped his rough fingers on the windowpane. He had just turned around to say something when the door opened, and Sibyl ran in.
tr: The young man, muttering something to himself, tapped on the windowpane with his blunt fingers as if playing a drum. Just as he was about to say something, the door opened, and Sibyl ran inside.
es: The young man murmured something to himself and tapped on the window glass with his worker's fingers. He had just turned to say something when the door opened and Sibyl entered.

en: “How serious you both are!” she cried. “What is the matter?”
vi: “Why are both of you so serious!” she exclaimed. “Is something wrong?”
tr: “How serious you both are!” he said. “What's wrong with you?”
es: —How serious you all are! —he exclaimed—. What is happening?

en: “Nothing,” he answered. “I suppose one must be serious sometimes. Good-bye, Mother; I will have my dinner at five o’clock. Everything is packed, except my shirts, so you need not trouble.”
vi: “Nothing,” he replied. “I suppose we should live seriously from time to time. Goodbye mother; I will have dinner at five o'clock. Everything is packed, except for my shirt, so you don't need to worry.”
tr: James Vane, "Nothing," he replied. "Can't a person be serious once in a while? Goodbye, mother. I will have dinner at five o'clock. I've packed everything in my suitcase except for my shirts, don't worry about it."
es: —Nothing —replied his brother—. I suppose sometimes you have to get serious. See you later, mother; I will have dinner at five. The luggage is packed, except for the shirts, so you don't have to worry.

en: “Good-bye, my son,” she answered with a bow of strained stateliness.
vi: “Goodbye, my son,” she replied, with an awkwardly formal bow.
tr: The woman, saying "Goodbye, my son," made a gesture as if to bow with a cold and formal demeanor.
es: —See you later, my son —she responded, with a resentfully majestic inclination.

en: She was extremely annoyed at the tone he had adopted with her, and there was something in his look that had made her feel afraid.
vi: She was extremely uncomfortable with the tone of voice he had started using with her, and there was something in his eyes that made her feel scared.
tr: She was angry at the tone of voice her son used when speaking to her. There was something in the young man's gaze that instilled fear in his mother.
es: She was very upset with the tone her son had adopted with her, and there was something in his gaze that made her feel afraid.

en: “Kiss me, Mother,” said the girl. Her flowerlike lips touched the withered cheek and warmed its frost.
vi: “Kiss me, mother,” the girl said. Her flower-like lips touched the withered cheek, warming its frost.
tr: Sibyl said, "Mommy, kiss me." Her bud-like lips touched the woman's faded cheeks, taking away the chill from them.
es: —Kiss me, mother —said Sibyl. Her floral lips touched the withered cheek, warming its frost.

en: “My child! my child!” cried Mrs. Vane, looking up to the ceiling in search of an imaginary gallery.
vi: “My child! My child!” Mrs. Vane cried out, looking up at the ceiling to find an imaginary gallery seat.
tr: Ms. Vane, "My dear! My dear!" she cried softly and lifted her eyes to the ceiling as if looking at the balcony of a theater.
es: —My daughter, my daughter! —exclaimed Mrs. Vane, raising her eyes to the ceiling in search of an imaginary amphitheater.

en: “Come, Sibyl,” said her brother impatiently. He hated his mother’s affectations.
vi: "Let's go, Sibyl," her brother said, impatiently. He hated his mother's pretentious mannerisms.
tr: James said impatiently, "Come on, Sibyl." He hated his mother's affectations and pretentious behavior.
es: —Come on, Sibyl —said her brother impatiently. Her mother's theatricality irritated him.

en: They went out into the flickering, wind-blown sunlight and strolled down the dreary Euston Road. The passersby glanced in wonder at the sullen heavy youth who, in coarse, ill-fitting clothes, was in the company of such a graceful, refined-looking girl. He was like a common gardener walking with a rose.
vi: They went outside and into the shimmering, breezy sunlight, strolling down the gloomy Euston Road. Passersby glanced with surprise at the gloomy, coarse, poorly dressed, and disheveled young man walking with a graceful young lady who looked very elegant. He looked like an ordinary gardener walking with a rose.
tr: They stepped into the sunlight that flickered and turned with the wind, and began to walk down the dreary Euston Street. Passersby were giving strange looks to the hulking, sullen young man walking beside such an elegant, polite girl, with his coarse, shapeless clothes. It was like an ordinary gardener walking arm in arm with a rose.
es: They went out into a light with reflections agitated by the wind and began to walk along the depressing Euston Road. The pedestrians looked in astonishment at the burly and sullen young man who, dressed in coarse and unflattering clothes, was accompanied by a young woman so attractive and refined in appearance. It was like a common gardener walking with a rose.

en: Jim frowned from time to time when he caught the inquisitive glance of some stranger. He had that dislike of being stared at, which comes on geniuses late in life and never leaves the commonplace. Sibyl, however, was quite unconscious of the effect she was producing. Her love was trembling in laughter on her lips. She was thinking of Prince Charming, and, that she might think of him all the more, she did not talk of him, but prattled on about the ship in which Jim was going to sail, about the gold he was certain to find, about the wonderful heiress whose life he was to save from the wicked, red-shirted bushrangers. For he was not to remain a sailor, or a supercargo, or whatever he was going to be. Oh, no! A sailor’s existence was dreadful. Fancy being cooped up in a horrid ship, with the hoarse, hump-backed waves trying to get in, and a black wind blowing the masts down and tearing the sails into long screaming ribands! He was to leave the vessel at Melbourne, bid a polite good-bye to the captain, and go off at once to the gold-fields. Before a week was over he was to come across a large nugget of pure gold, the largest nugget that had ever been discovered, and bring it down to the coast in a waggon guarded by six mounted policemen. The bushrangers were to attack them three times, and be defeated with immense slaughter. Or, no. He was not to go to the gold-fields at all. They were horrid places, where men got intoxicated, and shot each other in bar-rooms, and used bad language. He was to be a nice sheep-farmer, and one evening, as he was riding home, he was to see the beautiful heiress being carried off by a robber on a black horse, and give chase, and rescue her. Of course, she would fall in love with him, and he with her, and they would get married, and come home, and live in an immense house in London. Yes, there were delightful things in store for him. But he must be very good, and not lose his temper, or spend his money foolishly. She was only a year older than he was, but she knew so much more of life. He must be sure, also, to write to her by every mail, and to say his prayers each night before he went to sleep. God was very good, and would watch over him. She would pray for him, too, and in a few years he would come back quite rich and happy.
vi: Jim occasionally grimaced when he caught the curious gaze of some stranger. He had that trait of disliking being stared at, which often emerges in geniuses in their later years, and never abandons ordinary people. Sibyl, however, was completely unaware of the impression she made. Her love was trembling in the smile on her lips. She was thinking about Prince Charming, and, so that she could think about him even more, she didn't talk about him but continued to chatter about the ship Jim would sail on to the open sea, the gold he was sure to find, the wonderful heiress he would save from the hands of the evil brigands, dressed in red shirts. For he was no longer a sailor, or a seller and transporter of goods, or whatever he was about to become. Oh, no! The life of a sailor was truly dreadful. Just imagine being confined in a dreadful ship, with the hunchbacked waves, roaring hoarsely, trying to break in, and a black wind toppling the masts, tearing the sails into long, howling shreds! He had left the ship in Melbourne, politely bid farewell to the captain, and immediately dashed off to the goldfields. Less than a week had passed before he found an enormous gold nugget, the largest nugget ever discovered, and brought it down to the coast in a wagon guarded by six mounted policemen. The brigands attacked them three times and were defeated in an extremely brutal massacre. Oh, no. He would not go to the goldfields at all. They were dreadful places, where people got drunk, shot each other in saloons, and used foul language. He would become a kind shepherd, and one afternoon, while riding home, he would see a beautiful heiress being kidnapped by a bandit on a black horse, and he would chase after and rescue her. Of course, she would fall in love with him, and he with her, and then they would marry, return to their homeland, and live in a vast mansion in London. Yes, there were interesting things awaiting him there. But he had to be very good, not lose his temper or spend foolishly. She was only one year older than him, but she understood life much better. He also had to make sure to write to her with every mail, and say his prayers every night before he went to sleep. God was very merciful and would protect him. She would also pray for him, and after a few years, he would return, rich and happy.
tr: James would frown whenever he caught the curious gaze of a stranger. He never liked being looked at; this is something that comes to geniuses in their later years, but never leaves ordinary people alone. However, Sibyl was completely unaware of the effect she had on those around her. The love in her heart trembled on her lips as laughter. The young girl was thinking about her Sweet Prince. To think of him more comfortably, she never spoke of him, instead chattering about the ship James would board, the gold he would surely find at his destination, and the rich and magnificent girl he would rescue from the hands of bad natives. Because Jim was not going to remain a sailor. No way! The life of sailors was terrible. Just think, you're stuck on a filthy ship, outside the roaring, humped waves are trying to break in, a pitch-black wind is toppling the masts and tearing the sails into long, screaming strips! No, when James arrived in Melbourne, he would leave the ship, bid the captain a polite farewell, and then head straight for the gold mines. Within a week, he would find a huge, pure gold nugget, the largest nugget ever found, and he would bring it to the shore in a closed carriage protected by six mounted policemen. The natives would attack them three times and be repelled with great bloodshed. But no, James would not go to the gold mines either. Those were disgusting places where men got drunk and shot each other in bars, using foul language. James would run a sensible and well-behaved sheep farm. One evening, while returning home on horseback, he would see that beautiful, rich girl being kidnapped by a bandit on a black horse, and he would immediately chase after them and rescue the girl. Of course, the girl would fall in love with him, and he with her; they would get married, then return here and live in a huge house in London. Yes, very beautiful things awaited James. However, at the beginning, he had to behave very well; he should not get angry or squander his money. Sibyl was only a year older than him, yet she knew life much better. Then James had to write to her with every mail, and say his prayers every night before bed. God was very kind-hearted and would surely watch over him. Sibyl would also pray for him and a few years later, James would return very rich and happy.
es: Jim frowned from time to time when he caught the inquisitive gaze of a stranger. He felt, in the face of the insistent stares, the displeasure that geniuses only know late in life, and that always accompanies ordinary people. Sibyl, however, was completely unaware of the effect she caused. Love trembled on her lips in the form of laughter. She thought of the blue prince and, to be able to do so more freely, she started to chatter about the ship on which Jim was going to set sail, about the gold he would undoubtedly find, about the wonderful heiress whose life he would save from the evil red-shirted bandits. Because he would not remain a sailor, or a purser, or whatever it was he did on board. No, no! The life of a sailor was dreadful. How absurd to be confined in a horrible ship that the monstrous crests of the waves tried to invade, while a sinister wind knocked down masts and tore sails until they became long, disheveled, roaring rags. Without a doubt, Jim would leave the ship in Melbourne, politely bid farewell to the captain, and set off for the goldfields. Before a week had passed, he would have found a huge nugget, the largest ever discovered, and he would transport it to the coast in a cart protected by six mounted policemen. The robbers would attack them three times, and they would be repelled with immense losses. Or better yet, no. He would not go to the goldfields, which were horrible places where men got drunk and fought with guns in the bars and said foul words. He would raise sheep and, one night, when he returned home on horseback, upon seeing the beautiful heiress, kidnapped by a thief on a black horse, he would chase them and rescue her. Of course, the girl would fall in love with him, and he with her, they would marry, return to England, and live in a huge London house. Yes, wonderful adventures awaited him. But he had to be very good, and not get angry, nor spend his money foolishly. Sibyl was only a year older than Jim, but she knew much more about life. He also had to write to her whenever there was mail, and say his prayers every night before going to bed. God was very good and would take care of him. She would also pray for him, and in a very few years, he would return, very rich and very happy.

en: The lad listened sulkily to her and made no answer. He was heart-sick at leaving home.
vi: The young man listened to her gloomily, not responding. He was feeling down because he had to be away from home.
tr: James was listening with a sullen face, not responding. His heart was aching because he was going to leave his home and homeland.
es: The boy listened to her sullenly and made no comment. His heart broke at the thought of leaving his home.

en: Yet it was not this alone that made him gloomy and morose. Inexperienced though he was, he had still a strong sense of the danger of Sibyl’s position. This young dandy who was making love to her could mean her no good. He was a gentleman, and he hated him for that, hated him through some curious race-instinct for which he could not account, and which for that reason was all the more dominant within him. He was conscious also of the shallowness and vanity of his mother’s nature, and in that saw infinite peril for Sibyl and Sibyl’s happiness. Children begin by loving their parents; as they grow older they judge them; sometimes they forgive them.
vi: However, it was not just this matter that made him troubled. Despite his lack of experience, he still had a very uneasy feeling about the danger in Sibyl's situation. This dandy, who was courting her, might have bad intentions towards her. He was a nobleman, and he hated him for that, hated him due to some strange class instinct that he could not explain, and for that reason, it dominated him even more. He was also aware of the shallowness and frivolity in his mother's nature, and in that he saw endless danger for Sibyl and Sibyl's happiness. Children begin by loving their parents; as they grow older, they judge them; sometimes they forgive them.
tr: It wasn't just this that made him so joyless and sullen. Although still inexperienced, he was aware of the danger Sibyl was in. The young society dandy chasing after Sibyl couldn't have good intentions. He was a polite gentleman, and James resented him for this, harboring a strange instinctive grudge that he didn't fully understand, which made him feel it more intensely. The young man was also aware of the shallowness and arrogance in his mother's nature; he saw great danger in this for Sibyl, for Sibyl's happiness. Children initially love their parents, as they grow, they judge them, and sometimes they forgive them.
es: But it was not just that which depressed him and put him in a bad mood. Despite his lack of experience, he was fully aware of the dangers of Sibyl's situation. That young dandy who was courting her would not bring her happiness. He was a gentleman and he loathed him for that, with a strange instinctive repugnance that he could not explain and which, for that very reason, was even more compelling. He was also not blind to the superficiality and vanity of her mother, and he saw in that an infinite danger for Sibyl and her happiness. Children begin life loving their parents; as they grow older, they judge them, and sometimes they forgive them.

en: His mother! He had something on his mind to ask of her, something that he had brooded on for many months of silence. A chance phrase that he had heard at the theatre, a whispered sneer that had reached his ears one night as he waited at the stage-door, had set loose a train of horrible thoughts. He remembered it as if it had been the lash of a hunting-crop across his face. His brows knit together into a wedge-like furrow, and with a twitch of pain he bit his underlip.
vi: Mom! In your heart, you have something you want to ask your mom, something you have been holding onto for many months in silence. A casual remark you overheard in the theater, a mocking whisper that reached your ears one night while you were waiting at the stage door, unleashed a terrible stream of thoughts. You remember it as if it were a whip lash across your face. Your eyebrows furrowed together into a wedge-shaped wrinkle, and with a painful grimace, you bit your lower lip.
tr: Mother! There was something James wanted to ask his mother, something that had been quietly bothering him for months. A few words overheard in the theater, a few mocking remarks he heard while waiting at the backstage door one night, had started a terrible chain of thoughts in his mind. The young man remembered it as if it were a whip strike across his face. When he frowned, two deep lines formed in the middle of his forehead, and James bit his lip with an expression of pain.
es: His mother! There was something he wanted to ask her that obsessed him, something he had been pondering in silence for many months. A casual phrase he had heard at the theater, a mocking whisper that reached his ears one night while he waited by the artists' exit, had set off a horrible chain of thoughts. He remembered it like a whip strike across his face. He frowned deeply, forming a very deep furrow, and with a painful shudder, he bit his lips.

en: “You are not listening to a word I am saying, Jim,” cried Sibyl, “and I am making the most delightful plans for your future. Do say something.”
vi: "You don't listen to anything I say, Jim," Sibyl cried, "and I'm making the most exciting plans for your future." "Say something."
tr: Sibyl complained, "You are not listening to a single word I say!" "Yet I am making such brilliant plans for your future! Please, say something."
es: —You don't listen to a single word I say, Jim —exclaimed Sibyl—, even though I make the most wonderful plans for your future. Please do me the favor of talking to me.

en: “What do you want me to say?”
vi: “What do you want me to say?” “Oh!
tr: “What do you want me to say?”
es: —What do you want me to say?

en: “Oh! that you will be a good boy and not forget us,” she answered, smiling at him.
vi: That you will be a good boy, and not forget the whole family,” she replied, smiling at him.
tr: Sibyl looked at her brother and smiled, "Just tell him to behave and not forget us," she replied.
es: —Well, you're going to be a good boy and you won't forget about us —replied his sister, smiling at him.

en: He shrugged his shoulders. “You are more likely to forget me than I am to forget you, Sibyl.”
vi: He shrugged. “It's more likely that you forgot me than I forgot you, Sibyl.”
tr: James shrugged his shoulders. "It's more likely that you will forget me than I will forget you, Sibyl."
es: Jim shrugged. —It will be easier for you to forget me than for me to forget you.

en: She flushed. “What do you mean, Jim?” she asked.
vi: She blushed. "What do you mean, Jim?" she asked.
tr: The young girl turned bright pink. “What do you mean, Jim?””
es: Sibyl blushed. —What do you mean? —he asked.

en: “You have a new friend, I hear. Who is he? Why have you not told me about him? He means you no good.”
vi: "You have a new friend, I heard that." "Who is he? Why didn't you tell me about him?" "He doesn't have good intentions towards you."
tr: “I heard you have a new friend. Who is this?.. Why have you never told me about them? Their intentions towards you are not good at all.”
es: —You have a new friend, according to what I've heard. Who is it? Why haven't you told me about him? He won't do you any good.

en: “Stop, Jim!” she exclaimed. “You must not say anything against him. I love him.”
vi: “Stop, Jim!” she exclaimed. “I shouldn't say anything against him. I love him.”
tr: The girl said, "Stop, Jim!" "Don't say anything bad about him. I love him."
es: —Don't continue, Jim! —he exclaimed—. Don't say anything against him. I love him.

en: “Why, you don’t even know his name,” answered the lad. “Who is he? I have a right to know.”
vi: “Why, you don't even know his name yet,” the young man replied. “Who is he? I have the right to know.”
tr: The child replied, "My dear, you don't even know his name." "Who is this man? It's my right to know."
es: —How is it possible! You don't even know his name —the boy replied—. Who is he? I have the right to know.

en: “He is called Prince Charming. Don’t you like the name. Oh! you silly boy! you should never forget it. If you only saw him, you would think him the most wonderful person in the world. Some day you will meet him—when you come back from Australia. You will like him so much. Everybody likes him, and I ... love him. I wish you could come to the theatre to-night. He is going to be there, and I am to play Juliet. Oh! how I shall play it! Fancy, Jim, to be in love and play Juliet! To have him sitting there! To play for his delight! I am afraid I may frighten the company, frighten or enthrall them. To be in love is to surpass one’s self. Poor dreadful Mr. Isaacs will be shouting ‘genius’ to his loafers at the bar. He has preached me as a dogma; to-night he will announce me as a revelation. I feel it. And it is all his, his only, Prince Charming, my wonderful lover, my god of graces. But I am poor beside him. Poor? What does that matter? When poverty creeps in at the door, love flies in through the window. Our proverbs want rewriting. They were made in winter, and it is summer now; spring-time for me, I think, a very dance of blossoms in blue skies.”
vi: "His name is Prince Charming. Do you like that name? Oh! You are such a silly boy! You must never forget it. Just by seeing him, you will think he is the most wonderful person in the world. One day you will meet him: when you return from Australia. You will like him very much. Everyone likes him, and I... love him. I wish you could come to the theater tonight. He will be there, and I will play Juliet. Oh! How can I play that role! Imagine, Jim, being in love and playing Juliet! With him sitting there! Acting to please him! I fear I might frighten the audience, either scare them or enchant them. To love is to surpass oneself. Poor Mr. Isaacs will shout 'genius' to the idlers at the pub. He has praised me like a creed; tonight he will declare me a revelation. I feel it. And it is all for him, only for him, Prince Charming, my wonderful lover, my god of beauty. But I am too poor for him. Poor? So what? When poverty creeps in at the door, love flies in through the window. Our book of proverbs needs to be rewritten. They were made in winter, but now it is summer; no, I think for me it is spring, a true dance of flowers in the blue sky."
tr: "His name is Sweet Prince. Didn't you like this name? Oh, silly child! Never forget this. If you saw him, you too would say he is the most extraordinary person in the world. One day you will meet him. When you return from Australia. You will love him so much! Everyone adores him, and I... love him too. I wish you could come to the theater tonight. He will come, and I will play Juliet. If only you knew how I will play Juliet! Jim, just think about it, being in love and playing Juliet! Knowing that he is sitting there! Acting to give him hope! I am afraid I will either scare or enchant the audience. Being in love means surpassing oneself. That poor, ugly Mr. Isaacs will talk about my genius to his idle friends at the bar. How many sermons he has given about me, as if I were a dogma! Tonight he will declare to the world that I am an illusion! I feel it in my bones. It is all because of him, my Sweet Prince, my magnificent love, the god of all graces. Next to him, I am very poor. Poor? What does it matter? When poverty enters through the door, love flies out the window. Our proverbs need to be rewritten. They were written in winter, but now it is summer, even still spring for me, a dance of fruit blossoms against the blue sky."
es: —He's called Prince Charming. Don't you like him? Come on, don't be silly! You must never forget him. If you saw him, you would realize that he is the most wonderful person in the world. Someday you'll meet him, when you return from Australia. You will like him a lot. Everyone likes him; and I... I love him. I wish you could come to the theater tonight. He will be there, and I am going to play Juliet. Ah, how I will perform my role! Imagine, Jim! Being in love and playing Juliet! Having him there, watching me! Performing to please him! I'm afraid of scaring the company, of scaring them or captivating them. To love is to surpass oneself. That poor and terrible Mr. Isaacs will rave about my talent to the loafers in his bar. He has preached me as a dogma; tonight he will announce me as a revelation. I foresee it. And it is all his, only his, my Prince Charming, my wonderful lover, my divine giver of all graces. But I am poor beside him. Poor? What does that matter? If poverty humbly knocks at the door, love enters through the window. We need to rewrite our proverbs. They were made in winter, and now we are in summer; spring for me, I think, a dance of rosebuds in a blue sky.

en: “He is a gentleman,” said the lad sullenly.
vi: "He is a nobleman," the young man said, dejectedly.
tr: His brother said with a sullen face, "He was a gentleman."
es: —He is a gentleman —said the boy resentfully.

en: “A prince!” she cried musically. “What more do you want?”
vi: “A prince!” she exclaimed, melodiously. "What else do you want?"
tr: The girl shouted, "A prince!" in a voice like a song. "What more do you want?"
es: —A prince! —she exclaimed, her voice full of music—. What more is needed?

en: “He wants to enslave you.”
vi: “He wants to turn you into a slave.”
tr: “He wants to capture you.”
es: —He wants to enslave you.

en: “I shudder at the thought of being free.”
vi: “She shuddered at the thought of being free.”
tr: “The thought of freedom gives me chills.”
es: —The idea of being free makes me shudder.

en: “I want you to beware of him.”
vi: “I want you to be careful with him.”
tr: “I want you to stay away from him.”
es: —Be careful, I beg you.

en: “To see him is to worship him; to know him is to trust him.”
vi: “Seeing you is to worship you, knowing you is to trust you.”
tr: “To see him is to worship him, and to know him is to trust him.”
es: —To see him is to adore him, to know him is to trust him.

en: “Sibyl, you are mad about him.”
vi: "Sibyl, you are crazy about him."
tr: “Sibyl, you are going mad for him.”
es: —You have lost your mind, Sibyl.

en: She laughed and took his arm. “You dear old Jim, you talk as if you were a hundred. Some day you will be in love yourself. Then you will know what it is. Don’t look so sulky. Surely you should be glad to think that, though you are going away, you leave me happier than I have ever been before. Life has been hard for us both, terribly hard and difficult. But it will be different now. You are going to a new world, and I have found one. Here are two chairs; let us sit down and see the smart people go by.”
vi: She smiled and took his arm. “Dear old Jim, you talk as if you were a hundred years old. One day you will fall in love yourself. Then you will know what it's like. Don't act so sulky. You should certainly be happy thinking that even though I'm about to go far away, I'm leaving behind a sister who is happier than ever. Life has been harsh to both of us, so harsh and difficult. But now it will be different. I'm going to a new world, and I've found a world. There are two chairs here; let's sit down and watch the well-dressed people go by.”
tr: Sibyl, laughing, took his arm. "My dear Jim, you talk as if you were a hundred years old. One day you will love too. Then you will understand how it is. Don't sulk like that. You are leaving, but you are leaving me happier than I have ever been before: Shouldn't you be glad about that? Both of our lives have been tough, Jim; extremely tough, challenging. But from now on, it will be different. You are going to a brand new world, and I have found a brand new world. Look, there are two seats over there, let's sit down and watch these elegant people passing by."
es: His sister burst out laughing and took him by the arm. —My dear and mature Jim, you talk as if you were a hundred years old. Someday you too will fall in love. Then you will know what it's all about. Don't make that grumpy face. You should be happy to think that, even though you're leaving, you're leaving me happier than ever. Life has been hard for the two of us, terribly hard and difficult. But from now on it will be different. You are going to a new world, and I have discovered one. Here are two empty chairs; let's sit down and watch the elegant people go by.

en: They took their seats amidst a crowd of watchers. The tulip-beds across the road flamed like throbbing rings of fire. A white dust—tremulous cloud of orris-root it seemed—hung in the panting air. The brightly coloured parasols danced and dipped like monstrous butterflies.
vi: They sat amidst the crowd of people watching the scenery. The tulip flower beds across the street bloomed like lively rings of fire. White dust, like a cloud of iris root powder, swayed and hovered in the yearning air. The brightly colored umbrellas floated like giant butterflies.
tr: They took their places in the crowd. The tulip beds across the road were flickering like rings of fire. A trembling white mist, resembling iris dust, had settled in the air, which seemed to have lost its breath from the heat. Brightly colored umbrellas were bobbing up and down like giant butterflies.
es: They sat in the midst of a crowd of idlers. The tulip beds on the other side of the avenue burned, turned into throbbing rings of fire. A white dust, it seemed like a trembling cloud of lily dust, floated in the panting air. The bright-colored parasols rose and fell like giant butterflies.

en: She made her brother talk of himself, his hopes, his prospects. He spoke slowly and with effort. They passed words to each other as players at a game pass counters. Sibyl felt oppressed. She could not communicate her joy. A faint smile curving that sullen mouth was all the echo she could win. After some time she became silent. Suddenly she caught a glimpse of golden hair and laughing lips, and in an open carriage with two ladies Dorian Gray drove past.
vi: She made her brother talk about himself, about his hopes, about his expectations. He spoke slowly and with considerable effort. They exchanged words like gamblers exchanging chips in a card game. Sibyl felt heavy-hearted. She couldn't share her joy. A weary smile that curved her gloomy mouth was the only sign she could give. After a while, she began to fall silent. Suddenly, she caught a glimpse of golden hair and smiling lips, and in an open carriage, along with two ladies, Dorian Gray passed by.
tr: Sibyl directed her brother to talk about himself, his hopes, his expectations, and his possibilities. Like players passing the ball in a game, they were tossing words back and forth to each other. A heaviness settled within Sibyl. She couldn't instill her happiness in her brother! The only response she could get was a barely perceptible smile that curved those sullen lips. After a while, she fell silent. Then suddenly, she caught sight of golden hair and smiling lips, and Dorian Gray passed by in an open car, accompanied by two ladies.
es: Sibyl made her brother talk about himself, his hopes, his plans. Jim expressed himself slowly and with difficulty. They passed words to each other like players pass chips. Sibyl began to feel depressed. She couldn't convey her joy. All her efforts only elicited a faint smile at the corners of that stern mouth. After some time, she stopped talking. Suddenly, she glimpsed some golden hair and laughing lips: Dorian Gray was passing by in an open carriage with two ladies.

en: She started to her feet. “There he is!” she cried.
vi: She stood up abruptly. "It's him!" she exclaimed.
tr: Sibyl had jumped to her feet. “There he is!” she shouted.
es: Sibyl jumped to her feet. —There it is! —he exclaimed.

en: “Who?” said Jim Vane.
vi: “What?” Jim Vane said.
tr: "Kim?"
es: —Who?

en: “Prince Charming,” she answered, looking after the victoria.
vi: “Prince Charming,” she replied, watching the four-wheeled convertible carriage.
tr: The girl, looking after the "Victoria" type car, responded, "Sweet Prince."
es: —My Prince Charming —she replied, following the victory with her eyes.

en: He jumped up and seized her roughly by the arm. “Show him to me. Which is he? Point him out. I must see him!” he exclaimed; but at that moment the Duke of Berwick’s four-in-hand came between, and when it had left the space clear, the carriage had swept out of the park.
vi: He jumped up, grabbing her arm forcefully. "Show him to me. Who is he? Point him out. I must see him!" he shouted; but at that moment, the Duke of Berwick's four-horse carriage drove in between them, and by the time it left an opening, the open carriage had already glided out of the Park.
tr: His brother also jumped up and roughly grabbed his arm. “Show it to me. Which one? Point it out. Let me see it!” he shouted, but just then the Duke of Berwick's four-horse carriage got in the way. By the time it moved away, the other carriage had already left the park.
es: Her brother also stood up and grabbed her roughly by the arm. —Show it to me. Who is it? Point them out to me. I have to see them! —he exclaimed; but at that moment the Duke of Berwick's carriage, drawn by four horses, came between them, and when the horizon cleared again, the other vehicle had left the park.

en: “He is gone,” murmured Sibyl sadly. “I wish you had seen him.”
vi: “He is gone,” Sibyl whispered sadly. “I wish you had seen him.”
tr: Sibyl sadly murmured, "She left." "I wanted you to see her!" “I would also like to see him, because, as God in heaven knows, if this man ever harms you one day, I will kill him too.”
es: —He has gone —murmured Sibyl, saddened—. I wish you had seen him.

en: “I wish I had, for as sure as there is a God in heaven, if he ever does you any wrong, I shall kill him.”
vi: “I also wish I had seen it, because I swear to God in heaven, if he ever harms you, I will kill him.”
tr: “I would also like to see him, because, as God in heaven knows, if this man ever harms you one day, I will kill him too.”
es: —I would have liked it too, because as sure as there is a God in heaven, if he ever hurts you, I will kill him.

en: She looked at him in horror. He repeated his words. They cut the air like a dagger. The people round began to gape. A lady standing close to her tittered.
vi: She looked at him fearfully. He repeated his words. They cut through the air sweetly like a knife. Everyone around began to gape and stare. A woman stood close to her and giggled.
tr: Sibyl stared at her brother in horror. James repeated his earlier words. His words seemed to cut through the air like a dagger. Those around them began to look at them with curiosity. A lady standing nearby laughed with a giggle.
es: His sister looked at him horrified. Jim repeated what he had said, and his words cut through the air like a dagger. The people around him were left open-mouthed. A lady who was very close by laughed nervously.

en: “Come away, Jim; come away,” she whispered. He followed her doggedly as she passed through the crowd. He felt glad at what he had said.
vi: “Let's go, Jim; let's go,” she whispered. He stubbornly followed her as she moved through the crowd. He felt happy about what he had just said.
tr: Sibyl whispered, "Let's go, Jim, let's go." He made his way through the crowd, and James followed him. He was glad he had said those words earlier.
es: —Let's go, Jim, let's go - Sibyl whispered. He followed her, undaunted, through the crowd. He was glad he had said what he had said.

en: When they reached the Achilles Statue, she turned round. There was pity in her eyes that became laughter on her lips. She shook her head at him. “You are foolish, Jim, utterly foolish; a bad-tempered boy, that is all. How can you say such horrible things? You don’t know what you are talking about. You are simply jealous and unkind. Ah! I wish you would fall in love. Love makes people good, and what you said was wicked.”
vi: When they reached the statue of Achilles, she turned around. The pity in her eyes turned into laughter on her lips. She shook her head at him. "You are so silly, Jim, too silly; a naughty boy, that's all. How can you say such terrible things? You don't know what you're talking about. You are just jealous and bitter. Oh! I hope you will love. Love makes people kinder, and what you said is really cruel."
tr: When they arrived at the Statue of Achilles, Sibyl turned to her brother. The pity in her eyes was turning into a smile on her lips. She shook her head as if scolding him. "You're talking nonsense, Jim, absolute nonsense. You're just a grumpy child, that's all. How can you say such horrible things? You have no idea what you're talking about. You're jealous and hurtful. Oh, I wish you would fall in love with someone! Love instills goodness in a person, whereas what you're saying is both bad and sinful."
es: When they arrived at the statue of Achilles, Sibyl turned to her brother. The pity in her eyes turned into laughter as it reached her lips. —You are crazy, Jim, completely crazy —she said, shaking her head—; a boy with a very bad temper, that's all. How can you imagine such horrible things? You don't know what you're saying. You're simply jealous and very unkind. I wish you would fall in love! Love makes people good, and what you said was mean.

en: “I am sixteen,” he answered, “and I know what I am about. Mother is no help to you. She doesn’t understand how to look after you. I wish now that I was not going to Australia at all. I have a great mind to chuck the whole thing up. I would, if my articles hadn’t been signed.”
vi: “I am sixteen years old,” he replied, “and I know what I'm saying. Mom can't help you. Mom doesn't know how to take care of you. Now I wish I hadn't gone to Australia at all. I want to quit everything. I would probably do that if I hadn't signed the contract terms.”
tr: His brother said, "I'm sixteen years old, I know what things are." "My mother is of no use to you. She doesn't know how to look after you. I wish I had never tried to go to Australia! The devil says to give it all up. And I would give it up too, but my contracts are signed."
es: —I am sixteen years old —Jim replied—, and I know what I'm talking about. Our mother doesn't help you at all. She doesn't know how to take care of you. I would rather not have to go to Australia. I'm about to throw it all away. I would do it if I hadn't signed the contract.

en: “Oh, don’t be so serious, Jim. You are like one of the heroes of those silly melodramas Mother used to be so fond of acting in. I am not going to quarrel with you. I have seen him, and oh! to see him is perfect happiness. We won’t quarrel. I know you would never harm any one I love, would you?”
vi: “Oh, don't be so serious, Jim. You're like one of the characters in those naive melodramas that mother used to love performing. I won't argue with you. I've seen him, and oh my! Seeing him is a complete happiness. We won't argue anymore. I know you would never harm anyone I love, right?”
tr: “Oh, don't be so serious, Jim. You look like those heroes in silly melodramas. You know, the ones my mother loved to act in! Anyway, I'm not going to fight with you. I saw him! Oh, if you only knew, seeing him is pure happiness. We won't fight. I know, you could never harm someone I love, right?”
es: —Don't be so serious, Jim. You're like one of the heroes from those stupid melodramas that our mother loved to perform. I'm not going to fight with you. I've seen it and seeing it is perfect happiness. We won't quarrel. I know you'll never harm someone I love, will you?

en: “Not as long as you love him, I suppose,” was the sullen answer.
vi: “As long as you still love him, I don't think so,” was the gloomy reply.
tr: James replied with a frown, "I guess I can't do it as long as you love him."
es: —No, as long as you still want it, I suppose —was his gruff response.

en: “I shall love him for ever!” she cried.
vi: “I will love him forever!” she exclaimed.
tr: Sibyl shouted, "I will love him forever!"
es: —I will love him forever! —exclaimed Sibyl.

en: “And he?”
vi: “And him?”
tr: “What about it?”
es: —And him?

en: “For ever, too!”
vi: “The same, forever”
tr: “Forever and ever!””
es: —Always the same!

en: “He had better.”
vi: “He should be like that.”
tr: “Love, or it will be bad.”
es: —He better.

en: She shrank from him. Then she laughed and put her hand on his arm. He was merely a boy.
vi: She stepped back from him. Then she smiled and placed her hand on his arm. He was just a child.
tr: Sibyl moved a little away from him. Then, laughing, she took his arm. James was still a child.
es: Sibyl moved slightly away from him. Then she laughed and put her hand on his arm. He was nothing more than a child.

en: At the Marble Arch they hailed an omnibus, which left them close to their shabby home in the Euston Road. It was after five o’clock, and Sibyl had to lie down for a couple of hours before acting. Jim insisted that she should do so. He said that he would sooner part with her when their mother was not present. She would be sure to make a scene, and he detested scenes of every kind.
vi: At the Marble Arch, they hailed a bus, which dropped them off right next to their shabby house on Euston Road. It was past five o'clock, and Sibyl had to rest for a few hours before performing. Jim insisted that she do so. He said that he preferred to say goodbye to her when their mother was absent. Their mother would surely create a scene, and he hated all kinds of scenes.
tr: They took a marble there and boarded a bus. They got off near Euston Street, close to those poor houses. It was past five o'clock. Sibyl needed to lie down and rest for a few hours before going on stage. Jim insisted on this. He wanted to say goodbye to her away from their mother. Their mother would definitely cause a scene, and Jim was disgusted by all such scenes.
es: At Marble Arch, they took a bus that left them near their modest home. It was past five, and Sibyl had to rest lying down for a couple of hours before the performance. Jim insisted that she do so. He said he preferred to say goodbye to her when their mother wasn't present. She would certainly make a scene, and Jim detested any kind of scene.

en: In Sybil’s own room they parted. There was jealousy in the lad’s heart, and a fierce murderous hatred of the stranger who, as it seemed to him, had come between them. Yet, when her arms were flung round his neck, and her fingers strayed through his hair, he softened and kissed her with real affection. There were tears in his eyes as he went downstairs.
vi: They bid farewell to each other in Sibyl's private room. There was jealousy in the boy's heart, and a seething, murderous hatred towards the stranger, whom he perceived had come between them. Yet, when her arm wrapped around his neck and her fingers wandered through his hair, he softened, and kissed her with genuine affection. Tears blurred his vision as he descended the stairs.
tr: They said goodbye in Sibyl's room. The young man's heart was filled with jealousy, a bloody and bitter hatred towards the stranger he saw as coming between him and his sister. Yet, when Sibyl's arms wrapped around his neck and her fingers ran through his hair, James softened and kissed the girl with genuine affection. There were tears in his eyes as he walked down the stairs.
es: They parted in Sibyl's room. The boy's heart was dominated by jealousy, and he felt a fierce, murderous hatred against that stranger who, in his opinion, had come between them. However, when Sibyl threw her arms around his neck and caressed his hair with her fingers, Jim softened and kissed her with sincere affection. His eyes were full of tears as he went down the stairs.

en: His mother was waiting for him below. She grumbled at his unpunctuality, as he entered. He made no answer, but sat down to his meagre meal. The flies buzzed round the table and crawled over the stained cloth. Through the rumble of omnibuses, and the clatter of street-cabs, he could hear the droning voice devouring each minute that was left to him.
vi: Your mother is waiting for you downstairs. She grumbles about your lack of punctuality as you walk in. You don't respond, but sit down to eat your meager meal. Flies buzz around the table and crawl on the stained tablecloth. Through the rumble of buses and the clatter of hired carriages, you can hear a monotonous voice devouring the remaining minutes with you.
tr: His mother was waiting for him downstairs. She muttered because he was late. James sat down at the head of the poor table without responding. Flies were buzzing around the table, crawling on the stained tablecloth. Amid the growl of buses and the clatter of trams, the young boy heard the droning sound that swallowed up the last moments in his home.
es: His mother was waiting for him downstairs. She complained about his lack of punctuality when she saw him come in. Jim did not respond, but he sat down to consume his modest dinner. Flies buzzed around the table and ran over the slightly dirty tablecloth. Amid the dull noise of the buses and the clamor of the horse-drawn carriages, he heard the monotonous voice that devoured each of the minutes he had left.

en: After some time, he thrust away his plate and put his head in his hands. He felt that he had a right to know. It should have been told to him before, if it was as he suspected. Leaden with fear, his mother watched him. Words dropped mechanically from her lips. A tattered lace handkerchief twitched in her fingers. When the clock struck six, he got up and went to the door. Then he turned back and looked at her. Their eyes met. In hers he saw a wild appeal for mercy. It enraged him.
vi: A moment later, he pushed the plate aside and rested his head in his hands. He felt that he had the right to know. That matter should have been told to him earlier, if it was as he suspected. Stunned with fear, his mother watched him. Her words fell from her lips mechanically. The tattered lace handkerchief crumpled in her fingers. When the clock struck six, he stood up and walked to the door. Then he turned back and looked at her. Their eyes met. In her eyes, he saw a wild plea for forgiveness. It made him furious.
tr: After a while, he pushed his plate away and put his head in his hands. He thought he had the right to know. If the situation was as he suspected, they should have told him earlier. His mother, her heart heavy with fear, was looking at him. Words were spilling from her lips like a machine, and she was twisting a torn lace handkerchief between her hands. When the clock struck six, James got up and walked to the door. Then he turned and looked at his mother. Their eyes met. James read a faint plea for mercy in his mother's eyes. This drove him mad with rage.
es: After some time, he pushed the plate aside and hid his head in his hands. He was convinced that he had the right to know. They should have told him earlier if everything had happened as he suspected. His mother watched him, overcome with fear. The words came mechanically from her lips. With her fingers, she twisted a lace handkerchief that was in tatters. When the wall clock struck six, Jim stood up and headed for the door. Then he turned, and their eyes met. In his mother's eyes, he discovered a desperate plea for compassion that filled him with anger.

en: “Mother, I have something to ask you,” he said. Her eyes wandered vaguely about the room. She made no answer. “Tell me the truth. I have a right to know. Were you married to my father?”
vi: “Mom, I have something to ask you,” he said. Her eyes wandered around the room absentmindedly. She did not respond. “Tell me the truth. I have the right to know. Did you marry my father?”
tr: “Anne, there is something I want to ask you,” he said. Ms. Vane let her eyes wander aimlessly around the room, not responding. “Tell me the truth. I have the right to know. Were you married to my father?”
es: —Mother, there is something I need to ask you —he said. Mrs. Vane's eyes wandered aimlessly around the room, but she did not reply—. Tell me the truth. I have the right to know. Were you married to my father?

en: She heaved a deep sigh. It was a sigh of relief. The terrible moment, the moment that night and day, for weeks and months, she had dreaded, had come at last, and yet she felt no terror. Indeed, in some measure it was a disappointment to her. The vulgar directness of the question called for a direct answer. The situation had not been gradually led up to. It was crude. It reminded her of a bad rehearsal.
vi: She let out a deep sigh. It was a sign of relief. The dreadful moment, the moment that she had feared day and night, week after week, month after month, had finally come, yet she did not feel afraid. Indeed, to some extent, it was a disappointment to her. The bluntness of the question demanded a direct answer. The situation was not gradually led step by step. It was really crude. It reminded her of a bad rehearsal.
tr: Ms. Vane took a deep breath. It was a sigh of relief. That tremendous moment, the moment she had been waiting for with dread every day and night for weeks, months, had finally arrived, but the woman was not afraid. To tell the truth, it was somewhat disappointing for her. The question being asked so plainly and directly required a straightforward answer. The situation had not developed gradually! It was indeed rude. It reminded Ms. Vane of a poorly performed rehearsal.
es: Mrs. Vane let out a deep sigh, a sigh of relief. The terrible moment, the moment she had feared day and night, for weeks and months, had finally arrived, but she did not feel terror. To some extent, in fact, it was rather a disappointment. Such a vulgarly direct question demanded an equally direct answer. It was not a situation that had been reached gradually. It was crude. It made Mrs. Vane think of an unsatisfactory rehearsal.

en: “No,” she answered, wondering at the harsh simplicity of life.
vi: "No," she replied, astonished by the cruel simplicity of life.
tr: The woman, while responding "No," was feeling astonished by the harsh simplicity of life.
es: —No —she responded, amazed by the harsh simplicity of life.

en: “My father was a scoundrel then!” cried the lad, clenching his fists.
vi: “So my father is a bastard?” the young man shouted, clenching his fists tightly.
tr: The child clenched his fists and shouted, "So my father was a scoundrel!"
es: —In that case, my father was a scoundrel! —exclaimed the boy, clenching his fists.

en: She shook her head. “I knew he was not free. We loved each other very much. If he had lived, he would have made provision for us. Don’t speak against him, my son. He was your father, and a gentleman. Indeed, he was highly connected.”
vi: She shook her head. "I know he was preoccupied. Your father and I loved each other very much. If he were still alive, he would probably have provided for us. Do not criticize him, my son. He is your father, and a noble man. Indeed, he comes from a noble lineage."
tr: His mother shook her head. “I knew he wasn't free. We loved each other very much. If he had lived, he would have provided for us. Don't speak ill of him, my child. He was your father and a gentleman. Believe me, he came from a very distinguished family.”
es: His mother shook her head. —I knew he wasn't free. We loved each other very much. If he had lived, he would have attended to our needs. Do not condemn him, my son. He was your father and a gentleman. He belonged to an excellent family.

en: An oath broke from his lips. “I don’t care for myself,” he exclaimed, “but don’t let Sibyl.... It is a gentleman, isn’t it, who is in love with her, or says he is? Highly connected, too, I suppose.”
vi: A curse escaped his lips. "I don't care about myself," he shouted, "but don't let Sibyl... It's that nobleman, isn't it, who is in love with her, or says he is?" "Also, I suppose, he belongs to the nobility."
tr: A curse word escaped from James's lips. The boy said, "I don't care for myself." "But don't you dare... The man who is in love with her is a gentleman, isn't he, or at least he claims to be. Maybe he is also from a very high family."
es: A curse escaped Jim. —I don't care —he exclaimed—, but don't let anything happen to Sibyl... He's a gentleman, isn't he, the one who's in love with her, or says he is? From an excellent family, too, I imagine.

en: For a moment a hideous sense of humiliation came over the woman. Her head drooped. She wiped her eyes with shaking hands. “Sibyl has a mother,” she murmured; “I had none.”
vi: In an instant, an overwhelming sense of humiliation engulfed the woman. Her head drooped down. She wiped her eyes with trembling hands. “Sibyl has a mother,” she whispered; “a mother does not.”
tr: For a moment, the woman felt as if she was sinking into the ground. Her head dropped forward. She wiped her eyes with trembling hands. “Sibyl has a mother,” she murmured. “I was motherless.”
es: For an instant, Mrs. Vane felt terribly humiliated. She bowed her head. She wiped her eyes with trembling hands. —Sibyl has a mother —he murmured—; I did not have one.

en: The lad was touched. He went towards her, and stooping down, he kissed her. “I am sorry if I have pained you by asking about my father,” he said, “but I could not help it. I must go now. Good-bye. Don’t forget that you will have only one child now to look after, and believe me that if this man wrongs my sister, I will find out who he is, track him down, and kill him like a dog. I swear it.”
vi: The young man was moved. He approached his mother, bent down, and kissed her. "I'm sorry if I caused you pain by asking about father," he said, "but I couldn't help it. I have to go now. Goodbye. Don't forget that from now on, you will only have one child to look after, and believe me, if that man harms my sister, I will find out who he is, track him down, and kill him like a dog. I swear."
tr: The child's heart ached. He went and kissed his mother. “If I upset you by asking about my father, forgive me,” he said. “I couldn't help but ask. I have to go now. Goodbye. Remember: You now have only one child who needs care. Believe me, if this man harms Sibyl, I will find out who he is, track him down, and kill him like a dog. I swear it.”
es: The boy was moved. He went towards her, leaned in, and kissed her. —I'm sorry for making you sad by asking about my father —he said—, but I couldn't help it. I have to go now. Goodbye. Don't forget that now you only have to take care of Sibyl, and believe me when I say that if that man deceives my sister, I will find out who he is, I will find him and I will kill him like a dog, I swear.

en: The exaggerated folly of the threat, the passionate gesture that accompanied it, the mad melodramatic words, made life seem more vivid to her. She was familiar with the atmosphere. She breathed more freely, and for the first time for many months she really admired her son. She would have liked to have continued the scene on the same emotional scale, but he cut her short. Trunks had to be carried down and mufflers looked for. The lodging-house drudge bustled in and out. There was the bargaining with the cabman. The moment was lost in vulgar details. It was with a renewed feeling of disappointment that she waved the tattered lace handkerchief from the window, as her son drove away. She was conscious that a great opportunity had been wasted. She consoled herself by telling Sibyl how desolate she felt her life would be, now that she had only one child to look after. She remembered the phrase. It had pleased her. Of the threat she said nothing. It was vividly and dramatically expressed. She felt that they would all laugh at it some day.
vi: The exaggerated madness of threats, the lively gestures accompanying them, the frantic and impassioned words made life seem more colorful to her. She had become accustomed to this atmosphere. She could breathe more comfortably, and for the first time in many months, she felt a genuine admiration for her son. Perhaps she even wanted to continue this scene with the same emotional intensity, but he cut it short. Suitcases had to be brought down, scarves had to be found. The boarding house staff hurried in and out. Bargaining with the coachman. That moment was lost in the usual details. With a renewed sense of disappointment, she waved a tattered lace handkerchief from the window as her son was taken away. She knew well that a great opportunity had been squandered. She consoled herself by telling Sibyl how lonely her life felt, as now she had only one child left to care for. She remembered that phrase. It pleased her. As for the threat, she said nothing. It had been expressed vividly and tragically. She felt that the whole family would laugh about it someday.
tr: The exaggerated madness of the threat, the child's fiery behavior while saying it, the reckless melodrama in the words, seemed to have brought some liveliness to the woman's life. She knew this atmosphere well. Now she was breathing more easily and, for the first time in months, felt a genuine admiration for her son. She wished she could prolong this scene with such sentimentality, but her son cut it short. There were trunks to be moved downstairs, scarves to be found and packed. The boarding house servants were bustling about. There was still bargaining to be done with the coachman. The moment of departure got lost among trivial details. As she waved the torn lace handkerchief from the window after her son, Ms. Vane felt a fresh wave of disappointment within her. She was aware that a great opportunity had been wasted. To console herself, she told Sybil that her life would become much lonelier from now on because she had only one child left to care for. She had not forgotten her son's words. But she did not mention the threat he had made. The child had delivered this intimidation in a very lively, dramatic manner. Ms. Vane thought that one day all three of them would remember this and laugh.
es: The excessive nature of the threat, the passionate gesture that accompanied it, the melodramatic words, made life regain some of its sparkle for the actress for a moment. All of that recreated an environment with which she was familiar. She breathed more freely and for the first time in many months felt true admiration for her son.
