She would have liked to continue the scene at the same emotional level, but Jim prevented her. Trunks had to be brought down, some warm clothing had to be found. The all-purpose servant of the boarding house was coming in and out incessantly. The price had to be negotiated with the coachman. The intensity of the moment was lost in vulgar details. From the window, Mrs. Vane waved her tattered lace handkerchief with a renewed feeling of disappointment as her son walked away. She realized that she had missed a great opportunity. She consoled herself by telling Sibyl how desolate her life would be now that she only had a daughter to care for. She remembered Jim's phrase, which she had liked. She said nothing about his threats. The way he had expressed it had been vigorous and dramatic. Mrs. Vane had the impression that someday everyone would remember her laughing.

en: CHAPTER VI.
vi: Chapter 6
tr: 3. White bismuth is especially used in theater, stage makeup. (Ç. N.) Chapter Six
es: Chapter 6

en: “I suppose you have heard the news, Basil?” said Lord Henry that evening as Hallward was shown into a little private room at the Bristol where dinner had been laid for three.
vi: "I suppose you have already heard the news, Basil?" Lord Henry asked that afternoon, when Hallward appeared in a small private room at Bristol, where dinner was set for three people.
tr: That evening, when Basil Hallward was shown into the room where a table for three had been set up at the Briston Hotel, Lord Henry asked, "You must have heard the news, haven't you, Basil?"
es: —Have you heard the news? —asked Lord Henry that night to Hallward when a waiter showed him into the small private room at the Bristol where a dinner for three was prepared.

en: “No, Harry,” answered the artist, giving his hat and coat to the bowing waiter. “What is it? Nothing about politics, I hope! They don’t interest me. There is hardly a single person in the House of Commons worth painting, though many of them would be the better for a little whitewashing.”
vi: “Not yet, Harry,” the artist replied, handing his hat and coat to the bowing servant. “What news? It’s not about politics, I hope? I don’t care about it. There’s hardly a single figure in the House of Commons worth painting; although many of them should be whitewashed.”
tr: Handing his painter's hat and coat to the bowing waiter in front of him, he said, "No." "What happened? I hope it isn't something related to politics? Politics doesn't interest me at all. There's not a single person in the House of Commons worth painting, but it would be great if many of them got a good whitewashing."
es: —No —replied the artist, handing his hat and coat to the waiter, who proceeded to bow to him—. What is it about? Nothing to do with politics, I hope. I'm not interested. There is hardly a single person in the House of Commons who deserves a portrait, although many of them would improve by being whitewashed a bit.

en: “Dorian Gray is engaged to be married,” said Lord Henry, watching him as he spoke.
vi: "Dorian Gray has promised to get married," Lord Henry said and watched the artist as he spoke.
tr: Lord Henry, looking at him carefully, said, "Dorian Gray is engaged."
es: —Dorian Gray is engaged —said Lord Henry, carefully examining his friend as he spoke.

en: Hallward started and then frowned. “Dorian engaged to be married!” he cried. “Impossible!”
vi: Hallward started, then frowned. "Dorian has promised to marry!" he exclaimed. "Impossible!"
tr: The painter suddenly flinched, then frowned. “Did you say Dorian is engaged? Impossible!”
es: Hallward started and then frowned. —Dorian engaged! —he exclaimed—. Impossible!

en: “It is perfectly true.”
vi: "The truth is plain to see."
tr: "It has happened.""
es: —It is absolutely true.

en: “To whom?”
vi: “Marry whom?”
tr: “With whom?”
es: —With whom?

en: “To some little actress or other.”
vi: “Take some unknown little actress.”
tr: “With some little actress.”
es: —With a little-known actress.

en: “I can’t believe it. Dorian is far too sensible.”
vi: "I can't believe that. Dorian is too clever for that."
tr: “I can't believe it. Dorian is sensible enough not to do such a thing.”
es: —I can't believe it. Dorian is too sensible.

en: “Dorian is far too wise not to do foolish things now and then, my dear Basil.”
vi: “Dorian is too experienced to not occasionally do something foolish, my dear Basil.”
tr: “Dorian is wise enough to occasionally avoid making foolish mistakes, my dear Basil.”
es: —Dorian is too prudent not to do something foolish from time to time, my dear Basil.

en: “Marriage is hardly a thing that one can do now and then, Harry.”
vi: “Marriage isn't something that people can just do from time to time, Harry.”
tr: “Harry, marriage is not something one does just occasionally, surely.”
es: —Getting married is something that can hardly be done from time to time, Harry.

en: “Except in America,” rejoined Lord Henry languidly. “But I didn’t say he was married. I said he was engaged to be married. There is a great difference. I have a distinct remembrance of being married, but I have no recollection at all of being engaged. I am inclined to think that I never was engaged.”
vi: “Except for America,” Lord Henry replied, languidly. “But I did not say he was married. I said he was engaged to be married. There is a great difference. I have a very clear memory of being married, but I remember nothing at all about being engaged. I am inclined to think that I never was engaged.”
tr: “Unless we are in America,” said Lord Henry lazily. “I didn't tell you that he got married. I said he got engaged. There is a big difference between the two. I clearly remember getting married but I can't remember getting engaged at all. Many times, I feel like I never got engaged.”
es: —Except in the United States —replied Lord Henry languidly—. But I did not say that he got married. I said that he got engaged. There is a big difference. I clearly remember being married, but I have no recollection of being engaged. I am inclined to believe that I was never engaged.

en: “But think of Dorian’s birth, and position, and wealth. It would be absurd for him to marry so much beneath him.”
vi: “But think about Dorian's lineage, both his status and wealth. Marrying someone so much inferior is very foolish for him.”
tr: “But think about Dorian’s family, his place in society, and his wealth. It would be ridiculous for him to marry a girl of such a lower status.”
es: —But think of Dorian's cradle, his position, his wealth. It would be absurd for him to marry so far below his possibilities.

en: “If you want to make him marry this girl, tell him that, Basil. He is sure to do it, then. Whenever a man does a thoroughly stupid thing, it is always from the noblest motives.”
vi: "If you want him to marry this girl, then tell him that, Basil. He will certainly do it. Whenever people do something extremely foolish, it is always for the noblest reasons."
tr: “If you really want him to marry this girl, go and tell him that, Basil. Then he will definitely marry her. Whenever a person does something utterly foolish, it is always for the noblest of purposes.”
es: —If you really want him to marry the girl, tell him exactly that. You can be sure that he will do it. Whenever a man does something perfectly stupid, he does it for the noblest of reasons.

en: “I hope the girl is good, Harry. I don’t want to see Dorian tied to some vile creature, who might degrade his nature and ruin his intellect.”
vi: "I hope that girl is well-behaved, Harry. I don't want to see Dorian tied to some hideous creature, someone who could corrupt his nature and destroy his intellect."
tr: “I hope this girl is a good person, Harry. I don't want Dorian to be tied to a disgusting creature. Then his personality would degrade, his mind would dull.”
es: —I hope the girl is good. I would not want to see Dorian tied to some horrendous creature that could debase his body and destroy his intelligence.

en: “Oh, she is better than good—she is beautiful,” murmured Lord Henry, sipping a glass of vermouth and orange-bitters. “Dorian says she is beautiful, and he is not often wrong about things of that kind. Your portrait of him has quickened his appreciation of the personal appearance of other people. It has had that excellent effect, amongst others. We are to see her to-night, if that boy doesn’t forget his appointment.”
vi: “Ah, she is more than just well-behaved — she is beautiful,” Lord Henry whispered, sipping a glass of vermouth with bitters. “Dorian says she is beautiful; and he rarely makes mistakes about these sorts of things. His portrait of him has accelerated his ability to judge the personal appearance of others. It has had that wonderful effect, among other things. We will see her tonight, if he doesn't forget the appointment.”
tr: Lord Henry, sipping vermouth with an orange essence from his glass, murmured, "The girl is not just good, she is beautiful." "Dorian says she is beautiful, and he is rarely wrong about such things. Thanks to the portrait you painted, he has become more sensitive to the appearance of others. The portrait had such a good effect, besides its other benefits. If the boy doesn't forget his appointment, we will see the girl tonight."
es: —No, no; the girl is better than good..., she is beautiful —murmured Lord Henry, savoring a glass of vermouth with bitter orange juice—. Dorian says she is beautiful, and he is not usually wrong in such matters. Your portrait has refined his appreciation of people. That has been, among other things, one of its excellent results. We are going to meet her tonight, if that boy does not forget his appointment with us.

en: “Are you serious?”
vi: “Are you serious?”
tr: “Are you serious?”
es: —Are you serious?

en: “Quite serious, Basil. I should be miserable if I thought I should ever be more serious than I am at the present moment.”
vi: “Completely serious, Basil. I would be destitute if I thought I would ever be more serious than I am now.”
tr: “I am very serious, Basil. If I believed I could be more serious than I am right now, I would mourn.”
es: —Completely serious. I would feel terribly bad if I thought I would ever speak more seriously than I am right now.

en: “But do you approve of it, Harry?” asked the painter, walking up and down the room and biting his lip. “You can’t approve of it, possibly. It is some silly infatuation.”
vi: “But do you agree with this, Harry?” the artist asked, pacing back and forth in the room, biting his lip. “You can't possibly agree with this. It's just some foolish infatuation.”
tr: The painter paced up and down the room, biting his lip, and asked, "Well, do you approve of this, Harry?" "You can't possibly approve of it. It's a ridiculous, fleeting whim."
es: —But do you approve of it, Harry? —asked the painter, pacing the room and biting his lips—. It's impossible for you to approve of it. It's just a whim.

en: “I never approve, or disapprove, of anything now. It is an absurd attitude to take towards life. We are not sent into the world to air our moral prejudices. I never take any notice of what common people say, and I never interfere with what charming people do. If a personality fascinates me, whatever mode of expression that personality selects is absolutely delightful to me. Dorian Gray falls in love with a beautiful girl who acts Juliet, and proposes to marry her. Why not? If he wedded Messalina, he would be none the less interesting. You know I am not a champion of marriage. The real drawback to marriage is that it makes one unselfish. And unselfish people are colourless. They lack individuality. Still, there are certain temperaments that marriage makes more complex. They retain their egotism, and add to it many other egos. They are forced to have more than one life. They become more highly organized, and to be highly organized is, I should fancy, the object of man’s existence. Besides, every experience is of value, and whatever one may say against marriage, it is certainly an experience. I hope that Dorian Gray will make this girl his wife, passionately adore her for six months, and then suddenly become fascinated by some one else. He would be a wonderful study.”
vi: “I never approve or disapprove of anything now. That is an absurd attitude to take towards life. We are not sent into the world to air our moral prejudices. I never take any notice of what common people say, and I never interfere with what charming people do. If a personality fascinates me, whatever mode of expression that personality chooses is absolutely delightful to me. Dorian Gray falls in love with an actress who plays Juliet, and proposes to her. Why not? If he married Messalina, he would be none the less interesting. You know I am not a champion of marriage. The real drawback to marriage is that it makes one unselfish. And unselfish people are colourless. They lack individuality. However, there are certain temperaments that marriage makes more complex. They retain their egotism, and add to it many other egos. They have to live more than one life, and they become more highly organized, and to be more highly organized I think is the object of man’s existence. Besides, every experience is of value, and, whatever one may say against marriage, it is certainly an experience. I hope that Dorian Gray will marry this girl, worship her for six months, and then suddenly be fascinated by someone else. He would be a wonderful study.”
tr: “I no longer react to anything positively or negatively, my friend. Taking such an attitude towards life is ridiculous. We don't come into the world to explain our prejudices about morality. I never listen to what ordinary, stereotypical people say; nor do I interfere with the actions of charming, distinguished people. If I find someone very attractive, whatever method of expression they choose, it delights me. Dorian Gray is infatuated with a lovely girl who plays Juliet on stage and is planning to marry her. Why not? Even if Dorian married Messalina, he wouldn't lose any of his interest in my eyes. You know that I am not one of the defenders of marriage. The real drawback of marriage is that it makes a person domesticated. Domesticated people are also colorless. They lack individuality. On the other hand, there are those whom marriage complicates instead. Such people preserve their selfishness and add many other selves on top of it. They are forced to live multiple lives. They achieve better organization. In my opinion, this is the purpose of human existence. After all, every experience has value. No matter what anyone says, it is undeniable that marriage is an experience. My hope is that Dorian Gray marries this girl, worships her madly for six months, and then suddenly falls under the spell of someone else. It would be a delightful subject to study.”
es: —I no longer approve or disapprove of anything. It is an absurd attitude towards life. We are not put in the world to air our moral prejudices. I never give the slightest importance to what ordinary people say, and I never interfere with what charming people do. If a personality fascinates me, any mode of expression they choose will seem delightful to me. Dorian Gray falls in love with a beautiful girl who plays Juliet and intends to marry her. Why not? If he were to marry Messalina, it would not seem less interesting to me. You know perfectly well that I am not a defender of marriage. The real drawback of marriage is that it kills selfishness. And people without selfishness are colorless. They lack individuality. Anyway, there are some temperaments that become more complex with marriage. They retain their selfishness and add many others to it. They are forced to live more than one life. They become highly organized people, and organizing one's life very well, I believe, is the object of human existence. Moreover, every experience has value and, say what you will against marriage, there is no doubt that it is an experience. I hope that Dorian Gray makes that girl his wife, adores her passionately for six months, and then, suddenly, becomes fascinated by someone else. It will be a wonderful subject of study.

en: “You don’t mean a single word of all that, Harry; you know you don’t. If Dorian Gray’s life were spoiled, no one would be sorrier than yourself. You are much better than you pretend to be.”
vi: “You cannot speak seriously about any of this, Harry; you know that you are like that. If Dorian Gray's life is ruined, no one will be more upset than you. You are much better than you keep pretending to be.”
tr: “You are not serious about a single thing you say, Harry. You are not, and you know it. If Dorian Gray's life were to fade, you would be the most upset. You are actually much kinder at heart than the poses you assume.”
es: —You don't believe a single word of what you say; you know perfectly well that you don't. If Dorian Gray were to ruin his life, no one would feel it more than you. You are a much better person than you pretend to be.

en: Lord Henry laughed. “The reason we all like to think so well of others is that we are all afraid for ourselves. The basis of optimism is sheer terror. We think that we are generous because we credit our neighbour with the possession of those virtues that are likely to be a benefit to us. We praise the banker that we may overdraw our account, and find good qualities in the highwayman in the hope that he may spare our pockets. I mean everything that I have said. I have the greatest contempt for optimism. As for a spoiled life, no life is spoiled but one whose growth is arrested. If you want to mar a nature, you have merely to reform it. As for marriage, of course that would be silly, but there are other and more interesting bonds between men and women. I will certainly encourage them. They have the charm of being fashionable. But here is Dorian himself. He will tell you more than I can.”
vi: Lord Henry laughed. “The reason why all of us like to think so well of others is because we are all afraid of ourselves. The basis of optimism is sheer terror. We think we are generous because we credit our neighbors with the possession of those virtues that are likely to benefit us. We praise the banker so that we can overdraw our accounts, and find good qualities in the highwayman in the hope that he may spare our pockets. I am quite serious in all that I say. I disapprove of optimism more than anything. As for a spoiled life, no life is spoiled but one whose growth is arrested. If you want to harm nature, you only need to reform it. As for marriage, it is of course ridiculous, but there are other ties far more interesting between men and women. I am all for encouraging them. They have the charm of novelty. But here is Dorian himself. He will tell you more than I can.”
tr: Lord Henry laughed. "We all love to attribute goodness to others because we all fear for our own heads. The basis of optimism is sheer terror. We think ourselves magnanimous because we can see virtues in our neighbors that might benefit us. We praise the banker so we can withdraw more money from our account, and we find good qualities in the highwayman so he won't rob us. I was serious in everything I said. I utterly despise optimism. As for the extinguishing of life; no life is extinguished, as long as its development hasn't been cut short. If you want to ruin a character, just reform it! As for marriage, it's certainly nonsense, but there are other, more interesting bonds between men and women. I will not refrain from encouraging these. They all have the allure of being the latest fashion. But look, here comes Dorian. He will give you more information than I can."
es: Lord Henry burst out laughing. —The reason we like to think well of others is that we are afraid of what might happen to us. The basis of optimism is terror. We think we are generous because we attribute to our neighbor the virtues that can benefit us the most. We praise the banker so that he does not penalize us for being in the red, and we find good qualities in the highwayman in the hope that he will respect our purse. I believe everything I have said. I deeply despise optimism. As for ruining a life, a life is only ruined when its growth is stopped. If you want to spoil a personality, just reform it. As for marriage, of course it would be foolish, but there are other bonds, much more interesting, between men and women. I am certainly willing to encourage them. They have the charm of being fashionable. But here comes Dorian, who will tell you everything better than I can.

en: “My dear Harry, my dear Basil, you must both congratulate me!” said the lad, throwing off his evening cape with its satin-lined wings and shaking each of his friends by the hand in turn. “I have never been so happy. Of course, it is sudden—all really delightful things are. And yet it seems to me to be the one thing I have been looking for all my life.” He was flushed with excitement and pleasure, and looked extraordinarily handsome.
vi: “My dear Harry, my dear Basil, you should congratulate me!” the young man said, tossing aside his afternoon cloak with satin-lined wings, and shaking hands with each friend in turn. “I have never been so happy. Of course, it is sudden; everything is truly exciting. However, I feel it seems like the thing I have been searching for all my life.” He blushed with excitement and joy, and looked extraordinarily handsome.
tr: “Dear Harry, dear Basil, you both must congratulate me!” said the young man, throwing off his satin-lined cloak and shaking his friends' hands one by one. “I have never been this happy in my life. I know, it was sudden. All joyful things are, but still, it feels like this is what I have been searching for all my life.” Flushed with excitement and happiness, he looked extraordinarily handsome.
es: —Basil, Harry, you both have to congratulate me! —said the young man, impatiently shedding the satin-lined cloak and proceeding to shake hands with his two friends—. I've never been so happy. I know it's sudden; everything truly delightful is. And yet, it seems to me that I haven't sought anything else my entire life —his complexion was flushed with joy and emotion, and he looked remarkably handsome.

en: “I hope you will always be very happy, Dorian,” said Hallward, “but I don’t quite forgive you for not having let me know of your engagement. You let Harry know.”
vi: “I hope you will always be happy, Dorian,” Hallward said, “but I really cannot forgive you for not telling me about your engagement. Yet you told Harry.”
tr: Hallward said, "I hope you will be happy for life, Dorian." "Still, I can't quite forgive you for not informing me of your engagement. You told Harry.""
es: —I hope you are always very happy, Dorian —said Hallward—, but I do not entirely forgive you for not informing me of your engagement. You have told Harry.

en: “And I don’t forgive you for being late for dinner,” broke in Lord Henry, putting his hand on the lad’s shoulder and smiling as he spoke. “Come, let us sit down and try what the new chef here is like, and then you will tell us how it all came about.”
vi: “And I do not forgive you for being late for dinner,” Lord Henry interrupted, placing a hand on the young man's shoulder, and smiling as he spoke. “Now, let us sit down and see how the new chef here is, then you will tell us what happened.”
tr: "I can't forgive you for being late to dinner either," said Lord Henry, interrupting and placing his hand on the young man's shoulder. He was smiling. "Come on, let's sit down and see how the new chef is. You can tell us how all this happened."
es: —And I do not forgive you for being late to dinner —interjected Lord Henry, placing a hand on the boy's shoulder and smiling as he spoke—. Let's sit down and find out how the new chef is, and then you can explain to us how everything happened.

en: “There is really not much to tell,” cried Dorian as they took their seats at the small round table. “What happened was simply this. After I left you yesterday evening, Harry, I dressed, had some dinner at that little Italian restaurant in Rupert Street you introduced me to, and went down at eight o’clock to the theatre. Sibyl was playing Rosalind. Of course, the scenery was dreadful and the Orlando absurd. But Sibyl! You should have seen her! When she came on in her boy’s clothes, she was perfectly wonderful. She wore a moss-coloured velvet jerkin with cinnamon sleeves, slim, brown, cross-gartered hose, a dainty little green cap with a hawk’s feather caught in a jewel, and a hooded cloak lined with dull red. She had never seemed to me more exquisite. She had all the delicate grace of that Tanagra figurine that you have in your studio, Basil. Her hair clustered round her face like dark leaves round a pale rose. As for her acting—well, you shall see her to-night. She is simply a born artist. I sat in the dingy box absolutely enthralled. I forgot that I was in London and in the nineteenth century. I was away with my love in a forest that no man had ever seen. After the performance was over, I went behind and spoke to her. As we were sitting together, suddenly there came into her eyes a look that I had never seen there before. My lips moved towards hers. We kissed each other. I can’t describe to you what I felt at that moment. It seemed to me that all my life had been narrowed to one perfect point of rose-coloured joy. She trembled all over and shook like a white narcissus. Then she flung herself on her knees and kissed my hands. I feel that I should not tell you all this, but I can’t help it. Of course, our engagement is a dead secret. She has not even told her own mother. I don’t know what my guardians will say. Lord Radley is sure to be furious. I don’t care. I shall be of age in less than a year, and then I can do what I like. I have been right, Basil, haven’t I, to take my love out of poetry and to find my wife in Shakespeare’s plays? Lips that Shakespeare taught to speak have whispered their secret in my ear. I have had the arms of Rosalind around me, and kissed Juliet on the mouth.”
vi: “Actually, there isn't much to tell,” Dorian exclaimed, as they sat down around the small round table. “What happened is simply this. After I left you yesterday afternoon, Harry, I changed clothes, had a quick dinner at that tiny Italian restaurant on Rupert Street that you recommended to me, and at eight o'clock I went down to the theater. Sibyl was playing Rosalind. Of course, the scenery was dreadful, and Orlando was absurd. But Sibyl! If only you had seen her! When she came out in her boy's costume, she was absolutely perfect. She wore a moss-green velvet doublet with cinnamon-colored sleeves, long cross-gartered brown stockings, a small green cap with an eagle feather fastened by a jewel, and a cloak with a hood lined with dull red fabric. It seemed I had never seen her more exquisite. She had all the delicate charm of the Tanagra statue you have in your studio, Basil. Her hair clustered around her face like black leaves around a faded rose. As for her acting — well, you will see her tonight. She is simply a born artist. I sat in the darkened box and was absolutely enthralled. I forgot I was in London and in the nineteenth century. I had wandered far away with my love to a forest that no one had ever seen. After the performance ended, I went backstage and talked to her. As we sat together, suddenly there appeared in her eyes a look that I had never seen there before. My lips moved towards hers. We kissed. I cannot describe to you what I felt at that moment. It seemed as if my whole life had been narrowed to a perfect point of rosy joy. She trembled all over, and shook like a white narcissus. Then she sank down and knelt, kissing my hands. I feel I shouldn't be telling you all this, but I can't help it. Of course, our engagement is an absolute secret. She hasn't even told her mother. I don't know what my guardians will say. Lord Radley will certainly be furious. I don't care. I will come of age in less than a year, and then I can do whatever I like. I was right, Basil, wasn't I, to take my love out of poetry, and find my wife in Shakespeare's plays? The lips that Shakespeare taught to speak have whispered their secrets into my ear. I have been embraced by Rosalind's arms, and kissed by Juliet on the mouth.”
tr: As they sat down at the small, round table, Dorian said, "There isn't much to tell." "Here's what happened: Harry, after leaving you last night, I changed my clothes, had dinner at that little Italian restaurant on Rupert Street that you taught me about, and went to the theater at eight o'clock. Sibyl was playing Rosalind. The set was terrible, and the actor playing Orlando was ridiculous, naturally. But Sibyl! If only you could have seen her! When she came on stage dressed as a boy, she was simply marvelous. She wore a tight, moss-colored velvet jacket with loose, cinnamon-colored sleeves, long brown stockings, and a cloak with a dull red lining and a hood! She also had a delicate, tiny green hat on her head. A hawk feather was fastened to the hat with a shiny stone. She looked more elegant and perfect than ever to me. Basil, you know that Tanagra figurine in your studio, well, Sibyl reflected that delicate harmony. Her hair was piled around her face like dark leaves around a pale-colored rose. As for her performance... Well, you'll see her tonight. This girl is a born artist, in a word. While sitting in that musty box, I was completely captivated. I forgot I was in London, living in the nineteenth century. I was in a distant forest, unseen by anyone, with my beloved. When the curtain fell, I went backstage and talked to her. While we were sitting side by side, a look appeared in her eyes that I had never seen before. My lips moved towards hers. We kissed. I can't describe to you what I felt at that moment. It was as if my entire life had culminated in a perfect, rose-colored point of joy. She was trembling from head to toe, shaking like a white narcissus flower. Then she knelt down and began to kiss my hands... It feels as if I shouldn't be telling you all this, yet I can't help myself. Our engagement is very secret, of course. She hasn't even told her own mother yet. I don't know what my guardians will say about this. Lord Radley will be absolutely furious. I don't care. In less than a year, I'll come of age, and then I can do whatever I want. Basil, I did the right thing by finding my love in poetry and choosing my wife from Shakespeare's plays, didn't I? Lips that learned to speak from Shakespeare whispered their secrets into my ear. Rosalind wrapped her arms around my neck; I kissed Juliet on the mouth."
es: —Actually, there isn't much to tell —exclaimed Dorian as the three of them took their seats around the small round table—. Yesterday, simply, after leaving you, Harry, I got dressed, had dinner at the little Italian restaurant on Rupert Street that you introduced me to, and by eight I was at the theater. Sibyl was playing Rosalind. Of course, the set was horrible and the actor playing Orlando was absurd. Sibyl, on the other hand! You should have seen her! When she appeared dressed as a boy, she was absolutely marvelous. She wore a moss-colored velvet doublet with cinnamon-colored sleeves, brown hose, a lovely green hat with a hawk feather held by a jewel, and a hooded cloak lined with matte red. She had never seemed so exquisite to me. She had the delicate grace of that Tanagra figurine you have in your studio, Basil. Her hair framing her face like dark leaves around a pale rose. As for her performance..., well, you're going to see it tonight. She is, no more no less, a born artist. I was completely enthralled in my shabby box. I forgot that I was in London and in the 19th century. I had gone with my beloved to a forest that no one had ever seen. When the performance ended, I went backstage and talked to her. While we were sitting next to each other, a look suddenly appeared in her eyes that I had never seen before. My lips moved towards hers. We kissed. I can't describe to you what I felt at that moment. It seemed to me that my entire life was concentrated in a perfect point of rosy joy. Sibyl began to tremble from head to toe, shivering like a white narcissus. Then she knelt down and kissed my hands. I understand that I shouldn't be telling you all this, but I can't help it. Of course, our engagement is a total secret. Sibyl hasn't even told her mother. I don't know what my guardians will say. Lord Radley will undoubtedly be furious. I don't care. I'll be of age in less than a year, and then I can do whatever I want. Isn't it true that I did well by taking my love out of poetry and finding my wife in Shakespeare's plays? Lips that Shakespeare taught to speak have whispered their secret in my ear. Rosalind's arms have embraced me and I have kissed Juliet on the mouth.

en: “Yes, Dorian, I suppose you were right,” said Hallward slowly.
vi: "Yes, Dorian, I suppose you are right," Hallward said slowly.
tr: Hallward replied slowly, "Yes, Dorian, I think you have done the right thing."
es: —Yes, Dorian —said Hallward, speaking very slowly—; I suppose you have done well.

en: “Have you seen her to-day?” asked Lord Henry.
vi: "Did you see her today?" Lord Henry asked.
tr: Lord Henry asked, "Did you see Sibyl today?"
es: —Have you seen her today? —asked Lord Henry.

en: Dorian Gray shook his head. “I left her in the forest of Arden; I shall find her in an orchard in Verona.”
vi: Dorian Gray shook his head. "I left her in the forest of Arden, I will find her in an orchard in Verona."
tr: Dorian Gray shook his head. “I left it in the Forest of Aden, I will find it in an orchard in Verona.”
es: Dorian Gray shook his head. —I left her in the Forest of Arden and today I will find her in an orchard in Verona.

en: Lord Henry sipped his champagne in a meditative manner. “At what particular point did you mention the word marriage, Dorian? And what did she say in answer? Perhaps you forgot all about it.”
vi: Lord Henry sipped champagne thoughtfully. "So at what specific moment did you mention the word marriage, Dorian? And what did she say in response? Perhaps you've forgotten everything."
tr: Lord Henry, sipping his champagne thoughtfully, asked, "Dorian, at what point did you mention marriage?" "What was her response? Or have you forgotten these things?"
es: Lord Henry savored his champagne with a contemplative air. —At what point did you mention the word marriage, Dorian? And what did she respond? Perhaps you have completely forgotten.

en: “My dear Harry, I did not treat it as a business transaction, and I did not make any formal proposal. I told her that I loved her, and she said she was not worthy to be my wife. Not worthy! Why, the whole world is nothing to me compared with her.”
vi: “My dear Harry, I do not consider it as a commercial transaction, and I am not making any formal offer at all. I told her that I love her, and she said she is not worthy to be my wife. Not worthy! Why, to me, the whole world is nothing compared to her.”
tr: “Dear Harry, I didn't approach this matter like a job contract, nor did I make a formal proposal. I said that I loved her, and she said that she didn't consider herself worthy of being my wife. Not worthy! But in my eyes, the world on one side, and her on the other.”
es: —My dear Harry, I did not behave as if it were a business deal, and I did not explicitly make a marriage proposal. I told her that I loved her and she responded that she was not worthy to be my wife. That she was not worthy! When the entire world is nothing to me compared to her!

en: “Women are wonderfully practical,” murmured Lord Henry, “much more practical than we are. In situations of that kind we often forget to say anything about marriage, and they always remind us.”
vi: “Women are extremely practical,” Lord Henry muttered — "much more practical than we are. In those kinds of situations, we often forget to say anything about marriage, and they always remind us.”
tr: Lord Henry murmured, "Women are extraordinarily practical." "Much more practical than we are. In situations like this, we often forget to bring up marriage, but they always remind us."
es: —Women are wonderfully practical —murmured Lord Henry—; much more practical than we are. In situations like that, we often forget to mention the word marriage, but they always remind us.

en: Hallward laid his hand upon his arm. “Don’t, Harry. You have annoyed Dorian. He is not like other men. He would never bring misery upon any one. His nature is too fine for that.”
vi: Hallward put his hand on his arm. "Don't, Harry. You have already upset Dorian. He is not like other men. He will never bring sorrow to anyone. His nature is too noble for that."
tr: Hallward put his hand on his arm. "Don't do it, Harry." "You have upset Dorian." "Dorian is not like other men." "He would never intentionally cause anyone pain." "His soul is too noble for such things.""
es: Hallward put a hand on his arm. —No, Harry. You have upset Dorian, who is not like other men. Dorian would never make another person unhappy. He is too delicate for such a thing.

en: Lord Henry looked across the table. “Dorian is never annoyed with me,” he answered. “I asked the question for the best reason possible, for the only reason, indeed, that excuses one for asking any question—simple curiosity. I have a theory that it is always the women who propose to us, and not we who propose to the women. Except, of course, in middle-class life. But then the middle classes are not modern.”
vi: Lord Henry looked across the table. “Dorian is never annoyed with me,” he replied. “I asked that question for the best possible reason, the only reason that, indeed, excuses one for asking any question at all — sheer curiosity. I have a theory that it is always women who propose to us, and not we who propose to women. Except, of course, in the lives of the lower middle class. But nowadays the lower middle class is behind the times.”
tr: Lord Henry, looking across the table, replied, "Dorian never gets angry with me." "I asked that question for the most valid reason in the world; or rather, the only reason to ask any question, which is simple curiosity. I have a theory: Men do not propose to women. The marriage proposal always comes from the woman. The middle-class life is an exception to this, naturally. But the middle classes are not contemporary anyway."
es: Lord Henry looked over the table. —Dorian is never upset with me —he replied—. I asked the question for the best of reasons, for the only reason, in truth, that justifies asking any question: simple curiosity. I maintain the theory that it is always women who propose marriage to us and not we to them. Except, of course, for people of the middle class. But the truth is that the middle classes are not modern.

en: Dorian Gray laughed, and tossed his head. “You are quite incorrigible, Harry; but I don’t mind. It is impossible to be angry with you. When you see Sibyl Vane, you will feel that the man who could wrong her would be a beast, a beast without a heart. I cannot understand how any one can wish to shame the thing he loves. I love Sibyl Vane. I want to place her on a pedestal of gold and to see the world worship the woman who is mine. What is marriage? An irrevocable vow. You mock at it for that. Ah! don’t mock. It is an irrevocable vow that I want to take. Her trust makes me faithful, her belief makes me good. When I am with her, I regret all that you have taught me. I become different from what you have known me to be. I am changed, and the mere touch of Sibyl Vane’s hand makes me forget you and all your wrong, fascinating, poisonous, delightful theories.”
vi: Dorian Gray smiled and tossed his head. “You are incorrigible, Harry; but I don't mind. It is impossible to be angry with you. When you meet Sibyl, you will feel that anyone who could harm her must be a beast, a heartless beast. I cannot understand why anyone would want to disgrace the person they love. I love Sibyl Vane. I want to place her on a golden pedestal and watch the world worship the girl who belongs to me. What is marriage? An irrevocable vow. You mock it for that reason, don't you? Oh! don't mock it. It is an irrevocable vow that I want to bear. Her expectations make me faithful, her trust makes me kind. When I am with her, I regret everything you have taught me. I become different from the person you knew I used to be. I have changed, and just a touch of Sibyl Vane's hand is enough to make me forget you and all your wrong, fascinating, poisonous, delightful theories.”
tr: Dorian Gray threw his head back laughing. “You will never come around, Harry, but I don't care. There is no way to be angry with you. When you see Sibyl Vane, you will understand, anyone who harms her is a monster, a heartless monster. I can't understand how someone can disgrace what they love. I love Sibyl Vane. I want to raise her on a golden throne, to see the whole world worship the woman I love. What is marriage? An irrevocable vow. That is why you mock marriage. My dear, don't mock it. I want to take this irrevocable vow. Sibyl's trust in me instills loyalty in me, her faith makes me a good person. When I am with her, I regret learning what you taught me. I become a different person than the one you know. I am changing. A single touch of Sibyl Vane's hand makes me forget all your wrong, enchanting, poisonous, delightful theories.”
es: Dorian Gray laughed and shook his head. —You are completely incorrigible, Harry; but I don't mind. It is impossible to be angry with you. When you see Sibyl Vane, you will understand that the man who treated her badly would be a heartless, soulless being. I don't understand how anyone could want to shame the one they love. And I love Sibyl Vane. I want to place her on a golden pedestal and see the world revere the woman who is mine. What is marriage? An irrevocable promise. That is why you mock it. Don't do it! It is an irrevocable promise that I want to make. Sibyl's trust makes me faithful, her faith makes me good. When I am with her, I renounce everything you have taught me. I become someone different from the one you have known. I have changed, and the mere act of touching Sibyl Vane's hand makes me forget you and forget your false theories, so fascinating, so poisoned, so delightful.

en: “And those are ...?” asked Lord Henry, helping himself to some salad.
vi: "And that is...?" Lord Henry asked, serving himself some salad.
tr: Lord Henry, taking some salad onto his plate, asked, "Well, what are these theories?"
es: —My theories...? —asked Lord Henry, serving himself some salad.

en: “Oh, your theories about life, your theories about love, your theories about pleasure. All your theories, in fact, Harry.”
vi: “Oh, your theories about life, your theories about love, your theories about pleasure. In fact, all your theories, Harry.”
tr: "Oh, here are your theories about life, about love, about pleasure. In short, all your theories, Harry."
es: —Your theories about life, your theories about love, your theories about pleasure. All your theories, in fact.

en: “Pleasure is the only thing worth having a theory about,” he answered in his slow melodious voice. “But I am afraid I cannot claim my theory as my own. It belongs to Nature, not to me. Pleasure is Nature’s test, her sign of approval. When we are happy, we are always good, but when we are good, we are not always happy.”
vi: “Pleasure is the only thing worth having a theory about,” he replied, in his slow, melodious voice. “But I am afraid I cannot claim my theory as my own. It belongs to Nature, not to me. Pleasure is Nature's test, her sign of approval. When we are happy, we are always good, but when we are good, we are not always happy.”
tr: Lord Henry, with his languid, melodious voice, said, "The only thing worth developing a theory about is pleasure." "However, I cannot claim that this theory is my own. It belongs to Nature, not to me. Pleasure is Nature's test, its approval symbol. When we are happy, we are always good people, but when we are good people, we may not necessarily be happy."
es: —Pleasure is the only thing worth having a theory about —replied Lord Henry, carefully enunciating each word with his melodious voice—. But I am very much afraid that I cannot claim that theory as my own. It does not belong to me; it belongs to Nature. Pleasure is Nature's touchstone. When we are happy, we are always good, but when we are good, we are not always happy.

en: “Ah! but what do you mean by good?” cried Basil Hallward.
vi: “Oh! But what do you mean by kindness?” Basil Hallward exclaimed.
tr: Basil Hallward asked, "What do you mean by a beautiful but good person?"
es: —Yes, but what do you mean by good? —exclaimed Basil Hallward.

en: “Yes,” echoed Dorian, leaning back in his chair and looking at Lord Henry over the heavy clusters of purple-lipped irises that stood in the centre of the table, “what do you mean by good, Harry?”
vi: “Yes,” Dorian repeated, leaning back in his chair, and looking at Lord Henry over the heavy bunches of purple-lipped irises placed in the middle of the table, “what do you mean by kindness, Harry?”
tr: Dorian said, "Yes," approving him. He leaned back and looked at Lord Henry over the purple-lipped sesame flowers in the middle of the table. "What do you mean by the definition of a good person, Harry?"
es: —Yes —Dorian agreed, leaning back in his seat and looking at Lord Henry over the thick bouquet of purple irises that occupied the center of the table—, what do you mean by good?

en: “To be good is to be in harmony with one’s self,” he replied, touching the thin stem of his glass with his pale, fine-pointed fingers. “Discord is to be forced to be in harmony with others. One’s own life—that is the important thing. As for the lives of one’s neighbours, if one wishes to be a prig or a Puritan, one can flaunt one’s moral views about them, but they are not one’s concern. Besides, individualism has really the higher aim. Modern morality consists in accepting the standard of one’s age. I consider that for any man of culture to accept the standard of his age is a form of the grossest immorality.”
vi: “Living kindly means living in harmony with oneself,” he replied, touching the slender stem of the glass with his pale, delicate fingers. “Disagreement means being forced to live in harmony with others. One's own life — that is what matters. As for the lives of those around us, if we wish to become disdainful or strict, we can flaunt our moral views about them, but they are not our concern. Moreover, true Individualism has a higher purpose. Modern virtue lies in accepting the standards of our time. I believe that for any cultured person, accepting the standards of his time is the most blatant form of immorality.”
tr: Lord Henry, touching the thin stem of his glass with those pale, pointed fingers, said, "To be a good person means to be in harmony with oneself." "Disharmony is being forced to be in harmony with others. One's own life: That is what matters. As for the lives of our neighbors; if one wants to be conservative or puritanical, they can proclaim their moral views about them, but in reality, they do not concern us at all. Moreover, the aim pursued by individuality is higher. Contemporary morality is merely adopting the standards of the age. In my opinion, for any cultured person to adopt the standards of their age is the grossest form of immorality."
es: —To be good is to be in harmony with oneself —replied Lord Henry, touching the delicate foot of the glass with very white and fine fingers—. There is dissonance when one is forced to be in harmony with others. One's own life... that is what is important. As for the lives of our neighbors, if one wants to be a hypocrite or a puritan, we can flaunt our ideas about morality, but in reality, those people are not our concern. On the other hand, the goals of individualism are the highest. Modern morality consists in accepting the norms of one's own era. But I consider that, for a cultured man, accepting the norms of his era is the worst immorality.

en: “But, surely, if one lives merely for one’s self, Harry, one pays a terrible price for doing so?” suggested the painter.
vi: "But surely if we live only for ourselves, Harry, we will have to pay a terrible price for it, won't we?" the artist suggested.
tr: The painter said, "But Harry, if a person lives solely for themselves, don't they inevitably pay a tremendous price in return?"
es: —But, of course, if one lives only for oneself, one must pay a terrible price for it, isn't that right, Harry? —asked the painter.

en: “Yes, we are overcharged for everything nowadays. I should fancy that the real tragedy of the poor is that they can afford nothing but self-denial. Beautiful sins, like beautiful things, are the privilege of the rich.”
vi: “Yes, we have to pay too high a price for everything these days. I think the real tragedy of the poor is that they cannot afford to do anything except sacrifice. Beautiful sins, like beautiful things, are the privilege of the rich.”
tr: “Yes, these days I buy everything at an extremely high price. In my opinion, the real tragedy of the poor is that their purses are only enough to fill their stomachs. Beautiful sins, like beautiful objects, are the domain of the rich.”
es: —Yes, in these times we are excessively charged for everything. I have the impression that the true tragedy of the poor is that they cannot afford anything except to give up on themselves. Beautiful sins, like beautiful objects, are the privilege of the rich.

en: “One has to pay in other ways but money.”
vi: “I have to pay in ways other than money.”
tr: “A person has to pay this price with things other than money as well.”
es: —One must pay in ways other than with money.

en: “What sort of ways, Basil?”
vi: “What kind of method is that, Basil?”
tr: “For example, what kind of things, Basil?”
es: —In what ways, Basil?

en: “Oh! I should fancy in remorse, in suffering, in ... well, in the consciousness of degradation.”
vi: "Oh! I believe that through repentance, through suffering, through... yes, through the awareness of degradation.""
tr: “For example, what kind of things, Basil?” “How should I know, regret, remorse, then... The consciousness of humiliation.”
es: —I imagine with remorse, suffering..., well, realizing the degradation.

en: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. “My dear fellow, mediæval art is charming, but mediæval emotions are out of date. One can use them in fiction, of course. But then the only things that one can use in fiction are the things that one has ceased to use in fact. Believe me, no civilized man ever regrets a pleasure, and no uncivilized man ever knows what a pleasure is.”
vi: Lord Henry shrugged. “My friend, medieval art is truly beautiful, but medieval emotions are outdated. One can use them in novels, of course. But on the other hand, the only things one can use in novels are those that people have stopped using in reality. Believe me, no civilized person has ever regretted a pleasure, and no uncivilized person has ever known what pleasure is.”
tr: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. "My dear, Medieval art is quite charming, however, the fashion of Medieval sentiments is long gone. We can use these sentiments in novels. But aren't the things we use in novels precisely the things we don't use in real life? Believe me, no civilized person regrets the pleasure they have enjoyed, and no primitive person knows what pleasure is."
es: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. —My friend, medieval art is charming, but medieval emotions are outdated. They can be used in novels, of course. But the things that can be used in narrative are those that have ceased to be used in real life. Believe me, no civilized man ever regrets a pleasure, and the uncivilized never come to know what a pleasure is.

en: “I know what pleasure is,” cried Dorian Gray. “It is to adore some one.”
vi: “I know what pleasure is,” Dorian Gray exclaimed. “It is to adore someone.”
tr: Dorian exclaimed, "I know what pleasure is!" "Worshiping someone."
es: —I know what pleasure is —exclaimed Dorian Gray—. To adore someone.

en: “That is certainly better than being adored,” he answered, toying with some fruits. “Being adored is a nuisance. Women treat us just as humanity treats its gods. They worship us, and are always bothering us to do something for them.”
vi: “That is certainly better than being worshipped,” he replied, playing with some fruit. “Being worshipped is a terrible nuisance. Women treat me just like humans treat their gods. They worship me, and always bother me to do something for them.”
tr: Lord Henry, turning the fruits over, replied, "Yes, it is better than being worshipped." "Being worshipped is tedious. As mankind treats their gods, so do women treat us. They worship us, constantly prodding us to do something for them."
es: —Undoubtedly that is better than being adored —replied Lord Henry, playing with a fruit—. Being adored is very annoying. Women treat us like humanity treats its gods. They worship us and are always bothering us to do something for them.

en: “I should have said that whatever they ask for they had first given to us,” murmured the lad gravely. “They create love in our natures. They have a right to demand it back.”
vi: “I must say that whatever they ask of us, they have already given us first,” the young man murmured solemnly. “They created Love within our nature. They have the right to demand it back.”
tr: Dorian replied with a serious expression, "If you ask me, whatever it is they want from us, it's the things they initially gave us." "They create love within our being. They have the right to ask this from us."
es: —I would say that anything they ask for has been given to us before —murmured the young man very seriously—. They create love in our soul. They have the right to ask for reciprocation.

en: “That is quite true, Dorian,” cried Hallward.
vi: "That is absolutely true, Dorian," Hallward exclaimed.
tr: Hallward said, "You spoke very correctly, Dorian."
es: —That is completely true —exclaimed Hallward.

en: “Nothing is ever quite true,” said Lord Henry.
vi: “Nothing has ever been completely right,” Lord Henry said.
tr: Lord Henry speculated, "Nothing is completely true."
es: —Nothing is completely certain —said Lord Henry.

en: “This is,” interrupted Dorian. “You must admit, Harry, that women give to men the very gold of their lives.”
vi: "This is it," Dorian interrupted. "You must admit, Harry, that women give men the very gold of their lives."
tr: Dorian, "This is true, but," he cut him short. "You must accept this, Harry. Women give men the golden ore of their lives."
es: —This is true —Dorian interrupted him—. You have to admit, Harry, that women give men the very gold of their lives.

en: “Possibly,” he sighed, “but they invariably want it back in such very small change. That is the worry. Women, as some witty Frenchman once put it, inspire us with the desire to do masterpieces and always prevent us from carrying them out.”
vi: “It’s possible,” he sighed, “but they always want it to return to its original state.” “That is the worrying thing.” “Women, as some witty Frenchman once said, inspire in us the desire to create masterpieces, and always prevent us from achieving them.”
tr: Lord Henry sighed, "Maybe." "However, they always want it back as forty pence. That's the problem. As a witty Frenchman once said, women inspire us to create masterpieces, only to prevent us from doing so every time."
es: —It's possible -sighed the other—, but inevitably they demand it in small change. That is the problem. Women, as a very witty Frenchman once said, awaken in us the desire to produce masterpieces, but then they always prevent us from carrying them out.

en: “Harry, you are dreadful! I don’t know why I like you so much.”
vi: “Harry, you are really scary! I don't understand why I like you so much.”
tr: "Harry, you are so bad!" "I don't know why I love you so much."
es: —You're horrible, Harry! I don't know why I have so much affection for you.

en: “You will always like me, Dorian,” he replied. “Will you have some coffee, you fellows? Waiter, bring coffee, and fine-champagne, and some cigarettes. No, don’t mind the cigarettes—I have some. Basil, I can’t allow you to smoke cigars. You must have a cigarette. A cigarette is the perfect type of a perfect pleasure. It is exquisite, and it leaves one unsatisfied. What more can one want? Yes, Dorian, you will always be fond of me. I represent to you all the sins you have never had the courage to commit.”
vi: “You will always like me, Dorian,” he replied. “Shall we have some coffee, friends? — Waiter, bring coffee, fine-champagne, and a few cigarettes. No: never mind the cigarettes; I still have some. Basil, I can't let you smoke cigars. You must smoke a cigarette. A cigarette is the perfect example of a perfect pleasure. It is exquisite, and it leaves one unsatisfied. What more could one want? Yes, Dorian, you will always be fond of me. To you, I represent all the sins you have never had the courage to commit.”
tr: “You will love me for a lifetime, Dorian... Gentlemen, would you like some coffee?.. Waiter, bring coffee, the best champagne, and a box of cigarettes. No, he doesn't want cigarettes; I have some. Basil, I can't allow you to smoke a cigar, take a cigarette from there. A cigarette is a perfect example of perfect pleasure. It is insatiable and leaves one unsatisfied when it ends. What else is desired in life? Yes, Dorian, you will always love me. Because I symbolize all the sins you dare not commit.”
es: —You will always have me —replied Lord Henry—. Will you have coffee? Waiter, bring coffee, fine champagne, and cigarettes. No, forget the cigarettes; I have some myself. Basil, I do not permit you to smoke cigars. Light a cigarette. The cigarette is the perfect example of perfect pleasure. It is exquisite and leaves one unsatisfied. What more could one ask for? Yes, Dorian, you will always have affection for me. I represent to you all the sins you have never had the courage to commit.

en: “What nonsense you talk, Harry!” cried the lad, taking a light from a fire-breathing silver dragon that the waiter had placed on the table. “Let us go down to the theatre. When Sibyl comes on the stage you will have a new ideal of life. She will represent something to you that you have never known.”
vi: “What nonsense are you talking about, Harry!” the young man shouted, lighting a cigarette from the silver dragon that his servant had placed on the table. “Let's go down to the theater. When Sybil takes the stage, you will have a new ideal about life. To you, she will represent something that you have never known before.”
tr: The young man said, "You're talking nonsense, Harry!" and took a match from the silver dragon that the waiter had left on the table, which was breathing fire. "Let's go to the theater. When Sibyl takes the stage, you will have gained a new ideal in life. In your eyes, she will symbolize something you have never known before."
es: —What absurd things you say! —exclaimed the boy, using the silver dragon-shaped lighter that the waiter had left on the table. —Let's go to the theater. When Sibyl comes on stage, you will find a new ideal of life. It will mean something to you that you have never known before.

en: “I have known everything,” said Lord Henry, with a tired look in his eyes, “but I am always ready for a new emotion. I am afraid, however, that, for me at any rate, there is no such thing. Still, your wonderful girl may thrill me. I love acting. It is so much more real than life. Let us go. Dorian, you will come with me. I am so sorry, Basil, but there is only room for two in the brougham. You must follow us in a hansom.”
vi: "I already know everything," Lord Henry said, with a weary look in his eyes, "but I am always ready to wait for a new emotion. However, I still fear that, for me, there is no such thing. But who knows, your wonderful girl might be able to move me. I love acting. It is much more real than life. Let's go. Dorian, you will come with me. I am very sorry, Basil, there is only one double seat on that hansom cab. You will have to follow us in the two-wheeled carriage."
tr: Lord Henry, with a tired look in his eyes, said, "I have tasted everything." "Yet, I am always open to new emotions. But I fear that such a thing cannot happen, at least for me. Anyway, your wonderful girl might just enchant me. I adore theater acting. It is much more real than real life. Come on, let's go. Dorian, you are coming with me. Basil, I am very sorry, my car is a two-seater. You will have to follow in another car.
es: —I have known everything —said Lord Henry, with an expression of weariness in his eyes—, but I am always willing to experience a new emotion. I greatly fear, however, that, at least for me, that is something that does not exist. Anyway, perhaps your wonderful girl will captivate me. I love the theater. It is much more real than life. Come on, Dorian. You will come with me. I'm sorry, Basil, but there is only room for two in the carriage. You will have to follow us in a cab.

en: They got up and put on their coats, sipping their coffee standing. The painter was silent and preoccupied. There was a gloom over him. He could not bear this marriage, and yet it seemed to him to be better than many other things that might have happened. After a few minutes, they all passed downstairs. He drove off by himself, as had been arranged, and watched the flashing lights of the little brougham in front of him. A strange sense of loss came over him. He felt that Dorian Gray would never again be to him all that he had been in the past. Life had come between them.... His eyes darkened, and the crowded flaring streets became blurred to his eyes. When the cab drew up at the theatre, it seemed to him that he had grown years older.
vi: They stood up and put on their coats, drinking sips of coffee. The artist was silent and absent-minded. A melancholy ruled over him. He couldn't bear this marriage, but he felt it seemed much better than many other things that could possibly happen. After a few minutes, all of them went downstairs. He walked by himself, as arranged, and watched the twinkling lights of the small one-horse carriage in front of him. A different kind of sense of loss overwhelmed him. He felt that Dorian Gray would never again be to him what he had been in the past. Life had come between them... His eyes darkened, and the bustling, brightly lit streets blurred before him. When the carriage stopped in front of the theater, he felt as if he had aged many years.
tr: They stood up, sipping their coffee while putting on their coats. The painter was lost in his own thoughts, silent. A sense of unease had settled over him. He couldn't bear the thought of this marriage, yet he still thought it was better than many other possibilities that came to mind. They went down a few minutes later. The painter, as agreed, got into a carriage alone and fixed his eyes on the gleaming lights of the small carriage ahead. A strange feeling of loss enveloped him. He sensed that he would never again find the old closeness he had with Dorian Gray. Life had come between them... His vision darkened, and those crowded, lit-up streets vanished before his eyes. When the carriage stopped in front of the theater, Basil Hallward felt as if he had aged years.
es: They stood up to put on their coats, drinking their coffee while standing. The painter, worried, had fallen silent. Melancholy had overtaken him. He greatly disliked that marriage, although in reality, it seemed better to him than many other things that could have happened. Very shortly after, they went out into the street. Hallward headed alone towards the theater, as they had agreed, and was watching the flickering lights of the carriage ahead of him. He had the strange sensation of having lost something. He felt that Dorian Gray would never again be to him what he had been in the past. Life had come between them... His eyes filled with darkness, and he saw the crowded, glittering streets through a mist. When the cab stopped in front of the theater, he had the feeling of having aged several years.

en: CHAPTER VII.
vi: Chapter 7
tr: Seventh chapter
es: Chapter 7

en: For some reason or other, the house was crowded that night, and the fat Jew manager who met them at the door was beaming from ear to ear with an oily tremulous smile. He escorted them to their box with a sort of pompous humility, waving his fat jewelled hands and talking at the top of his voice. Dorian Gray loathed him more than ever. He felt as if he had come to look for Miranda and had been met by Caliban. Lord Henry, upon the other hand, rather liked him. At least he declared he did, and insisted on shaking him by the hand and assuring him that he was proud to meet a man who had discovered a real genius and gone bankrupt over a poet. Hallward amused himself with watching the faces in the pit. The heat was terribly oppressive, and the huge sunlight flamed like a monstrous dahlia with petals of yellow fire. The youths in the gallery had taken off their coats and waistcoats and hung them over the side. They talked to each other across the theatre and shared their oranges with the tawdry girls who sat beside them. Some women were laughing in the pit. Their voices were horribly shrill and discordant. The sound of the popping of corks came from the bar.
vi: For some unknown reason, the theater was packed that night, and the fat Jewish manager who met them at the door had a wide, beaming, sycophantic, and hesitant smile. He escorted them to their box with an exaggeratedly humble attitude, waving his fat hand adorned with jewels, and speaking in the loudest voice. Dorian Gray hated him more than ever. He felt as if he had come to find Miranda only to be greeted by Caliban. However, Lord Henry rather liked him. At least he declared that he did, repeatedly shaking the manager's hand, and assuring him that he was very proud to meet the man who had discovered a true genius and had once gone bankrupt because of a poet. Hallward amused himself by observing the faces in the second-class section. The heat was terribly stifling, and the giant sun shone brightly like a massive dahlia with blazing golden petals. The young men in the gallery seats had taken off their coats and vests and draped them over the sides. They talked to each other across the theater and shared oranges with the garishly dressed girls sitting next to them. Some women laughed in the second-class section. Their voices were terribly shrill and piercing. The popping sounds of corks echoed from the bar.
tr: For some reason, the theater was crowded that night. The fat Jewish manager who greeted them at the door was grinning from ear to ear with a shaky, slimy smile. He led them to their box seats with a mixture of ostentation and obsequiousness, waving his fat, ringed hands and speaking at the top of his voice. Dorian Gray felt a greater disgust for him than ever before. It was as if he had come to fetch Miranda and encountered Caliban instead. However, Lord Henry had taken quite a liking to him. Or rather, he said he had. He insisted on shaking his hand and remarked that he had discovered a true genius and was proud to meet a man who had been driven to bankruptcy because of a poet. Hallward was passing the time by observing the faces of the people in the hall. The heat was stifling, and the large chandelier blazed like a giant sunflower with yellow flames. The young men in the balcony had taken off their jackets and vests and hung them on the railing. They were talking to each other from one end of the theater to the other, sharing the oranges in their hands with the shabby-looking girls sitting next to them. Some women were laughing. Their voices were very shrill, very grating. The sound of popping corks was coming from the bar.
es: That night, for some reason, the theater was packed, and the fat Jewish impresario who greeted them at the door, smiling tremulously from ear to ear with an unctuous expression, proceeded to escort them to the box with pompous humility, waving his thick bejeweled hands and speaking in a loud voice. Dorian Gray felt that he disliked him more than ever. It seemed to him that in coming to seek Miranda, he had encountered Caliban. Lord Henry, on the other hand, rather liked him. At least that’s what he said, and he insisted on shaking his hand, assuring him that he was proud to meet the man who had discovered a gem of acting and had ruined himself because of a poet. Hallward amused himself with the faces in the stalls. The heat was unbearable, and the enormous lamp burned like a monstrous dahlia with petals of yellow fire. The young men in the gallery had taken off their jackets and vests, hanging them from the railings. They talked to each other across the theater and shared their oranges with the flashy girls who accompanied them. Some women laughed in the stalls, with shrill and discordant voices. From the bar came the sound of bottles being uncorked.

en: “What a place to find one’s divinity in!” said Lord Henry.
vi: “What a place to find a saint!” Lord Henry said.
tr: Lord Henry, "Just the place where one would find their goddess!" he said.
es: —What a place to find a goddess! —said Lord Henry.

en: “Yes!” answered Dorian Gray. “It was here I found her, and she is divine beyond all living things. When she acts, you will forget everything. These common rough people, with their coarse faces and brutal gestures, become quite different when she is on the stage. They sit silently and watch her. They weep and laugh as she wills them to do. She makes them as responsive as a violin. She spiritualizes them, and one feels that they are of the same flesh and blood as one’s self.”
vi: “Yes!” Dorian Gray replied. “This is where I found her, and she is divine, far surpassing any creature. When she performs, you will forget everything. The ordinary, rude, coarse-faced, and clumsy people will become entirely different when she is on stage. They sit still watching her. They laugh and cry whenever she wants them to. She makes them sensitive like a violin. She elevates them, and you feel that they are of the same flesh and blood as yourself.”
tr: Dorian Gray replied, "Yes." "I found her right here; she is more heavenly to me than all other creatures. Once she starts her performance, you will forget everything. All these vulgar, uncouth people with their coarse faces and rough manners... They become completely different when she steps onto the stage. They sit silently and watch her. They cry and laugh according to her will. She draws sounds from them like a violin. She spiritualizes them.
es: —It's true! —responded Dorian Gray—. But it was here where I found her, and Sibyl is the embodiment of divinity. When she performs, you will forget everything. Those vulgar and coarse people, with primitive faces and brutal gestures, transform when Sibyl is on stage. They fall silent and listen. They cry and laugh when Sibyl wants them to. She makes them respond like the strings of a violin. She spiritualizes them, and you feel that they are made of the same flesh and blood as us.

en: “The same flesh and blood as one’s self! Oh, I hope not!” exclaimed Lord Henry, who was scanning the occupants of the gallery through his opera-glass.
vi: “Also made of the same flesh and blood as myself! Oh, I hope not!” Lord Henry exclaimed, as he was watching the gallery patrons through the opera glasses.
tr: So much so that it feels like they carry the same flesh and blood as us." Lord Henry, who was surveying the people on the balcony with his binoculars, exclaimed, "The same flesh and blood as us! Never!"
es: —The same flesh and blood as us! I hope not! —exclaimed Lord Henry, who was observing the occupants of the paradise with his opera glasses.

en: “Don’t pay any attention to him, Dorian,” said the painter. “I understand what you mean, and I believe in this girl. Any one you love must be marvellous, and any girl who has the effect you describe must be fine and noble. To spiritualize one’s age—that is something worth doing. If this girl can give a soul to those who have lived without one, if she can create the sense of beauty in people whose lives have been sordid and ugly, if she can strip them of their selfishness and lend them tears for sorrows that are not their own, she is worthy of all your adoration, worthy of the adoration of the world. This marriage is quite right. I did not think so at first, but I admit it now. The gods made Sibyl Vane for you. Without her you would have been incomplete.”
vi: “Don't pay any attention to him, Dorian,” the artist said. “I understand what you mean, and I believe in this girl. Anyone you love must be wonderful, and any girl who can have the influence you describe must be beautiful and noble. Elevating our era — that is a very worthwhile endeavor. If this girl can breathe life into those who have lived without it, if she can create an appreciation for beauty in those whose lives have been mean and ugly, if she can drain selfishness from them and pour into them tears for sorrows that are not their own, then she deserves all your adoration, she deserves the adoration of the whole world. This marriage is entirely right. At first, I did not think so, but now I admit it. The gods have made Sibyl Vane for you. Without her, you would be incomplete.”
tr: The painter said, "Don't mind him, Dorian." "I understand what you mean, and I trust this girl too. Whoever you love is extraordinary; the girl who creates the effect you described is, whoever she may be, superior and noble. To spiritualize one's age... That is truly a valuable endeavor. If this girl can create a soul in those who have lived soulless lives, can evoke a sense of beauty in those who have led dirty and ugly lives, can strip them of their selfishness and make them shed tears for the troubles of others... Then this girl is worthy of your worship, and the world's worship. This marriage would be very fitting. I didn't think so at first, but now I accept its suitability. The gods have created Sibyl Vane for you. Without her, you would be incomplete."
es: —Don't pay attention to him, Dorian —said the painter—. I do understand what you mean and I am convinced that this girl is as you say. The woman you love must be wonderful, and any girl who achieves the effect you describe must be splendid and noble. To spiritualize one's own era..., that is something worthwhile. If Sibyl is capable of giving a soul to those who have lived without one, if she creates a sense of beauty in people whose lives have been sordid and miserable, if she frees them from their selfishness and lends them tears for sufferings that are not their own, she deserves all your adoration, she deserves the adoration of the entire world. Your marriage to her is a success. At first, I didn't believe so, but now I see it differently. The gods have made Sibyl Vane for you. Without her, you would have been incomplete.

en: “Thanks, Basil,” answered Dorian Gray, pressing his hand. “I knew that you would understand me. Harry is so cynical, he terrifies me. But here is the orchestra. It is quite dreadful, but it only lasts for about five minutes. Then the curtain rises, and you will see the girl to whom I am going to give all my life, to whom I have given everything that is good in me.”
vi: “Thank you, Basil,” Dorian Gray replied, gripping his hand tightly. “I knew you would understand me. Harry is so mocking, he terrifies me. But this is the orchestra. It is indeed frightening, but it only lasts about five minutes. Then the curtain rises, and you will see the girl to whom I am about to dedicate my whole life, the girl to whom I have dedicated everything good in me.”
tr: Dorian Gray, "Thank you, Basil," he said, shaking the painter's hand. "I knew you would understand me. Harry is so cynical that he scares me. Anyway, here's the orchestra. A rather terrible orchestra, but fortunately it only lasts five minutes. Then the curtain will rise... You will see the girl to whom I have dedicated my entire life. I have already dedicated everything good in me to her."
es: —Thank you, Basil —replied Dorian Gray, shaking his hand—. I knew you would understand me. Harry is so cynical that he terrifies me. But here comes the orchestra. Although dreadful, it only plays for about five minutes. Then the curtain rises, and you will see the girl to whom I am going to give my whole life, and to whom I have already given all the good that is in me.

en: A quarter of an hour afterwards, amidst an extraordinary turmoil of applause, Sibyl Vane stepped on to the stage. Yes, she was certainly lovely to look at—one of the loveliest creatures, Lord Henry thought, that he had ever seen. There was something of the fawn in her shy grace and startled eyes. A faint blush, like the shadow of a rose in a mirror of silver, came to her cheeks as she glanced at the crowded enthusiastic house. She stepped back a few paces and her lips seemed to tremble. Basil Hallward leaped to his feet and began to applaud. Motionless, and as one in a dream, sat Dorian Gray, gazing at her. Lord Henry peered through his glasses, murmuring, “Charming! charming!”
vi: A quarter of an hour later, amid unusually loud applause, Sibyl Vane stepped onto the stage. Yes, she truly looked beautiful — one of the most beautiful creations, Lord Henry thought, that he had ever seen. There was something very innocent in her shy grace and startled eyes. A slight blush of shyness, like the shadow of a rose in a silver mirror, appeared on her cheeks as she glanced at the packed, enthusiastic theater. She took a few steps back, and her lips seemed to tremble. Basil Hallward stood up abruptly and began to clap. Motionless, as if in a dream, Dorian Gray sat, staring at her. Lord Henry observed through his binoculars, muttering, “Charming! Charming!”
tr: A quarter of an hour later, amidst an astonishing storm of applause, Sibyl Vane came on stage. She was indeed beautiful; Lord Henry admitted that she was one of the most beautiful creatures he had ever seen in his life. There was something in her shy elegance, in her timid eyes that resembled a deer. As the girl looked at the crowded, enthusiastic hall, a blush resembling the shadow of a rose reflected in a silver mirror appeared on her cheeks. The young girl took a couple of steps back; her lips seemed to be trembling. Basil Hallward jumped up from his seat and started clapping. Dorian Gray, however, sat motionless, staring at the girl as if in a dream. Lord Henry, looking through his binoculars, murmured, “Very nice, very nice.”
es: A quarter of an hour later, accompanied by thunderous applause, Sibyl Vane appeared on the stage. Yes, there was no doubt about her charm; she was, thought Lord Henry, one of the most enchanting creatures he had ever seen. There was something of a gazelle in her shy grace and her surprised eyes. A slight blush, like the shadow of a rose in a silver mirror, appeared on her cheeks when she saw the crowded and enthusiastic theater. She took a few steps back and it seemed that her lips were trembling. Basil Hallward stood up and began to applaud. Motionless, as if in a dream, Dorian Gray remained seated, staring at her intently. Lord Henry examined her with his binoculars and murmured: "Charming, charming."

en: The scene was the hall of Capulet’s house, and Romeo in his pilgrim’s dress had entered with Mercutio and his other friends.
