The band, such as it was, struck up a few bars of music, and the dance began. Through the crowd of ungainly, shabbily dressed actors, Sibyl Vane moved like a creature from a finer world. Her body swayed, while she danced, as a plant sways in the water. The curves of her throat were the curves of a white lily. Her hands seemed to be made of cool ivory.
vi: The scene is the Capulet's hall, and Romeo, dressed as a pilgrim, enters with Mercutio and his other friends. The orchestra, still as bad as before, starts playing a few bars of music, and the dance begins. Through the crowd of clumsy, poorly dressed actors, Sibyl Vane moves like a creature from a nobler world. Her body sways, as she dances, like a tree swaying in the water. The curves of her throat are like the curves of a white lily flower. Her hands seem to be carved from cool ivory.
tr: The scene was the hall of the Capulet house. Disguised as a traveler, Romeo had entered with Mercutio and his other friends. The orchestra began to play something as best as they could, and the dance began. In the crowd of poorly dressed, clumsy actors, Sibyl Vane resembled a creature from a superior, more beautiful world. As she danced, her body swayed like reeds in the water. The round lines of her neck were like the round lines of a white lily. Her hands seemed to be made of cool ivory.
es: The action took place in the lobby of the Capulet house, and Romeo, dressed as a pilgrim, had entered with Mercutio and his friends. The musicians played a few bars to the best of their abilities and the dance began. Among the crowd of disheartened and poorly dressed actors, Sibyl Vane moved like a creature from a higher world. Her body swayed, as she danced, like a plant moves within water. The undulations of her throat were the undulations of a white lily. Her hands seemed made of serene ivory.

en: Yet she was curiously listless. She showed no sign of joy when her eyes rested on Romeo. The few words she had to speak—
vi: But she was strangely absent-minded. She showed no sign of joy when her eyes rested on Romeo. A few words she had to say...
tr: However, there was a strange awkwardness about him. When his eyes fell on Romeo, he showed no sign of joy. A few words he had to say:
es: And yet, she appeared curiously apathetic. She showed no sign of joy when her eyes fell upon Romeo. The few words she had to say:

en: Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much,
vi: Kind pilgrim, do not harm your mortal arm,
tr: "Dear traveler, you are being unfair to your hands,"
es: Good pilgrim, do not reproach so much

en: Which mannerly devotion shows in this;
vi: But there arises a reverence for goodness there;
tr: For the hands hold the greeting of God.
es: to your hand a fervor so true:

en: For saints have hands that pilgrims’ hands do touch,
vi: By the angels' hands that he has touched,
tr: The saints bless the travelers with their hands,
es: if pilgrim and saint join hands,

en: And palm to palm is holy palmers’ kiss—
vi: And palm to palm is holy palmers' kiss...
tr: The touching of palms is the kiss of sisters...”
es: palm to palm is a kiss from a palm tree grower...

en: with the brief dialogue that follows, were spoken in a thoroughly artificial manner. The voice was exquisite, but from the point of view of tone it was absolutely false. It was wrong in colour. It took away all the life from the verse. It made the passion unreal.
vi: The short dialogue that followed was spoken with an extremely artificial attitude. The voice was great, but in terms of tone, it was completely wrong. It was also off in terms of nuance. It drained the life out of the poem. It made the passion seem hollow.
tr: and then delivered the following short line with an entirely artificial demeanor. Although his voice was exquisite, his intonation was completely affected, the color was wrong. He was extinguishing all the vitality of the poem he read. He was rendering the fire of love insubstantial.
es: together with the brief dialogue that follows, were pronounced in a completely artificial manner. The voice was exquisite, but from the point of view of tone, absolutely false. The coloration was wrong. It deprived the verses of life. It made the passion seem unreal.

en: Dorian Gray grew pale as he watched her. He was puzzled and anxious. Neither of his friends dared to say anything to him. She seemed to them to be absolutely incompetent. They were horribly disappointed.
vi: Dorian Gray turned pale as he watched her. He was confused and anxious. Both of his friends did not dare to say anything to him. They found her seemingly completely incompetent. They were terribly disappointed.
tr: Dorian Gray was turning pale as he looked at her. He was surprised, anxious. Neither of his friends dared to say anything to him. The girl had seemed completely inadequate in their eyes. They were disappointed.
es: Dorian Gray grew pale as he watched her. He was bewildered and full of anxiety. Neither of his two friends dared to say anything. Sibyl seemed absolutely incompetent to them. They felt horribly disappointed.

en: Yet they felt that the true test of any Juliet is the balcony scene of the second act. They waited for that. If she failed there, there was nothing in her.
vi: They felt that the true test for any Juliet was the balcony scene in act two. They waited for that moment. If she failed there, then she had no talent at all.
tr: Gene believed that the real test for all Juliets was the balcony scene in the second act, and they were waiting for it. If the girl failed in this as well, it meant she had no talent at all.
es: In any case, they understood that the true test for any Juliet is the balcony scene in the second act. They would wait for it to arrive. If she failed there, everything would be over.

en: She looked charming as she came out in the moonlight. That could not be denied. But the staginess of her acting was unbearable, and grew worse as she went on. Her gestures became absurdly artificial. She overemphasized everything that she had to say. The beautiful passage—
vi: She looked very charming as she stepped out under the moonlight. That cannot be denied. But the theatricality in her performance was unbearable, and it worsened as she continued. Her gestures became ridiculously artificial. She overemphasized everything she had to say. The beautiful verse:
tr: When Sibyl stepped onto the moonlit stage, she was captivating. This was undeniable. However, the artificiality of her performance was unbearable, and it was getting worse. Now, a ridiculous artificiality had crept into her gestures as well. She was overemphasizing everything she said.
es: She was charming again when she reappeared in the moonlight. That could not be denied. But the forced nature of her performance was unbearable, and it worsened over time. Her gestures became absurdly artificial. She excessively emphasized everything she had to say. The beautiful passage:

en: Thou knowest the mask of night is on my face,
vi: He knows the night veil is covering your face,
tr: "You know, the mask of the night is on my face,"
es: The night hides me with its veil;

en: Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek
vi: Otherwise, the rosy hue of youth would have already colored your cheeks
tr: Or would the young girl paint my cheek pink
es: if not, the blush would tint my cheeks

en: For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night—
vi: Because of what you heard me say tonight...
tr: Because of the words I said to you tonight...”
es: for what you have heard me say before.

en: was declaimed with the painful precision of a schoolgirl who has been taught to recite by some second-rate professor of elocution. When she leaned over the balcony and came to those wonderful lines—
vi: Recited with the laborious precision of a schoolgirl who had once been taught to memorize by some second-rate elocution teacher. When she leaned over the balcony and came to these wonderful lines:
tr: that beautiful section was read with the tense attention of a school child trained by a second-rate rhetoric teacher. When Sibyl leaned over the balcony and it came to those magnificent lines;
es: it was declaimed with the painful precision of a schoolgirl who has been taught to recite by a third-rate elocution teacher. And when she leaned out the balcony and reached the marvelous verses:

en: Although I joy in thee,
vi: Even if you are happy beside him,
tr: “I'm happy that you're coming, but
es: Even though you are my joy,

en: I have no joy of this contract to-night:
vi: I'm not happy with tonight's deal:
tr: This evening's agreement does not bring me joy.
es: I am not pleased with our agreement tonight:

en: It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden;
vi: It was too hasty, too reckless, too abrupt;
tr: Because very sudden, very crazy, very reckless.
es: too abrupt, reckless, sudden,

en: Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be
vi: Too similar to lightning, the thing that was lost
tr: Just like lightning, it 'struck'
es: just like the lightning, which ceases

en: Ere one can say, “It lightens.” Sweet, good-night!
vi: Before I could speak, "lightning struck." My dear, sleep well!
tr: Fading away... Sweetheart, good night!
es: before being able to name it. Love, good night.

en: This bud of love by summer’s ripening breath
vi: Wishing that this bud of love ripens from the lush breath of summer
tr: I hope this small bud of love Let it flourish and grow with the warm breath of summer
es: With the breath of summer, this budding love

en: May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet—
vi: It will bloom into a beautiful flower when we meet again...
tr: Let Dilber be a flower, we start anew Until we meet again...”
es: it can give a beautiful flower when we see each other again...

en: she spoke the words as though they conveyed no meaning to her. It was not nervousness. Indeed, so far from being nervous, she was absolutely self-contained. It was simply bad art. She was a complete failure.
vi: She spoke the words as if they conveyed no meaning to her. It was not confusion. In fact, far from being confused, she was completely in control. It was simply bad art. She was a complete failure.
tr: He read these as if they meant nothing to him. This was not uneasiness or fear. On the contrary, the young woman was completely free from uneasiness, entirely in control of herself, in a word, she was acting poorly. She was completely unsuccessful.
es: He said the words as if they were completely meaningless. It wasn't nervousness. In fact, far from being nervous, she seemed absolutely in control of herself. It was simply a misunderstanding, and Sibyl a complete disaster.

en: Even the common uneducated audience of the pit and gallery lost their interest in the play. They got restless, and began to talk loudly and to whistle. The Jew manager, who was standing at the back of the dress-circle, stamped and swore with rage. The only person unmoved was the girl herself.
vi: Even the common, uneducated audience members in the second tier and the chicken coop section lost interest in the play. They fidgeted constantly, started talking loudly, and whistling. The Jewish impresario, who had been standing deep in the balcony, stomped his feet and cursed angrily. The only person who remained indifferent was the girl herself.
tr: Even the ordinary, uneducated spectators in the living room and on the balcony lost interest in the play. They started to fidget, talk loudly, and whistle. The Jewish manager standing in the back was stomping in anger, cursing and swearing. The only person who was indifferent was the girl herself.
es: Even the audience in the stalls and the gallery, vulgar and uneducated, had lost interest in the play. Uncomfortable, they began to talk loudly and whistle. The Jewish impresario, standing behind the seats of the first amphitheater, was stamping his feet and protesting indignantly. Only Sibyl remained indifferent.

en: When the second act was over, there came a storm of hisses, and Lord Henry got up from his chair and put on his coat. “She is quite beautiful, Dorian,” he said, “but she can’t act. Let us go.”
vi: When the second act ended, a whistling storm arose, and Lord Henry got up from his seat and put on his coat. “She is very beautiful, Dorian,” he said, “but she cannot act. Let's go.”
tr: When the second act ended, boos erupted like a storm, and Lord Henry stood up and put on his coat. "The girl is extremely beautiful, Dorian, but she has no acting talent," he said. "Let's go."
es: At the end of the second act, a storm of whistles erupted. Lord Henry rose from his seat and put on his overcoat. —She is very beautiful, Dorian —he said—, but incapable of acting. Let's go.

en: “I am going to see the play through,” answered the lad, in a hard bitter voice. “I am awfully sorry that I have made you waste an evening, Harry. I apologize to you both.”
vi: “I will watch until the end of the play,” the young man replied, in a harsh, bitter voice. “I am very sorry that I made you waste the entire evening, Harry. I apologize to both of you.”
tr: The young man said in a bitter, harsh voice, "I will watch until the end." "I am very sorry for wasting your night, Harry. I apologize to both of you."
es: —I am going to stay until the end —replied the young man, with a tense and bitter voice—. I am very sorry to have ruined the evening for you. I apologize to both of you.

en: “My dear Dorian, I should think Miss Vane was ill,” interrupted Hallward. “We will come some other night.”
vi: “My dear Dorian, I suppose Miss Vane is ill,” Hallward interrupted. “We will come another night.”
tr: Hallward said, "Dear Dorian, Miss Vane was probably ill." "We will come again another night."
es: —My dear Dorian, it seems to me that Miss Vane is unwell —interrupted Hallward—. We will come another night.

en: “I wish she were ill,” he rejoined. “But she seems to me to be simply callous and cold. She has entirely altered. Last night she was a great artist. This evening she is merely a commonplace mediocre actress.”
vi: “I also hope she is ill,” he replied. “But it seems to me that she is completely numb and cold. She has changed completely. Just the other night she was a great artist. Tonight she is just a mediocre, second-rate actress.”
tr: Dorian replied, "I wish she were ill." "She seemed emotionless, cold to me. She has fundamentally changed. Last night, she was a great artist. Tonight, she is an ordinary, average actress."
es: —I wish she were ill —replied Dorian Gray—. But to me, she simply seemed insensitive and cold. She has completely changed. Last night she was a great artist. Today she is a vulgar, mediocre actress.

en: “Don’t talk like that about any one you love, Dorian. Love is a more wonderful thing than art.”
vi: “Don't speak that way about anyone you love, Dorian. Love is a more wonderful thing than Art.”
tr: "Don't talk about your loved ones in this manner, Dorian. Love is something superior to art."
es: —Don't speak like that about someone you love, Dorian. Love is more wonderful than art.

en: “They are both simply forms of imitation,” remarked Lord Henry. “But do let us go. Dorian, you must not stay here any longer. It is not good for one’s morals to see bad acting. Besides, I don’t suppose you will want your wife to act, so what does it matter if she plays Juliet like a wooden doll? She is very lovely, and if she knows as little about life as she does about acting, she will be a delightful experience. There are only two kinds of people who are really fascinating—people who know absolutely everything, and people who know absolutely nothing. Good heavens, my dear boy, don’t look so tragic! The secret of remaining young is never to have an emotion that is unbecoming. Come to the club with Basil and myself. We will smoke cigarettes and drink to the beauty of Sibyl Vane. She is beautiful. What more can you want?”
vi: “Both are merely forms of imitation,” remarked Lord Henry. “But let's go now. Dorian, you shouldn't stay here any longer. Watching bad acting is not good for the spirit. Besides, I don't believe you would want your wife to act. So if she plays Juliet like a wooden doll, what does it matter? She is very beautiful, and assuming she knows as little about life as she does about acting, she will be an interesting experience. There are only two kinds of people who are really fascinating — those who know everything, and those who know nothing. Good heavens, my dear boy, don't look so tragic! The secret of remaining young is never to have an emotion that is unsuitable. Come to the club with Basil and me. We will smoke cigarettes and toast to the beauty of Sibyl Vane. She is truly beautiful. What more could you want?”
tr: Lord Henry expressed his opinion, "Both are nothing more than forms of imitation." "But come on, let's go. Dorian, don't linger here. Bad acting corrupts morals. Besides, I don't think you would want your wife to be on stage. So what if she acts like a wooden doll as Juliet? The girl is a sight to behold. If she is as naive in life as she is on stage, it will be an enjoyable experience for you. There are only two types of people who are interesting and attractive: those who know everything and those who know nothing. Oh dear, my dear boy, don't look so tragic! The secret to staying young is to avoid emotions that don't suit your face. Come, join us at the club. We'll light a cigarette and toast to Sibyl Vane's beauty. The girl is truly beautiful. What more do you want?"
es: —Both are forms of imitation —pointed out Lord Henry—. But it would be better if we leave. You shouldn't stay here any longer, Dorian. It's not good for the morale to see a bad performance. Besides, I suppose you wouldn't want your wife to act in the theater. In that case, what does it matter if she plays Juliet like a wooden doll? She is charming, and if she knows as little about life as she does about acting in the theater, it will be a delightful experience. There are only two kinds of people who are really fascinating: those who know absolutely everything and those who know absolutely nothing. Good heavens, boy, don't put on such a tragic expression! The secret to preserving youth is not to allow oneself any improper emotion. Come to the club with Basil and me. We will smoke cigarettes and drink to celebrate the beauty of Sibyl Vane, who is very beautiful. What more could you want?

en: “Go away, Harry,” cried the lad. “I want to be alone. Basil, you must go. Ah! can’t you see that my heart is breaking?” The hot tears came to his eyes. His lips trembled, and rushing to the back of the box, he leaned up against the wall, hiding his face in his hands.
vi: "Go away, Harry," the young man cried out. "I want to be alone. Basil, you should go too. Oh! Can't you see that my heart is breaking? Tears welled up in his eyes. His lips trembled, and, rushing deep into the box, he leaned against the wall, hiding his face in his hands.
tr: The young man shouted, "Harry, go away!" "I want to be alone. Basil, you go too. Oh, my heart is breaking, can't you see?" Warm tears filled her eyes, her lips were trembling. She ran and entered the box, leaning against the wall and hiding her face in her hands.
es: —Go away, Harry —exclaimed the young man—. I want to be alone. And you too, Basil. Can't you see that my heart is breaking? Burning tears welled up in his eyes. His lips trembled and, moving to the back of the box, he leaned against the wall, hiding his face in his hands.

en: “Let us go, Basil,” said Lord Henry with a strange tenderness in his voice, and the two young men passed out together.
vi: "Let's go, Basil," Lord Henry said, with a different kind of gentleness in his voice; and the two young men went out together.
tr: Lord Henry said, "Let's go, Basil." There was a strange softness, a tenderness in his voice. The two young men went out together.
es: —Let's go, Basil —said Lord Henry, with a strange tenderness in his voice.

en: A few moments afterwards the footlights flared up and the curtain rose on the third act. Dorian Gray went back to his seat. He looked pale, and proud, and indifferent. The play dragged on, and seemed interminable. Half of the audience went out, tramping in heavy boots and laughing. The whole thing was a fiasco. The last act was played to almost empty benches. The curtain went down on a titter and some groans.
vi: A few minutes later, the stage lights flared up, and the curtain rose for the third act. Dorian Gray returned to his seat. He looked pale, arrogant, indifferent. The play seemed to drag on endlessly. Half the audience left, dragging their heavy-shoed feet and laughing mockingly. The whole affair was a failure. The final act was performed before nearly empty rows of seats. The curtain fell amidst a few giggles and murmurs of disapproval.
tr: A few minutes later, the lights at the bottom of the stage came on and the third act began. Dorian took his place. He stood pale, proud, and indifferent. The play dragged on and seemed like it would never end. Half of the audience, clattering their rough shoes, left the hall laughing. It was a complete fiasco. The last part was performed to an almost empty hall. The curtain fell amidst giggles and sighs.
es: A moment later, they had disappeared. Almost immediately the footlights were lit and the curtain rose for the third act. Dorian Gray returned to his seat. He was pale, but proud and indifferent. The play dragged on, interminable. Half of the audience left the theater, making noise with their heavy boots and laughing. The performance had been a total fiasco. The last act was performed before an almost empty house. Suppressed laughter and some protests greeted the fall of the final curtain.

en: As soon as it was over, Dorian Gray rushed behind the scenes into the greenroom. The girl was standing there alone, with a look of triumph on her face. Her eyes were lit with an exquisite fire. There was a radiance about her. Her parted lips were smiling over some secret of their own.
vi: Right after it was over, Dorian Gray rushed backstage, into the break room. The girl stood there alone, with a joyful expression. Her eyes shone with a beautiful fire. An aura surrounded her. Her slightly parted lips smiled with some private secret.
tr: As soon as the play was over, Dorian ran backstage, to the dressing room. Sibyl was standing there alone, with an expression on her face as if she had won a victory. Her eyes were shining with a delightful light, her entire being seemed to be glowing. Her slightly parted lips were smiling as if at a secret only she knew.
es: As soon as the play ended, Dorian went backstage to head to the actress's dressing room. He found Sibyl there, with a triumphant expression on her face and her eyes full of fire. She was radiant. She smiled, her lips slightly parted, because of a very personal secret.

en: When he entered, she looked at him, and an expression of infinite joy came over her. “How badly I acted to-night, Dorian!” she cried.
vi: When he entered, she looked at him, and an expression of boundless joy appeared on her face. “Why did you perform so poorly tonight, Dorian!” she exclaimed.
tr: When Dorian entered, the girl looked at him, and an infinite joy spread across her face. "Dorian, I gave a terrible performance tonight!""
es: As Dorian entered, the girl looked at him and an expression of infinite joy appeared on her face. —How badly I acted tonight, Dorian! —she exclaimed.

en: “Horribly!” he answered, gazing at her in amazement. “Horribly! It was dreadful. Are you ill? You have no idea what it was. You have no idea what I suffered.”
vi: “Terrible!” he replied, looking at her in astonishment — “terrible! Truly horrifying. Are you sick? You can't imagine what it's like. You can't imagine what I have to endure.”
tr: Dorian looked at him in astonishment and said, "Terrible!" "Terrible! It was awful. Are you sick? You can't imagine how I writhed."
es: —Horribly bad! —he responded, looking at her amazed—. Awful! It was terrible. Are you sick? You can't imagine what it was like. You can't imagine how I suffered.

en: The girl smiled. “Dorian,” she answered, lingering over his name with long-drawn music in her voice, as though it were sweeter than honey to the red petals of her mouth. “Dorian, you should have understood. But you understand now, don’t you?”
vi: The girl laughed. “Dorian,” she replied, lingering on his name with a musical tone in her voice, as if it were sweeter than honey on the crimson petals of her lips — "Dorian, you should have understood. But now you do, don't you?”
tr: Sibyl smiled and said, "Dorian." She elongated his name with the languid music of her voice, as if this name was sweeter than honey on the red rose petal of her lips. "Dorian, you should have understood. Anyway, you understand now, don't you?"
es: The girl smiled. —Dorian —he replied, caressing the name of his beloved with the prolonged music of his voice, as if it were sweeter than honey to the red petals of his mouth—. Dorian, you should have understood it. But now you understand it already, don't you?

en: “Understand what?” he asked, angrily.
vi: “Understand what?” he asked, angrily.
tr: Dorian asked angrily, "What do I understand?"
es: —Understand what? —he asked, angrily.

en: “Why I was so bad to-night. Why I shall always be bad. Why I shall never act well again.”
vi: “Why were you so bad tonight. Why will you always be bad. Why will you never be able to perform well again.”
tr: “Why I played so badly tonight. Why I will always play badly from now on. Why I will never perform well again.”
es: —The reason why I did so poorly tonight. The reason why from now on I will always do poorly. The reason why I will never perform well again.

en: He shrugged his shoulders. “You are ill, I suppose. When you are ill you shouldn’t act. You make yourself ridiculous. My friends were bored. I was bored.”
vi: He shrugged. "You're sick, I think so. When you're sick, you shouldn't perform. You make yourself look ridiculous. My friends are sad. I'm sad too."
tr: The young man shrugged. “You must be sick. You shouldn't go on stage when you're sick. You're making a fool of yourself. My friends got bored. I got bored too.”
es: Dorian shrugged. —I suppose you are sick. When you are sick, you shouldn't act. You make a fool of yourself. My friends have gotten bored. I have gotten bored.

en: She seemed not to listen to him. She was transfigured with joy. An ecstasy of happiness dominated her.
vi: She seemed not to hear him. She was radiant with joy. An enchanting happiness dominated her.
tr: The girl seemed not to be listening to him. It was as if she had undergone a transformation from joy. She was in a state of euphoria.
es: Sibyl seemed not to hear him. She was transfigured by joy. Overcome by an ecstasy of happiness.

en: “Dorian, Dorian,” she cried, “before I knew you, acting was the one reality of my life. It was only in the theatre that I lived. I thought that it was all true. I was Rosalind one night and Portia the other. The joy of Beatrice was my joy, and the sorrows of Cordelia were mine also. I believed in everything. The common people who acted with me seemed to me to be godlike. The painted scenes were my world. I knew nothing but shadows, and I thought them real. You came—oh, my beautiful love!—and you freed my soul from prison. You taught me what reality really is. To-night, for the first time in my life, I saw through the hollowness, the sham, the silliness of the empty pageant in which I had always played. To-night, for the first time, I became conscious that the Romeo was hideous, and old, and painted, that the moonlight in the orchard was false, that the scenery was vulgar, and that the words I had to speak were unreal, were not my words, were not what I wanted to say. You had brought me something higher, something of which all art is but a reflection. You had made me understand what love really is. My love! My love! Prince Charming! Prince of life! I have grown sick of shadows. You are more to me than all art can ever be. What have I to do with the puppets of a play? When I came on to-night, I could not understand how it was that everything had gone from me. I thought that I was going to be wonderful. I found that I could do nothing. Suddenly it dawned on my soul what it all meant. The knowledge was exquisite to me. I heard them hissing, and I smiled. What could they know of love such as ours? Take me away, Dorian—take me away with you, where we can be quite alone. I hate the stage. I might mimic a passion that I do not feel, but I cannot mimic one that burns me like fire. Oh, Dorian, Dorian, you understand now what it signifies? Even if I could do it, it would be profanation for me to play at being in love. You have made me see that.”
vi: “Dorian, Dorian,” she cried, “before I knew you, acting was a reality of my life. Only in the theater did I truly live. I thought it was all true. I was Rosalind one night, Portia another. Beatrice's joy was my joy, Cordelia's sorrow belonged to me as well. I believed it all. It seemed to me that the mortals who acted with me were like gods. The painted scenery was my world. I knew nothing but shadows, and I thought they were real. You came — oh, my exquisite love! — and you freed my soul from its prison. You taught me what reality truly is. Tonight, for the first time in my life, I saw through the emptiness, the pretense, the foolishness of the meaningless spectacle in which I had always acted. Tonight, for the first time, I realized that Romeo is disgusting, old, painted, that the moonlight in the garden is fake, that the scenery is trivial, that the words I had to say were hollow, not my own, not what I wanted to say. You have brought me something greater, something that all art is merely a reflection of. You have made me understand what love truly is. My love! My love! Prince Charming! Prince of life! I am sick of shadows. To me, you are above all the art in the world that has ever existed. What should I do with the puppets in the play? When I went to the theater tonight, I couldn't understand why everything left me. I thought I would perform wonderfully. I found that I couldn't do anything at all. Suddenly my heart realized what all this meant. That realization was wonderful to me. I heard them whistle, and I laughed. What could they know about a love like ours? Take me away, Dorian — take me away with you, to a place where it's just the two of us. I hate the stage. I can mimic a passion that I do not feel, but I cannot mimic something that has burned me like fire. Oh, Dorian, Dorian, do you understand now what it means? Even if I could, I would still find acting out love scenes an insult. You have made me realize that.
tr: “Dorian, Dorian!” she cried softly. “Before I knew you, the only reality in my life was my play on the stage. I only lived when I was on stage. All the plays were real in my eyes. One night I was Rosalind, the next night Portia. Beatrice’s joy was my joy, Cordelia’s sorrows were my sorrows. I believed in everything. Alongside me, those rough people who appeared on stage seemed like gods to me. The painted sets were my world. I knew nothing but shadows, and I thought shadows were real. Then you came, my beautiful lover... You freed my soul from its prison. You taught me the true reality. Tonight, for the first time, I saw the hollowness, the artificiality, the stupidity of this empty show I had been acting in all my life. Tonight, I saw for the first time that Romeo was hideous, old, painted, and that the moonlight hitting the orchard was not real: The words I had to say were false, they were not my words, not what I wanted to say. I saw this tonight. You had given me something higher, something that all art is but a reflection of. You taught me what love really is, my lover, my lover! Sweet Prince! Prince of Life! I am tired of shadows now. You are more important to me than all art, forever. What do I have to do with puppets in a play? When I went on stage tonight, at first I couldn’t understand how the old enthusiasm had vanished. I thought I would be marvelous. I saw that I could do nothing. Then suddenly, I understood everything. And knowing this thrilled me with joy. I heard their boos, I smiled. What did they know of a love like ours? Take me away, Dorian! Take me to a place where we can be alone. I am disgusted with the stage. I might be able to mimic a passion I have never known, but I cannot mimic a passion that burns me like fire. Dorian, Dorian, now you understand, don’t you, the importance of everything? To play the role of a lover on stage would be like blasphemy for me, even if I could do it. You showed me this.”
es: "Dorian, Dorian," she exclaimed, "before I met you, acting was the only reality of my life. I lived only for the theater. I believed that everything that happened in the theater was true. I was Rosalind one night and Portia another. Beatrice's joy was my joy, and Cordelia's sorrows were equally mine. I believed it all. The common people who worked with me seemed touched by divinity. The sets were my world. I only knew shadows, but they seemed real to me. Then you came, my wonderful love, and freed my soul from its prison. You taught me what reality is. Tonight, for the first time in my life, I saw the emptiness, the imposture, the stupidity of the meaningless spectacle in which I participated. Today, for the first time, I realized that Romeo was horrible, old, and made-up; that the moon over the orchard was a lie, that the sets were vulgar and that the words I spoke were unreal, that they were not mine, not what I wanted to say. You have brought me something higher, something of which all art is but a reflection. You have made me understand what love truly is. My love! My prince charming! Prince of my life! I am tired of shadows. You are more to me than art could ever be. What do I have to do with the puppets of a play? When I went on stage tonight, I couldn't understand how I had been left with nothing. I thought I would give a wonderful performance and suddenly I found I was incapable of acting. Suddenly I understood what it means to love you. Knowing it made me happy. I smiled when I heard the audience protest. What do they know of a love like ours? Take me away, Dorian; take me with you to where we can be completely alone. I abhor the theater. I know how to imitate a passion I do not feel, but not the one that burns within me like a fire. Dorian, Dorian, don't you understand what it means? Even if I could do it, it would be a desecration for me to pretend to be in love. You have made me see it.

en: He flung himself down on the sofa and turned away his face. “You have killed my love,” he muttered.
vi: He let himself fall onto the sofa and turned away. "You have killed my love," he whispered.
tr: The young man threw himself onto the couch and turned his head to the other side. "You killed my love," he muttered.
es: Dorian let himself fall onto the sofa and avoided looking at her. —You have killed my love —she murmured.

en: She looked at him in wonder and laughed. He made no answer. She came across to him, and with her little fingers stroked his hair. She knelt down and pressed his hands to her lips. He drew them away, and a shudder ran through him.
vi: She looked at him in surprise and laughed. He did not respond. She approached him, gently stroking his hair with her small fingers. She knelt down and pressed his hands to her lips. He pulled them away, a shiver running through him.
tr: The girl laughed, looking at him as if she didn't understand. Dorian did not respond. The girl came over and stroked his hair with her tiny hands. She knelt down and pressed his hands to her lips. Dorian pulled his hands away, a shiver ran through his body.
es: Sibyl looked at him astonished and burst out laughing. The boy did not respond. She approached, and with one hand caressed his hair. Then she knelt down and took his hands, kissing them. Dorian withdrew them, shivering from a chill.

en: Then he leaped up and went to the door. “Yes,” he cried, “you have killed my love. You used to stir my imagination. Now you don’t even stir my curiosity. You simply produce no effect. I loved you because you were marvellous, because you had genius and intellect, because you realized the dreams of great poets and gave shape and substance to the shadows of art. You have thrown it all away. You are shallow and stupid. My God! how mad I was to love you! What a fool I have been! You are nothing to me now. I will never see you again. I will never think of you. I will never mention your name. You don’t know what you were to me, once. Why, once ... Oh, I can’t bear to think of it! I wish I had never laid eyes upon you! You have spoiled the romance of my life. How little you can know of love, if you say it mars your art! Without your art, you are nothing. I would have made you famous, splendid, magnificent. The world would have worshipped you, and you would have borne my name. What are you now? A third-rate actress with a pretty face.”
vi: Then he stood up abruptly and walked to the door. “Yes,” he cried out, “you have killed my love. You once stirred my imagination. Now you don't even arouse my curiosity. You simply don't make any impression at all. I loved you because you were marvelous, because you had genius and intellect, because you realized the dreams of great poets and gave shape and substance to the shadows of art. You have thrown it all away. You are empty and dull. God! How madly I loved you! How foolish I was! Now you are nothing to me. I will never see you again. I will never think of you again. I will never mention your name again. You don't know what you were to me, before. How, before... Oh, I can't bear to think about it! I wish I had never laid eyes on you! You have ruined the dreams of my life. How can you understand so little about love, if you say it ruins your art! Without art, you are nothing. I would have made you famous, splendid, magnificent. The world would have worshipped you, and you would have borne my name. What are you now? A third-rate actress with a pretty face.”
tr: Then, she sprang up and walked to the door. “Yes,” she shouted. “You killed my love. You used to nourish my imagination. Now you can't even arouse my curiosity. You don't affect me in the slightest. If I loved you, it was because you were magnificent; you had superior talent, mental strength, you realized the dreams of great poets, gave shape to the shadow of art, and added concreteness. You threw all of that away. You are shallow and stupid. My God! What madness it was to love you! How foolish I was! Now you are nothing in my eyes. I will never see you again, never think of you. I will never utter your name. You don't know what you used to be in my eyes. And I... Oh, I can't even bear to think about it! I wish I had never seen you! You ruined the great love of my life. If love ruins your art, it means you don't know love at all! Without your art, you are nothing. I was going to make you famous, brilliant, magnificent. The world would have knelt before you, and you would have borne my name. What are you now? A beautiful-faced, third-rate actress.”
es: Then he jumped to his feet, heading towards the door. —Yes —he exclaimed—; you have killed my love. You were a stimulus for my imagination. Now you don't even awaken my curiosity. You have no effect on me. I loved you because you were wonderful, because you had genius and intelligence, because you made the dreams of great poets real and gave shape and substance to the shadows of art. You have thrown all that out the window. You are superficial and stupid. Good heavens! How crazy I was to love you! What a fool I have been! You no longer mean anything to me. I will never see you again. I will never think of you. I will never mention your name. You don't realize what you represented to me. Thinking about it is intolerable to me. I wish I had never seen you! You have destroyed the poetry of my life. How little you know about love if you say it stifles art! Without art, you are nothing. I would have made you famous, splendid, dazzling. The world would have adored you, and you would have carried my name. But now, what are you? A third-rate actress with a pretty face.

en: The girl grew white, and trembled. She clenched her hands together, and her voice seemed to catch in her throat. “You are not serious, Dorian?” she murmured. “You are acting.”
vi: The girl turned pale and trembled. She clasped her hands tightly together, and her voice seemed to catch in her throat. “You can't be serious, Dorian?” she whispered. “You are acting.”
tr: The girl turned completely pale and was trembling. She clasped her hands together and murmured with a voice caught in her throat, "You're not serious, are you, Dorian?" "You're acting."
es: Sibyl turned pale and began to tremble. She clasped her hands tightly and said, in a voice that was almost lost in her throat: —You can't be serious, Dorian? —he murmured—. You're acting.

en: “Acting! I leave that to you. You do it so well,” he answered bitterly.
vi: "Act! I'll leave that job to you. You do it so well," he replied bitterly.
tr: The young man replied in a bitter voice, "Acting? I'll leave that to you," he responded. "You do it so well!"
es: —Acting? I'll leave that to you, since you do it so well —he responded bitterly.

en: She rose from her knees and, with a piteous expression of pain in her face, came across the room to him. She put her hand upon his arm and looked into his eyes. He thrust her back. “Don’t touch me!” he cried.
vi: She sat up, and, with a look of pitiable pain on her face, walked across the room to him. She placed her hand on his arm, looking into his eyes. He pushed her back. “Don't touch me!” he shouted.
tr: Sibyl rose from where she had knelt; there was an expression on her face that showed she was in pain. She placed her hand on his and looked into his eyes. Dorian pushed him. “Don't touch me!” he shouted.
es: Rising from where she had knelt and, with a painful expression of sorrow on her face, the girl crossed the room to approach him. She placed her hand on his arm, looking into his eyes. Dorian pushed her away violently. —Don't touch me! -he shouted.

en: A low moan broke from her, and she flung herself at his feet and lay there like a trampled flower. “Dorian, Dorian, don’t leave me!” she whispered. “I am so sorry I didn’t act well. I was thinking of you all the time. But I will try—indeed, I will try. It came so suddenly across me, my love for you. I think I should never have known it if you had not kissed me—if we had not kissed each other. Kiss me again, my love. Don’t go away from me. I couldn’t bear it. Oh! don’t go away from me. My brother ... No; never mind. He didn’t mean it. He was in jest.... But you, oh! can’t you forgive me for to-night? I will work so hard and try to improve. Don’t be cruel to me, because I love you better than anything in the world. After all, it is only once that I have not pleased you. But you are quite right, Dorian. I should have shown myself more of an artist. It was foolish of me, and yet I couldn’t help it. Oh, don’t leave me, don’t leave me.” A fit of passionate sobbing choked her. She crouched on the floor like a wounded thing, and Dorian Gray, with his beautiful eyes, looked down at her, and his chiselled lips curled in exquisite disdain. There is always something ridiculous about the emotions of people whom one has ceased to love. Sibyl Vane seemed to him to be absurdly melodramatic. Her tears and sobs annoyed him.
vi: A faint moan escaped from her, and she fell at his feet, lying there like a trampled flower. “Dorian, Dorian, don't leave me!” she whispered. “I am so sorry that I did not perform well. I think of you all the time. But I will try — really, I will try. How suddenly it came to me, the love I have for you. I think I would never have known it if you had not kissed me — if we had not kissed each other. Kiss me again, my love. Don't leave me. I can't bear it. Oh! Don't leave me. My brother… No; don't worry. It means nothing. He was just joking… But you, oh! Can't you forgive me for tonight? I will do my best, and try to improve. Don't be cruel to me because I love you more than anything in the world. After all, it is only this one time that I have not pleased you. But you are entirely right, Dorian. I should not have shown myself more than an actress. That was my foolishness; yet I could not help it. Oh, don't leave me, don't leave me.” An earnest sob choked her. She bent over the floor like a wounded animal, while Dorian Gray, with his beautiful eyes, looked down at her, and his chiselled lips curled in extreme disdain. There is always something ridiculous about the emotions of those whom one has ceased to love. He found Sibyl Vane to be absurdly melodramatic. Her tears and sobs irritated him.
tr: The young girl, from whose lips a faint moan escaped, threw herself at Dorian's feet and lay there like a bruised flower. “Dorian, don't leave me, Dorian!” she whispered. “I am so sorry for not giving a good performance. I was always thinking of you. But I will try, believe me, I will try. The love I feel for you caught me so off guard. If you hadn't kissed me, if we hadn't kissed, I think I would never have known love. Kiss me again, my love. Don't leave me, I can't bear it. Please, don't leave me. My brother... No, never mind. He wasn't serious, he was pretending. But you, oh, can't you forgive me just for tonight? I will work so hard on my roles, I will strive to be better. Please, don't be cruel to me, because I love you more than anything in the world. After all, I only disappointed you once. Still, you are very right, Dorian. I should have expressed my art. I acted foolishly but I couldn't help it. Please, don't leave me, don't leave me.” The girl, her breath choked with sobs, curled up on the ground like a wounded animal. Dorian was looking down at her with those beautiful eyes, his lips, which resembled something drawn with a pen, curved in an elegant disdain. There is always something that seems ridiculous to us in the emotions of people we no longer love. Dorian now found something laughably melodramatic in Sibyl's behavior, and he was irritated by her tears and sobs.
es: A barely audible moan escaped from the Sibyl as she threw herself at his feet, remaining there like a trampled flower. —Don't leave me, Dorian! —she whispered—. I'm sorry I didn't perform my role well. I was thinking of you the whole time. But I will try, of course I will try. It came to me so suddenly..., my love for you. I think I would never have known if you hadn't kissed me, if we hadn't kissed. Kiss me again, my love. Don't walk away from me. I couldn't bear it. Don't leave me. My brother... No; it doesn't matter. He didn't know what he was saying. It was a joke... But you, can't you forgive me for what happened tonight? I will work very hard and strive to improve. Don't be cruel to me, because I love you more than anything in the world. After all, I have only failed to please you once. But you are absolutely right, Dorian, I should have shown that I am an artist. What an absurd thing; although, in reality, I couldn't help it. Don't leave me, please —a fit of passionate sobs seized her. She curled up on the floor like a wounded creature, and the beautifully shaped lips of Dorian Gray, looking down at her, curved in a gesture of consummate disdain. The emotions of people one has ceased to love always have something ridiculous about them. Sibyl Vane seemed absurdly melodramatic to him. Her tears and sobs annoyed him.

en: “I am going,” he said at last in his calm clear voice. “I don’t wish to be unkind, but I can’t see you again. You have disappointed me.”
vi: “I'm leaving,” he finally said, in his calm, clear voice. “I don't want to become cruel, but I can't see you again. You have made me bored.”
tr: Finally, "I'm leaving," he said in a calm, clear voice. "I don't want to be hurtful, but I can't see you again. You have disappointed me."
es: —I'm leaving —he finally said, with a clear and calm voice—. I don't want to seem rude, but it will be impossible for me to see you again. You have disappointed me.

en: She wept silently, and made no answer, but crept nearer. Her little hands stretched blindly out, and appeared to be seeking for him. He turned on his heel and left the room. In a few moments he was out of the theatre.
vi: She cried silently, not responding, but crawled closer. Her small hands reached out, seemingly to find him. He turned on his heel and left the room. After a few minutes, he was out of the theater.
tr: The girl was crying silently. She didn't respond but approached him quietly. She had opened her tiny hands, as if she was searching for him. Dorian turned on his heel and walked out. A few minutes later, he had already left the theater.
es: Sibyl wept in silence, but did not respond; she only crawled to get closer to Dorian. She extended her hands blindly, giving the impression of searching for him. The boy turned around and left the room. A few moments later, he had left the theater.

en: Where he went to he hardly knew. He remembered wandering through dimly lit streets, past gaunt, black-shadowed archways and evil-looking houses. Women with hoarse voices and harsh laughter had called after him. Drunkards had reeled by, cursing and chattering to themselves like monstrous apes. He had seen grotesque children huddled upon door-steps, and heard shrieks and oaths from gloomy courts.
vi: You hardly knew where you were going. You remembered wandering through dimly lit streets, past deserted archways shrouded in darkness, and houses that looked very sinister. Women with hoarse voices and shrill laughter called out to you. Drunken men staggered by, cursing and muttering to themselves like giant monkeys. You saw strange children huddled together on doorsteps, and heard shouts and curses from gloomy courtyards.
tr: He was not quite aware of where he was going. Later, he would remember passing through dim streets, the dark shadows of bare arches, and in front of ominous-looking houses. Women with hoarse voices and harsh laughter had called out after him. Drunkards, muttering and cursing to themselves like giant monkeys, had stumbled past him. He had seen strange children crouched in doorways, and heard cries and curses rising from gloomy courtyards.
es: He barely knew where he was going. Later, he remembered wandering through poorly lit streets, having crossed gloomy passages populated with black shadows and unsettling houses. Women with hoarse voices and harsh laughs had called out to him. Drunkards with unsteady steps had passed by him, cursing, chattering to themselves like monstrous anthropoids. He had seen grotesque children huddled in doorways and heard screams and curses coming from melancholy courtyards.

en: As the dawn was just breaking, he found himself close to Covent Garden. The darkness lifted, and, flushed with faint fires, the sky hollowed itself into a perfect pearl. Huge carts filled with nodding lilies rumbled slowly down the polished empty street. The air was heavy with the perfume of the flowers, and their beauty seemed to bring him an anodyne for his pain. He followed into the market and watched the men unloading their waggons. A white-smocked carter offered him some cherries. He thanked him, wondered why he refused to accept any money for them, and began to eat them listlessly. They had been plucked at midnight, and the coldness of the moon had entered into them. A long line of boys carrying crates of striped tulips, and of yellow and red roses, defiled in front of him, threading their way through the huge, jade-green piles of vegetables. Under the portico, with its grey, sun-bleached pillars, loitered a troop of draggled bareheaded girls, waiting for the auction to be over. Others crowded round the swinging doors of the coffee-house in the piazza. The heavy cart-horses slipped and stamped upon the rough stones, shaking their bells and trappings. Some of the drivers were lying asleep on a pile of sacks. Iris-necked and pink-footed, the pigeons ran about picking up seeds.
vi: When dawn just broke, he found himself near Covent Garden. The darkness had dissipated, and, tinged pink by the pale fire, the sky curved into a perfect pearl. Huge horse-drawn carriages loaded with nodding lilies were clattering slowly down the shiny empty street. The air was fragrant with flowers, and their beauty seemed to bring him a soothing balm for his pain. He followed into the market, watching people unload the carriages. A coachman in a white coat offered him some cherries. He thanked him, wondering why he refused to accept even a penny for them, and began to eat them indifferently. They had been picked at midnight, and the cold moonlight had seeped into them. A long line of boys carrying crates of striped tulips and yellow with red roses marched in front of him, weaving their way through the massive emerald-green heaps of vegetables. Under the archway, with columns bleached gray by the sun, a group of girls with dirt-smeared bare heads were lingering, waiting for the auction to end. Other crowds gathered around the revolving doors of the coffee shop on the terrace. Heavy pack horses were both slipping and stamping on the rough stones, jingling their harnesses and saddles. Some coachmen were sleeping on piles of sacks. With rainbow necks and pink feet, the pigeons were scurrying around pecking at seeds.
tr: At dawn, he found himself near Covent Garden. The darkness had lifted, and the sky, illuminated by pale glimmers, had gathered into a perfect pearl. Along the bright-stoned, empty street, large carts loaded with lilies were slowly clattering forward. The air seemed to be drowsy with the scent of lilies. The beauty of the flowers felt like a balm to the young boy's suffering. Dorian walked to the marketplace following the carts, watching the men unload their cargo. A carter in a white, ruffled shirt offered him a handful of cherries. Dorian thanked him, reluctantly starting to eat the cherries, not understanding why the man didn't take any money. The cherries had been picked at night, with the frost of the moonlight seeping into them. A line of tall boys carrying crates full of striped tulips and red and yellow roses on their shoulders paraded in front of Dorian, making their way through the high, emerald green heaps of vegetables. Under the archway with sun-bleached gray pillars, a crowd of girls, dressed in ragged clothes and bareheaded, were waiting for the auction to end. Some had piled up in front of the swinging door of the café in the Piazza. There were carters who had fallen asleep on top of the piles of sacks. The hefty cart horses stumbled on the cobblestones, their saddles shaking and bells jingling as they staggered. Pigeons with purple necks and pink feet were running around, pecking at the seeds on the ground.
es: At the break of dawn, he found himself near Covent Garden. As the veil of darkness lifted, the sky, reddened by faint glows, emptied itself to become a perfect pearl. Large carts, filled with swaying lilies, slowly traveled down the gleaming and empty street. The air filled with the fragrance of flowers, and their beauty seemed to provide him with an analgesic for his pain. He continued walking to the market and watched as the vehicles were unloaded. A carter in a white blouse offered him some cherries. Dorian thanked him and, wondering why the other had refused to accept money in return, began to eat them absentmindedly. They had been picked at midnight and had the coolness of the moon. A long line of boys carrying crates of tulips and yellow and red roses paraded before him, making their way through enormous jade-green heaps of vegetables. Under the grand portico, with its sun-faded gray columns, a flock of ragged girls, bareheaded, waited idly for the auction to end. Others crowded around the swinging doors of the Piazza café. The heavy draft horses slipped and struck the rough cobblestones hard, shaking their harnesses with bells. Some of the drivers slept on piles of sacks. With their metallic necks and pinkish legs, the pigeons ran back and forth pecking at seeds.

en: After a little while, he hailed a hansom and drove home. For a few moments he loitered upon the doorstep, looking round at the silent square, with its blank, close-shuttered windows and its staring blinds. The sky was pure opal now, and the roofs of the houses glistened like silver against it. From some chimney opposite a thin wreath of smoke was rising. It curled, a violet riband, through the nacre-coloured air.
vi: A moment later, he called for a two-wheeled carriage and hurried home. For several minutes, he lingered on the doorstep, looking around the quiet square with its bare windows, tightly shut shutters, and exposed curtains. The sky now resembled a pure cat's eye gem, and the rooftops glittered like silver against the sky. From a chimney opposite, a thin wisp of smoke rose. It curled, a purple ribbon, through the pearlescent air.
tr: After a while, Dorian hailed a carriage and went home. He lingered on the threshold for a few minutes, gazing at the closed shutters and vacant-looking windows of the silent square. The sky was now a pure opal, and the rooftops of the houses gleamed like silver. A thin plume of smoke was rising from a chimney across the way. The smoke curled through the pearly air like a lilac ribbon.
es: After some time, Dorian Gray hailed a cab that took him to his house. Once there, he paused for a moment on the threshold, surveying the silent square with its empty windows, shutters, and fixed-gaze blinds. The sky had turned into a pure opal, and the rooftops of the houses shone like silver beneath it. From some chimney on the other side of the square, a thin column of smoke began to rise, soon curling its purple spirals in the pearly air.

en: In the huge gilt Venetian lantern, spoil of some Doge’s barge, that hung from the ceiling of the great, oak-panelled hall of entrance, lights were still burning from three flickering jets: thin blue petals of flame they seemed, rimmed with white fire. He turned them out and, having thrown his hat and cape on the table, passed through the library towards the door of his bedroom, a large octagonal chamber on the ground floor that, in his new-born feeling for luxury, he had just had decorated for himself and hung with some curious Renaissance tapestries that had been discovered stored in a disused attic at Selby Royal. As he was turning the handle of the door, his eye fell upon the portrait Basil Hallward had painted of him. He started back as if in surprise. Then he went on into his own room, looking somewhat puzzled. After he had taken the button-hole out of his coat, he seemed to hesitate. Finally, he came back, went over to the picture, and examined it. In the dim arrested light that struggled through the cream-coloured silk blinds, the face appeared to him to be a little changed. The expression looked different. One would have said that there was a touch of cruelty in the mouth. It was certainly strange.
vi: In the massive gold-plated Venetian lantern, once seized from the flagship of some governor, now hanging from the ceiling of the large oak-paneled hall, the lights still burned from three flickering nozzles: they looked like thin blue petals of fire, edged with white flames. He extinguished them, and, after tossing his hat and cloak onto the table, walked through the library towards the door of his bedroom, a vast octagonal room on the ground floor that, in accordance with his newly developed sense of luxury, he had just redecorated, hanging a few rare Renaissance tapestries that had been discovered stored in an abandoned attic at Selby Royal. As he turned the doorknob, his eyes caught sight of the portrait Basil Hallward had painted of him. He recoiled in surprise. Then he stepped into his room, looking somewhat bewildered. After unbuttoning his coat, he seemed to hesitate. Finally, he turned back, approached the painting, and examined it closely. In the dim light filtered through the cream-colored silk curtains, the face before him had changed a little. The expression looked different. One might say there was something cruel about the mouth. This was very strange.
tr: The house's oak-paneled, spacious entrance hall had a large, gilded Venetian chandelier –a spoil taken from a Doge's ship– whose three lamps were still flickering with trembling flames: They resembled three thin leaves of fire surrounded by white heat. Dorian threw his coat and hat onto the table, extinguished the lamps, and headed to the bedroom through the library. This room on the ground floor, an octagonal, spacious section, was decorated by Dorian according to his own taste, with a newly awakened penchant for ostentation. He had hung Renaissance-style, varied tapestries on the walls, which had been found in an unused attic on Selby Street. Just as he was turning the door handle, his eyes fell on the portrait painted by Basil Hallward. The young man recoiled as if startled. Then, with his eyebrows slightly furrowed, he entered the bedroom. After removing his collar, he seemed to hesitate for a moment. Finally, he turned back again, approached, and examined the portrait. In the dim light barely seeping through the cream-colored silk curtains, the face in the portrait seemed to have changed a bit. The expression looked different. There was a slight cruelty in the set of the mouth. It was truly a strange thing.
es: In the enormous Venetian lantern —a golden booty from some ducal gondola— that hung from the ceiling of the great oak-paneled hall, the lights of three burners still burned, resembling slender blue petals with a white fire edge. He extinguished them and, after throwing his cloak and hat onto the table, crossed the library towards the door of his bedroom, a spacious octagonal room on the ground floor that, given his recent passion for luxury, he had just had decorated to his taste, hanging curious Renaissance tapestries on the walls that had been found stored in a forgotten attic at Selby Royal. As he turned the door handle, his gaze fell upon the portrait painted by Basil Hallward. The surprise made him stop. Then he entered his room without losing the expression of perplexity. After removing the flower he wore in the buttonhole of his jacket, he seemed to hesitate. Finally, he returned to the library, approached the painting, and examined it closely. Illuminated by the scant light beginning to filter through the cream-colored silk blinds, it seemed to him that the face had changed slightly. The expression seemed different. It appeared that a touch of cruelty had emerged in the mouth. It was, without a doubt, something very strange.

en: He turned round and, walking to the window, drew up the blind. The bright dawn flooded the room and swept the fantastic shadows into dusky corners, where they lay shuddering. But the strange expression that he had noticed in the face of the portrait seemed to linger there, to be more intensified even. The quivering ardent sunlight showed him the lines of cruelty round the mouth as clearly as if he had been looking into a mirror after he had done some dreadful thing.
vi: He turned around, and, walking to the window, pulled up the curtain. The radiant dawn flooded into the room, sweeping the grotesque shadows into the dark corners where they lay trembling. But the strange feature he noticed on the face of the portrait seemed to linger there, even appearing more pronounced. The shimmering, scorching sunlight revealed the merciless wrinkles around the mouth as clearly as if he were looking into a mirror after doing something very bad.
tr: Dorian turned and went to the window, lifting the blind. The bright dawn light flooded the room, pushing the ghostly shadows into the corners, where they shivered and shrank, remaining there. However, the strange expression that Dorian thought he saw on the portrait's face remained, and it could even be said that it had become more pronounced. The trembling, exuberant sunlight showed Dorian the merciless lines at the corners of the mouth, as clear as if he were looking into a mirror after committing a terrible deed.
es: Turning around, he walked towards the window and lifted the blind. The glow of dawn flooded the room and swept the fantastic shadows into the dark corners, where they froze, trembling. But the strange expression that Dorian Gray had noticed on the face of the portrait remained, more intense if possible. The trembling and burning sunlight revealed the cruel folds around the mouth with the same clarity as if he had looked in a mirror after committing some abominable act.

en: He winced and, taking up from the table an oval glass framed in ivory Cupids, one of Lord Henry’s many presents to him, glanced hurriedly into its polished depths. No line like that warped his red lips. What did it mean?
vi: He drew back, and, picking up from the table an oval mirror framed with ivory Cupids, one of the many gifts Lord Henry had given him, hurriedly looked into its glossy depths. There was no wrinkle such as the one that had distorted his red lips. What did it mean?
tr: The young man flinched and blinked his eyes. He took an oval mirror surrounded by ivory Cupids, one of Lord Henry's numerous gifts, from the table and anxiously looked into its reflective depths. There was no such line that disfigured his red lips! What did this mean?
es: Trembling, he took from the table an oval mirror, framed by ivory cupids, one of the many gifts Lord Henry had given him, and cast a quick glance at its bright depths. No similar wrinkle had deformed his red lips. What did it mean?

en: He rubbed his eyes, and came close to the picture, and examined it again. There were no signs of any change when he looked into the actual painting, and yet there was no doubt that the whole expression had altered. It was not a mere fancy of his own. The thing was horribly apparent.
vi: He rubbed his eyes, approached the painting, and examined it closely. There were no signs of any repairs when he looked at the actual paint layer, yet it was certain that the entire expression had changed. It was not just his own imagination. That was terribly obvious.
tr: Dorian rubbed his eyes, moved closer, and examined the portrait again. There was no sign of any change when he looked at the picture, yet the entire expression of the face had unmistakably altered. It had not seemed so to him. The frightening change was visibly apparent.
es: After rubbing his eyes, he approached the painting and examined it again. There was no sign of change when he looked at the canvas, and yet, there was no doubt that the expression in the portrait was different. He had not imagined it. It was a horribly visible reality.

en: He threw himself into a chair and began to think. Suddenly there flashed across his mind what he had said in Basil Hallward’s studio the day the picture had been finished. Yes, he remembered it perfectly. He had uttered a mad wish that he himself might remain young, and the portrait grow old; that his own beauty might be untarnished, and the face on the canvas bear the burden of his passions and his sins; that the painted image might be seared with the lines of suffering and thought, and that he might keep all the delicate bloom and loveliness of his then just conscious boyhood. Surely his wish had not been fulfilled? Such things were impossible. It seemed monstrous even to think of them. And, yet, there was the picture before him, with the touch of cruelty in the mouth.
vi: He dropped himself into the chair and began to think. Suddenly, the words he had spoken in Basil Hallward's studio on the day the painting was completed flashed through his mind. Yes, he remembered them vividly. He had uttered a wild wish that he himself would remain young while the portrait aged; that his beauty would not fade, while the face on the canvas bore the burden of his passions and sins; that the painted image would wither with the lines of suffering and thought, while he retained all the freshness and charm of youth that he had just become conscious of at that time. Was it certain that his wish had not been fulfilled? Such things could not happen. Even thinking about them seemed bizarre. Yet, the painting was before him, with a cruel expression on its mouth.
tr: Dorian dropped himself into a chair and began to think. Suddenly, the words he had spoken in Basil Hallward's studio on the day the portrait was finished came to his mind. Yes, he remembered them clearly. He had made a wild wish that he might stay young while the portrait grew old; that his own beauty might never fade, and that the burden of his passions and sins might be borne by the face on the canvas; that the lines of thought and suffering might be etched onto that painted face while he kept the delicate freshness of his newly perceived youth. But that wish couldn't have come true, could it? Such things were impossible. Even thinking about it was irrational. Yet there was the picture before his eyes, with that cruel expression on its lips.
es: Letting himself fall onto a chair, he began to think. Suddenly, like a flash of lightning, he remembered what he had said in Basil Hallward's studio the day the painter finished the portrait. Yes; he remembered it perfectly. He had expressed a foolish wish: that the portrait would age and that he would remain young; that the perfection of his features would stay intact, and that the face on the canvas would bear the weight of his passions and his sins; that the painted image would show the wrinkles of suffering and contemplation, but that he would retain all the delicate brilliance and allure of an adolescence that had just become self-aware. It was not possible that his wish had been granted. Things like that didn't happen, they were impossible. It seemed monstrous even to think of it. And yet, there was the portrait, with a touch of cruelty in the mouth.

en: Cruelty! Had he been cruel? It was the girl’s fault, not his. He had dreamed of her as a great artist, had given his love to her because he had thought her great. Then she had disappointed him. She had been shallow and unworthy. And, yet, a feeling of infinite regret came over him, as he thought of her lying at his feet sobbing like a little child. He remembered with what callousness he had watched her. Why had he been made like that? Why had such a soul been given to him? But he had suffered also. During the three terrible hours that the play had lasted, he had lived centuries of pain, aeon upon aeon of torture. His life was well worth hers. She had marred him for a moment, if he had wounded her for an age. Besides, women were better suited to bear sorrow than men. They lived on their emotions. They only thought of their emotions. When they took lovers, it was merely to have some one with whom they could have scenes. Lord Henry had told him that, and Lord Henry knew what women were. Why should he trouble about Sibyl Vane? She was nothing to him now.
vi: Ruthless! Are you ruthless? It was the girl's fault, not yours. You dreamed of her as a great artist, offered your love to her because you thought she was great. Yet she bored you. She was shallow and unworthy. However, an immense sense of regret took over you when you thought of her lying at your feet, sobbing like a child. You remember how ruthlessly you observed her. Why were you made this way? Why was such a soul given to you? But you also suffered. Throughout the three terrible hours that the play lasted, you lived through centuries of pain, countless years of agony. Your life was as valuable as hers. She also ruined you for a moment, if you hurt her for a century. Besides, women are more accustomed to pain than men. They live by their emotions. They only think about their emotions. When they choose a lover, it's just to have someone to quarrel with. Lord Henry told you so, and Lord Henry knows what women are like. Why should you care about Sibyl Vane? She is nothing to you now.
tr: Is he cruel? Had he acted cruelly? The fault was with the girl, not him. He had imagined Sibyl as a great artist, and because he saw her as great, he had given her his love. Then the girl had disappointed him. She had behaved in a shallow manner unworthy of his love. Still, when he thought of the girl sobbing at his feet like a child, an endless feeling of regret arose within Dorian. He remembered how heartlessly he had watched her! Why was he created this way? Why was such a soul given to him? But he had suffered too. During those three terrible hours of the play, who knows how many centuries of agony, how many eternities of torment he had lived through. His own life was worth as much as hers. If he had wounded Sibyl for a while, Sibyl had also cast a shadow over his life for a moment. Besides, women were more prone to suffering than men. They thrived on their emotions. They only thought about their feelings. They took lovers just to have someone at hand, to share mutual experiences. Lord Henry had told him this, and Lord Henry knew what women were like. Why should Dorian trouble his sweet self over Sibyl Vane? The girl was now nothing in his eyes.
es: Cruelty! Had he been cruel? Sibyl was the one to blame, not him. He had dreamed of her as a great artist, and believing her to be great, he had given her his love. But Sibyl had disappointed him, proving to be superficial and unworthy. And yet, a feeling of infinite sorrow took hold of him, as he remembered her curled up at his feet, sobbing like a little girl. He recalled how indifferently he had watched her. Why had nature made him like this? Why had he been given a soul like that? But he had also suffered. During the three terrible hours of the performance, he had lived through centuries of pain, eternities of torture. His life was worth as much as Sibyl's. She had mistreated him, although Dorian had inflicted a lasting wound on her. Women, moreover, were better prepared for pain. They lived off their emotions. They only thought about their emotions. When they took a lover, they had no other goal than to have someone to make scenes with. Lord Henry had explained it to him, and Lord Henry knew how women were. What reason was there to worry about Sibyl Vane? She no longer meant anything to him.

en: But the picture? What was he to say of that? It held the secret of his life, and told his story. It had taught him to love his own beauty. Would it teach him to loathe his own soul? Would he ever look at it again?
vi: But what about the painting? What did you say about it? It holds the secret of your life, recounts your story. It taught you to love your own beauty. Did it teach you to hate your soul? Do you ever look at it again?
tr: Well, what about the painting? What should be said about the painting then? This portrait was hiding the secret of his life, telling his story. It had taught him to love his own beauty. Was it now going to teach him to loathe his own soul? Would Dorian be able to look at this painting again?
es: But, what about the portrait? What was he going to say about the portrait? Basil Hallward's canvas contained the secret of his life, it narrated his story. It had taught him to love his own beauty. Would it also teach him to loathe his own soul? Would he ever look at it again?

en: No; it was merely an illusion wrought on the troubled senses. The horrible night that he had passed had left phantoms behind it. Suddenly there had fallen upon his brain that tiny scarlet speck that makes men mad. The picture had not changed. It was folly to think so.
vi: No; it is merely an illusion crafted by chaotic sensations. The terrible night you experienced still leaves behind its ghosts. Suddenly, a tiny bright red spot dropped in your brain, still capable of driving a person mad. The painting remains unchanged. Thinking that is truly ridiculous.
tr: No, no; the issue was merely an illusion created by his tense nerves. The dreadful night he had experienced had left behind phantoms. Suddenly, that tiny red mole that drives people crazy had fallen into his mind. Otherwise, the portrait had not changed. Thinking this way was madness.
es: No; it was simply an illusion that took advantage of his disoriented senses. The horrible night past had spawned ghosts. Suddenly, that tiny scarlet spot that drives men mad had collapsed upon his brain. The scene had not changed. It was madness to think so.

en: Yet it was watching him, with its beautiful marred face and its cruel smile. Its bright hair gleamed in the early sunlight. Its blue eyes met his own. A sense of infinite pity, not for himself, but for the painted image of himself, came over him. It had altered already, and would alter more. Its gold would wither into grey. Its red and white roses would die. For every sin that he committed, a stain would fleck and wreck its fairness. But he would not sin. The picture, changed or unchanged, would be to him the visible emblem of conscience. He would resist temptation. He would not see Lord Henry any more—would not, at any rate, listen to those subtle poisonous theories that in Basil Hallward’s garden had first stirred within him the passion for impossible things. He would go back to Sibyl Vane, make her amends, marry her, try to love her again. Yes, it was his duty to do so. She must have suffered more than he had. Poor child! He had been selfish and cruel to her. The fascination that she had exercised over him would return. They would be happy together. His life with her would be beautiful and pure.
vi: However, it still observed him, with a beautiful face that had been marred and a cruel smile. Its radiant hair glowed in the early sunlight. Its blue eyes met his. An overwhelming sense of pity, not for him, but for the drawing of himself, consumed him. It had already transformed, and would continue to transform. Its golden hue would wither into gray. The red and white roses would die. For every sin he committed, a blemish would mar and spoil its beauty. But he would not sin. The painting, whether changed or unchanged, would still be a tangible symbol of his conscience. He would resist temptation. He would not see Lord Henry again — would not, in any case, listen to the insidious, poisonous theories that had first stirred in him a passion for the impossible in Basil Hallward's garden. He would return to Sibyl Vane, make amends to her, marry her, and try to love her again. Yes, that was his duty. She must have endured more suffering than he had. Poor girl! He had been selfish and cruel to her. The charm that she had once tormented him with would return. They would be happy together. His life with her would be beautiful and pure.
tr: But see, the portrait was watching him, with its beautiful, flawed face, with its cruel mouth. Its hair was shining in the early light of the morning, and its blue eyes were touching his. Dorian was filled with an infinite pity; not for himself, but for that painted image. The image had already undergone a change, and it would undergo more. Its golden hair would fade and turn gray. The red and white roses would wither. Every sin he committed would mar and ruin the beauty of the portrait with a stain. But no, Dorian would not sin. Whether the picture changed or not, it would be the visible symbol of his conscience. Dorian would not succumb to the devil. He would not meet with Lord Henry anymore. At least, he would close his ears to those insidious, poisonous ideas that had awakened passions for impossible things when he first heard them in Basil Hallward's garden.
