He would return to Sibyl Vane, make amends, marry her, and try to love her again. Yes, it was his duty to do these things. Sibyl must have suffered more than he had. Poor little child! Dorian had been selfish and had acted heartlessly towards her. The magic he found in her would surely return. They would be happy together. Dorian would lead a beautiful, pure life with her.
es: However, the portrait continued to gaze at him, with the beautiful face distorted by a cruel smile. Its hair shone, bright, under the morning sun. The blue eyes of the canvas were fixed on his own. An indescribable feeling of compassion overwhelmed him, but not for himself, rather for that painted image. It had already changed and would change even more. The gold would wither into gray. The roses, red and white, would die. For every sin he committed, a stain would come to soil and destroy its beauty. But he would not sin again. The painting, whether the same or different, would be the visible emblem of his conscience. He would resist temptation. He would never see Lord Henry again: at least, he would not listen to those subtly poisonous theories that, in Basil Hallward's garden, had first awakened in him the desire for impossible things. He would return to Sibyl Vane, ask her for forgiveness, marry her, and strive to love her again. Yes; it was his duty to do so. Surely she had suffered more than he had. Poor girl! How cruel and selfish he had been! The fascination she had once caused in him would be reborn. They would be happy together. His life with her would be beautiful and pure.

en: He got up from his chair and drew a large screen right in front of the portrait, shuddering as he glanced at it. “How horrible!” he murmured to himself, and he walked across to the window and opened it. When he stepped out on to the grass, he drew a deep breath. The fresh morning air seemed to drive away all his sombre passions. He thought only of Sibyl. A faint echo of his love came back to him. He repeated her name over and over again. The birds that were singing in the dew-drenched garden seemed to be telling the flowers about her.
vi: He stood up from the chair, pulled the large curtain right in front of the portrait, shuddering as he looked at it. “Horrifying!” he muttered to himself and walked over to the window, then opened it. When he stepped outside, onto the grass, he took a deep breath. The fresh morning air seemed to dispel all his gloomy passions. He thought only of Sibyl. A faint echo of love had returned to him. He repeated her name over and over. The birds singing in the dew-laden garden seemed to be telling the flowers about her.
tr: He stood up and drew a large screen right in front of the portrait. He shuddered when his eyes fell upon the painting. “How dreadful!” he murmured as he walked and opened the glass door. He took a deep breath as he stepped onto the grass. It was as if the fresh morning air had driven away all his dark feelings. Now he was thinking only of Sibyl. He felt as if he could hear a faint echo of his old love. He began to repeat Sibyl’s name. The birds singing in the dew-damp garden were singing Sibyl’s song to the flowers.
es: He got up from the chair and placed a large screen in front of the portrait, shuddering as he gazed at it. “What a horror!” he murmured, and, approaching the door that led to the garden, he opened it. As he stepped on the grass, he took a deep breath. The freshness of the morning air seemed to drive away all his dark passions. He thought only of Sibyl. A faint echo of the old love reappeared in his chest. He repeated her name many times. The birds singing in the dew-soaked garden seemed to speak of her to the flowers.

en: CHAPTER VIII.
vi: Chapter 8
tr: Eighth chapter
es: Chapter 8

en: It was long past noon when he awoke. His valet had crept several times on tiptoe into the room to see if he was stirring, and had wondered what made his young master sleep so late. Finally his bell sounded, and Victor came in softly with a cup of tea, and a pile of letters, on a small tray of old Sevres china, and drew back the olive-satin curtains, with their shimmering blue lining, that hung in front of the three tall windows.
vi: It was long past noon when he woke up. The servant had tiptoed into the room several times to see if he was awake yet, wondering what had caused his master to sleep so late. Finally, the bell rang, and Victor gently entered with a cup of tea, a stack of letters, on a small antique Sèvres porcelain tray, and drew back the olive satin curtains, lined with shimmering blue, hanging in front of the three tall windows.
tr: When Dorian woke up, it was already well past noon. His servant had tiptoed into the room several times to see if he had woken up, wondering why the young master was sleeping so late. Finally, the bell rang. Victor entered softly. On the antique Sèvres porcelain tray in his hand were a cup of tea and a stack of letters. He opened the olive-colored curtains lined with shimmering blue that covered the room's three tall windows.
es: It was past noon when he woke up. His valet had tiptoed into the room several times, wondering what could make his master sleep so late. Dorian finally rang the bell, and Victor appeared silently with a cup of tea and a pile of letters on a Sévres porcelain tray. Then he drew back the olive satin curtains, lined with iridescent blue, that covered the three tall windows of the alcove.

en: “Monsieur has well slept this morning,” he said, smiling.
vi: “You slept well this morning, sir,” he said, smiling.
tr: “Monsieur slept well this morning,” he said with a smile.
es: "The gentleman slept very well last night," he said, smiling.

en: “What o’clock is it, Victor?” asked Dorian Gray drowsily.
vi: "What time is it, Victor?" Dorian Gray asked, absent-mindedly.
tr: Dorian asked sleepily, "What time is it, Victor?"
es: —What time is it, Victor? —asked Dorian, still half asleep.

en: “One hour and a quarter, Monsieur.”
vi: “It’s one fifteen already, sir.”
tr: “An hour and a quarter, monsieur.”
es: —One fifteen, sir.

en: How late it was! He sat up, and having sipped some tea, turned over his letters. One of them was from Lord Henry, and had been brought by hand that morning. He hesitated for a moment, and then put it aside. The others he opened listlessly. They contained the usual collection of cards, invitations to dinner, tickets for private views, programmes of charity concerts, and the like that are showered on fashionable young men every morning during the season. There was a rather heavy bill for a chased silver Louis-Quinze toilet-set that he had not yet had the courage to send on to his guardians, who were extremely old-fashioned people and did not realize that we live in an age when unnecessary things are our only necessities; and there were several very courteously worded communications from Jermyn Street money-lenders offering to advance any sum of money at a moment’s notice and at the most reasonable rates of interest.
vi: It was really late! He sat up, and, after sipping some tea, turned to the letters. One of them was from Lord Henry, delivered by hand this morning. He hesitated for a moment, then set it aside. The other letters he opened indifferently. They included the usual collection of calling cards, dinner invitations, private exhibition tickets, charity concert programs, and the like, the things that are incessantly sent to fashionable young men every morning during the season. There was a rather hefty bill for a silver-gilt dressing set in the style of Louis XV, which he had not yet had the courage to send to his guardians, who were exceedingly old-fashioned and unaware that we live in an age where the unnecessary are our only necessities; there were also a few very politely presented notices from moneylenders on Jermyn Street offering to lend any amount of money immediately and at the most reasonable rates of interest.
tr: But it was already late, huh! Dorian sat up, took a few sips of tea, and then picked up his letters. One of them was from Lord Henry; it had been delivered by hand that morning. The young man hesitated for a moment, then put the letter aside. He opened the others reluctantly. As usual during the season, it was a pile consisting of calling cards, dinner invitations, private show tickets, and charity concert programs that rained down on the heads of young socialites. There was also a rather hefty bill for a silver Louis Quinze dressing set with embossed inlays, which he had not yet dared to forward to his guardians. His guardians were so narrow-minded that they couldn't understand that in this day and age, people only needed unnecessary things! There were also many letters written with great respect from pawnbrokers and moneylenders on Jermyn Street. They were offering Dorian as much money as he wanted, at the most favorable interest rates, whenever he desired.
es: How late it is already! He sat on the bed and, after taking a few sips of tea, attended to the mail. One of the letters was from Lord Henry, and it had been delivered by hand in the morning. Dorian hesitated for a moment and then ended up setting it aside. He opened the others absentmindedly. They contained the usual collection of cards, dinner invitations, tickets for private exhibitions, concert programs for charitable purposes, and other similar things that rain down every morning on young people of good society during the season. There was also a considerable bill for a set of Louis XV silver embossed grooming utensils, a bill that Dorian had not yet dared to forward to his guardians, extraordinarily old-fashioned people, incapable of understanding that we live in an age where certain unnecessary things are our only necessities; he also found several communications, written in very polite terms, from the moneylenders on Jermyn Street, offering to advance him any amount of money without bothersome delays and at very reasonable interest rates.

en: After about ten minutes he got up, and throwing on an elaborate dressing-gown of silk-embroidered cashmere wool, passed into the onyx-paved bathroom. The cool water refreshed him after his long sleep. He seemed to have forgotten all that he had gone through. A dim sense of having taken part in some strange tragedy came to him once or twice, but there was the unreality of a dream about it.
vi: About ten minutes later, he stood up, hastily put on a meticulously tailored cashmere coat embroidered with silk, and went into the agate-tiled bathroom. The cold water refreshed him after the long sleep. He seemed to have forgotten everything he had just gone through. A vague feeling of having participated in some strange tragedy came to him a few times, but there was something unreal about the dream of it.
tr: About ten minutes later, Dorian got out of bed, put on a luxurious kimono made of wool cashmere embroidered with silk, and went to the bathroom covered in veined black onyx. After the long sleep he had, the cool water refreshed him. It was as if he had forgotten all the troubles he had endured. Although a vague feeling of having played a role in a strange tragedy crossed his mind a few times, it had the baselessness of a dream.
es: After about ten minutes, Dorian got up and, throwing a luxurious Cashmere wool robe with silk embroidery over his shoulders, entered the bathroom with an onyx floor. The fresh water cleared him after many hours of sleep. He seemed to have forgotten what had happened the day before. A vague sensation of having participated in some strange tragedy crossed his mind once or twice, but with the unreality of a dream.

en: As soon as he was dressed, he went into the library and sat down to a light French breakfast that had been laid out for him on a small round table close to the open window. It was an exquisite day. The warm air seemed laden with spices. A bee flew in and buzzed round the blue-dragon bowl that, filled with sulphur-yellow roses, stood before him. He felt perfectly happy.
vi: Right after putting on his clothes, he went into the library and sat down to a light French breakfast that had been laid out for him on a small round table near the wide-open window. It was a beautiful day. The warm air seemed to be rich with flavor. A bee flew in, buzzing around the porcelain bowl decorated with blue dragons, filled with sulfur-yellow roses, placed in front of him. He felt extremely happy.
tr: As soon as Dorian dressed, he went to the library and had a light French-style breakfast at the small, round table set in front of the open glass door. It was a splendid day. The warm air seemed to be laden with spices. A bee flew in and buzzed around the vase with blue dragons, filled with sulfur-yellow roses, that stood in front of Dorian. Dorian felt pure happiness within him.
es: As soon as he had dressed, he entered the library and sat down to have a light French breakfast, served on a round table next to the open window. It was a wonderful day. The warm air seemed laden with spices. A bee flew in through the window and buzzed around the blue bowl with dragon motifs, filled with yellow roses, that he had in front of him. Dorian felt perfectly happy.

en: Suddenly his eye fell on the screen that he had placed in front of the portrait, and he started.
vi: Suddenly, his eyes noticed the shield he had placed in front of the portrait, and he was startled.
tr: When his eyes suddenly caught the screen placed in front of the portrait, the young man was startled.
es: Suddenly, his gaze fell upon the screen placed in front of the portrait, and he shuddered.

en: “Too cold for Monsieur?” asked his valet, putting an omelette on the table. “I shut the window?”
vi: "Are you too cold, sir?" the servant asked, placing the omelette on the table. "Shall I close the window?"
tr: As the boy placed an omelet on the table, he asked, "Did the weather feel chilly to Monsieur?" "I'm closing the window."
es: —Is the gentleman cold? —asked the valet, placing an omelet on the small table—. Shall I close the window?

en: Dorian shook his head. “I am not cold,” he murmured.
vi: Dorian shook his head. "I'm not cold," he muttered.
tr: Shaking his head, Dorian murmured, "I'm not cold."
es: Dorian shook his head. —I'm not cold —he murmured.

en: Was it all true? Had the portrait really changed? Or had it been simply his own imagination that had made him see a look of evil where there had been a look of joy? Surely a painted canvas could not alter? The thing was absurd. It would serve as a tale to tell Basil some day. It would make him smile.
vi: Is all of this really true? Did the portrait really change? Or was it just your own imagination that made you see the evil where there once was joy? Surely a painted canvas cannot change, right? This is really absurd. It could be used as a story to tell Basil someday. It would make him laugh.
tr: Were the memories real? Had the portrait truly undergone a change? Or was it merely his own imagination that led him to see an expression of treachery where once there had been an expression of pride? A painted canvas certainly couldn't change, could it? This was ridiculous. He now had a story he could tell Basil one day. Basil would smile when he heard it.
es: Was everything he remembered true? Had the portrait really changed? Or had his imagination made him see an evil expression where there was only a joyful gesture? It was impossible for a canvas to change. Absurd. It would be an excellent story to tell Basil someday. It would make him smile.

en: And, yet, how vivid was his recollection of the whole thing! First in the dim twilight, and then in the bright dawn, he had seen the touch of cruelty round the warped lips. He almost dreaded his valet leaving the room. He knew that when he was alone he would have to examine the portrait. He was afraid of certainty. When the coffee and cigarettes had been brought and the man turned to go, he felt a wild desire to tell him to remain. As the door was closing behind him, he called him back. The man stood waiting for his orders. Dorian looked at him for a moment. “I am not at home to any one, Victor,” he said with a sigh. The man bowed and retired.
vi: However, how vivid his memory of the whole incident was! At first, it was in the dim darkness, then in the bright dawn, he saw the cruel expression around the distorted lips. He was almost afraid of the servant leaving the room. He knew that at that moment he would be alone and perhaps he would check the portrait. He feared certainty. When the coffee and cigarettes had been brought in and the servant turned away, he felt a mad desire to tell him to stay. As the door was closing behind him, he called him back. The servant stood waiting for his orders. Dorian looked at him for a moment. “I am not at home, Victor, to anyone,” he said, with a sigh. The servant bowed and withdrew.
tr: On the other hand, how vivid was the memory of this event! First in the dimness of twilight, then in the bright dawn light, Dorian had seen the stone-hearted expression on those tense lips. Now the young man was almost terrified of his servant going outside. Because he knew that when he was alone, he wouldn't be able to resist examining the portrait. He was afraid of gaining definite knowledge. When the servant brought the coffee and cigarettes and was about to leave, Dorian was seized by a frantic desire to keep him. Just as the door was closing, he called the man back. The servant stopped, waiting for orders. Dorian looked at her. Then, sighing, he said, "Whoever calls, I'm not home, Victor." The man bent down, then withdrew.
es: However, how precise the memory was! First in the confusing twilight and then in the luminous dawn, he had seen the touch of cruelty in the contracted lips. He almost feared the moment when the servant would leave the library. He knew that when he was alone he would have to examine the portrait. He was afraid to face the certainty. When, after bringing the coffee and cigarettes, Victor turned to leave, Dorian felt an absurd desire to tell him to stay. As the door closed behind him, he called out to him. Victor stopped, waiting for instructions. Dorian stared at him for a few moments. —I'm not available for anyone —he said, accompanying the words with a sigh. Victor nodded and disappeared.

en: Then he rose from the table, lit a cigarette, and flung himself down on a luxuriously cushioned couch that stood facing the screen. The screen was an old one, of gilt Spanish leather, stamped and wrought with a rather florid Louis-Quatorze pattern. He scanned it curiously, wondering if ever before it had concealed the secret of a man’s life.
vi: Then he got up from the table, lit a cigarette, and let himself down onto the luxurious cushioned divan opposite the screen. The screen was an antique, made of gold-plated Spanish leather, embossed and crafted with a rather intricate design in the style of King Louis XV. He examined it curiously, wondering if it had ever concealed anyone's secrets before.
tr: Then Dorian got up from the table, lit a cigarette, and threw himself onto a sofa with plenty of cushions opposite the screen. The screen was very old, made of gilded Spanish leather, and adorned with a somewhat ostentatious Louis Quatorze pattern. As Dorian gazed at the screen curiously, he wondered if it had ever shielded the secret of a human life before.
es: Dorian then rose from the table, lit a cigarette, and let himself fall onto an extraordinarily comfortable divan situated in front of the screen. The screen was old, made of gilded Spanish leather, stamped with an overly florid Louis XIV design. Dorian examined it with curiosity, wondering if it had ever hidden the secret of a life.

en: Should he move it aside, after all? Why not let it stay there? What was the use of knowing? If the thing was true, it was terrible. If it was not true, why trouble about it? But what if, by some fate or deadlier chance, eyes other than his spied behind and saw the horrible change? What should he do if Basil Hallward came and asked to look at his own picture? Basil would be sure to do that. No; the thing had to be examined, and at once. Anything would be better than this dreadful state of doubt.
vi: In the end, should you move it over there? Why not just leave it there? What good is knowing? If it's true, then it's too terrible. If it isn't real, then why bother with it? But what if, due to fate or some fatal coincidence, eyes other than yours scrutinize it and see that terrible change? What would you do if Basil Hallward dropped by and demanded to see his painting? Basil would certainly do that. No; this thing must be checked again, immediately. Whatever happens, it would be better than this terrible state of suspicion.
tr: Should he pull the screen aside despite everything? But why not leave it where it is? What good would it do to know? If what he remembered was true, it was something terrifying. If it wasn't true, why upset himself? On the other hand, what if by some horrible coincidence, other eyes besides his own looked behind the screen and saw that dreadful change? What could Dorian do if Basil Hallward came and wanted to look at his own painting? Basil would certainly do this one day. No, no, the painting needed to be examined immediately, right now. It was preferable to this terrible tension caused by doubt.
es: Did he really have to put it away, after all? Why not leave it where it was? What was the use of knowing the truth? If it turned out to be true, it was terrible. If not, why worry? But, what if, by some fatality or an even more terrible chance, other eyes had looked behind the screen, witnessing the horrible change? What would he do if Basil Hallward showed up and asked to see the painting? It was certain that Basil would eventually do something like that. No; he had to examine the portrait, and do it immediately. Anything was better than that dreadful doubt.

en: He got up and locked both doors. At least he would be alone when he looked upon the mask of his shame. Then he drew the screen aside and saw himself face to face. It was perfectly true. The portrait had altered.
vi: He stood up and locked both doors. At least he would be alone when he looked at his shameful mask. Then he pulled the curtain aside and saw himself, face to face. It was true: the picture had changed.
tr: Dorian stood up and locked both doors. He had to be alone at least while looking at the mask of his shame. Dorian drew the screen and came face to face with himself. Everything was completely real: The portrait had changed.
es: He got up and locked the two doors. At least he would be alone while he contemplated the mask of his shame. Then he moved the screen and saw himself face to face. It was completely true. The portrait had changed.

en: As he often remembered afterwards, and always with no small wonder, he found himself at first gazing at the portrait with a feeling of almost scientific interest. That such a change should have taken place was incredible to him. And yet it was a fact. Was there some subtle affinity between the chemical atoms that shaped themselves into form and colour on the canvas and the soul that was within him? Could it be that what that soul thought, they realized?—that what it dreamed, they made true? Or was there some other, more terrible reason? He shuddered, and felt afraid, and, going back to the couch, lay there, gazing at the picture in sickened horror.
vi: As he often recalled later, and always with some surprise, he found himself initially gazing at the portrait with a sense of almost scientific fascination. Such a change occurring was something he found incredible. Yet it was the truth. Could there be some subtle affinity between the chemical atoms, which had arranged themselves into shape and color on the canvas, and his soul? Could it be that what his soul thought of would materialize? — and what it dreamed of would become reality? Or was there some other cause, more terrifying? He shuddered, feeling frightened, and, turning back to the couch, lay there, staring at the painting with a sickening dread.
tr: He scrutinized the portrait with an almost scientific interest. He would later recall this action with surprise. It was beyond his comprehension that such a transformation had taken place. Yet, the transformation was real, it existed, it was there. Was there a hidden connection between the chemical atoms that came together on the canvas to form color and shape and the soul within Dorian? Was it possible for those atoms to grasp the thoughts of this soul? Or was there another, more terrifying reason? The young man shuddered, frightened, and went back to the couch, lying down and fixing his eyes on the painting with a consuming horror.
es: As he would frequently recall later, and always with notable astonishment, he found himself looking at the portrait with a feeling that was almost of scientific curiosity. That such a change could have occurred seemed incredible to him. And yet, it was a fact. Was there some subtle affinity between the chemical atoms, which turned into form and color on the canvas, and the soul that inhabited the interior of his body? Could it be that what the soul thought, they made real? That they gave substance to what he dreamed? Or was there some other, more terrible reason? He shuddered, felt fear, and, returning to the divan, lay down on it, contemplating the portrait overwhelmed with horror.

en: One thing, however, he felt that it had done for him. It had made him conscious how unjust, how cruel, he had been to Sibyl Vane. It was not too late to make reparation for that. She could still be his wife. His unreal and selfish love would yield to some higher influence, would be transformed into some nobler passion, and the portrait that Basil Hallward had painted of him would be a guide to him through life, would be to him what holiness is to some, and conscience to others, and the fear of God to us all. There were opiates for remorse, drugs that could lull the moral sense to sleep. But here was a visible symbol of the degradation of sin. Here was an ever-present sign of the ruin men brought upon their souls.
vi: However, he felt that there was one thing it had done for him. It had made him realize how unjust and cruel he had been to Sibyl Vane. It was not too late to make amends for that. She could still become his wife. His unreal and selfish love would yield to some higher influence, would transform into some nobler passion, and the portrait that Basil Hallward had painted of him would be his guide throughout life, would become to him what sanctity has become to some, and conscience to others, and the fear of God to all of us. There are opiates for remorse in this world, drugs that can lull the moral sense to sleep. But this was a visible symbol of the degradation of sin. This was an ever-present sign of the ruin that men bring upon their souls.
tr: The young man shuddered, frightened, and went back to the couch, lying down and fixing his eyes on the painting with a consuming horror. Gene de bu işin ona bir yararı dokunduğunu düşünüyordu: Sibyl Vane’e ne kadar haksız ve acımasız davrandığını kafasına dank ettirmişti. Bu zalimliği onarmak için iş işten geçmiş değildi. Sibyl’le hâlâ evlenebilirdi. Gerçek olmayan ve bencil aşkı daha yüce bir ruh haline geçit verebilir, daha soylu bir tutkuya dönüşebilir; Basil Hallward’ın yapmış olduğu portre Dorian’a ömür boyu yol gösterebilirdi. Kimileri için sofuluk, kimileri için vicdan ve hepimiz için Tanrı korkusu neyse, bu resim de Dorian için o olabilirdi. Vicdan azabına karşı uyuşturucu maddeler vardı, ahlak duyusunu uykuya daldırtabilen ilaçlar... Ama işte şu karşıdaki, günahın alçaltıcı etkisinin gözle görülür bir simgesiydi. İnsanoğlunun kendi ruhunda yarattığı çöküşün elle tutulur bir göstergesi.
es: He understood, however, that the painting had done something for him. It had allowed him to understand how unjust, how cruel he had been to Sibyl Vane. It was not too late to make amends for that wrong. She could still be his wife. The selfish and unreal love he had felt would give way to a higher feeling, it would transform into a nobler passion, and the portrait painted by Basil Hallward would be his guide for life, it would be for him what sanctity is for some, conscience for others, and the fear of God for all. There were narcotics for remorse, drugs that silenced the moral sense and made it sleep. But there in front of him was a visible symbol of the degradation of sin. An incontestable proof of the ruin that men cause in their soul.

en: Three o’clock struck, and four, and the half-hour rang its double chime, but Dorian Gray did not stir. He was trying to gather up the scarlet threads of life and to weave them into a pattern; to find his way through the sanguine labyrinth of passion through which he was wandering. He did not know what to do, or what to think. Finally, he went over to the table and wrote a passionate letter to the girl he had loved, imploring her forgiveness and accusing himself of madness. He covered page after page with wild words of sorrow and wilder words of pain. There is a luxury in self-reproach. When we blame ourselves, we feel that no one else has a right to blame us. It is the confession, not the priest, that gives us absolution. When Dorian had finished the letter, he felt that he had been forgiven.
vi: The clock struck three, then four, then its half-hour double chime rang, but Dorian Gray still did not move. He was trying to gather the bright red threads of life, to weave them into a pattern; to find his way through the blood-red labyrinth of passion that he was wandering through. He did not know what to do, or what to think. Eventually, he approached the table, wrote a passionate letter to the girl he loved, begging for her forgiveness, and accusing himself of madness. He poured out page after page of wild words about sorrow, and even wilder words about pain. There was a luxurious pleasure in self-reproach. When we blame ourselves, we feel that no one else has the right to blame us. It is the confession, not the priest, that gives us absolution. When Dorian finished the letter, he felt that he had been forgiven.
tr: The clock struck three, then four, the double chimes of the half-hours were heard, but Dorian Gray did not move. He was trying to weave the crimson threads of life together to create a pattern, to find a way out of this blood-colored labyrinth of passion in which he wandered. He had no idea what to do or what to think. Finally, he sat down at the table and wrote a passionate letter to the girl he loved, asking for forgiveness and accusing himself of madness. He filled many pages one after another with words of sorrow and even more frenzied words expressing his pain. Self-reproach is a satisfying luxury. When we blame ourselves, it feels as if no one else has the right to blame us. It is the confession itself that purifies a person from sin, not the confessor priest. When Dorian finished the letter, he felt he had been forgiven.
es: The clock struck three in the afternoon, then four, and the half-hour chimed its double carillon, but Dorian Gray did not move. He tried to gather the scarlet threads of life and weave them following a pattern; to find a path, lost as he was in a labyrinth of unbridled passions. He did not know what to do, nor what to think. Finally, he returned to the table and wrote a fervent letter to the girl he had loved, imploring her forgiveness and accusing himself of madness. He filled sheet after sheet with tormented words of regret and even more pathetic ones of pain. There is a voluptuousness in self-reproach. When we blame ourselves, we feel that no one else has the right to do so. It is the confession, not the priest, that gives us absolution. When Dorian finished the letter, he felt that he had been forgiven.

en: Suddenly there came a knock to the door, and he heard Lord Henry’s voice outside. “My dear boy, I must see you. Let me in at once. I can’t bear your shutting yourself up like this.”
vi: Suddenly, there was a knock on the door, and he heard Lord Henry's voice outside. “My dear boy, I must see you. Let me in at once. I can't bear you shutting yourself up like this.”
tr: Suddenly, there was a knock on the door, Dorian heard Lord Henry's voice from outside: "My dear, I need to see you. Open this door at once. I can't stand you shutting yourself in like this."
es: Suddenly, there was a knock at the door, and he heard Lord Henry's voice outside. —Dorian, my friend. I must see you. Let me in right now. It is unacceptable for you to lock yourself up like this.

en: He made no answer at first, but remained quite still. The knocking still continued and grew louder. Yes, it was better to let Lord Henry in, and to explain to him the new life he was going to lead, to quarrel with him if it became necessary to quarrel, to part if parting was inevitable. He jumped up, drew the screen hastily across the picture, and unlocked the door.
vi: At first, he did not answer, but remained motionless. The knocking on the door continued, growing louder. Yes, it was better to let Lord Henry in, to explain to him about the new life he was about to live, to argue with him if an argument became necessary, to part ways if parting ways was unavoidable. He stood up abruptly, quickly drew the curtain across the painting, and unlocked the door.
tr: Dorian stood motionless, giving no response. The blows did not stop; they grew even more intense. Yes, it was better to let Lord Henry in, to tell him about the brand new life he was going to lead, to argue if necessary, and to part ways if separation became inevitable. Dorian jumped up and hurriedly pulled the screen in front of the painting, then unlocked the door.
es: At first, he did not respond, completely immobilized. But the knocks on the door continued, becoming more insistent. Yes, it was better to let Lord Henry in and explain the new life he had decided to lead, argue with him if necessary, distance himself from him if separation was inevitable. Jumping to his feet, he hurried to move the screen to hide the painting, and then proceeded to open the door.

en: “I am so sorry for it all, Dorian,” said Lord Henry as he entered. “But you must not think too much about it.”
vi: "I am very sorry about all of this," Lord Henry said, as he walked in. "But you shouldn't think too much about it."
tr: Lord Henry entered, saying, "I am very sorry about what happened, Dorian." "But don't worry too much about it."
es: —I am very sorry for everything that has happened, Dorian —said Lord Henry as he entered—. But you must not think too much about it.

en: “Do you mean about Sibyl Vane?” asked the lad.
vi: “Are you referring to Sibyl Vane?” the young man asked.
tr: The child asked, "Do you mean the matter of Sibyl Vane?"
es: —Are you referring to Sibyl Vane? —asked the young man.

en: “Yes, of course,” answered Lord Henry, sinking into a chair and slowly pulling off his yellow gloves. “It is dreadful, from one point of view, but it was not your fault. Tell me, did you go behind and see her, after the play was over?”
vi: “Yes, of course,” Lord Henry replied, lowering himself into a chair and slowly removing his yellow gloves. “It's terrible, in a way, but it's not your fault. Tell me, did you go backstage and see her after the play ended?”
tr: Lord Henry, "Yes, of course," he said, sinking into a chair and slowly starting to remove his yellow gloves. "It's a terrible thing in a way, but it wasn't your fault. Tell me, did you go backstage and see her after the play was over?"
es: —Yes, of course —replied Lord Henry, dropping into a chair and slowly removing his yellow gloves—. It is horrible, from a certain point of view, but it is not your fault. Tell me, did you go to see her after the play was over?

en: “Yes.”
vi: “Yes.”
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “I felt sure you had. Did you make a scene with her?”
vi: “I'm sure you went. Did you have a quarrel with her?”
tr: “I had guessed it would be like this too. Did you fight with him?”
es: —I was convinced that it had been that way. Did you make a scene?

en: “I was brutal, Harry—perfectly brutal. But it is all right now. I am not sorry for anything that has happened. It has taught me to know myself better.”
vi: "I was really rough, Harry — extremely rough. But now everything is fine. I don't regret anything that happened. It taught me to understand myself better."
tr: “Like an animal, Harry, literally like an animal. But everything is fine now. I'm very sorry for what happened. It taught me to know myself much better.”
es: —I was brutal, Harry, terribly brutal. But now everything is resolved. I don't regret what happened. It has taught me to know myself better.

en: “Ah, Dorian, I am so glad you take it in that way! I was afraid I would find you plunged in remorse and tearing that nice curly hair of yours.”
vi: "Oh, Dorian, I am so glad you are taking this in such a way! I was afraid I would see you drowning in regret and tearing out that beautiful curly hair of yours."
tr: "Dorian, I'm so glad you're approaching the matter this way! I thought I would find you buried in guilt, tearing out those lovely curly locks of yours."
es: —Ah, Dorian, how glad I am that you are taking it this way! I feared finding you sunk in remorse and tearing at that lovely hair of yours.

en: “I have got through all that,” said Dorian, shaking his head and smiling. “I am perfectly happy now. I know what conscience is, to begin with. It is not what you told me it was. It is the divinest thing in us. Don’t sneer at it, Harry, any more—at least not before me. I want to be good. I can’t bear the idea of my soul being hideous.”
vi: "I have overcome all that," Dorian said, shaking his head and smiling. "At this moment, I am extremely happy. First of all, I have learned what a conscience is. It is not what you told me it was. It is the most sacred thing within us. Do not mock it, Harry, any further — at least not in front of me. I want to be a good person. I cannot bear the thought that my soul will become loathsome."
tr: Dorian shook his head, smiling, "I have overcome all of them." "Now I am truly happy. Let me say first that I now know what conscience is. It is not what you said. It is the most divine part of our being. Don't sneer, Harry; at least not in my presence. I want to be a good person. I cannot bear my soul becoming ugly and horrible."
es: —I have overcome all that —said Dorian, shaking his head and smiling—. Now I am completely happy. I know what conscience is, to begin with. It is not what you told me it was. It is the most divine thing within us. Do not mock, Harry, do not do it again..., at least, not in front of me. I want to be good. I cannot bear the idea of the ugliness of my soul.

en: “A very charming artistic basis for ethics, Dorian! I congratulate you on it. But how are you going to begin?”
vi: "A very graceful foundation of art for ethics, Dorian! I congratulate you on that." "But how are you going to start?"
tr: “Dorian, what a delightful and artistic basis for ethics this is! Congratulations for thinking of it. So, how will you start this?”
es: —A charming artistic basis for ethics, Dorian! I congratulate you on that. But how do you propose to start?

en: “By marrying Sibyl Vane.”
vi: “By marrying Sibyl Vane.” "Marry Sibyl Vane!"
tr: “By marrying Sibyl Vane.”
es: —Marrying Sibyl Vane. —Marrying Sibyl Vane!

en: “Marrying Sibyl Vane!” cried Lord Henry, standing up and looking at him in perplexed amazement. “But, my dear Dorian—”
vi: Lord Henry exclaimed, standing up, looking at him in astonishment and confusion. "But, my dear Dorian..."
tr: “Marrying Sibyl Vane?” said Lord Henry, jumping up from his seat and staring at the boy in astonishment as if he hadn't understood what he had just heard. “Yes, Harry, I know what you're going to say.
es: —exclaimed Lord Henry, standing up and looking at him with infinite astonishment—. But, my dear Dorian...

en: “Yes, Harry, I know what you are going to say. Something dreadful about marriage. Don’t say it. Don’t ever say things of that kind to me again. Two days ago I asked Sibyl to marry me. I am not going to break my word to her. She is to be my wife.”
vi: “Yes, Harry, I know what you're about to say. Something terrible about marriage. Don't say it. Never say things like that to me again. Two days ago I proposed to Sibyl. I will not break my promise to her. She will be my wife!”
tr: “Yes, Harry, I know what you're going to say. Marriage is something that ruins everything! Don't say it. Never say such things to me again. Two days ago, I asked Sibyl Vane to marry me. I will not go back on my word. She will be my wife.”
es: —Yes, Harry, I know what you're going to tell me. Something terrible about marriage. Don't say it. Don't tell me things like that again. Two days ago I asked Sibyl to marry me. I'm not going to break my word. She will be my wife!

en: “Your wife! Dorian! ... Didn’t you get my letter? I wrote to you this morning, and sent the note down by my own man.”
vi: "Your wife! Dorian!..." "Did you receive my letter?" "I wrote to you this morning and sent it down with my man."
tr: “Is it you! Dorian!.. Didn't you get my letter? I wrote it this morning and sent it with my own man.”
es: —Your wife...? Haven't you received my letter? I wrote to you this morning, and I sent the note with my servant.

en: “Your letter? Oh, yes, I remember. I have not read it yet, Harry. I was afraid there might be something in it that I wouldn’t like. You cut life to pieces with your epigrams.”
vi: “Your letter? Ah, yes, I remember now. I haven't read it yet, Harry. I'm afraid there might be something in it that I don't like. You dissect life with your satirical maxims.”
tr: “Your letter? Oh yes! I hadn't read it yet, Harry. I was afraid you might have written something I wouldn't like. You always dissect life bit by bit with your aphorisms.”
es: —Your letter? Ah, yes, now I remember. I haven't read it yet, Harry. I was afraid there might be something in it that would upset me. You cut life into pieces with your epigrams.

en: “You know nothing then?”
vi: "So you don't know anything yet?"
tr: “So, you don't know anything at all?”
es: —So, you don't know anything?

en: “What do you mean?”
vi: “What do you mean?”
tr: "What do you mean?"
es: —What do you mean?

en: Lord Henry walked across the room, and sitting down by Dorian Gray, took both his hands in his own and held them tightly. “Dorian,” he said, “my letter—don’t be frightened—was to tell you that Sibyl Vane is dead.”
vi: Lord Henry walked across the room, and, sitting down beside Dorian Gray, took both of his hands in his own, holding them tightly. “Dorian,” he said, “my letter — don't be alarmed — is to tell you that Sibyl Vane is dead.”
tr: Lord Henry came, sat down beside Dorian, and took both of his hands in his own, holding them tightly. “Dorian,” he said. “In my letter... don't be afraid... I informed you of Sibyl Vane’s death.”
es: Lord Henry crossed the room and, sitting down next to Dorian Gray, took both his hands, squeezing them tightly. —Dorian... —he said—, my letter..., don't be frightened..., it was to tell you that Sibyl Vane has died.

en: A cry of pain broke from the lad’s lips, and he leaped to his feet, tearing his hands away from Lord Henry’s grasp. “Dead! Sibyl dead! It is not true! It is a horrible lie! How dare you say it?”
vi: A cry of pain broke from the young man's lips, he stood up abruptly, pulling his hand away from Lord Henry's grasp. “Dead! Sibyl dead! No, that's a terrible lie! How dare you say that?”
tr: Dorian leapt to his feet with a bitter cry escaping his lips, pulling his hands away from Lord Henry's grasp. “Death! Sibyl is dead? That can't be true! It's a filthy lie! How dare you say such a thing?”
es: A cry of pain escaped from the boy's lips, who stood up abruptly, freeing his hands from Lord Henry's grip. —Dead! Sibyl dead! It’s not true! It’s a dreadful lie! How dare you say such a thing?

en: “It is quite true, Dorian,” said Lord Henry, gravely. “It is in all the morning papers. I wrote down to you to ask you not to see any one till I came. There will have to be an inquest, of course, and you must not be mixed up in it. Things like that make a man fashionable in Paris. But in London people are so prejudiced. Here, one should never make one’s début with a scandal. One should reserve that to give an interest to one’s old age. I suppose they don’t know your name at the theatre? If they don’t, it is all right. Did any one see you going round to her room? That is an important point.”
vi: "Really, Dorian," Lord Henry said, solemnly. "The news is in every morning paper. I wrote to you to ask you not to meet anyone before I arrive. There will have to be an investigation, of course, and you shouldn't be involved in it. Such matters make one fashionable in Paris. But in London, people are too prejudiced. Here, one shouldn't enter life with a scandal. We should save it to draw attention to our old age. I suppose they don't know your name at the theater? If they don't, then it's all right. Did anyone see you going around to her room? That is the crucial point."
tr: Lord Henry said with a serious tone, "That's right, Dorian," he said. "All the morning newspapers are writing about it. I wrote to you so that you wouldn't see anyone until I arrived. There will inevitably be an investigation, but you must not get involved. Such things make a person sought after in Paris. However, the people of London are so narrow-minded! It's not good to take your first step into society here with a scandal. You should save the scandals and use them to be interesting in your old age. I suppose the people at the theater don't know your name, do they? If they don't, there's no problem. Did anyone see you go to his room? This point is very important."
es: —It is completely true, Dorian —said Lord Henry, with great seriousness—. You will find it in all the morning newspapers. I wrote to you to ask you not to receive anyone until I arrived. There will be an investigation, of course, but you must not get involved in it. In Paris, things like that make a man fashionable. But in London, people have many prejudices. Here it is unthinkable to debut with a scandal. That must be reserved to add interest to old age. I imagine that in the theater they don't know your name. If that is the case, there is no problem. Did anyone see you heading towards her dressing room? That is important.

en: Dorian did not answer for a few moments. He was dazed with horror. Finally he stammered, in a stifled voice, “Harry, did you say an inquest? What did you mean by that? Did Sibyl—? Oh, Harry, I can’t bear it! But be quick. Tell me everything at once.”
vi: Dorian did not respond for a moment. He was stunned with fear. Finally, he stammered in a choked voice, "Harry, did you say an investigation? What do you mean by that? Is it Sibyl...? Oh, Harry, I can't bear it! But hurry up. Tell me everything at once."
tr: Dorian did not respond for a while. He was stunned with horror. Finally, in a hoarse voice, he stammered, “Harry,” “Did you say an inquiry? What do you mean by that? Or is it Sibyl?.. Oh, Harry, I can't stand it! Hurry up. Tell me everything, right now.”
es: Dorian took a few moments to answer. He was stunned by the horror. —Have you spoken about an investigation? —he finally stammered with a choked voice—. What do you mean by that? Has Sibyl...? It's more than I can bear, Harry! But speak quickly. Tell me everything immediately.

en: “I have no doubt it was not an accident, Dorian, though it must be put in that way to the public. It seems that as she was leaving the theatre with her mother, about half-past twelve or so, she said she had forgotten something upstairs. They waited some time for her, but she did not come down again. They ultimately found her lying dead on the floor of her dressing-room. She had swallowed something by mistake, some dreadful thing they use at theatres. I don’t know what it was, but it had either prussic acid or white lead in it. I should fancy it was prussic acid, as she seems to have died instantaneously.”
vi: “I am certain it was not an accident, Dorian, although it had to be presented to the public that way. It seems that while she was leaving the theater with her mother, around half past twelve, she said she had forgotten something upstairs. They waited for her for a while, but she did not come back down. Eventually, they found her lying dead on the floor of her dressing room. She had accidentally ingested something, some terrible substance that they use in theaters. I don't know what it was, but it had either hydrocyanic acid or white lead in it. I assume it was hydrocyanic acid, because she seemed to have died instantly.”
tr: "I have no doubt that the death was not an accident, Dorian; however, she told everyone while leaving the theater that she had forgotten something upstairs. They waited for a while, but she didn't come down. Then they found her in the dressing room, lying on the floor, lifeless. She accidentally swallowed something, something terrible used in the theater. I don't know what it was, but it contained either prussic acid or white lead, which caused the poor girl to die immediately."
es: —I am convinced that it was not an accident, although we need to make the public opinion see it that way. It seems that when she was leaving the theater with her mother, around half past twelve or so, she said she had forgotten something upstairs. They waited for her for some time, but she did not return. Finally, they found her dead, lying on the floor of her dressing room. She had swallowed something by mistake, some terrible thing they use in theaters. I don't know what it was, but it had prussic acid or lead carbonate. I imagine it was prussic acid, because she seems to have died instantly.

en: “Harry, Harry, it is terrible!” cried the lad.
vi: “Harry, Harry, it's terrible!” the young man exclaimed.
tr: The young man shouted, "Harry, Harry, this is horrible!"
es: —What an atrocious thing, Harry! —exclaimed the young man.

en: “Yes; it is very tragic, of course, but you must not get yourself mixed up in it. I see by The Standard that she was seventeen. I should have thought she was almost younger than that. She looked such a child, and seemed to know so little about acting. Dorian, you mustn’t let this thing get on your nerves. You must come and dine with me, and afterwards we will look in at the opera. It is a Patti night, and everybody will be there. You can come to my sister’s box. She has got some smart women with her.”
vi: "Yes; this matter is very tragic, of course, but you must not let yourself get involved in it. I saw in The Standard that she was seventeen years old. I thought she was younger than that. She looked like a child, and seemed to know very little about acting. Dorian, you must not let this get into your head. You must have dinner with me, and then we will drop by the opera house. Tonight is Patti's night, and everyone will be there. You can come to my sister's box. She is going with a few well-dressed ladies."
tr: "Yes, yes, it's a very tragic thing, you shouldn't get involved in this. According to what I read in the Standard, he was seventeen years old. If you asked me, I would have said he was even younger. He looked so childish, so ignorant about acting! Dorian, don't let this upset your nerves. Come, have dinner with me, and then we can check out the opera. It's Patti's night tonight, which means everyone will be there. You can come to my sister's box. There will be very modern ladies with you."
es: —Yes, truly tragic, of course, but you must not get involved in it. I saw in the Standard that she was seventeen years old. I would have thought her even younger. She had such a childlike appearance and seemed like such an inexperienced actress! Dorian, you must not let this matter upset your nerves. You will dine with me and then we will go to the opera. Patti is singing tonight and everyone will be there. You can come to my sister's box. She will be there with some very elegant friends.

en: “So I have murdered Sibyl Vane,” said Dorian Gray, half to himself, “murdered her as surely as if I had cut her little throat with a knife. Yet the roses are not less lovely for all that. The birds sing just as happily in my garden. And to-night I am to dine with you, and then go on to the opera, and sup somewhere, I suppose, afterwards. How extraordinarily dramatic life is! If I had read all this in a book, Harry, I think I would have wept over it. Somehow, now that it has happened actually, and to me, it seems far too wonderful for tears. Here is the first passionate love-letter I have ever written in my life. Strange, that my first passionate love-letter should have been addressed to a dead girl. Can they feel, I wonder, those white silent people we call the dead? Sibyl! Can she feel, or know, or listen? Oh, Harry, how I loved her once! It seems years ago to me now. She was everything to me. Then came that dreadful night—was it really only last night?—when she played so badly, and my heart almost broke. She explained it all to me. It was terribly pathetic. But I was not moved a bit. I thought her shallow. Suddenly something happened that made me afraid. I can’t tell you what it was, but it was terrible. I said I would go back to her. I felt I had done wrong. And now she is dead. My God! My God! Harry, what shall I do? You don’t know the danger I am in, and there is nothing to keep me straight. She would have done that for me. She had no right to kill herself. It was selfish of her.”
vi: “So I have murdered Sibyl Vane,” Dorian Gray said, somewhat to himself — “murdered her as surely as if I had cut her little throat with a knife. Yet the roses are not less lovely for all that. The birds sing just as happily in my garden. And tonight I am dining with you, then going to the opera, and I suppose, afterwards, we will go somewhere for supper. How extraordinarily dramatic life is! If I had read all this in a book, Harry, I think I would have wept over it. Somehow, now that it has actually happened, and to me, it seems too strange for tears. This is the first passionate love letter I have ever written in my life. Strangely enough, my first passionate love letter was addressed to a dead girl. Can they feel, I wonder, those silent, white people we call the dead? Sibyl! Can she feel, or understand, or listen? Oh, Harry, how I loved her once! It seems years ago now. She was everything to me. Then came that dreadful night — was it really only last night? — when she played so badly, and my heart almost broke. She explained it all to me. It was really pathetic. But I was not moved a bit. I thought her shallow. Suddenly something happened that made me afraid. I cannot tell you what it was, but it was terrible. I said I would go back to her. I felt I had done wrong. And now she is dead. God! God! Harry, what am I to do? You don’t know the danger I am in, and there is nothing to keep me straight. She would have done that for me. She had no right to kill herself. It was selfish of her.”
tr: Dorian, somewhat to himself, said, "So I killed Sibyl Vane.""I killed her as surely as if I had cut her little throat with a knife.""Yet the beauty of the roses has not lessened because I killed her.""The birds are singing in my garden just as happily.""And tonight, I will dine with you and go to the opera, and then we will probably have supper somewhere. ""How dramatic life is!""Harry, if I had read all this in a book, I would undoubtedly have cried."" But now that it has actually happened, everything seems so extraordinary that I cannot shed a tear." "Look, here is the first passionate love letter I have ever written. " "How strange that my first passionate love letter is written to a dead girl!""Do they have feelings, those silent, white beings we call the dead?""Oh, Sibyl! Can she feel, can she know, can she listen?""Oh, Harry, how I loved her once!" "It feels like it was years ago now.""She was everything to me.""Then that terrible night happened...""Was it really last night...""Sibyl acted very badly, and my heart was almost shattered. ""Sibyl told me everything." "It was extremely touching, but it did not move my heart at all.""I found her shallow.""Then suddenly something happened that frightened me.""I cannot tell you what it was, but it was terrible.""I decided to go back to Sibyl.""I thought I had wronged her.""And now she is dead.""Oh, God, great God! Harry, what am I going to do now?""You don't know how much danger I am in; there is no one to keep me on the right path.""She would have done that for me.""She had no right to kill herself.""She was very selfish indeed.""
es: —So I have murdered Sibyl Vane —said Dorian Gray, speaking half to himself—; as if I had cut her throat with a knife. But the roses are no less beautiful for it. Nor do the birds sing with less joy in my garden. And tonight I will dine with you, and then we will go to the opera and I suppose we will end the evening somewhere else. How extraordinarily dramatic life is! If I had read all this in a book, Harry, I think it would have made me cry. However, now that it has really happened, and that it has happened to me, it seems too marvelous to shed tears over. Here is the first passionate love letter I have ever written in my life. It is very strange that my first love letter is addressed to a dead girl. Do those white silent beings we call the dead have feelings, I wonder? Can Sibyl feel, understand, or hear? Ah, Harry, how I loved her just a short while ago! But now it seems like years have passed. She was everything to me. Then came that horrible night, was it yesterday?, when she acted so dreadfully bad and my heart almost broke. She explained everything to me. It was terribly pathetic. But it did not move me in the least. She seemed a superficial person to me. Although something has happened since that has frightened me. I can't tell you what, but it has been terrible. And I decided to go back to Sibyl. I realized that I had treated her badly. And now she is dead. Good heavens, Harry! What am I going to do? You don't know what danger I am in, and there is nothing that can keep me on the right path. Sibyl would have managed it. She had no right to take her own life. She has behaved in a very selfish manner.

en: “My dear Dorian,” answered Lord Henry, taking a cigarette from his case and producing a gold-latten matchbox, “the only way a woman can ever reform a man is by boring him so completely that he loses all possible interest in life. If you had married this girl, you would have been wretched. Of course, you would have treated her kindly. One can always be kind to people about whom one cares nothing. But she would have soon found out that you were absolutely indifferent to her. And when a woman finds that out about her husband, she either becomes dreadfully dowdy, or wears very smart bonnets that some other woman’s husband has to pay for. I say nothing about the social mistake, which would have been abject—which, of course, I would not have allowed—but I assure you that in any case the whole thing would have been an absolute failure.”
vi: “My dear Dorian,” Lord Henry replied, taking a cigarette from the box and holding out a gold-leaf matchbox, “the only way women have ever reformed men is by boring them so completely that they lose all possible interest in life. If you marry this girl, you will be miserable. Of course, you will treat her kindly. We are always kind to those we care nothing about. But she will soon discover that you are absolutely indifferent to her. And when a woman finds that out about her husband, she either becomes terribly dowdy, or wears very chic hats that another woman's husband has to pay for. I am not even speaking of the social mistake, which would probably be disgraceful, and, of course, I would not allow it to happen, but I assure you that in any case, the whole affair will be an absolute failure.”
tr: Lord Henry took a cigarette from the table, pulled out a gold-plated matchbox, and said, "My dear Dorian." "There is only one way for a woman to reform a man: She bores him so much that he becomes utterly disenchanted with life. If you had married this girl, you would have been terribly unhappy. You would have taken good care of her, naturally. Yet she would soon realize that you were completely indifferent to her. When women learn of their husband's indifference, they either become utterly neglected and unkempt or start parading around in very chic hats that another woman has made her husband notice. I'm not even mentioning the social mistake of such a marriage. I would never have allowed such a thing, of course, but believe me, this would not have worked out in any way."
es: —My dear Dorian —replied Lord Henry, taking a cigarette from his cigarette case and then a gold-plated matchbox—, the only way for a woman to reform a man is by boring him so completely that he loses all interest in life. If you had married that girl, you would have been very unhappy. Of course, you would have treated her kindly. One can always be kind to people one doesn't care about at all. But she would have soon discovered that you only felt indifference towards her. And when a woman discovers that about her husband, she either starts dressing very poorly or wears very elegant hats that another woman's husband has to pay for. And I'm not talking about the social faux pas, which would have been regrettable, and which, of course, I would not have allowed, but I assure you that, in any case, the matter would have been a failure from start to finish.

en: “I suppose it would,” muttered the lad, walking up and down the room and looking horribly pale. “But I thought it was my duty. It is not my fault that this terrible tragedy has prevented my doing what was right. I remember your saying once that there is a fatality about good resolutions—that they are always made too late. Mine certainly were.”
vi: “I suppose it really will be like that,” the young man muttered, pacing back and forth in the room, and looking terribly pale. “But I think it is my duty. It's not my fault if this terrible tragedy prevents me from doing what is right. I remember you once said that there is always a bad fate with kind decisions — that they are always made too late. Mine must be the same.”
tr: The child said, "It probably wouldn't have worked." He was pacing up and down the room; his face was terribly pale. "But I considered this my duty. If this terrible tragedy prevented me from doing what I believed was right, it's not my fault. I remember you once said that there is a curse in good intentions, they always come too late. My good intention indeed came too late."
es: —I suppose so —murmured the boy, pacing around the room, horribly pale—. But I thought it was my duty. It is not my fault that this dreadful tragedy prevents me from acting correctly. I remember you once said that there is a fatality tied to good resolutions, and that is they always come too late. Mine certainly do.

en: “Good resolutions are useless attempts to interfere with scientific laws. Their origin is pure vanity. Their result is absolutely nil. They give us, now and then, some of those luxurious sterile emotions that have a certain charm for the weak. That is all that can be said for them. They are simply cheques that men draw on a bank where they have no account.”
vi: “Kind decisions are futile attempts to obstruct the laws of science. Their root cause is pure arrogance. Their result is absolute zero. They give us, from time to time, a few barren luxurious emotions that still hold a certain appeal to the weak. That is all that can be said about them. They are merely checks drawn on a bank where one has no account.”
tr: “Good intentions are futile attempts to interfere with scientific rules. Their starting point is pure arrogance, and their results amount to a big zero. From time to time, they allow us to experience the luxury of some barren yet pleasurable emotions, which can be quite appealing to weak individuals. This is the only positive thing that can be said about good intentions. Good intentions are nothing more than a check written on an account at a bank where people have not deposited any money.”
es: —Good resolutions are futile attempts to modify scientific laws. They have no other origin than vanity. And the result is absolutely null. From time to time they provide us with some of those sumptuous sterile emotions that have a certain charm for the weak. That is the best that can be said of them. They are checks that must be cashed from an account with no funds.

en: “Harry,” cried Dorian Gray, coming over and sitting down beside him, “why is it that I cannot feel this tragedy as much as I want to? I don’t think I am heartless. Do you?”
vi: "Harry," Dorian Gray exclaimed, approaching and sitting down beside him, "why can't I feel this tragedy as much as I want to? I don't think I'm heartless. What do you think?"
tr: Dorian Gray said, "Harry," as he sat down next to his friend. "Why can't I feel this tragedy as deeply as I want? Yet, I don't think I am stone-hearted. Do you think I am?"
es: —Harry —exclaimed Dorian Gray, approaching and sitting next to him—, why don't I feel this tragedy with the intensity I would like? I don't think I lack heart. What do you think?

en: “You have done too many foolish things during the last fortnight to be entitled to give yourself that name, Dorian,” answered Lord Henry with his sweet melancholy smile.
vi: "You have done too many foolish things over the past two weeks to have the right to call yourself that, Dorian," Lord Henry replied, with his sweet, melancholic smile.
tr: Lord Henry replied with that sweet, melancholy smile, "Dorian, you have done such foolish things in the last ten or fifteen days that I don't think you have the right to attribute this title to yourself."
es: —You have done too many foolish things over the last fortnight to be accused of that, Dorian —replied Lord Henry, with his sweet, melancholic smile.

en: The lad frowned. “I don’t like that explanation, Harry,” he rejoined, “but I am glad you don’t think I am heartless. I am nothing of the kind. I know I am not. And yet I must admit that this thing that has happened does not affect me as it should. It seems to me to be simply like a wonderful ending to a wonderful play. It has all the terrible beauty of a Greek tragedy, a tragedy in which I took a great part, but by which I have not been wounded.”
vi: The young man frowned. “I don't like that explanation, Harry,” he replied, “but I'm glad you don't think I'm heartless. I'm not that kind of person. I know I'm not. However, I must admit that what happened didn't affect me as it should have. It seemed to me like just a wonderful ending to a wonderful play. It had all the terrible beauty of a Greek tragedy, a tragedy in which I played a great role, yet I wasn't hurt by it.”
tr: Dorian frowned. “I don't like this explanation, Harry. Still, I'm glad you don't find me heartless. I'm not heartless at all. I know that. Yet I must admit that this event doesn't affect me as it should. In short, it feels like a wonderful scene, like the perfect ending of a play. It has the eerie beauty of an ancient Greek tragedy. It's as if I played a major role in this tragedy, but came out unscathed.”
es: The boy frowned. —I don't like that explanation, Harry —he replied—, but I'm glad you don't judge me as heartless. It's not true. I know I have one. And yet I must admit that what has happened does not affect me as it should. It simply seems to me a wonderful ending to a marvelous play. It has the terrible beauty of a Greek tragedy, a tragedy in which I played a very prominent role, but which has left me unscathed.

en: “It is an interesting question,” said Lord Henry, who found an exquisite pleasure in playing on the lad’s unconscious egotism, “an extremely interesting question. I fancy that the true explanation is this: It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of sheer brute force, and we revolt against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy that possesses artistic elements of beauty crosses our lives. If these elements of beauty are real, the whole thing simply appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather we are both. We watch ourselves, and the mere wonder of the spectacle enthralls us. In the present case, what is it that has really happened? Some one has killed herself for love of you. I wish that I had ever had such an experience. It would have made me in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me—there have not been very many, but there have been some—have always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they to care for me. They have become stout and tedious, and when I meet them, they go in at once for reminiscences. That awful memory of woman! What a fearful thing it is! And what an utter intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colour of life, but one should never remember its details. Details are always vulgar.”
vi: “That is an interesting question,” Lord Henry said, finding a refined pleasure in playing with the unconscious selfishness of the young man — “a very interesting question. I think the correct explanation is this. It often happens that the real tragedies in life occur in such an anti-artistic manner that they hurt us with their brutal aggression, absolute disjointedness, absurd senselessness, and lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of absolute malicious power, and we resist them. However, sometimes, a tragedy with beautiful artistic elements intersects our lives. If these beautiful elements are real, then the whole affair easily captivates our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer actors, but the audience of the play. Or rather, we are both. We watch ourselves, and it is the very surprise of this performance that fascinates us. In the current situation, what has actually happened? Someone has committed suicide because they loved you. I wish I could have such an experience sometime. It would make me love love for the rest of my life. The people who have been infatuated with me — not many, but there have been some — always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they for me. They fade away, become dull, and when I meet them again, they immediately drift into memory. That dreadful memory of women! How terrifying it is! And how it reveals a state of complete intellectual dullness! We should absorb the colors of life, but never remember its details. The details are always vulgar.”
tr: Lord Henry, who took great and secret pleasure in provoking the young man's unconscious selfishness, said, "This is an interesting problem, extremely interesting." " It seems to me that the real explanation is this: Often, the real tragedies of life are so far removed from the standards of art that they hurt us with their crude violence, their inconsistencies, the absurdity of their lack of meaning, their lack of elegance and grace. They affect us much like a crowd does. They leave us with an impression of pure brute force, and we rebel against it. On the other hand, occasionally, a tragedy with elements of artistic beauty enters our lives. If these elements of beauty are genuine, the event affects us directly, in terms of its dramatic structure. Suddenly, we find that we are no longer actors, but spectators of the play. Or rather, we are both actors and spectators. We watch ourselves and get carried away by the extraordinariness of the spectacle. So what has really happened in this event? A girl has killed herself for your love. I wish I had experienced something like that. It would have made me fall in love with love for a lifetime. The people who adored me...though they were not many in number...always insisted on surviving long after the interest I had in them or they had in me had faded. They became fat and tiresome people. Whenever we met, they immediately started to revive old memories. Ah, the terrible memory of a woman! What a dreadful thing it is! How it reveals the pure mossiness of the mind! One should absorb the color of life but never remember its details. Details are always the business of the vulgar."
es: —It is an interesting case —said Lord Henry, who found a subtle pleasure in playing with the unconscious selfishness of his young friend—; a most interesting case. I believe the true explanation is this: it often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an unartistic manner that they wound us by the rawness of their violence, by their absolute incoherence, their absurd lack of meaning, their complete lack of style. They affect us as vulgarity does. They only leave us with an impression of brute force, and we rebel against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy crosses our lives that possesses elements of artistic beauty. If those elements of beauty are real, the entire ensemble appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we discover that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather that we are both things. We observe ourselves, and the mere wonder of the spectacle seduces us. In the present case, what has really happened? Someone has killed themselves for love of you. I would have liked to have had such an experience once. It would have made me fall in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me (there have not been many, but a few), have always insisted on continuing to live after I stopped loving them and they stopped loving me. They have become corpulent and tedious, and when I meet them, they immediately dive into memories. Ah, that terrible memory of women! What a dreadful thing! And what total intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colors of life, but never remember the details. The details are always vulgar.

en: “I must sow poppies in my garden,” sighed Dorian.
vi: “I have to plant opium in my own garden,” Dorian sighed.
tr: Dorian sighed, "I should plant poppies in my garden."
es: —I must plant poppies in the garden —sighed Dorian.

en: “There is no necessity,” rejoined his companion. “Life has always poppies in her hands. Of course, now and then things linger. I once wore nothing but violets all through one season, as a form of artistic mourning for a romance that would not die. Ultimately, however, it did die. I forget what killed it. I think it was her proposing to sacrifice the whole world for me. That is always a dreadful moment. It fills one with the terror of eternity. Well—would you believe it?—a week ago, at Lady Hampshire’s, I found myself seated at dinner next the lady in question, and she insisted on going over the whole thing again, and digging up the past, and raking up the future. I had buried my romance in a bed of asphodel. She dragged it out again and assured me that I had spoiled her life. I am bound to state that she ate an enormous dinner, so I did not feel any anxiety. But what a lack of taste she showed! The one charm of the past is that it is the past. But women never know when the curtain has fallen. They always want a sixth act, and as soon as the interest of the play is entirely over, they propose to continue it. If they were allowed their own way, every comedy would have a tragic ending, and every tragedy would culminate in a farce. They are charmingly artificial, but they have no sense of art. You are more fortunate than I am. I assure you, Dorian, that not one of the women I have known would have done for me what Sibyl Vane did for you. Ordinary women always console themselves. Some of them do it by going in for sentimental colours. Never trust a woman who wears mauve, whatever her age may be, or a woman over thirty-five who is fond of pink ribbons. It always means that they have a history. Others find a great consolation in suddenly discovering the good qualities of their husbands. They flaunt their conjugal felicity in one’s face, as if it were the most fascinating of sins. Religion consoles some. Its mysteries have all the charm of a flirtation, a woman once told me, and I can quite understand it. Besides, nothing makes one so vain as being told that one is a sinner. Conscience makes egotists of us all. Yes; there is really no end to the consolations that women find in modern life. Indeed, I have not mentioned the most important one.”
vi: “No need,” your friend replied. “Life always has opium in hand. Of course, sometimes many things also drag on. There was a time I wore nothing but purple for an entire season, as a form of artistic mourning for a love that didn’t want to die. However, in the end, it still died. I forgot what killed it. I think it was her proposal to sacrifice the whole world for me. That is always a terrible moment. It makes one terrified of permanence. Oh, by the way — can you believe it? — last week, at Mrs. Hampshire’s place, I found myself sitting next to the lady in question at dinner, and she insisted on starting over, digging up the past, nurturing the future. I had buried my love under a bed of heliotrope. She dug it up again and assured me that I had ruined her life. I had to make it clear that she had eaten a dreadful meal, so I wasn’t worried. But how she displayed such a lack of tact. One charm of the past is that it is the past. But women never realize when the curtain has fallen. They always want a sixth act, and just when interest in the play has completely faded, they propose to continue it. If they were allowed to have their way, every comedy would end in a tragedy, and every tragedy would climax with a farce. They are charmingly artificial, but they lack the capacity to appreciate art. You are much luckier than I am. I assure you, Dorian, that no woman I have ever known could do for me what Sibyl Vane has done for you. Ordinary girls always console themselves. Some of them do so by favoring sentimental colors. Never trust a woman who wears mauve, no matter her age, or one over thirty-five who is fond of pink ribbons. It always means they are in trouble. Others find great comfort in suddenly discovering the good qualities of their husbands. They flaunt their marital happiness in our faces as if it were the most seductive sin. Religion also comforts some women. Its mysticism has all the allure of an illicit affair, one woman once told me; and I can quite understand that. Besides, nothing makes one so vain as being told that one is a sinner. Conscience makes us all self-centered. Yes; indeed, there are countless comforts that women have found in modern life. In fact, I haven’t even mentioned the most important one.”
tr: His friend replied, "There's no need." "Life always has bunches of poppies in its hand. Sometimes certain things don't just drag on. Once, for an entire season, I wore a violet on my lapel: as a kind of artistic mourning for a love that simply couldn't die. However, in the end, the love died. I don't remember why it died. It was because the girl proposed sacrificing the whole world for my sake, if I'm not mistaken. That is always a dreadful moment. It instills a fear of eternity in one's heart. Anyway...
