Would you believe... A week ago, at a dinner at Lady Hampshire's, I found myself next to the mentioned lady... And the lady insisted on reliving everything, digging up the past and talking about the future. I had buried the love I experienced in a flower bed. The woman dug it up, swore that I had ruined her life. I must say, I wasn't worried about it because she was eating heartily at the table. However, what she did was so crude! The only charm of the past is that it is the past. Yet women never know when the curtain has fallen. They always want a sixth act; they propose to continue when the play has lost all its interest. If I followed them, every comedy would end in a tragic note, and every tragedy would turn into a farce. Women have a very endearing artificiality, but no sense of art. You are luckier than I am. I assure you, Dorian, none of the women I know would do for me what Sibyl Vane did for you. Ordinary women always know how to console themselves. Some do it by cloaking themselves in romantic colors. Never trust a woman who wears purple, no matter her age... Nor a woman over thirty-five who is fond of pink ribbons. It means they definitely have a history behind them. Some women find great solace in suddenly discovering the good qualities of their husbands. They flaunt their happy marriages in one's face, like the most attractive sin. Some are consoled by religion. A woman once told me that the pleasure of flirting lies in the mysteries of religion. I understand this very well. Besides, the thing that flatters one's pride the most in the world is being told, you are a sinner. Conscience makes us all selfish. Yes, the consolations women find in contemporary life are endless. In fact, I haven't even touched on the most important one."
es: —No need —replied his friend—. Life always distributes poppies by the handful. Of course, from time to time things get prolonged. On one occasion, I wore nothing but violets for an entire season, as an artistic mourning for a love story that refused to die. In the end, it finally did. I no longer remember what killed it. Probably, her proposal to sacrifice the entire world for me. That is always a terrible moment. It fills one with the terror of eternity. Well, would you believe it? Last week, at Lady Hampshire's house, I found myself dining next to the lady I am telling you about, and she insisted on revisiting the entire story, unearthing the past and stirring up the future. I had buried my love under a bed of asphodels. She brought it back to light, assuring me that I had ruined her life. I must point out that she proceeded to devour a very copious dinner, so I felt no anxiety whatsoever. But, what a lack of good taste on her part! The only charm of the past is that it is the past. But women never realize that the curtain has fallen. They always want a sixth act, and as soon as the play loses interest, they suggest continuing it. If they were allowed to have their way, all comedies would end in tragedy, and all tragedies would culminate in farce. They are charmingly artificial, but they lack artistic sense. You have been luckier than I. I assure you that none of the women I have known would have done for me what Sibyl Vane has done for you. Ordinary women always console themselves. Some turn to sentimental colors. Never trust a woman who dresses in mauve, whatever her age, or a woman over thirty-five who is fond of pink ribbons. That always means they have a past. Others console themselves by suddenly discovering the excellent qualities of their husbands. They flaunt their marital happiness in your face, as if it were the most fascinating of sins. Some console themselves with religion, whose mysteries have all the charm of a flirtation, as a woman once told me; and I understand it perfectly. Besides, nothing makes one as vain as being accused of being a sinner. Conscience makes us all selfish. Yes; the consolations that women find in modern life are innumerable. And, in fact, I have not yet mentioned the most important one.

en: “What is that, Harry?” said the lad listlessly.
vi: "What is that, Harry?" the boy said, indifferently.
tr: The young man asked in a subdued voice, "What is that, Harry?"
es: —Which one is it, Harry? —asked the boy absentmindedly.

en: “Oh, the obvious consolation. Taking some one else’s admirer when one loses one’s own. In good society that always whitewashes a woman. But really, Dorian, how different Sibyl Vane must have been from all the women one meets! There is something to me quite beautiful about her death. I am glad I am living in a century when such wonders happen. They make one believe in the reality of the things we all play with, such as romance, passion, and love.”
vi: “Ah, the obvious consolation. Snatching away another woman's admirer when she loses her own. In the upper class, this always vindicates women. But in reality, Dorian, how different Sibyl Vane surely is from every woman we meet! I find something truly beautiful in her death. I am glad to live in a century where such wonders occur. They make us believe in the reality of things that we all jest about, like romance, passion, and love.”
tr: “Dear, the most clichéd consolation. When a person loses their own lover, they snatch someone else's. In polite society, this always exonerates a woman. But truly, Dorian, how different this Sibyl Vane was from all the other women we know! There is something very beautiful in her death, I think. I am so happy to live in a century where such wonderful things can happen. These events make one believe in the truth of things like romance, passion, love, which are toys in all our hands.”
es: —Oh, the most obvious consolation. The one that consists in seizing another's admirer when one loses their own. In good society, that always rehabilitates a woman. But, really, Dorian, how different Sibyl Vane must have been from the women we usually know! There is something that seems very beautiful to me about her death. I am glad to live in a century where such wonders occur. They make one believe in the reality of things we all play with, like romance, passion, and love.

en: “I was terribly cruel to her. You forget that.”
vi: “I was too cruel to her. Did you forget about that?”
tr: “I treated him very cruelly. You forget this.”
es: —I have been horribly cruel to her. You are forgetting it.

en: “I am afraid that women appreciate cruelty, downright cruelty, more than anything else. They have wonderfully primitive instincts. We have emancipated them, but they remain slaves looking for their masters, all the same. They love being dominated. I am sure you were splendid. I have never seen you really and absolutely angry, but I can fancy how delightful you looked. And, after all, you said something to me the day before yesterday that seemed to me at the time to be merely fanciful, but that I see now was absolutely true, and it holds the key to everything.”
vi: “I am afraid that women tend to value cruelty, blatant cruelty, more than anything else. They have marvelous primal instincts. We have liberated them, but they are still slaves searching for their masters, just the same. They like to be dominated. I am sure you are wonderful. I have never seen you truly and completely angry, but I can imagine how interesting you would look. And, after all, the other day you told me something that at the time seemed like mere imagination to me, but now I see it as absolutely accurate, and it holds the solution to all problems.”
tr: “I'm afraid that women know the value of cruelty, pure cruelty, more than anything else. Their instincts are extraordinarily primitive. We gave them their freedom, but they still continue to be slaves searching for their masters. They love to be ruled. I'm sure you behaved wonderfully. I've never seen you truly angry, but I can imagine how beautiful you would look. Besides, it wasn't yesterday but the day before that you told me something. At the time, it seemed like a figment of imagination to me, but it turns out it was completely true; now I see. The key to everything lies in this.”
es: —I very much fear that women appreciate cruelty, pure and simple cruelty, more than anything else. They have wonderfully primitive instincts. We have emancipated them, but they remain slaves in search of a master. They love to be dominated. I am sure you were splendid. I have never seen you truly angry, although I can imagine how delightful you must have looked. And, after all, the day before yesterday you told me something that seemed purely whimsical at the time, but now I consider absolutely true and that holds the key to everything that happened.

en: “What was that, Harry?”
vi: “What is it, Harry?”
tr: "What is it, Harry?""
es: —What was that, Harry?

en: “You said to me that Sibyl Vane represented to you all the heroines of romance—that she was Desdemona one night, and Ophelia the other; that if she died as Juliet, she came to life as Imogen.”
vi: "You told me that you saw Sibyl Vane as representing all the romantic heroines — that she was Desdemona one night, Ophelia another; that if she died as Juliet, she would come back to life as Imogen."
tr: "You had said that Sibyl Vane symbolized all the heroes of romantic literature in your eyes. One night she becomes Desdemona, the next night Ophelia, and even if she dies as Juliet, she is reborn as Imogen, you had said."
es: —You told me that for you Sibyl Vane represented all the heroines of novels; that one night she was Desdemona and another Juliet; that if she died as Juliet, she came back to life as Imogen.

en: “She will never come to life again now,” muttered the lad, burying his face in his hands.
vi: “She will never come back to life again,” the young man muttered, burying his face in his hands.
tr: The young man buried his face in his hands and muttered, "Now it will never be reborn again."
es: —He will never come back to life —murmured the boy, hiding his face in his hands.

en: “No, she will never come to life. She has played her last part. But you must think of that lonely death in the tawdry dressing-room simply as a strange lurid fragment from some Jacobean tragedy, as a wonderful scene from Webster, or Ford, or Cyril Tourneur. The girl never really lived, and so she has never really died. To you at least she was always a dream, a phantom that flitted through Shakespeare’s plays and left them lovelier for its presence, a reed through which Shakespeare’s music sounded richer and more full of joy. The moment she touched actual life, she marred it, and it marred her, and so she passed away. Mourn for Ophelia, if you like. Put ashes on your head because Cordelia was strangled. Cry out against Heaven because the daughter of Brabantio died. But don’t waste your tears over Sibyl Vane. She was less real than they are.”
vi: “No, she will never come back to life. She has played her final role. But you must think of that lonely death in that gaudy, cheap dressing room as just a bizarre, gruesome excerpt from some tragedy of the time of King James I, like a splendid scene of Webster, or Ford, or Cyril Tourneur. That girl never truly lived, and therefore she never truly died. To you, at least, she was always a dream, a phantom flitting through Shakespeare's plays and making them more beautiful by her presence, a reed through which Shakespeare's music sounded richer and more filled with joy. The moment she touched real life, she spoiled it, and it spoiled her, so she went away. Weep for Ophelia, if you like. Put ashes on your head for Cordelia being strangled. Cry to the heavens for Brabantio's daughter dying. But do not waste your tears for Sibyl Vane. She was less real than they are.”
tr: “No, she will never be born into life again. She played her last role. The thing is, you should think of that poor death in the vulgar dressing room as a strange, striking scene from a seventeenth-century tragedy: an extraordinary scene taken from Webster, Ford, or Cyril Tourneur. The poor girl never really lived, so she never really died. At least in your eyes, she was always a dream, a vision that flew through Shakespeare's plays, adding more beauty to them with her presence, a reed that gave a richer, more jubilant tone to Shakespeare's music. But the moment this girl touched real life, she left a stain; life also damaged her, and that's why she passed away. Mourn for Ophelia, if you wish. Wear black because Cordelia was strangled. Rebel against God because Brabantio's daughter died. But do not waste your tears on Sibyl Vane. She was much more unreal than all these women.”
es: —No, never again. She has played her last role. But you must think of that lonely death in a tinsel dressing room as a strange, eerie passage from a Jacobean tragedy, like a wonderful scene by Webster, Ford, or Cyril Tourneur. That girl never really lived, so she never truly died either. To you, at least, she was always a dream, a ghost flitting through Shakespeare's plays and making them more charming with her presence, a pipe with which Shakespeare's music sounded better and more joyful. The moment she touched real life, the charm vanished, life spoiled her, and Sibyl died. Mourn for Ophelia, if you wish. Cover your head with ashes because Cordelia has been strangled. Cry out against the heavens because Brabantio's daughter has died. But do not waste your tears for Sibyl Vane. She was less real than all of them.

en: There was a silence. The evening darkened in the room. Noiselessly, and with silver feet, the shadows crept in from the garden. The colours faded wearily out of things.
vi: Be still. The afternoon darkened in the room. In the silence, with silver legs, shadows crept in from the garden. The fading colors gradually disappeared from everything.
tr: There was a silence. The room darkened with the evening. It was as if silent shadows with silver feet glided in from the garden. Colors faded and vanished as if exhausted.
es: There was a moment of silence. The afternoon was darkening in the library. Mute, and with silver feet, the shadows from the garden entered the house. The colors wearily disappeared from the objects.

en: After some time Dorian Gray looked up. “You have explained me to myself, Harry,” he murmured with something of a sigh of relief. “I felt all that you have said, but somehow I was afraid of it, and I could not express it to myself. How well you know me! But we will not talk again of what has happened. It has been a marvellous experience. That is all. I wonder if life has still in store for me anything as marvellous.”
vi: A moment later, Dorian Gray looked up. "You have explained me to myself, Harry," he murmured, with a slight sigh of relief. "I feel everything you say, but somehow I am afraid, and I cannot express it to myself. How do you understand me so well! But we shall not speak again of what has happened. It is a wonderful memory. That's all. I wonder if life has anything as wonderful left for me."
tr: After a while, Dorian Gray lifted his head. “You have explained me to myself, Harry,” he murmured, with a sigh of relief. “I was feeling everything you said, but I was afraid, and then I couldn't express it. How well you know me! Anyway, we won't talk about this event anymore. It was a wonderful experience for me. That's all. I wonder if life has other such wonderful things in store for me?”
es: After some time, Dorian Gray raised his eyes. —You have explained myself to me, Harry —he murmured, with something like a sigh of relief—. Although I felt what you said, I was scared, and I was not able to tell it to myself. How well you know me! But let's not talk anymore about what happened. It has been a wonderful experience. That is all. I wonder if life still has something else as extraordinary in store for me.

en: “Life has everything in store for you, Dorian. There is nothing that you, with your extraordinary good looks, will not be able to do.”
vi: "Life still has everything ready for you, Dorian. There is nothing that you, with your exceptional beauty, cannot do."
tr: “Life is preparing everything for you, Dorian. With this extraordinary beauty of yours, there is nothing you cannot do.”
es: —Life has everything in store for you, Dorian. There is nothing you are not capable of doing, with your marvelous beauty.

en: “But suppose, Harry, I became haggard, and old, and wrinkled? What then?”
vi: “But suppose, Harry, I become haggard, old, wrinkled? Then what?”
tr: “But Harry, suppose I collapse, grow old, and become all wrinkled. What about then?”
es: —But suppose, Harry, that I became haggard and old and filled with wrinkles. What would happen then?

en: “Ah, then,” said Lord Henry, rising to go, “then, my dear Dorian, you would have to fight for your victories. As it is, they are brought to you. No, you must keep your good looks. We live in an age that reads too much to be wise, and that thinks too much to be beautiful. We cannot spare you. And now you had better dress and drive down to the club. We are rather late, as it is.”
vi: “Ah, at that time,” Lord Henry said, getting up as if to leave — “at that time, my dear Dorian, you will have to fight to win. As it is now, they are being brought to you. No, you must keep your beauty. We live in an age that reads too much to be wise, and thinks too much to be beautiful. We need you very much. And now you should change your clothes, then run down to the club. We are quite late already.”
tr: Lord Henry stood up to leave and said, "Then what?" "Then, dear Dorian, if you want to achieve victory, you will have to fight. In this situation, victories are being handed to you. No, no, you must preserve your beauty. We live in an age where everyone reads too much to be wise and thinks too much to be beautiful. We cannot do without you. Come on, it would be best if you got dressed now so we can head to the club. We are already late."
es: —Ah —said Lord Henry, standing up to leave—, in that case, my dear Dorian, you would have to fight for your victories. For now, they are thrown at your feet. No; you have to remain as you are. We live in an age that reads too much to be wise and thinks too much to be beautiful. We cannot do without you. And now you'd better get dressed and let's take the carriage to the club. We have already delayed enough.

en: “I think I shall join you at the opera, Harry. I feel too tired to eat anything. What is the number of your sister’s box?”
vi: “I think I will meet you at the opera house, Harry. I feel so tired, I can't eat anything. What is your sister's box number?”
tr: “Let me come and find you at the opera, Harry. I am very tired, I don't have the energy to eat anything. What is the number of your sister's box?”
es: —I think I will meet you at the opera. I am too tired to eat anything. What is your sister's box number?

en: “Twenty-seven, I believe. It is on the grand tier. You will see her name on the door. But I am sorry you won’t come and dine.”
vi: “Twenty-seven, I suppose. It's on the upper floor. You will see my brother's name on the door. But I am very sorry that you didn't come for dinner.”
tr: “Twenty-seven, I think. On the first floor. You will see the name on the door. I wish you could have come to dinner with me.”
es: —Twenty-seven, I think. It's on the first floor. You will find his name on the door. But I regret that you won't dine with me.

en: “I don’t feel up to it,” said Dorian listlessly. “But I am awfully obliged to you for all that you have said to me. You are certainly my best friend. No one has ever understood me as you have.”
vi: "I don't feel up to it," Dorian said, indifferently. "But I am very grateful to you for everything you have said to me. You are certainly my best friend. No one has ever understood me like you do."
tr: Dorian reluctantly said, "I don't feel like it." "But I am grateful to you for all that you have said. You really are my best friend. No one in the world has understood me the way you do."
es: —I don't feel capable —said Dorian distractedly—, although I am terribly grateful to you for everything you have said. You are without a doubt my best friend. No one has ever understood me like you do.

en: “We are only at the beginning of our friendship, Dorian,” answered Lord Henry, shaking him by the hand. “Good-bye. I shall see you before nine-thirty, I hope. Remember, Patti is singing.”
vi: “We are only at the beginning of our friendship, Dorian,” Lord Henry replied, shaking his hand. “Goodbye. I will see you before half-past nine, I hope. Remember, Patti will sing.”
tr: Lord Henry, shaking his hand, replied, "We are just at the beginning of our friendship, Dorian." "Goodbye. Remember to come before half-past nine. Don't forget, Patti is singing tonight."
es: —We are only at the beginning of our friendship —replied Lord Henry, shaking his hand—. See you later. I hope to see you before half-past nine. Don't forget that Patti is singing.

en: As he closed the door behind him, Dorian Gray touched the bell, and in a few minutes Victor appeared with the lamps and drew the blinds down. He waited impatiently for him to go. The man seemed to take an interminable time over everything.
vi: When he closed the door behind him, Dorian Gray rang the bell, and a few minutes later Victor appeared with the lamps and drew the curtains. He anxiously waited for him to leave. This servant seemed to take an eternity to do anything.
tr: As he pulled the door behind him and left, Dorian rang the bell; a few minutes later, Victor came with the lamps and drew the curtains. Dorian waited impatiently for him to leave. The man seemed to prolong every task he did.
es: When the library door closed, Dorian Gray rang the bell and a few minutes later Victor appeared with the lamps and lowered the blinds. Dorian waited impatiently for him to leave. He had the impression that each gesture took an infinite amount of time.

en: As soon as he had left, he rushed to the screen and drew it back. No; there was no further change in the picture. It had received the news of Sibyl Vane’s death before he had known of it himself. It was conscious of the events of life as they occurred. The vicious cruelty that marred the fine lines of the mouth had, no doubt, appeared at the very moment that the girl had drunk the poison, whatever it was. Or was it indifferent to results? Did it merely take cognizance of what passed within the soul? He wondered, and hoped that some day he would see the change taking place before his very eyes, shuddering as he hoped it.
vi: As soon as he was out, he rushed to the shield and pulled it back. No; there was no further change in the painting. It received the news of Sibyl Vane's death before he himself knew about it. It knew about the events in life the moment they happened. The cruel wickedness that marred the beauty of the mouth must have appeared at the very moment the girl drank the poison, no matter what. Or was it indifferent to the outcome? Could it only perceive what happened in the soul? He wondered, and both hoped that someday he would see the change happen before his very eyes, and shuddered at the thought.
tr: As soon as he left, Dorian ran and pulled the screen. No, there was no other change in the picture. So, the painting had received the news of Sibyl Vane's death before he did. It was learning about the events in Dorian's life as they happened. The cruelty that marred the beautiful line of the mouth had undoubtedly appeared the moment the poor girl drank the poison. Or was the portrait indifferent to the consequences? Was it only perceiving what was happening within the soul? Dorian was curious. He hoped that one day the change would occur before his very eyes, and while hoping, he couldn't help but shudder.
es: As soon as he had left, he ran towards the screen, removing it. No; no new change had occurred. The portrait had received the news of Sibyl's death before he did. It was aware of the events of life as they happened. The dissolute cruelty that disfigured the delicate lines of the mouth had undoubtedly appeared at the very moment the girl drank the poison, whatever it was. Or was it indifferent to the results? Did it simply become aware of what was happening inside the soul? He couldn't say, but he did not lose hope that one day he might see the change take place before his eyes, shuddering as he desired it.

en: Poor Sibyl! What a romance it had all been! She had often mimicked death on the stage. Then Death himself had touched her and taken her with him. How had she played that dreadful last scene? Had she cursed him, as she died? No; she had died for love of him, and love would always be a sacrament to him now. She had atoned for everything by the sacrifice she had made of her life. He would not think any more of what she had made him go through, on that horrible night at the theatre. When he thought of her, it would be as a wonderful tragic figure sent on to the world’s stage to show the supreme reality of love. A wonderful tragic figure? Tears came to his eyes as he remembered her childlike look, and winsome fanciful ways, and shy tremulous grace. He brushed them away hastily and looked again at the picture.
vi: Poor Sibyl! How romantic everything had been! She used to mimic death on stage. Then Death itself touched her, and took her away with it. How did she perform that final dreadful scene? Did she curse you when she died? No; she died because she loved you, and love will always be a curse for you now. She atoned for everything, with the sacrifice she made of her life. You will no longer think about what she made you go through, about that terrible night at the theater. When you think of her, it will be as if a tragic and wonderful image has been sent to the stage of this world to show the ultimate truth about Love. A tragic and wonderful image? Tears welled up in your eyes as you remembered her childlike face, her strange enchanting personality, and her hesitant shyness. You quickly brushed them away, and looked back at the painting.
tr: Poor Sibyl! What a love they had lived! How many times had the girl pretended to die on stage. Then death itself had marked her and taken her away. How had Sibyl played that final dreadful scene? Had she cursed Dorian while she was dying? But no, she had died for Dorian's love. From now on, love would always carry a sacred meaning in Dorian's eyes. Sibyl had sacrificed her life to pay for all sins. Dorian would no longer think about the torment she had endured on that terrible night in the theater. He would think of her as a unique, tragic symbol sent to earth to show the highest truth of love. A unique, tragic symbol, huh? When Dorian remembered her childlike appearance, her charming, dreamy manners, that shy deer-like grace, his eyes filled with tears. The young man quickly cleared his mind and looked at the picture again.
es: Poor Sibyl! How romantic it had all been! How many times had she pretended on stage the death that had finally touched her, taking her away! How would she have performed that last and terrible scene? Would she have cursed him while she died? No; she had died of love for him, and love would be his sacrament from then on. Sibyl had atoned for everything with the sacrifice of her life. He would no longer think of what he had made her suffer, on that horrible night at the theater. When he thought of her, he would see her as a wonderful tragic figure sent to the world's stage to show the supreme reality of love. A wonderful tragic figure? His eyes filled with tears as he remembered her childlike appearance, her attractive and fanciful manner, and her timid, throbbing grace. He hastily pushed those memories aside and looked back at the painting.

en: He felt that the time had really come for making his choice. Or had his choice already been made? Yes, life had decided that for him—life, and his own infinite curiosity about life. Eternal youth, infinite passion, pleasures subtle and secret, wild joys and wilder sins—he was to have all these things. The portrait was to bear the burden of his shame: that was all.
vi: You feel that it is truly time to make a choice. Or have you already chosen? Yes, life has decided that for you — life, and your own endless curiosity about it. Eternal youth, endless passion, refined and secret pleasures, wild joys and even wilder sins — you will have all these. The portrait will bear the burden of your shame: that is all.
tr: He felt that the time had come to make his choice. Or had it already been made? Yes, life had made this decision on his behalf, life and his boundless curiosity about it. Immortal youth, boundless passion, secret, mysterious, subtle pleasures, wild joys, even wilder sins: All these would be Dorian's. As for the burden of his shame, the portrait would bear it, that was all.
es: He understood that the moment to choose had truly arrived. Or had the choice already been made? Yes; life had decided for him; life and his infinite personal curiosity about life. Eternal youth, infinite passion, subtle and secret pleasures, violent joys, and even more violent sins; he did not want to forgo anything. The portrait would bear the weight of the shame; that was all.

en: A feeling of pain crept over him as he thought of the desecration that was in store for the fair face on the canvas. Once, in boyish mockery of Narcissus, he had kissed, or feigned to kiss, those painted lips that now smiled so cruelly at him. Morning after morning he had sat before the portrait wondering at its beauty, almost enamoured of it, as it seemed to him at times. Was it to alter now with every mood to which he yielded? Was it to become a monstrous and loathsome thing, to be hidden away in a locked room, to be shut out from the sunlight that had so often touched to brighter gold the waving wonder of its hair? The pity of it! the pity of it!
vi: A tingling pain spread throughout his body as he thought about the desecration that awaited the beautiful face on the canvas. Once, to childishly mimic Narcissus, he had kissed, or pretended to kiss, the painted lips that were now smiling so cruelly at him. Morning after morning, he had sat before the portrait, marveling at its beauty, almost infatuated with it, sometimes it seemed to him. Would it now change with every mood he endured? Would it become something hideous and disgusting, hidden away in a locked room, shielded from the sunlight that used to cast a golden hue on its wondrous wavy hair? Poor thing! Poor thing!
tr: As he thought of the horrors awaiting that beautiful face on the canvas, his heart filled with pain. He had once kissed, or rather pretended to kiss, those painted lips that now smiled at him so cruelly, in a childish Narcissistic imitation. Who knows how many mornings he had stood before the painting, gazing at its beauty with admiring disbelief. At times, it had seemed to him as if he were almost infatuated with this painting. Would this painting now change according to every mood he succumbed to? Would it become something disgusting, horrifying, something that needed to be hidden in a locked room, away from the sun that made the gold of those exquisite, curly locks shine even brighter? What a pity! What a pity!
es: A feeling of pain overcame him at the thought of the desecration that awaited the beautiful face in the portrait. On one occasion, in an adolescent mockery of Narcissus, he had kissed, or pretended to kiss, those painted lips that now smiled at him so cruelly. Day after day he had stood before the portrait, marveling at its beauty, almost —it sometimes seemed to him— in love with it. Would it now change every time he yielded to some whim? Was it going to become a monstrous and repugnant object, which would have to be hidden in a locked room, away from the sunlight that so often had turned the wavy marvel of his hair into dazzling gold? What a terrible prospect!

en: For a moment, he thought of praying that the horrible sympathy that existed between him and the picture might cease. It had changed in answer to a prayer; perhaps in answer to a prayer it might remain unchanged. And yet, who, that knew anything about life, would surrender the chance of remaining always young, however fantastic that chance might be, or with what fateful consequences it might be fraught? Besides, was it really under his control? Had it indeed been prayer that had produced the substitution? Might there not be some curious scientific reason for it all? If thought could exercise its influence upon a living organism, might not thought exercise an influence upon dead and inorganic things? Nay, without thought or conscious desire, might not things external to ourselves vibrate in unison with our moods and passions, atom calling to atom in secret love or strange affinity? But the reason was of no importance. He would never again tempt by a prayer any terrible power. If the picture was to alter, it was to alter. That was all. Why inquire too closely into it?
vi: He thought for a moment about pleading for the terrible empathy existing between him and the painting to end. It had changed in response to one plea; perhaps in response to another plea, it could remain unchanged. However, would someone who knew something about Life give up the chance to stay young forever, no matter how strange that chance might be, or how full of predetermined consequences it might be? Besides, was it really within his control? Could it be that the plea had indeed brought about the transformation? Could there be some strange scientific rationale for all of this? If thought could influence a living body, could thought also influence inanimate, lifeless things? Moreover, without conscious thought or desire, could things outside of us resonate in harmony with our moods and passions, could atoms call to atoms with the secret love of strange affinities? But reasoning no longer mattered. He would never again incite any terrible force with a plea. If the painting changed, then let it change. That was all. Why investigate it too closely?
tr: The young man thought for a moment about praying for this disgusting, terrifying connection between himself and the painting to be severed. The painting had changed in response to a prayer; perhaps it could remain as it was in response to another prayer. On the other hand, who with any knowledge of life would pass up the opportunity to stay young forever, no matter how irrational it might be, no matter what unknown consequences it might carry? Besides, was this really something that was within his control? Had his prayer truly been what caused this role reversal? Couldn't there be a strange scientific explanation for all these events? If thought could have an effect on living organisms, couldn't it also have an effect on inanimate, inorganic things? Moreover... Even without conscious desire and thought, couldn't something outside of us create vibrations in harmony with our mental states and intense emotions: the secret love of a strange affinity, the call of atom to atom? In any case, the reason didn't matter at all. From now on, Dorian would never attempt to provoke any terrible power with any wish or prayer. If the painting was going to change, it would change. That was all. What was the point of overthinking it?
es: For a moment he thought of praying for the dreadful communion that existed between the painting and himself to cease. The change had occurred in response to a prayer; perhaps in response to another, it would become unaltered again. And yet, who, knowing something about Life, would renounce the privilege of remaining forever young, no matter how fantastic that possibility might be or how fatal the consequences? Besides, was it really within his power to control it? Had a prayer been the cause of the change? Could there perhaps be some scientific reason? If thought influenced a living organism, could it not also exert that influence on dead and inorganic things? Moreover, was it not possible that, without conscious thoughts or desires, external things to us vibrated in union with our moods and passions, atom calling to atom in a secret love of strange affinity? But the reason mattered little. He would never again tempt any terrible power with a prayer. If the portrait had to change, it would change. That was all. What need was there to delve deeper?

en: For there would be a real pleasure in watching it. He would be able to follow his mind into its secret places. This portrait would be to him the most magical of mirrors. As it had revealed to him his own body, so it would reveal to him his own soul. And when winter came upon it, he would still be standing where spring trembles on the verge of summer. When the blood crept from its face, and left behind a pallid mask of chalk with leaden eyes, he would keep the glamour of boyhood. Not one blossom of his loveliness would ever fade. Not one pulse of his life would ever weaken. Like the gods of the Greeks, he would be strong, and fleet, and joyous. What did it matter what happened to the coloured image on the canvas? He would be safe. That was everything.
vi: There is indeed a certain pleasure in watching it. You will be able to follow your mind into its secret places. This portrait will become the most magical mirror for you. As it has revealed your body to you, it will reveal your soul to you. And when winter descends upon it, you will still stand in the trembling spring on the verge of summer. When the blood slips away from its face, leaving behind a pale mask with leaden eyes, you will still retain the enchanting beauty of youth. Not a single flower in your beauty will ever wither. Not a single heartbeat of your life will ever weaken. Like the Greek gods, you will be strong, agile, and joyful. What does it matter what happens to the many-colored image on the canvas? You will be safe. That is the most important thing.
tr: Actually, observing this change would have been really enjoyable. Thus, Dorian would be able to delve into the most secret corners of his own mind. This portrait would be the most magical of mirrors for him. Just as it had initially laid bare his body before his eyes, now it would lay bare his soul. And when winter came to the portrait, he would still be living in a spring season lingering on the threshold of summer. When the blood drained from the portrait's face, leaving behind a pale mask with leaden eyes drawn in chalk, he would still retain the allure and charm of youth. Not a single flower of his beauty would wither. Not a single pulse of his vitality would weaken. He would remain robust, agile, and joyous like the gods of ancient Greece! What did it matter what happened to the colorful image on the canvas? Dorian would be safe. This meant everything.
es: Because it would be a true pleasure to examine the portrait. In this way, I could penetrate even the most secret folds of his soul. The portrait would become the most magical of mirrors. Just as it had revealed his body, it would also reveal his soul. And when winter came to that soul, he would still remain where spring trembles, about to turn into summer. When the blood disappeared from his face, leaving a pale plaster mask with leaden eyes, he would retain the allure of adolescence. Not an atom of his beauty would ever wither. The rhythm of his life would never weaken. Like the gods of the Greeks, he would always be strong, swift, and joyful. What did it matter what happened to the colored image on the canvas? He would be safe. That was the only thing that mattered.

en: He drew the screen back into its former place in front of the picture, smiling as he did so, and passed into his bedroom, where his valet was already waiting for him. An hour later he was at the opera, and Lord Henry was leaning over his chair.
vi: He pulled the cover back over the painting, smiling as he did so, and went into the bedroom, where the servant was waiting for him. An hour later, he was at the opera house, and Lord Henry was leaning over his seat.
tr: Dorian, smiling, pulled the screen back in front of the portrait and entered the bedroom. His personal valet was waiting for him there. An hour later, Dorian Gray had arrived at the opera and taken his seat, and Lord Henry was already leaning against his chair, bending towards him.
es: He put the screen back in its previous position, in front of the portrait, smiling as he did so, and entered the bedroom, where his valet was already waiting for him. An hour later he was at the opera, and Lord Henry was leaning over his chair.

en: CHAPTER IX.
vi: Chapter 9
tr: Ninth chapter
es: Chapter 9

en: As he was sitting at breakfast next morning, Basil Hallward was shown into the room.
vi: The next morning, while he was having breakfast, Basil Hallward appeared in the room.
tr: The next morning, while Dorian was sitting at breakfast, the servant brought in Basil Hallward.
es: When I was having breakfast the next morning, the servant showed Basil Hallward in.

en: “I am so glad I have found you, Dorian,” he said gravely. “I called last night, and they told me you were at the opera. Of course, I knew that was impossible. But I wish you had left word where you had really gone to. I passed a dreadful evening, half afraid that one tragedy might be followed by another. I think you might have telegraphed for me when you heard of it first. I read of it quite by chance in a late edition of The Globe that I picked up at the club. I came here at once and was miserable at not finding you. I can’t tell you how heart-broken I am about the whole thing. I know what you must suffer. But where were you? Did you go down and see the girl’s mother? For a moment I thought of following you there. They gave the address in the paper. Somewhere in the Euston Road, isn’t it? But I was afraid of intruding upon a sorrow that I could not lighten. Poor woman! What a state she must be in! And her only child, too! What did she say about it all?”
vi: “I am very glad to have found you, Dorian,” he said, solemnly. “I called last night, and they told me you were at the opera house. Of course, I knew that couldn't be true. But I wish you had left a message about where you actually went. I had a terrible evening, somewhat fearing that this tragedy might follow another tragedy. I think you could have telegraphed me as soon as you heard the news. I read it entirely by chance in the late edition of The Globe, which I picked up at the club. I came here immediately and was distressed not to find you. I can't tell you how heartbroken I was over the whole affair. I understand what you must be going through. But where were you? Did you go down to see the girl's mother? For a moment, I thought about following you there. They gave the address in the paper. Somewhere on Euston Road, right? But I was afraid of intruding on a grief that I could not alleviate. Poor woman! She must be in such a terrible state! And her only child too! What did she say about all this?”
tr: The painter said with a serious expression, "I'm glad I found you at home, Dorian." "I came yesterday evening as well, they told me you were at the opera. I knew that wouldn't be true, naturally. I wish you had told the household where you were going. I had a terrible night: I was almost afraid that one tragedy would follow another. You could have sent me a telegram when you first got the news, couldn't you? By chance, I saw it in the evening edition of the Globe I found at the club. I ran here immediately, I was very upset when I couldn't find you. I can't tell you how shaken I was by this event. Who knows how devastated you must be. But where were you? Did you go to see the girl's mother? For a moment, I even thought of following you there. The addresses were in the newspaper. A place on Euston Street, right? But I was afraid of being disrespectful to a grief I couldn't alleviate. Poor woman! Who knows how devastated she must be! And her only child! What was she saying, poor thing?"
es: —I'm glad to have found you, Dorian —said the painter with a solemn tone—. I came to see you last night, and they told me you were at the opera. I understood that it wasn't possible. But I regret that you didn't say where you were really going. I had a horrible evening, half fearing that one tragedy might be followed by another. I think you should have telegraphed me when you found out what happened. I read it almost by chance in the last edition of the Globe, which I found at the club. I came here immediately, and I was very sorry not to see you. I don't know how to explain to you how much I regret what happened. I understand how much you are suffering. But, where were you? Did you go to see that girl's mother? For a moment I thought about following you there. They gave the address in the newspaper. A place on Euston Road, isn't that right? But I was afraid of stirring up a pain that I couldn't alleviate. Poor woman! In what state she must be! And her only daughter! What has she said about what happened?

en: “My dear Basil, how do I know?” murmured Dorian Gray, sipping some pale-yellow wine from a delicate, gold-beaded bubble of Venetian glass and looking dreadfully bored. “I was at the opera. You should have come on there. I met Lady Gwendolen, Harry’s sister, for the first time. We were in her box. She is perfectly charming; and Patti sang divinely. Don’t talk about horrid subjects. If one doesn’t talk about a thing, it has never happened. It is simply expression, as Harry says, that gives reality to things. I may mention that she was not the woman’s only child. There is a son, a charming fellow, I believe. But he is not on the stage. He is a sailor, or something. And now, tell me about yourself and what you are painting.”
vi: “My dear Basil, how would I know?” Dorian Gray muttered, sipping some pale gold wine from a delicate Venetian glass with golden bubbles, and looking very sad. “I was at the opera house. You should have been there. I met Harry's sister, Gwendolen, for the first time. We were in her box. She is extremely charming; and Patti sang wonderfully. Don't talk about dreadful subjects anymore. If we don't talk about something, it will never happen. Only words, as Harry says, bring reality to things. I can tell you that she is not the only child of that woman. There is a son, a charming fellow, I suppose. But he is not an actor. He is a sailor, I believe. And now tell me about yourself and what you are painting.”
tr: Dorian grumbled, "Dear Basil, how should I know?" He was drinking a pale yellow wine from a thin glass made of Venetian glass, resembling golden essence, and he looked extremely bored. "I was at the opera. You should have come there. I met Harry's sister, Lady Gwendolen. We were in her box. A lady as sweet as sugar. Patti sang wonderfully. My dear, don't talk about painful subjects. If you don't talk about an event, it means it didn't happen. As Harry says, what gives events and situations reality is their being spoken about, directly. Let me also point out that the girl was not that woman's only child. She also has a son, a very charming young man, from what I've heard. But he is not an actor. He's a sailor or something, something like that. Anyway, now tell me about yourself, what are you drawing?"
es: —My dear Basil, how do you expect me to know? —murmured Dorian Gray, taking a sip of pale white wine from a delicate Venetian crystal glass adorned with gold pearls, with an air of extreme boredom—. I was at the opera. You should have gone there. I met Lady Gwendolen, Harry's sister. We were in her box. She is absolutely charming; and Patti sang divinely. Don't talk about horrible things. It's enough not to talk about something for it to have never happened. As Harry says, the act of expressing things is what gives them reality. Though I might mention that she was not an only child. There is a male, an excellent boy, I believe. But he is not involved in the theater. He is a sailor or something like that. And now tell me about yourself and what you are painting.

en: “You went to the opera?” said Hallward, speaking very slowly and with a strained touch of pain in his voice. “You went to the opera while Sibyl Vane was lying dead in some sordid lodging? You can talk to me of other women being charming, and of Patti singing divinely, before the girl you loved has even the quiet of a grave to sleep in? Why, man, there are horrors in store for that little white body of hers!”
vi: “You went to the opera house?” Hallward said, pronouncing very slowly, with a bit of painful tension in his voice. “You went to the opera house while Sibyl Vane was lying dead in some filthy lodging? You can talk to me about other girls flaunting their charms, about Patti singing wonderfully, even before the girl you loved had the peace of a grave to sleep in? Why, my friend, there are horrors awaiting that small, pale corpse of hers!”
tr: “Did you go to the opera?” There was a tension in Basil Hallward's voice stemming from sadness. He asked, enunciating each word: “While Sibyl Vane lay dead in a filthy boarding house room, you went to the opera? While the girl you loved hasn't even found peace in her grave, you can talk to me about the sweetness of other women, about Patti’s magnificent voice? Man, don't you know what terrible things await that poor girl's tiny white body?”
es: —You went to the opera —exclaimed Hallward, speaking very slowly, his voice trembling with pain—. Did you go to the opera while Sibyl Vane's corpse lay in some sordid place? Are you capable of talking to me about how charming other women are and the wonderful voice of Patti, before the girl you loved even has the peace of a grave to rest in? Do you not know the horrors that await her body, still so white?

en: “Stop, Basil! I won’t hear it!” cried Dorian, leaping to his feet. “You must not tell me about things. What is done is done. What is past is past.”
vi: "Enough, Basil! I can't bear it any longer!" Dorian shouted, standing up abruptly. "You shouldn't talk to me about these things anymore. What's done is done. What's past is past." 1 One point of contention in the author's very hard-to-read handwritten manuscript is that many English prints suggest this word is “hear.” However, the translator chose the translation as “bear.”
tr: “Stop, Basil! I won't listen!” shouted Dorian as he jumped up. “You won't tell me such things. What's done is done. The past is the past.”
es: —Enough! I am not willing to listen to it! —exclaimed Dorian, standing up abruptly—. Do not talk to me about those things. What is done, is done. The past is the past.

en: “You call yesterday the past?”
vi: “You call yesterday the past?”
tr: “Are you saying that yesterday is in the past?”
es: —Do you call yesterday the past?

en: “What has the actual lapse of time got to do with it? It is only shallow people who require years to get rid of an emotion. A man who is master of himself can end a sorrow as easily as he can invent a pleasure. I don’t want to be at the mercy of my emotions. I want to use them, to enjoy them, and to dominate them.”
vi: “What does actual time have to do with it? Only shallow people need years to get over an emotion. Someone who is the master of themselves can end their pain as easily as they can create a pleasure. I do not want to let emotions decide my fate. I want to use them, to enjoy them, to control them.”
tr: “What does it matter how much time has passed? Only shallow people wait for years to get over a feeling. A person who can control themselves can soothe their pain just as easily as they can invent a pleasure. I don't want to be a toy in the hands of my own emotions. I want to use my emotions, enjoy them, dominate them...”
es: —What does the elapsed time have to do with it? Only superficial people need years to discard an emotion. A man who is master of himself ends a sorrow as easily as he invents a pleasure. I do not want to be at the mercy of my emotions. I want to use them, enjoy them, dominate them.

en: “Dorian, this is horrible! Something has changed you completely. You look exactly the same wonderful boy who, day after day, used to come down to my studio to sit for his picture. But you were simple, natural, and affectionate then. You were the most unspoiled creature in the whole world. Now, I don’t know what has come over you. You talk as if you had no heart, no pity in you. It is all Harry’s influence. I see that.”
vi: “Dorian, this is terrible! Something has completely changed you. You still look like that same boy, a wonderful boy, who day after day, came down to my studio to sit as a model for the painting of yourself. But back then you were simple, natural, affectionate. You used to be the purest creature in the whole world. Now I don't know what has influenced you. You speak as if you have no heart, no compassion within you. It's all due to Harry's influence. That's what I think.”
tr: “Dorian, this is so terrible! Something has fundamentally changed you. In appearance, you are still that wonderful boy who comes to my studio every day to pose for his portrait. But back then, you were uncomplicated, natural, and full of love. You were the most unspoiled creature in the world. But now, I don't know what has happened to you. You speak as if you are heartless and cruel. It's all Harry's influence. That's all I can see.”
es: —What you say is horrible, Dorian! Something has completely changed you. You still look like the wonderful young man who, day after day, came to my studio to pose. But then you were a simple, spontaneous, and affectionate person. You were the most honest creature on earth. Now, I don't know what has happened to you. You speak as if you have no heart, as if you are incapable of compassion. It's Harry's influence. I see it all too clearly.

en: The lad flushed up and, going to the window, looked out for a few moments on the green, flickering, sun-lashed garden. “I owe a great deal to Harry, Basil,” he said at last, “more than I owe to you. You only taught me to be vain.”
vi: The young man blushed, and, approaching the window, looked outside for a few minutes at the green lawn and the garden shimmering in the sunlight. “I owe Harry a lot, Basil,” he finally said, — “more than I owe you. You only taught me to be arrogant.”
tr: The child turned bright red, walked to the glass door, and for a moment looked at the green garden outside, which was whipped by the sun's rays, burning and swirling. Finally, he said, "I owe Harry a lot, Basil." "More than I owe you. You only taught me to be arrogant."
es: The boy blushed and, approaching the window, gazed for a few moments at the brilliant green of the garden, bathed in sunlight. —I owe a lot to Harry—he finally said—; more than I owe to you. You only taught me to be vain.

en: “Well, I am punished for that, Dorian—or shall be some day.”
vi: "That's it, I have been punished for that, Dorian — or someday will be."
tr: “Yes, that's why I was punished, Dorian, or one day I will be punished.”
es: —No doubt I am being punished for it; or I will be someday.

en: “I don’t know what you mean, Basil,” he exclaimed, turning round. “I don’t know what you want. What do you want?”
vi: "I don't understand what you mean, Basil," he exclaimed, turning around. "I don't understand what you want. What do you want?"
tr: Dorian turned hesitantly, "I don't understand, what do you mean, Basil?" "I don't know what you want either. What do you want?"
es: —I don't understand what you're saying, Basil —exclaimed Dorian Gray, turning around—. I also don't know what you want. What is it that you want?

en: “I want the Dorian Gray I used to paint,” said the artist sadly.
vi: "I want the Dorian Gray that I once painted," the artist said sadly.
tr: The painter replied sorrowfully, "I want the Dorian Gray I painted in that picture."
es: "I want the Dorian Gray whose portrait I painted long ago," said the artist sadly.

en: “Basil,” said the lad, going over to him and putting his hand on his shoulder, “you have come too late. Yesterday, when I heard that Sibyl Vane had killed herself—”
vi: "Basil," the young man said, approaching him, placing his hand on his shoulder. "You have come too late. Yesterday, when I heard that Sibyl Vane had committed suicide..."
tr: The young man went and put his hand on his shoulder, saying, "Basil, you are very late," he said. "When I heard yesterday that Sibyl Vane had killed herself..."
es: —Basil —said the boy, approaching him and placing his hand on his shoulder—, you have arrived too late. Yesterday, when I heard that Sibyl Vane had taken her own life...

en: “Killed herself! Good heavens! is there no doubt about that?” cried Hallward, looking up at him with an expression of horror.
vi: “Suicide! Oh my God! Are you sure about that?” Hallward cried out, looking up at him with a fearful expression.
tr: Basil Hallward, "Did he kill himself? Oh my God! Is it certain?" he exclaimed softly, looking at the young man with a face full of horror.
es: —Taken his life! Good heavens! Is it known for certain? —exclaimed Hallward, looking horrified at his friend.

en: “My dear Basil! Surely you don’t think it was a vulgar accident? Of course she killed herself.”
vi: “My dear Basil! Surely you don't think it was a mere accident? Of course, she committed suicide.”
tr: "My dear Basil! Surely you don't think this was just an ordinary accident, do you? Of course, he killed himself."
es: —My dear Basil! You don't think it was a mere accident, do you? Of course he committed suicide.

en: The elder man buried his face in his hands. “How fearful,” he muttered, and a shudder ran through him.
vi: The older person buried their face in their hands. "It's really scary," they muttered, and a shiver ran through their body.
tr: Burying his face in his hands, the painter muttered, "How terrible!"; a shiver ran through his entire body.
es: The oldest man covered his face with his hands. —What a terrible thing —he murmured, his whole body shaken by a tremor.

en: “No,” said Dorian Gray, “there is nothing fearful about it. It is one of the great romantic tragedies of the age. As a rule, people who act lead the most commonplace lives. They are good husbands, or faithful wives, or something tedious. You know what I mean—middle-class virtue and all that kind of thing. How different Sibyl was! She lived her finest tragedy. She was always a heroine. The last night she played—the night you saw her—she acted badly because she had known the reality of love. When she knew its unreality, she died, as Juliet might have died. She passed again into the sphere of art. There is something of the martyr about her. Her death has all the pathetic uselessness of martyrdom, all its wasted beauty. But, as I was saying, you must not think I have not suffered. If you had come in yesterday at a particular moment—about half-past five, perhaps, or a quarter to six—you would have found me in tears. Even Harry, who was here, who brought me the news, in fact, had no idea what I was going through. I suffered immensely. Then it passed away. I cannot repeat an emotion. No one can, except sentimentalists. And you are awfully unjust, Basil. You come down here to console me. That is charming of you. You find me consoled, and you are furious. How like a sympathetic person! You remind me of a story Harry told me about a certain philanthropist who spent twenty years of his life in trying to get some grievance redressed, or some unjust law altered—I forget exactly what it was. Finally he succeeded, and nothing could exceed his disappointment. He had absolutely nothing to do, almost died of ennui, and became a confirmed misanthrope. And besides, my dear old Basil, if you really want to console me, teach me rather to forget what has happened, or to see it from a proper artistic point of view. Was it not Gautier who used to write about la consolation des arts? I remember picking up a little vellum-covered book in your studio one day and chancing on that delightful phrase. Well, I am not like that young man you told me of when we were down at Marlow together, the young man who used to say that yellow satin could console one for all the miseries of life. I love beautiful things that one can touch and handle. Old brocades, green bronzes, lacquer-work, carved ivories, exquisite surroundings, luxury, pomp—there is much to be got from all these. But the artistic temperament that they create, or at any rate reveal, is still more to me. To become the spectator of one’s own life, as Harry says, is to escape the suffering of life. I know you are surprised at my talking to you like this. You have not realized how I have developed. I was a schoolboy when you knew me. I am a man now. I have new passions, new thoughts, new ideas. I am different, but you must not like me less. I am changed, but you must always be my friend. Of course, I am very fond of Harry. But I know that you are better than he is. You are not stronger—you are too much afraid of life—but you are better. And how happy we used to be together! Don’t leave me, Basil, and don’t quarrel with me. I am what I am. There is nothing more to be said.”
vi: “No,” Dorian Gray said, “There is nothing to be afraid of here. It is one of the greatest romantic tragedies of the age. As a rule, actors live the most mundane lives. They are good husbands, dutiful wives, or something equally dull. You understand what I mean — the virtues of the middle class, and all that sort of thing. How different Sibyl was! She lived her finest tragedy. She was always the heroine. The last night she acted — the night you saw her — she performed poorly because she had known real love. When she realized the unreality of it, she died, as Juliet might have died. She passed into the sphere of art once more. There was something of the martyr about her. Her death had all the pathetic uselessness of martyrdom, all its wasted beauty. But, as I said, you must not think I am heartless. If you had come here yesterday at a particular moment — around half-past five, perhaps, or a quarter to six — you would have found me weeping. Even Harry, who was here at the time, who brought me the news, could not really understand what I went through. I suffered immensely. Then it passed away. I cannot repeat an emotion. No one can, except sentimentalists. And you are very unfair, Basil. You come down here to console me. That is your charm. You find me consoled, and you are furious. How like a sympathetic person! You remind me of a story Harry told me about a charitable man who spent twenty years of his life trying to get some grievance redressed, or some unjust law altered — I forget exactly what it was. In the end, he succeeded, and nothing could exceed his disappointment. He had absolutely nothing to do, almost died of ennui, and became a confirmed misanthrope. Besides, my dear old Basil, if you really want to console me, teach me to forget what has happened, or to see it from the proper artistic point of view. Was it not Gautier who used to write about la consolation des arts? I remember picking up a little vellum-covered book in your studio the other day and chancing upon that delightful phrase. Indeed, I am not the same person who told you that satin could console one for all the miseries of life when we were down at Marlow together. I love beautiful things that one can touch and handle. Old brocades, green bronzes, lacquer-work, carved ivories, exquisite surroundings, luxury, pomp — there is much to be got from all these. But the artistic temperament they create, or at any rate reveal, is more to me than all these. To become the spectator of one's own life, as Harry says, is to escape the suffering of life. I know you are surprised at my talking to you like this. You have not realized how I have developed. I was a schoolboy when you knew me. Now I am a man. I have new passions, new thoughts, new ideas. I am different, but you must not love me less. I have changed, but you must always be my friend. Of course I am very fond of Harry. But I know you are better than he is. You are not strong — you are too afraid of life — but you are better. And how happy we used to be together! Don't leave me, Basil, and don't quarrel with me. I am what I am. There is nothing more to be said.”
tr: “No,” said Dorian Gray. “There is nothing terrible in this. It is one of the greatest romantic tragedies of the age. Generally, theater actors lead extremely stereotypical lives. They become good husbands, faithful wives, or something similarly tedious. You understand what I mean, middle-class morality, and all that. But how different Sibyl was! She didn’t just act out her greatest tragedy, she lived it. She was always a romantic hero. On that last night she went on stage...The night you saw her...She acted poorly because she had learned the reality of love. And when she learned that this reality wasn’t real, she died: Just as Juliet might have died. She returned to the realm of art. Sibyl has a saintly aspect too. In her death, there is all the heartbreaking futility of saintly deaths, the wasted beauty. But as I said, don’t think I didn’t suffer. If you had come here an hour earlier yesterday...Around half-past five, a quarter to six...You would have found me drowned in tears. Even Harry, who came here, or rather brought me the news, couldn’t perceive what I was feeling. I suffered immensely. Then it passed. I can’t repeat an emotion. Nobody can do that, except the sentimental. And you are being very unfair to me, Basil. You came here to console me. You are very sweet. But you see that I am already consoled. You are furious. Typical ‘understanding person’! You remind me of a story Harry told. A man who dedicated himself to charity spent twenty years trying to right a wrong or correct an unjust law, I forget which. Anyway, he finally succeeded but couldn’t have been more disappointed. Because he had nothing left to do, he nearly died of boredom and became a sworn enemy of the people. And besides, dear Basil, if you really want to console me, try to make me forget what happened or show the event to me from an artistic perspective! Wasn’t it Gautier who wrote about the consolation of the arts? I remember one day in your studio, a small parchment-covered book fell into my hands, and as I flipped through the pages, this exquisite sentence caught my eye. Anyway, when we went to Marlow together, you told me about a young man: Yellow satin soothes all the sorrows of life, he said, but I am not like him. I love tangible, touchable, beautiful things. Antique brocades, green bronzes, lacquer works, ivory carvings, beautiful places, luxury, splendor...These things have much to offer a person. But the artistic spirit they create, or at least bring out, is the most important to me. As Harry says, if we become spectators of our own lives, we will be freed from life’s troubles. I know, my talking like this surprises you. You weren’t aware of how much I had developed! When you met me, I was a schoolboy. Now I am a man. I have new feelings, new thoughts, new perspectives. I am different from before, but don’t love me any less. I have changed, but you must always be my friend. I love Harry very much, of course. But I am not unaware that you are a better person than he is. I can’t say you are stronger...You are excessively afraid of life...But you are still a better person. We would have such happy days together! Don’t leave me, Basil, but I don’t want you to judge me either. I am what I am. There is nothing more to say.”
es: —No —said Dorian Gray—; there is nothing terrible about it. It is one of the great romantic tragedies of our time. Generally, actors lead quite ordinary lives. They are good husbands, or faithful wives, or something equally tedious. You know what I mean, middle-class virtues and all that sort of thing. How different was Sibyl, who lived her greatest tragedy! She was always a heroine. The last night she acted, the night you saw her, her performance was bad because she had discovered the reality of love. When she realized its unreality, she died, as Juliet might have died. She returned once more to the sphere of art. There was something of the martyr about her. Her death has all the pathetic uselessness of martyrdom, all its wasted beauty. But, as I was saying, you must not think that I have not suffered. If you had come yesterday at a certain moment, around half-past five, perhaps, or a quarter to six, you would have found me weeping. Even Harry, who was here and brought me the news, did not realize what was happening to me. I suffered immensely. Then the suffering ended. I cannot repeat an emotion. No one can, except sentimental people. And you are terribly unjust, Basil. You come here to console me. It is very much appreciated. You find me consoled and you get furious. Bravo for compassionate people! You make me think of a story Harry told me about a certain philanthropist who spent twenty years trying to rectify a grievance or change an unjust law, I don't remember exactly what it was about. He finally succeeded, and his disappointment was immense. Having absolutely nothing to do, he almost died of ennui, becoming a perfect misanthrope. And besides, my dear Basil, if you really want to console me, teach me rather to forget what has happened or to see it from the most convenient artistic angle. Wasn't it Gautier who spoke about the consolation of the arts? I remember finding a little vellum-bound book in your studio one day where I discovered that delightful phrase by chance. Well, I am not like the young man you told me about when we were together in Marlow, the young man for whom yellow satin could console anyone for all the sorrows of life. I like beautiful things that can be touched and used. Old brocades, bronzes with patina, lacquered objects, carved ivories, exquisite surroundings, luxury, pomp: there is much to enjoy in all these things. But the artistic temperament they create, or at least reveal, is even more important to me. To become the spectator of one's own life, as Harry says, is to escape its sufferings. I know it surprises you that I speak to you this way. You have not realized how I have matured. I was only a schoolboy when you met me. I am a man now. I have new passions, new thoughts, new ideas. I am different, but you must not love me less. I have changed, but you will always be my friend. It is true that I am very fond of Harry. But I know you are better. Less strong, because you are too afraid of life, but better. And how happy we were when we were together! Don't leave me, Basil, nor quarrel with me. I am what I am. There is nothing more to say.

en: The painter felt strangely moved. The lad was infinitely dear to him, and his personality had been the great turning point in his art. He could not bear the idea of reproaching him any more. After all, his indifference was probably merely a mood that would pass away. There was so much in him that was good, so much in him that was noble.
vi: 1 A source of comfort in art. The artist felt strangely moved. The young man had been incredibly sincere with him, and his personality had been a great turning point in his art. He could no longer harbor the intention to scold him. After all, the young man's indifference was probably just a mood that would eventually pass. There were too many good things, too many noble qualities in him.
tr: The painter's heart was strangely wrenched. He loved this child very, very much; his personality had been an important turning point in his own art. He could not bear the thought of scolding him any further. There were so many good, noble things in Dorian's being!
es: The painter felt strangely moved. He infinitely appreciated Dorian, and thanks to his personality, his art had taken a decisive step forward. There was no point in thinking about reproaching him anymore. Perhaps his indifference was a passing mood. There was so much goodness in him, so much nobility!

en: “Well, Dorian,” he said at length, with a sad smile, “I won’t speak to you again about this horrible thing, after to-day. I only trust your name won’t be mentioned in connection with it. The inquest is to take place this afternoon. Have they summoned you?”
vi: “Alright, Dorian,” he said at last, with a sad smile, “I will not speak to you again about this dreadful matter after today. I just hope that your name will not be mentioned in connection with it. The investigation will take place this afternoon. Have they summoned you yet?”
tr: Finally, with a bitter smile, Hallward said, "Alright, Dorian." "After today, I will never speak to you about this painful matter again. I hope your name does not get involved in the incident. The inquiry will be held this afternoon. Have they summoned you?"
es: —Well, Dorian —he said, finally, with a sad smile—; from today onwards, I will not speak to you again about that terrible event. I only wish that your name is not involved in a scandal. The judicial investigation is being held this afternoon. Have you been summoned?

en: Dorian shook his head, and a look of annoyance passed over his face at the mention of the word “inquest.” There was something so crude and vulgar about everything of the kind. “They don’t know my name,” he answered.
vi: Dorian shook his head, and a look of discomfort crossed his face at the mention of the word "investigation." There was something crude and vulgar about everything of that sort. "They don't know my name," he replied.
tr: Dorian nodded. When he heard the word "interrogation," a look of displeasure crossed his face. There was something so crude, so vulgar about such matters! “They don't know my name.”
es: Dorian shook his head; and an expression of annoyance crossed his face upon hearing the word "investigation" mentioned. The whole affair had something vulgar and coarse about it. —They don't know my name —he replied.

en: “But surely she did?”
vi: “But surely she knows, right?”
tr: “But Sibyl knew, didn't she?”
es: —Not her either?

en: “Only my Christian name, and that I am quite sure she never mentioned to any one. She told me once that they were all rather curious to learn who I was, and that she invariably told them my name was Prince Charming. It was pretty of her. You must do me a drawing of Sibyl, Basil. I should like to have something more of her than the memory of a few kisses and some broken pathetic words.”
vi: “Only my Christian name, and that I am sure she never mentioned to anyone. She once told me that they were all quite curious to know who I was, and that she always told them my name was Prince Charming. That was her sweetness. You must paint me a picture of Sibyl, Basil. I want something of her more than the memory of a few kisses and some broken, pathetic words.”
tr: “He only knew the first step, and I'm sure he didn't tell anyone about it. He mentioned once: Everyone was curious about who I was, and he always said my name was Sweet Prince. Isn't that sweet? Draw me a picture of Sibyl, Basil. I want to have something of her, more than just the memory of a few kisses and some broken words.”
es: —Only my first name, and I'm sure she never told anyone. Once she told me that everyone was very curious to know who I was, but she always said I was Prince Charming. A kindness on her part. You must draw a picture of Sibyl for me, Basil. I would like to have more than just the memory of a few kisses and some broken words full of pathos.

en: “I will try and do something, Dorian, if it would please you. But you must come and sit to me yourself again. I can’t get on without you.”
vi: "I will try to do something, Dorian, if it makes you happy. But you must come and sit for me again. I can't continue without you."
tr: “I will try to do something, Dorian, if it will make you happy. But you must come and pose for me again. I can't work without you.”
es: —I will try to do something, Dorian, if that pleases you. But you have to come and pose for me again. Without you, I do nothing worthwhile.

en: “I can never sit to you again, Basil. It is impossible!” he exclaimed, starting back.
vi: "I can never sit for you again, Basil. It's impossible!" he cried, drawing back.
tr: The young man shuddered and said, "I can never pose for you again, Basil!"
es: —I will never pose for you again. It's impossible! —exclaimed Dorian, stepping back.

en: The painter stared at him. “My dear boy, what nonsense!” he cried. “Do you mean to say you don’t like what I did of you? Where is it? Why have you pulled the screen in front of it? Let me look at it. It is the best thing I have ever done. Do take the screen away, Dorian. It is simply disgraceful of your servant hiding my work like that. I felt the room looked different as I came in.”
vi: The artist stared at him intently. “My dear boy, how absurd!” he exclaimed. “Are you saying you don't like what I have done for you? Where is it? Why did you pull the screen in front of it? Let me see it. It is the best thing I have ever done. Take the screen away, Dorian. Your servant is shameful for covering my work like that. I felt that this room seemed different from the moment I entered.”
tr: The painter stared at her. "My dear child, don't be ridiculous!" he said. "Are you saying that you don't like the portrait I made of you? Where is it? Why did you put a screen in front of it? Let me see it. This is my best work. My dear, move that screen, Dorian. It's a disgrace if the servant is hiding my work like this. No wonder the room looked different to me when I entered."
es: The painter stared at him intently. —My dear Dorian, that's nonsense! —he exclaimed—. Do you mean to say you don't like the portrait I painted of you? Where is it? Why have you placed that screen in front of it? Let me see it. It's the best thing I've done. Please remove the screen, Dorian. I find it shameful that your servant hides my portrait in that manner. Now I understand why the room seemed different when I entered.

en: “My servant has nothing to do with it, Basil. You don’t imagine I let him arrange my room for me? He settles my flowers for me sometimes—that is all. No; I did it myself. The light was too strong on the portrait.”
vi: “My servant has nothing to do with it, Basil. You don't think I let him arrange my room for me, do you? He occasionally leaves flowers for me — that's all. No; I did it myself. The light is too strong for the portrait.”
tr: “My child has no connection with this, Basil. Do you think I allowed him to arrange my room! He just places the flowers occasionally, that's all. No, I did this. There was too much light falling on the portrait.”
es: —My servant has nothing to do with that. You wouldn't imagine that I let him arrange the library for me, would you? Sometimes he places the flowers... that's all. No; it was I who did it. The light was too strong for the portrait.

en: “Too strong! Surely not, my dear fellow? It is an admirable place for it. Let me see it.” And Hallward walked towards the corner of the room.
vi: “Too strong? Definitely not, my friend! This is a wonderful place for it. Let me see it.” And Hallward walked towards the corner of the room.
tr: “Is it too much? You are mistaken, my friend. This is a suitable place for the portrait. Wait, let me see,” said Hallward as he moved towards the corner where the painting stood.
es: —Too strong! It can't be. It's an admirable spot for that painting. Let me see it. A scream of terror escaped from the mouth of Dorian Gray, who ran to position himself between the painter and the screen.

en: A cry of terror broke from Dorian Gray’s lips, and he rushed between the painter and the screen. “Basil,” he said, looking very pale, “you must not look at it. I don’t wish you to.”
