vi: A terrified scream escaped from Dorian Gray's lips, and he rushed between the painter and the shield. “Basil,” he said, looking pale, “you shouldn't have looked at it. I didn't want you to do that.”
tr: Dorian Gray, with an exclamation of horror escaping from his lips, rushed forward and stood between the painter and the portrait. He had turned deathly pale. “Basil, you must not look at it. I don't want you to,” he said.
es: A scream of terror escaped from the mouth of Dorian Gray, who ran to position himself between the painter and the screen. —Basil —he said, extremely pale—, you must not see it. I don't want you to see it.

en: “Not look at my own work! You are not serious. Why shouldn’t I look at it?” exclaimed Hallward, laughing.
vi: "Don't look at my work! You're not serious. Why can't I look at it?" Hallward exclaimed, laughing.
tr: Hallward laughed, "Am I not going to look at the painting I made myself? You can't be serious!" he said. "Why wouldn't I look at it?"
es: —I must not see my own work! You're not serious. Why shouldn't I see it? —asked Hallward, laughing.

en: “If you try to look at it, Basil, on my word of honour I will never speak to you again as long as I live. I am quite serious. I don’t offer any explanation, and you are not to ask for any. But, remember, if you touch this screen, everything is over between us.”
vi: "If you try to look at it, Basil, I swear on my honor that I will never speak to you again as long as I live. I am completely serious. I offer no excuses, and don't ask for any. But remember, if you touch this shield, everything between us is over."
tr: "Basil, if you try to look, I swear on my honor that I will never speak to you again for the rest of my life. I am very serious. I am not giving any reason, and you will not ask. But remember, if you touch this screen, everything between us is over."
es: —If you try to look at it, I swear on my honor that I will never speak to you again as long as I live. I am completely serious. I am not giving you any explanation, nor do I allow you to ask for one. But remember, if you touch that screen, our friendship will be over forever.

en: Hallward was thunderstruck. He looked at Dorian Gray in absolute amazement. He had never seen him like this before. The lad was actually pallid with rage. His hands were clenched, and the pupils of his eyes were like disks of blue fire. He was trembling all over.
vi: Hallward was struck as if by lightning. He looked at Dorian Gray, completely astonished. He had never seen him like this. The young man was truly pale with anger. His hands were clenched, and his pupils were like discs of blue fire. He was trembling all over.
tr: Hallward looked like he had been struck by lightning. He was staring at Dorian in astonishment. He had never seen him like this before. The boy had turned deathly pale with anger. His fists were clenched, and his pupils were like rings of blue fire. He was trembling from head to toe.
es: Hallward was stunned. He looked at Dorian Gray with infinite astonishment. He had never seen him like this. The boy was livid with rage. He clenched his fists, and his pupils were like discs of blue fire. He was trembling from head to toe.

en: “Dorian!”
vi: "Dorian!"
tr: “Dorian!”
es: —Dorian!

en: “Don’t speak!”
vi: "Don't speak!"
tr: “Don't speak!”
es: —Don't say anything!

en: “But what is the matter? Of course I won’t look at it if you don’t want me to,” he said, rather coldly, turning on his heel and going over towards the window. “But, really, it seems rather absurd that I shouldn’t see my own work, especially as I am going to exhibit it in Paris in the autumn. I shall probably have to give it another coat of varnish before that, so I must see it some day, and why not to-day?”
vi: “But what is the problem?” “Of course I won't look at it if you don't want me to,” he said, quite coldly, turning on his heel and walking towards the window. “But, really, it seems quite unreasonable that I can't see my own work, especially when I'm about to exhibit it in Paris this fall. I'm certainly going to have to give it another coat of varnish before then, so I have to see it one day, and why not today?”
tr: “Well, but what's wrong with you?” The painter turned with a somewhat cold expression, saying, “If you don't want me to, of course, I won't look,” and walked towards the garden gate. “But it's truly ridiculous that I can't see my own work. Especially since I will exhibit it in Paris in the fall! Before that, I will probably need to apply a coat of varnish. So, given that I will inevitably have to see it someday, what difference does it make if I see it today?”
es: —But, what is wrong with you? Of course I'm not going to look at it if you don't want me to —he said, quite coldly, turning on his heels and approaching the window—. But it seems quite absurd to me that I can't see my own work, especially when I'm about to exhibit it in Paris in the fall. I'll probably have to give it another coat of varnish beforehand, so I'll have to see it someday, and why not today? —Expose it?

en: “To exhibit it! You want to exhibit it?” exclaimed Dorian Gray, a strange sense of terror creeping over him. Was the world going to be shown his secret? Were people to gape at the mystery of his life? That was impossible. Something—he did not know what—had to be done at once.
vi: “Exhibit it? You want to exhibit it?” Dorian Gray exclaimed, a strange feeling of dread tingling throughout his body. Is the whole world about to see his secret? Is everyone about to gape at the mystery of his life? Impossible. Something — he didn't know what — had to be done immediately.
tr: Dorian, "Exhibit it? Do you want to put it in an exhibition?" he asked, shouting slightly. A strange chill enveloped him. So, would his secret be shown to the whole world? Would everyone gawk at the mystery of his life? This couldn't be. Something had to be done immediately... though he didn't know what it was...
es: Do you want to expose it? —exclaimed Dorian Gray, feeling a strange terror engulf him. Was the world going to witness his secret? Would people be left gaping at the mystery of his life? Impossible. Something had to be done, he didn't know what yet, and it had to be done immediately.

en: “Yes; I don’t suppose you will object to that. Georges Petit is going to collect all my best pictures for a special exhibition in the Rue de Sèze, which will open the first week in October. The portrait will only be away a month. I should think you could easily spare it for that time. In fact, you are sure to be out of town. And if you keep it always behind a screen, you can’t care much about it.”
vi: "Yes; I don't think you will object to that." "George Petit is about to gather all my finest paintings for a special exhibition at Rue de Sèze, which will open in the first week of October. The portrait will only have to be away for a month." "I suppose you can easily part with it during that time." "In fact, you will certainly be out of town." "And if you always keep it behind a screen, you can't be too concerned about it."
tr: “Yes. I don't think you'll object to this. George Petit4 will gather my best paintings and open a private exhibition on Sèze Street, in the first week of October. You will be away from the portrait for only a month. I think you can easily endure this. In fact, you might even be away from London at that time. If you always keep it behind a screen, it means you don't like it very much anyway.”
es: —Yes; I hope you don't mind. George Petit is going to gather my best works for a personal exhibition on rue de Séze that will open the first week of October. The portrait will only be away for a month. I think you can do without it for that time. In fact, it's certain that you won't be in London. And if you have it behind a screen, it means you don't care too much about it.

en: Dorian Gray passed his hand over his forehead. There were beads of perspiration there. He felt that he was on the brink of a horrible danger. “You told me a month ago that you would never exhibit it,” he cried. “Why have you changed your mind? You people who go in for being consistent have just as many moods as others have. The only difference is that your moods are rather meaningless. You can’t have forgotten that you assured me most solemnly that nothing in the world would induce you to send it to any exhibition. You told Harry exactly the same thing.” He stopped suddenly, and a gleam of light came into his eyes. He remembered that Lord Henry had said to him once, half seriously and half in jest, “If you want to have a strange quarter of an hour, get Basil to tell you why he won’t exhibit your picture. He told me why he wouldn’t, and it was a revelation to me.” Yes, perhaps Basil, too, had his secret. He would ask him and try.
vi: Dorian Gray ran his hand across his forehead. There were beads of sweat there. He felt that he was on the brink of some terrible danger. “You told me a month ago that you would never exhibit it,” he cried out. “Why have you changed your mind? You are one of those people who try to be consistent but have as many moods as others. The only difference is that your moods are quite meaningless. You cannot forget that you solemnly assured me that nothing in the world would induce you to send it to any exhibition. You also told Harry the same thing.” He stopped abruptly and a flash of light appeared in his eyes. He remembered that Lord Henry had once told him, half in earnest, half in jest, “if you want to have fifteen strange minutes, ask Basil to tell you why he won’t exhibit your picture. He told me why he wouldn’t, and it was a revelation to me.” Well, perhaps Basil had his own secret. He would ask him and see what happened.
tr: Dorian passed his hand over his forehead. Sweat had beaded on his skin. He felt he was on the brink of a terrible danger. “A month ago you were saying you would never exhibit the portrait,” he retorted. “Why did you change your mind? People like you, who pride themselves on consistency, are just as fickle as others, to be honest. The difference is that your changes seem quite meaningless. You can't have forgotten, you had solemnly promised me that you would never exhibit my painting for any reason. You had told Harry the same thing.” Dorian suddenly stopped, a sparkle lit up in his eyes. Something Lord Henry had once said half-jokingly, half-seriously came to his mind: “If you want to spend a baffling half hour, ask Basil to explain why he won't exhibit your portrait. He explained it to me, and my eyes were wide open.” Yes, maybe Basil had a secret too. He should ask and probe.
es: Dorian Gray ran his hand across his forehead, where droplets of sweat had appeared. He felt on the edge of a dreadful abyss. —A month ago you told me you would never exhibit it —he exclaimed—. Why have you changed your mind? You people who boast about being consistent are as capricious as everyone else. The only difference is that your whims make no sense. It is not possible that you have forgotten: you assured me with all the solemnity in the world that nothing would compel you to send it to any exhibition. And you told Harry exactly the same thing. He stopped suddenly, and a special gleam appeared in his eyes. He remembered that Lord Henry had once told him, half-seriously and half-jokingly: "If you want to spend an unusual quarter of an hour, have Basil tell you why he doesn't want to exhibit your portrait. He told me, and it was quite a revelation." Yes; perhaps Basil also had his secret. What if he tried to question him?

en: “Basil,” he said, coming over quite close and looking him straight in the face, “we have each of us a secret. Let me know yours, and I shall tell you mine. What was your reason for refusing to exhibit my picture?”
vi: "Basil," he said, coming very close and looking straight into his face, "each of us has a secret. Tell me yours and I will tell you mine. What is the reason you refuse to exhibit my painting?"
tr: Going right up to the painter and looking directly into his face, Dorian said, “Basil.” “We both have our own secrets. Tell me yours, and I’ll tell you mine. What was the reason you opposed exhibiting my portrait?”
es: —Basil —he said, coming very close and looking him straight in the eyes—, we both have a secret. Tell me yours and I will tell you mine. What reason did you have for refusing to exhibit the portrait?

en: The painter shuddered in spite of himself. “Dorian, if I told you, you might like me less than you do, and you would certainly laugh at me. I could not bear your doing either of those two things. If you wish me never to look at your picture again, I am content. I have always you to look at. If you wish the best work I have ever done to be hidden from the world, I am satisfied. Your friendship is dearer to me than any fame or reputation.”
vi: The artist trembled, unable to control himself. "Dorian, if I tell you, you might like me less than you do now, and surely you will laugh at me. I cannot bear you doing either of these things. If you want me to never look at your painting again, I am willing. I always have you to look at. If you want the most beautiful work I have ever done to be hidden from the world, I am willing. Your friendship is more precious to me than any fame or reputation."
tr: The painter couldn't help but shudder. “Dorian, if I explain, you might not love me as you used to; you will definitely mock me. I can't endure either of those. If you don't want me to look at your portrait again, that's enough for me. I'll look at you instead. If you want the best painting I've ever done in my life to be hidden from eyes, I have nothing to say. Your friendship is more valuable to me than fame or glory.”
es: The painter shuddered despite himself. —If I told you, it might diminish the appreciation you have for me, and without a doubt, you would laugh at me. It is unbearable for me that either of those two things happen. If you don't want me to see the painting again, I accept it. I can always look at you. If you want my best work to remain hidden from the world, I am satisfied. Your friendship is more important to me than fame or reputation.

en: “No, Basil, you must tell me,” insisted Dorian Gray. “I think I have a right to know.” His feeling of terror had passed away, and curiosity had taken its place. He was determined to find out Basil Hallward’s mystery.
vi: "No, Basil, you must tell me," Dorian Gray insisted. "I think I have the right to know." His sense of dread had vanished, and curiosity took its place. He was determined to uncover Basil Hallward's secret.
tr: “No, Basil, tell me,” insisted Dorian. “I believe it is my right to know.” The earlier feeling of fear had vanished, replaced by curiosity. He was determined to uncover Basil Hallward’s secret.
es: —No, Basil; you have to tell me —insisted Dorian Gray—. I think I have the right to know it —the feeling of terror had disappeared, replaced by curiosity. He was determined to uncover the mystery of Basil Hallward.

en: “Let us sit down, Dorian,” said the painter, looking troubled. “Let us sit down. And just answer me one question. Have you noticed in the picture something curious?—something that probably at first did not strike you, but that revealed itself to you suddenly?”
vi: “Let's sit down, Dorian,” the artist said, looking worried. “Let's sit down. And just answer me one question. Do you notice anything strange about the painting? — something that perhaps didn't strike you at first, but suddenly revealed itself to you?”
tr: The painter said with a nervous expression, "Dorian, let's sit down." "Let's sit down. Answer me one question. Did you notice anything strange in the painting? Perhaps something that didn't catch your eye at first but suddenly struck you later?"
es: "Let's sit down, Dorian," said the painter with a worried expression. “Sit down and answer me just one question. Have you noticed anything peculiar in the painting? Something that you probably didn't notice at first, but that has suddenly revealed itself to you?”

en: “Basil!” cried the lad, clutching the arms of his chair with trembling hands and gazing at him with wild startled eyes.
vi: "Basil!" the young man cried out, clutching the arm of the chair with a trembling hand, and staring at him with wild, startled eyes.
tr: With trembling hands, Dorian clung to the edges of his chair and looked at the man in front of him with startled, wild eyes, speaking in a groan, "Basil!"
es: —Basil! —exclaimed the boy, gripping the arms of the chair with trembling hands, and looking at him with eyes more filled with fear than with surprise.

en: “I see you did. Don’t speak. Wait till you hear what I have to say. Dorian, from the moment I met you, your personality had the most extraordinary influence over me. I was dominated, soul, brain, and power, by you. You became to me the visible incarnation of that unseen ideal whose memory haunts us artists like an exquisite dream. I worshipped you. I grew jealous of every one to whom you spoke. I wanted to have you all to myself. I was only happy when I was with you. When you were away from me, you were still present in my art.... Of course, I never let you know anything about this. It would have been impossible. You would not have understood it. I hardly understood it myself. I only knew that I had seen perfection face to face, and that the world had become wonderful to my eyes—too wonderful, perhaps, for in such mad worships there is peril, the peril of losing them, no less than the peril of keeping them.... Weeks and weeks went on, and I grew more and more absorbed in you. Then came a new development. I had drawn you as Paris in dainty armour, and as Adonis with huntsman’s cloak and polished boar-spear. Crowned with heavy lotus-blossoms you had sat on the prow of Adrian’s barge, gazing across the green turbid Nile. You had leaned over the still pool of some Greek woodland and seen in the water’s silent silver the marvel of your own face. And it had all been what art should be—unconscious, ideal, and remote. One day, a fatal day I sometimes think, I determined to paint a wonderful portrait of you as you actually are, not in the costume of dead ages, but in your own dress and in your own time. Whether it was the realism of the method, or the mere wonder of your own personality, thus directly presented to me without mist or veil, I cannot tell. But I know that as I worked at it, every flake and film of colour seemed to me to reveal my secret. I grew afraid that others would know of my idolatry. I felt, Dorian, that I had told too much, that I had put too much of myself into it. Then it was that I resolved never to allow the picture to be exhibited. You were a little annoyed; but then you did not realize all that it meant to me. Harry, to whom I talked about it, laughed at me. But I did not mind that. When the picture was finished, and I sat alone with it, I felt that I was right.... Well, after a few days the thing left my studio, and as soon as I had got rid of the intolerable fascination of its presence, it seemed to me that I had been foolish in imagining that I had seen anything in it, more than that you were extremely good-looking and that I could paint. Even now I cannot help feeling that it is a mistake to think that the passion one feels in creation is ever really shown in the work one creates. Art is always more abstract than we fancy. Form and colour tell us of form and colour—that is all. It often seems to me that art conceals the artist far more completely than it ever reveals him. And so when I got this offer from Paris, I determined to make your portrait the principal thing in my exhibition. It never occurred to me that you would refuse. I see now that you were right. The picture cannot be shown. You must not be angry with me, Dorian, for what I have told you. As I said to Harry, once, you are made to be worshipped.”
vi: "I realize that you have already seen it. Don't speak. Wait until you have heard what I have to say. Dorian, from the moment I met you, your personality has had an extraordinarily special influence on me. I was dominated by you, soul, intellect, and power. To me, you became the tangible embodiment of the ideal type that the memory of them still haunts us artists like a wonderful dream. I worship you. I gradually became jealous of anyone you talked to. I wanted to have you entirely for myself. I was only happy when I was with you. But when you were away from me, you were still present in my art... Of course, I never let you know about this. Perhaps it was impossible. Perhaps you would not understand. I myself hardly understood. I only knew that I had come face to face with absolute beauty, and that the world became wondrous before my eyes — too wondrous, perhaps, for in these mad adorations there is danger, the danger of losing them, no less than the danger of keeping them... Week after week went by, and I was drawn more and more to you. Then came a new development. I painted you as Paris in beautiful armor, as Adonis with a hunter's cloak and a gleaming boar spear. Wearing a heavy lotus crown, you sat on the prow of Adrian's flagship, gazing across the muddy blue Nile. You bent over a still pond in some Greek forest, and saw in the quiet silver of the water your own wondrous face. And it was everything that art should become, unconscious, ideal, distant. One day, a day that I sometimes think was disastrous, I decided to paint a magnificent portrait of you as you actually are, not in the costume of dead ages, but in your own clothes and in your own time. Whether it was Realism in the painting style, or just the surprise of your personality appearing so directly before me, without any mist or veil, I cannot tell. But I knew that as I worked on it, it seemed as if every stroke and patch of color revealed my secret. I gradually became afraid that others might know about my idol worship. I felt, Dorian, that I had told too much, that I had put too much of myself into it. That was when I decided never to allow the painting to be exhibited. You were slightly annoyed; but at that time you did not realize what all this meant to me. Harry, with whom I discussed it, laughed at me. But I did not mind. When the painting was finished, and I sat alone with it, I felt that I was right... Then, a few days after it left my studio, and just after I escaped the unbearable enchantment of its presence, it seemed to me that I had been foolish to imagine that I had ever seen anything in it more than the fact that you are extraordinarily handsome, and I could paint that. Even now I cannot help feeling that it was a mistake to think that the passion we feel in creation ever really shows itself in the work we create. Art is always more abstract than we imagine. Form and color tell us about form and color — that is all. I often think that art conceals the artist far more completely than it ever reveals them. And so when I received this invitation from Paris, I decided to make your portrait the principal work in my exhibition. Never did it occur to me that you would refuse. Now I see that you were right. The painting should not be displayed. You should not be angry with me, Dorian, for what I have told you. As I once told Harry, you were made to be worshipped."
tr: “I see that it has been so. Do not say anything. Wait and listen to what I have to say. Dorian, from the moment I met you, your personality had an extraordinarily profound effect on me. My soul, my mind, my artistic power came under your dominion. There is an invisible ideal, the memory of which, like a unique dream, never leaves us artists. And you became the visible, living symbol of this ideal for me. I worshipped you. I became jealous of everyone you spoke to. I wanted to keep you entirely to myself. I was only happy when I was with you. When you were away from me, I found your presence in my art...Of course, I did not let you sense any of this. It was impossible. You could not have understood. I myself could not fully understand. I only knew that I had seen perfection face to face, and the world had taken on a marvelous appearance. Perhaps it had become too marvelous, because such a mad worship is fraught with dangers: the danger of losing what is worshipped as much as the danger of being able to keep it...Weeks added to weeks, and I gave myself more and more to you. Then a new development occurred. I had drawn you as Paris in elegant armor; as Adonis with a hunter's cloak and a shining spear in hand. You had sat crowned with heavy water lilies at the bow of Hadrian's boat, watching the murky green waters of the Nile. You had bent over a still pool in a Greek grove and seen your face in the silent silver of the water. All of this happened in a manner entirely suitable to art: ideal, distant, unconscious... Then one day, on what I might call an ominous day, I decided to draw your portrait as you truly are. I would draw you not in the costumes of past ages but in your own time, in your own clothes. I do not know if it was the realism in the method that pushed me to take you directly, away from veils and mists. What I do know is that every speck of paint, every shade of color that appeared while working on this portrait seemed to reveal my secret. I began to fear that others would understand this idolatrous side of me. Dorian, I sensed that I had said too much with this portrait, that I had put too much of myself into it. That is when I decided never to allow the painting to be exhibited. You were a bit upset by this; you could not know what the painting meant to me. I talked about it with Harry, he laughed at me, but I did not care. As I sat in front of the painting after finishing it, I felt that my decision was right...Anyway, a few days later, the portrait left my studio. When the unbearable enchantment of your presence lifted from me, I began to think that it was madness to believe I saw something special in this painting. All it was, was that you were extraordinarily handsome, and I was a good painter, that's all. It is wrong to think that the passion one feels while creating always reflects in the created work as it is. I still hold this view. Art is always more abstract than we think. Form and color tell us about form and color, that's all. Often it seems to me that instead of revealing the artist, art completely hides him from view. That's how it is. When I received this proposal from Paris, I decided to make your portrait the masterpiece of my exhibition. It never occurred to me that you would oppose it. But now I see that you are right. This painting cannot be exhibited. Dorian, do not be angry with me for what I have told you. As I once told Harry, you were created to be worshipped.”
es: —I see that you do. Don't say anything. Wait to hear what I have to say. From the moment I met you, your personality has had the most extraordinary influence on me. You have dominated my soul, my brain, my energies. You became the tangible embodiment of that unseen ideal whose memory haunts artists like an ineffable dream. I idolized you. I felt jealous of everyone you spoke to. I wanted you for myself alone. I was only happy when I was with you. And when you were away from me, you were still present in my art... Of course, I never let you know any of this. It would have been impossible. You wouldn't have understood it. I barely understood it myself. I only knew that I had seen perfection face to face, and that, before my eyes, the world had become something wonderful; too wonderful, perhaps, because in such excessive adoration there is a danger, the danger of losing it, no less serious than that of keeping it... Weeks and weeks passed, and I was more and more absorbed in you every day. Then something new happened. I had drawn you as Paris in a delicate armor, and as Adonis with a hunter's cloak and a polished spear. Crowned with lotus flowers at the prow of Hadrian's barge, looking towards the other shore over the green murky waters of the Nile. Bent over a still pond in some Greek forest, you had seen in the silent silver of the water the wonder of your own face. And everything had been, as befits art, unconscious, ideal, and remote. One day, a fateful day, I sometimes think, I decided to paint a wonderful portrait of you as you are, not in the garments of dead ages, but in your clothes and in your time. I don't know if it was the realism of the method or the very wonder of your personality, which presented itself to me then without intermediaries, without fog or veil. But I know that while I was working on it, with each brushstroke, with each touch of color, it seemed to me that I was revealing my secret. I was afraid that others would notice my idolatry. I realized that I had said too much, that I had put too much of myself into that painting. I then decided not to allow the portrait to ever be exhibited in public. You were a little upset; but you didn't realize all that it meant to me. Harry, to whom I spoke about it, laughed at me. But I didn't care. When the painting was finished, and I was alone with it, I felt that I was right... Then, a few days later, the canvas left my studio, and as soon as I was freed from the intolerable fascination of its presence, it seemed absurd to imagine that there was anything special about it, apart from the fact that you were very handsome and that I was capable of painting. Even now I can't help but think that it is a mistake to believe that the passion felt during creation truly appears in the created work. Art is always more abstract than we imagine. Form and color only speak of themselves..., that's all. It often seems to me that art hides the artist much more than it reveals him. So when I received the invitation from Paris, I decided to make your portrait the main piece of my exhibition. It never occurred to me that you would refuse. Now I understand that you were right. The portrait cannot be shown. Don't be angry with me for what I've told you, Dorian. As I once told Harry, you are made to be adored.

en: Dorian Gray drew a long breath. The colour came back to his cheeks, and a smile played about his lips. The peril was over. He was safe for the time. Yet he could not help feeling infinite pity for the painter who had just made this strange confession to him, and wondered if he himself would ever be so dominated by the personality of a friend. Lord Henry had the charm of being very dangerous. But that was all. He was too clever and too cynical to be really fond of. Would there ever be some one who would fill him with a strange idolatry? Was that one of the things that life had in store?
vi: Dorian Gray took a deep breath. Color returned to his cheeks, and a playful smile appeared on his lips. The danger had passed. He was safe now. However, he couldn't help but feel an infinite pity for the artist who had just made this strange confession to him, and wondered if he himself would ever be dominated by the personality of a friend like that. Lord Henry had a charm that was extremely dangerous. But that was all. He was too wise and too mocking to love sincerely. Would there ever be someone who made him feel a strange idol worship? Was life destined to give him such a person?
tr: Dorian Gray took a deep breath. The color returned to his face, a smile flickered on his lips. The danger had passed. For now, he was safe. Nevertheless, he couldn't help but feel an infinite pity for the painter who made this strange confession to him, and he wondered, "Will I ever fall under the dominance of a friend's personality like this?" Lord Henry had the allure of being very dangerous. But that was all. He was so excessively intelligent, so excessively cynical that one couldn't truly love him. Would anyone ever come into his life who could evoke such an idolatrously strange attachment within him? Was this one of the things life had prepared for him?
es: Dorian Gray took a deep breath. His cheeks regained their color and his lips played with a smile. The danger had passed. For the moment, he was safe. But he couldn't help feeling an infinite pity for the painter who had just made that strange confession to him, while wondering if he would ever feel so dominated by the personality of a friend. Lord Henry had the charm of being very dangerous. But nothing more. He was too intelligent and too cynical for anyone to feel a passionate affection for him. Would there ever be someone who would inspire in him, in Dorian Gray, such strange idolatry? Was that one of the things life had in store for him?

en: “It is extraordinary to me, Dorian,” said Hallward, “that you should have seen this in the portrait. Did you really see it?”
vi: “I find it extraordinary,” Hallward said, “that you can see this in the portrait. Do you really see it?”
tr: Hallward added, "I think it's surprising that you saw these things in the portrait." "Did you really see them?"
es: —It seems extraordinary to me, Dorian —continued Hallward—, that you have discovered my secret in the portrait. Have you really seen it?

en: “I saw something in it,” he answered, “something that seemed to me very curious.”
vi: “I see something on it,” he replied, “something that seems very strange to me.”
tr: Dorian replied, "I saw something." "I saw something that struck me as very strange."
es: —I saw something in him —replied the young man—; something that seemed extremely curious to me.

en: “Well, you don’t mind my looking at the thing now?”
vi: “Really? Do you mind if I watch it now?”
tr: “Do you think there's any harm in me looking now?”
es: —Well; now you won't mind if I see it, right?

en: Dorian shook his head. “You must not ask me that, Basil. I could not possibly let you stand in front of that picture.”
vi: Dorian shook his head. "You shouldn't ask me that, Basil. I can't let you stand in front of that painting."
tr: Dorian shook his head. "Don't ask this of me, Basil. I can't let you stand in front of that picture, not in this world."
es: Dorian shook his head. —Don't ask me that, Basil. I can't allow you to see that painting face to face.

en: “You will some day, surely?”
vi: “You will give it, someday, won't you?”
tr: “But one day you'll allow it, right?”
es: —But a day will come when it will.

en: “Never.”
vi: "Never."
tr: “Never.”
es: —Never.

en: “Well, perhaps you are right. And now good-bye, Dorian. You have been the one person in my life who has really influenced my art. Whatever I have done that is good, I owe to you. Ah! you don’t know what it cost me to tell you all that I have told you.”
vi: “Well, that's fine, maybe you are right. Now, goodbye, Dorian. You are the only person in my life who has truly influenced my art. Whatever I do that is good, I owe it to you. Ah! You have no idea the price I had to pay to be able to tell you everything I just told you.”
tr: “I don't know, maybe you're right. Now, goodbye, Dorian. You are the only person who has truly influenced my art in my life. Whatever good work I have produced, I owe it to you. Ah, Dorian, you can't imagine what it cost me to say all these things to you.”
es: —Well; perhaps you are right. I bid you farewell. You have been the only person who has truly influenced my art. If I have done anything worthwhile, I owe it to you. Ah! You don't know how much it has cost me to tell you everything I have told you.

en: “My dear Basil,” said Dorian, “what have you told me? Simply that you felt that you admired me too much. That is not even a compliment.”
vi: “My dear Basil,” Dorian said, “what did you say to me? You just feel that you admire me a lot. That is not even a compliment.”
tr: Dorian said, "Dear Basil, what did you tell me?" "You only said that you admired me excessively. That's not even a compliment."
es: —My dear Basil —replied Dorian—, what is it that you have told me? Simply, that it seemed to you that you admired me too much. That doesn't even amount to a compliment.

en: “It was not intended as a compliment. It was a confession. Now that I have made it, something seems to have gone out of me. Perhaps one should never put one’s worship into words.”
vi: “It was not meant as a compliment. It was a confession. Now, because I have expressed it, something seems to have left me. Perhaps one should never put their adoration into words.”
tr: “It wasn't said as a compliment anyway. It was a confession. Now that I've made this confession, it feels like something inside me has extinguished. Maybe one should never put the feeling of reverence into words.”
es: —It was not my intention to compliment you. It was a confession. Now that I have made it, I feel like I have lost something of myself. Perhaps one should never translate a feeling of adoration into words.

en: “It was a very disappointing confession.”
vi: “That is a very disappointing confession.”
tr: “It was a disappointing confession for me.”
es: —It has been a very disappointing confession.

en: “Why, what did you expect, Dorian? You didn’t see anything else in the picture, did you? There was nothing else to see?”
vi: “What do you mean, what are you expecting, Dorian? You don't see anything different in the painting, do you? Is there nothing else to see?”
tr: "How? What were you expecting, Dorian? Did you see something else in the portrait? But there was nothing else to see. Isn't that right?"
es: —What did you expect, Dorian? You haven't seen anything else in the picture, have you? Was there anything else to see?

en: “No; there was nothing else to see. Why do you ask? But you mustn’t talk about worship. It is foolish. You and I are friends, Basil, and we must always remain so.”
vi: “No; there is nothing else to see. Why do you ask that? But don't talk about worship. It is really silly. You and I are friends, Basil, and we should remain so forever.”
tr: “No, there was nothing else. Why did you ask? And don't talk so much about worshipping, Basil. These are foolish words. You and I are friends, and we should always remain friends.”
es: —No, there was nothing else. Why do you ask? But you must not speak of worship. It makes no sense. You and I are friends, and we must always remain so.

en: “You have got Harry,” said the painter sadly.
vi: "You have Harry," the artist said, sadly.
tr: The painter said in a sad voice, "Harry is your friend."
es: "You have Harry," said the painter sadly.

en: “Oh, Harry!” cried the lad, with a ripple of laughter. “Harry spends his days in saying what is incredible and his evenings in doing what is improbable. Just the sort of life I would like to lead. But still I don’t think I would go to Harry if I were in trouble. I would sooner go to you, Basil.”
vi: "Oh, Harry!" the young man exclaimed, with a murmuring laugh. "Harry spends many days talking about trivial matters, and many nights doing pointless things. It's truly a way of life that I would like to experience. But I still don't think I could turn to Harry if I were in trouble. I'd rather turn to you, Basil."
tr: The young man chuckled to himself, "Ah, Harry!" "Harry spends his days saying unbelievable things, and his nights doing unimaginable things. Exactly the kind of life I want to lead. Still, I don't think I would go to Harry if I had a problem. I would prefer to come to you, Basil."
es: —Ah, Harry! —exclaimed the boy with a laugh—. Harry spends his days saying incredible things and his evenings doing improbable things. Exactly the kind of life I would like to lead. But anyway, I don't think I would go looking for Harry when I had problems. I think I would go to see you first.

en: “You will sit to me again?”
vi: "Will you sit and model for me again?"
tr: “Will you give me a gene?”
es: —Will you pose for me again?

en: “Impossible!”
vi: "Impossible!"
tr: “It's impossible.”
es: —Impossible!

en: “You spoil my life as an artist by refusing, Dorian. No man comes across two ideal things. Few come across one.”
vi: "You have spoiled my life as an artist by refusing, Dorian. No one ever meets two ideal people. Only a few ever meet one."
tr: "By rejecting this, you are sabotaging my artistic life, Dorian. No one is ever faced with two ideal things. It is rare enough for even one to appear."
es: —You destroy my life as an artist by refusing. No one stumbles upon the ideal twice. And very few even find it once.

en: “I can’t explain it to you, Basil, but I must never sit to you again. There is something fatal about a portrait. It has a life of its own. I will come and have tea with you. That will be just as pleasant.”
vi: “I can't explain it to you, Basil, but I can never sit for you again. There is something fatal about a portrait. It has its own life. I will come and have tea with you. That will be enough fun.”
tr: “I can't explain, Basil, but I must never pose for you again. Is there some kind of curse in portraits or what! It's as if the portrait has a life of its own. I'll come and have tea with you. That would be just as enjoyable.”
es: —I can't explain it to you, but I can't pose for you again. There is something fatal in a portrait. It has a life of its own. I'll go have tea with you. It will be just as pleasant.

en: “Pleasanter for you, I am afraid,” murmured Hallward regretfully. “And now good-bye. I am sorry you won’t let me look at the picture once again. But that can’t be helped. I quite understand what you feel about it.”
vi: “Happier for you, I fear so,” Hallward muttered, regretfully. “Now, goodbye. I am very sorry that you won't let me see the painting one more time. But what can be done. I understand how you feel about it.”
tr: Hallward said sadly, "I'm afraid it would only be that way for you," he murmured. "Now, goodbye. I'm sorry you didn't let me look at the painting one more time, but what can be done? I understand your feelings on this matter very well."
es: —Pleasant for you, I very much fear —murmured Hallward, sorrowful—. And now, goodbye. I regret that you won't let me see the painting once more. But what can be done. I completely understand your feelings.

en: As he left the room, Dorian Gray smiled to himself. Poor Basil! How little he knew of the true reason! And how strange it was that, instead of having been forced to reveal his own secret, he had succeeded, almost by chance, in wresting a secret from his friend! How much that strange confession explained to him! The painter’s absurd fits of jealousy, his wild devotion, his extravagant panegyrics, his curious reticences—he understood them all now, and he felt sorry. There seemed to him to be something tragic in a friendship so coloured by romance.
vi: When he left the room, Dorian Gray smiled to himself. Poor Basil! How little he knew about the real reason! And it was very strange that, instead of being forced to reveal his own secret, he had succeeded, almost by chance, in extracting a secret from his friend! That strange confession had explained so many things to him! The painter's irrational jealousies, his fervent devotion, his excessive praises, his strange silence — now he understood them all, and he felt a bit of pity. It seemed to him that there was something tragic about a friendship colored by such romance.
tr: As he went outside, Dorian smiled to himself. Poor Basil! He never knew the real reason! Then, how strange it was that, almost by chance, he managed to extract the secret from his friend's mouth, where Dorian would have had to reveal his own secret! That strange confession explained so much to Dorian! The painter's ridiculous fits of jealousy, his mad devotion, his excessive praises, his inexplicable shyness... Dorian now understood all of this, and a feeling of pity enveloped him. Wasn't there a tragic aspect to a friendship in which such a color of love was mixed?
es: As he watched him leave the room, Dorian Gray couldn't help but smile. Poor Basil! How far he was from knowing the real reason! And how strange it was that, instead of being forced to reveal his own secret, he had managed, almost by chance, to extract his friend's! How many things that strange confession had explained to him! The painter's absurd fits of jealousy, his excessive devotion, his extravagant praises, his curious reticences... now he understood everything, and he felt pity. It seemed to him that there was something tragic in a friendship so close to love.

en: He sighed and touched the bell. The portrait must be hidden away at all costs. He could not run such a risk of discovery again. It had been mad of him to have allowed the thing to remain, even for an hour, in a room to which any of his friends had access.
vi: He sighed and rang the bell. The portrait had to be hidden at all costs. He couldn't risk being discovered again. He must have been out of his mind to allow this thing to remain, even for an hour, in a room where any of his friends could enter.
tr: The young man sighed deeply and rang the bell. The portrait had to be hidden at all costs. He could not risk such danger again as he did today. It had been madness to keep the painting in a room where his friends came and went, even for an hour. 4. At the end of the 19th century, the most popular art gallery was George Petit's. It was founded in 1882. It opened its doors to many different movements and exhibited the Impressionists during their initial successful period.
es: He sighed and rang the bell. He had to hide the portrait at all costs. He couldn't risk being discovered again. It had been madness to allow it to remain, even for an hour, in a room where his friends entered.

en: CHAPTER X.
vi: Chapter 10
tr: (Ç. N.) Tenth chapter
es: Chapter 10

en: When his servant entered, he looked at him steadfastly and wondered if he had thought of peering behind the screen. The man was quite impassive and waited for his orders. Dorian lit a cigarette and walked over to the glass and glanced into it. He could see the reflection of Victor’s face perfectly. It was like a placid mask of servility. There was nothing to be afraid of, there. Yet he thought it best to be on his guard.
vi: When his servant came in, he looked at him intently, wondering if he had thought about peeking behind the screen. The servant was quite calm, waiting for his orders. Dorian lit a cigarette, walked over to the mirror, and glanced into it. He could clearly see Victor's reflection. It was like the calm mask of a knowing slave. There was nothing to fear here. However, he thought it was better to remain cautious.
tr: When the servant entered, Dorian looked at him carefully. He wondered if the man had thought about looking behind the screen. The man stood calmly, waiting for his master's command. Dorian lit a cigarette, walked over, and glanced at the mirror. He could clearly see Victor's face reflected in the mirror. This face was like the mask of a "submissive servant." There was nothing to fear from this angle. Still, Dorian thought it best to remain vigilant.
es: When the servant entered, he looked at him intently, wondering if it had occurred to him to snoop behind the screen. Absolutely impassive, Victor awaited his orders. Dorian lit a cigarette and approached the mirror. In it, he saw the face of the valet reflected clearly, a perfect mask of servility. There was nothing to fear from that side. But he immediately thought it was better to stay on guard.

en: Speaking very slowly, he told him to tell the house-keeper that he wanted to see her, and then to go to the frame-maker and ask him to send two of his men round at once. It seemed to him that as the man left the room his eyes wandered in the direction of the screen. Or was that merely his own fancy?
vi: Speaking very slowly, he told him to inform the housekeeper that he wanted to meet her, then go to the frame maker and ask him to send two of his workers immediately. It seemed to him that when the servant left the room, his eyes glanced towards the screen. Or was that just his imagination?
tr: Speaking slowly, he told the man to summon the housekeeper to the room and then to go to the framer and send two men to the house. As the man was leaving the room, it seemed his eyes had glanced towards the screen. Or was Dorian becoming paranoid?
es: In a calm voice, he asked her to tell the housekeeper that he wanted to see her, and then to go to the marquis's shop and ask him to send two of his men immediately. It seemed to her that as she left the room, Victor's gaze shifted towards the screen. Or was it her imagination?

en: After a few moments, in her black silk dress, with old-fashioned thread mittens on her wrinkled hands, Mrs. Leaf bustled into the library. He asked her for the key of the schoolroom.
vi: A moment later, wearing a black silk dress and a pair of outdated fingerless gloves on her wrinkled hands, Mrs. Leaf hurried into the library. You asked her for the classroom key.
tr: A few minutes later, Ms. Leaf entered, wearing a black silk dress on her back, and with old-fashioned, fingerless silk gloves on her wrinkled hands. Dorian asked her for the key to the schoolroom.
es: After a moment, with her black silk dress and old-fashioned thread mittens covering her hands, Mrs. Leaf hurriedly entered the library. Dorian asked her for the key to the schoolroom.

en: “The old schoolroom, Mr. Dorian?” she exclaimed. “Why, it is full of dust. I must get it arranged and put straight before you go into it. It is not fit for you to see, sir. It is not, indeed.”
vi: “The old schoolroom, Mr. Dorian?” she exclaimed. “Why, it's full of dust. I must tidy it up and arrange it neatly before you go in. It's not suitable for you to see it now. Really, it isn't.”
tr: The woman shouted, "The old school room, Mr. Dorian?" "But it's covered in dust. I need to tidy it up a bit and put it in order before you can enter. It's not in a state to be seen, really, believe me, it's not in a state to be seen."
es: —The old classroom, Mr. Dorian? —exclaimed the housekeeper—. But it's full of dust! I have to clean and tidy up before letting you in. You can't see it as it is, no sir.

en: “I don’t want it put straight, Leaf. I only want the key.”
vi: “I don't need it to be tidied up, Leaf. I just need the key.”
tr: “I don't want it fixed, Ms. Leaf. I just want its key.”
es: —I don't want you to put things in order, Leaf. I just want the key.

en: “Well, sir, you’ll be covered with cobwebs if you go into it. Why, it hasn’t been opened for nearly five years—not since his lordship died.”
vi: “Yes, sir, but you will be covered in cobwebs if you go in there. Why is that? It hasn't been opened for nearly five years, since the old man passed away.”
tr: “But sir, if you go in there, you'll get covered in cobwebs. That room hasn't been opened in almost five years; it hasn't been opened since the Lord's death.”
es: —Whatever you say, sir, but it will be filled with cobwebs. It has been almost five years since it was last opened, since his lordship passed away.

en: He winced at the mention of his grandfather. He had hateful memories of him. “That does not matter,” he answered. “I simply want to see the place—that is all. Give me the key.”
vi: He recoiled at the mention of his grandfather. He had bitter memories of him. "It's okay," he replied. "I just want to see that place — that's all. Give me the key."
tr: Dorian flinched when his grandfather was mentioned. He had very bad memories related to his grandfather. “No harm,” he said. “I just want to take a look there, nothing else. Give me the key.”
es: Dorian made a grimace upon hearing about his grandfather. He had very bad memories of him. —It doesn't matter —he said—. I just want to see her, that's all. Give me the key.

en: “And here is the key, sir,” said the old lady, going over the contents of her bunch with tremulously uncertain hands. “Here is the key. I’ll have it off the bunch in a moment. But you don’t think of living up there, sir, and you so comfortable here?”
vi: "Here is the key, sir," the old woman said, rummaging through the bunch of keys with her two trembling, doubtful hands. "Here is the key. I will take it off the bunch right away. But you are not thinking of living up there, are you, sir, when you are so comfortable here?"
tr: The old woman, fumbling with the bunch of keys with her trembling hands, said, "Here you go, sir, here is the key." "I will take it out now. You don't want to move your room there or anything, do you, sir? You are so comfortable here.""
es: —And here it is —said the old woman, going through the contents of her bunch of keys with tremblingly uncertain hands—. This is it. I'll take it out right away. You don't think you'll live there as comfortably as you are here, do you?

en: “No, no,” he cried petulantly. “Thank you, Leaf. That will do.”
vi: “No, no,” he shouted, impatiently. “Thank you, Leaf. That's enough.”
tr: Dorian grumbled, "No way, no." "Thank you, Leaf. That's all for now."
es: —No, no —exclaimed Dorian, somewhat irritated—. Thank you very much, Leaf. That is all.

en: She lingered for a few moments, and was garrulous over some detail of the household. He sighed and told her to manage things as she thought best. She left the room, wreathed in smiles.
vi: She lingered for a moment, rambling about some minor details in the house. He sighed, telling her to handle everything as she thought was best. She left the room, smiling brightly.
tr: The housekeeper woman lingered for a few more minutes, chatting about a detail of the housework. The young man sighed and told her to manage things as she knew best. Ms. Leaf went outside with smiles.
es: The housekeeper took a few more moments to leave, elaborating on some detail of the household management. Dorian sighed and told her to manage everything as she saw fit. Finally, she left, beaming with smiles.

en: As the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and looked round the room. His eye fell on a large, purple satin coverlet heavily embroidered with gold, a splendid piece of late seventeenth-century Venetian work that his grandfather had found in a convent near Bologna. Yes, that would serve to wrap the dreadful thing in. It had perhaps served often as a pall for the dead. Now it was to hide something that had a corruption of its own, worse than the corruption of death itself—something that would breed horrors and yet would never die. What the worm was to the corpse, his sins would be to the painted image on the canvas. They would mar its beauty and eat away its grace. They would defile it and make it shameful. And yet the thing would still live on. It would be always alive.
vi: When the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and looked around the room. His eyes noticed a large satin bedspread, richly embroidered in gold, a splendid work from late seventeenth-century Venice that his grandfather had found in a nunnery near Bologna. Yes, it would be used to wrap that horrible thing. It might have once been frequently used as a shroud for the dead. Now it concealed something with its own decay, worse than the decay of death itself — something that would produce fears but never die. What worms do to a corpse, so would his sins do to the image painted on the canvas. They would mar its beauty, consume its grace. They would defile it, make it shameful. Yet it would continue to live. It would live on forever.
tr: When the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and looked around. A heavy, gold-embroidered, wide, purple satin cover caught his eye. This cover, a magnificent Venetian embroidery from the late seventeenth century, had been found by his grandfather in a monastery near Bologna. Yes, it was suitable to cover that dreadful thing. Perhaps it had generally been used to cover a corpse. Now it would serve to hide something that carried its own kind of decay; something that carried a decay worse than death's decay, something that continually spawned horrors yet never died. What worms and maggots are to a corpse in the ground, Dorian's sins would be to the painted image on the canvas. Sins would mar this image's beauty, gnaw at its delicacy. They would defile this image, turn it into something obscene. But the portrait would still continue to live. It would always remain alive.
es: As the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and scanned the library with his eyes. His eyes stopped on a large purple satin bedspread with gold embroidery that his grandfather had found in a convent near Bologna. Yes; it would serve to wrap the horrible canvas. Perhaps it had been used more than once as a shroud. Now it would have to hide something with a peculiar corruption, worse than that of the dead: something that would spawn horrors without ever dying. What worms were to the corpse, his sins would be to the image painted on the canvas, destroying its comeliness and devouring its grace. They would stain it, turning it into something shameful. And yet that thing would remain alive, it would live forever.

en: He shuddered, and for a moment he regretted that he had not told Basil the true reason why he had wished to hide the picture away. Basil would have helped him to resist Lord Henry’s influence, and the still more poisonous influences that came from his own temperament. The love that he bore him—for it was really love—had nothing in it that was not noble and intellectual. It was not that mere physical admiration of beauty that is born of the senses and that dies when the senses tire. It was such love as Michelangelo had known, and Montaigne, and Winckelmann, and Shakespeare himself. Yes, Basil could have saved him. But it was too late now. The past could always be annihilated. Regret, denial, or forgetfulness could do that. But the future was inevitable. There were passions in him that would find their terrible outlet, dreams that would make the shadow of their evil real.
vi: He shuddered and, for a moment, regretted not telling Basil the real reason why he wanted to hide the painting. Basil would help him resist the influence of Lord Henry, and the even more harmful influences stemming from his own temperament. The love that he cherished for him — because it was true love — had nothing in it that was not noble and intellectual. It was not merely the natural admiration for beauty, an admiration that is born from the senses and also dies when the senses grow weary. It was the kind of love that Michael Angelo, Montaigne, Winckelmann, and even Shakespeare had known. Yes, Basil could have saved him. But now it was too late. The past can always be destroyed. Regret, denial, or forgetfulness can do that. But the future is inevitable. The passions within him would find their terrible outlet, the dreams would turn their shadow of guilt into reality.
tr: The young man shivered from head to toe, regretting for a moment that he hadn't told Basil the real reason for wanting to keep the portrait a secret. Basil would have helped him resist falling under Lord Henry's influence or becoming a prisoner of his own hedonism. In Basil's love for him – for it truly was love – there was nothing base or unspiritual. It was not a mere physical admiration for beauty. Such admiration is born of the senses and dies when the senses grow weary. No, this was the kind of love that Michelangelo had experienced, the kind that Montaigne, Winckelmann, and even Shakespeare had known. Yes, yes, if he had told him, Basil could have saved him. But now it was too late. The past could always be erased. This could be achieved through remorse, forgetfulness, and denial. But the future was inevitable. Within Dorian lay passions that would eventually find their dreadful outlets, dreams that would turn the shadows of his vices into reality.
es: Dorian shuddered and for a few moments regretted not having told Basil the real reason for hiding the portrait. The painter would have helped him resist the influence of Lord Henry, and another, even more poisonous one, that came from his own temperament. In the love that Basil professed for him—because it was true love—there was nothing that was not noble and intellectual. It was not the simple admiration of beauty that arises from the senses and dies when the senses grow tired. It was a love like that known by Michelangelo, and Montaigne, and Winckelmann, and Shakespeare himself. Yes, Basil could have saved him. But it was already too late. The past could always be annihilated. Repentance, rejection, or forgetfulness could do it. But the future was inevitable. There were passions in him that would find their terrible incarnation, dreams that would make real the shadow of his perversity.

en: He took up from the couch the great purple-and-gold texture that covered it, and, holding it in his hands, passed behind the screen. Was the face on the canvas viler than before? It seemed to him that it was unchanged, and yet his loathing of it was intensified. Gold hair, blue eyes, and rose-red lips—they all were there. It was simply the expression that had altered. That was horrible in its cruelty. Compared to what he saw in it of censure or rebuke, how shallow Basil’s reproaches about Sibyl Vane had been!—how shallow, and of what little account! His own soul was looking out at him from the canvas and calling him to judgement. A look of pain came across him, and he flung the rich pall over the picture. As he did so, a knock came to the door. He passed out as his servant entered.
vi: He picked up the large purple-and-gold cloth from the divan that was covering it, and, holding the cloth in both hands, walked behind the screen. Had the face on the canvas become more vile than before? It seemed to him that it had not changed; however, his hatred for it had increased. Blonde hair, blue eyes, rosy-red lips — they were all still there. Only the expression had changed. There was something terrible in its cruelty. Compared to what he saw in it of criticism or reproach, how superficial — how shallow and absurd — Basil's rebukes about Sibyl Vane seemed! His soul was looking at him from the canvas and demanding that he be judged. A look of pain appeared on his face, and he flung the magnificent funeral cloth over the painting. As he did so, a knock sounded at the door. He stepped out as the servant entered.
tr: He took the large, embroidered, purple cover from the divan; with the cover in his hand, he went behind the screen. Did the face on the canvas bear a lower expression than before? The painting seemed unchanged to his eye, yet his disgust towards this object had intensified. Golden hair, blue eyes, rose-red lips... Everything was in its place. The only thing that had changed was the expression. This expression was now so cruel that it sent shivers down his spine. Compared to the criticism and condemnation he found in this expression, Basil's reproaches about Sibyl Vane seemed so weak, so feeble and insignificant! It was his own soul looking at him, judging him from the canvas. Dorian, grimacing in pain, hung the magnificent cover over the painting. Just then, there was a knock at the door. As the servant entered, Dorian emerged from behind the screen.
es: Dorian removed the large purple and gold cloth that covered the sofa and, with it in his hands, went behind the screen. Had the face on the canvas degraded even more? It seemed to him that it had not changed; however, the repulsion it inspired in him was increasing. Golden hair, blue eyes, burning lips: everything was there. Only the expression was different. Its cruelty frightened him. Compared to what he discovered there of censure and condemnation, how superficial Basil's reproaches about Sibyl Vane were! Superficial and trivial. His very soul looked at him from the canvas, calling him to judgment. Painfully affected, Dorian threw the luxurious shroud over the painting. As he did so, there was a knock at the door. He came out from behind the screen as the servant entered.

en: “The persons are here, Monsieur.”
vi: “They have arrived, sir.”
tr: "The men have arrived, monsieur."
es: —Sir, those people have arrived.

en: He felt that the man must be got rid of at once. He must not be allowed to know where the picture was being taken to. There was something sly about him, and he had thoughtful, treacherous eyes. Sitting down at the writing-table he scribbled a note to Lord Henry, asking him to send him round something to read and reminding him that they were to meet at eight-fifteen that evening.
vi: You felt that this servant had to be dismissed immediately. You must not let him know where the painting is about to be taken. There was something cunning about him, and he had deep, deceitful eyes. Sitting down at the writing desk, you hastily wrote a short letter to Lord Henry, asking him to send you something to read, and reminding him that they would meet at eight fifteen tonight.
tr: Dorian thought that he should get rid of this man immediately. There was a slyness in the man; his eyes looked deceitful and cunning. Dorian sat at his writing desk and scribbled a note to Lord Henry, asking him to send something to read, then reminded him that they would meet at a quarter past eight that evening.
es: Dorian felt that he had to get rid of Victor as soon as possible. He must not know where the painting was being taken. There was something malicious about him, and in his eyes shone calculation and betrayal. Sitting at the desk, he quickly drafted a note to Lord Henry, asking him to send some reading material and reminding him that they had agreed to meet at a quarter past eight.

en: “Wait for an answer,” he said, handing it to him, “and show the men in here.”
vi: “Wait for a response,” he said, handing it to him, “and bring them in here.”
tr: Handing the note to his servant, he said, "Wait for the reply." "Also, bring the men here."
es: —Wait for the response —he said to the valet as he handed him the letter—, and let those men in here.

en: In two or three minutes there was another knock, and Mr. Hubbard himself, the celebrated frame-maker of South Audley Street, came in with a somewhat rough-looking young assistant. Mr. Hubbard was a florid, red-whiskered little man, whose admiration for art was considerably tempered by the inveterate impecuniosity of most of the artists who dealt with him. As a rule, he never left his shop. He waited for people to come to him. But he always made an exception in favour of Dorian Gray. There was something about Dorian that charmed everybody. It was a pleasure even to see him.
vi: After two or three minutes, there was another knock, and it was Mr. Hubbard, the renowned frame-maker from South Audley Street, who entered with a slightly clumsy young assistant. Mr. Hubbard was a small, rosy man with long red sideburns, whose admiration for art had been significantly restrained by the chronic poverty of most of the artists he dealt with. As a rule, he never left his shop. He waited for people to come to him. But he always made an exception to show his affection for Dorian Gray. There was something about Dorian that charmed everyone. Even just seeing him made them happy.
tr: A few minutes later, the door knocked again and Mr. Hubbard, the famous framer from South Audley Street, entered. He was accompanied by a rough-looking young assistant. Mr. Hubbard was a man with a red face and red beard. The unchanging poverty of the artists who were his clients served to temper his admiration for art. He generally never left his shop, waiting for others to come to him. But he always made an exception for Dorian Gray. Dorian had a charm that captivated everyone. Just seeing him was a pleasure in itself.
es: Two or three minutes later, there was another knock at the door, and Mr. Hubbard himself, the famous framer from South Audley Street, entered with a rather coarse-looking young assistant. Mr. Hubbard was a little man with a ruddy complexion and red sideburns, whose enthusiasm for art was tempered by the persistent lack of resources of most of the artists he dealt with. He never left his shop in principle. He waited for customers to come to see him. But he always made an exception for Mr. Gray. There was something about Dorian that charmed everyone. Just seeing him was a pleasure.

en: “What can I do for you, Mr. Gray?” he said, rubbing his fat freckled hands. “I thought I would do myself the honour of coming round in person. I have just got a beauty of a frame, sir. Picked it up at a sale. Old Florentine. Came from Fonthill, I believe. Admirably suited for a religious subject, Mr. Gray.”
vi: “What can I do for you, Mr. Gray?” he said, rubbing his freckled, chubby hands together. “I thought I would give myself the honor of coming here in person. I have just acquired a very beautiful frame, sir. I picked it up at an auction. Antique Florence. From Fonthill, I believe. Admirably suitable for a religious subject, Mr. Gray.”
tr: Mr. Hubbard, rubbing his plump, freckled hands together, asked, "What can I do for you, Mr. Gray?" "I did not want to miss the honor of coming to you personally. I have a frame as delicate as a girl, sir. I acquired it at an auction. Old Florentine work. If I am not mistaken, it came from Fronthill. Perfect for a religious painting, Mr. Gray."
es: —What can I do for you, Mr. Gray? —he said, rubbing his plump and freckled hands—. I thought it would be an honor for me to come in person. I have just acquired a frame that is a gem. At an auction. Ancient Florentine. I believe it comes from Fonthill. Wonderfully suitable for a religious subject, Mr. Gray.

en: “I am so sorry you have given yourself the trouble of coming round, Mr. Hubbard. I shall certainly drop in and look at the frame—though I don’t go in much at present for religious art—but to-day I only want a picture carried to the top of the house for me. It is rather heavy, so I thought I would ask you to lend me a couple of your men.”
vi: “I am very sorry that you had to come here in person, Mr. Hubbard. I will definitely drop by to see the frame — although currently, I am not very fond of religious art — but today I just need you to help me bring a painting up to the rooftop of the house. It is quite heavy, so I think I will need to borrow a few of your workers.”
tr: “I am sorry for putting you through the trouble of coming here, Mr. Hubbard. Although I am not very interested in religious paintings, I will definitely come and look at your frame. What I want today is simply to have a painting carried to the upper floor of the house. It is quite a heavy thing; that's why I thought of asking you for two helpers.”
es: —I'm very sorry that you went to so much trouble, Mr. Hubbard. I will certainly go to your establishment to see the frame, although lately, religious painting doesn't interest me much, but today it's just about getting a painting to the top of the house. It's quite heavy, and that's why I thought of asking you to lend me a couple of men.

en: “No trouble at all, Mr. Gray. I am delighted to be of any service to you. Which is the work of art, sir?”
vi: "It's no trouble at all, Mr. Gray. I'm very happy to serve you in any way. Which artwork is it, sir?"
tr: “It's no trouble at all, Mr. Gray. It is a pleasure to serve you. Where is the painting in question, sir?”
es: —It is no trouble at all, Mr. Gray. It is a joy for me to be of service to you. What is the work of art?

en: “This,” replied Dorian, moving the screen back. “Can you move it, covering and all, just as it is? I don’t want it to get scratched going upstairs.”
vi: “This one,” Dorian replied, shifting the shield. “Can you move it while still covering everything like this? I don't want it to get scratched when we take it upstairs.”
tr: Dorian said, "Here," and pulled the screen. "Will you be able to carry this with its cover and all? I don't want it to get scratched while going upstairs."
es: —This one —replied Dorian Gray, moving the screen aside—. Can you move it, with the cloth covering it, just as it is? I don't want it to get scratched on the stairs.

en: “There will be no difficulty, sir,” said the genial frame-maker, beginning, with the aid of his assistant, to unhook the picture from the long brass chains by which it was suspended. “And, now, where shall we carry it to, Mr. Gray?”
vi: "There will be nothing difficult at all, sir," the cheerful framer said and began, with the help of his assistant, to remove the painting from the long brass chains that hung it. "And now, where will we have to carry it, Mr. Gray?"
tr: The cheerful framer said, "Easy, sir," and began to remove the hooks of the long brass chains holding the portrait with his assistant. "Now... Where shall we take it, Mr. Gray?"
es: —There is no difficulty at all —said the affable framer, beginning, with the help of his subordinate, to unhook the painting from the long bronze chains from which it was suspended—. And now, Mr. Gray, where do we need to take it?

en: “I will show you the way, Mr. Hubbard, if you will kindly follow me. Or perhaps you had better go in front. I am afraid it is right at the top of the house. We will go up by the front staircase, as it is wider.”
vi: “I will show you the way, Mr. Hubbard, if you would kindly follow me. Or perhaps it would be better if you went ahead. I am afraid it is right at the top of the house. We will go up by the front stairs, as they are wider.”
tr: “Let me lead the way, Mr. Hubbard; please follow me. Or you go ahead, that's better. I'm afraid we will have to climb to the top floor. Let's take the front stairs, they are wider.”
es: —I will show you the way, Mr. Hubbard, if you would be so kind as to follow me. Or perhaps it would be better if you went ahead. I am very much afraid that the room is at the very top of the house. We will take the main staircase, which is wider.

en: He held the door open for them, and they passed out into the hall and began the ascent. The elaborate character of the frame had made the picture extremely bulky, and now and then, in spite of the obsequious protests of Mr. Hubbard, who had the true tradesman’s spirited dislike of seeing a gentleman doing anything useful, Dorian put his hand to it so as to help them.
vi: You held the door open for them, and they went through to the hall and then began to climb up. The elaborate nature of the frame made the painting extremely cumbersome, and occasionally, despite the humble protests of Mr. Hubbard, a man with the characteristic trait of all true merchants of disliking to see a nobleman do anything useful, Dorian would place his hand on it as if to help them.
tr: Dorian held the door for them, the men passed into the hall and began to climb the stairs. Due to the ornate frame, the painting was extremely bulky. Like all true craftsmen, Mr. Hubbard, who did not enjoy seeing polite gentlemen doing useful work in the slightest, had to extend his hand occasionally to help them despite his overly respectful objections.
es: He kept the door open to let them pass, they went out into the lobby and began the ascent up the stairs. The baroque ornamentation of the frame had made the portrait very bulky and, from time to time, despite the obsequious protests of Mr. Hubbard, who was horrified, as all true merchants are, by the idea of a gentleman doing something useful, Dorian tried to lend them a hand.

en: “Something of a load to carry, sir,” gasped the little man when they reached the top landing. And he wiped his shiny forehead.
vi: "It's relatively heavy to carry, sir," the small man panted as they reached the top of the stairs. And he wiped his shiny forehead.
tr: When they reached the top landing, Mr. Hubbard, out of breath, muttered, "It was quite heavy, huh!" Then he wiped his sweat-shining forehead.
es: —You can't say it's too light —said the sign maker with a breathless voice when they reached the last landing, proceeding to wipe his forehead.

en: “I am afraid it is rather heavy,” murmured Dorian as he unlocked the door that opened into the room that was to keep for him the curious secret of his life and hide his soul from the eyes of men.
vi: “I’m afraid it’s quite heavy,” Dorian muttered, as he turned the key to the door that would keep the strange secret of his life and hide his soul from the eyes of the world.
tr: Dorian, "Yes, I'm sorry, it is really quite heavy," he murmured as he opened the door to the room that would henceforth harbor the strange secret of his life, shielding his soul from foreign eyes.
es: —I'm afraid it weighs quite a bit —murmured Dorian, while, with the key that Mrs. Leaf had given him, he opened the door to the room that was going to guard the strange secret of his life and hide his soul from the eyes of men.

en: He had not entered the place for more than four years—not, indeed, since he had used it first as a play-room when he was a child, and then as a study when he grew somewhat older. It was a large, well-proportioned room, which had been specially built by the last Lord Kelso for the use of the little grandson whom, for his strange likeness to his mother, and also for other reasons, he had always hated and desired to keep at a distance. It appeared to Dorian to have but little changed. There was the huge Italian cassone, with its fantastically painted panels and its tarnished gilt mouldings, in which he had so often hidden himself as a boy. There the satinwood book-case filled with his dog-eared schoolbooks. On the wall behind it was hanging the same ragged Flemish tapestry where a faded king and queen were playing chess in a garden, while a company of hawkers rode by, carrying hooded birds on their gauntleted wrists. How well he remembered it all! Every moment of his lonely childhood came back to him as he looked round. He recalled the stainless purity of his boyish life, and it seemed horrible to him that it was here the fatal portrait was to be hidden away. How little he had thought, in those dead days, of all that was in store for him!
vi: You hadn't entered this place for more than four years — indeed, not since you first used it as a playroom when you were a child, and later as a study room when you were a bit older. It was a spacious, well-proportioned room, specially built by the last Lord Kelso for his little grandson, a boy whom he always hated and wanted to keep at a distance due to his uncanny resemblance to his mother and for other reasons as well. It appeared before Dorian's eyes without any change. Here was that enormous Italian cassone, with its beautifully painted panels and tarnished gilt moldings, in which you used to hide so often as a child. Here was the lacquered bookcase filled with your dog-eared textbooks. On the wall behind it still hung that tattered Flanders tapestry, where a faded king and queen were playing chess in a garden, while a group of falconers rode by, carrying their hooded birds on long-gloved hands. How clearly you remembered everything! Every moment of your lonely childhood came back to you as you looked around. You recalled the unstained purity of your childhood, and it seemed so terrible that this was the place where the cursed portrait would be hidden. You hadn't thought much, in those lost days, about all that had been destined for you! 1 Chest.
tr: He had not set foot in this room, which he used as a playroom when he was a child and later as a study room when he grew older, for over four years. This spacious, airy room was specially made by the late Lord Kelso for his young grandson. Due to his astonishing resemblance to his daughter and other reasons, Lord Kelso had always hated this child and wanted to keep him away from himself. Dorian found the room almost unchanged. There was the Italian cassone with its wings adorned with fanciful pictures and its gilded reliefs tarnished, where he had hidden so many times as a child. There was the yellow Indian wood bookcase, holding his school books with their dog-eared pages.
