With the blood he has in his veins, how could his background be clean? You ask me about Henry Ashton and young Perth. Did I teach one his vices and the other his depravity? If Kent's foolish son picked up his wife from the street, what does that have to do with me? If Adrian Singleton wrote his friend's name on a check, am I his guardian? I am well aware of how everyone gossips in England. The middle class expresses their moral prejudices over their greasy dinner tables, and gossip about what they call the debauchery of those above them to try to appear as if they belong to the upper class and have intimate relations with those they slander. In this country, all one needs is to be different and have a brain for every common tongue to lash out at them. And what kind of lives do those very people, who consider themselves moral, lead? My friend, you forget that we are in the homeland of hypocrisy."
tr: Dorian bit his lip and said, "Enough, Basil."" You are talking about things you know nothing about. "There was an infinite contempt in his voice. " You are asking why Berwick left the room when I entered. It is because I know everything about his life; not because he knows everything about mine. How can his record be clean with that kind of blood running through his veins? You asked me about Henry Ashton and young Perth. Did I teach one those vile passions and the other that moral depravity? If Kent's foolish son picked up a woman from the street, what is it to me? Was I supposed to set Adrian Singleton on the right path when he forged his friend's signature on a note while I was beside him? I know that in England, no one has a bone in their tongue. The middle classes express their moral prejudices at their uncouth tables. The upper classes whisper about supposed immoralities to appear as if they are part of society; they pretend to know closely the people they slander. In this country, as soon as someone is a bit distinguished, a bit intellectual, they immediately become the subject of the common people's gossip...Well, what about the lives of those who present themselves as symbols of morality? My dear friend, do not forget that we live in a country that is the homeland of hypocrisy."
es: —That's enough, Basil. You are talking about things you know nothing about —said Dorian Gray, biting his lips and with a tone of infinite contempt in his voice—. You ask me why Berwick leaves a room when I enter. It is due to everything I know about his life, not what he knows about mine. With the blood he has in his veins, how could he be a person without blemish? You ask me about Henry Ashton and young Perth. Am I the one who taught them their vices and the other his debauchery? If the fool son of Kent goes to look for his wife in the gutter, what does that have to do with me? If Adrian Singleton acknowledges a debt by signing the promissory note with the name of one of his friends, am I his guardian? I know very well to what extent the English like to talk. The middle classes air their moral prejudices in their vulgar dining rooms, and murmur about what they call the depravity of the upper classes in order to make believe they belong to good society and are intimate with the people they slander. In this country, it is enough for a man to be distinguished and intelligent for all vulgar tongues to be unleashed against him. Tell me, what kind of life do all those people who claim to be the guardians of morality lead? My dear friend, you forget that we live in the country of hypocrisy.

en: “Dorian,” cried Hallward, “that is not the question. England is bad enough I know, and English society is all wrong. That is the reason why I want you to be fine. You have not been fine. One has a right to judge of a man by the effect he has over his friends. Yours seem to lose all sense of honour, of goodness, of purity. You have filled them with a madness for pleasure. They have gone down into the depths. You led them there. Yes: you led them there, and yet you can smile, as you are smiling now. And there is worse behind. I know you and Harry are inseparable. Surely for that reason, if for none other, you should not have made his sister’s name a by-word.”
vi: “Dorian,” Hallward shouted, “that is not the issue. England is indeed quite bad, I know, and English society is all wrong. That is why I want you to be a noble person. You are not a noble person. One has the right to judge a person by the influence they exert on their friends. Your friends seem to have lost all sense of honor, of kindness, of purity. You have instilled in them a mad craving for pleasure. They have hit rock bottom. You have led them there. Yes: you have led them there, and you can still laugh, as you are laughing now. And there is something even more outrageous behind it. I know you and Harry are inseparable. Clearly for that reason, if for no other, you should not have made his sister's name a laughingstock.”
tr: Hallward scolded, "Dorian, that's not the issue." "I'm not unaware that England has its bad sides. The structure of English society is fundamentally flawed. That's why I want you to be pure and superior. You haven't been able to be so until now. We have the right to judge a person by the influence they have on their friends. It's as if your friends are losing all sense of honor, goodness, and cleanliness. You instill in them a frenzy of pleasure and indulgence. They've all fallen into the depths of an abyss. You dragged them there. Yes, you dragged them, yet you can still smile and brush it off, just like you're doing right now. And there's something even worse than that. I know that you and Harry are inseparable. If for no other reason, you should have avoided bringing disgrace to his sister's name just because of that."
es: —Dorian —exclaimed Hallward—, that is not the issue. England is not free from sin, I know, and English society has much to repent for. That is precisely the reason why I want you to be blameless. But you have not been. One can judge a person by the effect they have on their friends. Yours seem to completely lose their sense of honor, kindness, and purity. The only thing you transmit to them is an unbridled thirst for pleasure, and they do not stop until they reach the bottom of the abyss. But it is you who has led them there. Yes, it has been you, and yet you are still capable of smiling, as you are doing now. But there is still more. I know that Harry and you are inseparable. For that very reason, if for no other, you should not have allowed his sister to become the talk of the town.

en: “Take care, Basil. You go too far.”
vi: "Be careful, Basil." "You are going too far."
tr: "Take it easy, Basil. You are going too far."
es: —Careful, Basil. You are going too far.

en: “I must speak, and you must listen. You shall listen. When you met Lady Gwendolen, not a breath of scandal had ever touched her. Is there a single decent woman in London now who would drive with her in the park? Why, even her children are not allowed to live with her. Then there are other stories—stories that you have been seen creeping at dawn out of dreadful houses and slinking in disguise into the foulest dens in London. Are they true? Can they be true? When I first heard them, I laughed. I hear them now, and they make me shudder. What about your country-house and the life that is led there? Dorian, you don’t know what is said about you. I won’t tell you that I don’t want to preach to you. I remember Harry saying once that every man who turned himself into an amateur curate for the moment always began by saying that, and then proceeded to break his word. I do want to preach to you. I want you to lead such a life as will make the world respect you. I want you to have a clean name and a fair record. I want you to get rid of the dreadful people you associate with. Don’t shrug your shoulders like that. Don’t be so indifferent. You have a wonderful influence. Let it be for good, not for evil. They say that you corrupt every one with whom you become intimate, and that it is quite sufficient for you to enter a house for shame of some kind to follow after. I don’t know whether it is so or not. How should I know? But it is said of you. I am told things that it seems impossible to doubt. Lord Gloucester was one of my greatest friends at Oxford. He showed me a letter that his wife had written to him when she was dying alone in her villa at Mentone. Your name was implicated in the most terrible confession I ever read. I told him that it was absurd—that I knew you thoroughly and that you were incapable of anything of the kind. Know you? I wonder do I know you? Before I could answer that, I should have to see your soul.”
vi: “I must speak, and you must listen. You will have to listen. When I met Miss Gwendolen, not a single breath of scandal had ever touched her. But now is there even one respectable woman in London who would still ride with her in the Park? Why, even her own children are not allowed to live with her. Then there are other stories — stories that you were seen sneaking out at dawn from dreadful houses and disguising yourself to slip into the filthiest slums in London. Are they true? Can they be true? When I first heard them, I laughed. Now I hear them, and they make me shudder. And what about your country house, and the life that is lived there? Dorian, you don’t know what people say about you. I won’t tell you that I don’t want to lecture you. I remember Harry once said that everyone who turns themselves into an amateur priest for a moment always begins by saying that, and then breaks their promise. I do want to lecture you. I want you to live a life that makes the world respect you. I want you to have a clean name and a fair record. I want you to get rid of those dreadful people you are associating with. Don’t shrug like that. Don’t be so indifferent. You have a wonderful influence. Let it be for good, not for evil. They say you corrupt everyone you become intimate with, and that just your entering a house is enough to bring some shame in your wake. I don’t know if it’s true or not. How could I know? But that is what is said about you. I have been told things that seem impossible to doubt. Lord Gloucester was one of my closest friends at Oxford. He showed me the letter his wife wrote to him when she was dying alone at their villa in Mentone. Your name was mentioned in the most terrible confession I have ever read. I told him it was absurd — that I knew you well, and that you couldn’t have done anything of that kind. Know you? I wonder if I really know you? Before I can answer that, perhaps I need to see your soul.”
tr: “I have to speak, and you will have to listen whether you want to or not. When you met Lady Gwendolen, her name was spotless. But now, is there a single family woman in London who would take a walk with her in the park? What are you saying, even her children are not allowed to sit with her. Then there are other rumors: people have seen you secretly leaving notorious houses; it is observed that you go to the most vile, dirtiest dens of debauchery in London in disguise. Are these true? Could they be true? When I first heard, I laughed it off. Now, as I hear more, my hair stands on end. And your house in the countryside, what goes on there? Dorian, you don’t know what people are saying behind your back! I am not going to claim that I don’t want to give you advice. I will never forget, Harry once said that everyone who sets out to mentor starts by saying this and then contradicts it. I intend to teach you wisdom. I want you to have a respectable reputation, a clean record. I want you to get rid of those horrible people you are involved with. Don’t shrug your shoulders like that. Don’t be so indifferent. You are extraordinarily influential. Use this influence for good, not evil. They say that everyone you associate with has their morals corrupted. They say that once you step over the threshold of a house, disgrace and shame inevitably follow. Is it true or not, I don’t know. How should I know? But this is what they say about you. They say things that leave no room for doubt, Lord Glouchester was one of my closest friends when he was at Oxford. His wife wrote him a letter while she was alone on her deathbed at their villa in Mentone; he showed it to me. It was the most horrifying confession I have ever read; it implicated your name. I told my friend that it was ridiculous, that I knew you very well, that you could never do such a thing in the world. Know you? Do I really know you? To answer that, I would need to see your soul.”
es: —I must speak, and you have to listen to me. When you met Lady Gwendolen, not even the slightest shadow of scandal had touched her yet. But is there a single decent woman in London now willing to ride with her in the park? Not even her children are allowed to live with her! And then there are other rumors... rumors that say you have been seen sneaking out at dawn from dreadful houses and entering the most infamous dens in London in disguise. Are those rumors true? Can they be true? When I first heard them, I laughed. Now, when I hear them, they make me shudder. What about your house in the country and the life that is led there? You don't know what is said about you, Dorian. I'm not going to tell you that I don't want to lecture you. I remember how Harry once said that every man who, at a certain moment, decides to play the role of a priest, starts by saying that, and then proceeds to break his word. I want to lecture you. I want your life to make the world respect you. To have a spotless name and a reputation above all suspicion. To rid yourself of those terrible people you associate with. Don't shrug your shoulders once more. Don't show such indifference. You have a lot of influence. Let it be for good, not for evil. They say you corrupt everyone you become intimate with, and that when you enter a house, shame of one kind or another follows closely behind you. I don't know if it's true or not. How could I know? But that is what they say about you. I've been told things that seem impossible to doubt. Lord Gloucester was one of my best friends at Oxford. He showed me a letter his wife wrote to him when she was dying, alone, in her villa in Mentone. Your name appeared in it, mixed with the most terrible confession I have ever read. I told him it was absurd; that I knew you perfectly, and that you were incapable of anything like that. Do I know you? I wonder if it's true that I know you. Before answering, I would have to see your soul. —See my soul!

en: “To see my soul!” muttered Dorian Gray, starting up from the sofa and turning almost white from fear.
vi: "See my soul!" Dorian Gray muttered, standing up abruptly from the sofa and almost turning pale with fear.
tr: Dorian Gray, "See my soul, huh!" he muttered, jumping up from his seat. His face had turned pale with fear.
es: —murmured Dorian Gray, rising from the sofa and paling with fear.

en: “Yes,” answered Hallward gravely, and with deep-toned sorrow in his voice, “to see your soul. But only God can do that.”
vi: “Yes,” Hallward replied, solemnly, and with a deep sadness in his tone — “to see your soul. But only God can do that.”
tr: Hallward replied seriously, with a deep tone of sadness in his voice, "Yes." "To see your soul. But only God can do that."
es: —Yes —replied Hallward with great seriousness and a deeply sorrowful tone—; to see your soul. But only God can do that.

en: A bitter laugh of mockery broke from the lips of the younger man. “You shall see it yourself, to-night!” he cried, seizing a lamp from the table. “Come: it is your own handiwork. Why shouldn’t you look at it? You can tell the world all about it afterwards, if you choose. Nobody would believe you. If they did believe you, they would like me all the better for it. I know the age better than you do, though you will prate about it so tediously. Come, I tell you. You have chattered enough about corruption. Now you shall look on it face to face.”
vi: A bitter, mocking laugh escaped from the younger person's lips. "You will see it with your own eyes, tonight!" he shouted, grabbing a lamp on the table. "Go: it is something made by your own hands. Why shouldn't you look at it? Then you can tell the world all about it, if you decide to. Nobody will believe you. If they do believe you, they will like me more because of it. I understand this era better than you do, even though you will boast about it in the most boring way. Go, I tell you. You have prattled enough about decay already. Now you will see it face to face."
tr: Dorian, with a pained, mocking laugh, grabbed a lamp from the table and shouted, "You will see with your own eyes, tonight!" "Walk! It is your handiwork anyway. Why shouldn't you see it? Later, if you wish, you can tell the whole world. No one will believe you, anyway. Even if they do, they will like me even more because of it. Even if you sit and give dreary speeches, I know our age better than you do. Walk, I told you. Enough of your prattling about moral decay. Now you will see it face to face!"
es: A bitter mocking laugh escaped from the lips of his interlocutor. —You will have the chance to see it tonight! —he exclaimed, taking a lamp from the table—. Come: it is your work. Why should I hide it from you? Later you can tell the world, if you decide to do so. Nobody will believe you. If they truly believed you, they would hold me in even higher regard. I know the times we live in better than you, even though you drone on about them as tediously as you do. Come, I tell you. You have talked enough about corruption. Now you will have the chance to see it face to face.

en: There was the madness of pride in every word he uttered. He stamped his foot upon the ground in his boyish insolent manner. He felt a terrible joy at the thought that some one else was to share his secret, and that the man who had painted the portrait that was the origin of all his shame was to be burdened for the rest of his life with the hideous memory of what he had done.
vi: There is a mad pride in every word you utter. You stomp your foot on the floor with a childish insolence. You feel a terrible joy at the thought that there is someone else to share your secret, and that the person who painted the portrait, which is the source of all your shame, will have to bear the dreadful memory of what he has done for the rest of his life.
tr: In every word that fell from her lips, there was the madness of arrogance. She stomped her foot on the ground with a childish insolence. The thought of sharing her secret with someone else, knowing that the man who painted the portrait, which was the beginning of all her shame, would carry the terrible memory of his work as a burden on his shoulders for life, gave her a chilling delight.
es: The madness of pride was present in every word. Dorian Gray struck the ground with the insolence of a child. The idea that someone might share his secret filled him with a dreadful joy, especially that the man who had painted the portrait, which was the source of all his shame, would carry for the rest of his life the horrible memory of what he had done.

en: “Yes,” he continued, coming closer to him and looking steadfastly into his stern eyes, “I shall show you my soul. You shall see the thing that you fancy only God can see.”
vi: "Yes," he continued, approaching him, not taking his eyes off his stern gaze, "I will show you my soul." "You will see what you thought only God could see."
tr: The painter leaned in closer, fixing his gaze deep into his stern eyes, and added, "Yes." "I will show you my soul. You will see what you thought only God could see."
es: —Yes —he continued, getting closer to him, and staring unblinkingly into his friend's stern eyes—. I'm going to show you my soul. I'm going to show you that thing which, according to you, only God can see.

en: Hallward started back. “This is blasphemy, Dorian!” he cried. “You must not say things like that. They are horrible, and they don’t mean anything.”
vi: Hallward started back with a look of horror. "Blasphemy, Dorian!" he cried. "You must not say such things. They are horrible, and they mean nothing at all."
tr: Hallward took a step back, shouting, "You are sinning, Dorian!" "Don't talk like that. What you are saying is terrible, and nonsense."
es: Hallward instinctively stepped back. —That is blasphemy, Dorian! —he exclaimed—. You must not say such things. They are horrible, and they mean nothing.

en: “You think so?” He laughed again.
vi: "Do you think so?" He smiled again.
tr: "Is that what you think?" Dorian laughed again.
es: —Is that what you think? —replied Dorian Gray, laughing again.

en: “I know so. As for what I said to you to-night, I said it for your good. You know I have been always a stanch friend to you.”
vi: “I know that. As for what I told you tonight, I said it because I want the best for you. You know I have always been a loyal friend to you.”
tr: “I know it is so. As for what I told you tonight; I said it for your own good. I have always been your most reliable friend, you know this.”
es: —I know. As for what I told you tonight, I did it for your own good. You know that I have always been a loyal friend.

en: “Don’t touch me. Finish what you have to say.”
vi: "Don't touch me. Say whatever you have to say."
tr: “Don't push me. Finish what you were saying.”
es: —Don't touch me. Finish what you have to say.

en: A twisted flash of pain shot across the painter’s face. He paused for a moment, and a wild feeling of pity came over him. After all, what right had he to pry into the life of Dorian Gray? If he had done a tithe of what was rumoured about him, how much he must have suffered! Then he straightened himself up, and walked over to the fire-place, and stood there, looking at the burning logs with their frostlike ashes and their throbbing cores of flame.
vi: A fleeting grimace of pain flashed across the artist's face. He paused for a moment, and a fierce feeling of pity came over him. After all, what right did he have to pry into Dorian Gray's life? Even if the young man had done a fraction of what people gossiped about, he must have suffered immensely! Then he straightened up, walked over to the fireplace, stood there, watching the burning logs with frost-like ashes and the glowing embers.
tr: A painful expression briefly crossed the painter's face. Hallward paused for a moment, then was overwhelmed by a deep sense of pity. After all, what right did he have to interfere in Dorian Gray's life? If Dorian had done even a fraction of what was said about him, who knows what he had endured! Hallward straightened up and walked towards the fireplace, where he stood and looked at the frost-like ashes of the burning logs, and the heart-like core of the fire.
es: The pain contorted the painter's features for an instant. He remained silent, overwhelmed by a feeling of infinite compassion. After all, what right did he have to interfere in Dorian's life? Even if he had done only a tenth of what was said about him, how much he must have suffered! But he immediately straightened up, heading towards the fireplace, and there he stayed, gazing at the logs, which burned with ashes resembling frost and throbbing hearts made of flames.

en: “I am waiting, Basil,” said the young man in a hard clear voice.
vi: “I am waiting here, Basil,” the young man said, in a clear, firm voice.
tr: Dorian said in a firm, clear voice, "I am waiting, Basil."
es: —I am waiting, Basil —said the young man, with a clear and hard voice.

en: He turned round. “What I have to say is this,” he cried. “You must give me some answer to these horrible charges that are made against you. If you tell me that they are absolutely untrue from beginning to end, I shall believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them! Can’t you see what I am going through? My God! don’t tell me that you are bad, and corrupt, and shameful.”
vi: He turned back. "What I have to say is this," he shouted. "You must give me some answer to these terrible accusations that have been made against you. If you tell me that they are absolutely false from beginning to end, I will believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them! Can't you see what I have to go through? Good God! Don't tell me that you are wicked, depraved, and dishonorable."
tr: The painter turned towards him. “What I have to say is this: You must give me an explanation regarding these disgusting accusations directed at you. If you tell me they are completely fabricated, I will believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them all! Can't you see what I've been through? Good God, don't tell me you are a wicked, immoral, disgraceful person!”
es: The painter turned around. —What I have to say is this —he exclaimed—. You must give me some answer to the terrible accusations made against you. If you tell me that they are absolutely false from beginning to end, I will believe you. Deny them, Dorian, do me the favor of denying them! Don't you see how much I am suffering? Good heavens! Don't tell me that you are a wicked, corrupt, infamous person.

en: Dorian Gray smiled. There was a curl of contempt in his lips. “Come upstairs, Basil,” he said quietly. “I keep a diary of my life from day to day, and it never leaves the room in which it is written. I shall show it to you if you come with me.”
vi: Dorian Gray laughed. There was a contemptuous curl on his lips. "Come upstairs, Basil," he said calmly. "I keep a diary of my life from day to day, and it never leaves the room in which it is written. I will show it to you if you come with me."
tr: Dorian Gray smiled. His lips curled in a contemptuous smile. The young man, with composure, “Come upstairs, Basil,” he said. “I have a diary where I note down my daily life, but I never take it out of the room where I write it. If you come, I'll show it to you too.”
es: Dorian Gray smiled. A gesture of disdain curved his lips. —Come upstairs with me, Basil —he said calmly—. I keep a diary of my life that never leaves the room where it is written. I will show it to you if you accompany me.

en: “I shall come with you, Dorian, if you wish it. I see I have missed my train. That makes no matter. I can go to-morrow. But don’t ask me to read anything to-night. All I want is a plain answer to my question.”
vi: “I will go with you, Dorian, if you want that. I see that I have missed the train. That’s alright. I can go tomorrow. But don’t ask me to read anything tonight. All I want is a straightforward answer to my question.”
tr: "I'll come, Dorian, since you want me to. Anyway, I've missed my train as well. It's not important. I'll go tomorrow. Just don't make me read anything tonight. All I want is a clear answer to my question."
es: —I will go up with you, Dorian, if you wish. I see that I have already missed the train. It doesn't matter. I will leave tomorrow. But don't ask me to read anything tonight. All I want is a direct answer to my question.

en: “That shall be given to you upstairs. I could not give it here. You will not have to read long.”
vi: “It will be given to you upstairs. I can't bring it out here. You won't have to read for long.”
tr: "This answer will be given to you above. I can't say it here. You won't need to read for long either."
es: —It will be given to you on the top floor. I can't give it to you here. It won't be necessary for you to read for long.

en: CHAPTER XIII.
vi: Chapter 13
tr: Chapter Thirteen
es: Chapter 13

en: He passed out of the room and began the ascent, Basil Hallward following close behind. They walked softly, as men do instinctively at night. The lamp cast fantastic shadows on the wall and staircase. A rising wind made some of the windows rattle.
vi: He left the room and began to go upstairs, with Basil Hallward following closely behind. They walked quietly, as people instinctively do at night. The lights cast strange shadows on the walls and stairs. A gust of wind arose, causing a few windows to rattle.
tr: Dorian Gray stepped outside and began to climb the stairs; Basil Hallward was following him. As people instinctively do at night, they were walking quietly. The lamp cast improbable shadows on the walls of the staircase, and the wind picking up outside rattled some of the windows.
es: Dorian left the room and began to ascend, closely followed by Basil Hallward. They walked without making noise, as one instinctively does at night. The lamp cast fantastic shadows on the wall and the staircase. The wind, which was beginning to rise, made some windows rattle.

en: When they reached the top landing, Dorian set the lamp down on the floor, and taking out the key, turned it in the lock. “You insist on knowing, Basil?” he asked in a low voice.
vi: When they reached the top of the highest staircase. Dorian put the lamp down on the floor, took out a key, and turned it in the lock. “You really insist on knowing, don't you Basil?” he asked, in a gentle voice.
tr: At the top landing, Dorian placed the lamp on the ground, took out the key, and turned it in the lock. In a low voice, "Are you resisting learning, Basil?" he asked.
es: When they reached the attic landing, Dorian placed the lamp on the floor and, taking out the key, inserted it into the lock. —Do you really want to know, Basil? —he asked in a low voice.

en: “Yes.”
vi: “Correct.”
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “I am delighted,” he answered, smiling. Then he added, somewhat harshly, “You are the one man in the world who is entitled to know everything about me. You have had more to do with my life than you think”; and, taking up the lamp, he opened the door and went in. A cold current of air passed them, and the light shot up for a moment in a flame of murky orange. He shuddered. “Shut the door behind you,” he whispered, as he placed the lamp on the table.
vi: “I am very honored,” he replied, smiling. Then he added, somewhat bitterly, “you are the only person in the world who has the right to know everything about me. You have been more involved in my life than you think,” and, picking up the lamp, he opened the door and went in. A cold draft passed through them, the light flared for a moment in the dim orange flame. He shivered. “Close the door behind you,” he whispered, and placed the lamp on the table.
tr: Dorian smiled, "I am very glad," he said. Then, in a slightly harsh voice, he added, "If there is one person in the world who has the right to know everything about me, it is you. The role you play in my life is greater than you think." Then he picked up the lamp from the floor, opened the door, and went inside. A cold draft brushed past them, and the light of the lamp flared up for a moment with a sooty orange flame. Dorian shivered. "Close the door," he whispered, placing the lamp on the table.
es: —You can't imagine how glad I am —he replied, smiling. Then he added, with a certain violence—: you are the only person in the world who has the right to know everything about me. You are more closely tied to my life than you think —then, picking up the lamp, he opened the door and entered the old playroom. A cold draft assaulted them, and the lamp emitted for a few moments a flame of murky orange color. Dorian Gray shivered—. Close the door —he whispered to Basil, while placing the lamp on the table.

en: Hallward glanced round him with a puzzled expression. The room looked as if it had not been lived in for years. A faded Flemish tapestry, a curtained picture, an old Italian cassone, and an almost empty book-case—that was all that it seemed to contain, besides a chair and a table. As Dorian Gray was lighting a half-burned candle that was standing on the mantelshelf, he saw that the whole place was covered with dust and that the carpet was in holes. A mouse ran scuffling behind the wainscoting. There was a damp odour of mildew.
vi: Hallward looked around him, with a bewildered expression. The room looked as if it hadn't been inhabited for many years. A faded Flanders carpet, a veiled painting, an old Italian cassone, and an almost empty bookshelf — that seemed to be all it contained, apart from a chair and a table. When Dorian Gray relit a half-burned candle on the mantelpiece, he saw that the entire place was covered in dust, and the carpet was riddled with holes. A rat scurried behind the wainscoting. The smell of damp mold lingered in the air.
tr: Hallward looked around with a surprised expression on his face. The room seemed to have been unused for years. A faded Flemish tapestry, a picture with a curtain in front of it, an old Italian chest, an almost empty bookcase... These seemed to be the only things in the room; and a table and a chair. While Dorian Gray lit the half-burnt candle on the mantelpiece, Hallward saw that everything was covered in dust and the carpet was full of holes. A rat was scurrying behind the wall paneling. There was a damp, musty smell in the air.
es: Hallward looked around, bewildered. It seemed as if that room had not been used for years. A faded Flemish tapestry, a painting behind a curtain, an old Italian cassone, and an almost empty bookshelf were all it seemed to contain, besides a chair and a table. While Dorian Gray lit a half-burned candle that rested on the mantelpiece, Basil noticed that everything was covered in dust and that the carpet had many holes. A mouse ran to hide behind the wooden paneling. The entire room smelled of mold and dampness.

en: “So you think that it is only God who sees the soul, Basil? Draw that curtain back, and you will see mine.”
vi: “So you think that only God can see the soul, right Basil? Pull this curtain aside, and you will see my soul.”
tr: "So you think only God can see a person's soul, do you Basil? Draw that curtain, and you will see my soul."
es: —So, according to you, only God sees the soul, isn't that right? Draw back the curtain and you will see mine.

en: The voice that spoke was cold and cruel. “You are mad, Dorian, or playing a part,” muttered Hallward, frowning.
vi: That voice was cold and cruel. "You're mad, Dorian, or you're playing a part," Hallward whispered, grimacing.
tr: The voice that spoke was cold and cruel. Frowning, Hallward said, "Dorian, you are either mad or pretending,"
es: The voice that spoke was cold and cruel. —You are crazy, Dorian, or you are playing a role —murmured Hallward, frowning.

en: “You won’t? Then I must do it myself,” said the young man, and he tore the curtain from its rod and flung it on the ground.
vi: “You won't do it? Then I'll have to do it myself,” the young person said, yanking the curtain off the bar and throwing it onto the floor.
tr: "Aren't you opening it? Then it's up to me," said the young man, pulling the curtain from its rod and throwing it to the ground.
es: —Don't you dare? In that case, I'll do it —said the young man, tearing the curtain from the bar that held it and throwing it to the ground.

en: An exclamation of horror broke from the painter’s lips as he saw in the dim light the hideous face on the canvas grinning at him. There was something in its expression that filled him with disgust and loathing. Good heavens! it was Dorian Gray’s own face that he was looking at! The horror, whatever it was, had not yet entirely spoiled that marvellous beauty. There was still some gold in the thinning hair and some scarlet on the sensual mouth. The sodden eyes had kept something of the loveliness of their blue, the noble curves had not yet completely passed away from chiselled nostrils and from plastic throat. Yes, it was Dorian himself. But who had done it? He seemed to recognize his own brushwork, and the frame was his own design. The idea was monstrous, yet he felt afraid. He seized the lighted candle, and held it to the picture. In the left-hand corner was his own name, traced in long letters of bright vermilion.
vi: A horrifying scream burst from the artist's lips when he saw the grotesque face on the canvas grinning at him in the dim light. There was something about its expression that made him feel utterly disgusted and hateful. My God! It was the face of Dorian Gray himself, he was looking at the face of Dorian Gray himself! The horror had not yet completely ruined that extraordinary beauty. There was still some golden hue in the thinning hair and some pink on the sensual lips. The dull eyes still retained some charm in their blue, the noble curves had not entirely vanished from the sculpted nostrils and the chiseled throat. Yes, it was Dorian. But who had created it? He seemed to recognize his own brushwork, and the frame was his own design. The thought was bizarre, yet it frightened him. He grabbed the lit candle and brought it closer to the painting. In the lower left corner was his name, sketched in long, fresh red letters.
tr: When the painter saw the hideous face grinning at him from the canvas in that dim light, a cry of horror escaped his lips. There was something in the expression of that face that filled him with disgust and dread. Good God! The thing in front of him was the face of Dorian Gray. The dreadful influence that had settled on the portrait –what could it be?– had not yet completely ruined that exquisite beauty. There was still a bit of golden shimmer in the thinning hair, and a bit of redness in that sensual mouth. Something of the old beautiful blue remained in the watery, drunken eyes, and the noble curve of the pencil-drawn nose and shapely neck had not yet entirely vanished. Yes, it was Dorian himself. But who had painted it? Hallward seemed to recognize his own brush strokes; the design of the frame was also his. It was impossible, yet the painter, seized by fear, took the candle and raised it towards the painting. In the bottom left corner, his own name was written in long, bright red letters.
es: A cry of horror escaped the painter's lips upon seeing, in the dim light, the ghastly face that smiled at him from the canvas. There was something in its expression that immediately filled him with disgust and loathing. Good heavens! It was the face of Dorian Gray that he was seeing! The mysterious abomination had not yet completely destroyed its extraordinary beauty. There were still traces of gold in the lightening hair and a hint of color in the sensual mouth. The swollen eyes retained some of the purity of their blue, the noble curves had not entirely vanished from the chiseled nose nor from the well-shaped neck. Yes, it was Dorian. But who had done it? He seemed to recognize his own brushstrokes, and as for the frame, the design was also his. The idea was monstrous, but nonetheless, he felt afraid. Seizing the lit candle, he approached the painting. Below, on the left, he found his name, inscribed in long letters of bright vermilion.

en: It was some foul parody, some infamous ignoble satire. He had never done that. Still, it was his own picture. He knew it, and he felt as if his blood had changed in a moment from fire to sluggish ice. His own picture! What did it mean? Why had it altered? He turned and looked at Dorian Gray with the eyes of a sick man. His mouth twitched, and his parched tongue seemed unable to articulate. He passed his hand across his forehead. It was dank with clammy sweat.
vi: It was some terrible imitation, a vile, despicable parody. He had never created such a thing. Yet, it was still his painting. He knew it, and he felt as if his blood had changed in an instant from fire to sluggish ice water. His very own painting! What did that mean? How had it transformed? He turned back, looking at Dorian Gray with the eyes of a sick man. His mouth twitched, his parched tongue seemed unable to articulate clearly. He passed his hand across his forehead. It was clammy with cold sweat.
tr: This must have been a disgusting imitation, a vile, treacherous mockery. The person who made this painting was never him. Yet the painting was the one he had made. Hallward had recognized it, and it was as if the blood in his veins had suddenly turned from fire to ice. His own painting, huh! What did this mean? Why had this painting undergone such a transformation! Hallward turned and looked at Dorian with the eyes of a feverish patient. His mouth was twitching, his dry tongue seemed incapable of turning to speak. He ran his hand across his forehead. His skin was wet with sweat, sticky.
es: It was a repugnant parody, an infamous and ignoble caricature. That canvas was not his work. And yet, it was his portrait. There was no doubt about it, and he felt as if, in a moment, the blood running through his veins had gone from fire to inert ice. His painting! What did it mean? Why had it changed? Turning around, he looked at Dorian Gray with sick eyes. His mouth contracted and his tongue, completely dry, was unable to articulate the slightest sound. He wiped his forehead with his hand, collecting a sticky sweat.

en: The young man was leaning against the mantelshelf, watching him with that strange expression that one sees on the faces of those who are absorbed in a play when some great artist is acting. There was neither real sorrow in it nor real joy. There was simply the passion of the spectator, with perhaps a flicker of triumph in his eyes. He had taken the flower out of his coat, and was smelling it, or pretending to do so.
vi: The young man leaned against the mantelpiece, observing him with the strange expression one often sees on the faces of those who are captivated by a play when some great artist performs. There was no real sorrow and no real joy on it. Only the fascination of a spectator, with perhaps a shimmering glint of triumph in his eyes. He had taken the flower out of his coat, and was smelling it, or pretending to do so.
tr: Dorian Gray was leaning against the frame of the fireplace, watching him; on his face was that strange expression seen on the faces of those watching a great artist perform on stage. It was neither genuine sorrow nor genuine joy. Only the passion of watching, and perhaps a spark of triumph in his eyes. Dorian had removed the flower from his coat collar and was either smelling it or pretending to do so.
es: His young friend, leaning against the mantelpiece, watched him with the strange expression one sees on those who are absorbed in a theatrical performance when a great actor is performing. It was neither of true sorrow nor of true joy. It was simply the passion of the spectator, perhaps with a fleeting glimmer of triumph in his eyes. Dorian Gray had removed the flower he wore in his buttonhole and was smelling it or pretending to smell it.

en: “What does this mean?” cried Hallward, at last. His own voice sounded shrill and curious in his ears.
vi: “What does this mean?” Hallward finally exclaimed. His voice sounded strangely shrill in his own ears.
tr: Finally, Hallward shouted softly, "What does this mean?" His own voice sounded shrill and strange to his ears.
es: —What does this mean? —exclaimed Hallward, finally. His own voice sounded discordant and strange to him.

en: “Years ago, when I was a boy,” said Dorian Gray, crushing the flower in his hand, “you met me, flattered me, and taught me to be vain of my good looks. One day you introduced me to a friend of yours, who explained to me the wonder of youth, and you finished a portrait of me that revealed to me the wonder of beauty. In a mad moment that, even now, I don’t know whether I regret or not, I made a wish, perhaps you would call it a prayer....”
vi: “Many years ago, when I was just a boy,” Dorian Gray said, crushing the flower in his hand, “you met me, flattered me, taught me to be proud of my beauty. One day, you introduced me to a friend of yours, and he explained to me the wonders of youth, while you completed the portrait of me, a painting that revealed to me the marvel of beauty. In a moment of madness, which, even now, I do not know if I regret, I uttered a wish, perhaps you would call it a prayer…”
tr: Dorian Gray, crushing the flower in his hand, said, "Years ago, when I was a young boy, we met." "You flattered me, taught me to take pride in my beauty. One day, you introduced me to a friend; he explained the miracle of youth to me, and the portrait you had completed revealed the miracle of beauty before my eyes. In a moment of madness... Though even now, I don't know if I regret it... I made a wish, or perhaps you could call it a plea..."
es: —Years ago, when I was nothing more than a teenager —said Dorian Gray, crushing the flower with his hand—, you met me, flattered my vanity, and taught me to take pride in my beauty. One day you introduced me to one of your friends, who explained the wonder of youth to me, while you finished the portrait that revealed to me the miracle of beauty. In a moment of madness, of which even now I still do not know if I regret or not, I made a wish, although perhaps you would call it a prayer...

en: “I remember it! Oh, how well I remember it! No! the thing is impossible. The room is damp. Mildew has got into the canvas. The paints I used had some wretched mineral poison in them. I tell you the thing is impossible.”
vi: "I remember it now!" "Oh, I remember it so clearly! No! This cannot happen." "The room is damp." "Mold is spreading on the canvas." "The paints I used had some harmful minerals in them." "I assure you that this cannot happen."
tr: “I remember! I remember so clearly! But no, this can't be happening. The room must be damp, the canvas covered in mold. Was there some damn mineral poison in the paints I used! It's impossible, I'm telling you.”
es: —I remember! Yes, I remember it perfectly! No! That is impossible. This room is full of humidity. The mold has attacked the canvas. The colors I used contained some unfortunate mineral poison. I assure you it is impossible. —What is impossible?

en: “Ah, what is impossible?” murmured the young man, going over to the window and leaning his forehead against the cold, mist-stained glass.
vi: “Well, what can't happen?” the young person muttered, approaching the window and resting their forehead on the cold, mist-covered glass.
tr: Dorian murmured, "Is there anything that won't happen?" as he walked to the window and pressed his forehead against the fogged-up glass.
es: —murmured Dorian, approaching the balcony and resting his forehead against the cold glass fogged by the mist.

en: “You told me you had destroyed it.”
vi: “You told me that you had destroyed it.”
tr: “You said you had removed the picture.”
es: —You told me that you had destroyed it.

en: “I was wrong. It has destroyed me.”
vi: “I was wrong. It destroyed me.”
tr: “I lied. It destroyed me.”
es: —I was wrong. The portrait has destroyed me.

en: “I don’t believe it is my picture.”
vi: “I don't believe it is my painting.”
tr: “This is the painting I made, huh... I can't believe it.”
es: —I don't think it's my painting.

en: “Can’t you see your ideal in it?” said Dorian bitterly.
vi: “Don’t you see your ideal in it?” Dorian said, bitterly.
tr: "Can't you see your ideal in the painting?" Dorian asked bitterly.
es: —Don't you see your ideal in him? —asked Dorian bitterly.

en: “My ideal, as you call it...”
vi: “My ideal, as you call it…”
tr: “My ideal, as you said...”
es: —My ideal, as you call it...

en: “As you called it.”
vi: “As you call it.”
tr: “Not as I say, but as you say.”
es: —As you called it.

en: “There was nothing evil in it, nothing shameful. You were to me such an ideal as I shall never meet again. This is the face of a satyr.”
vi: “There is nothing evil in it, nothing shameful. To me, you are like an ideal that I will never encounter again. And this is the face of the god of lust.”
tr: “No evil, no sin had touched her, there was nothing to be ashamed of. You were such an ideal in my eyes that I will never find again. Yet this is the face of a demon.”
es: —There was no malice in him, he had nothing to be ashamed of. You were for me the ideal that I will never find again. And that is the face of a satyr.

en: “It is the face of my soul.”
vi: “That is the face of my soul.”
tr: “This is the face of my soul.”
es: —It is the face of my soul.

en: “Christ! what a thing I must have worshipped! It has the eyes of a devil.”
vi: "Oh God! And to think I have been venerating something like this!" "It has the eyes of a demon."
tr: "Oh Great God! Have I worshipped something like this! Its eyes are the eyes of the devil."
es: —Heavens above! What a creature I chose to adore! It has the eyes of a demon.

en: “Each of us has heaven and hell in him, Basil,” cried Dorian with a wild gesture of despair.
vi: "Each of us has Heaven and Hell within us, Basil," Dorian exclaimed, with a gesture of wild despair.
tr: Opening his arms with wild abandon, Dorian said, "Each of us carries both Heaven and Hell within us, Basil."
es: —We all carry heaven and hell within us, Basil —exclaimed Dorian with an excessive gesture of despair.

en: Hallward turned again to the portrait and gazed at it. “My God! If it is true,” he exclaimed, “and this is what you have done with your life, why, you must be worse even than those who talk against you fancy you to be!” He held the light up again to the canvas and examined it. The surface seemed to be quite undisturbed and as he had left it. It was from within, apparently, that the foulness and horror had come. Through some strange quickening of inner life the leprosies of sin were slowly eating the thing away. The rotting of a corpse in a watery grave was not so fearful.
vi: Hallward turned back to the portrait and stared at it. "Good God! If it is true," he cried, "and this is what you have done with your life, why, then you must be worse than what people whisper about you!" He took the candle closer to the canvas and examined it. The surface seemed completely unchanged, exactly as he had left it. It seemed that the hideous horror came from within. Through some strange inner life force, the leprosy of sin had slowly eaten away at this thing. The decay of a corpse in a watery grave was not as dreadful as this.
tr: Hallward turned towards the portrait and stared at it. "Good God, if what you say is true, if you have lived your life in this way... You are worse than what your detractors think!" He raised the light again and examined the portrait. The surface of the canvas was as he had left it, untouched. It was as if the hideousness, the horror, had been revealed from within. With a strange life festering from within, the leprous sores of sin were slowly gnawing at the face in the picture. Even the decay of a corpse in a damp grave could not be so horrifying.
es: Hallward turned again towards the portrait and stared at it intently. —My God! If it's true —he exclaimed—, and this is what you've done with your life, you are even worse than those who attack you imagine! —he brought the candle closer to the canvas again to examine it. The surface seemed to remain exactly as he had left it. The corruption and horror appeared to emerge from the depths of the painting. The inner life of the portrayed person manifested mysteriously, and the leprosy of sin slowly devoured the painting. The decomposition of a corpse in a damp grave would not be such a dreadful sight.

en: His hand shook, and the candle fell from its socket on the floor and lay there sputtering. He placed his foot on it and put it out. Then he flung himself into the rickety chair that was standing by the table and buried his face in his hands.
vi: With a swift motion, the candle fell from its holder to the floor, lying there with a sizzle. He stepped on it and extinguished it. Then he let himself fall into the wobbly chair next to the table and buried his face in his hands.
tr: Hallward's hands began to tremble; the candle on the candelabrum fell to the ground and started to sizzle there. The painter stepped on the candle with his foot and extinguished it. Then, dropping himself into the wobbling chair by the table, he buried his face in his hands.
es: His hand trembled; the candle fell from the candlestick to the floor and began to sputter. Hallward extinguished it with his foot. Then he let himself fall into the rickety chair near the table and hid his face in his hands.

en: “Good God, Dorian, what a lesson! What an awful lesson!” There was no answer, but he could hear the young man sobbing at the window. “Pray, Dorian, pray,” he murmured. “What is it that one was taught to say in one’s boyhood? ‘Lead us not into temptation. Forgive us our sins. Wash away our iniquities.’ Let us say that together. The prayer of your pride has been answered. The prayer of your repentance will be answered also. I worshipped you too much. I am punished for it. You worshipped yourself too much. We are both punished.”
vi: "Good Lord, Dorian, what a dreadful lesson! What a terrible lesson!" There was no answer, but he could hear the young man sobbing by the window. "Pray, Dorian, pray," he murmured. "What was that phrase we were taught to say as children? 'Lead us not into temptation. Forgive us our sins. Cleanse us of our vices.' Let us say it together. Your prayer of self-respect will be answered. Your prayer of repentance will also be answered. I worshipped you too much. I am punished for that. You also worshipped yourself too much. We are both punished."
tr: “My God, Dorian, what a lesson this is! What a tremendous lesson!” There was no response, but the painter could hear Dorian sobbing by the window. “Pray, Dorian, pray,” he murmured. “There was a prayer they taught us in our childhood; how did it go? Lead us not into temptation. Forgive us our sins. Wash away the stain of our wickedness. Come, let’s recite it together. Your plea of pride has been answered. Your plea of remorse will also be answered. I had exalted you too much. Now I am seeing the punishment for it. You also exalted yourself too much. We are both being punished.”
es: —Good heavens, Dorian, what a lesson! What a terrible lesson! —he received no response, but he heard his friend sobbing by the window—. Pray, Dorian, pray —he murmured—. What was it that they taught us to say when we were children? “Lead us not into temptation. Forgive us our sins. Blot out our iniquities.” Let's repeat it together. Your prayer of pride was answered. Your prayer of repentance will also be heard. I admired you too much. We have both been punished.

en: Dorian Gray turned slowly around and looked at him with tear-dimmed eyes. “It is too late, Basil,” he faltered.
vi: Dorian Gray slowly turned around, looking at him with tear-filled eyes. "It's too late, Basil," he stammered.
tr: Dorian Gray turned slowly and looked at the painter with eyes dimmed by tears. “It's too late now, Basil,” he stammered. “The deed is done.”
es: Dorian Gray slowly turned, looking at him with eyes clouded by tears. —It's too late -he stammered.

en: “It is never too late, Dorian. Let us kneel down and try if we cannot remember a prayer. Isn’t there a verse somewhere, ‘Though your sins be as scarlet, yet I will make them as white as snow’?”
vi: “It is never too late, Dorian. Let us kneel down and try even if we cannot remember the prayer. There is a verse, isn’t there, ‘Though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow’?”
tr: “It is never too late, Dorian. Come, let us kneel here; let's see if we can think of a prayer. Wasn't there a prayer that went something like: Even if your sins are scarlet, I can make them white as snow?”
es: —It is never too late. Let us kneel and try together to remember a prayer. Isn't there a verse that says: "Though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow[13]"?

en: “Those words mean nothing to me now.”
vi: “Those words have no meaning to me at this moment.”
tr: “These words mean nothing to me anymore.”
es: —Those words mean nothing to me anymore.

en: “Hush! Don’t say that. You have done enough evil in your life. My God! Don’t you see that accursed thing leering at us?”
vi: "Shh! Don't say that. You've already done enough bad things in your life." "Oh God! Do you see that cursed thing giving me a dirty look?"
tr: "Shh, don't talk like that. Your sins are enough. Oh my God! Can't you see, how that damned thing is staring at us and grinning?"
es: —Quiet! Don't say that. You have already done enough evil in your life. Good heavens! Don't you see how that hateful creature is laughing at us?

en: Dorian Gray glanced at the picture, and suddenly an uncontrollable feeling of hatred for Basil Hallward came over him, as though it had been suggested to him by the image on the canvas, whispered into his ear by those grinning lips. The mad passions of a hunted animal stirred within him, and he loathed the man who was seated at the table, more than in his whole life he had ever loathed anything. He glanced wildly around. Something glimmered on the top of the painted chest that faced him. His eye fell on it. He knew what it was. It was a knife that he had brought up, some days before, to cut a piece of cord, and had forgotten to take away with him. He moved slowly towards it, passing Hallward as he did so. As soon as he got behind him, he seized it and turned round. Hallward stirred in his chair as if he was going to rise. He rushed at him and dug the knife into the great vein that is behind the ear, crushing the man’s head down on the table and stabbing again and again.
vi: Dorian Gray glanced at the painting, and suddenly an uncontrollable hatred for Basil overwhelmed him, as if it was evoked by the image on the canvas, whispered into his ear by those sneering lips. The frenzied rage of a hunted animal rose within him, and he hated the man sitting by the table more than he had ever hated anything in his entire life. He looked around frantically. There was something faintly gleaming on top of the painted chest in front of him. His eyes caught sight of it. He knew what it was. It was the knife he had brought up a few days ago to cut a piece of string and had forgotten to take with him. He slowly edged towards it, passing by Hallward as he did so. As soon as he was behind him, he grabbed it and turned around. Hallward stirred in his chair as if he was about to stand up. He rushed at him, stabbing the large artery behind his ear, pressing the man's head down on the table, stabbing again and again.
tr: Dorian Gray glanced at the painting. A sudden, uncontrollable hatred towards Basil Hallward filled his heart. It was as if the image on the canvas had instilled this in him, those grinning lips had whispered it into his ear. Inside him, the wild emotions of an animal being hunted tingled, and Dorian felt a hatred towards the man at the table that he had never felt towards anything in his life. He looked around with mad eyes. Something was gleaming on the chest with the pictures in front of him. Dorian's eyes fixed on it. He knew what it was. A knife he had brought a few days ago to cut a rope, and then forgotten to take downstairs. Dorian slowly walked towards the chest, passing by Hallward. As soon as he got behind Hallward, he turned, taking the knife in his hand. Hallward had stirred as if to get up. Dorian leapt upon him, drove the knife into the thick vein behind his ear, and pressing his head down onto the table, struck him again and again with the knife.
es: Dorian Gray glanced at the picture and, suddenly, an uncontrollable hatred towards Basil Hallward seized him, as if it had been suggested by the image on the canvas, as if those mocking lips had whispered it into his ear. The wild passions of a cornered animal ignited within him, and he hated the man sitting at the table more than he had ever hated anything or anyone in his entire life. He cast frantic glances around. Something gleamed on top of the painted dresser in front of him. His eyes fixed on that object. He knew what it was. It was a knife he had brought a few days earlier to cut a piece of rope and then had forgotten to take away. He moved slowly in its direction, passing by Hallward. When he was behind him, he grasped it and turned around. Hallward shifted in his chair, as if preparing to stand up. Throwing himself upon him, he plunged the knife into the large vein behind his ear, banging his head against the table, and then stabbing him repeatedly.

en: There was a stifled groan and the horrible sound of some one choking with blood. Three times the outstretched arms shot up convulsively, waving grotesque, stiff-fingered hands in the air. He stabbed him twice more, but the man did not move. Something began to trickle on the floor. He waited for a moment, still pressing the head down. Then he threw the knife on the table, and listened.
vi: A choking moan, and the terrible sound of someone suffocating on their own blood. Three times in a row, those outstretched arms tried to jerk up, waving those bizarre hands with stiff fingers in the air. He stabbed him two more times, but the person no longer moved. Something began to drip onto the floor. He waited a moment, still pressing the head down. Then he threw the knife onto the table, listening.
tr: A muffled moan was heard, then the terrifying sound made by a person suffocating and choking on their own blood. The painter's outstretched arms flailed in the air three times, his clawing fingers scratching at the air. Dorian stabbed him twice more, but the man was no longer moving. Something began to drip onto the floor. Dorian still held the man's head down on the table for a while. Then he threw the knife onto the table and listened intently.
es: Only a muffled groan was heard, and the horrible sound of someone choking on their own blood. Three times the outstretched arms rose, convulsing, shaking grotesque hands with rigid fingers in the air. Dorian Gray stabbed the knife twice more, but Basil did not move. Something began to drip onto the floor. Dorian Gray waited a moment, still pressing the head against the table. Then he dropped the weapon and listened.

en: He could hear nothing, but the drip, drip on the threadbare carpet. He opened the door and went out on the landing. The house was absolutely quiet. No one was about. For a few seconds he stood bending over the balustrade and peering down into the black seething well of darkness. Then he took out the key and returned to the room, locking himself in as he did so.
vi: You can't hear anything except the dripping sound, dripping onto the worn-out carpet. You open the door and step out onto the landing. The house is as silent as a sheet. Not a single person around. You stand for a few seconds, leaning over the railing, staring down into the boiling black well of darkness. Then you take out the key and return to the room, locking yourself inside.
tr: He heard nothing but the patter of drops falling on the shabby carpet. He opened the door and stepped out onto the landing. There was no sound, no movement of feet inside the house. Dorian leaned over the railing and looked down into the seething dark pit below. Then he took out his key, re-entered the room, and locked the door from the inside.
es: Only the sound of blood drops hitting the worn-out carpet could be heard. He opened the door and stepped out onto the landing. The house was in absolute silence. No one had gotten up. For a few seconds, he remained leaning over the railing, trying to pierce the black well of tormented darkness with his gaze. Then he took the key out of his pocket and returned to the portrait room, locking himself inside.

en: The thing was still seated in the chair, straining over the table with bowed head, and humped back, and long fantastic arms. Had it not been for the red jagged tear in the neck and the clotted black pool that was slowly widening on the table, one would have said that the man was simply asleep.
vi: That person was still sitting on the chair, stretching across the table with their head bowed, hunchbacked, and with grotesquely long arms. If it weren't for the jagged red tear on their neck and the thick black puddle slowly spreading across the table, one might say that they were just sleeping.
tr: That thing was still sitting on the chair, leaning on the table, with its bent head, hunched back, and incredibly long arms. If it weren't for the bright red tear on its neck and the growing pool of clotted black on the table, you might have thought the man had fallen asleep.
es: The body remained seated in the chair, partly slumped over the table, head tilted, back bent, and arms hanging down, strangely long. If it weren't for the irregular red gash on the neck, and the dark, almost coagulated pool slowly spreading over the table, one might have thought that the reclining figure was merely sleeping.

en: How quickly it had all been done! He felt strangely calm, and walking over to the window, opened it and stepped out on the balcony. The wind had blown the fog away, and the sky was like a monstrous peacock’s tail, starred with myriads of golden eyes. He looked down and saw the policeman going his rounds and flashing the long beam of his lantern on the doors of the silent houses. The crimson spot of a prowling hansom gleamed at the corner and then vanished. A woman in a fluttering shawl was creeping slowly by the railings, staggering as she went. Now and then she stopped and peered back. Once, she began to sing in a hoarse voice. The policeman strolled over and said something to her. She stumbled away, laughing. A bitter blast swept across the square. The gas-lamps flickered and became blue, and the leafless trees shook their black iron branches to and fro. He shivered and went back, closing the window behind him.
vi: Everything was done so quickly! He felt strangely calm, and, approaching the window, opened it, and stepped out onto the balcony. The wind had blown the fog away, and the sky was like a giant peacock tail, dotted with countless golden eyes. He looked down and saw a patrolling policeman casting a long beam of light from his lantern onto the doors of the silent houses. The red dot of a two-wheeled carriage wandered around, flickering at the corner of the street, then disappeared. A woman wrapped in a fluttering shawl was stealthily walking beside the fence, staggering as she stepped. Occasionally, she stopped and looked back. Once, she began to sing in a hoarse voice. The policeman leisurely approached and said something to her. She staggered away, laughing. A cold gust of wind swept across the square. The gas lamps flickered, turned blue, and the leafless trees shook their black iron branches back and forth. He shivered and turned back, closing the window behind him.
tr: How quickly everything had happened! Dorian was in a strange state of calmness. He went, opened the balcony door, and stepped out onto the balcony. The wind had dispersed the mist, and the sky resembled a giant peacock tail dotted with countless golden eyes. When Dorian looked down, he saw the patrolling policeman passing by, shining the long beam of his lantern on the doors of the silent houses. The red light of a silently and seemingly stealthily advancing carriage glimmered at a corner, then disappeared. A woman, with her shawl fluttering in the wind, was moving along the railing with unsteady steps, almost crawling. Every now and then, she would stop and look back over her shoulder. Once, she started singing a song in a hoarse, rough voice. The policeman came and said something to her. The woman laughed and staggered away. A sharp gust of wind swept across the square. The flames of the gas lamps flickered and turned a deep blue, and the bare trees waved their pitch-black, iron-like branches. Dorian shivered, went back inside, and closed the door.
es: How quickly everything had happened! He felt a strange calmness and, approaching the balcony, opened it to step outside. The wind had carried away the fog, and the sky was like the wheel of a monstrous peacock, studded with countless golden eyes. Looking down at the street, he saw the neighborhood policeman making his rounds and directing the long beam of his dim flashlight towards the doors of silent houses. The crimson stain of a cab glowed at the corner only to disappear a moment later. A woman with a shawl fluttering in the wind was advancing slowly, with an unsteady step, leaning on the garden railings. From time to time she would stop and look back. On one occasion she began to sing in a hoarse voice. The policeman approached her and said something to her. The woman staggered away, laughing. A very cold gust of wind swept through the square. The gas lights flickered, turning blue, and the bare trees shook their black iron branches. Dorian Gray shivered and returned to the room, closing the balcony.

en: Having reached the door, he turned the key and opened it. He did not even glance at the murdered man. He felt that the secret of the whole thing was not to realize the situation. The friend who had painted the fatal portrait to which all his misery had been due had gone out of his life. That was enough.
vi: Reaching the door, he turned the key and opened it. He didn't even glance at the person who had been killed. He felt that the secret to the whole affair was not being aware of the situation. The friend who had painted the disastrous portrait, which was the cause of all his suffering, had vanished from his life. That was enough.
tr: He walked, turned the key, and opened the room door. He didn't even look at the man he had killed. He felt that the key to this situation was not becoming aware of the events. The friend who had drawn that cursed portrait, the source of all his suffering, had left his life. This was enough.
es: Upon reaching the door, he turned the key and opened it. He didn't even turn around to glance at the corpse. He understood that the secret of success was to not acknowledge what had happened. The friend who had painted the fateful portrait, the cause of all his suffering, had disappeared from his life. That was enough.

en: Then he remembered the lamp. It was a rather curious one of Moorish workmanship, made of dull silver inlaid with arabesques of burnished steel, and studded with coarse turquoises. Perhaps it might be missed by his servant, and questions would be asked. He hesitated for a moment, then he turned back and took it from the table. He could not help seeing the dead thing. How still it was! How horribly white the long hands looked! It was like a dreadful wax image.
vi: Then he remembered the lamp. It was a rather strange object from Moroccan craftsmanship, made of tarnished silver inlaid with polished steel Arabic motifs, studded with raw turquoise. Perhaps his servant might remember it again and would ask about it. He hesitated for a moment, then turned back and took it from the table. He couldn't help but look at that dead thing. How silent it was! How terribly white those long hands looked. It was like a dreadful wax figure.
tr: Suddenly, he thought of the lamp. It was a Moorish piece, something unusual: made of dull silver covered with bright steel arabesques, inlaid with turquoise roots. His servant might notice the absence of the lamp, which could lead to questions being asked. Dorian hesitated a bit, then turned and took the lamp from the table. His eyes involuntarily fell on the dead thing. How motionless it was! How dreadful was the whiteness of those long hands! It looked like a terrible sculpture made of wax.
es: It was then that he remembered the lamp. It was a rather curious example of Muslim craftsmanship, wrought in matte silver with inlays of burnished steel arabesques, studded with unpolished turquoise. Perhaps his servant would miss it and ask questions. He hesitated for a moment, but eventually went back in and retrieved it. This time he couldn't help but see the corpse. How still it was! How horribly white and long its hands seemed! It was like a ghastly wax figure.

en: Having locked the door behind him, he crept quietly downstairs. The woodwork creaked and seemed to cry out as if in pain. He stopped several times and waited. No: everything was still. It was merely the sound of his own footsteps.
vi: After locking the door behind him, he quietly sneaked down the stairs. The wooden item creaked, and seemed to cry out as if in pain. He stopped a few times, waiting. No: everything was quiet. It was just his footsteps.
tr: Dorian locked the door behind him and quietly descended to the lower floor. The floorboards creaked, as if they were screaming in pain. Dorian stopped and waited several times. But no, there was neither a sound nor a movement. The only thing he heard was the sound of his own footsteps.
es: After locking the door again, Dorian Gray silently descended the staircase. The creaking of some steps seemed like cries of pain to him. He stopped several times and waited. No: everything was silent. It was just the sound of his footsteps.

en: When he reached the library, he saw the bag and coat in the corner. They must be hidden away somewhere. He unlocked a secret press that was in the wainscoting, a press in which he kept his own curious disguises, and put them into it. He could easily burn them afterwards. Then he pulled out his watch. It was twenty minutes to two.
vi: When he returned to the library, he saw the bag and the coat in the corner. They had to be hidden somewhere. He opened the secret closet in the baseboard paneling, a closet where he kept his strange disguises, and put it inside. He could easily burn them later. Then he pulled out the watch. It was twenty to two.
tr: When he reached the bookshelf, he saw the bag and coat standing in the corner. These needed to be hidden somewhere. Dorian opened a secret compartment behind the wall paneling. He placed the bag and coat in this compartment where he stored various, interesting clothes he used when he wanted to disguise himself. It was no big deal to burn them later. Dorian looked at his pocket watch and saw that it was twenty to two.
es: Upon arriving at the library, he saw the coat, cap, and briefcase in a corner. They needed to be hidden somewhere. He opened a secret wardrobe, concealed in the wood paneling, where he hid his curious costumes, and left them there. He could burn them without any problems later. Then he took out the watch. It was twenty to two.

en: He sat down and began to think. Every year—every month, almost—men were strangled in England for what he had done. There had been a madness of murder in the air. Some red star had come too close to the earth.... And yet, what evidence was there against him? Basil Hallward had left the house at eleven. No one had seen him come in again. Most of the servants were at Selby Royal. His valet had gone to bed.... Paris! Yes. It was to Paris that Basil had gone, and by the midnight train, as he had intended. With his curious reserved habits, it would be months before any suspicions would be roused. Months! Everything could be destroyed long before then.
vi: You sat down and began to think. Every year — almost every month — many people are hanged in England for what they have done. The madness of murder is in the air. Some red star has come too close to the earth... However, what evidence is there against you? Basil Hallward had left your house at eleven o'clock. No one saw him come back. Most of the servants are at Selby Royal. Your valet had gone to bed... Paris! That's right. Paris is where Basil went, by the midnight train, as he had planned. With his strange, cautious habits, it would be many months before any suspicion arose. Months! Everything could be destroyed long before then.
tr: Dorian sat down and began to think. In England, every year, almost every month, people were being hanged because of what he had done. A madness of murder was in the air. Had a red star come too close to our world or what... On the other hand, what evidence was there to incriminate him? Basil Hallward had left his house at eleven o'clock. No one had seen him come a second time. Most of the servants were at the Selby Royal estate in the countryside. His personal valet had gone to bed and fallen asleep... Paris! Yes, yes. Basil had gone to Paris, after all, by the midnight train, as planned. Being a reserved person, it would take months for his absence to arouse suspicion. Months! By then, everything would have been disposed of.
es: He sat down and began to think. Every year —almost every month— someone was hanged in England for a crime similar to the one he had just committed. It seemed as if a murderous madness had arisen in the air. Some red star had come too close to the Earth... But then, what evidence was there against him? Basil Hallward left the house at eleven. No one had seen him re-enter. Most of the servants were at Selby Royal. His valet had gone to bed... Paris! Yes. Basil had gone to Paris on the midnight train, just as he had planned to do. Given the curious reserve that characterized him, it would be months before the first suspicions arose. Months! Everything could be destroyed long before that.

en: A sudden thought struck him. He put on his fur coat and hat and went out into the hall. There he paused, hearing the slow heavy tread of the policeman on the pavement outside and seeing the flash of the bull’s-eye reflected in the window. He waited and held his breath.
vi: An unexpected thought flashed through his mind. He put on his fur coat and hat, then went out to the hall. He stopped there, listening to the slow and heavy footsteps of the policeman on the sidewalk outside, and saw the light from the bull's-eye lantern reflecting on the window. He waited, holding his breath.
tr: Suddenly, something occurred to Dorian. The young man put on his fur coat and hat and stepped into the hall. Here, he paused to listen to the heavy, slow footsteps of the watchman echoing on the pavement and saw the reflection of the lantern light on the windows. He waited, barely daring to breathe.
es: An idea suddenly crossed his mind. He put on his fur coat and hat and went out to the hallway. Then he stopped, hearing the slow, heavy steps of the policeman on the sidewalk and seeing the reflection of the dim lantern in the window. He waited, holding his breath.

en: After a few moments he drew back the latch and slipped out, shutting the door very gently behind him. Then he began ringing the bell. In about five minutes his valet appeared, half-dressed and looking very drowsy.
vi: Moments later, he pulled the latch, slipped outside, and closed the door very quietly behind him. Then he began to ring the bell. About five minutes later, his servant appeared, half-dressed, looking very sleepy.
tr: A few minutes later, he unlocked the bolt, stepped outside, and gently closed the door behind him. Then he started ringing the bell. Within five minutes, his servant appeared at the threshold, half-dressed, with sleep streaming from his eyes.
es: After a few moments, he slid back the bolt and slipped out stealthily, closing the door very gently behind him. Then he began to ring the front doorbell. About five minutes later, his valet appeared, half-dressed and looking sleepy.

en: “I am sorry to have had to wake you up, Francis,” he said, stepping in; “but I had forgotten my latch-key. What time is it?”
vi: “I'm sorry for having to wake you up, Francis,” he said, stepping into the house; “but I forgot the key. What time is it?”
tr: Dorian said, "I'm sorry, Francis, I had to wake you up." "I forgot my key. What time is it, dear?"
es: —I am sorry to have had to wake you, Francis —said Dorian Gray, entering the house—, but I forgot the keys. What time is it?

en: “Ten minutes past two, sir,” answered the man, looking at the clock and blinking.
vi: “Ten minutes to two, sir,” the servant replied, looking at the clock and blinking.
tr: Adam, blinking his eyes as he looked at the clock, said, "It's ten past two, sir."
es: —Two ten —replied the servant, looking at the clock and blinking.
