en: “Ten minutes past two? How horribly late! You must wake me at nine to-morrow. I have some work to do.”
vi: "Ten minutes to two? Why is it so late already! You should have woken me up at nine in the morning. I have some things to do."
tr: “Is it ten past two? It's quite late! You'll wake me up at nine tomorrow. I have things to do.”
es: —Two ten? Horribly late! Wake me up tomorrow at nine. I have to do an urgent job.

en: “All right, sir.”
vi: "Yes, sir."
tr: "At your service, sir."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Did any one call this evening?”
vi: "Is anyone coming over tonight?"
tr: “Did anyone call or ask about me in the evening?”
es: —Has any visitor come this afternoon?

en: “Mr. Hallward, sir. He stayed here till eleven, and then he went away to catch his train.”
vi: "There is Mr. Hallward, sir. He stayed here until eleven o'clock, then he left to catch the train."
tr: "Mr. Hallward, sir." "He waited until eleven o'clock, then he left; he had to catch a train.""
es: —Mr. Hallward. He was here until eleven, and then he left to catch the train.

en: “Oh! I am sorry I didn’t see him. Did he leave any message?”
vi: "Oh! I'm sorry I didn't get to meet him." "Did he leave any message?"
tr: “Oh! I'm really sorry I missed him. Did he leave any message or something?”
es: —Ah! I'm sorry I missed him. Did he leave any message?

en: “No, sir, except that he would write to you from Paris, if he did not find you at the club.”
vi: "No, sir, except that he will write to you from Paris if he does not find you at the club."
tr: “No, sir. He only said that if he couldn't find you at your club, he would write a letter from Paris.”
es: —No, sir, except that he would write to you from Paris if he didn't find you at the club.

en: “That will do, Francis. Don’t forget to call me at nine to-morrow.”
vi: "Alright, Francis. Don't forget to call me at nine in the morning."
tr: “Well, Francis, thank you. Don't forget to wake me up at nine tomorrow morning.”
es: —Nothing else, Francis. Don't forget to call me tomorrow at nine.

en: “No, sir.”
vi: “Yes, sir.”
tr: “I won't forget, sir.”
es: —Yes, sir.

en: The man shambled down the passage in his slippers.
vi: The servant shuffled along the hallway in slippers.
tr: Adam shuffled down the corridor in his slippers.
es: The servant walked away down the corridor, slightly dragging his slippers.

en: Dorian Gray threw his hat and coat upon the table and passed into the library. For a quarter of an hour he walked up and down the room, biting his lip and thinking. Then he took down the Blue Book from one of the shelves and began to turn over the leaves. “Alan Campbell, 152, Hertford Street, Mayfair.” Yes; that was the man he wanted.
vi: Dorian Gray threw his hat and coat onto the table, then went into the library. For a quarter of an hour, he paced back and forth in the room, biting his lip, thinking. Then he took the Blue Book down from one of the shelves and began flipping through the pages. "Alan Campbell, 152 Hertford Street, Mayfair." Yes; that was the person he needed.
tr: Dorian Gray placed his coat and hat on the table and went to the bookshelf. For a quarter of an hour, he wandered around the room, biting his lip and racking his brain. Then he took down the Blue Book that was on one of the shelves and started flipping through the pages. “Alan Campbell, No. 152, Hetford Street, Mayfair.” Yes, this was the man he was looking for.
es: Dorian Gray threw his hat and coat onto the table and entered the library. For a quarter of an hour, he paced, biting his lips and thinking. Then he took a directory from one of the shelves and began to flip through the pages. “Alan Campbell, 152 Hertford Street, Mayfair.” Yes; he was the man he needed.

en: CHAPTER XIV.
vi: Chapter 14
tr: Chapter Fourteen
es: Chapter 14

en: At nine o’clock the next morning his servant came in with a cup of chocolate on a tray and opened the shutters. Dorian was sleeping quite peacefully, lying on his right side, with one hand underneath his cheek. He looked like a boy who had been tired out with play, or study.
vi: At 9 o'clock in the morning, his servant came in with a cup of chocolate on a tray and opened the shutters. Dorian was sleeping very soundly, lying on his right side, with one hand under his cheek. He looked like a little boy exhausted from playing too much or studying hard.
tr: The next morning at nine o'clock, Dorian's servant entered the room with a tray holding a glass of cocoa and opened the shutters. Dorian was lying on his right side, one hand under his cheek, sleeping comfortably. He resembled a child tired from playing games or studying.
es: At nine o'clock in the morning the next day, the servant entered with a cup of chocolate on a tray and opened the shutters. Dorian was sleeping peacefully, lying on his right side, with one hand under his cheek. He looked like a teenager exhausted from play or study.

en: The man had to touch him twice on the shoulder before he woke, and as he opened his eyes a faint smile passed across his lips, as though he had been lost in some delightful dream. Yet he had not dreamed at all. His night had been untroubled by any images of pleasure or of pain. But youth smiles without any reason. It is one of its chiefest charms.
vi: The servant had to touch his shoulder twice before he woke up, and when he opened his eyes, a shy smile flickered across his lips, as if he had just been lost in some delightful dream. However, he absolutely did not dream of anything. His night was not disturbed by any joyful or painful images. But youth can smile without any reason. That is one of its main charms.
tr: Adam had to shake his shoulder twice to wake him up. As Dorian woke up, a slight smile trembled on his lips as if he were in a sweet dream. Yet he had not dreamed at all, no sweet or bitter image had disturbed his night. However, youth smiles for no reason. This is one of its most charming aspects.
es: The valet had to tap him twice on the shoulder to wake him, and as he opened his eyes, the shadow of a smile crossed his lips, as if he had been lost in some pleasant dream. In reality, he had not dreamed at all. No image, neither pleasant nor painful, had disturbed his rest. But youth smiles without reason. It is one of its greatest charms.

en: He turned round, and leaning upon his elbow, began to sip his chocolate. The mellow November sun came streaming into the room. The sky was bright, and there was a genial warmth in the air. It was almost like a morning in May.
vi: He turned around, and, leaning on his elbow, began to nibble on chocolate. The sweet November sunlight poured into the room. The sky was bright, and there was a pleasant warmth in the air. It felt like a morning in May.
tr: Dorian turned and began sipping his cocoa while leaning on his elbow. The soft November light was pouring into the room. The sky was sparkling, and there was a friendly warmth in the air. Almost like a May morning.
es: Turning around, Dorian Gray began to sip the chocolate, leaning on his elbow. The sweet November sun poured into the room. The sky was radiant, and there was a comforting warmth in the air. It was almost like a May morning.

en: Gradually the events of the preceding night crept with silent, blood-stained feet into his brain and reconstructed themselves there with terrible distinctness. He winced at the memory of all that he had suffered, and for a moment the same curious feeling of loathing for Basil Hallward that had made him kill him as he sat in the chair came back to him, and he grew cold with passion. The dead man was still sitting there, too, and in the sunlight now. How horrible that was! Such hideous things were for the darkness, not for the day.
vi: Slowly, the events of the previous night stealthily crept with blood-stained steps into his brain, and replayed there with terrible clarity. He recoiled at the memory of everything he had endured, and for a moment, that same strange hatred for Basil Hallward that had driven him to murder while he sat in the chair returned to him, chilling him with anger. The dead man was still sitting there, now in the sunlight. How horrifying that was! Such ghastly things are meant for the dark, not for the daylight.
tr: Over time, the events of the night, blood-stained and with silent steps, walked into his brain, where they coalesced and took shape with a terrible clarity. Dorian shuddered as he recalled all that he had endured. For a moment, that strange hatred that had led him to kill Basil Hallward as he sat in the chair enveloped him again, and Dorian froze with a vengeful fury. The dead man was still sitting in that chair; the sunlight must have been shining on him by now. What a dreadful thing this was! Such hideous ugliness belonged to the night, not to the daylight.
es: Little by little, the events of the previous night penetrated his brain, advancing stealthily with blood-stained feet, until they regained their shape with terrible clarity. A grimace of pain appeared on his face as he remembered all he had suffered and, for a moment, the strange feeling of hatred that had compelled him to kill Basil Hallward took hold of him again, filling him with an icy rage. The dead man was undoubtedly still sitting in the chair, now illuminated by the sun. What a horrible image! Such dreadful things were meant for the darkness of night, not for the light of day.

en: He felt that if he brooded on what he had gone through he would sicken or grow mad. There were sins whose fascination was more in the memory than in the doing of them, strange triumphs that gratified the pride more than the passions, and gave to the intellect a quickened sense of joy, greater than any joy they brought, or could ever bring, to the senses. But this was not one of them. It was a thing to be driven out of the mind, to be drugged with poppies, to be strangled lest it might strangle one itself.
vi: You find that if you keep brooding over what you have gone through, you will fall ill or go mad. There are sins whose allure lies more in the memory than in the act; strange victories that satisfy pride more than passion, and give the intellect a lively, intense joy greater than any pleasure it brings, or could ever bring, to the senses. But this was not one of them. It is something to be driven out of the soul, drugged with opium, strangled so that it cannot strangle itself.
tr: It seemed to Dorian that if he let the torments of last night replay in his mind, he would either fall ill or go mad. There were sins whose allure lay not in their commission but in their recollection: strange victories that flattered one's pride more than they dulled the fire of emotions, giving a surge of pride to the mind that was far greater and more vivid than the pleasure they gave to the senses. However, this event was not one of those sins. It was something that needed to be banished from the mind, numbed with opium. It had to be drowned, or else it could drown the man.
es: He felt that if he meditated on what had happened to him, he risked falling ill or going mad. There were sins whose fascination lay more in memory than in their actual commission; strange triumphs more gratifying to pride than to passions, and which gave the intellect a livelier feeling of joy, superior to the pleasure that they procure or could ever procure for the senses. But this last one did not belong to that category. It was something that needed to be expelled from the mind, lulled with opium, strangled before it could strangle you.

en: When the half-hour struck, he passed his hand across his forehead, and then got up hastily and dressed himself with even more than his usual care, giving a good deal of attention to the choice of his necktie and scarf-pin and changing his rings more than once. He spent a long time also over breakfast, tasting the various dishes, talking to his valet about some new liveries that he was thinking of getting made for the servants at Selby, and going through his correspondence. At some of the letters, he smiled. Three of them bored him. One he read several times over and then tore up with a slight look of annoyance in his face. “That awful thing, a woman’s memory!” as Lord Henry had once said.
vi: When the clock struck the half-hour, he wiped his hand across his forehead, then hurriedly stood up, dressed himself with more care than usual, paid much attention to choosing a tie with a pin for his scarf, and changed rings more than once. He also spent a lot of time on breakfast, tasting different dishes, talking to the servants about some new uniforms he was thinking of having made for the staff at Selby, and then went through the correspondence. He smiled at a few letters. Three of them bothered him. One letter he read several times and tore up with a slightly annoyed look on his face. “That terrible thing, a woman's memory!” as Lord Henry once said.
tr: When the clock struck half-past seven, Dorian quickly got up, passing his hand over his forehead, carefully selected his tie and tie pin, and dressed more meticulously than usual, changing his rings several times. He lingered at the breakfast table for a long time, tasting the various foods on the table, talked with his servant about the new uniforms he planned to have made for the servants at Selby, and reviewed the letters that had arrived in the mail. Some of the letters made him smile. Three of them gave him a sense of unease. One of them, after reading it from start to finish many times, he tore up with a slight anger on his face. As Lord Henry once said: “That dreadful thing called women's memory!”
es: When the clock struck half past, Dorian Gray ran his hand over his forehead, stood up decisively, and dressed with even more care than usual, paying great attention to the choice of tie and pin, and changing his rings more than once. He also spent a lot of time on breakfast, trying the different dishes, talking with his valet about the new liveries he was thinking of ordering for the servants at Selby, and going through his correspondence. Some of the letters made him smile. Three bored him. One he read several times and then tore up with a slight gesture of irritation on his face. "What a calamity, a woman's memories!" as Lord Henry had said on one occasion.

en: After he had drunk his cup of black coffee, he wiped his lips slowly with a napkin, motioned to his servant to wait, and going over to the table, sat down and wrote two letters. One he put in his pocket, the other he handed to the valet.
vi: After finishing his black coffee, he leisurely wiped his mouth with a napkin, signaled for the servant to wait, and went to the table to write two letters. He put one letter in his pocket and gave the other to the servant.
tr: After drinking his plain coffee from the cup, Dorian wiped his lips with a napkin, signaled his servant to wait, and went to the desk to write two letters. He put one of them in his pocket and handed the other to his servant.
es: After drinking the cup of black coffee, he slowly wiped his lips with the napkin, gestured to his servant to wait, and, heading towards his desk, sat down and wrote two letters. He put one in his pocket and handed the other to the servant.

en: “Take this round to 152, Hertford Street, Francis, and if Mr. Campbell is out of town, get his address.”
vi: "Take this to house number 152, Hertford Street, Francis, and if Mr. Campbell is out of town, get his address."
tr: "Francis, take this to 152 Hertford Street. If Mr. Campbell is out of town, get his address."
es: —Take her to 152 Hertford Street, Francis, and if Mr. Campbell has left London, ask for his address.

en: As soon as he was alone, he lit a cigarette and began sketching upon a piece of paper, drawing first flowers and bits of architecture, and then human faces. Suddenly he remarked that every face that he drew seemed to have a fantastic likeness to Basil Hallward. He frowned, and getting up, went over to the book-case and took out a volume at hazard. He was determined that he would not think about what had happened until it became absolutely necessary that he should do so.
vi: As soon as he was alone, he lit a cigarette and began sketching on a piece of paper, first drawing flowers, then structural patterns, and then faces. Suddenly, he noticed that every face he drew seemed to bear a strange resemblance to Basil Hallward. He frowned, stood up, went to the bookshelf, and randomly took out a book. He decided that he would not think about what had happened until it was absolutely necessary to do so.
tr: As soon as Dorian was alone, he lit a cigarette and started sketching something on a piece of paper. At first, he drew pictures of flowers, then human faces. Suddenly, he noticed that every face he drew bore a striking resemblance to Basil Hallward's face. Frowning, he got up and went to the bookshelf, picking a book at random. He was determined not to think about the night's event until it became unavoidable.
es: When he was left alone, he lit a cigarette and began to draw on a piece of paper: first flowers, then architectural details, and finally, faces. Suddenly, he noticed that all the faces he drew seemed to have a strange resemblance to Basil Hallward. He frowned and, standing up, walked over to a shelf and took a volume at random. He was determined not to think about what had happened until it was absolutely necessary to do so.

en: When he had stretched himself on the sofa, he looked at the title-page of the book. It was Gautier’s “Émaux et Camées”, Charpentier’s Japanese-paper edition, with the Jacquemart etching. The binding was of citron-green leather, with a design of gilt trellis-work and dotted pomegranates. It had been given to him by Adrian Singleton. As he turned over the pages, his eye fell on the poem about the hand of Lacenaire, the cold yellow hand “du supplice encore mal lavée,” with its downy red hairs and its “doigts de faune.” He glanced at his own white taper fingers, shuddering slightly in spite of himself, and passed on, till he came to those lovely stanzas upon Venice:
vi: As he stretched out on the sofa, he looked at the title page of the book. It was the book Émaux et Camées, by Gautier, the Japanese paper edition by Charpentier, with acid engravings by Jacquemart. The cover was of lemon-green leather, with a gold lattice pattern and speckled pomegranates. Adrian Singleton had given it to him. As he turned the page, his eyes noticed the poem about Lacenaire's hand, the cold golden hand “du supplice encore mal lavée1," with red down and "doigts de faune2.” He glanced at his own slender white fingers, shuddered involuntarily, and read on, until he came to those lovely stanzas about Venice:
tr: When he lay down on the couch, he looked at the title of the book in his hand. It was Gautier's Émaux et Camées, the Charpentier edition adorned with Jacquemart engravings on Japanese paper. The binding was of lemon-green morocco, with gilt latticework and speckled pomegranate designs. Adrian Singleton had given him this book. As Dorian turned the pages, his eye caught a poem about Lacenaire's hand: that cold yellow hand with fine red hairs and fingers "like those of a forest god": "du supplice encore mal lavée" –still unwashed from the torture–. Dorian looked at his own long-fingered, snow-white hands and involuntarily shuddered slightly as he turned the page. A little later, he found those beautiful quatrains written about Venice:
es: After lying down on the sofa, he looked at the title of the book. It was Émaux et Camées[14], the Charpentier edition on Japan paper, with an engraving by Jacquemart[15]. The binding was of lime green leather, with a gold lattice, sprinkled with pomegranates. It had been given to him by Adrian Singleton. As he turned the pages, his eyes stopped at a poem about Lacenaire's[16] hand, the icy yellowish hand «du supplice encore mal lavée», with its red hair and its «doigts de faune». Dorian Gray looked at his own fingers, white as wax, shuddered involuntarily, and moved on until he reached the splendid stanzas dedicated to Venice:

en: Sur une gamme chromatique,
vi: "On a chromatic scale,
tr: "In the carnival of ever-changing colors"
es: On a chromatic scale,

en: Le sein de perles ruisselant,
vi: The breast of pearls glistening,
tr: Their chests shimmering with pearls
es: The breast glistening with pearls,

en: La Vénus de l’Adriatique
vi: The Venus of the Adriatic
tr: Venus of the Adriatic Sea
es: The Venus of the Adriatic

en: Sort de l’eau son corps rose et blanc.
vi: Her pink and white body emerges from the water.
tr: She emerges from the waters with her pink and white body.
es: Emerges from the water, her body pink and white.

en: Les dômes, sur l’azur des ondes
vi: "The domes, on the azure of the waves
tr: The domes reflect in the blue of the waters,
es: The domes, on the azure of the waves

en: Suivant la phrase au pur contour,
vi: Following the sentence with a pure outline,
tr: By watching a pure feeling.
es: Following the sentence with a pure outline,

en: S’enflent comme des gorges rondes
vi: Swell like round throats
tr: Rising with a sigh of love Swell like round breasts
es: Swell like round throats

en: Que soulève un soupir d’amour.
vi: That raises a sigh of love.
tr: Tying the mooring line to a post
es: That raises a sigh of love.

en: L’esquif aborde et me dépose,
vi: "The skiff lands and drops me off,
tr: The boat left me on the shore,
es: The skiff approaches and drops me off

en: Jetant son amarre au pilier,
vi: Throwing its mooring to the pillar,
tr: On the marble steps
es: Throwing his anchor at the pilferer,

en: Devant une façade rose,
vi: In front of a pink façade, On the marble of a staircase." 3 1 Just washed away the disgust. 2 The fingers of the prodigy. 3 Breasts covered in pearls / A person sweet and fragrant / Adriatic Venus rises / On the waves of the strait / The arches of the waves / Chasing after the music / To the rhythm of the waves / Like the chest of love sighing / Throwing chains around the anchor post / I dock at the market / The rosy facade finally /
tr: The facade of a pink building.”
es: In front of a pink facade,

en: Sur le marbre d’un escalier.
vi: On the marble steps.
tr: The facade of a pink building.”
es: On the marble of a staircase.

en: How exquisite they were! As one read them, one seemed to be floating down the green water-ways of the pink and pearl city, seated in a black gondola with silver prow and trailing curtains. The mere lines looked to him like those straight lines of turquoise-blue that follow one as one pushes out to the Lido. The sudden flashes of colour reminded him of the gleam of the opal-and-iris-throated birds that flutter round the tall honeycombed Campanile, or stalk, with such stately grace, through the dim, dust-stained arcades. Leaning back with half-closed eyes, he kept saying over and over to himself:
vi: How wonderful they are! When I read them, I seem to drift along the green canals of a pink pearl city, sitting in a black boat with a silver prow and a trailing canopy. Just the lines of poetry alone, to you, seem like turquoise streaks following me as I speed towards Lido. The sudden flashes of color remind you of the flickering light of the cat-eyed, emerald-throated, and multi-colored birds fluttering around the towering, honeycomb-like Bell Tower, or gracefully soaring, with an air of majestic elegance, through the dark, dusty arches. Leaning back, eyes half-closed, you keep talking to yourself endlessly:
tr: How exquisite were these verses! While reading these lines, one felt as if they were gliding through the green water roads of that pink and pearly city in a black gondola with silver prow and fluttering curtains. The mere form of these lines evoked for Dorian the turquoise blue, straight lines followed when going to Lido. The sudden flashes of color reminded him of those iridescent purple-necked birds flapping around the high, honeycombed Campanile and walking with dignified harmony under the dusty, dim arches. Dorian half-closed his eyes and leaned back, saying to himself, On the marble steps
es: What exquisite verses! Reading them gave the impression of floating through the green canals of the city of pink and pearl gray, sitting in a black gondola with a silver prow and some veils dragged by the breeze. The verses themselves seemed like the straight turquoise blue wakes that follow the visitor when sailing towards the Lido. The sudden bursts of color reminded him of the flashes of the pigeons —the opal and iris-colored throats— that flutter around the slender beehive-shaped campanile, or that stroll, with quiet elegance, among the dusty arches in the shadows. Leaning back, with his eyes half-closed, Dorian repeated the verses over and over again:

en: “Devant une façade rose,
vi: "In front of a pink facade,
tr: The facade of a pink building...
es: “In front of a pink facade,

en: Sur le marbre d’un escalier.”
vi: On the marble of a staircase."
tr: He started repeating the lines over and over again.
es: On the marble of a staircase.

en: The whole of Venice was in those two lines. He remembered the autumn that he had passed there, and a wonderful love that had stirred him to mad delightful follies. There was romance in every place. But Venice, like Oxford, had kept the background for romance, and, to the true romantic, background was everything, or almost everything. Basil had been with him part of the time, and had gone wild over Tintoret. Poor Basil! What a horrible way for a man to die!
vi: All of Venice in these two lines of poetry. You remember the autumn you spent here, and a wonderful romance that inspired you to do crazy, delightful things. Romance is everywhere. But Venice, like Oxford, provides the backdrop for romance, and with true romance, the backdrop is everything, or nearly everything. Basil was with you for part of that time, very excited about Tintoret. Poor Basil! What a tragic death!
tr: All of Venice was in these two lines. Dorian remembered the autumn season he spent there, that marvelous love that incited him to magnificent follies. Everywhere was filled with romance. Venice, like Oxford, had managed to preserve its romantic decor, which meant everything, or almost everything, to true romantics. Basil had also stayed with him for a while, becoming madly infatuated with Tintoretto. Poor Basil! What a terrible death he had met.
es: All of Venice was contained there. He remembered the autumn he had spent in the city, and the wonderful love that drove him to wild and delightful madness. There was poetry everywhere. Because Venice, like Oxford, preserved the proper poetic atmosphere and, for the true romantic, the atmosphere was everything, or almost everything. Basil spent some time with him during that stay, and he had become enthusiastic about Tintoretto. Poor Basil! What a horrible death he had!

en: He sighed, and took up the volume again, and tried to forget. He read of the swallows that fly in and out of the little café at Smyrna where the Hadjis sit counting their amber beads and the turbaned merchants smoke their long tasselled pipes and talk gravely to each other; he read of the Obelisk in the Place de la Concorde that weeps tears of granite in its lonely sunless exile and longs to be back by the hot, lotus-covered Nile, where there are Sphinxes, and rose-red ibises, and white vultures with gilded claws, and crocodiles with small beryl eyes that crawl over the green steaming mud; he began to brood over those verses which, drawing music from kiss-stained marble, tell of that curious statue that Gautier compares to a contralto voice, the “monstre charmant” that couches in the porphyry-room of the Louvre. But after a time the book fell from his hand. He grew nervous, and a horrible fit of terror came over him. What if Alan Campbell should be out of England? Days would elapse before he could come back. Perhaps he might refuse to come. What could he do then? Every moment was of vital importance.
vi: He sighed, picked up the book again, and tried to forget. He read about the swallows flying in and out of a small café in Smyrna where the Hadjis sat counting amber beads while the turbaned merchants smoked long tasseled pipes and solemnly conversed with each other; he read about the Obelisk in the Place de la Concorde, weeping granite tears in its gloomy, lonely exile, longing to return to the hot Nile covered with lotus flowers, where there were Sphinx statues, red-pink ibises, white vultures with gilded claws, and crocodiles, with tiny berin eyes, crawling through the green steaming mud; he began to ponder the verses that, drawing music from the marble kissed by a kiss, spoke of the strange statue that Gautier had compared to a contralto voice, “monstre charmant” still lying in the porphyry room at the Louvre. But after a while, the book fell from his hands. He became restless, a terrible fear overwhelmed him. What if Alan Campbell had left England? Many days would pass before he could return. He might even refuse to come. Then what would he do? Every moment was of critical importance.
tr: Dorian sighed deeply and picked up the book again, trying to forget everything. He read the lines describing the small café in Izmir: the swallows flitting in and out of the windows, the pilgrims sitting and pulling their amber rosaries, the turbaned merchants having solemn conversations while puffing on their long, tasseled pipes. He read the poem describing the obelisk at Place de la Concorde in Paris: In its sunless exile, utterly alone, shedding granite tears and longing to be on the warm banks of the Nile covered with water lilies, among the sphinxes, rose-red ibises, white hawks with gilded talons, and the small jade-eyed crocodiles crawling through the steaming mud. The verses describing that strange sculpture, which Gautier likened to a deep, resonant voice, the monstre charmant crouching in ambush in the porphyry room of the Louvre, and distilling poetry from marble covered in lip marks, enveloped Dorian's mind. But after a while, the book fell from his hand. He was filled with dread, then he was seized by a terrible fear. What if Alan Campbell was out of the country? Days would pass until he returned. Perhaps he would refuse to come to Dorian. What would Dorian do then? Every passing minute carried vital importance.
es: Dorian Gray sighed, opened Gautier's book again, and tried to forget. He read the verses dedicated to the little café in Smyrna where the hajis pass their amber beads, and the turbaned merchants smoke their long pipes adorned with tassels, while they converse about profound topics as the swallows dart in and out making quick turns; he read about the obelisk in the Place de la Concorde that sheds granite tears in its lonely sunless exile and longs to return to the burning Nile covered with lotus flowers, where there are sphinxes and pink ibises and white vultures with golden claws and crocodiles with beryl eyes that crawl through the steaming green mud; and he began to dream with the stanzas that, drawing music from the marble stained with kisses, speak of the curious statue that Gautier compares to a contralto voice, the "monstre charmant" lying in the Louvre in the hall of porphyries. But after some time the book fell from his hands. Nervousness began to dominate him, culminating in a tremendous attack of terror. What would happen if Alan Campbell was not in England? Days and days would have to pass before he returned. Perhaps he would refuse to come back. What to do then? Every minute counted; it was of vital importance.

en: They had been great friends once, five years before—almost inseparable, indeed. Then the intimacy had come suddenly to an end. When they met in society now, it was only Dorian Gray who smiled: Alan Campbell never did.
vi: They had been close friends, five years ago — almost inseparable, really. Then the closeness had suddenly come to an end. Now when they met in high society, only Dorian Gray smiled; Alan Campbell never did.
tr: Once, five years ago, they were very close friends. Alan Campbell and he were inseparable. Then, this closeness suddenly came to an end. Now, when they met in public, only Dorian Gray would smile and greet him. Alan Campbell never responded to these greetings.
es: They had been great friends once, five years ago; almost inseparable, to tell the truth. Then their intimacy ended abruptly. When they met in public, it was Dorian Gray who smiled, never Alan Campbell.

en: He was an extremely clever young man, though he had no real appreciation of the visible arts, and whatever little sense of the beauty of poetry he possessed he had gained entirely from Dorian. His dominant intellectual passion was for science. At Cambridge he had spent a great deal of his time working in the laboratory, and had taken a good class in the Natural Science Tripos of his year. Indeed, he was still devoted to the study of chemistry, and had a laboratory of his own in which he used to shut himself up all day long, greatly to the annoyance of his mother, who had set her heart on his standing for Parliament and had a vague idea that a chemist was a person who made up prescriptions. He was an excellent musician, however, as well, and played both the violin and the piano better than most amateurs. In fact, it was music that had first brought him and Dorian Gray together—music and that indefinable attraction that Dorian seemed to be able to exercise whenever he wished—and, indeed, exercised often without being conscious of it. They had met at Lady Berkshire’s the night that Rubinstein played there, and after that used to be always seen together at the opera and wherever good music was going on. For eighteen months their intimacy lasted. Campbell was always either at Selby Royal or in Grosvenor Square. To him, as to many others, Dorian Gray was the type of everything that is wonderful and fascinating in life. Whether or not a quarrel had taken place between them no one ever knew. But suddenly people remarked that they scarcely spoke when they met and that Campbell seemed always to go away early from any party at which Dorian Gray was present. He had changed, too—was strangely melancholy at times, appeared almost to dislike hearing music, and would never himself play, giving as his excuse, when he was called upon, that he was so absorbed in science that he had no time left in which to practise. And this was certainly true. Every day he seemed to become more interested in biology, and his name appeared once or twice in some of the scientific reviews in connection with certain curious experiments.
vi: A Muslim pilgrim once journeyed to the holy city of Mecca He was an extremely intelligent young man, although he did not truly appreciate the tangible arts, and any ability to perceive the beauty of poetry that he possessed was entirely absorbed from Dorian. His predominant intellectual passion was for science. At Cambridge, he spent a lot of time working in the laboratory, achieving high marks in the annual examination for outstanding natural science students. Indeed, he remained devoted to the study of chemistry, and had a private laboratory where he often secluded himself all day long, much to the distress of his mother, who earnestly wished for him to have a position in Parliament, and had a vague notion that a chemist was someone who wrote prescriptions. However, he was also an excellent musician and played both the violin and the piano better than most amateurs. In fact, it was music that first brought him and Dorian Gray together — music and the indefinable charm that Dorian seemed able to wield whenever he wished, and indeed did so frequently and unconsciously. They met at Mrs. Berkshire's on the night Rubinstein performed there, and subsequently often encountered each other at the opera house, and anywhere there was good music. Their closeness lasted eighteen months. Campbell was always at Selby Royal or Grosvenor Square. To him, as to many others, Dorian Gray was the epitome of all that was wonderful and enchanting in life. Whether any quarrel had occurred between them, no one ever knew. But suddenly people noticed that they hardly spoke to each other when they met, and that Campbell seemed always to leave early from any party where Dorian Gray was present. He also changed — sometimes becoming strangely melancholic, appearing almost to hate music, never playing himself, and apologizing when invited to do so, saying that he was so engrossed in science that he had no time to practice. And this was probably true. With each passing day, he seemed to become more interested in biology, and his name appeared a few times in various scientific journals, related to some peculiar experiments.
tr: Although he didn't really understand visual arts, he had barely learned to appreciate the beauty of poetry from Dorian, but he was an extremely intelligent young man. His main intellectual passion was the natural sciences. While at Cambridge, he spent most of his time working in the laboratory. In his final year, he had also achieved a good grade in the honors exams for natural sciences. He was still interested in chemistry studies, and he even had a private laboratory. By shutting himself in there from morning till night, he would get on the nerves of his mother, who thought chemists were just people who filled prescriptions and was fixated on him entering Parliament. On the other hand, he was an excellent musician; he played both the violin and the piano much better than most amateurs. In fact, it was music that brought him together with Dorian Gray; music, and that indescribable attraction Dorian often (unconsciously) evoked whenever he wished. They had met at Lady Berkshire's, on the night Rubinstein played the piano there. Later, they were often seen together at the opera, and everywhere quality music was played. This closeness lasted for eighteen months. Campbell had practically moved into the house on Grosvenor Square from Selby Royal. Like many others, to him, Dorian Gray was the symbol of everything magnificent and enchanting in the world. It was never known whether they had a quarrel. However, it soon became noticeable that they hardly spoke when they met. Campbell began to leave gatherings where Dorian Gray was present, early. Campbell had changed a lot; he seemed to fall into a strange lethargy, as if he no longer enjoyed listening to music; he no longer played the piano, and when asked to play, he would excuse himself by saying that he was too engrossed in his scientific pursuits to have time for music practice, which was indeed true. The young man's interest in biology seemed to grow with each passing day. His name had appeared several times in some scientific journals in connection with strange experiments.
es: He was an extraordinarily intelligent young man, although without a true appreciation for the visual arts, and if he had come to grasp the beauty of poetry at all, he owed it entirely to Dorian. His dominant intellectual passion was science. At Cambridge, he spent a large part of his time working in the laboratory, and he had obtained a good grade in the final natural sciences exam. In fact, he was still dedicated to the study of chemistry, and he had his own laboratory, where he would often lock himself up all day, much to the irritation of his mother, who tended to confuse chemists with apothecaries, and who was especially hopeful that he would secure a seat in Parliament. Campbell was, on the other hand, an excellent musician, and he played the violin and the piano better than most amateurs. Music had, in fact, been the bond between Dorian Gray and him: music and the indefinable charm that Dorian could use at will and often did use without being aware of it. They had met at Lady Berkshire's house the night Rubinstein played there, and afterward, they were frequently seen together at the opera and wherever good music was performed. Their intimacy had lasted eighteen months. Campbell was always at Selby Royal or in Grosvenor Square. For him, as for many others, Dorian Gray represented the model of everything wonderful and fascinating in life. Nobody knew if they had ended up fighting. But, suddenly, other people noticed that they barely spoke when they saw each other, and that Campbell would soon leave the parties that Dorian Gray attended. He had changed, moreover: he sometimes appeared strangely melancholic, almost as if music displeased him, and he never played, giving as an excuse, when asked to perform something, that he was so absorbed in science that he lacked time to practice. And it was undoubtedly true. With each passing day, he seemed more interested in biology, and his name had appeared once or twice in some scientific journals, in relation to certain curious experiments.

en: This was the man Dorian Gray was waiting for. Every second he kept glancing at the clock. As the minutes went by he became horribly agitated. At last he got up and began to pace up and down the room, looking like a beautiful caged thing. He took long stealthy strides. His hands were curiously cold.
vi: That is the person whom Dorian Gray is waiting for. He keeps looking at the clock every second. As the minutes pass, he becomes terribly anxious. Finally, he stands up and begins to pace back and forth in the room, looking like a beautiful beast trapped in a cage. He takes long, stealthy strides. His hands are strangely cold.
tr: This was the man Dorian Gray had been waiting for. Dorian kept looking at the clock on the wall every moment, and as the minutes passed, the ugly, anxious excitement inside him grew. Finally, he got up and began pacing the room: He was like a beautiful creature trapped in a cage. He walked with long, stealthy steps. His hands were ice-cold, for some reason.
es: Such was the man that Dorian Gray was waiting for. His gaze turned towards the clock every moment. As the minutes passed, his agitation increased. Finally, he got up and began to pace around the room, with the appearance of a beautiful caged animal. He walked with long strides that had something furtive about them. And his hands had become strangely cold.

en: The suspense became unbearable. Time seemed to him to be crawling with feet of lead, while he by monstrous winds was being swept towards the jagged edge of some black cleft of precipice. He knew what was waiting for him there; saw it, indeed, and, shuddering, crushed with dank hands his burning lids as though he would have robbed the very brain of sight and driven the eyeballs back into their cave. It was useless. The brain had its own food on which it battened, and the imagination, made grotesque by terror, twisted and distorted as a living thing by pain, danced like some foul puppet on a stand and grinned through moving masks. Then, suddenly, time stopped for him. Yes: that blind, slow-breathing thing crawled no more, and horrible thoughts, time being dead, raced nimbly on in front, and dragged a hideous future from its grave, and showed it to him. He stared at it. Its very horror made him stone.
vi: The state of waiting became unbearable. He felt time dragging its leaden feet, while he was swept by monstrous gusts towards the jagged edge of some black fissure on the cliff face. He knew what was waiting for him there; saw it truly, and, shuddering, pressed his damp hands to his burning eyelids as if he could steal his vision, pushing his eyeballs back into their sockets. In vain. The brain has its own nutrients that it still feeds on, and the imagination, twisted by fear, writhed and contorted like a pained creature, dancing like some ugly puppet on a stage, grinning through its twitching mask. Then, suddenly, Time stopped for him. Yes: that blind, slow-breathing thing no longer crawled, and the terrible thoughts, with Time paralyzed, raced ahead, dragging a ghastly future out of its grave, showing it to him. He stared at it. Its very horror turned him to stone.
tr: The tension of his waiting was at unbearable levels. It seemed to Dorian that while he was being swept towards jagged rocks at the mouth of a pitch-black abyss by tremendous winds, time was crawling with leaden feet. Dorian knew what awaited him in that abyss; he didn't just know, he saw it, and he shuddered from head to toe, pressing his burning eyelids with his damp hands, wanting to crush the vision in his brain, to push his eyes back into their sockets. But it wasn't working. The brain was finding nourishment on its own to feed itself. Imagination, driven mad by horror, was writhing and struggling like a living creature in pain, playing like a disgusting puppet on a string, grinning from beneath shifting masks. Then, suddenly, time stopped for Dorian Gray. Yes, that heavy-breathing, blind-eyed thing was no longer moving. Now that time had died, chilling thoughts raced ahead, unearthing a hideous, horrifying future and showing it to Dorian. Dorian stood transfixed by it. He was petrified by the horror of what he saw.
es: The uncertainty became unbearable. He had the impression that time was dragging its feet, while he, pushed by monstrous hurricanes, advanced towards the jagged edge of a black precipice. Dorian knew what awaited him down there; he even saw it, and, trembling, he pressed his burning eyelids with damp hands as if he wanted to steal the sight from his very brain, pushing his eyeballs deep into their sockets. But it was useless. The brain had its own sustenance, on which it fed, and the imagination, driven to grotesque excesses by terror, writhed and deformed like a living being in pain, danced like a horrible puppet on a stage, and grimaced behind animated masks. Then, suddenly, Time stopped for him. Yes; that blind dimension, with its slow breathing, ceased to drag on, and horrible thoughts, since Time had died, began a rapid race and unearthed the dreadful future from its grave to show it to him. Dorian stared at it fixedly. And the horror he felt left him petrified.

en: At last the door opened and his servant entered. He turned glazed eyes upon him.
vi: Finally, the door opened, and his servant stepped in. He looked at him with glazed eyes.
tr: Finally, the door opened, and the servant entered. Dorian turned his glazed eyes to him.
es: Finally, the door opened, giving way to the valet. Dorian Gray looked at him with glassy eyes.

en: “Mr. Campbell, sir,” said the man.
vi: “Mr. Campbell has arrived, sir,” the person said.
tr: "Mr. Campbell, sir," said the man.
es: —Mr. Campbell —he announced.

en: A sigh of relief broke from his parched lips, and the colour came back to his cheeks.
vi: A sigh of relief escaped from his parched lips, and color returned to his cheeks.
tr: A relieved breath escaped from Dorian's parched lips, and the color returned to his face.
es: A sigh of relief then escaped from the parched lips of Dorian Gray, and color returned to his cheeks.

en: “Ask him to come in at once, Francis.” He felt that he was himself again. His mood of cowardice had passed away.
vi: "Please let him in immediately, Francis." He felt like himself again. His cowardly mood had vanished.
tr: "Please come in, Francis." Dorian had composed himself by now. The earlier cowardice had passed.
es: —Have him come in right now, Francis —he felt like his old self again. He had overcome the moment of cowardice.

en: The man bowed and retired. In a few moments, Alan Campbell walked in, looking very stern and rather pale, his pallor being intensified by his coal-black hair and dark eyebrows.
vi: The servant bowed his head and withdrew. A moment later, Alan Campbell walked in, looking very stern and quite pale, his pallor further accentuated by his coal-black hair and dark eyebrows.
tr: The servant bowed and withdrew. A few minutes later, Campbell entered. His face was very stern, a bit pale, and the coal-black of his hair and eyebrows seemed to accentuate the pallor of his complexion.
es: The servant bowed his head and withdrew. Moments later, Alan Campbell entered, looking severe and quite pale, the pallor intensified by his jet-black hair and eyebrows.

en: “Alan! This is kind of you. I thank you for coming.”
vi: “Alan! You are so kind. Thank you for coming.”
tr: “Alan! You are very good. Thank you for coming, much appreciated.”
es: —Atan! How kind of you! Thank you so much for coming.

en: “I had intended never to enter your house again, Gray. But you said it was a matter of life and death.” His voice was hard and cold. He spoke with slow deliberation. There was a look of contempt in the steady searching gaze that he turned on Dorian. He kept his hands in the pockets of his Astrakhan coat, and seemed not to have noticed the gesture with which he had been greeted.
vi: “I had decided never to step into your house again, Gray. But you said this was a matter of life and death.” His voice was harsh and cold. He spoke slowly. A look of contempt in the calm scrutinizing gaze he cast at Dorian. He kept his hands in the pockets of his karakul wool coat, and seemed indifferent to the gesture with which he was greeted.
tr: “I was determined never to set foot in your house again, Gray. But you wrote that this is a matter of life and death.” The young man's voice was firm and cold. He spoke slowly and deliberately. There was a hint of disdain in the sharp look he directed at Dorian. He hadn't taken his hands out of the pockets of his astrakhan coat and had ignored Dorian's gesture of greeting.
es: —I had resolved not to set foot in your house again, Gray. But I was told it was a matter of life and death —his voice was hard and cold, and he spoke with studied slowness. There was an expression of contempt in the insistent gaze with which he proceeded to study Dorian's face. He kept his hands in the pockets of his astrakhan coat and gave the impression of not having noticed the gesture with which he had been received.

en: “Yes: it is a matter of life and death, Alan, and to more than one person. Sit down.”
vi: “Correct: this is a matter of life and death, Alan, and for more than one individual. Please have a seat.”
tr: “Yes, it's a matter of life and death, Alan, and not just for one single person. Have a seat, dear.”
es: —Yes; it is a matter of life and death, Alan, and for more than one person. Please sit down.

en: Campbell took a chair by the table, and Dorian sat opposite to him. The two men’s eyes met. In Dorian’s there was infinite pity. He knew that what he was going to do was dreadful.
vi: Campbell took the seat next to the table, while Dorian sat opposite him. Their eyes met. There was boundless affection in Dorian's eyes. He knew that what he was about to do was very frightening.
tr: Campbell sat down on a chair at the desk. Dorian stood across from him. Their gazes met. There was infinite pity in Dorian's eyes. He knew the task he was about to do was dreadful.
es: Campbell occupied a chair next to the table, and Dorian sat across from him. The two men looked into each other's eyes. In Dorian's eyes, there was infinite compassion. He knew that what he was about to do was dreadful.

en: After a strained moment of silence, he leaned across and said, very quietly, but watching the effect of each word upon the face of him he had sent for, “Alan, in a locked room at the top of this house, a room to which nobody but myself has access, a dead man is seated at a table. He has been dead ten hours now. Don’t stir, and don’t look at me like that. Who the man is, why he died, how he died, are matters that do not concern you. What you have to do is this—”
vi: After a moment of tense silence, he leaned over and said, very calmly, but carefully observing the impact of each word he conveyed on his face, "Alan, in a locked room on the top floor of this building, a room that no one but me has the right to enter, there is a dead man sitting at the table. He has been dead for about ten hours. Don't move, and don't look at me like that. Who that person is, why he died, how he died, are matters that do not concern you. What you need to do is this…”
tr: After a short, tense silence, he leaned towards his guest, calmly, yet observing the effect of each of his words on the face opposite him, and said, "Alan." "In a locked room on the top floor of this house, there is a dead man sitting at a desk. No one but me can enter or leave the room. The man has been dead for ten hours. Don't fidget, and don't look at me like that. Who this man is, how he died, why he died... These are matters that do not concern you. Now, the only thing you need to do is..."
es: After a tense moment of silence, he leaned forward and said, very calmly, but attentive to the effect of each word on the face of his visitor: —Alan, in a locked room in the attic of this house, in a room that no one, except myself, has access to, there is a dead man sitting at a table. He has been dead for ten hours now. Do not move, nor look at me that way. Who that person is, why he died, how he died, are matters that do not concern you. What you have to do is this...

en: “Stop, Gray. I don’t want to know anything further. Whether what you have told me is true or not true doesn’t concern me. I entirely decline to be mixed up in your life. Keep your horrible secrets to yourself. They don’t interest me any more.”
vi: “Stop, Gray. I don't want to know anything more. Whether what you tell me is true or not, it doesn't concern me. I completely refuse to be involved in your life. Keep your terrible secrets to yourself. I don't care about them anymore.”
tr: “Enough, Gray. I don't want to know anything else. I don't care whether what you told me is true or not. I refuse to interfere in your life. Keep your dirty secrets to yourself. These things don't concern me in the slightest anymore.”
es: —Enough, Gray. I don't want to know anything more. I don't know if what you just told me is a lie or the truth. I don't care. I completely refuse to get involved in your life. Keep your horrible secrets to yourself. They no longer interest me.

en: “Alan, they will have to interest you. This one will have to interest you. I am awfully sorry for you, Alan. But I can’t help myself. You are the one man who is able to save me. I am forced to bring you into the matter. I have no option. Alan, you are scientific. You know about chemistry and things of that kind. You have made experiments. What you have got to do is to destroy the thing that is upstairs—to destroy it so that not a vestige of it will be left. Nobody saw this person come into the house. Indeed, at the present moment he is supposed to be in Paris. He will not be missed for months. When he is missed, there must be no trace of him found here. You, Alan, you must change him, and everything that belongs to him, into a handful of ashes that I may scatter in the air.”
vi: “Alan, you will have to take care of them. You will have to take care of this one thing. I am very sorry for you, Alan. But I cannot help myself. You are the only one who can save me. I am forced to drag you into this. I have no choice. Alan, you are a scientist. You know about chemistry, and things of that sort. You conduct experiments. What you have to do is destroy the thing in the attic — destroy it so that not a trace of it remains. No one saw this person enter the house. Indeed, everyone thinks he is currently in Paris. He will not be remembered for many months. We must make sure that when people do remember him, they cannot find anything of him here. You, Alan, you must turn him, and everything of his, into a handful of ashes that I can scatter into the air.”
tr: “It will inevitably concern you, Alan. This secret, helplessly, will concern you. I pity you a lot, very much, my friend, but I have no other way out. You are the only person who can save me. I have to involve you in this matter. I have no other option. You are a scientist, Alan. You understand chemistry and such. You have conducted experiments. Now, what you need to do is to get rid of that thing upstairs, leaving no trace behind. No one saw anyone enter this house. It will be months before anyone notices its absence. When they do notice, there should be no trace of it in this house. You, Alan, yes, you must turn the man and everything belonging to him into a handful of ashes that I can scatter into the air.”
es: —They have to interest you, Alan. This one, in particular, is going to have to interest you. I'm very sorry for you, but I can't help it. You are the only person who can save me. I am forced to compel your intervention. I have no alternative. You are a man of science, Alan. You know chemistry and other related things. You have conducted experiments. The matter at hand is for you to destroy the lifeless body that is up there; to destroy it in such a way that not the slightest trace remains. No one saw that person enter this house. It is believed, in fact, that they are currently in Paris. Months will pass before they are missed. When that happens, it is essential that no trace of them remains here. You, Alan, must take charge of turning them, and all their belongings, into a handful of ashes that can be scattered to the wind.

en: “You are mad, Dorian.”
vi: “You are crazy, Dorian.”
tr: “You have gone mad, Dorian.”
es: —You are crazy, Dorian.

en: “Ah! I was waiting for you to call me Dorian.”
vi: "Wow! I was waiting for you to call me Dorian."
tr: “Ah! I was expecting you to call me, Dorian.”
es: —Ah! I was eagerly waiting for you to call me, Dorian.

en: “You are mad, I tell you—mad to imagine that I would raise a finger to help you, mad to make this monstrous confession. I will have nothing to do with this matter, whatever it is. Do you think I am going to peril my reputation for you? What is it to me what devil’s work you are up to?”
vi: “You’re crazy, I’m telling you — crazy for thinking I would lift even a finger to help you, crazy for uttering this horrendous confession. I will have nothing to do with this, whatever it is. Do you think I would risk my reputation for you? Whatever devilish thing you’re doing, what does it have to do with me?”
tr: “You are insane, I'm telling you. You think I would even lift a finger to help you... Confessing this horrible thing to me, it's all madness. No matter what this is about, I'm not getting involved. Do you think I would risk tarnishing my name for your sake? Why should I care about whatever devilish scheme you've gotten yourself into this time?”
es: —You are crazy, I repeat... Crazy to imagine that I would lift a finger to help you, crazy to make that monstrous confession. I don't want to have anything to do with that matter, whatever it is. Do you think I'm willing to put my reputation at risk for you? What do I care about what diabolical task you've gotten yourself into?

en: “It was suicide, Alan.”
vi: “It was a suicide, Alan.”
tr: “It was suicide, Alan.”
es: —This is a suicide, Alan.

en: “I am glad of that. But who drove him to it? You, I should fancy.”
vi: “I am very happy with that. But who pushed him to do that? You, I suppose.”
tr: “Well, I'm glad about that. But what was the factor that drove the man to suicide? It was probably because of you.”
es: —I'm glad to hear that. But, who pushed him to suicide? I'm sure it was you.

en: “Do you still refuse to do this for me?”
vi: “Are you still refusing to do this for me?”
tr: “You still refuse to do this job for me, huh?”
es: —Are you still refusing to do what I ask?

en: “Of course I refuse. I will have absolutely nothing to do with it. I don’t care what shame comes on you. You deserve it all. I should not be sorry to see you disgraced, publicly disgraced. How dare you ask me, of all men in the world, to mix myself up in this horror? I should have thought you knew more about people’s characters. Your friend Lord Henry Wotton can’t have taught you much about psychology, whatever else he has taught you. Nothing will induce me to stir a step to help you. You have come to the wrong man. Go to some of your friends. Don’t come to me.”
vi: “Of course I refuse. I will absolutely have nothing to do with it. I don't care what disgrace will come to you. You completely deserve it. I will not be saddened to see you being abandoned, being publicly abandoned. How dare you ask me, among so many people in the world, to get involved in this horrendous affair? I thought you understood more about human nature. Lord Henry Wotton, your friend, cannot teach you much about psychology, even though he has taught you many other things. Nothing could compel me to take a step to help you. You have come to the wrong person. Go to someone else among your friends. Do not come to see me.
tr: “Of course I refuse. I will not get involved in this matter in any way. So, even if you become disgraced, it doesn't matter to me. You deserve every kind of disgrace. Even if I see you being humiliated in front of everyone, I wouldn't feel sorry. As if there were no other men left in the world, how can you ask me to get involved in such a terrible thing with what face? I thought you understood human character better. I don't know what else your friend Lord Henry Wotton has taught you, but he must not have taught you much in the field of psychology. No pressure in the world can make me help you. You chose the wrong man. Go to one of your friends. Don't come to me.”
es: —Of course, I refuse. I don't want to have anything to do with it. I don't care what it brings you. You deserve everything that happens to you. It won't sadden me to see you dishonored, publicly dishonored. How dare you ask me, especially me, to take part in that horror? I would have thought you understood people's nature better. Maybe your friend Lord Henry Wotton hasn't taught you much about psychology, even though he has taught you a lot about other things. Nothing will make me take a step to help you. You have chosen the wrong person. Go to one of your friends. Not to me.

en: “Alan, it was murder. I killed him. You don’t know what he had made me suffer. Whatever my life is, he had more to do with the making or the marring of it than poor Harry has had. He may not have intended it, the result was the same.”
vi: “Alan, that's murder. I killed him. You don't know what he made me endure. No matter how my life turned out, he was more involved in creating or ruining it than poor Harry ever was. He may not have intended it, but the result is the same.”
tr: “Alan, this is murder. I killed him. You have no idea what he put me through! No matter what kind of life I lived, this man's influence in causing destruction was far greater than poor Harry's. Maybe he didn't do it intentionally, but the result doesn't change!”
es: —It has been a murder, Alan. I have killed him. You don't know how much he made me suffer. Think what you will of my life, he has contributed more to ruining it than poor Harry. Perhaps it wasn't his intention, but the result has been the same.

en: “Murder! Good God, Dorian, is that what you have come to? I shall not inform upon you. It is not my business. Besides, without my stirring in the matter, you are certain to be arrested. Nobody ever commits a crime without doing something stupid. But I will have nothing to do with it.”
vi: “Murder! Good Lord, Dorian, have you gone this far? I will not turn you in. That is not my business. Besides, even if I do nothing in this matter, you will surely be caught. No one has ever committed a crime without doing something foolish afterward. But I will not get involved in it.”
tr: “Murder, oh my God! Did you finally come to this, Dorian? I won't turn you in. It doesn't concern me. Even if I don't investigate, you'll get caught sooner or later. Criminals always make a mistake. But I won't get involved in this.”
es: —Murder! Good heavens, Dorian! Is that what you've come to at last? I won't turn you in. It's none of my business. Besides, without me lifting a finger, they'll end up catching you. No one ever commits a crime without doing something stupid. But I refuse to get involved.

en: “You must have something to do with it. Wait, wait a moment; listen to me. Only listen, Alan. All I ask of you is to perform a certain scientific experiment. You go to hospitals and dead-houses, and the horrors that you do there don’t affect you. If in some hideous dissecting-room or fetid laboratory you found this man lying on a leaden table with red gutters scooped out in it for the blood to flow through, you would simply look upon him as an admirable subject. You would not turn a hair. You would not believe that you were doing anything wrong. On the contrary, you would probably feel that you were benefiting the human race, or increasing the sum of knowledge in the world, or gratifying intellectual curiosity, or something of that kind. What I want you to do is merely what you have often done before. Indeed, to destroy a body must be far less horrible than what you are accustomed to work at. And, remember, it is the only piece of evidence against me. If it is discovered, I am lost; and it is sure to be discovered unless you help me.”
vi: “You have to get involved in it to some extent. Wait, wait a moment; listen to me. Just listen, Alan. All I ask of you is to conduct some scientific experiment. You go to the hospital and the morgue, and the gruesome things you do there don't affect you. If in some ghastly operating room or some stinking laboratory, you see this person lying on a lead table with red channels draining blood through it, you would only look at him as an admirable subject. You wouldn't even blink. You wouldn't think you were doing anything wrong. On the contrary, you would probably feel that you are helping humanity, or increasing the total sum of worldly knowledge, or satisfying intellectual curiosity, or something of that sort. What I need you to do is just what you have always done before. In fact, destroying a corpse must be much less horrible than what you are used to doing. And, remember, it is the only evidence against me. If it is discovered, I lose; and it will certainly be discovered unless you help me.”
tr: “Even if you don't want to, you'll get involved, Alan. Wait, hold on a minute, listen to me. Just listen, Alan. All I want from you is to conduct a scientific experiment. You go to hospitals, morgues, and such places, and the disgusting things you do there don't shake you. If you saw this man in a creepy autopsy room, in a laboratory reeking of stench... If you found him on a lead table with grooves for the blood to flow, you would see it as an interesting subject for examination. You wouldn't even flinch. You wouldn't think what you were doing was a bad thing. On the contrary, you would think you were working for the benefit of humanity, contributing to the world's knowledge, satisfying an intellectual curiosity, and such things. What I want from you is something you've done countless times before. In fact, disposing of a corpse should be much less horrifying than the things you usually do! And don't forget that this corpse is the only evidence that can be used against me. If it's found, it will be the day I'm ruined. And if you don't help me, it will definitely be found.”
es: —You will have to do it. Wait, wait a moment; listen to me. You just have to hear me out. All I ask is that you carry out a certain scientific experiment. You go to hospitals and morgues, and the horrors you see there do not affect you. If in a ghastly dissection room or a foul-smelling laboratory you found a human being on a lead table with red incisions made to let the blood out, you would look at it as something admirable. You wouldn't flinch. You wouldn't think you were doing anything reprehensible. On the contrary, you would consider that you were working for the benefit of the human race, or increasing its store of knowledge, or satisfying its intellectual curiosity, or something of the sort. What I want you to do is simply something you have done many times before. To tell the truth, destroying a corpse must be much less horrible than what you are used to doing. And remember that it is the only evidence against me. If it is discovered, I am lost; and it will undoubtedly be known, unless you help me.

en: “I have no desire to help you. You forget that. I am simply indifferent to the whole thing. It has nothing to do with me.”
vi: “I don't want to help you. Did you forget? I'm simply indifferent to this whole thing. It has nothing to do with me.”
tr: “I have absolutely no desire to help you. You forget this. The matter is completely irrelevant to me. It has nothing to do with me.”
es: —I have no desire whatsoever to help you. That is something you forget. The only thing this whole matter inspires in me is indifference. It has nothing to do with me.

en: “Alan, I entreat you. Think of the position I am in. Just before you came I almost fainted with terror. You may know terror yourself some day. No! don’t think of that. Look at the matter purely from the scientific point of view. You don’t inquire where the dead things on which you experiment come from. Don’t inquire now. I have told you too much as it is. But I beg of you to do this. We were friends once, Alan.”
vi: “Alan, I beg you. Think about the situation I am in. Just before you arrived, I almost fainted from fear. Someday, you might know that terror yourself. No! Don’t think that. Look at the issue purely from a scientific perspective. You never asked where the deadly things you experiment on came from. And don’t ask now. I’ve already told you too much. But I ask you to do this. We were friends once, Alan.”
tr: “Alan, I beg you. Think about my position in society. Just before you arrived, I was almost fainting from terror. One day, you might experience such terror yourself. No, don't think about that side of it. Look at the matter purely from a formal perspective. You don't ask where the dead things you experiment on come from. Don't ask questions now either. I've already given you too much information. I beg you to do this job. We were once friends, Alan.”
es: —Alan, I beg you. Think about the situation I am in. A few moments before you arrived, the terror almost made me faint. Perhaps you too will know terror someday. No! Don't think about that. Look at it from a strictly scientific perspective. You don't ask where the corpses you experiment on come from. Nor is it necessary for you to investigate it now. I've already told you too much. But I beg you to do it. We were friends once, Alan.

en: “Don’t speak about those days, Dorian—they are dead.”
vi: “Don't talk about those days anymore, Dorian: they are dead.”
tr: “Don't remember those days, Dorian. They are dead.”
es: —Don't talk about that. Those days are dead.

en: “The dead linger sometimes. The man upstairs will not go away. He is sitting at the table with bowed head and outstretched arms. Alan! Alan! If you don’t come to my assistance, I am ruined. Why, they will hang me, Alan! Don’t you understand? They will hang me for what I have done.”
vi: "Death sometimes delays." "The person upstairs will not go far." "He sits by the table with his head bowed and his arms outstretched." "Alan! Alan!" "If you don't help me, I am doomed." "Why, because they will hang me, Alan! Do you understand?" "They will hang me for what I have done."
tr: “The dead sometimes linger among us, Alan. Look, the man upstairs isn't disappearing. His head is bowed, his arms are outstretched, he's sitting at the table. Alan! Alan, if you don't come to my rescue, I'm doomed. They'll hang me, Alan! Don't you understand? They'll string me up for what I've done.”
es: —Sometimes what is dead endures. The individual in the attic will not disappear. He is sitting at the table with his head down and his arms hanging. Alan, please! If you don't come to my aid, I am lost. They will hang me! Don't you understand? They will hang me for what I have done.

en: “There is no good in prolonging this scene. I absolutely refuse to do anything in the matter. It is insane of you to ask me.”
vi: “There is nothing good about prolonging this scene. I am determined to refuse to do anything in this matter. You are really crazy to ask me.”
tr: “There is no point in prolonging this scene and leaving. I absolutely refuse to get involved in this matter. It's already madness to consult me.”
es: —It is useless to prolong this scene. I categorically refuse to intervene in this matter. You must be crazy to ask me such a thing.

en: “You refuse?”
vi: "You refuse?" "Correct."
tr: “You are refusing, huh?”
es: —Do you refuse?

en: “Yes.”
vi: “I beg you, Alan.”
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “I entreat you, Alan.”
vi: “I beg you, Alan.”
tr: “I beg you, Alan.””
es: —I beg you, Alan.

en: “It is useless.”
vi: "It's useless."
tr: “In vain.”
es: —It's useless.

en: The same look of pity came into Dorian Gray’s eyes. Then he stretched out his hand, took a piece of paper, and wrote something on it. He read it over twice, folded it carefully, and pushed it across the table. Having done this, he got up and went over to the window.
vi: That look of pity reappeared in Dorian Gray's eyes. Then he reached out, took a piece of paper, and wrote something on it. He read it twice, folded it carefully, and pushed it across the table. After finishing this task, he stood up and approached the window.
tr: The same pained look appeared in Dorian Gray's eyes again. Then the young man reached out and took a sheet of paper. He wrote something. He read what he had written twice, carefully folded the paper, and pushed it towards his guest from across the table. Then he stood up and went to the window.
es: The same compassionate expression appeared again in Dorian Gray's eyes. Then he extended his arm, took a piece of paper, and wrote something on it. He reread it twice, folded it carefully, and pushed it to the other side of the table. Afterwards, he got up and approached the window.

en: Campbell looked at him in surprise, and then took up the paper, and opened it. As he read it, his face became ghastly pale and he fell back in his chair. A horrible sense of sickness came over him. He felt as if his heart was beating itself to death in some empty hollow.
vi: Campbell looked at him in surprise, then picked up the piece of paper and opened it. As he read it, his face turned as pale as a corpse, and he fell back into his chair. A terrible feeling of nausea overwhelmed him. He felt as if his heart was beating itself to death in some deep, empty void.
tr: Campbell was staring at him in amazement. He took the paper and opened it. As he read, his face turned as pale as a dead man's and he leaned back. A terrible faintness enveloped him, and his heart was pounding as if it would burst in the void.
es: Campbell looked at him surprised, and then picked up the paper and opened it. As he read it, his face turned an ashen pallor and he had to lean back in his chair. A sensation of infinite nausea overcame him. He felt his heart beating with an empty premonition of death.

en: After two or three minutes of terrible silence, Dorian turned round and came and stood behind him, putting his hand upon his shoulder.
vi: After a few terrifying minutes of silence, Dorian turned around, stood behind him, and placed his hand on his shoulder.
tr: After a few minutes filled with a dreadful silence, Dorian turned, came to stand beside his guest, and placed his hand on his shoulder.
es: After two or three minutes of terrible silence, Dorian, leaving the window, positioned himself behind him and placed a hand on his shoulder.

en: “I am so sorry for you, Alan,” he murmured, “but you leave me no alternative. I have a letter written already. Here it is. You see the address. If you don’t help me, I must send it. If you don’t help me, I will send it. You know what the result will be. But you are going to help me. It is impossible for you to refuse now. I tried to spare you. You will do me the justice to admit that. You were stern, harsh, offensive. You treated me as no man has ever dared to treat me—no living man, at any rate. I bore it all. Now it is for me to dictate terms.”
vi: “I am very sorry for you, Alan,” he murmured, “but you have left me no other choice. I have a letter already written. Here it is. You see the address. If you don't help me, I have to send it. If you don't help me, I will send it. You know what the consequences will be. But you are going to help me. Now you can't refuse me anymore. I tried to spare you. You will have to be fair to me and admit that. You have been strict, harsh, aggressive. You have treated me in a way that no one has ever dared to treat me — no living person, anyway. I have endured it all. Now it's my turn to set the terms.”
tr: “I pity you, but you leave me no other choice, Alan,” she said. “I wrote and prepared the letter. Here, look. You see the address too. If you don't help me, I have no other way but to send this. If you don't help me, I will really send this. You know what the outcome will be. But you will help me. There's no way to say no anymore. I tried to protect you. If you don't admit this, you will be unfair to me. You acted harshly, treated me cruelly, insulted me. No one has ever dared to treat me like this, Alan. I mean no one alive, at least. I endured it all. Now it's my turn to set conditions.”
es: —I'm sorry for you, Alan —he murmured—, but you haven't given me another choice. The letter is written. I have it here. You see who it is addressed to. If you don't help me, I will send it. You know what the consequences will be. But you are going to help me. It is impossible for you to refuse. I have tried to avoid this for you. You must acknowledge it. You have shown yourself to be inflexible, harsh, offensive. You have treated me like no one has ever dared to treat me; no one who is alive, at least. I have endured it all. But now it is I who sets the conditions.

en: Campbell buried his face in his hands, and a shudder passed through him.
vi: Campbell buried his face in his hands, a shiver ran through him.
tr: Campbell buried his face in his hands and shivered from head to toe.
es: Campbell hid his face in his hands, his body shaken by a tremor.

en: “Yes, it is my turn to dictate terms, Alan. You know what they are. The thing is quite simple. Come, don’t work yourself into this fever. The thing has to be done. Face it, and do it.”
vi: "Yes, it's my turn to set the conditions, Alan. You already know what they are. It's very simple. Come on, stop making a fuss. It needs to be done. Face it, deal with it."
tr: “Yes, it's my turn to set the conditions, Alan. You know what they are. The issue is extremely simple. Come on, don't torment yourself unnecessarily. There is a job to be done. Accept it and do it.”
es: —Yes; I am the one who sets the conditions, Alan. You already know what they are. It's about doing something very simple. Come on, don't despair. It's inevitable. Accept it, and do what you have to do.

en: A groan broke from Campbell’s lips and he shivered all over. The ticking of the clock on the mantelpiece seemed to him to be dividing time into separate atoms of agony, each of which was too terrible to be borne. He felt as if an iron ring was being slowly tightened round his forehead, as if the disgrace with which he was threatened had already come upon him. The hand upon his shoulder weighed like a hand of lead. It was intolerable. It seemed to crush him.
vi: A groan escaped Campbell's lips, and he trembled all over. He felt the ticking of the clock on the mantelpiece seemed to divide time into atoms of agony, each one too terrible to endure. He felt as if an iron band was slowly tightening around his forehead, as if the humiliation he was threatened with had already descended upon him.
