The hand on his shoulder was as heavy as a leaden hand. He couldn't bear it. It seemed as if it was about to crush him.
tr: Campbell groaned softly; his whole body was trembling. The ticking of the clock above the fireplace seemed to divide time into atoms of torture, each one more dreadful to endure than the last. An iron band encircled his forehead, tightening slowly; the disgrace he faced seemed as if it had already come to pass. The hand on his shoulder felt as heavy as a hand of lead. It was unbearable. It was crushing him.
es: A moan escaped from Campbell, and he began to tremble from head to toe. It seemed to him that the ticking of the clock on the mantelpiece was dividing time into atoms of pain, each one too terrible to bear. He felt as if an iron ring was slowly tightening around his forehead, as if the dishonor he was being threatened with had already descended upon him. The hand resting on his shoulder felt like it was made of lead.

en: “Come, Alan, you must decide at once.”
vi: "Come on, Alan, you have to decide right now."
tr: “Come on, Alan, you need to make a decision right now.”
es: —Come on, Alan; you have to make up your mind now.

en: “I cannot do it,” he said, mechanically, as though words could alter things.
vi: "I can't do this," he said mechanically, as if words could change everything.
tr: Like a programmed machine, the young man said, "I can't," as if he thought words could change the situation.
es: —I can't do it —he said mechanically, as if the words could alter reality.

en: “You must. You have no choice. Don’t delay.”
vi: “You have to do it. You have no choice. Don't delay.”
tr: “You will do it. You have no other choice. Don't dawdle.”
es: —You have to do it. You have no choice. Don't insist on delaying it.

en: He hesitated a moment. “Is there a fire in the room upstairs?”
vi: He hesitated for a moment. "Is there a fireplace in the room upstairs?"
tr: Campbell paused for a moment. "Is there a fire in the room upstairs?" “Yes.
es: Campbell hesitated for a moment. —Is there a fire in the attic room?

en: “Yes, there is a gas-fire with asbestos.”
vi: “Yes, there is a gas heater with asbestos.”
tr: There is an asbestos stove.”
es: —Yes; a gas fixture with asbestos plates.

en: “I shall have to go home and get some things from the laboratory.”
vi: “I have to go home to get a few things from the laboratory.”
tr: “I need to go home and get some things from the laboratory.”
es: —I will have to go to my house and pick up some things from the laboratory.

en: “No, Alan, you must not leave the house. Write out on a sheet of notepaper what you want and my servant will take a cab and bring the things back to you.”
vi: "No, Alan, you must not leave this house." "Write down on a piece of paper what you need, and my servant will take the car to get those things for you."
tr: “No, Alan, you cannot leave here; write down what you want on a piece of paper. My servant will hop into a carriage, get everything, and bring it to you.”
es: —No, Alan; you cannot leave this house. Write on a piece of paper what you want, and my servant will go by carriage to fetch it.

en: Campbell scrawled a few lines, blotted them, and addressed an envelope to his assistant. Dorian took the note up and read it carefully. Then he rang the bell and gave it to his valet, with orders to return as soon as possible and to bring the things with him.
vi: Campbell scribbled a few lines, blotted them, and then addressed an envelope for his assistant. Dorian picked up the letter and read it very carefully. Then he rang the bell, handed it to the servant, ordered him to return as soon as possible, and to bring the items back with him.
tr: Campbell scribbled a few lines and wrote his assistant's name on the envelope. Dorian took the note and read it carefully. Then he rang the bell; he instructed his servant, to whom he had given the list, to return as soon as possible with the requested items.
es: Campbell scribbled a few lines, dried the ink, and wrote his assistant's name on an envelope. Dorian took the note and read it carefully. Then he rang the bell and handed the letter to his valet, instructing him to return as soon as possible with the requested items.

en: As the hall door shut, Campbell started nervously, and having got up from the chair, went over to the chimney-piece. He was shivering with a kind of ague. For nearly twenty minutes, neither of the men spoke. A fly buzzed noisily about the room, and the ticking of the clock was like the beat of a hammer.
vi: When the outer hall door closed, Campbell started in worry, and, standing up from his chair, went near the fireplace. He shivered as if he had malaria. For nearly twenty minutes, no one said anything. A fly buzzed noisily around the room, the ticking of the clock sounded like hammer blows.
tr: As the door closed, Campbell flinched in fright, then got up and went to the fireplace. He was trembling as if he had malaria. For about twenty minutes, neither of them spoke. There was a fly buzzing around the room. The ticking of the clock was like the strike of a hammer.
es: When the front door closed, Campbell was startled and, getting up from the chair, he approached the fireplace. He was trembling as if struck by a fever. For about twenty minutes, no one spoke. A fly buzzed loudly around the room and the ticking of the clock was like the pounding of a hammer.

en: As the chime struck one, Campbell turned round, and looking at Dorian Gray, saw that his eyes were filled with tears. There was something in the purity and refinement of that sad face that seemed to enrage him. “You are infamous, absolutely infamous!” he muttered.
vi: When the clock struck one, Campbell returned, and, looking at Dorian Gray, saw that his eyes were full of tears. There was something in the purity and elegance of that sorrowful face that seemed to drive him mad. "You are vile, utterly vile!" he muttered.
tr: As one o'clock struck, Campbell turned and looked at Dorian, seeing that his eyes were filled with tears. Something about the purity and gentleness of that face seemed to have infuriated him. “You are a despicable bastard!” he muttered. “You are a disgrace.”
es: When the chimes struck one, Campbell turned around and, upon looking at Dorian Gray, saw that his eyes were filled with tears. There was something in the purity and refinement of that sorrowful face that seemed to enrage him. —You are despicable! An absolutely repugnant being! —she murmured.

en: “Hush, Alan. You have saved my life,” said Dorian.
vi: "Shh, Alan: you saved my life," Dorian said.
tr: “Stop, Alan. You saved my life.”
es: —Hush, Alan: you have saved my life —said Dorian Gray.

en: “Your life? Good heavens! what a life that is! You have gone from corruption to corruption, and now you have culminated in crime. In doing what I am going to do—what you force me to do—it is not of your life that I am thinking.”
vi: “Your life? Oh God! What kind of life is this! You go from one corruption to another, now you have reached the peak with a crime. To do what I am about to do, what you force me to do, I do not think about your life.”
tr: “Your life, huh? Oh my God! But what a life, huh! You went from filth to filth and finally ended up committing murder. If I am doing this thing, that is, the thing I am forced to do because of you, it is not because I am thinking of you.”
es: —My life? Good heavens! What kind of life is that? You have gone from corruption to corruption and now you have crowned your exploits with a murder. In doing what I am about to do, what you force me to do, it is not your life that I am thinking of.

en: “Ah, Alan,” murmured Dorian with a sigh, “I wish you had a thousandth part of the pity for me that I have for you.” He turned away as he spoke and stood looking out at the garden. Campbell made no answer.
vi: "Oh, Alan," Dorian murmured with a sigh, "I wish you would show me even one-thousandth of the compassion I have for you." He turned away as he spoke, looking out into the garden. Campbell did not reply.
tr: Dorian sighed, "Ah, Alan." "I wish you could pity me even a thousandth as much as I pity you!" He turned and fixed his gaze on the garden. Campbell did not respond.
es: —Stay, Alan —murmured Dorian Gray with a sigh—, I wish you could feel for me a thousandth part of the compassion you inspire in me —he turned as he spoke and stood looking at the garden. Campbell did not respond.

en: After about ten minutes a knock came to the door, and the servant entered, carrying a large mahogany chest of chemicals, with a long coil of steel and platinum wire and two rather curiously shaped iron clamps.
vi: A few minutes later, a knock on the door echoed, and a servant entered, carrying a large mahogany chest containing chemicals, a long coil of steel and platinum wire with two rather oddly shaped iron clamps.
tr: Ten minutes later, there was a knock on the door, and the servant entered. In his hand, he had a large mahogany medicine chest, a coil of steel cable, a coil of platinum wire, and two rather oddly shaped iron vices.
es: After about ten minutes, there was a knock at the door, and the servant entered with a large mahogany box full of chemical products, along with a roll of steel and platinum wire, as well as two rather strangely shaped iron tongs.

en: “Shall I leave the things here, sir?” he asked Campbell.
vi: "May I leave my things here, sir?" he asked Campbell.
tr: "Shall I leave these here, sir?" the servant asked Campbell.
es: —Should I leave these things here? —he asked Campbell.

en: “Yes,” said Dorian. “And I am afraid, Francis, that I have another errand for you. What is the name of the man at Richmond who supplies Selby with orchids?”
vi: “Alright,” Dorian said. “And I’m afraid, Francis, I have another errand for you. What’s the name of that person in Richmond who still supplies orchids to Selby?”
tr: Dorian replied, "Yes." "Ah, Francis, I'm afraid I have one more task. What was the name of the man in Richmond who sent orchids to Selby?"
es: —Yes —replied Dorian—. And I'm very much afraid, Francis, that I have another task for you. What is the name of that person from Richmond who brings orchids to Selby?

en: “Harden, sir.”
vi: “Harden, sir.”
tr: "Certainly, sir."
es: -Harden, sir.

en: “Yes—Harden. You must go down to Richmond at once, see Harden personally, and tell him to send twice as many orchids as I ordered, and to have as few white ones as possible. In fact, I don’t want any white ones. It is a lovely day, Francis, and Richmond is a very pretty place—otherwise I wouldn’t bother you about it.”
vi: “That's right — Harden. You need to go down to Richmond immediately, meet Harden in person, and tell him to send double the number of orchids I ordered, with as few white ones as possible. In fact, I don't want any white ones at all. It's a beautiful day today, Francis, and Richmond is a very lovely place, otherwise, I wouldn't trouble you with this.”
tr: “Indeed. Harden. Now you will immediately go to Richmond and see this Harden for yourself. Have him send twice the amount of orchids I ordered there; and as few white ones as possible. In fact, I don't want any white ones at all. The weather is very nice, Francis. Richmond is a very charming neighborhood, otherwise I wouldn't trouble you with this task.”
es: —That's right, Harden. You need to go to Richmond immediately, see Harden in person and tell him to send double the orchids that were ordered, and to include as few white ones as possible. In fact, tell him I don't want any white ones. It's a very nice day, Francis, and Richmond is a very beautiful place, otherwise I wouldn't tell you to go.

en: “No trouble, sir. At what time shall I be back?”
vi: "It's alright, sir. When do I have to return?"
tr: "It's no trouble at all, sir. When should I return?"
es: —It is no trouble at all, sir. What time should I be back?

en: Dorian looked at Campbell. “How long will your experiment take, Alan?” he said in a calm indifferent voice. The presence of a third person in the room seemed to give him extraordinary courage.
vi: Dorian looked at Campbell. "How long will your experiment take, Alan?" he said, in a calm, indifferent voice. The presence of a third person in the room seemed to give him unusual courage.
tr: Dorian turned and looked at Campbell. In a calm, indifferent voice, he asked, "Alan, how long will your experiment take?" The presence of a third person in the room seemed to give him extraordinary courage.
es: Dorian looked at Campbell. —How long will your experiment last, Alan? —she asked in a calm, indifferent voice. The presence of a third person in the room seemed to give it extraordinary value.

en: Campbell frowned and bit his lip. “It will take about five hours,” he answered.
vi: Campbell frowned, biting his lip. “It will take about five hours,” he replied.
tr: Campbell frowned and bit his lip. "About five hours."
es: Campbell frowned and bit his lips. —About five hours —he replied.

en: “It will be time enough, then, if you are back at half-past seven, Francis. Or stay: just leave my things out for dressing. You can have the evening to yourself. I am not dining at home, so I shall not want you.”
vi: “So if you come back at seven-thirty, that will be enough time, Francis. Or just stay there: just have my clothes prepared and laid out. You have a free afternoon for yourself. I'm not having dinner at home, so I won't need you.”
tr: "Then it would be fine if you could return around half-past seven, Francis. But wait: You can take out the clothes I'll be wearing; you can have the evening off. Since I won't be eating at home, I won't need you."
es: —It will be enough, then, if you are back by seven-thirty. Better yet, stay there: get things ready so I can get dressed. Take the afternoon off. I won't be dining at home, so I won't need you.

en: “Thank you, sir,” said the man, leaving the room.
vi: “Thank you, sir,” the servant said, leaving the room.
tr: Adam said, "Thank you, sir," and went outside.
es: —Thank you very much, sir —said the valet, leaving the room.

en: “Now, Alan, there is not a moment to be lost. How heavy this chest is! I’ll take it for you. You bring the other things.” He spoke rapidly and in an authoritative manner. Campbell felt dominated by him. They left the room together.
vi: “Now then, Alan, we shouldn't waste a moment. Why is this chest so heavy! I'll carry it for you. You carry those other things.” He said quickly, in a commanding tone. Campbell felt dominated by him. They left the room together.
tr: “Come on, Alan, we don't have a single minute to waste. This chest is really heavy! I'll carry it for you. You bring the other things.” Dorian was speaking quickly and authoritatively. It was as if Campbell had come under his command. They left the room together.
es: —Well, Alan, there's no time to lose. This box is so heavy! I'll carry it for you. You take care of the rest —he spoke quickly and with an authoritative tone. Campbell felt dominated by him. Together they left the room.

en: When they reached the top landing, Dorian took out the key and turned it in the lock. Then he stopped, and a troubled look came into his eyes. He shuddered. “I don’t think I can go in, Alan,” he murmured.
vi: When they reached the top of the stairs, Dorian took out a key and turned it in the lock. Then he stopped, a look of worry appearing in his eyes. He shuddered. "I don't think I can go in, Alan," he muttered.
tr: When they reached the landing of the upper floor, Dorian took out the key and inserted it into the lock. Then he stopped, a worried look appeared in his eyes. "Alan, I don't think I can go inside."
es: When they reached the attic landing, Dorian took out the key and turned it in the lock. Then he paused, a look of uncertainty in his eyes. He shuddered. —I don't think I can go in —he murmured.

en: “It is nothing to me. I don’t require you,” said Campbell coldly.
vi: "A trivial matter to me. I don't need you," Campbell said coldly.
tr: "Alan, I don't think I can go inside." Campbell said coolly, "I think the weather is nice." "I don't need you."
es: —It doesn't matter. I don't need you for anything —replied Campbell coldly.

en: Dorian half opened the door. As he did so, he saw the face of his portrait leering in the sunlight. On the floor in front of it the torn curtain was lying. He remembered that the night before he had forgotten, for the first time in his life, to hide the fatal canvas, and was about to rush forward, when he drew back with a shudder.
vi: Dorian slightly opened the door. As he did so, he saw the face of his portrait sneering at him in the sunlight. On the floor, opposite it, the torn curtain was lying. He remembered that, the night before, for the first time in his life, he had forgotten to cover the cursed canvas, and had almost rushed forward, when he was pulled back by a shudder.
tr: Dorian slightly opened the door. At that moment, he saw the sneering face of his portrait in the daylight. At the bottom, the torn curtain lay on the floor. Dorian remembered for the first time that he hadn't covered the ominous painting last night. Just as he was about to move forward, he recoiled with a shudder.
es: Dorian Gray half-opened the door. As he did so, he saw the face of the portrait, mocking, illuminated by the sunlight. On the floor in front of it lay the torn curtain. He remembered that the night before he had forgotten, for the first time in his life, to hide the cursed canvas, and he was about to pounce when he recoiled, trembling.

en: What was that loathsome red dew that gleamed, wet and glistening, on one of the hands, as though the canvas had sweated blood? How horrible it was!—more horrible, it seemed to him for the moment, than the silent thing that he knew was stretched across the table, the thing whose grotesque misshapen shadow on the spotted carpet showed him that it had not stirred, but was still there, as he had left it.
vi: Where did that disgusting red drop of dew come from, glistening wet, shining on that hand, like a canvas sweating blood? How horrifying it was! — more horrifying, as you felt at that moment, compared to the silence that you knew was stretching across the table, the thing whose misshapen shadow on the stained carpet showed you that it wasn't moving, but still there, just as you left it.
tr: What was that disgusting red stain shining on one of the hands, as if blood had seeped from the canvas? How horrible it was! For a moment, it seemed to Dorian even more horrible than that silent thing slumped over the table. Like the crooked, terrifying shadow cast on the stained carpet, it showed that the thing had not moved and was still there, where he had left it.
es: What was that repugnant red dew that shone, gleaming and wet, on one of his hands, as if the canvas had sweated blood? What a horrifying thing! For a moment it seemed even more horrifying than the silent presence collapsed on the table, the presence whose grotesque shadow on the blood-stained carpet indicated that it remained unmoved, still there, in the same place where he had left it.

en: He heaved a deep breath, opened the door a little wider, and with half-closed eyes and averted head, walked quickly in, determined that he would not look even once upon the dead man. Then, stooping down and taking up the gold-and-purple hanging, he flung it right over the picture.
vi: He let out a deep breath, opened the door a bit wider, and with half-closed eyes and a turned-away head, quickly stepped in, determined not to look even once at the dead person. Then, bending down, he picked up the golden and purple curtain and threw it straight over the painting.
tr: Dorian took a deep breath, opened the door a bit more, then turned his head and darted inside, half-closing his eyes. He was determined not to look at the dead body even once. He bent down, lifted the embroidered purple cloth, and threw it over the painting.
es: He took a deep breath, opened the door a bit wider, and, with his eyes half-closed and his head turned away, quickly entered, determined not to look at the dead man even once. Then, bending down, he picked up the purple and gold cloth and threw it directly over the painting.

en: There he stopped, feeling afraid to turn round, and his eyes fixed themselves on the intricacies of the pattern before him. He heard Campbell bringing in the heavy chest, and the irons, and the other things that he had required for his dreadful work. He began to wonder if he and Basil Hallward had ever met, and, if so, what they had thought of each other.
vi: He stopped there, feeling afraid to turn around, and his eyes were fixed on the intricate patterns in front of him. He heard Campbell bringing in the heavy chest, the iron items, and other things he required for his gruesome work. He began to wonder if he and Basil Hallward had ever met, and, if so, what they thought of each other?
tr: He hesitated there, afraid to look around; his eyes were fixed on the complicated things in front of him. He watched as Campbell brought in the heavy chest, clamps, and other tools he would use for the dreadful task. At that moment, he could hardly believe that they had even met Basil Hallward. If they had met, how had they found each other?
es: Then he froze, fearing to turn around, and his eyes focused on the complexities of the decorative motif in front of him. He heard Campbell enter the room with the heavy mahogany box, as well as the irons and other things he had requested for his dreadful work. He began to wonder if Basil Hallward and Alan had ever met and, if so, what they would have thought of each other.

en: “Leave me now,” said a stern voice behind him.
vi: "Now just leave me alone," a stern voice spoke up behind him.
tr: A harsh voice rising from behind said, "Leave me alone now."
es: —Now leave me —said a stern voice behind him.

en: He turned and hurried out, just conscious that the dead man had been thrust back into the chair and that Campbell was gazing into a glistening yellow face. As he was going downstairs, he heard the key being turned in the lock.
vi: He turned around and hurried out, only realizing that the dead person had been pushed back into the chair, while Campbell was staring at the shiny yellow face. As he descended the stairs, he heard the sound of a key turning in the lock.
tr: Dorian turned and quickly went outside. He caught a glimpse of the dead body being pushed backward, and Campbell staring at that moist, glistening, pale yellow face. As he descended the stairs, he heard the key turning in the lock.
es: Dorian Gray turned around and left hastily, not without noticing that the dead man had leaned back against the chair again and that Campbell was gazing at a yellowish face that was shining. As he descended the stairs, he heard the key turn in the lock from the inside.

en: It was long after seven when Campbell came back into the library. He was pale, but absolutely calm. “I have done what you asked me to do,” he muttered. “And now, good-bye. Let us never see each other again.”
vi: When Campbell returned to the library, it was well past seven o'clock. He was pale, but completely calm. “I have done what you asked me to do,” he muttered. “And now, goodbye. We will never see each other again.”
tr: When Campbell returned to the library, it was already past seven o'clock. The young man was pale but extremely calm. "I did what you asked of me," he said. "Now it's goodbye. Let's never see each other again."
es: It had been a while since seven o'clock had struck when Campbell appeared again in the library. He was pale, but very calm. —I have done what you asked me to do —he murmured—. And now, goodbye. I hope we never see each other again.

en: “You have saved me from ruin, Alan. I cannot forget that,” said Dorian simply.
vi: "You saved me, otherwise I would have been done for, Alan. I can't forget that," Dorian said simply.
tr: Dorian briefly said, "You saved me from ruin, Alan. I cannot forget this," he said.
es: —You have saved me from disaster, Alan. That I cannot forget—said Dorian Gray simply.

en: As soon as Campbell had left, he went upstairs. There was a horrible smell of nitric acid in the room. But the thing that had been sitting at the table was gone.
vi: As soon as Campbell got back, he went straight upstairs. There was a terrible smell of nitric acid in the room. But the thing that had been sitting at the table was gone.
tr: As soon as Campbell left, Dorian went upstairs. There was a disgusting smell of acid in the room. But the thing that had been sitting at the desk earlier was nowhere to be seen.
es: As soon as Campbell left the house, he went up to the attic. In the room, there was a horrible smell of nitric acid. But the thing sitting at the table had disappeared.

en: CHAPTER XV.
vi: Chapter 15
tr: Fifteenth chapter
es: Chapter 15

en: That evening, at eight-thirty, exquisitely dressed and wearing a large button-hole of Parma violets, Dorian Gray was ushered into Lady Narborough’s drawing-room by bowing servants. His forehead was throbbing with maddened nerves, and he felt wildly excited, but his manner as he bent over his hostess’s hand was as easy and graceful as ever. Perhaps one never seems so much at one’s ease as when one has to play a part. Certainly no one looking at Dorian Gray that night could have believed that he had passed through a tragedy as horrible as any tragedy of our age. Those finely shaped fingers could never have clutched a knife for sin, nor those smiling lips have cried out on God and goodness. He himself could not help wondering at the calm of his demeanour, and for a moment felt keenly the terrible pleasure of a double life.
vi: That evening, at half-past eight, dressed elegantly and with a large bunch of Parma larkspur pinned to his lapel, Dorian Gray was ushered into Mrs. Narborough's drawing-room by the bowing servants. His forehead was throbbing with furious nerves, and he felt intensely agitated, but his demeanor as he bowed over the hostess's hand remained as composed and graceful as ever. Perhaps one never seems so at ease as when one is playing a part. Surely no one who saw Dorian Gray that night could have believed that he had just gone through a tragedy as terrible as any of our age. Those beautifully shaped fingers could never have clutched a knife to commit a crime, and those smiling lips could never have uttered blasphemies against God and goodness. Even he could not help but be amazed at his own calm demeanor, and for a moment, he felt the terrible deep joy of living a double life.
tr: That evening at half-past eight, dressed extremely elegantly with a large bouquet of Parma violets on his lapel, Dorian Gray was taken to Lady Narborough's drawing room by the servants who bowed respectfully before him. The veins in his temples throbbed with tension, and he was filled with a fervent excitement. But as he bowed to kiss the hostess's hand, his demeanor was as relaxed and courteous as ever. Perhaps when one has to play a role, they appear even more at ease than they are. Indeed, none of those who looked at Dorian Gray that night would have believed that he had experienced a tragedy so dreadful it could rival any tragedy of our age. Those well-shaped fingers could not have held a knife with the intent to sin, those smiling lips could not have cursed God and goodness. Even he was surprised by the calmness of his behavior. For a moment, he savored the intense pleasure of leading a double life with all its sharpness.
es: At half past eight, some servants who were lavish with their bows showed Dorian Gray into Lady Narborough's drawing room, dressed to the nines and with a bouquet of Parma violets in the buttonhole of his jacket. His temples throbbed violently, and he felt seized by an extraordinary nervous agitation, but his manners, when he bowed over his hostess's hand, had the same elegance and naturalness as always. Perhaps one is never so natural as when playing a role. Certainly, no one observing Dorian Gray that night could have believed that he had just lived through a tragedy comparable to the most horrible of our time. It was impossible that those delicately chiseled fingers could have wielded a knife with sinful intent or that those smiling lips could have blasphemed and mocked goodness. He himself could not help but be amazed at his own calmness and, for a few moments, intensely felt the terrible joy of someone successfully leading a double life.

en: It was a small party, got up rather in a hurry by Lady Narborough, who was a very clever woman with what Lord Henry used to describe as the remains of really remarkable ugliness. She had proved an excellent wife to one of our most tedious ambassadors, and having buried her husband properly in a marble mausoleum, which she had herself designed, and married off her daughters to some rich, rather elderly men, she devoted herself now to the pleasures of French fiction, French cookery, and French esprit when she could get it.
vi: It was a small party, hastily prepared by Mrs. Narborough, a very intelligent woman, with what Lord Henry often described as the remnants of truly extraordinary ugliness. She had proven to be a wonderful lady of one of our most insipid ambassadors, and after carefully burying her husband in a marble tomb, which she designed herself, and marrying off her daughters to several wealthy, rather old men, she now devoted herself to the pleasures of French novels, French culinary arts, and French wit whenever she could grasp it.
tr: It was a small gathering that Lady Narborough had hastily organized. According to Lord Henry's description, the Lady, who still bore traces of an extraordinary ugliness, was a very intelligent woman. She had married one of the most tedious ambassadors of our country and had become a perfect wife. After burying her husband in a marble tomb, which she had designed herself, and marrying off her daughters to somewhat older but wealthy men, she now devoted herself to the pleasures of French novels, French cuisine, and –when she could find it– French wit.
es: It was a dinner with few guests, hastily gathered by Lady Narborough, a very intelligent woman, who possessed what Lord Henry used to describe as the remnants of a truly remarkable ugliness, who had turned out to be an excellent wife for one of the most tedious ambassadors of the British crown, and who, after burying her husband with all honors in a marble mausoleum designed by herself, and marrying off her daughters to rich and rather elderly men, had dedicated herself to the pleasures of French narrative, French cuisine, and even French esprit when it was within her reach.

en: Dorian was one of her especial favourites, and she always told him that she was extremely glad she had not met him in early life. “I know, my dear, I should have fallen madly in love with you,” she used to say, “and thrown my bonnet right over the mills for your sake. It is most fortunate that you were not thought of at the time. As it was, our bonnets were so unbecoming, and the mills were so occupied in trying to raise the wind, that I never had even a flirtation with anybody. However, that was all Narborough’s fault. He was dreadfully short-sighted, and there is no pleasure in taking in a husband who never sees anything.”
vi: Dorian was one of the people she was particularly fond of, and she always told him that she was extremely happy not to have known him when she was young. “I know, dear, that I might have gone madly in love with you,” she often said, “and thrown my cap over the windmill for you. Luckily, you weren't even thought of back then. Besides, our clothes were too ugly, and the windmill too calm, so I never even had a single flirtation with anyone. However, that was entirely Narborough's fault. He was terribly nearsighted, and there was no fun in deceiving a husband who never saw anything.”
tr: Dorian was one of her favorites. Lady Narborough always used to tell the young man that she was grateful she hadn't met him in her youth. “I know, my dear, I would have fallen madly in love with you,” she would say. “I would have sacrificed everything for you. Fortunately, you weren't even a thought in your parents' minds back then. Actually, I never even tried to flirt with anyone. But that was Narborough's fault. He was so nearsighted! What's the fun in cheating on a husband who can't even see the tip of his own nose?”
es: Dorian was one of her favorite guests, and she always told him that she was very glad not to have known him when she was young. “I know, my dear, that I would have fallen madly in love with you,” she used to say, “and that I would have thrown caution to the wind for your sake. It's a good thing no one thought of you back then. However, it may be that the idea of throwing caution to the wind didn't appeal to me much, because I never ended up flirting with anyone. Although I think the blame was more Narborough's. He was terribly nearsighted, and there's very little pleasure in deceiving a husband who can't see a thing.”

en: Her guests this evening were rather tedious. The fact was, as she explained to Dorian, behind a very shabby fan, one of her married daughters had come up quite suddenly to stay with her, and, to make matters worse, had actually brought her husband with her. “I think it is most unkind of her, my dear,” she whispered. “Of course I go and stay with them every summer after I come from Homburg, but then an old woman like me must have fresh air sometimes, and besides, I really wake them up. You don’t know what an existence they lead down there. It is pure unadulterated country life. They get up early, because they have so much to do, and go to bed early, because they have so little to think about. There has not been a scandal in the neighbourhood since the time of Queen Elizabeth, and consequently they all fall asleep after dinner. You shan’t sit next either of them. You shall sit by me and amuse me.”
vi: The guests that afternoon were quite boring. The thing is, as she explained to Dorian behind a very worn fan, one of her married daughters had suddenly moved in with her, and, to make matters worse, had brought her husband along. "I think she's very mean, dear," she whispered. "Of course, I stay with them every summer after I return from Homburg, but after all, an old lady like me sometimes needs fresh air, and besides, I really stir them up. You have no idea what kind of life they lead down there. A simple, rustic country life. They wake up early because there's so much to do, and go to bed early because there's so little to think about. There hasn't been a scandal in the village since the time of Queen Elizabeth, so they all fall asleep after dinner. You won't have to sit next to both of them. You will sit next to me and make me happy."
tr: The guests that night were quite annoying. Lady Narborough shielded her face with an old fan and told Dorian: One of her married daughters had suddenly come to stay the night, and as if that wasn't enough, she had brought her husband along. Lady Narborough whispered, “My daughter was very rude, my dear.” “Although I go and stay with them every summer on my way back from Hamburg, an old woman like me needs to get some fresh air from time to time. And besides, believe me, I bring a bit of life to them. If you knew what kind of life they lead there, you'd be astonished. Simple, village life. They wake up early in the morning because they have a lot to do; they go to bed early in the evening because they have nothing to think about. There hasn't been a scandal in that area since the time of Queen Elizabeth, so they fall asleep where they sit after dinner. I won't sit you next to them. You will sit next to me and entertain me.”
es: His guests that night were rather boring people. The truth, the hostess explained to Dorian Gray from behind a rather shabby fan, was that one of her married daughters had suddenly shown up to spend some time with her and, to make matters worse, she had done so accompanied by her husband. —I believe it was cruel of you, my dear —she whispered—. It is true that I visit them every summer upon returning from Homburg, but an old woman like me needs fresh air sometimes and, besides, I manage to wake them up. You cannot imagine the existence they lead. Pure rural life. They get up early because they have a lot to do, and they also go to bed early because they have hardly anything to think about. There hasn't been a scandal around here since the days of Queen Elizabeth, and consequently, everyone falls asleep after dinner. Please do not sit next to either of them. Sit next to me.

en: Dorian murmured a graceful compliment and looked round the room. Yes: it was certainly a tedious party. Two of the people he had never seen before, and the others consisted of Ernest Harrowden, one of those middle-aged mediocrities so common in London clubs who have no enemies, but are thoroughly disliked by their friends; Lady Ruxton, an overdressed woman of forty-seven, with a hooked nose, who was always trying to get herself compromised, but was so peculiarly plain that to her great disappointment no one would ever believe anything against her; Mrs. Erlynne, a pushing nobody, with a delightful lisp and Venetian-red hair; Lady Alice Chapman, his hostess’s daughter, a dowdy dull girl, with one of those characteristic British faces that, once seen, are never remembered; and her husband, a red-cheeked, white-whiskered creature who, like so many of his class, was under the impression that inordinate joviality can atone for an entire lack of ideas.
vi: Dorian softly uttered a graceful compliment and looked around the room. Indeed: it was a dull party. Among them were two people he had never seen before, and the others included Ernest Harrowden, one of those very common middle-aged civilians at London clubs, a man with no enemies but deeply hated by his friends; Mrs. Ruxton, an overly dressed woman of forty-seven, with a hooked nose, always deliberately putting herself in harm's way, but so particularly naive that no one ever believed anything against her to the point of frustration; Mrs. Erlynne, an audacious nobody with an interesting lisp and Venetian red hair; Miss Alice Chapman, the hostess's daughter, a dull-witted girl dressed out of fashion, with one of those distinctly English faces that once seen is never remembered; and her husband, a rosy-cheeked, white-whiskered creature who, like many of his class, believed that excessive cheerfulness could make up for the complete absence of thought.
tr: Dorian mumbled a polite compliment as he looked around. Yes, it was indeed a boring gathering. Dorian had never seen two of the people there. The others were: Ernest Harrowden, one of those middle-aged, stereotypical types often seen in London clubs, who, despite having no enemies, managed to earn the hatred of his friends. Lady Ruxton, a forty-seven-year-old, hook-nosed, overdressed woman who constantly tried to ruin her own reputation but was so utterly meaningless that she couldn't convince anyone of it, and was quite upset about that. Ms. Erlynne, with her Venetian red hair and sweet lisp, an ambitious, intrusive nobody. Lady Alice Chapman, the host's daughter. A drab, dowdy girl with a typical English face that one could never remember after seeing it once. And her husband, a red-cheeked, white-bearded creature who, like many of his class, believed he could compensate for his lack of intelligence with excessive cheerfulness.
es: Dorian murmured the appropriate compliment and scanned the room with his eyes. Yes; there wasn't much to be expected from those guests. Two of the guests he had never seen before, and the rest were: Ernest Harrowden, one of those middle-aged mediocrities that are so abundant in London clubs and who have no enemies but are cordially despised by their friends; Lady Ruxton, a forty-seven-year-old woman with a hooked nose, who dressed extravagantly and always tried to place herself in compromising situations, although, much to her disappointment, no one was ever willing to believe anything against her, given her extreme ugliness; Mrs. Erlynne, a social climber who was a nobody, with a delightful lisp and Venetian red hair; Lady Alice Chapman, the hostess's daughter, a boring young woman without the slightest elegance, with one of those characteristic British faces that, once seen, are never remembered; and her husband, a creature with ruddy cheeks and gray sideburns who, like so many of his kind, lived convinced that excessive joviality was sufficient excuse for the absolute lack of ideas.

en: He was rather sorry he had come, till Lady Narborough, looking at the great ormolu gilt clock that sprawled in gaudy curves on the mauve-draped mantelshelf, exclaimed: “How horrid of Henry Wotton to be so late! I sent round to him this morning on chance and he promised faithfully not to disappoint me.”
vi: Dorian felt quite regretful for having come here, until Mrs. Narborough, looking at the large gilded bronze clock that was languidly curving its ornate lines on the pale purple curtain holder above the fireplace, exclaimed loudly: "Why is Henry Wotton so terribly late! This morning I sent a message to his house on a whim, and he promised me he would definitely not disappoint me."
tr: Dorian had just begun to regret coming here when the hostess, looking at the large, gilded brass clock with its ostentatious curves on the lilac-colored cloth of the mantelpiece, said, "It's quite naughty of Henry Wotton to be this late!" "I sent word this morning, and he promised he wouldn't disappoint me."
es: He was already quite regretful for having accepted the invitation when Lady Narborough, looking at the large golden clock that spread its striking curves over the mantelpiece, covered with mauve cloth, exclaimed —How bad it seems to me that Henry Wottom is arriving so late! This morning, on a whim, I sent a messenger to his house, and he promised with great seriousness not to disappoint me.

en: It was some consolation that Harry was to be there, and when the door opened and he heard his slow musical voice lending charm to some insincere apology, he ceased to feel bored.
vi: If Harry were here, it would be somewhat comforting, and when the door opened and he heard the melodious, deliberate voice adding a touch of charm to some insincere apology, he no longer felt sad.
tr: Anyway, knowing that Henry would come was a consolation, at least. When the door opened a little later and he heard that slow, melodious voice of his that added sweetness to a feigned apology, all of Dorian Gray's anxiety vanished.
es: It was a comfort to have Harry's company, and when the door opened and Dorian heard his slow and melodious voice, which lent charm to an insincere apology for his tardiness, his boredom left him.

en: But at dinner he could not eat anything. Plate after plate went away untasted. Lady Narborough kept scolding him for what she called “an insult to poor Adolphe, who invented the menu specially for you,” and now and then Lord Henry looked across at him, wondering at his silence and abstracted manner. From time to time the butler filled his glass with champagne. He drank eagerly, and his thirst seemed to increase.
vi: But he couldn't eat anything at dinner. Dish after dish was taken away untouched. Mrs. Narborough kept scolding him for what she called “an affront to poor Adolphe, who had devised the menu especially for him,” and occasionally Lord Henry glanced at him, surprised by his silence and distracted demeanor. From time to time, the butler refilled his glass with champagne. He drank eagerly, and his thirst seemed to grow more intense.
tr: However, he couldn't eat anything at the meal. The plates placed in front of him were taken away untouched. Lady Narborough kept scolding him, saying, "You're humiliating poor Adolphe, who prepared this menu especially for you," while Lord Henry occasionally looked across, trying to understand his silence and distraction. Whenever the servant filled his glass with champagne, Dorian drank as if he were thirsty, and the more he drank, the thirstier he seemed to become.
es: During dinner, however, he was unable to eat. The servants kept removing one dish after another without him tasting anything. Lady Narborough did not stop scolding him for what she called "an insult to poor Adolphe, who has invented the menu especially for you," and occasionally Lord Henry looked at him from the other side of the table, surprised by his silence and distant demeanor. From time to time the butler would fill his glass with champagne. Dorian Gray drank eagerly, but his thirst kept increasing.

en: “Dorian,” said Lord Henry at last, as the chaud-froid was being handed round, “what is the matter with you to-night? You are quite out of sorts.”
vi: “Dorian,” Lord Henry finally said, as the chaud-froid was being passed around, “what's the matter with you tonight? You seem very upset.” 1 Frozen meat.
tr: In the end, as the chaud-froid9 was being served, Lord Henry said, "Dorian." "What's wrong with you tonight? You seem quite out of sorts."
es: —Dorian —said Lord Henry finally, while serving himself the chaud froid—, what is wrong with you tonight? You seem downcast.

en: “I believe he is in love,” cried Lady Narborough, “and that he is afraid to tell me for fear I should be jealous. He is quite right. I certainly should.”
vi: "I believe he is in love," exclaimed Mrs. Narborough, "and he is afraid to tell me because he worries that I will be jealous. He is absolutely right. I would certainly be jealous."
tr: Lady Narborough interrupted, "But Dorian is in love!" "However, he doesn't dare tell me for fear that I might be jealous. He's quite right to think so. I really would be jealous."
es: —I believe he is in love —exclaimed Lady Narborough—, and he doesn't dare to tell me for fear that I might feel jealous. And he is absolutely right, because I would feel jealous.

en: “Dear Lady Narborough,” murmured Dorian, smiling, “I have not been in love for a whole week—not, in fact, since Madame de Ferrol left town.”
vi: "Dear Mrs. Narborough," Dorian murmured, smiling, "I haven't been in love for a whole week — truly not since Madame de Ferrol left town."
tr: Dorian smiled and murmured, "Dear Lady Narborough," "It has been a week since I have given my heart to anyone. That is, since Madam Ferrol left London."
es: —My dear Lady Narborough —murmured Dorian Gray, smiling—. I haven't fallen in love for a whole week; precisely since Madame de Ferroll left London.

en: “How you men can fall in love with that woman!” exclaimed the old lady. “I really cannot understand it.”
vi: “How can you men love that woman!” the old lady shouted. “I really can't understand.”
tr: The old lady shouted, "You men!" "How can you fall in love with that woman! I just don't understand."
es: —How is it possible that men fall in love with that woman! —exclaimed the elderly lady—. It is something I cannot understand.

en: “It is simply because she remembers you when you were a little girl, Lady Narborough,” said Lord Henry. “She is the one link between us and your short frocks.”
vi: “Simply because she remembers you as a petite young girl, Mrs. Narborough,” Lord Henry said. “She is the only link between us and your short dresses.”
tr: Lord Henry, "He reminds you of your childhood, Lady Narborough," he said. "He is the only link between your short dresses and us."
es: —It is simply because Madame de Ferroll remembers the time when you were just a child, Lady Narborough —said Lord Henry—. She is the only link between us and your short dresses.

en: “She does not remember my short frocks at all, Lord Henry. But I remember her very well at Vienna thirty years ago, and how décolletée she was then.”
vi: “She doesn't remember anything about my short dresses, Lord Henry. But I remember her very well in Vienna thirty years ago, and how décolletée1 she was back then.” 1 Wear an off-shoulder top.
tr: “It doesn't remind me of my short dresses at all, Lord Henry. But I remember her very well from Vienna thirty years ago: how she used to walk around décolletée and all.”
es: —You don't remember my short dresses at all, Lord Henry. But I remember you perfectly in Vienna thirty years ago, as well as the necklines you wore back then.

en: “She is still décolletée,” he answered, taking an olive in his long fingers; “and when she is in a very smart gown she looks like an édition de luxe of a bad French novel. She is really wonderful, and full of surprises. Her capacity for family affection is extraordinary. When her third husband died, her hair turned quite gold from grief.”
vi: “She is still décolletée,” he replied, picking up an olive with his long fingers; “and when she wears a very elegant dress, she looks like a deluxe edition of a terribly bad French novel. She is truly wonderful, and full of surprises. “Her ability to love her family is extraordinary. When her third husband died, her hair turned golden from grief.” 2 Premium prints.
tr: Lord Henry, taking an olive with his long fingers, replied, "She is now going around décolletée." "Even when she dresses very stylishly, she resembles a de luxe edition of a bad French novel. She is truly a marvelous woman, full of surprises. Especially her family affection is something unseen. When her third husband died, the poor woman's hair turned completely yellow from grief."
es: —She still favors low necklines —replied Lord Henry, picking up an olive with his fingers—, and when she wears a very elegant dress, she looks like a deluxe edition of a bad French novel. She is truly wonderful and always full of surprises. Her capacity for family affection is extraordinary. When her third husband died, her hair turned completely golden from grief.

en: “How can you, Harry!” cried Dorian.
vi: “How could you, Harry!” Dorian exclaimed.
tr: Dorian said, "Harry, shame on you!"
es: —Harry, how dare you! —protested Dorian.

en: “It is a most romantic explanation,” laughed the hostess. “But her third husband, Lord Henry! You don’t mean to say Ferrol is the fourth?”
vi: “A very romantic explanation,” the hostess laughed. “But her third husband, Lord Henry! You don't mean to say Ferrol is the fourth, do you?”
tr: The hostess laughed, "A very romantic comparison." "But did you say her third husband, Lord Henry? Do you mean to say Ferrol is her fourth husband?"
es: —It is an extremely romantic explanation —laughed the hostess—. But, her third husband, Lord Henry! Are you not suggesting that Ferroll is the fourth?

en: “Certainly, Lady Narborough.”
vi: “That's right, Mrs. Narborough.”
tr: “Of course, madam.”
es: —Indeed, Lady Narborough.

en: “I don’t believe a word of it.”
vi: "I don't believe it at all."
tr: “I don't believe a single word.”
es: —I don't believe a single word.

en: “Well, ask Mr. Gray. He is one of her most intimate friends.”
vi: “Then ask Mr. Gray. He is one of her closest friends.”
tr: "Then ask Mr. Gray. He is one of that lady's closest friends."
es: —Well, ask Mr. Gray. He is one of his closest friends.

en: “Is it true, Mr. Gray?”
vi: “Is that true, Mr. Gray?”
tr: “Are these true, Mr. Gray?”
es: —Is it true, Mr. Gray?

en: “She assures me so, Lady Narborough,” said Dorian. “I asked her whether, like Marguerite de Navarre, she had their hearts embalmed and hung at her girdle. She told me she didn’t, because none of them had had any hearts at all.”
vi: “She is so determined, Mrs. Narborough,” said Dorian. “I asked her if, like Marguerite de Navarre, she preserved their hearts and hung them at her waist. She told me she didn't, because none of them had any hearts at all.”
tr: Dorian said, "He swears that it is so, sir." "I asked him: Did she, like Marguerite de Navarre, mummify their hearts and hang them on her belt? He said she did not, because they were all heartless."
es: —That is what she assured me, Lady Narborough —replied Dorian—. I asked her if, like Margaret of Navarre, she had embalmed the hearts of the deceased to hang them from her waist. She told me no, because none of them had a heart.

en: “Four husbands! Upon my word that is trop de zêle.”
vi: "Four husbands! I swear on my honor, that's too much zeal."
tr: “Four big ha! Wow, that's exactly trop de zèle –overzealousness– this is!”
es: —Four husbands! By my faith, that is trop de zéle.

en: “Trop d’audace, I tell her,” said Dorian.
vi: “Too much audacity2, I told her that,” Dorian said.
tr: Dorian said, "Too much audacity –recklessness– I would say to him."
es: —Trop d'audace, I told him —commented Dorian Gray.

en: “Oh! she is audacious enough for anything, my dear. And what is Ferrol like? I don’t know him.”
vi: Too excited. Too daring. “Oh! She has the guts to do anything, my friend. And what about Ferrol? I don't know him.”
tr: “Oh, he is certainly daring, my dear. What does this Ferrol look like, then? I don't know him at all.”
es: —It's not audacity that he lacks, my dear. And, what is Ferroll like? I don't know him.

en: “The husbands of very beautiful women belong to the criminal classes,” said Lord Henry, sipping his wine.
vi: "The husbands of beautiful women are all thieves," said Lord Henry as he sipped his drink.
tr: Lord Henry, "Husbands of very beautiful women are considered to be in the class of heavy criminals," he said, taking a sip of his wine.
es: —Husbands of very beautiful women belong to the criminal class —said Lord Henry, savoring the wine.

en: Lady Narborough hit him with her fan. “Lord Henry, I am not at all surprised that the world says that you are extremely wicked.”
vi: Mrs. Narborough tapped him with her fan. "Lord Henry, I am not at all surprised that people say you are extremely wicked."
tr: Lady Narborough struck him with her fan. "Lord Henry, I am not at all surprised that the whole world says you are an extremely bad, mischievous man."
es: Lady Narborough struck him with her fan. —Lord Henry, I am not at all surprised that the world says you are extraordinarily wicked.

en: “But what world says that?” asked Lord Henry, elevating his eyebrows. “It can only be the next world. This world and I are on excellent terms.”
vi: “But who said that?” Lord Henry said, raising an eyebrow. “It could only be someone from the future. I have a very good relationship with people of this time.”
tr: Lord Henry raised his eyebrows, "Well, which world is that?" "It must be the other world. Because there is no gap between this world and me."
es: —But, which world says that? —asked Lord Henry, raising his eyebrows—. It can only be the world to come. This world and I maintain excellent relations.

en: “Everybody I know says you are very wicked,” cried the old lady, shaking her head.
vi: “Everyone I know says you are very depraved,” the old woman exclaimed, shaking her head.
tr: The elderly lady nodded her head and said, "Everyone I know says that you are very mischievous."
es: —All the people I know say that you are the most wicked —exclaimed the elderly lady, shaking her head.

en: Lord Henry looked serious for some moments. “It is perfectly monstrous,” he said, at last, “the way people go about nowadays saying things against one behind one’s back that are absolutely and entirely true.”
vi: Lord Henry looked very serious for a moment. “How dreadful,” he finally said, “the way people nowadays gossip behind one's back about things that are absolutely and entirely true.”
tr: Lord Henry stood serious for a while. Finally, he said, "It's an outright scandal!" "These days, everyone spreads such rumors about a person that they are absolutely, one hundred percent true."
es: Lord Henry adopted a serious air for a moment. "It is perfectly intolerable," he said finally, "the way people go around saying, behind one's back, things that are absolutely and completely true."

en: “Isn’t he incorrigible?” cried Dorian, leaning forward in his chair.
vi: “Is he incorrigible?” Dorian exclaimed, leaning forward in his chair.
tr: Dorian leaned forward and said, "This man won't come around, will he?"
es: "Isn't he incorrigible?" exclaimed Dorian, leaning forward in his seat.

en: “I hope so,” said his hostess, laughing. “But really, if you all worship Madame de Ferrol in this ridiculous way, I shall have to marry again so as to be in the fashion.”
vi: "I hope so," the hostess said with a smile. "But really, if all of you worship Madame de Ferrol in this ridiculous manner, I will have to remarry to keep up with the trend."
tr: The hostess laughed, "I hope so." "But I'm serious, if you all are so enamored with Madam Ferrol, it means I'll have to get married again to be in fashion.""
es: —I hope so —said the hostess, laughing—. But if all of you adore Madame de Ferroll in such a ridiculous manner, I will have to remarry to stay in fashion.

en: “You will never marry again, Lady Narborough,” broke in Lord Henry. “You were far too happy. When a woman marries again, it is because she detested her first husband. When a man marries again, it is because he adored his first wife. Women try their luck; men risk theirs.”
vi: "You will never remarry, Mrs. Narborough," Lord Henry interrupted. "You are too happy. Women remarry because they hate their first husband. Men remarry because they are enamored with their first wife. Women take a chance; men take a risk."
tr: Lord Henry, "You will never marry again, my lady," he said. "You are too happy to think about it. Women remarry because they hate their first husbands. Men remarry because they adore their first wives. Women do it to try their luck, men do it at the risk of losing theirs."
es: —You will never remarry, Lady Narborough —interjected Lord Henry—. You were too happy. When a woman remarries, it is because she detested her first husband. When a man remarries, it is because he adored his first wife. Women try their luck. Men risk theirs.

en: “Narborough wasn’t perfect,” cried the old lady.
vi: “Narborough is not perfect either,” the old lady exclaimed.
tr: The elderly lady said, "My husband Narborough was not perfect!"
es: —Narborough was not perfect —exclaimed the elderly lady.

en: “If he had been, you would not have loved him, my dear lady,” was the rejoinder. “Women love us for our defects. If we have enough of them, they will forgive us everything, even our intellects. You will never ask me to dinner again after saying this, I am afraid, Lady Narborough, but it is quite true.”
vi: “If he were like that, you probably wouldn't have loved him, madam,” was the reply. “Women love us for our weaknesses. If we have enough of those, they will forgive us for everything, even intelligence. You will never invite me to dinner again after this remark, I fear, will you, Mrs. Narborough; but it is entirely accurate.”
tr: “If he were perfect, you wouldn't love him anyway, madam! Women love us for our flaws. If we have enough flaws, they forgive all our shortcomings, even our intelligence. Now that I've said this, I know you will never invite me to dinner again, my lady, but what can I do, this is the truth.”
es: —If he had been, you would not have loved him, my dear lady —was Lord Henry's response—. Women love us for our defects. If we have enough of them, they forgive us everything, including intelligence. I very much fear that after this you will never invite me to dinner again, Lady Narborough, but it is completely true.

en: “Of course it is true, Lord Henry. If we women did not love you for your defects, where would you all be? Not one of you would ever be married. You would be a set of unfortunate bachelors. Not, however, that that would alter you much. Nowadays all the married men live like bachelors, and all the bachelors like married men.”
vi: "Of course it's accurate, Lord Henry. If we women didn't love you for your weaknesses, what would become of all of you? None of you would ever get married. You would all be an unhappy bunch of bachelors. No, after all, that wouldn't change you much. Nowadays, a married man lives like a bachelor, and a bachelor lives like a married man."
tr: “Of course, Lord Henry. If we women didn't love you for your flaws, what would become of you? Not a single one of you would be able to marry. A hapless herd of bachelors! On the other hand, remaining single wouldn't change you much either! Nowadays, all married men live like bachelors, and all bachelors live as if they were married.”
es: —Of course it's true, Lord Henry. If women didn't love men for their flaws, where would all of you be? None would have gotten married. You would be a collection of unhappy bachelors. Although that wouldn't have changed you much either. Nowadays, all married men live like bachelors, and all bachelors like married men.

en: “Fin de siêcle,” murmured Lord Henry.
vi: "End of the century," Lord Henry muttered.
tr: Lord Henry murmured, "Fin de siècle, the end of the century."
es: —End of the century —murmured Lord Henry.

en: “Fin du globe,” answered his hostess.
vi: "End of the world2," the hostess replied. 1 End of the century. 2 Apocalypse.
tr: The landlady replied, "Fin du globe, the end of the world."
es: —End of the world —replied his hostess.

en: “I wish it were fin du globe,” said Dorian with a sigh. “Life is a great disappointment.”
vi: "I hope it is the end of the world," Dorian sighed, saying. "Life is one great disappointment."
tr: Dorian sighed, "I wish it were the end of the world!" "Living is such a great disappointment!"
es: —Yes, I would like it to be the end of the world —said Dorian with a sigh—. Life is a great disappointment.

en: “Ah, my dear,” cried Lady Narborough, putting on her gloves, “don’t tell me that you have exhausted life. When a man says that one knows that life has exhausted him. Lord Henry is very wicked, and I sometimes wish that I had been; but you are made to be good—you look so good. I must find you a nice wife. Lord Henry, don’t you think that Mr. Gray should get married?”
vi: "Oh, dear," Mrs. Narborough exclaimed, putting on her gloves, "don't tell me that you have exhausted Life already. When someone says that, it is immediately clear that Life has exhausted them. Lord Henry is very corrupt, and sometimes I wish I were too; but you were made to be a good person — you look so decent. I must find you a beautiful wife. Lord Henry, do you think Mr. Gray here should get married?”
tr: Putting on her gloves, the hostess said, "Ah, my dear, don't talk as if you've already exhausted life! When someone talks like that, it means life has exhausted them. Look, Lord Henry is a very bad man, very mischievous. Sometimes I envy him for that. But you were created for goodness. You have such an angelic appearance that I feel like finding you a nice spouse. Lord Henry, don't you think Mr. Gray should get married by now?"
es: —Ah, my dear —exclaimed Lady Narborough while putting on her gloves—, don't tell me that you have already exhausted life. When a man says that, it is known that it is life that has exhausted him. Lord Henry is very wicked, and sometimes I wish I had been; but you are made to be good: you seem so good that I must find you a charming wife. Don't you think, Lord Henry, that Mr. Gray should get married?

en: “I am always telling him so, Lady Narborough,” said Lord Henry with a bow.
vi: "I always tell him that, Mrs. Narborough," Lord Henry said, with a bow.
tr: Lord Henry, bowing slightly, said, "I always keep telling him that, Lady Narborough."
es: —It is what I always tell you, Lady Narborough —replied Lord Henry with a nod of his head.

en: “Well, we must look out for a suitable match for him. I shall go through Debrett carefully to-night and draw out a list of all the eligible young ladies.”
vi: "Alright, we have to find a suitable match for you. Tonight, I will thoroughly review Debrett and draft a list of all the eligible young ladies."
tr: "Alright then, let's find a suitable match for him now. I'll thoroughly go through Debrett's this evening and make a list of eligible young ladies for marriage."
es: —Agreed; in that case, we must find him a good match. Tonight, I will carefully examine the Debrett and prepare a list of the most suitable young ladies.

en: “With their ages, Lady Narborough?” asked Dorian.
vi: “With their age too, right Mrs. Narborough?” Dorian asked.
tr: Dorian said, "By stating their ages as well."
es: —Without forgetting the age of the candidates, Lady Narborough? —asked Dorian.

en: “Of course, with their ages, slightly edited. But nothing must be done in a hurry. I want it to be what The Morning Post calls a suitable alliance, and I want you both to be happy.”
vi: “Of course, at their age, there are some minor adjustments. But there's no need to rush. I want it to be what The Morning Post calls a well-matched marriage, and I want you two to be happy.”
tr: “Of course, their ages will also be mentioned, with minor retouches. But this job should not be rushed. I want this to be, as they say in The Morning Post newspaper, an appropriate composition, I want both of you to be very happy.”
es: —Without forgetting the age, of course, although slightly revised. But nothing should be done in a hurry. I want it to be what The Morning Post calls a convenient match, and for both to be happy.

en: “What nonsense people talk about happy marriages!” exclaimed Lord Henry. “A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love her.”
vi: “People have said so many nonsensical things about happy marriages!” Lord Henry exclaimed. “A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love her.”
tr: Lord Henry said, "How people do talk nonsense about happy marriages!" "A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love her."
es: —What absurd things people say about happy marriages! —exclaimed Lord Henry—. A man can be happy with a woman as long as he does not love her.

en: “Ah! what a cynic you are!” cried the old lady, pushing back her chair and nodding to Lady Ruxton. “You must come and dine with me soon again. You are really an admirable tonic, much better than what Sir Andrew prescribes for me. You must tell me what people you would like to meet, though. I want it to be a delightful gathering.”
vi: "Oh! You really are a mocker!" the old lady exclaimed, pushing her chair back and nodding at Mrs. Ruxton. "You must come to dinner with me again soon. You truly are a wonderful tonic, much better than what Sir Andrew prescribed for me. However, you must tell me what kind of people you like to meet. I want it to be an interesting gathering."
tr: The hostess, "Ah, you, the chief of cynics!" she said, pushing her chair back and nodding to Lady Ruxton. "Come again for dinner soon, will you? You are quite an effective tonic, much more effective than Sir Andrew's prescription. Just tell me who you would like to be with. I want it to be a fun gathering."
es: —Ah! What cynicism on your part! —said the elderly lady, pushing the chair back and nodding to Lady Ruxton—. You must come back very soon to have dinner with me. You are truly an admirable tonic, much better than what Sir Andrew prescribes for me. You must tell me which people you would like to meet. I want it to be an absolutely delightful evening.

en: “I like men who have a future and women who have a past,” he answered. “Or do you think that would make it a petticoat party?”
vi: “I like men with a future, and women with a past,” he replied. “Or do you think that will make it too much of a ladies' party?”
tr: Lord Henry replied, "I like men with a future and women with a past." "Or is it impossible to find men who would come to such a gathering?"
es: —I like men with a future and women with a past —replied Lord Henry—. Or do you think the imbalance would be too great?

en: “I fear so,” she said, laughing, as she stood up. “A thousand pardons, my dear Lady Ruxton,” she added, “I didn’t see you hadn’t finished your cigarette.”
vi: “I'm afraid so,” she said with a smile, as she stood up. “A thousand apologies, my dear Mrs. Ruxton,” she added. “I didn't realize you hadn't finished your cigarette.”
tr: The hostess stood up laughing, "I'm afraid it will be so," she said. Then she added, "A thousand apologies, my dear Lady Ruxton." "I hadn't noticed you hadn't finished your cigarette."
es: —I greatly fear —she said laughing, as she stood up—. A thousand pardons, my dear Lady Ruxton —she added instantly—. I see that you have not finished your cigarette.

en: “Never mind, Lady Narborough. I smoke a great deal too much. I am going to limit myself, for the future.”
vi: "Don't worry, Mrs. Narborough. I smoke too much." "I am about to cut down, for the future.""
tr: "No harm, Lady Narborough, I already drink too much. From now on, I will reduce it."
es: —Don't worry, Lady Narborough. I smoke too much. I intend to do it less in the future.

en: “Pray don’t, Lady Ruxton,” said Lord Henry. “Moderation is a fatal thing. Enough is as bad as a meal. More than enough is as good as a feast.”
vi: “Please don't, Mrs. Ruxton,” said Lord Henry. “Abstinence is a very harmful thing. Moderation is like a regular meal. Excess is like a lavish banquet.”
tr: Lord Henry intervened, "My dear, don't do that, Lady Ruxton!" "Moderation is a disaster. A meal that spreads the concept of enough is a feast that spreads the concept of excess."
es: —Don't do it, I beg you, Lady Ruxton —intervened Lord Henry—. Moderation is a very pernicious virtue. Enough is as bad as a meal. Too much, as good as a feast.

en: Lady Ruxton glanced at him curiously. “You must come and explain that to me some afternoon, Lord Henry. It sounds a fascinating theory,” she murmured, as she swept out of the room.
vi: Mrs. Ruxton looked at him curiously. "You must come and explain that to me one afternoon, Lord Henry." "It sounds like a fascinating theory," she said softly as she grandly exited the room.
tr: Lady Ruxton looked at him with curiosity. “One day, come and explain this to me, Lord Henry. It sounds like an interesting theory,” she murmured, fluttering her skirts as she left the room.
es: Lady Ruxton looked at him with curiosity. —You will have to come and explain it to me some afternoon, Lord Henry. It seems like a fascinating theory —he murmured as he left the room.

en: “Now, mind you don’t stay too long over your politics and scandal,” cried Lady Narborough from the door. “If you do, we are sure to squabble upstairs.”
vi: "Now, be sure not to linger too long on politics and scandals," Mrs. Narborough called out from the door. "If you do, we are sure to argue upstairs."
tr: Lady Narborough turned at the threshold and called out, "Don't drag out your politics and gossip too much." "Otherwise, we will start bickering upstairs."
es: —Please, gentlemen, do not spend too much time talking about politics and scandals —exclaimed Lady Narborough from the door—. If you do, we will end up fighting upstairs.

en: The men laughed, and Mr. Chapman got up solemnly from the foot of the table and came up to the top. Dorian Gray changed his seat and went and sat by Lord Henry. Mr. Chapman began to talk in a loud voice about the situation in the House of Commons. He guffawed at his adversaries. The word doctrinaire—word full of terror to the British mind—reappeared from time to time between his explosions. An alliterative prefix served as an ornament of oratory. He hoisted the Union Jack on the pinnacles of thought. The inherited stupidity of the race—sound English common sense he jovially termed it—was shown to be the proper bulwark for society.
vi: Everyone burst into laughter, Mr. Chapman leisurely stood up from the end of the table and walked to the head. Dorian Gray changed his seat, sitting next to Lord Henry again. Mr. Chapman began to speak loudly about the situation in the House of Commons. He laughed heartily at his opponents. The term demagogue — a word that horrifies the English mind — appeared repeatedly amidst the uproarious laughter. An alliterative prefix was used as an ornament for his rhetoric. He hoisted the British flag to the pinnacle of Thought. The inherited dullness of the race — the sound common sense of the English as he cheerfully called it — proved to be a suitable bulwark for Society.
tr: The men laughed. Mr. Chapman, with great solemnity, rose from his place at the lower end of the table and moved to the upper end. Dorian Gray also changed his seat and went to sit next to Lord Henry. Mr. Chapman began to speak loudly about the situation in the House of Commons. He laughed loudly whenever he mentioned his opponents. Among these outbursts, the word "doctrinaire" was occasionally heard. The word that instilled terror in the English mind. Mr. Chapman thought he was embellishing his speech by adding prefixes that repeated the same sound at the beginning of words. He hoisted the English flag to the pinnacle of thought. He tried to prove that the hereditary foolishness of his race – which he called solid English common sense – was the best defense for society.
es: The men laughed, and Mr. Chapman solemnly rose from the end of the table and moved to occupy the head. Dorian Gray also changed his seat and went to place himself next to Lord Henry. Mr. Chapman began to speak, raising his voice significantly, about the situation in the House of Commons, mocking his adversaries. The word doctrinaire (a term that inspires terror in British minds) reappeared from time to time amidst his bursts of laughter. An alliterative prefix served as an ornament to his eloquence, while he raised the flag of the Empire over the pinnacles of Thought. The innate stupidity of the race (he jovially called it good English common sense) was offered to those present as the bulwark that Society needed.

en: A smile curved Lord Henry’s lips, and he turned round and looked at Dorian.
vi: A smile curved Lord Henry's lips, and he turned to look at Dorian.
tr: Lord Henry turned with a smile curling on his lips and looked at Dorian.
es: A smile curved Lord Henry's lips, who, turning, looked at Dorian.

en: “Are you better, my dear fellow?” he asked. “You seemed rather out of sorts at dinner.”
vi: "Are you feeling better, my friend?" he asked. "You seemed quite uncomfortable during dinner."
tr: “Are you feeling better, my dear friend?” he asked. “You seemed quite unhappy at dinner.”
es: —Are you feeling better? —he asked—. You seemed a bit lost during dinner.

en: “I am quite well, Harry. I am tired. That is all.”
vi: “I'm fine, Harry. I'm just a bit tired. That's all.”
tr: “I'm fine, Harry. Just a bit tired, that's all.”
es: —I'm perfectly fine, Harry. A little tired. That's all.

en: “You were charming last night. The little duchess is quite devoted to you. She tells me she is going down to Selby.”
vi: "You were very charming last night. The little duchess was very devoted to you. She told me that she would go down to Selby."
tr: "You were very charming last night. Our little duchess is fond of you. She told me you are going to Selby."
es: —Last night you outdid yourself. The little duchess only sees through your eyes. She told me she will go to Selby.

en: “She has promised to come on the twentieth.”
vi: “She promised to come on the twentieth.”
tr: “I will come when I am twenty, he promised.”
es: —He has promised to be there by the twentieth.

en: “Is Monmouth to be there, too?”
vi: "Is Monmouth going there too?"
tr: “Is Monmouth coming too?”
es: —Will Monmouth go as well?

en: “Oh, yes, Harry.”
vi: “Ah, yes, Harry.”
tr: "Of course, Harry.""
es: —Yes, Harry.

en: “He bores me dreadfully, almost as much as he bores her. She is very clever, too clever for a woman. She lacks the indefinable charm of weakness. It is the feet of clay that make the gold of the image precious. Her feet are very pretty, but they are not feet of clay. White porcelain feet, if you like. They have been through the fire, and what fire does not destroy, it hardens. She has had experiences.”
vi: “He bores me to death, almost as much as he bores her. She is very intelligent, too intelligent for a woman. She lacks the indefinable charm of weakness. It is the feet of clay that make the golden statue precious. Her feet are very beautiful, but they are not feet of clay. Porcelain feet, if you like. They have been through the fire, and what the fire does not destroy, it hardens. She is experienced.”
tr: “That man is driving me crazy, at least as much as he annoys his wife! The Duchess is very intelligent, too intelligent for a woman. She lacks that indescribable charm of being delicate. What makes golden sculptures valuable is the mixture of clay inside them. In the composition of our Duchess, there is no clay. At most, she is white porcelain. She has been tested by fire! Fire hardens what it does not burn to ashes. This is a woman who has seen and experienced much.”
es: —It bores me terribly, almost as much as it bores her. My cousin is very intelligent, too intelligent for a woman. She lacks the indefinable charm of weakness. The feet of clay give all their value to the golden image. She has beautiful feet, but they are not made of clay. White porcelain feet, if you like. They have passed through the fire, and what the fire does not destroy, it hardens. She has had experiences.

en: “How long has she been married?” asked Dorian.
vi: “How long has she been married?” Dorian asked.
tr: Dorian asked, "How long have you been married?"
es: —How long have you been married? —asked Dorian.

en: “An eternity, she tells me. I believe, according to the peerage, it is ten years, but ten years with Monmouth must have been like eternity, with time thrown in. Who else is coming?”
vi: “An endless amount of time, she told me so. I think, according to the noble genealogy book, it is ten years, but ten years with Monmouth must feel like an eternity, with time thrown into it. Did anyone else come?”
tr: “Since time immemorial, according to what he says. According to the almanac of the nobles, it's ten years, I believe. However, ten years spent with Monmouth must have felt longer than eternity. Who else is coming?”
es: —An eternity, she tells me. According to the peerage book, I believe ten years, but ten years with Monmouth can be an eternity and even a bit more. Who are the other guests?

en: “Oh, the Willoughbys, Lord Rugby and his wife, our hostess, Geoffrey Clouston, the usual set. I have asked Lord Grotrian.”
vi: “Oh, the Willoughbys, Lord Rugby with his wife, our hostess, Geoffrey Clouston, a group as always. I have already asked Lord Grotrian.”
tr: “Here are the Willoughbys, Lord Rugby and his wife, our hostess, Geofreyy Clouston, the usual team. I also invited Lord Grotrian.”
es: —The Willoughbys, Lord Rugby and his wife, our hostess, Geoffrey Clouston, the usual ones. I have asked Lord Grotrian to go.

en: “I like him,” said Lord Henry. “A great many people don’t, but I find him charming. He atones for being occasionally somewhat overdressed by being always absolutely over-educated. He is a very modern type.”
vi: "I like him," Lord Henry said. "Many people don't, but I find him charming. He compensates for the occasional overdressing by always being highly educated. He is a very modern type of person."
tr: “I like him,” said Lord Henry. “Many do not, but I find him quite charming. He makes up for the occasional fault of being overdressed by always being overly cultured. A very contemporary type.”
es: —I like him —said Lord Henry—. There are many people who disagree, but I find him charming. He compensates for his occasional excesses in dressing with an always ultra-refined education. He is a very modern person.

en: “I don’t know if he will be able to come, Harry. He may have to go to Monte Carlo with his father.”
vi: “I don't know if he can come, Harry. He might have to go to Monte Carlo with his father.”
tr: "I don't know if he will come or not, Harry. He might have to go to Monte Carlo with his father."
