es: —I don't know if he will be able to join the group, Harry. He might have to go to Monte Carlo with his father.

en: “Ah! what a nuisance people’s people are! Try and make him come. By the way, Dorian, you ran off very early last night. You left before eleven. What did you do afterwards? Did you go straight home?”
vi: “Oh! How troublesome public figures are! Try to invite him over. By the way, Dorian, you left too early last night. You left before eleven o'clock. What did you do after that? Did you go straight home?”
tr: “Ugh, friends' families are such a headache, huh! Come on, Dorian, come by force if you must. Hey, you left very early last night. You got up before eleven. What did you do afterwards? Did you go straight home?”
es: —Ah! How annoying families are! Make sure she goes. By the way, Dorian, you disappeared very early last night. What did you do afterwards? Go straight home?

en: Dorian glanced at him hurriedly and frowned.
vi: Dorian hastily looked at him and frowned.
tr: Dorian gave him a quick glance, then frowned and said, "No, it was almost three o'clock when I got home."
es: Dorian looked at him for a moment and frowned.

en: “No, Harry,” he said at last, “I did not get home till nearly three.”
vi: "No, Harry," he finally said, "I didn't get home until nearly three o'clock."
tr: Dorian gave him a quick glance, then frowned and said, "No, it was almost three o'clock when I got home."
es: "No, Harry," he said finally. "I didn't return home until around three."

en: “Did you go to the club?”
vi: "Are you going to the club?"
tr: “Did you go to the cabin?”
es: —Did you go to the club?

en: “Yes,” he answered. Then he bit his lip. “No, I don’t mean that. I didn’t go to the club. I walked about. I forget what I did.... How inquisitive you are, Harry! You always want to know what one has been doing. I always want to forget what I have been doing. I came in at half-past two, if you wish to know the exact time. I had left my latch-key at home, and my servant had to let me in. If you want any corroborative evidence on the subject, you can ask him.”
vi: "Yes," he replied. Then he bit his lip. "No, I didn't mean to say that. I didn't go to the club. I wandered around. I forgot what I did... Why are you so curious, Harry! You always want to know what people have done. I always want to forget what I've done. I got home at half past two, if you want to know the exact time. I forgot my keys at home, so my servant had to open the door for me. If you need any concrete proof of this, you can ask him."
tr: “Did you go to the cabin?” Dorian replied, "Yes," then bit his lip. "No, I didn't mean it that way, I didn't go to the club. I walked around a bit. I can't remember what I did now. You're so curious, Harry! You always want to know what people are doing. But I always want to forget what I've done. If you want to know the exact time, I came home at two-thirty. I had forgotten my key inside, so I had my man open the door. If you want corroborative evidence on this, you can ask him."
es: —Yes —he replied. Then he bit his lips—. No; that wasn't what I meant to say. I didn't go to the club. I was out walking. I don't remember what I did... How inquisitive you are, Harry! You always want to know what one does. I always want to forget it. I got home at half past two, if you want to know the exact time. I had left my key, and Francis had to open the door for me. If you need confirmation on that point, you can ask him.

en: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. “My dear fellow, as if I cared! Let us go up to the drawing-room. No sherry, thank you, Mr. Chapman. Something has happened to you, Dorian. Tell me what it is. You are not yourself to-night.”
vi: Lord Henry shrugged. "My friend, as if I care! Let's go to the drawing room." I don't drink sherry, thank you, Mr. Chapman. Something has happened to you, Dorian. Tell me what it is. You are not yourself tonight."
tr: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. “Oh my friend, as if I cared! Let's go to the living room. Thank you, Mr. Chapman; I won't have any sherry. Dorian, there's something about you. What happened, tell me. You're not yourself at all tonight.”
es: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. —My dear friend, as if I cared! Let's go up to the living room. No, thank you very much, Mr. Chapman, I don't want sherry. Something has happened to you, Dorian. Tell me what it is. You seem different tonight.

en: “Don’t mind me, Harry. I am irritable, and out of temper. I shall come round and see you to-morrow, or next day. Make my excuses to Lady Narborough. I shan’t go upstairs. I shall go home. I must go home.”
vi: "Don't mind me, Harry. I'm irritable and losing my temper. I'll come see you tomorrow or the day after. Give my apologies to Mrs. Narborough. I can't go upstairs. I'll go home. I must go home."
tr: “Don't mind me, Harry. My nerves are frayed. I'm in a bad mood. I'll come knocking on your door tomorrow or the day after. Dear, please apologize to Lady Narborough on my behalf. I don't want to go upstairs. I'm going home. I must go home.”
es: —Don't take it the wrong way, Harry. I'm nervous and in a bad mood. I'll come see you tomorrow or the day after tomorrow. Give my apologies to Lady Narborough. I'm not going upstairs to join the ladies. I have to go home. I must go home.

en: “All right, Dorian. I dare say I shall see you to-morrow at tea-time. The duchess is coming.”
vi: "Alright, Dorian. I believe I will see you tomorrow at tea time. The Duchess will be coming."
tr: “Alright, Dorian. We'll see each other at tea time tomorrow, I suppose. The Duchess is coming too.”
es: —Very well. I hope to see you tomorrow at tea time. The duchess will come.

en: “I will try to be there, Harry,” he said, leaving the room. As he drove back to his own house, he was conscious that the sense of terror he thought he had strangled had come back to him. Lord Henry’s casual questioning had made him lose his nerve for the moment, and he wanted his nerve still. Things that were dangerous had to be destroyed. He winced. He hated the idea of even touching them.
vi: "I will try to get there, Harry," he said and left the room. As he ran back to his house, he realized that the feeling of fear he thought he had suppressed was returning to him. The unintentional inquiry of Lord Henry had unnerved him for a moment, and he needed to regain his composure. Dangerous things must be destroyed. He cringed. He hated even the thought of touching them.
tr: Dorian said, "I'll try to come," and left the room. As Dorian was driving home, he noticed that the feeling of horror he thought he had overcome was reviving within him. Lord Henry's casual questions had made him shiver and unnerved him. Yet he still needed to remain calm. A couple of things that might arouse suspicion needed to be eliminated. Dorian shuddered and grimaced. The very thought of touching them made him feel sick.
es: —I will try to be there —said Dorian Gray, leaving the room. As he returned home, he realized that the feeling of terror he thought he had suppressed was resurfacing. Lord Henry's trivial questions had unsettled him for a moment, and he had to keep his composure at all costs. Dangerous objects had to be destroyed. His face contorted. He loathed even the idea of touching them.

en: Yet it had to be done. He realized that, and when he had locked the door of his library, he opened the secret press into which he had thrust Basil Hallward’s coat and bag. A huge fire was blazing. He piled another log on it. The smell of the singeing clothes and burning leather was horrible. It took him three-quarters of an hour to consume everything. At the end he felt faint and sick, and having lit some Algerian pastilles in a pierced copper brazier, he bathed his hands and forehead with a cool musk-scented vinegar.
vi: However, that task still had to be completed. He realized this, and after he had locked his library door, he opened the secret closet where he had stuffed Basil Hallward's cloak and bag. A large fireplace was blazing fiercely. He added another log to it. The smell of burning clothes and singed leather was truly awful. It took him about forty-five minutes to burn everything completely. At the end, he felt dizzy and nauseous, and after burning a few sticks of Algerian incense in a perforated bronze censer, he washed his hands and forehead with cool musk-scented vinegar.
tr: But see, this task had to be done. Dorian was aware of this. After locking the door of his library from the inside, he opened the secret compartment where he had stashed Basil Hallward's coat and bag. A roaring fire was burning in the fireplace. Dorian threw another log onto it. The smell of scorched fabric and charred leather was nauseating. It took him three-quarters of an hour to burn everything to ashes. When he was done, he felt nauseous, almost faint. He burned some Algerian incense in a perforated copper brazier; he washed his forehead with a cooling vinegar mixed with musk.
es: But it had to be done. He understood it perfectly and, after locking the library door, he opened the secret closet into which he had thrown Basil's coat and briefcase. A very lively fire was burning in the fireplace. He added another log. The smell of burning clothes and leather was horrible. It took three quarters of an hour for everything to be consumed. When he finished, he felt weak and dizzy, and after burning some Algerian tablets in a copper censer, he moistened his hands and forehead with musk-scented vinegar.

en: Suddenly he started. His eyes grew strangely bright, and he gnawed nervously at his underlip. Between two of the windows stood a large Florentine cabinet, made out of ebony and inlaid with ivory and blue lapis. He watched it as though it were a thing that could fascinate and make afraid, as though it held something that he longed for and yet almost loathed. His breath quickened. A mad craving came over him. He lit a cigarette and then threw it away. His eyelids drooped till the long fringed lashes almost touched his cheek. But he still watched the cabinet. At last he got up from the sofa on which he had been lying, went over to it, and having unlocked it, touched some hidden spring. A triangular drawer passed slowly out. His fingers moved instinctively towards it, dipped in, and closed on something. It was a small Chinese box of black and gold-dust lacquer, elaborately wrought, the sides patterned with curved waves, and the silken cords hung with round crystals and tasselled in plaited metal threads. He opened it. Inside was a green paste, waxy in lustre, the odour curiously heavy and persistent.
vi: Suddenly, he was startled. His eyes lit up in a strange way, and he nervously bit his lower lip. Between the two windows stood a large Florence cabinet, made of ebony, inlaid with ivory and lapis lazuli. He looked at it as if it could hypnotize or cause fear, as if it held something he desired yet almost detested. His breath quickened. A mad desire overwhelmed him. He lit a cigarette and then threw it away. His eyelids drooped until those long fringed lashes almost touched his cheeks. But he still looked at the cabinet. Finally, he got up from the sofa he was lying on, approached it, and, after opening it, touched some hidden spring. A triangular drawer slowly slid out. His fingers instinctively fumbled towards it, reaching inside, close to something. It was a Chinese lacquer box with black and gold dust, intricately crafted, the sides decorated with undulating waves, with silk cords hanging round crystals and tassels braided with metallic threads. He opened it. Inside was a greenish-blue lump, shiny like wax, with a strangely persistent and heavy scent.
tr: Finally, he got up from the couch he had been lying on and went to the cabinet, opened its door, and pressed a hidden spring inside. Slowly, a triangular drawer emerged. Dorian's fingers seemed to move towards the drawer on their own, plunged inside, found something, and grasped it. It was a black lacquered Chinese box sprinkled with gold dust. Its sides were rounded and wave-shaped, with round glass beads threaded onto its silk cords, and its tassels were woven from metallic threads. Dorian opened the box. Inside was a green paste with the pallor of wax, its scent strange, heavy, and lingering.
es: Suddenly, he had a start. His eyes lit up strangely and he began to nibble on his lower lip. Between two of the library windows, there was a large Florentine mahogany cabinet, inlaid with ivory and lapis lazuli. He gazed at it as if it were something terrible and fascinating at the same time, as if it contained something he longed for and yet almost loathed. His breathing quickened. A furious desire took hold of him. He lit a cigarette which he discarded moments later. He let his eyelids drop until his long lashes almost touched his cheek. But he kept looking at the cabinet. Finally, he got up from the sofa where he had been lying, approached it, and, after sliding back the latch, touched a hidden spring. A triangular drawer slowly appeared. His fingers instinctively moved inside and seized something. It was a Chinese box of black lacquer covered in gold dust, delicately crafted; its walls were decorated with sinuous undulations, and round crystals and tassels woven with metallic threads hung from the silk cords. Dorian Gray opened it. Inside, there was a green paste that had the sheen of wax and emitted a peculiar, dense, and persistent odor.

en: He hesitated for some moments, with a strangely immobile smile upon his face. Then shivering, though the atmosphere of the room was terribly hot, he drew himself up and glanced at the clock. It was twenty minutes to twelve. He put the box back, shutting the cabinet doors as he did so, and went into his bedroom.
vi: He hesitated for a moment, with a strange, motionless smile on his face. Then he shivered, even though the air in the room was unbearably hot, he straightened up, glanced at the clock. It was twenty to twelve. He pushed the box back, closed the cabinet door as he did so, and went into the bedroom.
tr: Dorian paused for a moment with a strange, dull smile on his face. Then, despite the room being extremely warm, he shivered, straightened up, and glanced at the wall clock. It was twenty minutes to twelve. Dorian put the box back in its place, closed the closet door, and went to the bedroom.
es: He hesitated for a few moments, with a strange, immobile smile on his face. Then, shivering, although it was very warm in the library, he stood up and looked at the clock. It was twenty minutes to twelve. He returned the Chinese box to the writing desk, closed the door, and went to his bedroom.

en: As midnight was striking bronze blows upon the dusky air, Dorian Gray, dressed commonly, and with a muffler wrapped round his throat, crept quietly out of his house. In Bond Street he found a hansom with a good horse. He hailed it and in a low voice gave the driver an address.
vi: At midnight, as the chimes echoed through the dim sky, Dorian Gray, dressed in common clothes with a scarf wrapped around his neck, quietly slipped out of the house. On Bond Street, he saw a two-wheeled carriage with a fine horse. He hailed it and softly gave the address to the coachman.
tr: As the midnight darkness struck with bronze fists, Dorian Gray, dressed like an ordinary person with a scarf wrapped around his neck, secretly left the house. On Rond Street, he found a carriage with a sturdy-looking horse. He waved and quietly gave an address to the coachman.
es: When midnight struck twelve bronze chimes in the darkness, Dorian Gray, dressed in inconspicuous clothes and a scarf wrapped around his neck, stealthily left his house. On Bond Street, he found a hansom cab with a good horse. He called it, but when he gave an address in a low voice, the cabman shook his head.

en: The man shook his head. “It is too far for me,” he muttered.
vi: The person shook their head. "Too far for me," he muttered.
tr: The man nodded his head. "I can't go, it's too far," he said.
es: He called it, but when he gave an address in a low voice, the cabman shook his head. —It's too far for me —he murmured.

en: “Here is a sovereign for you,” said Dorian. “You shall have another if you drive fast.”
vi: “Here, a sovereign for you,” Dorian said. “You can get another one if you run fast.”
tr: "Here's a gold coin for you. If you drive fast, I'll give you another one."
es: —Here is a sovereign —Dorian Gray said to him—. I'll give you another if you hurry.

en: “All right, sir,” answered the man, “you will be there in an hour,” and after his fare had got in he turned his horse round and drove rapidly towards the river.
vi: “Yes, sir,” the man replied, “you will be there within an hour,” and after the fare was in his pocket, he turned the horse and sped quickly towards the river.
tr: Adam said, "Yes, sir, we will arrive in an hour." After the passenger mounted, he turned his horse's head and quickly headed towards the river. 9. Meat, poultry, etc. in jelly.
es: —Alright, sir —replied the coachman—; we will be there within an hour —and after his passenger got into the vehicle, he turned the horse around and headed quickly towards the river.

en: CHAPTER XVI.
vi: Chapter 16
tr: (C. N.) Chapter Sixteen
es: Chapter 16

en: A cold rain began to fall, and the blurred street-lamps looked ghastly in the dripping mist. The public-houses were just closing, and dim men and women were clustering in broken groups round their doors. From some of the bars came the sound of horrible laughter. In others, drunkards brawled and screamed.
vi: Cold rain began to fall, the streetlights blurred, looking truly eerie in the soaking mist. The pubs had just closed, and men and women were faintly gathering into fragmented groups around the doors. From a few bars came horrifying laughter. At other bars, the drunkards were arguing and shouting.
tr: A cold rain had started to fall; the blurry street lamps in the splashing mist resembled dead eyes. It was exactly the closing time for the taverns; faint silhouettes of men and women were forming scattered groups in front of the doors. From some of the bars, hair-raising laughter echoed, while in others, drunks were shouting and fighting.
es: A cold rain began to fall, and the blurred streetlights no longer cast anything more than a faded glow through the fog. It was the time when public establishments were closing, and men and women still gathered in front of their doors began to disperse. From the interior of some of the taverns, horrible laughter still erupted. In others, the drunks argued and shouted.

en: Lying back in the hansom, with his hat pulled over his forehead, Dorian Gray watched with listless eyes the sordid shame of the great city, and now and then he repeated to himself the words that Lord Henry had said to him on the first day they had met, “To cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul.” Yes, that was the secret. He had often tried it, and would try it again now. There were opium dens where one could buy oblivion, dens of horror where the memory of old sins could be destroyed by the madness of sins that were new.
vi: Lying on his back in the car, hat pulled over his forehead, Dorian Gray listlessly watched the sordid shame of that great city, and occasionally he repeated to himself the words that Lord Henry had said to him the very first day they met, "Cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul." Yes, that was the secret. He often tried it, and would try it again right now. There were opium dens, where one could buy oblivion, hideous haunts where the memory of old sins could be destroyed by the madness of new ones.
tr: Dorian, leaning back in the car with his hat pulled down over his eyes, was gazing with a blank stare at the filthy, vile depravity of the big city and occasionally repeating to himself the words he had heard from Lord Henry on the day they first met: "To cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul..." Yes, that was the crux of the matter. Dorian had tried this many times, and now he would try it again. There were opium dens where "forgetfulness" could be bought with money, dens of horror where you could erase the memories of old sins with the madness of new ones.
es: Almost lying down in the cab, his hat pulled down over his forehead, Dorian Gray gazed indifferently at the sordid abjection of the great city, and from time to time he repeated to himself the words that Lord Henry had said to him the day they met: "Cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul." Yes, that was the secret. Dorian Gray had often tried it and was about to do so again. There were opium dens where one could buy forgetfulness, dreadful haunts where one could destroy the memory of old sins with the frenzy of newly committed ones.

en: The moon hung low in the sky like a yellow skull. From time to time a huge misshapen cloud stretched a long arm across and hid it. The gas-lamps grew fewer, and the streets more narrow and gloomy. Once the man lost his way and had to drive back half a mile. A steam rose from the horse as it splashed up the puddles. The sidewindows of the hansom were clogged with a grey-flannel mist.
vi: The waning moon hung in the sky like a golden skull. Occasionally, a gigantic misshapen cloud would stretch its long arm across and obscure it. Gas lamps became rarer, the streets narrower and gloomier. The coachman once got lost and had to turn back half a mile. Steam rose from the horse as it splashed through a puddle of rainwater. The windows on the side of the carriage were sealed with a gray flannel mist.
tr: The moon was swaying on the horizon like a yellow skull. Occasionally, a huge, crooked cloud would stretch out its long arm and hide the moon from view. Now the street lamps had thinned out, the streets were narrower, more enclosed. At one point, the coachman lost his way and had to turn back almost half a kilometer. Steam was rising from the body of the horse as it splashed through puddles. A mist cut from gray cloth had covered the side windows of the carriage.
es: The moon, near the horizon, looked like a yellow skull. From time to time, an enormous deformed cloud extended a long arm and completely obscured it. The gas lamps grew further apart, and the streets became narrower and gloomier. On one occasion, the coachman took the wrong path and had to retrace his steps for almost a kilometer. The horse was enveloped in clouds of vapor when it trampled the puddles. The windows of the cab became covered with a film of mud resembling gray flannel.

en: “To cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul!” How the words rang in his ears! His soul, certainly, was sick to death. Was it true that the senses could cure it? Innocent blood had been spilled. What could atone for that? Ah! for that there was no atonement; but though forgiveness was impossible, forgetfulness was possible still, and he was determined to forget, to stamp the thing out, to crush it as one would crush the adder that had stung one. Indeed, what right had Basil to have spoken to him as he had done? Who had made him a judge over others? He had said things that were dreadful, horrible, not to be endured.
vi: “Healing the soul by using the senses, and healing the senses by using the soul!” How these words resonated in his ears! His soul was surely fed up. Is it true that the senses can heal it? Innocent blood has been shed. What can atone for that sin? Oh! There is no redemption for that sin; but even if it cannot be forgiven, it can still be forgotten, and he decided to forget, to erase it, to crush it as one would crush a venomous snake. Indeed, what right did Basil have to speak to him as he did? Who made him judge over others? He had said terrible, disgusting, unbearable things.
tr: “To heal the soul through the senses, and the senses through the soul!” How these words echoed in his ears! Indeed, his soul was mortally ill at this moment. Was it really possible for the senses to heal the soul? Innocent blood had been shed. What could pay the price for this? No, nothing could pay for this. However, even if forgiveness was not possible, forgetting was still an option. Dorian was determined to forget, to erase this memory, to crush and destroy it like one would crush a venomous snake that had bitten them. Besides, with what right had Basil said those words to him? Who had appointed him as a judge over others? He had said things that were terrible, disgusting, unbearable.
es: “Cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul!” How those words resonated in his ears! His soul, of course, had a mortal disease. Could it be true that the senses could cure it? Innocent blood had been shed. How to atone for it? No; there was no possible atonement; but although forgiveness was impossible, forgetting was not, and Dorian Gray was determined to forget, to trample that memory, to crush it as we crush the viper that has injected its venom into us. After all, what right did Basil have to speak to him as he had? Who had granted him the authority to judge others? He had said dreadful, horrible, unbearable things.

en: On and on plodded the hansom, going slower, it seemed to him, at each step. He thrust up the trap and called to the man to drive faster. The hideous hunger for opium began to gnaw at him. His throat burned and his delicate hands twitched nervously together. He struck at the horse madly with his stick. The driver laughed and whipped up. He laughed in answer, and the man was silent.
vi: He felt as if the two-wheeled carriage was laboriously dragging itself along, dragging itself along, slowing down with each step. He pushed up the trapdoor and called out to the coachman to make the carriage go faster. The horrible craving for drugs began to torment him. His throat burned, and his soft hands twitched restlessly. He beat the horse madly with his stick. The coachman laughed and urged the horse forward. He laughed in response, and the coachman fell silent.
tr: The carriage was still moving, but it seemed to Dorian that it was slowing down with every step. Dorian lifted the front flap and shouted at the driver to go faster. The disgusting craving for opium had started to gnaw at him. His throat was burning, and his slender hands were clenching and unclenching with nerves. He struck the horse wildly with his cane. The driver laughed and cracked his whip. When Dorian laughed in response, the man fell silent.
es: The cab moved laboriously, slowing down, it seemed to Dorian Gray, with each step. He violently opened the roof hatch and ordered the driver to speed up. The terrible craving for opium began to consume him. His throat burned and his delicate hands had caught a nervous tremor. Sticking an arm out the window, he fiercely struck the horse with his cane. The driver laughed and he too used his whip. Dorian Gray responded by laughing in turn and the other fell silent.

en: The way seemed interminable, and the streets like the black web of some sprawling spider. The monotony became unbearable, and as the mist thickened, he felt afraid.
vi: The road seemed endless, and the streets like a black web of a spider sprawled somewhere. The monotony became unbearable, and, as the fog thickened, he felt afraid.
tr: The end of the road seemed like it would never come, the roads resembled the pitch-black web of a giant spider. The monotony of the journey had become unbearable. As the fog thickened, Dorian began to feel afraid.
es: The journey seemed endless, and the streets resembled the black threads of an immense spider web. The monotony became unbearable and, as the fog thickened, Dorian Gray felt fear.

en: Then they passed by lonely brickfields. The fog was lighter here, and he could see the strange, bottle-shaped kilns with their orange, fanlike tongues of fire. A dog barked as they went by, and far away in the darkness some wandering sea-gull screamed. The horse stumbled in a rut, then swerved aside and broke into a gallop.
vi: Then they ran past the desolate brickworks. The fog here was thinner, and he could see the strange bottle-shaped kilns with orange tongues of flame that looked like fans. A dog barked loudly as they ran past, and far away, in the darkness, some wandering seagull screeched. The horse stumbled on the trail, then turned aside, and suddenly broke into a gallop.
tr: Then they began to pass by desolate brick fields. Here the mist had lightened; Dorian could make out those strange, bottle-shaped kilns, and the fan-shaped orange flames inside them. A dog barked after the carriage, and somewhere far off in the darkness, a wandering seagull cried. The horse stumbled and lurched as it stepped into a pothole in the road; then it reared up.
es: Then they passed by the solitary brick factories. The fog was less dense there, and he could see the strange bottle-shaped kilns and their tongues of orange fire that spread out like fans. A dog barked as they passed, and in the distance, in the darkness, a stray seagull screeched. The horse stumbled in a pothole in the road, swerved, and began to gallop.

en: After some time they left the clay road and rattled again over rough-paven streets. Most of the windows were dark, but now and then fantastic shadows were silhouetted against some lamplit blind. He watched them curiously. They moved like monstrous marionettes and made gestures like live things. He hated them. A dull rage was in his heart. As they turned a corner, a woman yelled something at them from an open door, and two men ran after the hansom for about a hundred yards. The driver beat at them with his whip.
vi: A moment later, they left the dirt road and started clattering along the rough cobbled streets again. Most of the windows were dark, but occasionally strange shadows were cast on the lit curtains. He curiously observed them. They moved like giant puppets, gesturing as if they were alive. He hated them. A smoldering anger burned in his heart. As they turned a corner, a woman shouted something at them from an open window, and two men chased the carriage for about a hundred yards before giving up. The coachman whipped them with a leather strap.
tr: After a while, they left the muddy road and clattered through the bumpy cobblestone streets. Most of the windows around here were dark, yet occasionally, strange shadows were cast on a curtain lit by a lamp, and Dorian watched them with curiosity. The shadows moved like giant puppets, waving their arms as if they were living creatures. Dorian hated them. A dull resentment filled his heart. As they turned a corner, a woman shouted something at them from the gap of an open door; two men ran after the carriage for about a hundred steps. The coachman struck them with his whip.
es: After some time, they left the dirt road and began to rattle along poorly paved streets again. Most of the windows were dark, but occasionally, fantastic shadows were cast on the blinds illuminated by some lamp. Dorian Gray watched them with curiosity. They moved like monstrous puppets and made gestures like living creatures. He felt that he loathed them. His heart was dominated by a dull rage. As they turned a corner, a woman shouted something at them from an open door, and two men ran after the cab for about a hundred meters. The coachman struck them with his whip.

en: It is said that passion makes one think in a circle. Certainly with hideous iteration the bitten lips of Dorian Gray shaped and reshaped those subtle words that dealt with soul and sense, till he had found in them the full expression, as it were, of his mood, and justified, by intellectual approval, passions that without such justification would still have dominated his temper. From cell to cell of his brain crept the one thought; and the wild desire to live, most terrible of all man’s appetites, quickened into force each trembling nerve and fibre. Ugliness that had once been hateful to him because it made things real, became dear to him now for that very reason. Ugliness was the one reality. The coarse brawl, the loathsome den, the crude violence of disordered life, the very vileness of thief and outcast, were more vivid, in their intense actuality of impression, than all the gracious shapes of art, the dreamy shadows of song. They were what he needed for forgetfulness. In three days he would be free.
vi: It is rumored that passion makes people think in circles. Indeed, with the monotonous repetition, Dorian Gray's tightly pressed lips kept molding and reshaping those wicked words about the soul and emotions, until he saw in them the full expression, so to speak, of his mood, and justified, with the approval of intelligence, the passions that without such justification would still dominate his mood. From one brain cell to another, a thought sneaked through; and the intense craving for life, the most terrible of all human desires, revived powerfully every nerve and each trembling muscle fiber. The ugliness that he once found repulsive because it brought things back to reality now became dear to him for that very reason. Ugliness was the only reality. The obscene quarrels, the disgusting den, the crude violence of a disordered life, and even the baseness of the street thieves, were more vivid, thanks to their intense impression of reality, than any form of decent Art, the dreamy shadows of Poetry. They were what he needed to forget. He would be free in three days.
tr: They say that passion circles a person's thoughts like a ring and brings them back to where they started. Indeed, Dorian, with his gnawed lips, kept repeating those meaningful words about soul and sense like a disgusting chant. So much so that in the end, he began to find a complete explanation of his spiritual state in these words and thus justified his passions with the approval of his mind. But even without this approval, these passions would not withdraw their hands from his being, anyway. This single thought was seeping from one cell in his brain to another, and the mad desire to live, this most dreadful appetite of mankind, was giving strength to every trembling nerve and fiber like sap. Once, he hated ugliness because it added reality to everything, but now he found it close to himself for the same reason. The only reality was ugliness. Vulgar brawls, disgusting slums, the harsh violence of vagrant lives, the baseness of thieves, dogs, and scoundrels, the products of ugliness, were more vivid and distinct than all the beautiful forms that art entered, and all the imaginary shadows that song sang, because of the tangible intensity of the impressions they created. These were the things Dorian needed to forget. In three days, he would be free.
es: It is said that passion makes one think in circles. And, certainly, the lips that Dorian Gray kept biting formed and reformed, in a dreadful repetition, the subtle words that dealt with the soul and the senses, until he found in them the full expression, so to speak, of his state of mind, and thus justified, by intellectually approving them, passions that without that justification would have dominated his will. From cell to cell that single idea took hold of his brain; and the frantic desire to live, the most terrible of human appetites, redoubled the vigor of every trembling nerve and muscle. The ugliness that had once seemed odious to him because it made things real, now seemed kind to him for that very reason. Ugliness was the only reality. The vulgar brawl, the repugnant den, the brutal violence of a disordered life, the very vileness of the thief and the outlaw, had more life, created a more intense impression of reality than all the elegant forms of Art, than the dreamy shadows of Song. They were what he needed to achieve oblivion. In the span of three days, he would be free.

en: Suddenly the man drew up with a jerk at the top of a dark lane. Over the low roofs and jagged chimney-stacks of the houses rose the black masts of ships. Wreaths of white mist clung like ghostly sails to the yards.
vi: Suddenly, the person stopped the vehicle with a sudden, strong jerk at the head of a dark alley. On the low, squat roofs and the jagged clusters of chimneys of the houses, the black masts of ships rose up. Billowing white fog clung to the taut masts like ghostly sails.
tr: At the beginning of a dark dirt road, the coachman suddenly pulled the reins and stopped. Behind the low roofs of the houses here, and the jagged clusters of chimneys, black ship masts were rising. White rings of mist over the courtyards and spars were like ghostly sails.
es: Suddenly, the coachman stopped abruptly at the beginning of a shadowy alley. Above the low rooftops, bristling with chimneys, the black masts of the ships rose. Spirals of white mist clung to the yards like ghostly sails.

en: “Somewhere about here, sir, ain’t it?” he asked huskily through the trap.
vi: "Somewhere around here, perhaps, sir?" he asked hoarsely through the trapdoor.
tr: The coachman asked in a muffled voice from behind the cover, "Somewhere around here, right, sir?"
es: —It's somewhere around here, isn't it, sir? —asked the coachman in a hoarse voice through the hatch.

en: Dorian started and peered round. “This will do,” he answered, and having got out hastily and given the driver the extra fare he had promised him, he walked quickly in the direction of the quay. Here and there a lantern gleamed at the stern of some huge merchantman. The light shook and splintered in the puddles. A red glare came from an outward-bound steamer that was coaling. The slimy pavement looked like a wet mackintosh.
vi: Dorian started, looking around. “Alright then,” he replied, and, after hastily getting out, handed the coachman the extra tip he had promised him, and walked briskly towards the harbor. Here and there, lanterns flickered at the stern of some gigantic merchant ship. The light shimmered and shattered in the puddles. A glaring red light was cast from an ocean-going steamship taking on coal. The slimy pavement looked like a wet raincoat.
tr: Dorian shuddered and looked around. “This is good,” he said, quickly getting out, paid the promised fare to the driver, and then walked briskly towards the pier. Here and there, a lantern on the stern of a large cargo ship was shining. As the light flickered, the puddles were breaking into a thousand pieces. A crimson light was cast from a steamship taking on coal in preparation for setting sail. The slippery pavement resembled a wet raincoat.
es: Dorian, startled, looked around. —Leave me here —he replied and, after dismounting hastily and handing over the promised money, he hurried away towards the dock. Here and there a lantern shone on the bow of some gigantic merchant ship. The light trembled and broke up in the puddles. From a steamer about to depart, which was stoking the fire to increase boiler pressure, a red glow emerged. The slippery ground looked like a wet raincoat.

en: He hurried on towards the left, glancing back now and then to see if he was being followed. In about seven or eight minutes he reached a small shabby house that was wedged in between two gaunt factories. In one of the top-windows stood a lamp. He stopped and gave a peculiar knock.
vi: You hurriedly continued to the left, occasionally glancing back to see if you were being followed. After about seven or eight minutes, you arrived at a small, dilapidated house, wedged between two abandoned factories. In a high window, there was a lamp. You stopped and knocked a distinctive knock.
tr: Dorian turned left with quick steps. Occasionally, he looked back to see if anyone was following him. In seven or eight minutes, he reached a small, poor-looking house squeezed between two large factories. There was a lamp in one of the upper floor windows of the house. Dorian stopped and knocked on the door with a special password.
es: Dorian Gray hurried to the left, turning his head from time to time to check if someone was following him. Seven or eight minutes later, he arrived at a dilapidated little house, wedged between two gloomy factories. A light was shining in one of the upstairs windows. He stopped at the door and knocked in a peculiar manner.

en: After a little time he heard steps in the passage and the chain being unhooked. The door opened quietly, and he went in without saying a word to the squat misshapen figure that flattened itself into the shadow as he passed. At the end of the hall hung a tattered green curtain that swayed and shook in the gusty wind which had followed him in from the street. He dragged it aside and entered a long low room which looked as if it had once been a third-rate dancing-saloon. Shrill flaring gas-jets, dulled and distorted in the fly-blown mirrors that faced them, were ranged round the walls. Greasy reflectors of ribbed tin backed them, making quivering disks of light. The floor was covered with ochre-coloured sawdust, trampled here and there into mud, and stained with dark rings of spilled liquor. Some Malays were crouching by a little charcoal stove, playing with bone counters and showing their white teeth as they chattered. In one corner, with his head buried in his arms, a sailor sprawled over a table, and by the tawdrily painted bar that ran across one complete side stood two haggard women, mocking an old man who was brushing the sleeves of his coat with an expression of disgust. “He thinks he’s got red ants on him,” laughed one of them, as Dorian passed by. The man looked at her in terror and began to whimper.
vi: A moment later, he heard footsteps in the hallway, and the chain being unhooked. The door opened silently, and he stepped in without saying a word to the short, fat, deformed figure that had flattened itself into a shadow as he passed by. At the end of the hall hung a tattered green curtain, trembling and swaying in the gust of wind that had followed him in from the street. He pulled it aside and stepped into a long, low room that looked as if it had once been a third-rate dance hall. The gas lamps blazed brightly, hissing deafeningly, blurred and distorted in the fly-specked mirrors facing them, arranged in rows around the walls. The tin reflectors behind them, greasy and embossed, cast out trembling discs of light. The floor was covered in ochre-colored sawdust, trampled here and there into mud, stained with dark rings from spilled spirits. A few Malays crouched by a small charcoal stove, playing with bone tiles, revealing white teeth as they chattered. In one corner, with his head buried in his arms, a sailor sprawled across a table, and by the garishly painted bar running along one wall, two haggard women stood teasing an old man who was brushing off his coat with a look of disgust. “He thinks he's got red ants on him,” one of the women laughed, as Dorian walked past. The man looked at her in terror and began to whimper.
tr: After a while, he heard footsteps walking in the corridor and the chain being unhooked. The door opened quietly. Dorian entered without saying a word to the short, crooked shadow that shrank back into the shadows as he passed. The green curtain at the end of the corridor was fluttering and shaking with the strong gust of wind that had followed Dorian inside. Dorian pushed the curtain aside and entered a low-ceilinged, long room that seemed to have once been used as a third-class dance hall. The light from the gas lamps flickering loudly on the walls was hitting the fly-specked mirrors in front of them, dimming and distorting. The oily, corrugated tin reflectors behind the lamps were forming circles of flickering light. The floors were covered with yellow sawdust, trampled and muddied in places, stained black in rings by spilled drinks. A few Malays squatting by a small coal stove were playing with bone chips, their white teeth showing as they chatted. In one corner, a sailor had collapsed onto a table, his head resting on his arms. In front of the dew-painted bar that covered an entire wall, two shabby, skinny women were mocking an old man. The man was shaking the cuffs of his jacket with an expression of disgust on his face. As Dorian passed by, one of the women laughed and said, "He thinks there are red ants on him." The poor man looked at her in horror, sighed, and sobbed.
es: After some time, he heard footsteps in the corridor and then the sliding of a bolt. The door opened silently and Dorian Gray entered without saying a single word to the deformed, chubby creature that pressed itself against the shadowy wall to let him pass. At the end of the hallway hung a tattered green curtain, swaying and trembling from the gust of wind that followed Dorian Gray from the street. Pulling it aside, he entered a long, low-ceilinged room that gave the impression of having once been a third-rate ballroom. On the walls, gas burners hissed and burned, their dim and deformed images reflected in numerous mirrors, blackened with fly specks. The greasy, wavy tin reflectors placed behind them turned them into trembling discs of light. The floor was covered with ochre sawdust, which, from being trodden on, had turned into mud, further stained by dark rings of spilled drinks. Some Malays, crouched by a small charcoal stove, played with bone chips and showed very white teeth as they spoke. In a corner, with his head hidden in his arms, a sailor had collapsed over a table, and next to the garishly painted bar that occupied one side of the room, two haggard women mocked an old man who was shaking the sleeves of his jacket with an expression of disgust. —He thinks he's being attacked by red ants —laughed one of them as Dorian Gray walked past. The old man looked at her terrified and began to moan.

en: At the end of the room there was a little staircase, leading to a darkened chamber. As Dorian hurried up its three rickety steps, the heavy odour of opium met him. He heaved a deep breath, and his nostrils quivered with pleasure. When he entered, a young man with smooth yellow hair, who was bending over a lamp lighting a long thin pipe, looked up at him and nodded in a hesitating manner.
vi: At the end of the room, there was a small staircase leading up to a darkened chamber. As Dorian hurriedly climbed the three creaky steps, the strong smell of opium greeted him. He took a deep breath, his nose trembling with pleasure. When he entered, a young man with sleek blonde hair, bent over a lamp and lighting a small long pipe, looked at him and nodded in greeting with a hesitant attitude.
tr: A low staircase at the back of the room led to a dark compartment. As Dorian ran up the shaky three steps of the staircase, the heavy scent of opium greeted him. Dorian took a deep breath, his nostrils quivering with pleasure. When he entered, a young man with straight, blond hair, who was leaning over a lamp lighting a long, thin pipe in his hand, looked up at him and then greeted him with a bit of hesitation.
es: At the back of the room, a small staircase led to a dark room. As Dorian hurried to ascend the three rickety steps, the dense smell of opium assaulted him. He took a deep breath, and his nostrils quivered with pleasure. Upon entering, a young man with smooth blond hair, who was leaning over a lamp lighting a long, very thin pipe, looked in his direction and greeted him hesitantly with a nod.

en: “You here, Adrian?” muttered Dorian.
vi: "Is that you, Adrian?" Dorian muttered.
tr: Dorian muttered, "So, you're here, Adrian?"
es: —You here, Adrian? —murmured Dorian.

en: “Where else should I be?” he answered, listlessly. “None of the chaps will speak to me now.”
vi: "Where else could I be?" he replied, listlessly. "Now no one is willing to talk to me anymore."
tr: The other replied in a calm voice, "Where else would I be?" "None of our children talk to me anymore."
es: —Where do you want me to be? —the other responded apathetically—. All my friends have stopped greeting me.

en: “I thought you had left England.”
vi: “I thought you had left England.”
tr: “I thought you had left England.”
es: —I thought you had left England.

en: “Darlington is not going to do anything. My brother paid the bill at last. George doesn’t speak to me either.... I don’t care,” he added with a sigh. “As long as one has this stuff, one doesn’t want friends. I think I have had too many friends.”
vi: “Darlington doesn't do anything. In the end, my brother paid the bill. George doesn't talk to me either… I don't care,” he added, with a sigh. “As long as I have this thing, I don't need friends. I think I have too many friends.”
tr: “Darlington is not going to do anything. My brother finally paid the bill. George is not talking to me either...” Then the young man sighed and added, “I don't care,” “Who needs a friend when you have this at your disposal! I had too many friends anyway, I guess.”
es: —Darlington will do nothing against me. My brother ended up paying the debt. George doesn't speak to me either... I don't care —he added with a sigh—. As long as this is not lacking, friends are not needed. I think I had too many.

en: Dorian winced and looked round at the grotesque things that lay in such fantastic postures on the ragged mattresses. The twisted limbs, the gaping mouths, the staring lustreless eyes, fascinated him. He knew in what strange heavens they were suffering, and what dull hells were teaching them the secret of some new joy. They were better off than he was. He was prisoned in thought. Memory, like a horrible malady, was eating his soul away. From time to time he seemed to see the eyes of Basil Hallward looking at him. Yet he felt he could not stay. The presence of Adrian Singleton troubled him. He wanted to be where no one would know who he was. He wanted to escape from himself.
vi: Dorian grimaced, looking around at the bizarre things lying in very strange positions on the torn mattresses. Twisted limbs, wide-open mouths, dull eyes glaring, hypnotizing him. He knew they were enduring suffering in some strange paradises, and some gray hells were teaching them some new secret of joy. They were better off than him. He was imprisoned in thought. Memory, like a terrible disease, was slowly consuming his soul. Sometimes it seemed he saw Basil Hallward's eyes looking at him. However, he felt he could not stay. The presence of Adrian Singleton disturbed him. He wanted to be somewhere where no one knew who he was. He needed to escape from himself.
tr: Dorian winced and grimaced; he looked around at the misshapen things sprawled in impossible positions on the tattered mattresses. Twisted legs, gaping mouths, lifeless eyes staring blankly seemed to mesmerize him. He knew in which strange heavens they suffered, and the secrets of the brand-new pleasures they learned in which lightless hells. Their situation was better than his own. Because he was in the prison of his thoughts. Memories were gnawing at his soul like a terrible disease. He kept seeing the eyes of Basil Hallward looking at him. Yet he didn't think he could stay here. The presence of Adrian Singleton disturbed him. He wanted to be somewhere no one would recognize him. He wanted to escape from himself.
es: Dorian Gray's face twitched for an instant; then he gazed at the grotesque figures lying on the filthy mattresses in strange postures. The contorted limbs, the open mouths, the lost gazes, and the glassy eyes fascinated him. He knew in what strange paradises they indulged in suffering and what sad hells taught them the secret of some new joy. They were more fortunate than he, a prisoner of his thoughts. Memory, like a horrible disease, devoured his soul. From time to time, it seemed to him that he saw Basil Hallward's eyes looking at him. He understood, however, that he could not stay there. The presence of Adrian Singleton disturbed him. He wanted to be in a place where no one knew who he was. He wanted to flee from himself.

en: “I am going on to the other place,” he said after a pause.
vi: "I will go somewhere else," he said, after a moment of hesitation.
tr: After a pause, he said, "I am going to the other place."
es: —I'm going to the other place —he said, after a pause.

en: “On the wharf?”
vi: “Crossing the dock?”
tr: "The one on the dock?"
es: —At the dock?

en: “Yes.”
vi: "Yes."
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “That mad-cat is sure to be there. They won’t have her in this place now.”
vi: “That crazy cat will definitely be there. Now they don't let it in this place anymore.”
tr: “That rabid cat is definitely there. They don't let it in here anymore.”
es: —That crazy cat will definitely be there. They don't let her in here anymore.

en: Dorian shrugged his shoulders. “I am sick of women who love one. Women who hate one are much more interesting. Besides, the stuff is better.”
vi: Dorian shrugged. “I’m sick of those girls who are in love with someone. Girls who hate someone are actually much more interesting. Besides, that’s also more fun.”
tr: Dorian shrugged his shoulders. “I'm tired of women who fall in love with me. Women who bear a grudge are more interesting. Besides, the goods there are better.”
es: Dorian shrugged. —I am fed up with women who love me. Women who hate are much more interesting. Besides, the merchandise is better there.

en: “Much the same.”
vi: “The same.”
tr: "Hit one with the other."
es: —More or less the same thing.

en: “I like it better. Come and have something to drink. I must have something.”
vi: “I like it more.” “Let's go get a drink.” “I need to drink something.”
tr: "I like the one over there more." "Come and have a drink." "I need to drink.""
es: —I prefer her. Come have a drink. I need a drink.

en: “I don’t want anything,” murmured the young man.
vi: “I don't want anything,” the young man muttered.
tr: The young man muttered, "I don't want anything."
es: —I don't want anything —murmured the young man.

en: “Never mind.”
vi: “Just leave it.”
tr: "Don't worry."
es: —It doesn't matter.

en: Adrian Singleton rose up wearily and followed Dorian to the bar. A half-caste, in a ragged turban and a shabby ulster, grinned a hideous greeting as he thrust a bottle of brandy and two tumblers in front of them. The women sidled up and began to chatter. Dorian turned his back on them and said something in a low voice to Adrian Singleton.
vi: Adrian Singleton lazily stood up, following Dorian to the bar. A half-Indian man, wearing a torn turban and a worn ulster coat, grinned grotesquely as he pushed a bottle of brandy and two glasses in front of them. The women timidly approached and began to chatter incessantly. Dorian turned his back to them, whispering something to Adrian Singleton.
tr: Adrian Singleton, with a weary demeanor, got up and followed Dorian to the bar. A half-breed with a shabby turban and a worn-out coat greeted them with a dirty grin and placed a bottle of brandy and two glasses in front of them. The women approached and started to chatter. Dorian turned his back to them and said something in a low voice to Adrian Singleton.
es: Adrian Singleton got up with a tired air and followed Dorian Gray to the bar. A mulatto, with a tattered turban and a long filthy coat, greeted them with a hideous grin as he placed a bottle of brandy and two glasses before them. The women approached and began to chatter. Dorian turned his back on them and said something in a low voice to his companion.

en: A crooked smile, like a Malay crease, writhed across the face of one of the women. “We are very proud to-night,” she sneered.
vi: A crooked smile, like a Malay wrinkle, twisted across the face of a woman. “Tonight we are very proud,” she mocked.
tr: One of the women, with a mocking smile curving on her face like Malayan daggers, sneered, "Tonight, nothing but our arrogance is visible."
es: A smile as twisted as a Malay kris crossed the face of one of the women. —How proud we are tonight! —were his mocking words.

en: “For God’s sake don’t talk to me,” cried Dorian, stamping his foot on the ground. “What do you want? Money? Here it is. Don’t ever talk to me again.”
vi: "For God's sake, don't talk to me," Dorian shouted, stamping his foot on the ground. "What do you want? Money? Here. Never talk to me again."
tr: Dorian stomped his foot and shouted, "For God's sake, don't talk to me!" "What do you want? Money? Take it. Don't ever speak to me again."
es: —For the love of God, do not speak to me —exclaimed Dorian, stamping his foot—. What do you want? Money? Here you have it. But do not speak to me again.

en: Two red sparks flashed for a moment in the woman’s sodden eyes, then flickered out and left them dull and glazed. She tossed her head and raked the coins off the counter with greedy fingers. Her companion watched her enviously.
vi: Two red sparks flashed briefly in the dull eyes of the woman, then gradually faded, leaving them cloudy and vacant. She jerked her head up, greedily scraping the coins off the counter with her fingers. Her companion watched her with envy.
tr: For a moment, two red sparks flashed in the woman's alcohol-clouded eyes, then they faded and her eyes became dull and glassy again. The woman threw her head back slightly, greedily raking and grabbing the coins on the bar counter with her fingers. Her friend was eyeing her with envy.
es: In the woman's eyes, dulled by alcohol, two red flashes appeared for a moment, but they quickly faded, leaving them dead and glassy once again. Then she shook her head and with greedy fingers gathered the coins from the counter. Her companion watched her with envy.

en: “It’s no use,” sighed Adrian Singleton. “I don’t care to go back. What does it matter? I am quite happy here.”
vi: "It's no use," Adrian Singleton sighed. "I don't want to go back. What's the point? I'm very happy here."
tr: Adrian sighed, "It's pointless." "I don't want to go back. What difference does it make? I'm perfectly happy here."
es: —It's useless —sighed Adrian Singleton—. I don't feel like going back. What difference does it make? I'm very well here.

en: “You will write to me if you want anything, won’t you?” said Dorian, after a pause.
vi: “You will write to me if you need anything, promise?” Dorian said, after a moment's pause.
tr: After a pause, Dorian asked, "If you need anything, you'll write to me, won't you?"
es: —You will write to me if you need anything, alright? —said Dorian after a pause.

en: “Perhaps.”
vi: “Maybe.”
tr: “Maybe.”
es: —Maybe.

en: “Good night, then.”
vi: "Well then, goodbye."
tr: “Good night, then.”
es: —Good night, then.

en: “Good night,” answered the young man, passing up the steps and wiping his parched mouth with a handkerchief.
vi: "Goodbye," the young man replied, walking up the steps, wiping his dry, chapped mouth with a handkerchief.
tr: The young man replied, "Good night," wiping his parched lips with a handkerchief as he climbed the stairs.
es: —Good evening —replied the young man, going back up the steps while wiping his dry mouth with a handkerchief.

en: Dorian walked to the door with a look of pain in his face. As he drew the curtain aside, a hideous laugh broke from the painted lips of the woman who had taken his money. “There goes the devil’s bargain!” she hiccoughed, in a hoarse voice.
vi: Dorian walked to the door with a look of pain on his face. As he pulled the curtain aside, a hideous laugh burst from the painted lips of the woman who had just taken his money. "A devil's bargain has just been struck!" she said with a thick, hoarse voice, hiccuping.
tr: Dorian walked towards the door with an expression on his face that showed he was in pain. As he drew the curtain aside, an ugly laugh burst from the painted lips of the woman who had just taken his money. In a raspy voice, as if caught by a sob, the woman said, "There goes the man bought by the devil!"
es: Dorian walked towards the door with a pained expression on his face. As he drew aside the green curtain, a ghastly laugh escaped the painted lips of the woman who had collected the coins. —There goes the devil's protégé! —he exclaimed in a hoarse voice between two hiccups.

en: “Curse you!” he answered, “don’t call me that.”
vi: “You bitch!” he replied, “don’t call me that.”
tr: Dorian said, "Damn you." "Don't say that.""
es: —Damn you! —responded Dorian—, don't call me that!

en: She snapped her fingers. “Prince Charming is what you like to be called, ain’t it?” she yelled after him.
vi: She snapped her fingers. "Prince Charming is the name you want to be called, right?" she yelled behind him.
tr: The woman snapped her fingers. “You like the name Sweet Prince, don't you?” she shouted after him.
es: The woman snapped her fingers. —Prince Charming is what you like to be called, isn't it? —he shouted at her as he left.

en: The drowsy sailor leaped to his feet as she spoke, and looked wildly round. The sound of the shutting of the hall door fell on his ear. He rushed out as if in pursuit.
vi: The dozing sailor jumped up when he heard the woman speak, frantically looking around. The sound of the hall door closing reached his ears. He rushed outside as if to pursue.
tr: Upon hearing these words, the sailor who was dozing at the table jumped up and scanned his surroundings with wild eyes. He heard the sound of a door closing. The man ran outside as if he were chasing someone.
es: The drowsy sailor jumped up upon hearing the woman, and looked around with crazed eyes. The sound of the door closing reached his ears, and he rushed out, as if in pursuit of someone.

en: Dorian Gray hurried along the quay through the drizzling rain. His meeting with Adrian Singleton had strangely moved him, and he wondered if the ruin of that young life was really to be laid at his door, as Basil Hallward had said to him with such infamy of insult. He bit his lip, and for a few seconds his eyes grew sad. Yet, after all, what did it matter to him? One’s days were too brief to take the burden of another’s errors on one’s shoulders. Each man lived his own life and paid his own price for living it. The only pity was one had to pay so often for a single fault. One had to pay over and over again, indeed. In her dealings with man, destiny never closed her accounts.
vi: Dorian Gray hurried along the quay, through the drizzle. The meeting with Adrian Singleton had unsettled him strangely, and he wondered whether the degeneration of that young life was really his fault, as Basil Hallward had once told him with such shameful reproach. He bit his lip, and for a few seconds, his eyes grew sad. However, in the end, what did it matter to him? Life was too short to bear the burden of another's sins on one's shoulders. Everyone had to live their own life, and pay their own price for living it. The only pity was that one often had to pay so frequently for just a single mistake. One had to keep paying and paying, it was truly so. In dealings with humans, Fate never agreed to close the account.
tr: Dorian Gray was walking briskly along the quay under the drizzle. Meeting Adrian Singleton had affected him in a strangely emotional way: Was the blame for the ruin of this fresh life really to be placed on his shoulders, as Basil Hallward had so basely suggested? Dorian bit his lip, his eyes filled with sorrow for a moment. On the other hand, what did this matter have to do with him? Human life was too short to bear the weight of others' mistakes. Everyone lived their own life and paid the price for living it. The tragic part was that a person had to pay for a single mistake many times over. They had to keep paying, that was the truth of it. In its dealings with humans, Fate never closed its ledger.
es: Dorian Gray walked briskly along the dock, indifferent to the rain. His encounter with Adrian Singleton had strangely moved him, and he wondered if that disaster was his responsibility, as Basil Hallward had so insultingly told him. He bit his lips, and for a moment his eyes filled with sadness. Although, after all, what did it matter to him? Life is too short to bear the weight of others' mistakes. Each person spent their own life and paid their own price for living it. The only regrettable thing was that for a single fault one had to pay so many times. That indeed, one had to pay and pay again and keep paying. In its dealings with human beings, Fate never closed the accounts.

en: There are moments, psychologists tell us, when the passion for sin, or for what the world calls sin, so dominates a nature that every fibre of the body, as every cell of the brain, seems to be instinct with fearful impulses. Men and women at such moments lose the freedom of their will. They move to their terrible end as automatons move. Choice is taken from them, and conscience is either killed, or, if it lives at all, lives but to give rebellion its fascination and disobedience its charm. For all sins, as theologians weary not of reminding us, are sins of disobedience. When that high spirit, that morning star of evil, fell from heaven, it was as a rebel that he fell.
vi: Psychologists tell us that there are times when the passion for sin, or what the world calls sin, dominates human nature to such an extent that every muscle fiber, as well as every brain cell, seems to be imbued with terrifying impulses. Men and women in such moments often lose their freedom of will. They move towards their terrible end like automatons, the power of choice taken from them, and their conscience either killed or, if it still lives, it lives only to struggle against the temptation, and to defy its allure. For every sin, as theologians tirelessly remind us, is a sin of disobedience. When that supreme deity, that morning star of evil, fell from heaven, it was due to a rebellion that he fell.
tr: According to psychologists, there are moments in life when the passion for sin—or for what society deems sinful—takes such hold of a person's nature that every fiber of the body, every cell of the brain, seems to revolt with dreadful impulses. At such times, men and women lose the independence of their will. They move towards their impending fate like programmed machines. The ability to choose has been taken from them. Conscience has been killed, and if it exists at all, it lives only to add allure to rebellion and to make stubbornness seem charming. For the source of all sin, as theologians tirelessly say, is great disobedience. If that exalted spirit, the morning star of sin, was cast out of heaven, it was because he was rebellious.
es: There are moments, psychologists tell us, when the passion for sin, or for what the world calls sin, dominates our being to such an extent that all the fibers of the body, as well as the cells of the brain, are nothing but instinct with horrifying impulses. In such moments, men and women cease to be free. They move towards their terrible objective like automatons. They lose the ability to choose, and the conscience is crushed or, if it lives, it does so to fill rebellion with fascination and to give charm to disobedience. When that powerful spirit, that perverse morning star fell from heaven, it did so as a rebel.

en: Callous, concentrated on evil, with stained mind, and soul hungry for rebellion, Dorian Gray hastened on, quickening his step as he went, but as he darted aside into a dim archway, that had served him often as a short cut to the ill-famed place where he was going, he felt himself suddenly seized from behind, and before he had time to defend himself, he was thrust back against the wall, with a brutal hand round his throat.
vi: Hardened, focused on evil, with a tainted soul and a spirit yearning for rebellion, Dorian Gray hurried, quickening his pace, but as he dashed aside, into the pitch-dark road under the archway that often served him as a shortcut to the infamous place he was heading to, he suddenly felt himself grabbed from behind, and before he had time to defend himself, he was shoved against the wall, with a vicious hand wrapped around his neck.
tr: With his heart hardened from being mired in sinful thoughts, his mind darkened, and his soul hungry for rebellion, Dorian Gray continued to walk at full speed, quickening his steps more and more. Then, as he turned into a dim archway, as he often did to take a shortcut to the bad place he was heading, he felt someone suddenly grab him from behind. Before he had a chance to defend himself, he was pushed against the wall, a ruthless hand gripping his throat.
es: Insensible, with no other goal than evil, his spirit contaminated and his soul hungry for rebellion, Dorian Gray hurried, quickening his pace as he went. But at the moment he turned to enter a dark passage that had often served as a shortcut to his destination, he felt himself grabbed from behind, and before he had time to defend himself, he was thrown against the wall, with a brutal hand squeezing his throat.

en: He struggled madly for life, and by a terrible effort wrenched the tightening fingers away. In a second he heard the click of a revolver, and saw the gleam of a polished barrel, pointing straight at his head, and the dusky form of a short, thick-set man facing him.
vi: He struggled frantically to live, and, with a tremendous effort, managed to pry those tightly gripping fingers apart. In a second, he heard the click of the revolver, saw the glimmer of the shiny barrel pointing straight at his head, and the dim figure of a short, stout man facing him.
tr: Dorian began to struggle frantically to save his life, pulling away the fingers that were squeezing his throat with tremendous effort. In an instant, he heard the click of a gun, saw the glint of a polished barrel aimed at his head, and made out the silhouette of a short, stocky man standing before him.
es: He fought desperately and, with a tremendous effort, managed to free himself from the increasing pressure of the fingers. But a second later he heard the click of a revolver and saw the gleam of a barrel pointing directly at his head, as well as the indistinct silhouette of the short and sturdy individual facing him.

en: “What do you want?” he gasped.
vi: “What do you want?” he panted.
tr: "What do you want?" he asked haltingly.
es: —What do you want? —he gasped.

en: “Keep quiet,” said the man. “If you stir, I shoot you.”
vi: “Stay still,” the person said. “If you move, I will shoot you.”
tr: "Shut up," said the man. "If you move, I'll shoot."
es: —Stay still —said the other—. If you move, I'll shoot.

en: “You are mad. What have I done to you?”
vi: “You're crazy. What have I done to you?”
tr: “Are you crazy? What did I ever do to you?”
es: —You've lost your mind. What do you have against me?

en: “You wrecked the life of Sibyl Vane,” was the answer, “and Sibyl Vane was my sister. She killed herself. I know it. Her death is at your door. I swore I would kill you in return. For years I have sought you. I had no clue, no trace. The two people who could have described you were dead. I knew nothing of you but the pet name she used to call you. I heard it to-night by chance. Make your peace with God, for to-night you are going to die.”
vi: “You ruined Sibyl Vane's life,” was the reply, “and Sibyl Vane was my sister. She committed suicide. I know about it. She died because of you. I swore I would kill you to avenge her. For many years, I searched for you. I had no clues, no traces. The two people who could describe you were both dead. I knew nothing about you except the affectionate nickname she used to call you. Tonight I happened to hear it. Pray to God, for tonight you will die.”
tr: The man replied, “You extinguished Sibyl Vane’s life.” “Sibyl Vane was my sister. She took her own life. I am sure of it. You are the cause of her death. I swore to kill you in return. I have been searching for you for years. I had no trace, no clue. The two people who could identify you were dead. I knew nothing about you except the name she gave you. Tonight, by chance, I heard that name. Pray to your god, because tonight you die.”
es: —You destroyed Sibyl Vane's life —was the response—. And Sibyl Vane was my sister. She committed suicide. I know. You are responsible. I swore to kill you. I've been looking for you for years. I had no clue or the slightest trace. The two people who could give me a description of you are dead. I only knew the affectionate name that Sibyl used. A moment ago, I heard it by chance. Make peace with God, because you are going to die tonight.

en: Dorian Gray grew sick with fear. “I never knew her,” he stammered. “I never heard of her. You are mad.”
vi: Dorian was scared to death. “I have never met her,” he stammered. “I have never heard of her. You are crazy.”
tr: Dorian Gray felt like he was going to faint from fear. “I don't know him,” he stammered. “I haven't even heard his name. You are mad.”
es: Dorian Gray felt sick with fear. —I don't know what you're talking about —he stammered—. I've never heard that name. You're crazy.

en: “You had better confess your sin, for as sure as I am James Vane, you are going to die.” There was a horrible moment. Dorian did not know what to say or do. “Down on your knees!” growled the man. “I give you one minute to make your peace—no more. I go on board to-night for India, and I must do my job first. One minute. That’s all.”
vi: "You'd better confess, for as sure as I am James Vane, you're about to die." A dreadful moment. Dorian didn't know what to say or do. "Kneel down!" the man growled. "I'll give you one minute to pray — no more. Tonight, I'm boarding a ship to India, and I must do my duty first. One minute. That's all."
tr: "You better confess your sin, because just as sure as my name is James Vane, you will die." A terrible moment passed. Dorian didn't know what to say or what to do. The man snarled, "Kneel down!" "I'm giving you one minute for your last prayer; you have no other time. We are going to India tonight. I need to finish this before boarding the ship. One single minute. That's all."
es: —He'd better confess his sin, because he's going to die, as surely as my name is James Vane. During a terrible moment, Dorian did not know what to do or say. —On your knees! —growled his assailant—. I'll give you one minute to repent, nothing more. I'm embarking for India, but first I must fulfill my promise. One minute. That's all.

en: Dorian’s arms fell to his side. Paralysed with terror, he did not know what to do. Suddenly a wild hope flashed across his brain. “Stop,” he cried. “How long ago is it since your sister died? Quick, tell me!”
vi: Dorian's arms fell to his sides. Paralyzed by fear, he didn't know what to do. Suddenly, a wild hope flashed through his mind. "Stop," he shouted. "How long has it been since your sister died? Tell me, quickly!"
tr: Dorian's arms fell to his sides. He was paralyzed with horror, not knowing what to do. Suddenly, a wild hope flashed through his mind. "Stop!" he shouted. "How long has it been since your sister died? Quick, tell me!"
es: Dorian let his arms fall. Paralyzed by terror, he didn't know what to do. Suddenly, a wild hope crossed his mind. —Wait —he exclaimed—. How long has it been since your sister died? Quickly, tell me!

en: “Eighteen years,” said the man. “Why do you ask me? What do years matter?”
vi: "Eighteen years," the person said. "Why are you asking me? What does it matter how many years?"
tr: Adam replied, "Eighteen years." "Why are you asking? What difference does the year make?"
es: —Eighteen years —replied the sailor—. Why do you ask me that? What difference does it make?

en: “Eighteen years,” laughed Dorian Gray, with a touch of triumph in his voice. “Eighteen years! Set me under the lamp and look at my face!”
vi: "Eighteen years," Dorian Gray laughed loudly, with a hint of joy in his voice. "Eighteen years! Bring me under the light and look at my face!"
tr: Dorian Gray laughed, "Eighteen years, huh!" There was a tone of triumph in his voice. "Eighteen years! Take me to the base of that lantern and look at my face!"
es: —Eighteen years —laughed Dorian Gray, with a triumphant tone in his voice—. Eighteen years! Take me under the light and look at my face!

en: James Vane hesitated for a moment, not understanding what was meant. Then he seized Dorian Gray and dragged him from the archway.
vi: James Vane hesitated for a moment, not understanding what it meant. Then he grabbed Dorian Gray and dragged him out of the archway.
tr: James Vane paused for a moment, unable to make any sense of what was being said. Then he grabbed Dorian Gray and pulled him out from under the archway.
es: James Vane hesitated for a moment, not understanding what it was about. Then he grabbed Dorian Gray to take him out of the arcades.

en: Dim and wavering as was the wind-blown light, yet it served to show him the hideous error, as it seemed, into which he had fallen, for the face of the man he had sought to kill had all the bloom of boyhood, all the unstained purity of youth. He seemed little more than a lad of twenty summers, hardly older, if older indeed at all, than his sister had been when they had parted so many years ago. It was obvious that this was not the man who had destroyed her life.
vi: Dim and flickering in the wind, but the light was still enough for him to see the terrible mistake he seemed to have made, because the face of the person he sought to kill had all the freshness of youth, all the purity untouched by the dust of life. That person seemed to be just a young man who had just gone through twenty summers, hardly older, if indeed older at all, compared to his sister when they parted many years ago. Clearly, this was not the person who had ruined his sister's life.
tr: Although the light of the lantern swaying in the wind was dim and flickering, it was enough to show the sailor the dreadful mistake he had made, because the face of the man he attempted to kill bore all the freshness of youth and the untainted purity of adolescence. This man did not look much older than a twenty-year-old boy; he did not look much older than the age his sister had remained when they parted years ago. It was clear that this was not the person who had extinguished Sibyl's life.
es: Although the light, due to the violence of the wind, was weak and flickering, it nevertheless allowed him to confirm the horrifying mistake he had apparently made, because the face of his victim possessed all the freshness of adolescence, the spotless purity of youth. She barely seemed to be over twenty springs; the age his sister had been, if she even reached it, when he first embarked, so many years ago. Without a doubt, this was not the man who had ruined Sibyl's life.

en: He loosened his hold and reeled back. “My God! my God!” he cried, “and I would have murdered you!”
vi: He loosened his grip and staggered back. "Oh my God! Oh my God!" he shouted, "I almost killed you!"
tr: James Vane staggered backward, leaving Dorian. “Great God!” he moaned. “Oh my God! I was going to kill you.”
es: James Vane loosened the pressure of his hand and took a step back. —My God! —he exclaimed—. And I was about to kill him!

en: Dorian Gray drew a long breath. “You have been on the brink of committing a terrible crime, my man,” he said, looking at him sternly. “Let this be a warning to you not to take vengeance into your own hands.”
vi: Dorian Gray took a deep breath. "You almost committed a terrible crime, my friend," he said, looking at him sternly. "Let this be a lesson to you not to take revenge into your own hands."
tr: Dorian Gray took a deep breath. Looking sternly at the man in front of him, he said, "You were about to commit an almost terrible crime, my friend." "Let this be a lesson to you and leave revenge to God."
