es: Dorian Gray breathed deeply. —You were about to make a terrible mistake —he said, looking at him sternly—. Let this be a lesson to you not to take justice into your own hands.

en: “Forgive me, sir,” muttered James Vane. “I was deceived. A chance word I heard in that damned den set me on the wrong track.”
vi: “Forgive me, sir,” James Vane whispered. “I was deceived. A chance word I overheard in that wretched den led me astray.”
tr: James Vane, "Forgive me, sir," he murmured. "I was mistaken. A word I overheard in that godforsaken dive misled me."
es: —Forgive me —murmured the other—. I was mistaken. A word heard in that damned den made me confused.

en: “You had better go home and put that pistol away, or you may get into trouble,” said Dorian, turning on his heel and going slowly down the street.
vi: "You should go home, and put that gun away, or else you might get into trouble," Dorian said, turning on his heel, and slowly walked down the street.
tr: Dorian said, "It would be good if you went home now and put away that gun, otherwise you might get into trouble," and then turned and walked away slowly.
es: —It would be better if you go back home and abandon that weapon. Otherwise, you will have problems —said Dorian Gray, turning around and slowly walking down the street.

en: James Vane stood on the pavement in horror. He was trembling from head to foot. After a little while, a black shadow that had been creeping along the dripping wall moved out into the light and came close to him with stealthy footsteps. He felt a hand laid on his arm and looked round with a start. It was one of the women who had been drinking at the bar.
vi: James Vane stood on the sidewalk, terrified. He was trembling from head to toe. A moment later, a shadow crept along the drenched wall, moving into the light and approaching him with stealthy steps. He felt a hand placed on his arm and started, looking around. It was one of the women who had been drinking at the bar.
tr: James Vane stood frozen on the sidewalk, in horror. He was trembling from head to toe. A little later, a small, black figure that had been slowly approaching from the wet wall came into the light, and with silent, stealthy steps, it approached him. James Vane turned around with a start as he felt a hand touch his arm. It was one of the women who had been drinking in the bar.
es: James Vane, horrified, motionless in the middle of the street, began to tremble from head to toe. Shortly after, a dark shadow that had been stealthily approaching along the wall came into the light and approached him with furtive steps. The sailor felt a hand on his arm and turned around startled. It was one of the women who drank in the bar.

en: “Why didn’t you kill him?” she hissed out, putting haggard face quite close to his. “I knew you were following him when you rushed out from Daly’s. You fool! You should have killed him. He has lots of money, and he’s as bad as bad.”
vi: “Why didn't you kill it?” She hissed, bringing her gaunt face close to his. “I know you followed it when you rushed out of Daly. You are so stupid! You should have killed it. It has a lot of money, and it is truly evil.”
tr: Bringing her sunken face close to the man's, the woman asked in a shrill whisper, "Why didn't you kill him?" "When Daly rushed out from there, I knew he was after him. Idiot! You should have killed him. He has a ton of money. He's the worst of the worst himself."
es: —Why haven't you killed him? —he whispered, bringing his haggard face very close to James's—. I realized you were following him when you ran out of Daly's house. Poor fool! You should have killed him. He has a lot of money and is the worst of the worst.

en: “He is not the man I am looking for,” he answered, “and I want no man’s money. I want a man’s life. The man whose life I want must be nearly forty now. This one is little more than a boy. Thank God, I have not got his blood upon my hands.”
vi: “He is not the person I am looking for,” he replied, “and I do not need anyone's money. I need a person's life. The person whose life I want to take must be nearly forty by now. But this one is just a little older than a boy. Thank God, I did not let my hands be stained with his blood.”
tr: James Vane replied, "The man I'm looking for is not him." "I have no interest in anyone's money. I want a man's life. The man whose life I want should be around forty years old now. This one here is just a young boy. Thank God my hands are not stained with his blood."
es: —He is not the man I am looking for —replied James Vane—, and I am not interested in anyone's money. I want a life. The one I am looking for is around forty. The one I let go is little more than a child. Thank God I have not stained my hands with his blood.

en: The woman gave a bitter laugh. “Little more than a boy!” she sneered. “Why, man, it’s nigh on eighteen years since Prince Charming made me what I am.”
vi: The woman laughed bitterly. “Only a little older than a boy!” she sneered. “Why, my dear, it has been nearly eighteen years since Prince Charming made me this way.”
tr: The woman laughed bitterly. "Did you say yesterday's child?" she scoffed, curling her lip. "My dear, it's been almost eighteen years since the Sweet Prince put me in this state!"
es: The woman let out a bitter laugh. —Little more than a child! —he repeated in a mocking voice—. My poor dear, it's been almost eighteen years since Prince Charming made me what I am.

en: “You lie!” cried James Vane.
vi: “You are lying!” James Vane shouted.
tr: James Vane shouted, "You are lying!"
es: —You're lying! —exclaimed the sailor.

en: She raised her hand up to heaven. “Before God I am telling the truth,” she cried.
vi: She raised her hand to the sky. "I swear before God, I have told the truth," she exclaimed.
tr: The woman raised her hand towards the sky. “I am telling the truth in the presence of God.”
es: The woman raised her arms to the sky. —I swear to God I'm telling you the truth! —he exclaimed.

en: “Before God?”
vi: “Swear before God?”
tr: “Did you say in the presence of God?”
es: —Before God?

en: “Strike me dumb if it ain’t so. He is the worst one that comes here. They say he has sold himself to the devil for a pretty face. It’s nigh on eighteen years since I met him. He hasn’t changed much since then. I have, though,” she added, with a sickly leer.
vi: “Strike me dumb if it isn't so. He is the worst one ever to come here. They say he sold his soul to the devil for a handsome face. It's been nearly eighteen years since I met him. He hasn't changed much since then. Though I have,” she added, with a miserable glance.
tr: “If I'm lying, may my eyes fall out. He is the worst of those who haunt this place. They say he sold his soul to the devil to keep his face beautiful. It's been about eighteen years since I got to know him. In the meantime, he has hardly changed. But I have changed,” the woman added with a bitter grin.
es: —May I be struck dumb if it isn't true. He is the worst of all the scoundrels that come around here. They say he sold his soul to the devil for a pretty face. I've known him for almost eighteen years. He hasn't changed much since then. I, on the other hand, have —she added with a horrible grimace.

en: “You swear this?”
vi: “Do you swear?”
tr: “Do you swear to this?”
es: —Do you swear to me that it's true?

en: “I swear it,” came in hoarse echo from her flat mouth. “But don’t give me away to him,” she whined; “I am afraid of him. Let me have some money for my night’s lodging.”
vi: “I swear,” the hoarse repetition came from her thin, pinched mouth. “But don't tell on me to it,” she moaned; “I'm very afraid of it. Give me some money to pay for tonight's lodging.”
tr: From the woman's flat mouth, a muffled echo rose, "I swear." Then she pleaded, whining, "Don't tell him, please." "I'm afraid of him. Come on, give me some money so I can find a place to sleep for the night."
es: —I swear —the two words came out like a hoarse echo from his sunken mouth—. But don't tell him that I reported him —he whimpered—. I'm afraid of him. Give me something to pay for a bed tonight.

en: He broke from her with an oath and rushed to the corner of the street, but Dorian Gray had disappeared. When he looked back, the woman had vanished also.
vi: He cursed and left her, rushing to the corner of the street, but Dorian Gray had disappeared. When he looked back, the woman was also no longer there.
tr: James Vane, cursing, wrenched his arm free from the woman's grasp and ran to the corner, but Dorian Gray was nowhere to be seen. When James Vane looked back, he saw that the woman had also disappeared.
es: James Vane moved away from her with a curse and ran to the corner of the street, but Dorian Gray had disappeared. When he looked back, he couldn't find the woman either.

en: CHAPTER XVII.
vi: Chapter 17
tr: The seventeenth chapter
es: Chapter 17

en: A week later Dorian Gray was sitting in the conservatory at Selby Royal, talking to the pretty Duchess of Monmouth, who with her husband, a jaded-looking man of sixty, was amongst his guests. It was tea-time, and the mellow light of the huge, lace-covered lamp that stood on the table lit up the delicate china and hammered silver of the service at which the duchess was presiding. Her white hands were moving daintily among the cups, and her full red lips were smiling at something that Dorian had whispered to her. Lord Henry was lying back in a silk-draped wicker chair, looking at them. On a peach-coloured divan sat Lady Narborough, pretending to listen to the duke’s description of the last Brazilian beetle that he had added to his collection. Three young men in elaborate smoking-suits were handing tea-cakes to some of the women. The house-party consisted of twelve people, and there were more expected to arrive on the next day.
vi: One week later, Dorian Gray was sitting in the conservatory at Selby Royal estate and conversing with the beautiful Duchess of Monmouth, she and her husband, a weary-looking man in his sixties, were his guests. It was tea time, and the gentle light from the large lace-covered lamp on the table illuminated the exquisite porcelain and the hammered silver of the tea set at the party hosted by the duchess. Her delicate white hands fluttered gracefully among the cups, and her full red lips smiled at something Dorian whispered in her ear. Lord Henry lay back on a silk-covered wicker chair and watched them. On the peach-colored sofa, Mrs. Narborough sat pretending to listen to the duke describe the latest Brazilian beetle he had added to his collection. Three young men in elaborate smoking attire were serving pastries and tea to several women. The group of guests staying at the house comprised twelve people, and hopefully more would arrive tomorrow.
tr: A week had passed. Dorian Gray was sitting in the conservatory of Royal Selby, talking with the beautiful Duchess of Monmouth. The duchess's husband, a weary-looking man in his sixties, was also among the guests. It was tea time. The soft light of the large lamp with a lace shade on the table illuminated the fine porcelain and wrought silver of the tea set. The duchess was serving. As her white hands gently moved among the cups, her full red lips were smiling at something Dorian had whispered. Lord Henry, who was reclining in a wicker chair covered with silk, was observing them. Lady Narborough, who was sitting on a peach-colored sofa, was pretending to listen to the duke describing the latest Brazilian insect he had added to his collection. Three young men, dressed in stylish, pretentious tuxedos, were distributing cakes to the ladies. Twelve people had gathered at the mansion that day. More guests were expected to arrive the next day.
es: A week later, Dorian Gray, in the conservatory of Selby Royal, was speaking with the Duchess of Monmouth, a very beautiful woman who, along with her husband, a weary-looking sexagenarian, was among his guests. It was tea time, and on the table, the soft light of the large lace-covered lamp illuminated the delicate porcelain and the embossed silver of the service. The Duchess was playing hostess: her white hands moved harmoniously among the cups, and her sensuous red lips smiled as she listened to the words Dorian whispered in her ear. Lord Henry, reclining in a wicker chair covered with a silk cloth, watched them. Seated on a peach-colored divan, Lady Narborough pretended to listen to the Duke's description of the latest Brazilian beetle he had just added to his collection. Three young men elegantly dressed in tuxedos offered tea pastries to some of the ladies. The guests formed a group of twelve people, and a few more were expected to arrive the next day.

en: “What are you two talking about?” said Lord Henry, strolling over to the table and putting his cup down. “I hope Dorian has told you about my plan for rechristening everything, Gladys. It is a delightful idea.”
vi: "What are you two talking about?" Lord Henry said, strolling leisurely towards the table and setting down his cup. "I hope Dorian has told you about my plan to rename everything, Gladys. It's an interesting idea."
tr: Lord Henry approached the table slowly, putting down his tea cup, and asked, "What are you two talking about?" "I hope Dorian has told you about my plan to rename everything, Gladys. A splendid idea."
es: —What are you talking about? —asked Lord Henry, approaching the table and setting down the cup—. I trust that Dorian has told you about my plan to rename everything, Gladys. It's a delightful idea.

en: “But I don’t want to be rechristened, Harry,” rejoined the duchess, looking up at him with her wonderful eyes. “I am quite satisfied with my own name, and I am sure Mr. Gray should be satisfied with his.”
vi: “But I don't want to be renamed, Harry,” the duchess retorted, looking up at him with her beautiful eyes. “I am very satisfied with my name, and I am sure that Mr. Gray is also satisfied with his.”
tr: The Duchess raised her magnificent eyes to Lord Henry's face and said, "But I don't want my name to be changed, Harry." "I am pleased with my own name. I think Mr. Gray is not complaining about his own name either."
es: —But I don't want to change my name, Harry —replied the duchess, bestowing him with a wonderful look of reproach—. I like the one I have very much, and I am sure that Mr. Gray is also satisfied with his.

en: “My dear Gladys, I would not alter either name for the world. They are both perfect. I was thinking chiefly of flowers. Yesterday I cut an orchid, for my button-hole. It was a marvellous spotted thing, as effective as the seven deadly sins. In a thoughtless moment I asked one of the gardeners what it was called. He told me it was a fine specimen of Robinsoniana, or something dreadful of that kind. It is a sad truth, but we have lost the faculty of giving lovely names to things. Names are everything. I never quarrel with actions. My one quarrel is with words. That is the reason I hate vulgar realism in literature. The man who could call a spade a spade should be compelled to use one. It is the only thing he is fit for.”
vi: “Dear Gladys, I would never change your names. Both names are already perfect. I am mainly thinking about flowers. Yesterday I cut an orchid to wear in my buttonhole. It was a marvelous, mottled thing, as effective as the seven deadly sins. In a moment of carelessness, I asked a gardener what it was called. He told me it was a beautiful specimen of Robinsoniana, or some other dreadful name like that. It is a sad truth, but we have lost the ability to give lovely names to things. Names are everything. I never complain about actions. My only complaint is about words. That is why I hate the vulgar realism in literature. Anyone who can call a spade a spade should be made to use it. It is the only thing suitable for him.”
tr: "Dear Gladys, I wouldn't change either your name or his, even if they gave me the world. Both are perfect. I was mostly thinking about the flowers. Yesterday, I cut an orchid to wear on my lapel. It was as striking as the seven deadly sins, speckled, a wonderful thing. In my foolishness, I asked one of the gardeners for the name of the flower. He said something awful like a very rare Robinsoniana. A sad truth, but we have lost the ability to give beautiful names to things. Yet, a name means everything. I never quarrel with actions. The only thing I quarrel with are names. That's why I despise crude realism in literature."
es: —My dear Gladys, I wouldn't change the name of either of you for anything in the world. Both are perfect. I was mostly thinking about the flowers. Yesterday I cut an orchid to put in my buttonhole. It was a small speckled marvel, as effective as the seven deadly sins. In a moment of unconsciousness, I asked one of the gardeners what it was called. He told me it was a beautiful specimen of Robinsoniana or some other similar horror. It's a sad truth, but we have lost the ability to give pleasant names to things. Names are everything. I never complain about actions, only about words. That is why I abhor vulgar realism in literature. The person capable of calling a spade a spade should be forced to use it. It's the only thing it's good for.

en: “Then what should we call you, Harry?” she asked.
vi: "So what should we call you, Harry?" she asked.
tr: The Duchess asked, "So what shall we call you, Harry?"
es: —And you, Harry, what should we call you? —asked the duchess.

en: “His name is Prince Paradox,” said Dorian.
vi: “His name is the Contrary Prince,” Dorian said.
tr: Dorian said, "His name is Prince Dilemma."
es: —His name is Prince Paradox —said Dorian. —There is no doubt that it is him!

en: “I recognize him in a flash,” exclaimed the duchess.
vi: “I recognized him immediately,” the duchess exclaimed.
tr: The Duchess clapped her hands and exclaimed, "I recognized it instantly!"
es: —exclaimed the duchess.

en: “I won’t hear of it,” laughed Lord Henry, sinking into a chair. “From a label there is no escape! I refuse the title.”
vi: “I will not agree,” Lord Henry laughed, lowering himself into the chair. “Once the label is attached, it cannot be escaped! I refuse this title.”
tr: Lord Henry, "Don't you dare!" he said, laughing as he sank into a chair. "Once a person is branded, there is no escape! I reject this notion."
es: —By no means —laughed Lord Henry, dropping into a chair—. There is no way to escape a label! I reject that title.

en: “Royalties may not abdicate,” fell as a warning from pretty lips.
vi: “Princes cannot abdicate,” slipped out as a warning from her lovely lips.
tr: A warning fell from the Duchess's beautiful lips, "The nobles are not allowed to renounce their titles."
es: —Royalty must not abdicate —was the warning issued by some beautiful lips.

en: “You wish me to defend my throne, then?”
vi: “So you want me to keep the throne, don't you?”
tr: "So, you want me to defend my throne?""
es: —Do you wish, then, that I defend my throne?

en: “Yes.”
vi: “Yes.”
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “I give the truths of to-morrow.”
vi: “I will reveal the truths of tomorrow.”
tr: “I will inform the truths of tomorrow.”
es: —I offer the truths of tomorrow.

en: “I prefer the mistakes of to-day,” she answered.
vi: “I prefer today's mistakes,” she replied.
tr: The young woman replied, "I prefer today's mistakes."
es: —I prefer today's mistakes —she replied.

en: “You disarm me, Gladys,” he cried, catching the wilfulness of her mood.
vi: “You've stripped me of all my weapons, Gladys,” he exclaimed, catching on to her stubborn temperament.
tr: Lord Henry, matching her capricious mood, said, "You are disarming me, Gladys!"
es: —You disarm me, Gladys —exclaimed Lord Henry, noticing the stubbornness of her attitude.

en: “Of your shield, Harry, not of your spear.”
vi: "Take off the shield, Harry: not the spear.""
tr: “I took his shield, Harry, not his spear.”
es: —Of your shield, but not of your spear.

en: “I never tilt against beauty,” he said, with a wave of his hand.
vi: “I never poke a spear at Beauty,” he said, with a wave of his hand.
tr: Lord Henry, waving his hand slightly, said, "I never argue with beauty."
es: —I never attack beauty —he said, making a gesture of submission with his hand.

en: “That is your error, Harry, believe me. You value beauty far too much.”
vi: “It is your fault, Harry, believe me. You overestimate beauty too much.”
tr: “That's your mistake too, believe me, Harry. You place too much value on beauty.”
es: —That is your mistake, Harry, believe me. You value beauty too much.

en: “How can you say that? I admit that I think that it is better to be beautiful than to be good. But on the other hand, no one is more ready than I am to acknowledge that it is better to be good than to be ugly.”
vi: “How can you say that? I admit that I think being beautiful is better than being obedient. But on the other hand, no one is more willing to acknowledge than I am that being obedient is better than being ugly.”
tr: "How can you say such a thing? Although I admit, I am of the opinion that being beautiful is better than being virtuous. On the other hand, I am the first to accept that being virtuous is preferable to being ugly."
es: —How can you say that? I recognize that, in my opinion, it is better to be beautiful than good. But, on the other hand, no one is more willing than I am to admit that it is better to be good than ugly.

en: “Ugliness is one of the seven deadly sins, then?” cried the duchess. “What becomes of your simile about the orchid?”
vi: “So, is ugliness one of the seven deadly sins?” the duchess exclaimed. “What happened to your smile about the orchids?”
tr: The Duchess asked, "Do you think ugliness is one of the seven deadly sins?" "Then what about your metaphor regarding the orchid?"
es: —In that case, is ugliness one of the seven deadly sins? —exclaimed the duchess—. And what about your metaphor about the orchid?

en: “Ugliness is one of the seven deadly virtues, Gladys. You, as a good Tory, must not underrate them. Beer, the Bible, and the seven deadly virtues have made our England what she is.”
vi: “Ugliness is one of the seven deadly virtues, Gladys. You, as a loyal member of the Conservative party, should not underestimate them. Beer, the Bible, and the seven deadly virtues have made our England what it is.”
tr: “Ugliness is one of the seven deadly virtues, Gladys. As a loyal member of the Conservative Party, you must not underestimate these virtues. It is beer, the Bible, and the seven deadly virtues that have brought our England to its current state.”
es: —Ugliness is one of the seven capital virtues, Gladys. You, as a good Tory, should not underestimate them. Beer, the Bible, and the seven capital virtues have made our England what it is.

en: “You don’t like your country, then?” she asked.
vi: “So, you don't like our country?” she asked.
tr: The Duchess asked, "So, you don't love your country very much?"
es: —Does that mean you don't like your country? —asked the duchess.

en: “I live in it.”
vi: “I live in it.”
tr: “I live in my homeland.”
es: —I live in it.

en: “That you may censure it the better.”
vi: "So that he can criticize it better."
tr: “It would be better if you criticized.”
es: —To be able to censor it better.

en: “Would you have me take the verdict of Europe on it?” he inquired.
vi: "Do you really want me to accept Europe's opinion about it?" he asked back.
tr: Lord Henry, "Would you like me to take Europe's view on my homeland?" he asked.
es: "Do you prefer that I accept Europe's verdict?" Lord Henry wanted to know.

en: “What do they say of us?”
vi: “What are they saying about me?”
tr: “What are they saying about us?”
es: —What do they say about us?

en: “That Tartuffe has emigrated to England and opened a shop.”
vi: “It was Hypocrisy who emigrated to England and opened a shop.”
tr: "They say Tartuffe has settled in England and is running a shop."
es: —That Tartuffe has emigrated to England and opened a shop.

en: “Is that yours, Harry?”
vi: “Your story, Harry?”
tr: "Is this your invention, Harry?"
es: —Is that your own doing, Harry?

en: “I give it to you.”
vi: “I give it to you.”
tr: “I present it to you.”
es: —I give it to you as a gift.

en: “I could not use it. It is too true.”
vi: “I can't use it. It's too accurate.”
tr: “I can't use it! It's too accurate.”
es: —I couldn't use it. It's too true.

en: “You need not be afraid. Our countrymen never recognize a description.”
vi: "You don't have to worry." "My compatriots will never recognize any description."
tr: “There is no reason for worry. Our citizens cannot infer anything from the definitions.”
es: —You have no reason to be scared. Our compatriots never recognize a description.

en: “They are practical.”
vi: “They are practical.”
tr: “They are also imitators of him.”
es: —They are practical people.

en: “They are more cunning than practical. When they make up their ledger, they balance stupidity by wealth, and vice by hypocrisy.”
vi: “They are more cunning than practical. When they create a ledger, they balance stupidity with wealth, and depravity with hypocrisy.”
tr: “They are more cunning than practical. While keeping their account books, they balance foolishness with wealth, and their bad habits with hypocrisy.”
es: —They are more cunning than practical. When it comes to accounting, they compensate stupidity with wealth and vice with hypocrisy.

en: “Still, we have done great things.”
vi: “However, I have done many great things.”
tr: “We have accomplished great things together.”
es: —We have done great things, anyway.

en: “Great things have been thrust on us, Gladys.”
vi: "Great things have been impressed upon us, Gladys."
tr: “Big things were forced upon us, Gladys.”
es: —Great things have come upon us, Gladys.

en: “We have carried their burden.”
vi: “We have borne their burdens.”
tr: “But we carried their loads.”
es: —We have carried their weight.

en: “Only as far as the Stock Exchange.”
vi: “Only as far as the stock exchange.”
tr: “Only in the stock market.”
es: —Just to the Stock Exchange building.

en: She shook her head. “I believe in the race,” she cried.
vi: She shook her head. “I believe in the race,” she shouted.
tr: The Duchess nodded, "I have faith in my race," she said.
es: The duchess moved her head. —I believe in the race —he exclaimed.

en: “It represents the survival of the pushing.”
vi: “It symbolizes the remnants of self-assertion.”
tr: “However, it is the picture of the torn ones that can stand, our race.”
es: —The race represents the triumph of the social climbers.

en: “It has development.”
vi: “It has development.”
tr: “It has shown improvement.”
es: —That means progress.

en: “Decay fascinates me more.”
vi: “The decline fascinates me more.”
tr: “Corruption concerns me more.”
es: —Decadence fascinates me more.

en: “What of art?” she asked.
vi: “What about Art?” she asked.
tr: The Duchess asked, "And what do you say about art?"
es: —And where do you leave art? —she asked.

en: “It is a malady.”
vi: “It is a disease.”
tr: “It is a disease.”
es: —It's an illness.

en: “Love?”
vi: “Love?”
tr: “Love?”
es: —Love?

en: “An illusion.”
vi: “An illusion.”
tr: “Illusion.”
es: —An illusion.

en: “Religion?”
vi: “Religion?”
tr: “Day?”
es: —Religion?

en: “The fashionable substitute for belief.”
vi: "The fashionable substitute for Faith."
tr: “The fashion of the day that replaces faith.”
es: —The elegant substitute for faith.

en: “You are a sceptic.”
vi: “You are a skeptic.”
tr: “You are skeptical.”
es: —You are a skeptic.

en: “Never! Scepticism is the beginning of faith.”
vi: "Not at all! Skepticism is the root of faith."
tr: “Not at all. Skepticism is the beginning of faith.”
es: —Never! Skepticism is the beginning of faith.

en: “What are you?”
vi: "Who are you?"
tr: “What are you then?”
es: —What are you then?

en: “To define is to limit.”
vi: "To define is to limit.""
tr: “To define is to limit.”
es: —To define is to limit.

en: “Give me a clue.”
vi: "Give me a lead."
tr: “Give me a clue.”
es: —Give me a hint.

en: “Threads snap. You would lose your way in the labyrinth.”
vi: “Just broken. You will get lost in the maze.”
tr: “A string can break. You can get lost in the labyrinth.”
es: —The threads break. You would get lost in the labyrinth.

en: “You bewilder me. Let us talk of some one else.”
vi: "You make me confused. Let's talk about someone else."
tr: "You astonish me. Let's talk about someone else."
es: —You baffle me. Let's talk about other people.

en: “Our host is a delightful topic. Years ago he was christened Prince Charming.”
vi: “Our host is an interesting subject. Many years ago, he was named Prince Charming.”
tr: “Our host is a delightful subject. Years ago, they named him Sweet Prince.”
es: —Our host is an unbeatable topic. Years ago, they gave him the name Prince Charming.

en: “Ah! don’t remind me of that,” cried Dorian Gray.
vi: “Oh! Don't remind me of that,” Dorian Gray exclaimed.
tr: Dorian shouted, "Oh, don't remind me of that!"
es: —Ah! Don't remind me —exclaimed Dorian Gray.

en: “Our host is rather horrid this evening,” answered the duchess, colouring. “I believe he thinks that Monmouth married me on purely scientific principles as the best specimen he could find of a modern butterfly.”
vi: “Our host this afternoon was quite unpleasant,” the duchess replied, blushing. “I believe he thinks that Monmouth married me based on purely scientific principles, like the best specimen he could find of a modern butterfly.”
tr: The Duchess blushingly said, "Our host is a bit unpleasant tonight." "I think he believes Monmouth married me for purely scientific reasons; because he considers me the best example of contemporary butterflies."
es: —Our host is not very kind today -replied the duchess, blushing—. In my opinion, he believes that Monmouth married me for purely scientific reasons, for being the best available specimen of the modern butterfly.

en: “Well, I hope he won’t stick pins into you, Duchess,” laughed Dorian.
vi: "Is that so? I hope he doesn't stick a pin in you, Duchess," Dorian laughed.
tr: Dorian laughed, "Well, then I hope she doesn't prick you with a needle, Duchess."
es: "I hope you are not keeping her by sticking pins into her, Duchess," laughed Dorian.

en: “Oh! my maid does that already, Mr. Gray, when she is annoyed with me.”
vi: "Oh! My servant did that, Mr. Gray, when he was angry with me."
tr: Dorian laughed, "Well, then I hope she doesn't prick you with a needle, Duchess." "Oh dear, my room maid often does that when she is upset with me."
es: "I hope you are not keeping her by sticking pins into her, Duchess," laughed Dorian. —My maid already does that, Mr. Gray, when she's angry with me.

en: “And what does she get annoyed with you about, Duchess?”
vi: "So why is he angry with you, Duchess?"
tr: “Well, why is she upset with you, Duchess?”
es: —And, what reasons does she have to be angry with you, Duchess?

en: “For the most trivial things, Mr. Gray, I assure you. Usually because I come in at ten minutes to nine and tell her that I must be dressed by half-past eight.”
vi: "For the most trivial matters, Mr. Gray, I assure you. Usually because I arrive at ten to nine and tell him that I must be dressed by half past eight."
tr: “Believe me, Mr. Gray, it's often over the most trivial things. When I call him at ten to nine and tell him that I should have been dressed and ready by half-past eight, he gets upset, most of the time.”
es: —The most trivial things, Mr. Gray, I assure you. Usually, I show up at ten to nine and tell him that I must be dressed by half-past eight.

en: “How unreasonable of her! You should give her warning.”
vi: “How unreasonable it is! You have to warn her.”
tr: “What an inconsistent girl! You should let her pass.”
es: —How unreasonable of her! You should fire her.

en: “I daren’t, Mr. Gray. Why, she invents hats for me. You remember the one I wore at Lady Hilstone’s garden-party? You don’t, but it is nice of you to pretend that you do. Well, she made it out of nothing. All good hats are made out of nothing.”
vi: “I don't dare, Mr. Gray. Because, she makes hats for me. Do you remember the one I wore at Mrs. Hilstone's garden party? You don't remember, but you are so kind to pretend that you do. Well, she made that hat out of nothing. All beautiful hats are made out of nothing.”
tr: “I can't risk it, Mr. Gray. This girl invents hats for me. Do you remember the hat I wore at Lady Hilstone's garden party? You don't, but you're pretending to remember because you're so sweet. Anyway, my maid conjured that hat out of nothing. All beautiful hats are conjured out of nothing.”
es: —I don't dare, Mr. Gray. She invents hats for me, to say the least. Do you remember the one I wore to Lady Hilstone's outdoor party? Of course you don't, but you're very kind to pretend otherwise. Well, she made it for me out of nothing. All good hats are made out of nothing.

en: “Like all good reputations, Gladys,” interrupted Lord Henry. “Every effect that one produces gives one an enemy. To be popular one must be a mediocrity.”
vi: “Like all reputations, Gladys,” Lord Henry interrupted. “Every impression we create brings us an enemy. To be liked by everyone, we must be a mediocre person.”
tr: “Like the fame of beautiful people, Gladys!” Lord Henry interjected. “Every effect a person creates earns them an enemy. To be popular in society, one must be mediocre.”
es: —Like all good reputations, Gladys —interrupted Lord Henry—. Every effect one produces creates an enemy. To achieve popularity, one must be mediocre.

en: “Not with women,” said the duchess, shaking her head; “and women rule the world. I assure you we can’t bear mediocrities. We women, as some one says, love with our ears, just as you men love with your eyes, if you ever love at all.”
vi: “Not with women,” the duchess said, shaking her head; “and women rule the world. I assure you that we cannot stand ordinary people. We women, as someone said, love with our ears, just as you men love with your eyes, that is, assuming you ever know how to love at all.”
tr: The Duchess shook her head, "Not at all for women," she said. "It is women who rule the world. Believe me, we hate mediocre things. As someone once said, we women love with our ears, just as you men love with your eyes, that is, if you love at all."
es: —Not in the case of women —said the duchess, shaking her head—; and women rule the world. I assure you they do not tolerate mediocrity. We women, as someone says, love with our ears, just as you men love with your eyes, if you ever love at all.

en: “It seems to me that we never do anything else,” murmured Dorian.
vi: “It seems like we never do anything else, do we?” Dorian whispered.
tr: “It seems to me that we do nothing but love,” Dorian murmured.
es: —I would say we hardly do anything else —murmured Dorian.

en: “Ah! then, you never really love, Mr. Gray,” answered the duchess with mock sadness.
vi: "Oh! Then you have never truly loved, Mr. Gray," the duchess replied, appearing sorrowful.
tr: The Duchess said with a feigned sadness, "Oh! So you don't actually love it at all, Mr. Gray!"
es: —I would say we hardly do anything else —murmured Dorian. —In that case, Mr. Gray, you never truly love —said the duchess with feigned sadness.

en: “My dear Gladys!” cried Lord Henry. “How can you say that? Romance lives by repetition, and repetition converts an appetite into an art. Besides, each time that one loves is the only time one has ever loved. Difference of object does not alter singleness of passion. It merely intensifies it. We can have in life but one great experience at best, and the secret of life is to reproduce that experience as often as possible.”
vi: “My dear Gladys!” Lord Henry exclaimed. “How can you say that? Love lives on repetition, and repetition transforms desire into art. Moreover, each time we love is the only time we have ever loved. The difference in the object does not change the uniqueness of the passion. It only deepens it. We are fortunate if we can have one great experience in life, and the secret of life is to recreate that experience as often as possible.”
tr: Lord Henry, "Dear Gladys, how can you say that?" he exclaimed. "What keeps romance alive is repetition; repetition turns an appetite into art. Besides, every love is a unique love. Changing goals does not undermine the singularity of passion! It only serves to intensify it. In life, at most, we can experience one sublime moment; the secret of life is to multiply this experience as much as possible."
es: —My dear Gladys! —exclaimed Lord Henry—. How can you say that? Romantic feeling is nourished by repetition, and repetition turns an appetite into art. Moreover, every time one loves is the only time one has ever loved. The diversity of the object does not alter the uniqueness of the passion. It only intensifies it. At best, we can only have one experience in life, and the secret is to reproduce it as frequently as possible.

en: “Even when one has been wounded by it, Harry?” asked the duchess after a pause.
vi: "Even if it hurts me, Harry?" the duchess asked, after a moment of hesitation.
tr: After a pause, the duchess asked, "Even if it has hurt a person, is that so, Harry?"
es: —Even when one has been hurt by it, Harry? —asked the Duchess after a pause.

en: “Especially when one has been wounded by it,” answered Lord Henry.
vi: “Especially when it has hurt us,” Lord Henry replied.
tr: Lord Henry, "Especially then," he replied.

en: The duchess turned and looked at Dorian Gray with a curious expression in her eyes. “What do you say to that, Mr. Gray?” she inquired.

es: The duchess turned to look at Dorian Gray with a curious expression in her eyes. —What do you say to that, Mr. Gray? —he wanted to know.

en: Dorian hesitated for a moment. Then he threw his head back and laughed. “I always agree with Harry, Duchess.”

en: “I have never searched for happiness. Who wants happiness? I have searched for pleasure.”

en: The duchess sighed. “I am searching for peace,” she said, “and if I don’t go and dress, I shall have none this evening.”
vi: The Duchess sighed. “I seek peace,” she said, “and if I don't go change my clothes, I won't have any this afternoon.”
tr: The Duchess sighed. “I am looking for peace,” she said. “If I don't go and get ready right now, I won't find any peace tonight.”
es: The duchess sighed. —My goal is peace —he said—. And if I don't leave and get dressed, I won't have any tonight.

en: “Let me get you some orchids, Duchess,” cried Dorian, starting to his feet and walking down the conservatory.
vi: "Let me get you some orchids, Duchess," Dorian exclaimed, jumping up, and heading down to the greenhouse.

es: —Allow me to bring you some orchids, Duchess —exclaimed Dorian, standing up and moving towards the back of the greenhouse.

en: “You are flirting disgracefully with him,” said Lord Henry to his cousin. “You had better take care. He is very fascinating.”
vi: "She flirts with him so shamelessly," Lord Henry said to his cousin. "You should be more careful. He is very charming."
tr: Lord Henry said to his cousin, "You are flirting with him shamelessly." "You better watch your step. He is a charming man."
es: —You flirt outrageously with him —Lord Henry said to his cousin—. I advise you to be cautious. He is a fascinating creature.

en: “If he were not, there would be no battle.”
vi: "If he wasn't like that, he wouldn't have had to fight."
tr: "If it weren't like that, there wouldn't be any struggle either."
es: —If it weren't so, there wouldn't be a struggle.

en: “Greek meets Greek, then?”
vi: “So, it's Greeks fighting Greeks, huh?”
tr: “Greek against Greek, is that so?”
es: —Is it then a Greek against another?

en: “I am on the side of the Trojans. They fought for a woman.”

en: “They were defeated.”

en: “There are worse things than capture,” she answered.

en: “You gallop with a loose rein.”

en: “Pace gives life,” was the riposte.
vi: "The trot brings life," was the reply.
tr: The Duchess retorted, "Speed creates life."
es: —Speed is life —was his response.

en: “I shall write it in my diary to-night.”

es: —I will write it in my diary tonight.

en: “What?”
vi: "What?"
tr: "What?"
es: —What will you write down?

en: “That a burnt child loves the fire.”
vi: “As a child who was burned but still loves fire.”
tr: “The child whose hand is burned by fire loves the fire.”
es: —That a child with burns likes fire.

en: “I am not even singed. My wings are untouched.”
vi: “I wasn't even singed. My wings are intact.”
tr: "The fire didn't touch me! My wings are perfectly intact."
es: —I haven't even singed myself. My wings are intact.

en: “You use them for everything, except flight.”
vi: “She uses it for everything, except flying.”
tr: “You use them for every purpose except flying.”
es: —You use them for everything except flying.

en: “Courage has passed from men to women. It is a new experience for us.”
vi: "Courage has shifted from men to women. This is a new experience for us."
tr: "Courage has passed from men to women. This is something entirely new for us."
es: —Courage has passed from men to women. It is a new experience for us.

en: “You have a rival.”
vi: "You have a rival."
tr: "You have a rival."
es: —You have a rival.

en: “Who?”

tr: “Kim?”
es: —Who?

en: He laughed. “Lady Narborough,” he whispered. “She perfectly adores him.”
vi: He smiled. “Mrs. Narborough,” he whispered. “She is extremely fond of him.”
tr: Lord Henry laughed. “Lady Narborough,” he whispered. “She practically worships Dorian.”
es: His cousin burst out laughing. —Lady Narborough—he whispered—. She adores him.

en: “You fill me with apprehension. The appeal to antiquity is fatal to us who are romanticists.”
vi: "You scare me. The attraction to antiques is very harmful to romantics like us."
tr: "You instill fear in me! For romantics like us, the love for antiques is deadly."
es: —You fill me with apprehension. We romantics cannot compete with the allure of Antiquity.

en: “Romanticists! You have all the methods of science.”
vi: “Romantics! You have all the scientific methods.”
tr: “Did you say romantic? My dear, you are equipped with every method of the natural sciences.”
es: —Romantics! You employ all the methods of science.

en: “Men have educated us.”

en: “But not explained you.”

es: —But they haven't explained it to you.

en: “Describe us as a sex,” was her challenge.
vi: “Describe us as a gender, then,” was her challenge.
tr: The young woman defiantly said, "Go ahead, define us as a whole!"
es: —Describe women —was his challenge.

en: “Sphinxes without secrets.”
vi: “The Sphynx cats have no secrets.”
tr: “You are Sphinxes without riddles.”
es: Sphinxes without secrets.

en: She looked at him, smiling. “How long Mr. Gray is!” she said. “Let us go and help him. I have not yet told him the colour of my frock.”
vi: She looked at him, smiling. "Mr. Gray, it's been so long!" she said. "Let's go help him." "I still haven't told him the color of my dress."
tr: The Duchess looked at him with a smile. "Mr. Gray is taking forever! Let's go and help him. I haven't even told him the color of my dress yet."
es: She looked at him, smiling. —How long Mr. Gray is taking! —he said—. Let's go help him. I haven't told him the color of my dress.

en: “Ah! you must suit your frock to his flowers, Gladys.”
vi: "Ah! You have to choose a dress that matches his flowers, Gladys."
tr: "You should match the color of your dress to the flowers he gave you, Gladys."
es: —Ah! You will have to choose the dress according to its flowers, Gladys.

en: “That would be a premature surrender.”
vi: “That would be too early of a surrender.”

en: “Romantic art begins with its climax.”
vi: “Romantic art begins with the climax.”

en: “I must keep an opportunity for retreat.”
vi: “I must keep an opportunity to retreat.”

en: “In the Parthian manner?”
vi: "In the Parthian style?"

es: —In the manner of the Parthians?

en: “They found safety in the desert. I could not do that.”
vi: “They feel safe in the desert. I cannot do that.”
tr: “They found safety in the desert. I can't do this.”
es: —They found salvation in the desert. That is beyond my reach.

en: “Women are not always allowed a choice,” he answered, but hardly had he finished the sentence before from the far end of the conservatory came a stifled groan, followed by the dull sound of a heavy fall. Everybody started up. The duchess stood motionless in horror. And with fear in his eyes, Lord Henry rushed through the flapping palms to find Dorian Gray lying face downwards on the tiled floor in a deathlike swoon.
vi: “Women are not always allowed to choose,” he replied, but just as he finished his sentence, a stifled groan echoed from the end of the greenhouse, followed by the dull thud of a heavy fall. Everyone sprang up. The duchess stood motionless in fear. And with worry in his eyes, Lord Henry rushed through the swaying palm leaves to find Dorian Gray lying face down on the tiled floor in a deathlike faint.
tr: Lord Henry replied, "Women are not always given a choice," but before he could finish his sentence, a muffled groan was heard from the other end of the conservatory, followed immediately by a hollow thud indicating that a heavy object had fallen to the ground. Everyone had jumped to their feet. The Duchess was frozen in horror. Lord Henry, his eyes filled with fear, ran through the rustling broad leaves of the palm trees. He found Dorian Gray lying face down on the brick floor, unconscious as if dead.
es: —Women are not always allowed to choose —replied Lord Henry. But just as the sentence was finished, from the farthest end of the greenhouse came a muffled groan, followed by the dull sound of a fall. Everyone was startled. The duchess remained motionless, horrified. And Lord Henry, fear in his eyes, ran through the swaying palm trees until he found Dorian Gray lying face down on the tiled floor, a victim of a fainting spell that resembled death.

en: He was carried at once into the blue drawing-room and laid upon one of the sofas. After a short time, he came to himself and looked round with a dazed expression.
vi: You were immediately carried into the blue living room and placed on a sofa. After a short while, you regained consciousness and looked around with a bewildered expression.
tr: They immediately carried Dorian to the blue salon and laid him on one of the couches. A little later, the young man came to his senses and looked around dazedly.
es: He was instantly transported to the blue room, placing him on one of the sofas. Shortly after, he regained consciousness and looked around with a bewildered air.

en: “What has happened?” he asked. “Oh! I remember. Am I safe here, Harry?” He began to tremble.
vi: “What happened?” he asked. “Oh! I remember now. Am I safe here, Harry?” He began to tremble.
tr: “What happened?” he asked. “Oh, I know. Harry, am I safe here?” She had started trembling.
es: —What has happened? —he asked—. Ah! Now I remember. Am I safe here, Harry? —and he began to tremble.

en: “My dear Dorian,” answered Lord Henry, “you merely fainted. That was all. You must have overtired yourself. You had better not come down to dinner. I will take your place.”
vi: “My dear Dorian,” Lord Henry replied, “you just fainted. That's all. You must have overworked yourself. It would be better if you didn't come down for dinner. I'll take your place.”
tr: Lord Henry replied, "Dear Dorian, you just fainted, that's all." "You must have overexerted yourself. It would be better if you didn't come to dinner. I'll take your place."
es: —My dear Dorian —responded Lord Henry—, you have merely fainted. That is all. You must have overexerted yourself. It would be better if you didn't come down for dinner. I will take your place.

en: “No, I will come down,” he said, struggling to his feet. “I would rather come down. I must not be alone.”
vi: "No, I will go downstairs," he said, struggling to stand up. "I prefer going downstairs. I shouldn't be alone."
tr: Dorian, "No, I will come," he said, struggling to his feet. "It would be better if I came. I shouldn't be alone."
es: —No; I will go down —he said, standing up with some effort—. I prefer to do it. I must not stay alone.

en: He went to his room and dressed. There was a wild recklessness of gaiety in his manner as he sat at table, but now and then a thrill of terror ran through him when he remembered that, pressed against the window of the conservatory, like a white handkerchief, he had seen the face of James Vane watching him.
vi: You went into your room and changed clothes. There was a careless abandon in your cheerful demeanor as you sat by the table, but occasionally a shudder of fear ran through you when you remembered that, pressed against the greenhouse window like a white handkerchief, you had seen James Vane's face looking at you.
tr: He went up to his room and changed his clothes. When he sat down at the table, he was in an unrestrained, boundless joy. However, every now and then, the thought of having seen James Vane’s face, pressed against the greenhouse window like a white handkerchief, made him shudder with terror from head to toe.
es: He went to his room to get dressed. When he sat down at the table, there was a strange reckless joy in his demeanor, although, from time to time, a shudder ran through him as he remembered that, crushed like a white handkerchief against the glass of the greenhouse, he had seen the face of James Vane watching him.

en: CHAPTER XVIII.
vi: Chapter 18
tr: Eighteenth chapter
es: Chapter 18

en: The next day he did not leave the house, and, indeed, spent most of the time in his own room, sick with a wild terror of dying, and yet indifferent to life itself. The consciousness of being hunted, snared, tracked down, had begun to dominate him. If the tapestry did but tremble in the wind, he shook. The dead leaves that were blown against the leaded panes seemed to him like his own wasted resolutions and wild regrets. When he closed his eyes, he saw again the sailor’s face peering through the mist-stained glass, and horror seemed once more to lay its hand upon his heart.
vi: The next day, he did not leave the house, and, indeed, spent most of the time in his own room, falling ill from the fear of going mad, yet indifferent to life itself. The awareness of being hunted, trapped, watched, and caught began to dominate him. Whenever the embroidered carpet fluttered in the wind, he would tremble. He felt as if the dead leaves blown against the leaded glass panes were like his wasted decisions and his wild regrets. When he closed his eyes, he saw the face of that sailor peering through the misted glass, and the horror seemed to lay its hand on his heart once more.
tr: The next day, Dorian did not leave the house; or rather, he spent most of his time in his own room. Fallen ill with a frantic fear of death, he was still indifferent to life. The awareness of being hunted, trapped, and about to be caught had begun to take hold of his consciousness. He would shudder if the wind made a curtain flutter. The dry leaves hitting the leaded windows were like his own wasted oaths, his mad regrets. Whenever he closed his eyes, he saw the sailor looking at him through that misted glass, and terror gripped his heart.
es: The next day, Dorian Gray did not leave the house and, in fact, spent most of the time in his room, gripped by a mad fear of dying and, yet, indifferent to life. The conviction of being pursued, of traps being set for him, of being cornered, began to dominate him. If the wind slightly stirred the tapestries, he would start to tremble. The dry leaves thrown against the glass panes seemed to him the image of his abandoned resolutions and his vain regrets. When he closed his eyes, he saw again the face of the sailor looking through the fogged glass, and he believed he felt once more how horror gripped his heart.

en: But perhaps it had been only his fancy that had called vengeance out of the night and set the hideous shapes of punishment before him. Actual life was chaos, but there was something terribly logical in the imagination. It was the imagination that set remorse to dog the feet of sin. It was the imagination that made each crime bear its misshapen brood. In the common world of fact the wicked were not punished, nor the good rewarded. Success was given to the strong, failure thrust upon the weak. That was all. Besides, had any stranger been prowling round the house, he would have been seen by the servants or the keepers. Had any foot-marks been found on the flower-beds, the gardeners would have reported it. Yes, it had been merely fancy. Sibyl Vane’s brother had not come back to kill him. He had sailed away in his ship to founder in some winter sea. From him, at any rate, he was safe. Why, the man did not know who he was, could not know who he was. The mask of youth had saved him.
vi: But, perhaps it is only your imagination that calls forth vengeance from the night, and places the grotesque form of punishment before you. Real life is indeed chaotic, but there is also a terrifying logic in imagination. It is imagination that makes remorse cling to the heels of guilt. It is imagination that makes every crime carry its own deformed offspring. In the ordinary real world, evil is not punished, nor is good rewarded. Success is offered to the strong, failure is stamped on the weak. That's all. Moreover, if any stranger were lurking around the house, he would likely be caught by the servants or guards. If any footprints were found in the flower beds, the gardeners would have reported it. Yes: it is only imagination. Sibyl Vane's brother did not come back to kill you. He boarded a ship to some distant winter sea. In any case, you are certainly not under attack by him. Why, someone who doesn't know who you are cannot know who you are. The mask of youth has saved you.
tr: But perhaps it was only his own imagination that pulled this image of revenge out of the darkness of the night and set before him scenes of terrible punishment. Life itself was nothing but chaos, yet the thing called imagination had a tremendous logic. It was the imagination that sent remorse to trace the mark of sin. It was the imagination that gave birth to twisted offspring for every crime. In the world of everyday phenomena, neither the wicked were punished nor the good rewarded. Success was given to the strong, and defeat was handed to the weak. That was all. Besides, if a stranger had been wandering around the house, the servants and guards would have seen him. If footprints were found in the flower beds, the gardeners would have reported it. Yes, yes, it was all just imagination. Otherwise, Sibly Vane's brother could not have come back to kill him. He had boarded his ship and sailed away, now who knows in which winter seas he was rocking. At least Dorian had no fear from him. After all, the man did not know who he was! He could not have known. The mask of youth had saved him.
es: Although perhaps only his imagination had conjured the vengeance of the night, placing before his eyes the horrible forms of punishment. Real life was chaotic, but imagination followed a terrible logic. Imagination sent remorse in the footsteps of sin. Imagination made each crime conceive its monstrous progeny. In the ordinary universe of facts, the wicked were not punished, nor were the good rewarded. Success belonged to the strong and failure befell the weak. That was all. Moreover, if some stranger had been lurking around the house, the servants or the guards would have seen him. If footprints had been found in the flowerbeds, the gardeners would have reported it. Undoubtedly, it was only his imagination. Sibyl Vane's brother had not come to Selby Royal to kill him. He had set sail on his ship only to finally sink in some winter sea. From him, at least, he had nothing to fear. That poor wretch didn't even know who he was, couldn't know who he was. The mask of youth had saved him.

en: And yet if it had been merely an illusion, how terrible it was to think that conscience could raise such fearful phantoms, and give them visible form, and make them move before one! What sort of life would his be if, day and night, shadows of his crime were to peer at him from silent corners, to mock him from secret places, to whisper in his ear as he sat at the feast, to wake him with icy fingers as he lay asleep! As the thought crept through his brain, he grew pale with terror, and the air seemed to him to have become suddenly colder. Oh! in what a wild hour of madness he had killed his friend! How ghastly the mere memory of the scene! He saw it all again. Each hideous detail came back to him with added horror. Out of the black cave of time, terrible and swathed in scarlet, rose the image of his sin. When Lord Henry came in at six o’clock, he found him crying as one whose heart will break.
vi: However, if it is just an illusion, it is truly terrifying to think that the conscience could conjure up such dreadful phantoms, give them a clear form, and make them move before one's eyes! What kind of life would you have if day and night, your guilty shadows kept peering at you from silent corners, mocking you from secret places, whispering in your ear while you sit at feasts, waking you with icy fingers as you sleep! As that thought slithered through your mind, you turned pale with fear, and it seemed as if the air suddenly grew colder. Oh! How you killed your friend in a moment of madness! Even the memory of that scene is horrifying! You see it all again. Every gruesome detail returns to you with added horror. Out of the dark cave of Time, terrible and wrapped in bright red bandages, your sinful image rises. When Lord Henry arrived at six o'clock, he found you crying like someone with a heart about to break.
tr: On the other hand, if what he saw was merely an illusion, how terrifying it was: to think that the conscience could create such chilling phantoms, give them visible forms, and make them move before one's eyes! What kind of life would his be, if the shadows of the crimes he committed were to watch him from silent corners day and night, stick their tongues out at him from hidden places, whisper in his ear at banquet tables, and wake him from his sleep with icy fingers! As these thoughts passed through his mind, Dorian turned pale with fear, feeling as if the air had suddenly grown cold. My God! How he had killed his friend in a moment of wild madness! Even the mere memory of this scene was so dreadful! Dorian felt as if he were seeing everything anew. Every detail, in all its ugliness, appeared before his eyes more terrifying than ever before. From the dark cave of time, the image of his horrifying sin, cloaked in crimson, rose up. When Lord Henry came to his room at six o'clock, he found Dorian crying as if he would never be consoled again.
es: But if it had only been an illusion, how terrible to think that the mind could spawn such fearful phantoms, giving them visible form, making them move like real beings! What kind of life would his be if, day and night, shadows of his crime watched him from silent corners, mocked him from secret places, whispered in his ear in the midst of a banquet, woke him with icy fingers while he slept? As this idea presented itself in his brain, he turned pale with terror and had the impression that the air had suddenly cooled. In what dreadful hour of madness had he murdered his friend! How atrocious the mere memory of the scene! He saw it all again. Every hateful detail appeared to him with renewed horror. From the black cavern of time, terrible and wrapped in scarlet, rose the image of his sin. When Lord Henry arrived at six o'clock sharp, he found him crying like someone whose heart was about to break.

en: It was not till the third day that he ventured to go out. There was something in the clear, pine-scented air of that winter morning that seemed to bring him back his joyousness and his ardour for life. But it was not merely the physical conditions of environment that had caused the change. His own nature had revolted against the excess of anguish that had sought to maim and mar the perfection of its calm. With subtle and finely wrought temperaments it is always so. Their strong passions must either bruise or bend. They either slay the man, or themselves die. Shallow sorrows and shallow loves live on. The loves and sorrows that are great are destroyed by their own plenitude. Besides, he had convinced himself that he had been the victim of a terror-stricken imagination, and looked back now on his fears with something of pity and not a little of contempt.
vi: It wasn't until Tuesday that he finally dared to step outside. There was something in the fresh, pine-scented air of that winter morning that seemed to bring back to him the joy and zest for life. But it wasn't just the natural conditions of the surrounding environment that caused the change. His own nature had also risen up against the excess of the anguish that kept trying to destroy the perfection of the calmness that belonged to it. It is always so with those who have a delicate and finely tuned temperament. Their strong passions must be distorted or bent. They either kill or die themselves. Shallow sorrows and shallow loves continue to live on. Great loves and great sorrows are destroyed by their own fullness. Moreover, he convinced himself that he was the victim of an imagination influenced by terror, and now looked back at his fears with something like pity and great disdain.
tr: Dorian could only muster the courage to step out of his room on the third day. Something in the pine-scented, clear air of that winter morning seemed to have rekindled his desire and joy for life. Yet, it wasn't just the objective conditions of the environment that caused this change. His own nature had also rebelled against the excessive sorrow that tried to erode and overshadow the perfection of his existence. People with complex and tense temperaments are always like this. Very strong emotions either hurt or yield. They either kill or die. Shallow sorrows, shallow loves are long-lived. Great loves, great sorrows become victims of their own greatness. After all, Dorian had convinced himself that he was a victim of his terrified imagination, and now he recalled his fears with a bit of pity and quite a bit of disdain.
es: Only on the third day did he venture out. There was something in the clear air of that winter morning, in which the scent of pines floated, that seemed to restore his joy and zest for life. But it was not only the external conditions that had caused the change. His own nature was rebelling against the excess of anguish that had tried to alter, to mutilate, his perfect serenity. It is always so with subtle and delicate temperaments. Their burning passions either wound or yield. They kill or die. Superficial sufferings and loves live long. Great loves and sufferings are destroyed by their own fullness. Dorian Gray was also convinced that he had been the victim of a terrified imagination, and he now viewed the fears of yesterday with a bit of compassion and a good dose of contempt.

en: After breakfast, he walked with the duchess for an hour in the garden and then drove across the park to join the shooting-party. The crisp frost lay like salt upon the grass. The sky was an inverted cup of blue metal. A thin film of ice bordered the flat, reed-grown lake.
vi: After breakfast, he strolled with the duchess for about an hour in the garden, then drove through the park to join the hunting party. The crisp frost lay like salt on the grass. The sky was an inverted cup of blue metal. A thin layer of ice bordered the flat lake filled with reeds.
tr: After breakfast, he walked in the garden with the duchess for an hour, then got into the carriage and went to join the hunting party at the other end of the park. The crackling frost was spread over the grass like salt. The sky was an inverted cup of blue metal. A thin layer of salt surrounded the shores of the still, reedy lake.
es: After breakfast, he walked with the duchess in the garden for an hour, and then crossed the park by carriage to join the hunting party. The morning frost covered the grass like a mantle of salt. The sky was an inverted cup of blue metal. A thin layer of ice bordered the still lake where the reeds grew.

en: At the corner of the pine-wood he caught sight of Sir Geoffrey Clouston, the duchess’s brother, jerking two spent cartridges out of his gun. He jumped from the cart, and having told the groom to take the mare home, made his way towards his guest through the withered bracken and rough undergrowth.
vi: At the corner of the pine forest, he glimpsed Mr. Geoffrey Clouston, the duke's brother, forcefully pulling two spent shells out of his gun. He jumped out of the car, and after instructing the stable hand to take the mare back home, he headed towards his guest through the withered bracken ferns and the tangled underbrush.
tr: At the corner of the pine grove, Dorian saw the Duchess's brother, Sir Geoffrey Clouston. Sir Geoffrey was removing two spent cartridges from his rifle. Dorian jumped down from the carriage, told the coachman to take the mare back, and then went to his guest, passing through the dried bushes and thorny heathers.
es: At the edge of the pine forest, he recognized Sir Geoffrey Clouston, the Duchess's brother, who was ejecting two spent cartridges from his hunting rifle. Dismounting from the vehicle, after telling the groom to return with the mare, he made his way to his guest through the dry ferns and thick underbrush.

en: “Have you had good sport, Geoffrey?” he asked.
vi: "Did you have fun, Geoffrey?" he asked.
tr: “Did you hunt well, Geoffrey?” he asked.
es: —Good hunting, Geoffrey? —he asked.

en: “Not very good, Dorian. I think most of the birds have gone to the open. I dare say it will be better after lunch, when we get to new ground.”
vi: "Not very happy, Dorian. I think most of the birds have flown to the desolate fields. I dare say it will be more enjoyable after lunch, when we reach the new land."
tr: “It wasn't very good, Dorian. I think most of the birds have been exposed. After dinner, it will probably be better when we go to a new area.”
es: —Not too good, Dorian. It seems to me that most of the birds have already flown out into the open sky. I hope we have better luck after lunch, when we start another drive.

en: Dorian strolled along by his side. The keen aromatic air, the brown and red lights that glimmered in the wood, the hoarse cries of the beaters ringing out from time to time, and the sharp snaps of the guns that followed, fascinated him and filled him with a sense of delightful freedom. He was dominated by the carelessness of happiness, by the high indifference of joy.
vi: Dorian walked beside him. The air was fragrant, red and brown light flickered in the forest, the hoarse cries of the beaters occasionally rang out, followed by the sharp clatter of guns, enchanting him, and filling him with a sense of joyful freedom. He was completely dominated by a careless happiness, by an overwhelming sense of euphoric detachment.
tr: Dorian began to walk slowly beside him. The fragrant, clean, crisp air, the brown and red lights shining within the grove, the muffled shouts of the men chasing away the birds, and the sharp sounds of rifles following these shouts almost enchanted him, filling him with a sweet sense of freedom. The carefreeness brought by happiness, the indifference awakened by joy, now dominated all his other feelings.
es: Dorian walked by his side. The intensely aromatic air, the brown and red glows that momentarily appeared in the pine forest, the hoarse cries of the beaters that occasionally echoed, and the dry noise of the gunshots that followed were a source of fascination for him, filling him with a delightful sense of freedom. He was dominated by the carefree nature of happiness, the supreme indifference of joy.

en: Suddenly from a lumpy tussock of old grass some twenty yards in front of them, with black-tipped ears erect and long hinder limbs throwing it forward, started a hare. It bolted for a thicket of alders. Sir Geoffrey put his gun to his shoulder, but there was something in the animal’s grace of movement that strangely charmed Dorian Gray, and he cried out at once, “Don’t shoot it, Geoffrey. Let it live.”
vi: Suddenly, from the old, scraggly bushes, about twenty yards in front of them, with black-tipped ears standing upright and long hind legs pushing its body forward, a hare abruptly appeared. It fled into a thicket of brambles. Sir Geoffrey raised his gun to his shoulder, but something about the grace of the animal in motion strangely captivated Dorian Gray, and he immediately shouted, “Don’t shoot it, Geoffrey. Let it live.”
tr: Suddenly, from within a dense cluster of dry grass about twenty meters ahead, a rabbit with black-tipped ears sprang up, hopping on its long hind legs. It immediately started running towards the maple trees opposite. Sir Geoffrey had already shouldered his rifle. However, Dorian, greatly pleased by the harmony in the animal's movements, shouted at that very moment, "Geoffrey, don't shoot!" "Let it live!"
es: Suddenly, from a thick clump of yellowish grass, about twenty meters from where they were standing, with its black-tipped ears erect, hopping on its long hind legs, a hare emerged, which immediately headed towards a group of alders. Sir Geoffrey raised his shotgun to his shoulder, but something in the agile movements of the animal strangely captivated Dorian Gray, who immediately shouted: —Don't shoot, Geoffrey! Let her live.

en: “What nonsense, Dorian!” laughed his companion, and as the hare bounded into the thicket, he fired. There were two cries heard, the cry of a hare in pain, which is dreadful, the cry of a man in agony, which is worse.
vi: “That's nonsense, Dorian!” his friend laughed, and as the rabbit leaped into the bush, he fired. There were two cries: the cry of the rabbit in pain, very frightening, and the cry of a person in their death throes, even more terrifying.
tr: Adam laughed, "Don't be ridiculous, Dorian!" and fired his rifle just as the rabbit darted into the thicket. Two cries were heard: the cry of a rabbit in pain – which is dreadful – and the even worse cry of a human in pain.
es: —How absurd, Dorian! —laughed Clouston, shooting as the hare leaped into the thicket. Two cries were heard: the terrible one of the mortally wounded hare, and the even worse one of a dying human being.

en: “Good heavens! I have hit a beater!” exclaimed Sir Geoffrey. “What an ass the man was to get in front of the guns! Stop shooting there!” he called out at the top of his voice. “A man is hurt.”
vi: “Oh my God! I shot a beater!” Sir Geoffrey shouted. “What kind of fool would walk right into the line of fire! Stop shooting over there!” he yelled at the top of his lungs. “Someone is injured.”
tr: Sir Geoffrey shouted, "My God, I shot one of the beaters!" "What stupidity! Who stands in front of the guns?" Then, with all his might, he started yelling, "Hey, you over there, cease fire, a man has been shot!"
es: —Good heavens! I've hit a beater! —exclaimed Sir Geoffrey—. What stupidity to get in front of the guns! Stop shooting! —he shouted with all his might—. There is an injured person.

en: The head-keeper came running up with a stick in his hand.
vi: The forest guard leader ran over with a stick in his hand.
tr: The head guard came running with a stick in his hand.
es: The chief guard arrived running with a baton in his hand.

en: “Where, sir? Where is he?” he shouted. At the same time, the firing ceased along the line.
vi: "Where, sir?" "Where is it?" he shouted. At the same time, the shooting stopped all along the line.
tr: "Where, sir? Where is the man?" he was shouting. Meanwhile, the rifle shots in the line of fire had also ceased.
es: —Where, sir? Where is it? —he shouted. At the same time, the fire ceased along the entire line.

en: “Here,” answered Sir Geoffrey angrily, hurrying towards the thicket. “Why on earth don’t you keep your men back? Spoiled my shooting for the day.”
vi: “Here,” Sir Geoffrey replied angrily, hurrying towards the bushes. “Good heavens, why didn't you keep your men behind? You've ruined my entire hunting day.”
tr: Sir Geoffrey angrily replied, "Here," and ran towards the heath. "Why don't you hold your men back? Today's hunt is ruined!"
es: —There —replied Sir Geoffrey very irritated, approaching the grove—. Why the devil don't you control your men? They have ruined an entire day of hunting for me.

en: Dorian watched them as they plunged into the alder-clump, brushing the lithe swinging branches aside. In a few moments they emerged, dragging a body after them into the sunlight. He turned away in horror. It seemed to him that misfortune followed wherever he went. He heard Sir Geoffrey ask if the man was really dead, and the affirmative answer of the keeper. The wood seemed to him to have become suddenly alive with faces. There was the trampling of myriad feet and the low buzz of voices. A great copper-breasted pheasant came beating through the boughs overhead.
vi: Dorian watched them as they rushed into the thicket, brushing aside the soft, swaying branches. A moment later, they emerged, dragging a corpse out into the sunlight. He turned away in fear. He felt as if misfortune followed him wherever he went. He heard Sir Geoffrey question whether the person was truly dead, and the ranger's affirmative response. He felt as if the forest suddenly became teeming with faces. There was the trampling sound of thousands of feet, and the soft murmur of voices. A giant copper-breasted pheasant flew through the branches overhead.
tr: Dorian watched them as they parted the lively, supple, swaying branches of the maple trees and plunged into the thicket. A few minutes later, they returned and dragged a body into the daylight behind them. Dorian turned his head away in horror and disgust. It seemed as if misfortune followed him wherever he went. Sir Geoffrey asked if the man was dead. The ranger replied, yes. Dorian heard this. Suddenly, the grove seemed to be teeming with countless human faces. The sound of countless footsteps and low voices could be heard. A large pheasant with a copper-colored chest appeared, rustling the upper branches.
es: Dorian watched them as they entered the alder grove, pushing aside the thin, flexible branches. Seeing them reappear a few moments later, dragging a lifeless body which they brought into the sunlight, he turned away in horror. It seemed to him that misfortunes followed him wherever he went. He heard Sir Geoffrey ask if the man was really dead, and the chief gamekeeper's affirmative response. Suddenly, he had the impression that the forest was filled with faces. He heard the footsteps of thousands of feet and a confused murmur of voices. A large pheasant with a coppery breast flew flapping through the highest branches.

en: After a few moments—that were to him, in his perturbed state, like endless hours of pain—he felt a hand laid on his shoulder. He started and looked round.
vi: After a few minutes that, in his agitated state, felt like endless hours of pain, he felt a hand placed on his shoulder. He started and looked around.
tr: Dorian was shaken; after a few minutes that felt like hours of agony, he felt a hand touch his shoulder. He turned around with a start.
es: After a few moments that felt to him, given the agitation of his spirit, like endless hours of pain, he felt a hand rest on his shoulder. Startled, he turned his gaze.

en: “Dorian,” said Lord Henry, “I had better tell them that the shooting is stopped for to-day. It would not look well to go on.”
vi: "Dorian," Lord Henry said, "I should tell them that the hunt should stop today." "It doesn't seem very appropriate to continue."
tr: “Dorian,” said Lord Henry. “I should tell everyone that the hunt is over for today. It would not be appropriate to continue.”
es: —Dorian —said Lord Henry—. It would be better to tell them that the hunt is over for today. It wouldn't seem right to continue.

en: “I wish it were stopped for ever, Harry,” he answered bitterly. “The whole thing is hideous and cruel. Is the man ...?”
vi: "I hope it stops forever, Harry," he replied, bitterly. "This whole thing is disgusting and cruel. That person has..."
tr: Dorian bitterly said, "I wish it would end forever, Harry!" "A filthy, savage business! The man..."
es: —I would like to stop it forever, Harry —he responded bitterly—. Everything is horrible and cruel. Is it...?

en: He could not finish the sentence.
vi: You couldn't finish the sentence.
tr: He couldn't finish his sentence.
es: He couldn't finish the sentence.

en: “I am afraid so,” rejoined Lord Henry. “He got the whole charge of shot in his chest. He must have died almost instantaneously. Come; let us go home.”
vi: “I’m afraid so,” Lord Henry replied. “He took all the bullets to the chest. He must have died almost instantly. Come; let’s go home.”
tr: Lord Henry replied, "I'm afraid so." "He took all the nonsense to heart. He must have died instantly. Come on, let's go home."
es: —I greatly fear so —replied Lord Henry—. The shot hit him squarely in the chest. He must have died almost instantly. Come; let's go back home.

en: They walked side by side in the direction of the avenue for nearly fifty yards without speaking. Then Dorian looked at Lord Henry and said, with a heavy sigh, “It is a bad omen, Harry, a very bad omen.”
vi: They walked side by side along the path under the trees for about fifty meters without saying a word. Then Dorian looked at Lord Henry and said, with a heavy sigh, "It is a bad omen, Harry, a very bad omen."
tr: They walked almost fifty meters towards the main road, side by side, without speaking. Then Dorian looked at Lord Henry and, sighing deeply, said, "This is a bad omen, Harry," "A very bad omen."
es: They started walking, side by side, towards the promenade, and covered almost fifty meters without speaking. Then Dorian looked at Lord Henry and said, with a deep sigh: —It's a bad omen, Harry; a terrible omen.

en: “What is?” asked Lord Henry. “Oh! this accident, I suppose. My dear fellow, it can’t be helped. It was the man’s own fault. Why did he get in front of the guns? Besides, it is nothing to us. It is rather awkward for Geoffrey, of course. It does not do to pepper beaters. It makes people think that one is a wild shot. And Geoffrey is not; he shoots very straight. But there is no use talking about the matter.”
vi: “What do you mean?” Lord Henry asked. “Oh! This accident, huh. My friend, it's hopeless. It was his own fault. Why did he get right in front of the gun? Besides, it has nothing to do with us. It's quite a hassle for Geoffrey, of course. Shooting at the person driving the game is really not okay at all. It makes people think he's a reckless shooter. But Geoffrey isn't like that; he's a very accurate shooter. But talking about this is pointless.”
tr: Lord Henry asked, "What?" "Oh, you mean that accident, I suppose. My dear friend, what's done is done. It was the man's own fault. Can you step in front of a gun? And anyway, what does it matter to us, dear? It's a bit awkward for Geoffrey, naturally. Shooting beaters is not a pleasant thing. Then the man gets a reputation for being a bad shot. But Geoffrey is not a bad shot. When he pulls the trigger, he hits the mark. Anyway, there's no point in talking about this."
es: —What do you mean? —asked Lord Henry—. Ah, you're talking about the accident, I imagine. But, who could have foreseen it? It was his fault. What was he doing in front of the firing line?
