In any case, it's not our concern. Annoying for Geoffrey, no doubt. It's not well-regarded to shoot beaters. It makes people think one doesn't know where they're aiming. And Geoffrey knows perfectly well; where he sets his eye, he sets his bullet. But it's no use talking about this matter.

en: Dorian shook his head. “It is a bad omen, Harry. I feel as if something horrible were going to happen to some of us. To myself, perhaps,” he added, passing his hand over his eyes, with a gesture of pain.
vi: Dorian shook his head. "That is a bad point, Harry. I feel as if something terrible is about to happen to one of us. To myself, perhaps," he added, brushing his hand across his eyes with a pained expression.
tr: Dorian nodded his head. "Harry, this is ominous. I have a feeling that something terrible is going to happen to one of us. Maybe to me," he added, pressing his hand to his eyes as if in pain.
es: Dorian shook his head. —It's a bad omen, Harry. I feel like something horrible is going to happen to one of us. To me, perhaps —he added, passing his hands over his eyes, with a gesture of pain.

en: The elder man laughed. “The only horrible thing in the world is ennui, Dorian. That is the one sin for which there is no forgiveness. But we are not likely to suffer from it unless these fellows keep chattering about this thing at dinner. I must tell them that the subject is to be tabooed. As for omens, there is no such thing as an omen. Destiny does not send us heralds. She is too wise or too cruel for that. Besides, what on earth could happen to you, Dorian? You have everything in the world that a man can want. There is no one who would not be delighted to change places with you.”
vi: The older person laughed. “The only terrible thing in this world is boredom, Dorian. It is an unforgivable sin. But surely we don't have to endure it, unless those friends of ours keep babbling about it at dinner. I must tell them that this topic is forbidden. As for omens, there is no such thing as an omen. Fate does not send messengers to us. In this regard, she is either too wise or too cruel. Besides, what on earth could possibly happen to you, Dorian? You have everything a person could need. No one would be unwilling to trade places with you.”
tr: His friend laughed. “The only dreadful thing in the world is boredom, Dorian. It is the only sin for which there is no forgiveness. Anyway, it is unlikely that we will suffer from this calamity, except for these guys chewing over the same topic at the table. I might as well tell them that the subject is taboo. As for the sign of bad luck, there is no such thing. Fate does not have the habit of sending us a warning in advance. It is too wise or too ruthless to do so: Besides, my dear Dorian, what could possibly happen to you? You have everything a person could desire. Anyone would gladly trade places with you.”
es: His older friend burst out laughing. —The only horrible thing in the world is ennui, Dorian. That is the only sin that is unforgivable. But it is unlikely that we will suffer from it, unless our friends continue talking during dinner about what happened. I must tell them that it is a taboo subject. As for omens, there is no such thing. Fate does not send us heralds. It is too prudent or too cruel for that. Besides, what the hell could happen to you? You have everything a man could desire. Anyone would trade places with you.

en: “There is no one with whom I would not change places, Harry. Don’t laugh like that. I am telling you the truth. The wretched peasant who has just died is better off than I am. I have no terror of death. It is the coming of death that terrifies me. Its monstrous wings seem to wheel in the leaden air around me. Good heavens! don’t you see a man moving behind the trees there, watching me, waiting for me?”
vi: “There is no one I wouldn't want to trade places with, Harry. Don't laugh like that. I'm telling you the truth. Even that poor farmer who just died is happier than I am. I'm not afraid of Death. It's the approach of Death that terrifies me. Its enormous wings seem to be circling in the leaden gray air around me. Oh my God! Do you see someone moving behind those trees over there, watching me, waiting for me?”
tr: “I would switch places with anyone who wants, Harry. Don't laugh like that. Even the wretched peasant who just died is in a better situation than me. I'm not afraid of death. What horrifies me is the approach of death. It's as if death's giant wings are swimming through this leaden air around us. My God! There's a man behind those trees, don't you see? He's watching me, waiting for my path.”
es: —There is no one with whom I wouldn't be willing to trade places, Harry. Don't laugh like that. I'm telling you the truth. That poor peasant who just died is luckier than I am. I'm not afraid of death. It's the way it comes that terrifies me. Its monstrous wings seem to whirl in the leaden air around me. Good heavens! Didn't you see a man moving behind those trees, an individual who is watching me, who is waiting for me?

en: Lord Henry looked in the direction in which the trembling gloved hand was pointing. “Yes,” he said, smiling, “I see the gardener waiting for you. I suppose he wants to ask you what flowers you wish to have on the table to-night. How absurdly nervous you are, my dear fellow! You must come and see my doctor, when we get back to town.”
vi: Lord Henry looked in the direction the trembling gloved hand was pointing. "Yes," he said with a smile, "I see the gardener waiting for you. I suppose he needs to ask you which flowers you want on the table tonight. Why are you so unreasonably anxious, my friend! You must see my doctor when we return to the city."
tr: Lord Henry shivered and looked in the direction indicated by the gloved hand. Smiling, he replied, "Yes." "I see the gardener is waiting for you. He probably wants to ask which flowers you want on the table tonight. Your nerves are ridiculously tense, my dear. When we return to the city, you must go see my doctor."
es: Lord Henry looked in the direction indicated by the trembling gloved hand. —Yes —he said, smiling—; I see a gardener waiting for you. I imagine he wants to ask you which flowers you want on the table tonight. How incredibly nervous you are, my dear friend! You must go see my doctor when you return to London.

en: Dorian heaved a sigh of relief as he saw the gardener approaching. The man touched his hat, glanced for a moment at Lord Henry in a hesitating manner, and then produced a letter, which he handed to his master. “Her Grace told me to wait for an answer,” he murmured.
vi: Dorian breathed a sigh of relief when he saw the gardener approaching. The gardener touched his hat, glanced hesitantly at Lord Henry, then took out a letter and handed it to his master. “The lady told me to wait for a reply,” he whispered.
tr: Dorian breathed a sigh of relief when he saw the gardener approaching. The man touched his hat, hesitated for a moment while looking towards Lord Henry, then took out a letter and handed it to his master. “Her Grace, the Duchess, commanded me to wait and bring back a response,” he murmured.
es: Dorian let out a sigh of relief upon seeing the gardener approach, who, touching his hat, looked at Lord Henry for a moment, as if hesitant, and then took out a letter, which he handed to his master. —His grace told me to wait for the response —he murmured.

en: Dorian put the letter into his pocket. “Tell her Grace that I am coming in,” he said, coldly. The man turned round and went rapidly in the direction of the house.
vi: Dorian put the letter in his pocket. "Tell her I am coming immediately," he said coldly. The servant turned away and walked quickly towards the house.
tr: Dorian put the letter in his pocket. Coldly, he said, "Tell Her Grace the Duchess that I am coming now." Adam turned and quickly walked away towards the house.
es: Dorian put the letter in his pocket. —Tell his grace that I will arrive shortly —he responded coldly. The messenger turned around, quickly returning to the house.

en: “How fond women are of doing dangerous things!” laughed Lord Henry. “It is one of the qualities in them that I admire most. A woman will flirt with anybody in the world as long as other people are looking on.”
vi: “Why do women like to do such dangerous things!” Lord Henry laughed. “That is one of the qualities in them that I admire the most. Women will flirt with anyone in the world as long as others are paying attention.”
tr: Lord Henry laughed, "How women love dangerous things!" he said. "It is one of the qualities I admire most about them. As long as it is in front of everyone."
es: —How much women love to do dangerous things! —laughed Lord Henry—. It is one of the qualities I admire most in them. A woman can flirt with anyone as long as there are other people watching.

en: “How fond you are of saying dangerous things, Harry! In the present instance, you are quite astray. I like the duchess very much, but I don’t love her.”
vi: “Why do you like to say such dangerous things, Harry! In this case, you are greatly mistaken. I like the duchess very much, but I do not love her.”
tr: “How you love to say dangerous things, Harry! But right now, you are very wrong. I like Duchess very much, but I am not in love with her.”
es: —How much you like to say dangerous things, Harry! In this case, you are completely wrong. I like the duchess a lot, but I am not in love with her.

en: “And the duchess loves you very much, but she likes you less, so you are excellently matched.”
vi: “As for the duchess, she loves you very much, but she doesn't like you as much, so you two are extremely well-matched.”
tr: “The Duchess is very much in love with you, but she doesn't quite like you. So, you are equal to each other.”
es: —And the duchess loves you more than she likes you, so you are perfectly matched.

en: “You are talking scandal, Harry, and there is never any basis for scandal.”
vi: "You're making things up, Harry, without any basis for it.""
tr: "You are talking about a scandal, Harry. However, there is no basis for a scandal."
es: —That is defamation, Harry, and there is never any reason for defamation!

en: “The basis of every scandal is an immoral certainty,” said Lord Henry, lighting a cigarette.
vi: “The basis of all scandal is an unwavering belief in some form of immorality,” Lord Henry said, lighting a cigarette.
tr: “The basis of every scandal is an immoral confidence.”
es: —The basis of all slander is an immoral certainty —said Lord Henry, lighting a cigarette.

en: “You would sacrifice anybody, Harry, for the sake of an epigram.”
vi: “You would probably sacrifice anyone, Harry, for a witty remark.”
tr: "Harry, there is no one you wouldn't sacrifice for the pleasure of a witty aphorism!""
es: —You would sacrifice anyone for an epigram.

en: “The world goes to the altar of its own accord,” was the answer.
vi: “People willingly go to the altar,” was the answer.
tr: His friend replied, "The world is a sacrificial lamb; it comes meekly and lies down under the knife."
es: —The world is heading towards the altar by its own decision —was the response.

en: “I wish I could love,” cried Dorian Gray with a deep note of pathos in his voice. “But I seem to have lost the passion and forgotten the desire. I am too much concentrated on myself. My own personality has become a burden to me. I want to escape, to go away, to forget. It was silly of me to come down here at all. I think I shall send a wire to Harvey to have the yacht got ready. On a yacht one is safe.”
vi: “I wish I could love.” Dorian Gray exclaimed, with a deep note of emotion in his voice. “But I seem to have lost passion, forgotten desire. I am too focused on myself. My personality has become a burden to me. I want to escape, to go far away, to forget everything. I was so naive to come down here. I think I will send a telegram to Harvey to prepare the sailboat. On the sailboat, we will be safe.”
tr: Dorian Gray shouted with deep emotion, "I wish I could love!" "But it seems I have lost the passion to love, I have forgotten what it means to love. My own personality has become a burden on my shoulders. I have become too self-centered. I want to escape, to get away, to forget. Coming here was sheer folly. I'd better wire Harvey to prepare the yacht. On the yacht, one is safe from dangers."
es: —I would like to be able to love —exclaimed Dorian Gray with a note of deep pathos in his voice—. But it seems that I have lost passion and forgotten desire. I am too focused on myself. My personality has become a burden. I want to escape, get away, forget. It was foolish to come back here. I think I will telegraph Harvey to prepare the yacht. On the yacht, I will be safe.

en: “Safe from what, Dorian? You are in some trouble. Why not tell me what it is? You know I would help you.”
vi: "Safe with what, Dorian? You seem to be unhappy about something. Why don't you tell me what it is? You know I will help you."
tr: “What danger, Dorian? You are in trouble. Tell me, what is it. You know I will help you.”
es: —Safe from what, Dorian? Do you have a problem. Why don't you tell me what it's about? You know I would help you.

en: “I can’t tell you, Harry,” he answered sadly. “And I dare say it is only a fancy of mine. This unfortunate accident has upset me. I have a horrible presentiment that something of the kind may happen to me.”
vi: "I can't tell you, Harry," he replied, sadly. "And I dare say it is just my imagination. This unfortunate accident worries me. I have a terrible feeling that something like this might happen to me."
tr: Dorian said sadly, "I can't tell you, Harry." "Besides, it might just be a figment of my imagination. This troublesome accident has shaken me. I have a bad feeling that something like this will happen to me too."
es: —I can't tell you, Harry—he responded sadly—. And I suppose it's just my imagination. That unfortunate accident has unsettled me. I have a horrible premonition that something similar could happen to me.

en: “What nonsense!”
vi: "Nonsense!"
tr: “But you're talking nonsense!”
es: —How absurd!

en: “I hope it is, but I can’t help feeling it. Ah! here is the duchess, looking like Artemis in a tailor-made gown. You see we have come back, Duchess.”
vi: "I hope so, but I can't help feeling it." "Ah! Here comes the Duchess, looking like Artemis in a tailored gown." "You see, we have returned, Duchess."
tr: “I hope so, but I can't suppress this feeling. Oh, there's the duchess, she looks like a tailor-made Artemis! Madam duchess, as you can see, we've come back.”
es: —I hope you're right, but that's how I feel. Ah! There is the duchess, who looks like Artemis in a tailored suit. You see that we are back, duchess.

en: “I have heard all about it, Mr. Gray,” she answered. “Poor Geoffrey is terribly upset. And it seems that you asked him not to shoot the hare. How curious!”
vi: “I heard everything, Mr. Gray,” she replied. “Poor Geoffrey is very worried. And it seems that you asked him not to shoot that hare. How strange!”
tr: The young woman said, "I heard everything, Mr. Gray." "Poor Geoffrey is so upset! I think you also told him not to shoot the rabbit. How strange!"
es: —I have been informed of everything, Mr. Gray —she replied—. Poor Geoffrey is terribly affected. And it seems you had asked him not to shoot at the hare. How curious!

en: “Yes, it was very curious. I don’t know what made me say it. Some whim, I suppose. It looked the loveliest of little live things. But I am sorry they told you about the man. It is a hideous subject.”
vi: “That's right, very strange. I don't know what made me say that. Some sudden thought, I think. It's like the cutest little creature. But I'm sorry they told you about that person. It's a disgusting subject.”
tr: “Yes, it really was strange. I don't know why I said that. It must have just come to my mind. The rabbit looked so cute to me: a tiny, adorable creature. Anyway, I was sorry to hear them talk about the dead man. It's a terrible situation.”
es: —Yes; very curious. I don't know what pushed me to say it. A sudden impulse, I suppose. It seemed like a charming little creature to me. I'm sorry they told you about the scout. It's a regrettable thing.

en: “It is an annoying subject,” broke in Lord Henry. “It has no psychological value at all. Now if Geoffrey had done the thing on purpose, how interesting he would be! I should like to know some one who had committed a real murder.”
vi: “That is an unpleasant topic,” Lord Henry interrupted. “It has no psychological value at all. Now, suppose Geoffrey had deliberately done it, how interesting he would be! I would love to know someone who has actually committed a real murder.”
tr: Lord Henry interrupted, "A boring subject," he said. "It has no value from a psychological standpoint. Look, if Geoffrey had done this intentionally, I would indeed start to find it very interesting! I would really like to meet someone who has actually committed a murder."
es: —It's an annoying topic —interjected Lord Henry—. It lacks psychological value. On the other hand, if Geoffrey had done it on purpose, how interesting it would be! I would like to meet a real murderer.

en: “How horrid of you, Harry!” cried the duchess. “Isn’t it, Mr. Gray? Harry, Mr. Gray is ill again. He is going to faint.”
vi: “Why are you being so unreasonable, Harry!” the duchess exclaimed. “Isn't that right, Mr. Gray? Harry, Mr. Gray is sick again. He's about to faint.”
tr: The Duchess shouted, "What a monster you are, Harry!" "Isn't that right, Mr. Gray? Harry, Mr. Gray is feeling unwell again. He might faint."
es: —How unpleasant you are, Harry! —exclaimed the duchess—. Don't you think so, Mr. Gray? Harry, Mr. Gray is feeling unwell again. I think he is going to faint.

en: Dorian drew himself up with an effort and smiled. “It is nothing, Duchess,” he murmured; “my nerves are dreadfully out of order. That is all. I am afraid I walked too far this morning. I didn’t hear what Harry said. Was it very bad? You must tell me some other time. I think I must go and lie down. You will excuse me, won’t you?”
vi: Dorian tried to stand up straight and laughed. “It's nothing, Duchess,” he muttered; “my nerves are terribly upset. That's all. I'm afraid I walked too far this morning. I didn't hear what Harry said. Was it very bad? You must tell me another time. I think I must lie down. You will forgive me, won't you?”
tr: Dorian forced himself to smile. “It's nothing, Duchess,” he murmured. “My nerves are terribly frayed. Nothing else. I must have walked a lot this morning. What did Harry say? I didn't hear. Was it very mischievous? Tell me another time. I should go lie down. You won't mind, will you?”
es: Dorian made an effort to recover and smiled. —It's nothing, Duchess —he murmured—; it's just that I'm very nervous. Nothing more than that. I'm afraid I've walked too much this morning. I didn't hear what Harry said. Something very inappropriate? You'll have to tell me another time. I think I'm going to lie down for a while. You will excuse me, won't you?

en: They had reached the great flight of steps that led from the conservatory on to the terrace. As the glass door closed behind Dorian, Lord Henry turned and looked at the duchess with his slumberous eyes. “Are you very much in love with him?” he asked.
vi: They reached the wide staircase leading from the conservatory to the terrace. As the glass door closed behind Dorian, Lord Henry turned to look at the duchess with dreamy eyes. “Do you love it very much?” he asked.
tr: They had reached the large staircase rising from the lemon-scented terrace. When the glass door closed behind Dorian, Lord Henry turned and looked at the duchess with his sleepy eyes. “Are you very much in love with her?” he asked.
es: They had already reached the grand staircase that led from the greenhouse to the terrace. As the glass door closed behind Dorian, Lord Henry turned and looked at his cousin with languid eyes. —Are you very much in love with him? —he asked.

en: She did not answer for some time, but stood gazing at the landscape. “I wish I knew,” she said at last.
vi: She didn't respond for a moment, just stood looking at the scenery. "I wish I knew," she finally said.
tr: The young woman, without responding for a while, let her eyes wander over the scenery. Finally, she said, "If only I knew!"
es: The duchess took some time to respond, contemplating the landscape motionlessly. —I would like to know —he said, finally.

en: He shook his head. “Knowledge would be fatal. It is the uncertainty that charms one. A mist makes things wonderful.”
vi: Y shook his head. "Knowing clearly only harms. Being vague is more attractive. The fog makes things magical."
tr: Lord Henry nodded his head. "To know would be the end of everything. What is attractive is not knowing. Mist adds a wonderful beauty to everything."
es: Lord Henry shook his head. —Knowing it would be fatal. It is the uncertainty that attracts us. A little fog improves things a lot.

en: “One may lose one’s way.”
vi: “Could be lost.”
tr: “Or it confuses a person’s way.”
es: —You can lose the way.

en: “All ways end at the same point, my dear Gladys.”
vi: "All roads end at the same point, Gladys."
tr: “All roads lead to the same point, my dear Gladys.”
es: —All roads lead to the same place, my dear Gladys.

en: “What is that?”
vi: "What is it?"
tr: “What is that?”
es: —What is...?

en: “Disillusion.”
vi: “Disillusioned.”
tr: “Disappointment.”
es: —The disappointment.

en: “It was my début in life,” she sighed.
vi: “That was also my debut into life,” she sighed.
tr: The young woman sighed, "That was the first step I took in life."
es: —It was my debut in life —sighed the duchess.

en: “It came to you crowned.”
vi: “It came to you wearing a crown.”
tr: “He came to you with a crown on his head.”
es: —But he arrived with the ducal crown.

en: “I am tired of strawberry leaves.”
vi: "I am tired of mulberry leaves." 1 Duke's row (on the hat decorated with a strawberry leaf.)
tr: “I am tired of flower petals.”
es: —I'm fed up with strawberry leaves.

en: “They become you.”
vi: “They suit you.”
tr: “It suits you.”
es: —They look good on you.

en: “Only in public.”
vi: “Only when public.”
tr: “Only when in the hand.”
es: —Only in public.

en: “You would miss them,” said Lord Henry.
vi: “She will miss them,” Lord Henry said.
tr: Lord Henry, "You lose it, you search for it," he said.
es: —You would miss them —said Lord Henry.

en: “I will not part with a petal.”
vi: “I will not pluck any petals.”
tr: “I won't give up even a single leaf.”
es: —I wouldn't give up even a single petal.

en: “Monmouth has ears.”
vi: "Monmouth has ears."
tr: “Monmouth has an ear.”
es: —Monmouth has ears.

en: “Old age is dull of hearing.”
vi: “Old age is hard of hearing.”
tr: “In old age, ears become heavy.”
es: —The elderly are hard of hearing.

en: “Has he never been jealous?”
vi: “Has he ever been jealous?”
tr: “Didn't he ever get jealous of you?”
es: —Have you never been jealous?

en: “I wish he had been.”
vi: “I wish he had.”
tr: "I wish he had been jealous!""
es: —I wish I had had them.

en: He glanced about as if in search of something. “What are you looking for?” she inquired.
vi: He looked around as if searching for something. “What are you looking for?” she asked.
tr: Lord Henry looked around as if searching for something. The Duchess asked, "What are you looking for?"
es: Lord Henry looked around as if he were searching for something. —What are you looking for? —she asked.

en: “The button from your foil,” he answered. “You have dropped it.”
vi: “The pommel of your sword,” he replied. “You dropped it.”
tr: “Your sword. You have dropped it from your hand.”
es: —The button of your foil —he replied—. It just fell off.

en: She laughed. “I have still the mask.”
vi: She burst out laughing. "I still have the mask."
tr: The Duchess laughed. “My mask is still in place.”
es: The duchess burst out laughing. —I still have the mask left.

en: “It makes your eyes lovelier,” was his reply.
vi: “It makes your eyes more beautiful,” was his response.
tr: Lord Henry replied, "The mask makes your eyes look more beautiful."
es: —It makes your eyes look even more beautiful —was his response.

en: She laughed again. Her teeth showed like white seeds in a scarlet fruit.
vi: She laughed again. Her teeth appeared like white seeds in a persimmon.
tr: The Duchess laughed again. Her teeth looked like white seeds in red fruit.
es: Her cousin laughed again. Her teeth shone like white seeds in a scarlet fruit.

en: Upstairs, in his own room, Dorian Gray was lying on a sofa, with terror in every tingling fibre of his body. Life had suddenly become too hideous a burden for him to bear. The dreadful death of the unlucky beater, shot in the thicket like a wild animal, had seemed to him to pre-figure death for himself also. He had nearly swooned at what Lord Henry had said in a chance mood of cynical jesting.
vi: Upstairs, in his private room, Dorian Gray was lying on the sofa, with terror tingling in every fiber of his being. Life had suddenly become an unbearably loathsome burden for him to carry. The terrible death of the unlucky animal trainer, shot in the bushes like a wild beast, made him feel as if it was a foretelling of his own demise. He nearly fainted at what Lord Henry said in a mood of bitter jest.
tr: In his room upstairs, Dorian Gray was lying on a couch, every fiber of his being trembling with fear. Life had suddenly become an unbearably ugly, disgusting burden. The death of the unfortunate man, struck down like a wild animal among the bushes, appeared to him as a symbol foretelling his own death. He had felt faint when he heard the words Lord Henry had casually uttered in a moment of mockery.
es: On the upper floor, Dorian Gray was lying on a sofa in his room, feeling every fiber of his body vibrate with terror. Suddenly, life had become an unbearable burden. The horrible death of the unfortunate gamekeeper, struck down among the underbrush like a wild animal, had seemed to him a prefiguration of his own death. He had almost fainted upon hearing the cynical joke that Lord Henry had made at random.

en: At five o’clock he rang his bell for his servant and gave him orders to pack his things for the night-express to town, and to have the brougham at the door by eight-thirty. He was determined not to sleep another night at Selby Royal. It was an ill-omened place. Death walked there in the sunlight. The grass of the forest had been spotted with blood.
vi: At five o'clock, he rang the bell to call the servant and ordered him to pack his belongings for the night express train to the city, and to arrange for a one-horse carriage at the door at half-past eight. He was determined not to spend another night at Selby Royal. It was a place of ominous signs. Death walked there in the sunlight. The grass in the forest was stained with blood.
tr: At five o'clock, he rang the bell and called his servant: Since he would be returning to the city with the night express, he told him to prepare his bag and to have the carriage at the door by half-past eight. He was determined not to spend another night at Selby Royal. This place was filled with ominousness. Death roamed here in broad daylight. Blood had fallen on the forest grass.
es: At five o'clock, he called his servant and ordered him to prepare a suitcase to return to London on the night express, and that the carriage should be in front of the door at half-past eight. He had decided not to spend another night at Selby Royal. It was a place of bad omens. Death roamed there in broad daylight. The forest grass had been stained with blood.

en: Then he wrote a note to Lord Henry, telling him that he was going up to town to consult his doctor and asking him to entertain his guests in his absence. As he was putting it into the envelope, a knock came to the door, and his valet informed him that the head-keeper wished to see him. He frowned and bit his lip. “Send him in,” he muttered, after some moments’ hesitation.
vi: Then he wrote a short letter to Lord Henry, telling him that he was returning to the city to see a doctor, and asking him to entertain guests in his absence. As he was putting the letter into an envelope, there was a knock on the door, and his servant informed him that the head forester wished to see him. He frowned, biting his lip. "Let him in," he muttered, after a moment's hesitation.
tr: Then he wrote a note to Lord Henry, informing him that he would go to the city to see his doctor, and asked him to entertain his guests in his absence. As he was putting it in the envelope, there was a knock at the door; his servant informed him that the head gamekeeper wanted to see him. Dorian frowned and bit his lip. After a moment's hesitation, he said, "Let him come in."
es: Then he wrote a note to Lord Henry, telling him that he was returning to London to consult his doctor, and asking him to entertain his guests during his absence. As he was putting it into the envelope, he heard a knock at the door, and his valet informed him that the chief guard wanted to see him. Dorian Gray frowned and bit his lips. "Tell him to come in," he murmured, after a brief hesitation.

en: As soon as the man entered, Dorian pulled his chequebook out of a drawer and spread it out before him.
vi: As soon as the person entered, Dorian pulled the checkbook out of the drawer and laid it out in front of him.
tr: As soon as Adam entered, Dorian took the checkbook out of his drawer and placed it on the table.
es: As soon as his visitor entered, Dorian took a checkbook out of a drawer and opened it.

en: “I suppose you have come about the unfortunate accident of this morning, Thornton?” he said, taking up a pen.
vi: "I suppose you are here about the unfortunate accident this morning, aren't you Thornton?" he said, picking up a pen.
tr: Taking his pen in hand, he said, "I assume you came for the unfortunate accident this morning, didn't you, Thornton?"
es: —I imagine, Thornton, that you have come to talk to me about the unfortunate accident this morning —he said, gripping the pen.

en: “Yes, sir,” answered the gamekeeper.
vi: “Yes, sir,” the ranger replied.
tr: The ranger replied, "Yes, sir."
es: —That's right, sir —replied the forest ranger.

en: “Was the poor fellow married? Had he any people dependent on him?” asked Dorian, looking bored. “If so, I should not like them to be left in want, and will send them any sum of money you may think necessary.”
vi: “Does that poor fellow have a wife?” “Does he have anyone dependent on him?” Dorian asked, looking very sad. “If so, I wouldn't want them to be left in poverty, and I will send them whatever amount of money you think is necessary.”
tr: “Is the poor man married? Does he have anyone dependent on him?” asked Dorian wearily. “If there is, I don't want them to be left out in the cold. I'll send them some money, as much as you see fit.”
es: —Was that poor wretch married? Did he have dependents? —asked Dorian, with a bored air—. If so, I wouldn't want them to be in need, and I am willing to send them the amount you deem necessary.

en: “We don’t know who he is, sir. That is what I took the liberty of coming to you about.”
vi: "We don't know who he is, sir." That is the reason I took the liberty to come see you."
tr: "We don't know who the man is, sir. That's why I'm bothering you."
es: —We don't know who it is, sir. That is what I have taken the liberty to come and tell you.

en: “Don’t know who he is?” said Dorian, listlessly. “What do you mean? Wasn’t he one of your men?”
vi: “Don't know who he is?” Dorian asked, indifferently. “What do you mean? Isn't he your man?”
tr: Dorian asked in a troubled voice, "Don't you know who he is?" "What do you mean? Isn't he one of your men?"
es: —Don't you know who he is? —asked Dorian distractedly—. What do you mean? Wasn't he one of your men?

en: “No, sir. Never saw him before. Seems like a sailor, sir.”
vi: “No, sir. I have never seen him before. He seems to be a sailor, sir.”
tr: "Yes, sir. Someone I've never seen before. He looks like a sailor, sir."
es: —No, sir. I had never seen him before. He looks like a sailor, sir.

en: The pen dropped from Dorian Gray’s hand, and he felt as if his heart had suddenly stopped beating. “A sailor?” he cried out. “Did you say a sailor?”
vi: The pen dropped from Dorian Gray's hand, he felt as if his heart had suddenly stopped beating. "A sailor?" he exclaimed. "Did you say a sailor?"
tr: The pen fell from his hand and it was as if Dorian's heart suddenly stopped. “A sailor?” he shouted. “Did you say a sailor?”
es: Dorian Gray dropped the pen from his hand and felt as if his heart had stopped beating. —A sailor? —he exclaimed—. Did you say a sailor?

en: “Yes, sir. He looks as if he had been a sort of sailor; tattooed on both arms, and that kind of thing.”
vi: "Yes, sir." "He looks like he might have been a sailor; tattoos on both arms, and that sort of thing."
tr: "Yes, sir. He looks like a sailor: He has tattoos on both arms."
es: —Yes, sir. It seems as if he had been a sailor or something similar; tattoos on both arms and other things like that.

en: “Was there anything found on him?” said Dorian, leaning forward and looking at the man with startled eyes. “Anything that would tell his name?”
vi: “Did you find anything on him?” Dorian said, leaning forward and looking at the person with startled eyes. “Anything that could tell us his name?”
tr: Dorian leaned forward and scanned the ranger's face with surprised eyes. "Did anything come out of him? Something that shows his name or identity?"
es: —Did he have anything on him? —asked Dorian, leaning forward and looking at the gamekeeper with eyes full of shock—. Anything that would allow us to know his name?

en: “Some money, sir—not much, and a six-shooter. There was no name of any kind. A decent-looking man, sir, but rough-like. A sort of sailor we think.”
vi: “A little money, sir — not much, and a revolver. No identification at all. A person who seemed respectable, sir, but somewhat rough. A sailor, we think.”
tr: “A little money, sir; not much, a pistol. No name or anything. He looks like a gentleman, sir, but his clothes are rough. We think he must be a sailor or something.”
es: —Some money, sir, not much, and a six-shot revolver. Nothing that identifies him. He looks like a decent person, without being a gentleman. Something like a sailor, we believe.

en: Dorian started to his feet. A terrible hope fluttered past him. He clutched at it madly. “Where is the body?” he exclaimed. “Quick! I must see it at once.”
vi: Dorian stood up abruptly. A terrible hope fluttered across him. He desperately grasped at it. “Where is the body?” he shouted. “Quick! I must see it immediately.”
tr: Dorian jumped up from his seat. A tremendous hope fluttered past him. Dorian clung to this hope like a madman. “Where is the body?” he shouted. “Quick! I want to see it immediately.”
es: Dorian stood up. An impossible hope brushed him with its wing, and he clung to it frantically. —Where is the corpse? —he exclaimed—. Quickly! I must see it as soon as possible.

en: “It is in an empty stable in the Home Farm, sir. The folk don’t like to have that sort of thing in their houses. They say a corpse brings bad luck.”
vi: “It is in an empty stable at the Family Farm, sir. People don't like to keep that kind of thing in the house. They say dead bodies bring bad luck.”
tr: "By the farmhouse, in an empty barn, sir. No one wanted to take it into the house. They say the presence of the dead brings bad luck."
es: —In an empty barn on the farm, sir. Nobody wants to have something like that in their house. They say a corpse brings bad luck.

en: “The Home Farm! Go there at once and meet me. Tell one of the grooms to bring my horse round. No. Never mind. I’ll go to the stables myself. It will save time.”
vi: “Family Farm! Go there immediately and pick me up. Tell a stable hand to bring my horse here. No. Never mind. I will go to the stable myself. That will save time.”
tr: “The farmhouse, huh! You go there immediately and wait for me. Tell one of the grooms to bring my horse. But no, never mind. I'll go to the stable myself. I'll save some time.”
es: —The farm! Go there immediately and wait for me. Tell one of the stable boys to bring me the horse. No. Don't worry. I'll go to the stable myself. We'll save time.

en: In less than a quarter of an hour, Dorian Gray was galloping down the long avenue as hard as he could go. The trees seemed to sweep past him in spectral procession, and wild shadows to fling themselves across his path. Once the mare swerved at a white gate-post and nearly threw him. He lashed her across the neck with his crop. She cleft the dusky air like an arrow. The stones flew from her hoofs.
vi: In less than a quarter of an hour, Dorian Gray galloped down the long road under the trees, trying to run as fast as he could. The trees seemed to sweep past him in a ghostly procession, and wild shadows flung themselves across his path. Once the mare swerved at a white gatepost and nearly threw him off. He lashed its neck with the whip. It cut through the dim air like an arrow. Stones flew from its hooves.
tr: Before another quarter of an hour had passed, Dorian was riding his horse at full gallop along the long, tree-lined road. The trees flew past him like a parade of ghosts, and strange shadows seemed to throw themselves under his horse's hooves. At one point, when the horse suddenly veered at a white gate, it almost threw Dorian off its back. Dorian brought his whip down on its neck. The mare pierced through the dim air like an arrow, her hooves flinging stones into the air.
es: In less than a quarter of an hour, Dorian Gray was galloping down the grand avenue. The trees seemed to parade on either side like a procession of ghosts, and strange shadows furiously threw themselves in his path. On one occasion, the mare shied at a white post and nearly threw him off. Dorian struck her neck with the whip. The animal darted into the darkness like an arrow. Her hooves sent pebbles flying.

en: At last he reached the Home Farm. Two men were loitering in the yard. He leaped from the saddle and threw the reins to one of them. In the farthest stable a light was glimmering. Something seemed to tell him that the body was there, and he hurried to the door and put his hand upon the latch.
vi: Finally, you arrived at the Family Farm. Two men were wandering in the yard. You jumped off the saddle and threw the reins to one of them. In the farthest stable, a light flickered. Something seemed to tell you that the body was there, and you hurriedly ran to the door, placing your hand on the latch.
tr: Finally, they arrived at the farmhouse. Two men were standing in the yard. Dorian jumped to the ground and threw the reins to one of the men. A light was shining in the stable in front of him. As if a voice had told him the dead body was there, Dorian quickly walked to the door and reached for the latch.
es: Finally, he arrived at the farm and found two idle men in the yard. Dorian jumped off the saddle and threw the reins to one of them. A light flickered in the farthest stable. Something told him that the corpse was there. He ran to the door and put his hand on the doorknob.

en: There he paused for a moment, feeling that he was on the brink of a discovery that would either make or mar his life. Then he thrust the door open and entered.
vi: There, he paused for a moment, feeling that he was on the verge of a discovery that could either make or break his life. Then he pushed the door open and stepped inside.
tr: He paused here for a moment: He felt that he was on the verge of a discovery, one that would either save or ruin his life. Then he pushed the door open and entered.
es: Then he paused for a moment, feeling that he was about to make a discovery that would either revive his life or destroy it. Next, he flung the door open and entered.

en: On a heap of sacking in the far corner was lying the dead body of a man dressed in a coarse shirt and a pair of blue trousers. A spotted handkerchief had been placed over the face. A coarse candle, stuck in a bottle, sputtered beside it.
vi: On a pile of fabric for making sacks in the far corner, a human corpse was lying, dressed in a coarse shirt and blue pants. A spotted handkerchief was placed across the face. A crude candle, stuck in a bottle, sizzled beside it.
tr: The body of a man dressed in a coarse blue shirt and blue pants was laid on top of a pile of sacks in the opposite corner. A spotted handkerchief was draped over his face. Beside him, a cheap candle stuck into the mouth of a bottle was burning with a sputter.
es: On a pile of empty sacks, and in the corner farthest from the door, lay the corpse of a man dressed in a coarse cloth shirt and blue trousers. A polka-dotted handkerchief had been placed over his face. A poor-quality candle, sunk into the neck of a bottle, sputtered beside him.

en: Dorian Gray shuddered. He felt that his could not be the hand to take the handkerchief away, and called out to one of the farm-servants to come to him.
vi: Dorian Gray shuddered. He felt that he could not take out the handkerchief himself, and loudly called a tenant over to him.
tr: Dorian Gray shuddered. Realizing that he could not lift that handkerchief himself, he called one of the laborers over.
es: Dorian Gray shuddered. He felt that it could not be his hand that removed the handkerchief, and asked one of the laborers to come closer.

en: “Take that thing off the face. I wish to see it,” he said, clutching at the door-post for support.
vi: "Take that off your face. I want to see it," he said, grabbing the doorpost for support.
tr: Holding onto the doorpost, he said, "Take that thing off his face. I want to see!"
es: —Take off whatever is on his face. I want to see him —he said, holding onto the door jamb to avoid falling.

en: When the farm-servant had done so, he stepped forward. A cry of joy broke from his lips. The man who had been shot in the thicket was James Vane.
vi: When the tenant did so, he stepped forward. A cry of joy escaped his lips. The person shot in the bushes was James Vane.
tr: When the laborer did as he was told, Dorian stepped forward. A cry of joy escaped from his lips. The man who had been shot in the thicket was James Vane.
es: When the laborer did what they asked of him, Dorian Gray stepped forward. A cry of joy escaped from his lips. The dead man among the undergrowth was James Vane.

en: He stood there for some minutes looking at the dead body. As he rode home, his eyes were full of tears, for he knew he was safe.
vi: He stood there for a few minutes, looking at the corpse. When he rode the horse back home, his eyes were filled with tears, because he knew he was safe.
tr: Dorian stood there for minutes, looking at the dead. As he rode his horse towards home, his eyes were filled with tears because he knew he had escaped the danger.
es: He remained there for a few minutes, contemplating the corpse. Then he returned to the main house with his eyes full of tears, knowing that he was safe.

en: CHAPTER XIX.
vi: Chapter 19
tr: Nineteenth chapter
es: Chapter 19

en: “There is no use your telling me that you are going to be good,” cried Lord Henry, dipping his white fingers into a red copper bowl filled with rose-water. “You are quite perfect. Pray, don’t change.”
vi: "You told me that you would live decently, but it doesn't help at all," Lord Henry exclaimed, dipping his white fingers into a red copper bowl filled with rose water. "You are already perfect. Please, don't change."
tr: Lord Henry, "There is no use in saying I will be a good person," he said, dipping his white fingers into a copper bowl filled with rose water. "You are perfect. My dear, do not change."
es: —Don't tell me you're going to be good —exclaimed Lord Henry, dipping his fingers into a red copper bowl filled with rose water—. You are absolutely perfect. Do me a favor and don't change.

en: Dorian Gray shook his head. “No, Harry, I have done too many dreadful things in my life. I am not going to do any more. I began my good actions yesterday.”
vi: Dorian Gray shook his head. "No, Harry, I have done too many terrible things in my life. I will not do any more. I started doing good deeds from yesterday."
tr: Dorian Gray shook his head. "No, Harry, the ugly things I've done are more than enough. From now on, I repent. I started doing good things yesterday."
es: Dorian Gray moved his head. —No, Harry, no. I have done too many horrible things in my life. I am not going to do any more. Yesterday, I started with good deeds.

en: “Where were you yesterday?”
vi: "Where were you yesterday?"
tr: “Where were you yesterday?”
es: —Where were you yesterday?

en: “In the country, Harry. I was staying at a little inn by myself.”
vi: "In the countryside, Harry. I have checked myself into a small hotel."
tr: “I was outside the city. I stayed in a small inn, alone.”
es: —In the countryside, Harry. Alone, in a humble inn.

en: “My dear boy,” said Lord Henry, smiling, “anybody can be good in the country. There are no temptations there. That is the reason why people who live out of town are so absolutely uncivilized. Civilization is not by any means an easy thing to attain to. There are only two ways by which man can reach it. One is by being cultured, the other by being corrupt. Country people have no opportunity of being either, so they stagnate.”
vi: “My boy,” Lord Henry said, smiling, “anyone can be good in the countryside. There are no temptations there. That is why people who live outside the city are so completely uncivilized. Civilization is not something easily achieved. There are only two ways for a person to approach it. One is through education, the other is through corruption. Country folk have no opportunity for either, so they remain dull."
tr: Lord Henry, "My dear friend," he said with a smile. "Everyone behaves well outside the city. There is nothing seductive there. That is why those who live outside the city are quite far from civilization. Civilization is not something that is easy to attain. One can only reach civilization in two ways. One is by being cultured, the other by being immoral. Since those who live outside the city have no opportunity for either, they become stagnant waters covered with algae."
es: —My dear boy —said Lord Henry, smiling—, anyone can be good in the countryside, where there are no temptations. That is why people who do not live in cities still live in a state of barbarism. Civilization is not something that is easily achieved. There are only two ways. Either one is cultured or one is corrupt. Country people lack opportunities for both, so they only know stagnation.

en: “Culture and corruption,” echoed Dorian. “I have known something of both. It seems terrible to me now that they should ever be found together. For I have a new ideal, Harry. I am going to alter. I think I have altered.”
vi: “Education and corruption,” Dorian repeated. “I have known a little about both. Now I see something that seems very terrible: we always see them together. Because I have my new ideal, Harry. I am going to change. I think I have changed.”
tr: Repeating his friend's words, Dorian said, "Culture and immorality!" "I have experienced both to some extent. Their coexistence now terrifies me. Because I have adopted a new ideal. Harry. I will fundamentally change. I think I have already changed."
es: -Culture and corruption —repeated Dorian—. I know something about those two things. Now it seems terrible to me that they ever go together. Because I have a new ideal, Harry. I am going to change. I think I have already changed.

en: “You have not yet told me what your good action was. Or did you say you had done more than one?” asked his companion as he spilled into his plate a little crimson pyramid of seeded strawberries and, through a perforated, shell-shaped spoon, snowed white sugar upon them.
vi: “You haven't told me what your good deed is yet. Or did you just say that you have done more than one thing?” your friend asked, as he poured onto his plate a small red pyramid of hulled strawberries, and, through a perforated shell-shaped spoon, sprinkled white sugar on them like snow.
tr: Your friend said, "You didn't mention the good thing you did. Or was there more than one?" and as he asked, he toppled the small, red strawberry pyramid on his plate and sprinkled powdered sugar over them with a perforated, seashell-shaped spoon.
es: —You haven't told me what your good deed was yesterday. Or was it more than one? —asked his interlocutor, while pouring a small crimson pyramid of ripe strawberries onto his plate, then whitening them with sugar using a perforated spoon shaped like a shell.

en: “I can tell you, Harry. It is not a story I could tell to any one else. I spared somebody. It sounds vain, but you understand what I mean. She was quite beautiful and wonderfully like Sibyl Vane. I think it was that which first attracted me to her. You remember Sibyl, don’t you? How long ago that seems! Well, Hetty was not one of our own class, of course. She was simply a girl in a village. But I really loved her. I am quite sure that I loved her. All during this wonderful May that we have been having, I used to run down and see her two or three times a week. Yesterday she met me in a little orchard. The apple-blossoms kept tumbling down on her hair, and she was laughing. We were to have gone away together this morning at dawn. Suddenly I determined to leave her as flowerlike as I had found her.”
vi: "I can tell you, Harry. It's not a story I can tell anyone else. I let someone go. It sounds presumptuous, but you understand what I mean. She was very beautiful, and wonderful like Sibyl Vane. I think that was the first thing that attracted me to her. You still remember Sibyl, don't you? It seems like such a long time ago! There, Hetty is not a person of our class, of course. She is just a village girl. But I truly love her. I am sure that I have loved her. Throughout this wonderful month of May that we are enjoying, I often ran down to meet her two or three times a week. Yesterday she met me in a small garden. Apple blossoms kept falling onto her hair, and she laughed all the time. We planned to run away together this morning at dawn. Suddenly I was determined to leave her as untouched as the flower when I first saw her.”
tr: "I will tell you, Harry. This is not something I can tell anyone else but you. I spared a person! It sounds like boasting, but you understand what I mean. She was truly a beautiful girl; she resembled Sibyl Vane so much, it was uncanny. I think that was what first attracted me to her. You remember Sibyl, don't you? How it feels like it was a million years ago! Anyway, Hetty was not a girl from our class, naturally. A simple peasant girl. But I truly loved her. I am sure that I loved her. During this wonderful May we had, I would go and see her two or three times a week. Yesterday, we met in a small orchard. Apple blossoms were falling into her hair, and she was laughing. This morning at dawn, we were determined to run away together. Suddenly, I decided to leave her as I found her: like a flower."
es: —I can tell you, Harry, though no one else. I gave up harming a person. It seems pretentious, but you understand what I mean. She was very beautiful, and extraordinarily similar to Sibyl Vane. I think that was the first thing that attracted me to her. You remember Sibyl, don't you? How much time seems to have passed! Hetty, of course, is not someone of our standing, just a village girl. But I had fallen in love. I am completely sure that I loved her. During this wonderful month of May that we have enjoyed, I went to see her two or three times a week. Yesterday she met me in an orchard. The apple blossoms were falling on her hair and she laughed a lot. We were going to run away together this morning at dawn. Suddenly, I decided that she shouldn't change because of me.

en: “I should think the novelty of the emotion must have given you a thrill of real pleasure, Dorian,” interrupted Lord Henry. “But I can finish your idyll for you. You gave her good advice and broke her heart. That was the beginning of your reformation.”
vi: "I suppose the novelty of that emotion must have given you real excitement and joy, Dorian," Lord Henry interrupted. "But I can finish your pastoral poem for you. You gave her good advice, and broke her heart. That is the beginning of your reformation."
tr: Lord Henry, "This feeling being so new and different must have given you a real thrill of pleasure, Dorian," he interjected. "Still, let me conclude this rustic love story for you: You gave the girl very appropriate advice and disappointed her. The first step you took on the right path was this."
es: —I imagine that the novelty of that feeling must have given you a genuine thrill of pleasure —interrupted Lord Henry—. But I am in a position to tell you the end of your idyll. You gave her good advice and broke her heart. That has been the beginning of your amendment.

en: “Harry, you are horrible! You mustn’t say these dreadful things. Hetty’s heart is not broken. Of course, she cried and all that. But there is no disgrace upon her. She can live, like Perdita, in her garden of mint and marigold.”
vi: "Harry, you are really outrageous! You shouldn't say such terrible things. Hetty's heart isn't broken. Of course she cried, and things like that. But she wasn't humiliated. She can live, like Perdita, in her garden of mint and marigolds." 1 Character in William Shakespeare's play The Winter's Tale.
tr: “Harry, you are so bad! Don't say such unpleasant things! Hetty is not at all disappointed. She cried, of course, and so on. But her name wasn't tarnished! Just like Perdita, she can live a peaceful life in her garden full of mints and marigolds.”
es: —How unpleasant you are, Harry! You shouldn't say such dreadful things. Hetty's heart hasn't been broken. She cried, of course, and all that. But she hasn't lost her honor. She can live, like Perdita[18], in her garden of mint and marigolds.

en: “And weep over a faithless Florizel,” said Lord Henry, laughing, as he leaned back in his chair. “My dear Dorian, you have the most curiously boyish moods. Do you think this girl will ever be really content now with any one of her own rank? I suppose she will be married some day to a rough carter or a grinning ploughman. Well, the fact of having met you, and loved you, will teach her to despise her husband, and she will be wretched. From a moral point of view, I cannot say that I think much of your great renunciation. Even as a beginning, it is poor. Besides, how do you know that Hetty isn’t floating at the present moment in some starlit mill-pond, with lovely water-lilies round her, like Ophelia?”
vi: "And lamenting the fickle Florizel," Lord Henry said with a laugh, as he leaned back in his chair. "My dear Dorian, you have the most peculiar childish nature. Do you think that now this girl will ever truly be satisfied with anyone of her own class again? I suppose she will marry one day a rough coachman or a grinning plowman. See, having met you, having loved you, will teach her to scorn her husband, and she will suffer. From a moral standpoint, I can't say I think much of your great sacrifice. Even to begin with, it was poor. Besides, how do you know that Hetty is not at this moment floating in some starlit pond, with lovely water lilies around her, like Ophelia?" 2 Lovers of Perdita.
tr: Lord Henry laughed, "Shedding tears for the unfaithful Florizel," and leaned back. "My dear Dorian, you do such strange childish things sometimes! Do you think this girl can now be happy with someone from her own class? One day she will probably marry an unrefined coachman or a grinning laborer. And then, having known and loved you will teach her to despise her husband. And the poor girl will be unhappy. I can't say I place much moral value on this sacrifice of yours. It falls short even as a start. Besides, how do you know, maybe Hetty is lying in a starry mill pond right now, just like Ophelia, among the beautiful water lilies?"
es: —And cry over the infidelity of Florisel —said Lord Henry, laughing, as he leaned back in his chair—. My dear Dorian, you have curious adolescent ideas. Do you really think that girl will now be content with someone of her own station? I imagine that someday she will be married off to a foul-mouthed carter or a humorous farmer. And the fact that she has known you, and loved you, will allow her to despise her husband, which will make her perfectly miserable. From a moral standpoint, I can't say that your great renunciation impresses me much. Even as a modest beginning, it is very little. Besides, who is to say that at this moment Hetty is not floating in some star-lit pond surrounded by lilies, like Ophelia?

en: “I can’t bear this, Harry! You mock at everything, and then suggest the most serious tragedies. I am sorry I told you now. I don’t care what you say to me. I know I was right in acting as I did. Poor Hetty! As I rode past the farm this morning, I saw her white face at the window, like a spray of jasmine. Don’t let us talk about it any more, and don’t try to persuade me that the first good action I have done for years, the first little bit of self-sacrifice I have ever known, is really a sort of sin. I want to be better. I am going to be better. Tell me something about yourself. What is going on in town? I have not been to the club for days.”
vi: “I can't stand this, Harry! You mock everything, then bring up the most serious tragedies. At this moment, I regret telling you. I don't care about what you say to me. I know I was right in doing what I did. Poor Hetty! When I rode past the farm this morning, I saw her pale face in the window, like a jasmine flower. Let's not talk about it anymore, and don't try to convince me that the first good thing I've done in years, the first small sacrifice I've ever known, is actually a sin. I want to live more kindly. I'm about to live more kindly. Tell me something about yourself. What's happening in the city? I haven't been to the club for many days."
tr: “I can't stand it, Harry! You make fun of everything, and then you touch upon the most bitter tragedies. I'm now a thousand times sorry that I told you. No matter what you say, it doesn't matter to me. I know I'm doing the right thing by acting this way. Poor Hetty! This morning, as I passed by the farm on my horse, I saw her pale face at the window; it was like a bunch of jasmine. Let's not talk about this anymore. This is the first good thing I've done in all these years, the first sacrifice of my life! Don't try to convince me that this is some kind of sin. I want to be a better person. I will be a better person. Tell me a bit about yourself. What's happening in the city? I haven't visited the cabin for days.”
es: —You are unbearable, Harry! You mock everything and then imagine the most dreadful tragedies. I'm sorry I told you about it. I don't care what you say. I know I have acted rightly. Poor Hetty! When I rode past her farm this morning, I saw her face at the window, like a bouquet of jasmine. Let's not talk about it anymore, and don't try to convince me that my first good deed in many years, my first attempt at self-sacrifice in my entire life, is actually just another sin. I want to be better. I'm going to be better. Tell me something about yourself. What's happening in London? It's been days since I went to the club.

en: “The people are still discussing poor Basil’s disappearance.”
vi: “Everyone is still talking about poor Basil's disappearance.”
tr: “Everyone is still talking about poor Basil's disappearance.”
es: —People are still talking about the disappearance of poor Basil.

en: “I should have thought they had got tired of that by this time,” said Dorian, pouring himself out some wine and frowning slightly.
vi: "I thought they would be tired of that by now," Dorian said, pouring himself some wine, and slightly grimacing.
tr: Dorian slightly grimaced and, pouring himself some wine, said, "I thought they would have been tired of this topic by now."
es: —I thought they would have gotten tired after so much time —exclaimed Dorian, pouring himself a bit more wine and slightly furrowing his brow.

en: “My dear boy, they have only been talking about it for six weeks, and the British public are really not equal to the mental strain of having more than one topic every three months. They have been very fortunate lately, however. They have had my own divorce-case and Alan Campbell’s suicide. Now they have got the mysterious disappearance of an artist. Scotland Yard still insists that the man in the grey ulster who left for Paris by the midnight train on the ninth of November was poor Basil, and the French police declare that Basil never arrived in Paris at all. I suppose in about a fortnight we shall be told that he has been seen in San Francisco. It is an odd thing, but every one who disappears is said to be seen at San Francisco. It must be a delightful city, and possess all the attractions of the next world.”
vi: “My dear boy, they have only been talking about it for six weeks, and the British public really cannot endure the mental strain of having more than one topic every three months. However, they have been very fortunate lately. They had my divorce and Alan Campbell's suicide. Now they have the mysterious disappearance of an artist. Scotland Yard still insists that the man in the gray ulster who left for Paris on the midnight train on November ninth was poor Basil, while the French police declare that Basil never arrived in Paris at all. I suppose in about a fortnight they will tell us that he has been seen in San Francisco. It is odd, but everyone who disappears is said to be seen in San Francisco. It must be a delightful city, and possess all the attractions of the next world.”
tr: “My dear, they've only been talking for six weeks. If the English society changes the topic it talks about before three months or adds an extra topic, it cannot withstand the mental stress! Still, they've had some luck recently. They talked about my divorce case, then Alan Campbell’s suicide. And now, the mystery of a painter's disappearance. Scotland Yard still insists that the man in the gray coat who left London on the midnight train on November 9th was not poor Basil. The French police, however, claim that Basil definitely did not set foot in Paris. In ten to fifteen days, we'll probably hear that he was seen in San Francisco. It's strange, whenever someone disappears, it's said they were seen in San Francisco. It must be a wonderful city; it seems all the curiosities of the other world are there.”
es: —My dear boy, they've only been talking about it for six weeks, and the British public needs three months to endure the mental strain that a change of topic requires. Anyway, he has been quite lucky in recent times. First, there was my divorce case and Alan Campbell's suicide. Now they are offered the mysterious disappearance of an artist. Scotland Yard continues to insist that the person in a gray coat who took the midnight train to France on November ninth was poor Basil, and the French police claim that Hallward never arrived in Paris. I suppose that in a couple of weeks we will be told that he has been seen in San Francisco. It's a strange thing, but of all the people who disappear, it always ends up being said that they have been seen in San Francisco. It must be a charming city, and it possesses all the attractions of the world to come.

en: “What do you think has happened to Basil?” asked Dorian, holding up his Burgundy against the light and wondering how it was that he could discuss the matter so calmly.
vi: “What do you think happened to Basil?” Dorian asked, holding the Burgundy wine glass against the light, and marveling at how he could discuss this matter so calmly.
tr: Dorian asked, "What do you think happened to Basil?" while holding his glass of black wine up to the light. He was surprised at his own ability to discuss the matter so calmly.
es: —What do you think has happened to Basil? —asked Dorian, holding the glass of burgundy up to the light, and wondering how it was possible for him to speak about the matter so calmly.

en: “I have not the slightest idea. If Basil chooses to hide himself, it is no business of mine. If he is dead, I don’t want to think about him. Death is the only thing that ever terrifies me. I hate it.”
vi: “I have no idea at all. If Basil chooses to hide himself, it’s none of my business. If he is dead, I don't want to think about him anymore. Death is the only thing that has ever scared me. I hate it.”
tr: “I have absolutely no idea. If Basil has chosen to hide, it doesn't concern me. If he's dead, I don't want to think about him. The only thing that fills me with terror is death. I hate death.”
es: —I don't have the slightest idea. If Basil decides to hide, it's none of my business. If he is dead, I don't want to think about him. Death is the only thing that truly terrifies me. I abhor it.

en: “Why?” said the younger man wearily.
vi: “Why?” the younger person said, tiredly.
tr: Dorian asked in a listless voice, "Why?"
es: —Why? —asked the youngest one in a tired tone.

en: “Because,” said Lord Henry, passing beneath his nostrils the gilt trellis of an open vinaigrette box, “one can survive everything nowadays except that. Death and vulgarity are the only two facts in the nineteenth century that one cannot explain away. Let us have our coffee in the music-room, Dorian. You must play Chopin to me. The man with whom my wife ran away played Chopin exquisitely. Poor Victoria! I was very fond of her. The house is rather lonely without her. Of course, married life is merely a habit, a bad habit. But then one regrets the loss even of one’s worst habits. Perhaps one regrets them the most. They are such an essential part of one’s personality.”
vi: “Because,” Lord Henry said, passing under his nose the gold-plated latticework of an open vinaigrette, “one can survive everything nowadays except that. Death and vulgarity are the only two things in the nineteenth century that one cannot explain. Let's go have coffee in the music room, Dorian. You must play Chopin for me. The man my wife ran away with was an excellent Chopin player. Poor Victoria! I was very fond of her. The house is quite lonely without her. Of course, married life is just a habit, a bad habit. But we still regret the loss of even our worst habits. Perhaps we regret them the most. They are an essential part of our character.”
tr: Lord Henry passed the gilded cage of an open ammonia bottle under his nostrils and said, "Because nowadays one can survive any disaster except death." "If there are two phenomena that we haven't managed to eliminate in the nineteenth century, they are death and vulgarity. Dorian, let's have our coffee in the music room. Play me some Chopin. The man my wife ran away with played Chopin beautifully. Poor Victoria! I was very fond of her. The house feels a bit empty without her. Although married life is nothing but a habit, a bad habit, still one misses even the worst habits. Perhaps one misses the bad ones the most. They are such an indispensable part of one's personality."
es: —Because —responded Lord Henry, bringing a golden vinaigrette to his nose and inhaling the scent— nowadays one can survive everything, except that. Death and vulgarity are the two facts of the 19th century that lack explanation. We will have coffee in the music room, Dorian. You must play Chopin in my honor. The man with whom my wife ran away played Chopin in a truly exquisite manner. Poor Victoria! I was very fond of her. The house has become very lonely without her. Of course, married life is nothing but a habit, a bad habit. But the truth is that we regret the loss even of our worst habits. Perhaps they are the ones we regret the most. They are too essential a part of our personality.

en: Dorian said nothing, but rose from the table, and passing into the next room, sat down to the piano and let his fingers stray across the white and black ivory of the keys. After the coffee had been brought in, he stopped, and looking over at Lord Henry, said, “Harry, did it ever occur to you that Basil was murdered?”
vi: Dorian said nothing, but rose from the table and walked to the next room, sitting down at the piano and letting his fingers wander across the black and white ivory keys. After the coffee was brought in, he stopped, and, looking at Lord Henry, said, "Harry, have you ever thought that Basil might have been murdered?"
tr: Dorian stood up from the table without saying anything, went to the other room, and sat at the piano, letting his fingers roam over the black and white ivory keys. When the coffee was brought, he stopped playing the piano and looked towards Lord Henry, "Harry, did it ever occur to you that Basil might have been murdered?" he asked.
es: Dorian said nothing, but he got up from the table and, moving to the adjacent room, sat at the piano and let his fingers wander over the black and white ivory of the keys. When they brought the coffee, he stopped playing and, turning to Lord Henry, said: —Harry, has it ever occurred to you that perhaps Basil Hallward was murdered?

en: Lord Henry yawned. “Basil was very popular, and always wore a Waterbury watch. Why should he have been murdered? He was not clever enough to have enemies. Of course, he had a wonderful genius for painting. But a man can paint like Velasquez and yet be as dull as possible. Basil was really rather dull. He only interested me once, and that was when he told me, years ago, that he had a wild adoration for you and that you were the dominant motive of his art.”
vi: Lord Henry yawned. "Basil is very down-to-earth, and always wears a Waterbury watch. How could he possibly have been killed?" He wasn't even clever enough to have enemies. Of course, he had an extraordinary genius for painting. But a person can paint like Velasquez and still be stupid. Basil was really quite dull. He only caught my attention once, and that was when he told me, many years ago, that he was madly in love with you, and you were the central motif in his art." 1 A cheap type of watch at that time.
tr: Lord Henry yawned. “Basil was a much-loved person, and he always carried a Waterbury brand watch. Why would he be killed? He wasn't smart enough to make enemies. As a painter, he was a genius, of course. However, a person can paint like Velasquez and still be extremely dull and boring. Basil was indeed a bit dull. He only caught my interest once. That was years ago when he told you he adored you madly. He had said that you were the dominant force guiding his art.”
es: Lord Henry yawned. —Basil was very popular, and he always wore a Waterbury watch[19]. Why would anyone have wanted to murder him? He wasn't smart enough to make enemies. It's true that he had great talent for painting. But a person can paint like Velázquez and still be perfectly boring. Basil was. He only interested me once, and that was when he told me, years ago, that he adored you madly, and that you were the dominant motive of his art.

en: “I was very fond of Basil,” said Dorian with a note of sadness in his voice. “But don’t people say that he was murdered?”
vi: “I care about Basil a lot,” Dorian said, with a note of sadness in his voice. “But didn't people say he was murdered?”
tr: Dorian said with a tremor of sadness in his voice, "I loved Basil very much." "But isn't there anyone saying that he was murdered?"
es: —I was very fond of him —said Dorian with a note of sadness in his voice—. But, don't people say that he was murdered?

en: “Oh, some of the papers do. It does not seem to me to be at all probable. I know there are dreadful places in Paris, but Basil was not the sort of man to have gone to them. He had no curiosity. It was his chief defect.”
vi: “Oh, some newspapers mentioned it. I find it seems completely impossible. I know there are terrible places in Paris, but Basil is not the kind of person who would go there. He is not curious. That is his main weakness.”
tr: “Some newspapers write that way, but it doesn't seem like something that would happen to me. I know there are terrible places in Paris, but Basil is not the type of man to go to such places. He was never curious. That was his main flaw.”
es: —Some newspapers say so, but it doesn't seem likely to me at all. I know there are terrible places in Paris, but Basil wasn't the type of person who goes to those places. He wasn't curious. That was his main flaw.

en: “What would you say, Harry, if I told you that I had murdered Basil?” said the younger man. He watched him intently after he had spoken.
vi: “What would you say, Harry, if I told you that I had killed Basil?” the younger man said. He looked at him intently after he had finished speaking.
tr: Dorian asked, "Harry, what would you say if I told you I killed Basil?" As he spoke, he did not take his eyes off his friend's face.
es: —What would you say, Harry, if I confessed that I had murdered Basil? —said the younger man. Then he stared at him intently.

en: “I would say, my dear fellow, that you were posing for a character that doesn’t suit you. All crime is vulgar, just as all vulgarity is crime. It is not in you, Dorian, to commit a murder. I am sorry if I hurt your vanity by saying so, but I assure you it is true. Crime belongs exclusively to the lower orders. I don’t blame them in the smallest degree. I should fancy that crime was to them what art is to us, simply a method of procuring extraordinary sensations.”
vi: “I would say, my dear friend, that you are playing a character that does not suit you. All crime is vulgar, just as all vulgarity is a crime. You do not have the capacity, Dorian, to commit murder. I apologize if I hurt your pride by saying so, but I assure you that it is the truth. Crime belongs exclusively to the lower classes. I do not blame them at all. I can imagine that crime to them is like art to us, merely a method of seeking new sensations.”
tr: “You are playing a role that doesn't suit you, my friend, I would say. All serious crimes are vulgar, and at the same time, all vulgarities are serious crimes. Committing murder is not for you, Dorian. If saying this hurts your pride, I am sorry, but believe me, I am telling the truth. Serious crimes are entirely characteristic of the lower classes. I do not condemn them in the slightest. It seems to me that committing crimes for them is what art is for us: a method of creating extraordinary excitements.”
es: —I would say, my dear friend, that you are trying to play a role that does not suit you at all. Every crime is vulgar, just as everything vulgar is a crime. It is not in your nature, Dorian, to commit a murder. I regret hurting your vanity by saying this, but I assure you it is true. Crime belongs exclusively to the lower classes. I do not blame them in the slightest. I imagine that for them it is like art is for us, a way to procure extraordinary sensations.

en: “A method of procuring sensations? Do you think, then, that a man who has once committed a murder could possibly do the same crime again? Don’t tell me that.”
vi: “A method to find a strange sensation? So you think that a person who has committed murder once will be able to commit the same crime again? Don't tell me that.”
tr: “A method to create extraordinary excitement, huh? So, according to you, someone who has committed murder once can commit this crime again, right? This is no joke.”
es: —A way to procure sensations? Do you think, then, that a person who has once committed a murder could relapse into the same crime? Don't tell me that's true.

en: “Oh! anything becomes a pleasure if one does it too often,” cried Lord Henry, laughing. “That is one of the most important secrets of life. I should fancy, however, that murder is always a mistake. One should never do anything that one cannot talk about after dinner. But let us pass from poor Basil. I wish I could believe that he had come to such a really romantic end as you suggest, but I can’t. I dare say he fell into the Seine off an omnibus and that the conductor hushed up the scandal. Yes: I should fancy that was his end. I see him lying now on his back under those dull-green waters, with the heavy barges floating over him and long weeds catching in his hair. Do you know, I don’t think he would have done much more good work. During the last ten years his painting had gone off very much.”
vi: “Oh! Anything can become a joy if one does it too often,” the lord exclaimed, laughing loudly. “That is one of the most important secrets of life. However, I can imagine that murder is always a mistake. One should never do anything that one cannot recount after dinner. But let's leave poor Basil aside. I wish I could believe that he met a truly romantic end as you suggested; but I cannot. I am sure he fell into the Seine from a bus, and that the conductor covered up the scandal. Yes: I suppose that was his end. I see him now lying on his back under that murky water with heavy barges floating above him, and long weeds tangled in his hair. You know, I don't think he would have produced much better work anymore. In the last ten years, his paintings have become very dull.”
tr: Lord Henry laughed, "Oh, when you go to extremes, everything becomes a pleasure." "This is one of the most important secrets of life. In my opinion, committing murder is always a mistake. One should never do anything that cannot be talked about after dinner. But let's move on from poor Basil. I wish the romantic end you thought of had happened to him. But I don't think so. I think he fell from the carriage into the Seine River, and the driver covered it up. Yes, yes, I believe that was his end. I can almost see it now: lying on his back under those dull green waters, with heavy barges passing over him, long water reeds tangled in his hair. You know, I don't think Basil could have produced much good work after this. The quality of his work had significantly declined in the last ten years."
es: Don't tell me that's true. —Anything becomes a pleasure if done often enough —exclaimed Lord Henry, laughing—. That is one of the most important secrets of life. But it seems to me, anyway, that murder is always a mistake. One should never do anything that cannot be talked about after dinner. But let's forget about poor Basil. I would like to believe that he ended in as romantic a way as you suggest, but I can't. My opinion, rather, is that he fell into the Seine from the top of a bus, and the driver covered it up to avoid scandal. Yes; I imagine that's how it ended. I see him lying on his back under those matte green waters with heavy barges passing over him and seaweed tangled in his hair. You know? I don't think he would have done anything worthwhile in the future. For the last ten years, his painting had declined a lot.

en: Dorian heaved a sigh, and Lord Henry strolled across the room and began to stroke the head of a curious Java parrot, a large, grey-plumaged bird with pink crest and tail, that was balancing itself upon a bamboo perch. As his pointed fingers touched it, it dropped the white scurf of crinkled lids over black, glasslike eyes and began to sway backwards and forwards.
vi: Dorian let out a sigh, while Lord Henry strolled leisurely across the room and began to stroke the head of a strange Java parrot, a large gray-feathered bird with a pink tail and crest, balancing itself on a bamboo branch.
