As his sharp fingers touched it, it lowered the white membrane of its wrinkled eyelids over its glassy black eyes and began to sway back and forth.
tr: Dorian sighed, Lord Henry walked to the opposite corner and began to stroke the head of an interesting Java parrot balanced on a bamboo perch. It was a large bird with a pink crest and tail, and gray feathers. When Lord Henry's pointed fingers touched it, it lowered the white shell of its wrinkled eyelids over its glassy black eyes and began to sway back and forth.
es: Dorian let out a sigh, and Lord Henry crossed the room and began to stroke the head of a curious Java parrot, a large bird with gray plumage, red crest and tail, which balanced itself on a bamboo perch. When touched by those sharp fingers, it let the white foam of its wrinkled eyelids fall over eyes resembling black crystals, and began to sway.

en: “Yes,” he continued, turning round and taking his handkerchief out of his pocket; “his painting had quite gone off. It seemed to me to have lost something. It had lost an ideal. When you and he ceased to be great friends, he ceased to be a great artist. What was it separated you? I suppose he bored you. If so, he never forgave you. It’s a habit bores have. By the way, what has become of that wonderful portrait he did of you? I don’t think I have ever seen it since he finished it. Oh! I remember your telling me years ago that you had sent it down to Selby, and that it had got mislaid or stolen on the way. You never got it back? What a pity! it was really a masterpiece. I remember I wanted to buy it. I wish I had now. It belonged to Basil’s best period. Since then, his work was that curious mixture of bad painting and good intentions that always entitles a man to be called a representative British artist. Did you advertise for it? You should.”
vi: “Yes,” he continued, turning around, taking a handkerchief out of his pocket; “his paintings are indeed boring. It seems to me that they have lost something. They have lost an ideal. When you and he were no longer close friends, he also seemed to no longer be a great artist. What separated you two? I suppose he bored you. If so, he will never forgive you. That is a habit that boring people tend to have. By the way, what happened to the wonderful painting he made for you? I don't think I've ever seen it since he finished it. Oh! I remember you told me many years ago that you sent it down to Selby, and that it got lost or stolen on the way. Did you never get it back? What a pity! It was truly a masterpiece. I remember I wanted to buy it. I wish I had it now. It belonged to Basil's best period. Since then, his work has been a strange mix of bad painting and good intentions, something that always gives one the right to call him a typical English artist. Did you advertise for it? You should.”
tr: Lord Henry, turning back, continued, "Yes," he said. "The quality of his paintings had declined. Something was missing, in my opinion. An ideal had been lost. When his friendship with you ended, so did the greatness of his painting. By the way, why did you two drift apart? I suppose Basil must have bored you. In that case, he never forgave you. It's the nature of boring people. Speaking of which, he had painted a wonderful portrait of you, what happened to it? I don't think I ever saw it after it was finished. Oh, I remember; you sent it to Selby years ago and it got lost or stolen on the way. You never found it, did you? What a pity! It was a true masterpiece. I remember, I wanted to buy it. I wish I had! It was the best period of Basil's painting. Since then, his works have become a mix of good intentions and bad paintings, and for some reason, the man who draws this strange combination is deemed worthy of the title of exemplary English artist. Did you ever put out an ad for the portrait? You should."
es: —Yes —continued Lord Henry, turning around and taking a handkerchief out of his pocket—, he was painting worse and worse. It was as if he had lost something. Probably an ideal. When you stopped being great friends, Basil stopped being a great artist. What was it that separated you? I imagine he bored you immensely. If so, he never forgave you for it. It's a habit that boring people have. By the way, what happened to that wonderful portrait he made of you? I don't think I've seen it again since he finished it. Oh, yes! Years ago you told me, now I remember, that you had sent it to Selby and that it was lost or stolen along the way. Did you never recover it? What a pity! It was truly a masterpiece. I remember I wanted to buy it. I wish I had done so. It belonged to Basil's best period. Since then, his work has had that curious mix of bad painting and good intentions that always gives one the right to say someone is a representative British artist. Didn't you publish ads to try to recover it? You should have done so.

en: “I forget,” said Dorian. “I suppose I did. But I never really liked it. I am sorry I sat for it. The memory of the thing is hateful to me. Why do you talk of it? It used to remind me of those curious lines in some play—Hamlet, I think—how do they run?—
vi: “I forgot,” Dorian said. “I think I did. But I never really liked it. I regret having sat for it. The memory of it is really unpleasant to me. Why do you talk about it? It often reminds me of those strange lines in some play — Hamlet, I think — how does it go?...
tr: Dorian said, "I don't remember." "I probably gave it away. Anyway, I never really liked that portrait. I even hate its memory. Why did you bring it up? That portrait reminded me of some strange lines I heard in a play. I think it was in Hamlet. Let me see, how did it go?
es: —I don't remember —said Dorian—. I suppose I did. But the truth is that I never really liked it. I'm sorry I posed for him. His memory is odious to me. Why do you talk about that portrait? It always reminded me of those curious verses from some play, I think Hamlet... how do they go, exactly?

en: “Like the painting of a sorrow,
vi: Like a sorrowful painting,
tr: Like a picture of sorrow,
es: Or are you like an image of sorrow,

en: A face without a heart.”
vi: A heartless face.
tr: A face without a heart.
es: like a face without a soul?

en: Yes: that is what it was like.”
vi: Yes: it is like that."
tr: Yes, the portrait was just like that."
es: Yes: that is what it was.

en: Lord Henry laughed. “If a man treats life artistically, his brain is his heart,” he answered, sinking into an arm-chair.
vi: Lord Henry laughed. "If one looks at life as an artist, his brain is his heart," he replied, lowering himself into an armchair.
tr: Lord Henry laughed. "If one treats life as a work of art, the heart is the brain," he said, sinking into an armchair.
es: Lord Henry burst out laughing. —If a person treats life artistically, their brain is their soul —he replied, sinking into an armchair.

en: Dorian Gray shook his head and struck some soft chords on the piano. “‘Like the painting of a sorrow,’” he repeated, “‘a face without a heart.’”
vi: Dorian Gray shook his head, gently striking a few chords on the piano. "Like the sorrowful painting," he repeated, "a heartless face."
tr: Dorian Gray shook his head, then played a few soft notes on the piano. "Like a picture of sadness," he repeated. "A face without a heart."
es: Dorian Gray shook his head and drew some melancholy chords from the piano. —"Image of pain" —he repeated—, "soulless face."

en: The elder man lay back and looked at him with half-closed eyes. “By the way, Dorian,” he said after a pause, “‘what does it profit a man if he gain the whole world and lose—how does the quotation run?—his own soul’?”
vi: The older man lay on his back, looking at him with half-closed eyes. "Ah, Dorian," he said, after a moment of hesitation, "what does it profit a man if he gains the whole world but loses' — how is that quote written again? — 'his own soul'?"
tr: His friend leaned back, eyeing him with half-closed eyes. A little later, he said, "Ah, Dorian." "There is a saying: A man who has lost his soul, even if he owns the whole world... How did it go after that?.. How much would it be worth... was it?"
es: His older friend reclined in the armchair and gazed at him with half-closed eyes. —By the way, Dorian —he said, after a pause—, "What does it profit a man"..., how exactly does the quote end?, "to gain the whole world and lose his own soul[20]?"

en: The music jarred, and Dorian Gray started and stared at his friend. “Why do you ask me that, Harry?”
vi: The music screeched and Dorian Gray started, staring intently at his friend. “Why do you ask me that, Harry?”
tr: The notes got mixed up; Dorian Gray started and stared at his friend's face. "Why are you asking me this, Harry?"
es: The piano let out a discordant note and Dorian Gray, startled, turned to look at Lord Henry. —Why do you ask me that, Harry?

en: “My dear fellow,” said Lord Henry, elevating his eyebrows in surprise, “I asked you because I thought you might be able to give me an answer. That is all. I was going through the park last Sunday, and close by the Marble Arch there stood a little crowd of shabby-looking people listening to some vulgar street-preacher. As I passed by, I heard the man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being rather dramatic. London is very rich in curious effects of that kind. A wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a mackintosh, a ring of sickly white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase flung into the air by shrill hysterical lips—it was really very good in its way, quite a suggestion. I thought of telling the prophet that art had a soul, but that man had not. I am afraid, however, he would not have understood me.”
vi: “My dear friend,” Lord Henry said, raising an eyebrow in surprise, “I asked you because I thought you might be able to give me an answer. That's all. Last Sunday, I was passing through the Park, and near the Marble Arch, there was a small group of haggard-looking people listening to some mediocre street preacher. As I walked by, I heard him shout that question to his audience. It caught my attention because it was quite dramatic. London is very rich in such strange impressions. A rainy Sunday, a coarse Christian zealot in a raincoat, a circle of pale, sickly faces under the arch bobbing from waterlogged umbrellas, and a soul-stirring proclamation thrown into the air by frenzied, shrill lips — it was truly quite wonderful in its own way, a real suggestion. I thought about telling that prophet that Art has a soul, but man does not. I fear, however, that he might not have understood me.”
tr: Lord Henry raised his eyebrows in surprise and replied, "My dear, I asked because I thought you might be able to inform me." "That's all. Last Sunday, I was passing through the park; near the Marble Arch, a group of shabbily dressed men had stopped and were listening to a scruffy street preacher. As I passed by, I heard the fellow shouting this question to his listeners. It struck me as quite dramatic. Our London is indeed very rich in such strange scenes. A rainy Sunday, a scruffy Christian in a raincoat, a tattered roof formed by dripping umbrellas, and pale white faces gathered underneath... Then a splendid sentence thrown into the air in a shrill, hysterical voice... It was truly extraordinary in its own way, quite affecting. I felt like telling that so-called prophet: Art has a soul, but man does not. But he wouldn't have understood what I meant, anyway."
es: —My dear friend —said Lord Henry, raising his eyebrows in a gesture of surprise—, I asked you because I thought you capable of giving me an answer. That's all. When I was walking through the Park this past Sunday, I came across, near Marble Arch, a small group of poorly dressed people listening to a vulgar street preacher. As I was passing by, I heard that man shouting that question to his audience. It all seemed quite dramatic to me. London abounds with curious effects like that. A rainy Sunday, a vulgar Christian in a raincoat, a circle of pale sickly faces under an uneven roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase thrown into the air by hysterical lips and a shrill voice... it was quite good, in its own way: quite suggestive. It occurred to me to tell the prophet that Art does have a soul, but not the human being. I'm very much afraid, however, that he wouldn't have understood me.

en: “Don’t, Harry. The soul is a terrible reality. It can be bought, and sold, and bartered away. It can be poisoned, or made perfect. There is a soul in each one of us. I know it.”
vi: “Don't, Harry. The soul is a terrible thing that truly exists. It can be bought and sold. It can be poisoned, or made perfect. There is a soul in each of us. I know.”
tr: “You know, Harry. The soul is an amazing reality. It can be bought, sold, and traded. It is possible to poison the soul or to elevate it. We all have a soul within us. I know this.”
es: —Don't say that, Harry. The soul is a terrible reality. It can be bought and sold, and even traded. It can be poisoned or perfected. Each and every one of us has a soul. I know it very well.

en: “Do you feel quite sure of that, Dorian?”
vi: "Do you feel certain about that, Dorian?"
tr: “Are you absolutely sure about this, Dorian?”
es: —Are you sure, Dorian?

en: “Quite sure.”
vi: “Sure.”
tr: “Absolutely.”
es: —Completely sure.

en: “Ah! then it must be an illusion. The things one feels absolutely certain about are never true. That is the fatality of faith, and the lesson of romance. How grave you are! Don’t be so serious. What have you or I to do with the superstitions of our age? No: we have given up our belief in the soul. Play me something. Play me a nocturne, Dorian, and, as you play, tell me, in a low voice, how you have kept your youth. You must have some secret. I am only ten years older than you are, and I am wrinkled, and worn, and yellow. You are really wonderful, Dorian. You have never looked more charming than you do to-night. You remind me of the day I saw you first. You were rather cheeky, very shy, and absolutely extraordinary. You have changed, of course, but not in appearance. I wish you would tell me your secret. To get back my youth I would do anything in the world, except take exercise, get up early, or be respectable. Youth! There is nothing like it. It’s absurd to talk of the ignorance of youth. The only people to whose opinions I listen now with any respect are people much younger than myself. They seem in front of me. Life has revealed to them her latest wonder. As for the aged, I always contradict the aged. I do it on principle. If you ask them their opinion on something that happened yesterday, they solemnly give you the opinions current in 1820, when people wore high stocks, believed in everything, and knew absolutely nothing. How lovely that thing you are playing is! I wonder, did Chopin write it at Majorca, with the sea weeping round the villa and the salt spray dashing against the panes? It is marvellously romantic. What a blessing it is that there is one art left to us that is not imitative! Don’t stop. I want music to-night. It seems to me that you are the young Apollo and that I am Marsyas listening to you. I have sorrows, Dorian, of my own, that even you know nothing of. The tragedy of old age is not that one is old, but that one is young. I am amazed sometimes at my own sincerity. Ah, Dorian, how happy you are! What an exquisite life you have had! You have drunk deeply of everything. You have crushed the grapes against your palate. Nothing has been hidden from you. And it has all been to you no more than the sound of music. It has not marred you. You are still the same.”
vi: "Ah! Then it must be an illusion. The things we are completely certain about never actually exist. That is the risk of Faith, the lesson of Love. Why are you so serious! Don't be so serious. What do you or I have to do with the superstitions of our age? No: I have abandoned my belief in the soul. Play something for me. Play a nocturne for me, Dorian, and, as you play, tell me softly how you have kept your youth. Surely you must have some secret. I am only ten years older than you, yet I am wrinkled, tired, and sallow. You are marvelous, Dorian. You have never looked more charming than you do tonight. You remind me of the day I first saw you. You were quite insolent, very shy, and absolutely extraordinary. You have changed, of course, but not in appearance. I wish you would tell me your secret. To be young again, I would do anything in the world, except take exercise, get up early, or be respectable. Youth! Nothing is like it. It's really foolish to talk about the ignorance of youth. The only people whose opinions I still listen to with a bit of respect now are those much younger than me. They seem to be ahead of me. Life reveals to them its latest wonders. As for the old, I always have conflicts with the old. I do it on principle. If you ask their opinion on something that happened yesterday, they will solemnly tell you the prevailing opinions of 1820, when people still wore high socks, believed everything, and knew nothing. How lovely the thing you are playing is! I wonder if Chopin wrote it in Majorca, with the sea crying around the house, and salt spraying up on the window panes? It's extraordinarily romantic. How fortunate that there is still an art left to us that cannot be imitated! Don't stop. I need music tonight. I feel as if you are young Apollo, and I am Marsyas listening to you. I have my own sorrows, Dorian, that even you absolutely do not know. The tragedy of old age is not that one is old, but that one is young. I sometimes marvel at my own honesty. Oh, Dorian, how happy you are! What a wonderful life you have had! You have drained everything. You have crushed grapes on your palate. Nothing is hidden from you. And it is to you nothing more than music. It hasn't spoiled you. You are still the same.”
tr: “Hmm. It must be an illusion. The things one is a hundred percent sure of are never true. This is the disaster of faith and the lesson taught by romanticism. How serious you are! My dear, don't be so serious. What do you and I have to do with the blind beliefs of our age? No, no, we are people who have given up our belief in the existence of the soul. Play me something. Play me a nocturne, Dorian. And while playing, tell me in a low voice how you have kept your youth. You must know a secret. I am only ten years older than you, yet I am wrinkled, worn out, and faded. You truly seem to be something extraordinary. You remind me of the day I first saw you. Somewhat arrogant, very shy, you were something unseen. You have changed, naturally, but not in appearance. I wish you would tell me your secret. I would do anything to get my youth back: anything except exercise, getting up early, and being a respectable citizen. Oh youth! Is there anything like youth? How ridiculous it is to talk about the ignorance of youth! Nowadays, the only people whose opinions I listen to with respect are those who are considerably younger than me. They seem to have surpassed me. Life has revealed its latest marvel to them. As for the old; I oppose every thought of the old. I do this as a principle. Ask them their opinion about something that happened yesterday: They will tell you the views that were valid in the 1820s, the days when everyone wore long socks, believed in everything, and knew nothing. What you are playing is so beautiful! Did Chopin write this in Majorca? While the sea wept at the foot of his villa, and the salty foam hit the window panes? Wonderful romantic. What a great blessing it is that we still have at least one art form that is not imitative! Don't stop. I want music tonight. It feels as if you are Apollo, and I am Marsyas listening to you. Oh, Dorian, I have such sorrows of my own that even you do not know. The tragedy of old age is not that one is old, but that one is young. Sometimes I am amazed at my own sincerity. Oh, Dorian, how lucky you are! What a wonderful life you have led! You have lived everything to the fullest. You have tasted the pleasures of the world. There is no secret left in life for you. Yet you have passed through all of this as if listening to music. No bad trace remains on you. You are still what you were.”
es: —Ah! then it must be an illusion. The things one is completely sure of are never true. That is the fatality of faith and the lesson of romanticism. What a solemn air! Don't get so serious. What do you and I have to do with the superstitions of our time? No; we have renounced believing in the soul. Play a nocturne for me, Dorian, and while you play, tell me, in a low voice, how you have managed to keep your youth. You must have some secret. I'm only ten years older than you, but I have wrinkles and I'm worn and yellow. You are truly admirable, Dorian. You have never seemed so charming to me as tonight. You make me remember the day I met you. You were quite impertinent, very shy, and absolutely extraordinary. You have changed, of course, but your appearance has not. I would like you to tell me your secret. I would do anything to regain youth, except exercise, get up early, or be respectable... Youth! There is nothing like youth. It is absurd to talk about the ignorance of youth. The only people whose opinions I listen to with respect are those much younger than me. They seem to be ahead of me. Life has revealed its latest wonders to them. As for older people, I always contradict them. I do it on principle. If you ask their opinion about something that happened yesterday, they solemnly give you the opinions that were current in 1820, when people wore high stockings, believed in everything, and knew absolutely nothing. How beautiful is that which you are playing! I wonder if Chopin wrote it in Mallorca, with the sea crying around the villa where he lived, and with drops of salt water hitting the windows. Wonderfully romantic! It is a blessing that we still have a non-imitative art! Don't stop. Tonight I need music. You seem to me like young Apollo, and I am Marsyas, listening to you. I have my own sufferings, Dorian, of which even you are unaware. The tragedy of old age is not being old, but young. Sometimes my own sincerity surprises me. Ah, Dorian, how happy you are! What an exquisite life you have! You have drunk your fill of all pleasures. You have tasted the ripest grapes. Nothing has been hidden from you. And all of it has been nothing more to you than a few musical bars. Nothing has spoiled you. You remain the same.

en: “I am not the same, Harry.”
vi: “I'm not like that anymore, Harry.”
tr: “I'm not, Harry.”
es: —I'm not the same, Harry.

en: “Yes, you are the same. I wonder what the rest of your life will be. Don’t spoil it by renunciations. At present you are a perfect type. Don’t make yourself incomplete. You are quite flawless now. You need not shake your head: you know you are. Besides, Dorian, don’t deceive yourself. Life is not governed by will or intention. Life is a question of nerves, and fibres, and slowly built-up cells in which thought hides itself and passion has its dreams. You may fancy yourself safe and think yourself strong. But a chance tone of colour in a room or a morning sky, a particular perfume that you had once loved and that brings subtle memories with it, a line from a forgotten poem that you had come across again, a cadence from a piece of music that you had ceased to play—I tell you, Dorian, that it is on things like these that our lives depend. Browning writes about that somewhere; but our own senses will imagine them for us. There are moments when the odour of lilas blanc passes suddenly across me, and I have to live the strangest month of my life over again. I wish I could change places with you, Dorian. The world has cried out against us both, but it has always worshipped you. It always will worship you. You are the type of what the age is searching for, and what it is afraid it has found. I am so glad that you have never done anything, never carved a statue, or painted a picture, or produced anything outside of yourself! Life has been your art. You have set yourself to music. Your days are your sonnets.”
vi: “Right: you are still the same. I wonder what the rest of your life will be like. Don't ruin it with abandonments. Right now you are a perfect model. Don't turn yourself into an incomplete person. You are now completely flawless. You don't need to shake your head: you know you are. Moreover, Dorian, don't deceive yourself. Life is not governed by will or purpose. Life is a matter of nerves, fibers, and slowly growing cells, where thought hides and passion has its own dreams. You may think you are safe, and believe you are strong. But a chance tone in a room or on the morning sky, a particular scent you once loved and that carries with it magical memories, a line from some forgotten poem that you happen to come across, a melody from a piece of music that you have stopped playing — I tell you, Dorian, that our lives depend on such things. Browning wrote about them somewhere; but our own emotions will imagine them for us. There are moments when the scent of lilas blanc1 suddenly passes by me, and I have to relive the strangest honeymoon of my life once again. I wish I could trade places with you, Dorian. People complain about both of us, but they always worship you. They will always worship you. You are the quintessential model of what this age seeks, and what I fear it has found. I am very glad that you have never done anything, never sculpted a statue, painted a picture, or created anything outside of yourself! Life is your art. You have set your own music. Your days are your sonnet.” 1 White lilac.
tr: “No, no, you are always the same. I am very curious about how your life will go on from now. Don't ruin it with sacrifices. You are perfect as you are, complete. Don't diminish. You are flawless now. There's no need to shake your head: you know you are flawless. And besides, don't deceive yourself, Dorian. Life is not governed by will or intention. Life is a matter of nerves and fibers, a matter of cells. Our thoughts enter and hide in these slowly forming cells, our passions dwell and dream there. You may think you are safe, you may believe you are strong. But then a shade of color that randomly catches your eye in a room or in the morning sky, the hidden memories brought by a scent you once loved, a melody from music you haven't heard in a long time, a line from a forgotten poem that reappears... Believe me, Dorian, our lives depend on such things. Browning wrote a poem on this subject. Then our own senses sometimes remember and dream of these things on our behalf. There are moments when the scent of white lilac suddenly comes to my nose, and I am forced to relive the strangest month of my life. Oh, Dorian, I wish I could trade places with you! Our surroundings often condemned both of us, but they always adored you. And they always will. You are the image that our age both seeks and fears to find. I am so glad you have never produced a single thing in your life! You have neither sculpted a statue nor painted a picture nor created anything, except yourself! Life became your art. You composed yourself. The days you lived are your poems.”
es: —Yes, you are. I wonder what the rest of your life will be like. Don't ruin it with renunciations. At the present moment, you are perfection itself. Don't make yourself voluntarily incomplete. You lack nothing. Don't shake your head: you know it's true. Moreover, Dorian, don't deceive yourself. Life is not governed by will or intention. Life is a matter of nerves, of fibers, and of slowly elaborated cells in which thought hides and passion has its dreams. You might imagine that you are safe and believe that you are strong. But a casual change of color in a room or in the morning sky, a certain perfume that you liked once and that brings back subtle memories, a verse from a forgotten poem that you stumble upon again, a cadence from a musical composition that you have stopped playing... I assure you, Dorian, that life depends on things like those. Browning writes about it somewhere, but our own senses invent it for us. There are moments when the smell of white lilacs suddenly overpowers me, and I have to relive the strangest month of my life. I would gladly change places with you, Dorian. The world never tires of denouncing us both, but it has always worshipped you. And it always will. You are the prototype of what this era of ours seeks and fears it has found. I am so glad that you have never done anything, never carved a statue, nor painted a picture, nor produced anything other than yourself! Life has been your art. You have made music of yourself. Your days are your sonnets.

en: Dorian rose up from the piano and passed his hand through his hair. “Yes, life has been exquisite,” he murmured, “but I am not going to have the same life, Harry. And you must not say these extravagant things to me. You don’t know everything about me. I think that if you did, even you would turn from me. You laugh. Don’t laugh.”
vi: Dorian stood up from the piano and ran his hand through his hair. “Yes, life is wonderful,” he whispered, “but I will not live that kind of life anymore, Harry. And you shouldn't speak too highly of me. You don't know everything about me. I think that if you knew, you might even turn your back on me. You laugh? Don't laugh.”
tr: Dorian got up from the piano and ran his hand through his hair. “Yes, I have led a delightful life,” he murmured. “However, I am not going to lead the same life, Harry. Don't say such extravagant things to me. You don't know me at all. If you did, I think you would turn away from me. You are laughing. Don't laugh.”
es: Dorian got up from the piano and ran his hand through his hair. —Yes; life has given me exquisite pleasures —he murmured—, but I am going to change, Harry. And you must not give me such excessive praise. You don't know everything. I think that if you knew, you too would distance yourself from me. You laugh. You shouldn't do that.

en: “Why have you stopped playing, Dorian? Go back and give me the nocturne over again. Look at that great, honey-coloured moon that hangs in the dusky air. She is waiting for you to charm her, and if you play she will come closer to the earth. You won’t? Let us go to the club, then. It has been a charming evening, and we must end it charmingly. There is some one at White’s who wants immensely to know you—young Lord Poole, Bournemouth’s eldest son. He has already copied your neckties, and has begged me to introduce him to you. He is quite delightful and rather reminds me of you.”
vi: “Why did you stop playing, Dorian? Turn back and play that nocturne for me again. Look at the great honey-colored moon hanging in the dim sky. She is waiting for you to charm her, and if you play, she will come closer to the earth. Are you stopping? Then let's go to the club. This evening is so beautiful, and we must end it beautifully. Someone at White's is very eager to meet you — young Lord Poole, the eldest son of Bournemouth. He has been imitating your tie and keeps asking me to introduce you to him. He is quite interesting, and somewhat reminds me of you.”
tr: “Why did you stop playing, Dorian? Go and play that nocturne for me again. Look at the huge amber-colored moon hanging in the shadowy sky. It is waiting for the magic of your music. If you play the piano, it will come closer. You're not playing, huh? Let's go to the club then. We had a very beautiful evening, let's end it nicely. There's someone at White's who is dying to meet you: Young Lord Poole. The eldest son of Bournemouth. He already wears ties like yours and keeps begging me to introduce you. A very charming, attractive young man, he reminds me a bit of you.”
es: —Why did you stop playing, Dorian? Go back to the piano and delight me again with that nocturne. Look at the enormous honey-colored moon hanging in the darkness. It is waiting for you to enchant it, and if you play, it will come closer to the earth. Don't you want to? Then let's go to the club. It has been a delightful evening and we should end it in the same manner. There is someone at the White who has an immense desire to meet you: it's young Lord Poole, the eldest son of Bournemouth. He has already copied your ties, and now he begs me to introduce you to him. He is a charming boy and reminds me a lot of you.

en: “I hope not,” said Dorian with a sad look in his eyes. “But I am tired to-night, Harry. I shan’t go to the club. It is nearly eleven, and I want to go to bed early.”
vi: “I hope not,” Dorian said, with a sad look in his eyes. “But tonight I'm a bit tired, Harry. I can't go to the club. It's almost eleven o'clock, and I want to go to bed early.”
tr: Dorian turned his eyes to the ground with a sad look and said, "I hope he doesn't resemble me." "I'm tired tonight, Harry. I'm not going to the club. It's almost eleven o'clock. I want to go to bed early."
es: —I hope not —said Dorian, with a sad expression in his eyes—. The truth is that tonight I'm tired, Harry. I'm not going to the club. It's almost eleven and I want to go to bed early.

en: “Do stay. You have never played so well as to-night. There was something in your touch that was wonderful. It had more expression than I had ever heard from it before.”
vi: "Then stay. You have never played as well as you did tonight. There is something wonderful in your playing. It is much more expressive than anything I have ever heard from it before."
tr: "Please don't go. You have never played the piano as beautifully as you did tonight. Your performance tonight was marvelous. I have never heard you play with such meaning before."
es: —Stay, please. You have never played as well as you did tonight. There was something wonderful about your style. It was more expressive than ever.

en: “It is because I am going to be good,” he answered, smiling. “I am a little changed already.”
vi: “That is because I am about to live kindly,” he replied, smiling, “I have changed a bit.”
tr: Dorian replied with a smile, "Because I am determined to be a good person." "I feel like I've already changed a little bit."
es: —That is because I am going to be good —he replied, smiling—. I have already changed a bit.

en: “You cannot change to me, Dorian,” said Lord Henry. “You and I will always be friends.”
vi: "You cannot change with me, Dorian," Lord Henry said. "You and I will always be friends."
tr: Lord Henry, "In my eyes, you can never change, Dorian," he said. "We will remain friends for life."
es: —You cannot change for me —said Lord Henry—. You and I will always be friends.

en: “Yet you poisoned me with a book once. I should not forgive that. Harry, promise me that you will never lend that book to any one. It does harm.”
vi: “However, you poisoned me with a book, before. I cannot forgive that. Harry, promise me that you will never lend that book to anyone else again. It is harmful.”
tr: "Yet once upon a time, you poisoned me with a book. For this reason, I should never forgive you. Harry, swear that you will not give this book to anyone. It causes a lot of harm."
es: —On one occasion, however, you poisoned me with a book. I will not forget that. Harry, promise me that you will never lend that book to anyone. It causes harm.

en: “My dear boy, you are really beginning to moralize. You will soon be going about like the converted, and the revivalist, warning people against all the sins of which you have grown tired. You are much too delightful to do that. Besides, it is no use. You and I are what we are, and will be what we will be. As for being poisoned by a book, there is no such thing as that. Art has no influence upon action. It annihilates the desire to act. It is superbly sterile. The books that the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame. That is all. But we won’t discuss literature. Come round to-morrow. I am going to ride at eleven. We might go together, and I will take you to lunch afterwards with Lady Branksome. She is a charming woman, and wants to consult you about some tapestries she is thinking of buying. Mind you come. Or shall we lunch with our little duchess? She says she never sees you now. Perhaps you are tired of Gladys? I thought you would be. Her clever tongue gets on one’s nerves. Well, in any case, be here at eleven.”
vi: “My dear boy, you really are beginning to moralize. You will soon be going about like a converted person, and a missionary, warning everyone against all the sins you have grown tired of. You are far too delightful to do that. Besides, it is quite useless. Whatever we are, we are. As for being poisoned by a book, there is no such thing. Art has no influence upon action. It annihilates the desire to act. It is superbly sterile. The books that the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame. That is all. But we are not discussing literature. Come round tomorrow. I am going to ride at eleven. We might ride together, and then I will take you to lunch with Mrs. Branksome. She is a charming woman, and wants to consult you about some tapestries she is thinking of buying. Remember to come. Or shall we lunch with my little duchess? She says she never sees you now. Perhaps you are tired of Gladys? I think you are sure to be. Her clever tongue gets on one’s nerves. Well, anyhow, be here at eleven.”
tr: "My dear boy, you've already started giving moral lessons. At this rate, soon you'll be wandering around like those zealots who convert to religion later in life, warning everyone about the sins that once bored you. But you're so charming that it wouldn't suit you at all to do that. Besides, it wouldn't work anyway! You and I are who we are, and we'll always stay that way. As for being poisoned by books; that's impossible. Art has no effect on action. Art destroys the desire to act. It has a magnificent sterility. The books that society considers immoral are the ones that show society its own shame. That's all. But we're not going to have a literary debate. Come again tomorrow. I'm going out on horseback at eleven. Maybe we can go together. Then I'll take you to Lady Branksome for lunch. She's a very charming woman. She wanted to consult you about buying a few tapestries. Make sure you come, okay? Or should we have lunch with our little duchess instead? Apparently, you two aren't seeing each other anymore. Or have you grown tired of Gladys? I suspected as much. Her quick wit can get on one's nerves. Anyway, be here at eleven."
es: —My dear boy, it is true that you are beginning to moralize. Very soon you will go around like converts and evangelists, warning people against all the sins you have grown tired of. You are too charming to do such a thing. Besides, it is useless. You and I are what we are, and we will be what we will be. As for being poisoned by a book, no such thing exists. Art has no influence over action. It annihilates the desire to act. It is magnificently sterile. The books that the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame. That is all. But let's not argue about literature. Come see me tomorrow. I will go horseback riding at eleven. We can do it together and then I'll take you to lunch with Lady Branksome. She is a charming woman, and she wants to consult you about certain tapestries she is thinking of buying. Don't forget to come. Or do you think it's better if we have lunch with our little duchess? She says she never sees you anymore. Have you grown tired of Gladys? I thought it would eventually happen to you. That clever tongue of hers ends up exasperating anyone. Anyway, make sure to be here at eleven.

en: “Must I really come, Harry?”
vi: "Do I really have to go, Harry?"
tr: "Do I have to come, Harry?"
es: —Is it necessary for me to come, Harry?

en: “Certainly. The park is quite lovely now. I don’t think there have been such lilacs since the year I met you.”
vi: “Of course. The park is very beautiful now. I don't think there were ever lilacs like that there since the year I met you.”
tr: "It can't be." "The park is very beautiful this season." "I don't think the lilacs have ever bloomed like this since the year we met.""
es: —Of course. Now the Park is wonderful. I don't think there have ever been such beautiful lilacs since the year I met you.

en: “Very well. I shall be here at eleven,” said Dorian. “Good night, Harry.” As he reached the door, he hesitated for a moment, as if he had something more to say. Then he sighed and went out.
vi: “Alright. I will be here at eleven o'clock,” Dorian said. “Good night, Harry.” As he walked to the door, he hesitated for a moment, as if he had something more to say. Then he sighed and went out.
tr: "Well then," said Dorian. "I'll come at eleven. Good night, Harry." When he reached the door, he hesitated for a moment as if he had something more to say. Then he sighed and went outside.
es: —Very well. I will be here at eleven —said Dorian—. Good night, Harry. Upon reaching the door, he hesitated for a moment, as if he had something more to say. Then he let out a sigh and left the room.

en: CHAPTER XX.
vi: Chapter 20
tr: Twentieth chapter
es: Chapter 20

en: It was a lovely night, so warm that he threw his coat over his arm and did not even put his silk scarf round his throat. As he strolled home, smoking his cigarette, two young men in evening dress passed him. He heard one of them whisper to the other, “That is Dorian Gray.” He remembered how pleased he used to be when he was pointed out, or stared at, or talked about. He was tired of hearing his own name now. Half the charm of the little village where he had been so often lately was that no one knew who he was. He had often told the girl whom he had lured to love him that he was poor, and she had believed him. He had told her once that he was wicked, and she had laughed at him and answered that wicked people were always very old and very ugly. What a laugh she had!—just like a thrush singing. And how pretty she had been in her cotton dresses and her large hats! She knew nothing, but she had everything that he had lost.
vi: It was a beautiful night, so warm that he draped his coat over his arm and didn't even wrap his silk scarf around his neck. As he was leisurely walking home, smoking a cigarette, two young men in evening dress passed by him. He heard one of them whisper to the other, "That's Dorian Gray." He remembered how he used to feel pleased whenever he was pointed out, looked at, or talked about. Now he no longer cared to hear his own name. Half the charm of the small village he had been frequenting lately was that no one knew who he was. He often told the girl he had seduced that he was poor, and she believed him. Once he even told her that he was very wicked, and she laughed at him, replying that wicked people were always very old and very ugly. What a strange laugh she had! — just like a thrush singing. And how beautiful she looked in her cotton dresses and wide-brimmed hats! She knew nothing at all, but she had everything he had lost.
tr: It was a splendid night. The weather was so warm that Dorian slung his jacket over his arm and didn't even wrap his silk scarf around his neck. As he wandered back home, two young men in tuxedos passed by him. Dorian heard one of them whisper to the other, "That's Dorian Gray!" He remembered how he once enjoyed being pointed at, looked at, and talked about. Now he was sick of hearing his own name. The charm of that small village he had recently frequented was that no one there knew him. He had told the girl who had turned his head and stolen his heart that he was a poor young man, and she had believed him. One day, when Dorian told her that he was a very bad person, she laughed at him, claiming that truly bad-hearted people were always very old and very ugly. What a beautiful laugh she had! Like the chirping of birds. How beautiful she was in those calico dresses and big hats! She knew nothing, but she possessed everything that Dorian had lost.
es: The night air was a delight, so warm that Dorian Gray draped his coat over his arm and didn't even tie the silk scarf around his neck. As he headed home, smoking a cigarette, two young men in formal attire crossed paths with him, and he heard one whisper to the other, "That's Dorian Gray. "He remembered how much he used to enjoy being pointed at or stared at and talked about. Now he was tired of hearing his name. A large part of the charm of the little village he had been visiting so frequently lately was that no one knew him. To the girl he courted until she fell in love with him, he had said he was poor, and Hetty had believed him. On another occasion, he told her he was a wicked person, and she laughed, replying that the wicked were always very old and very ugly. Ah, her way of laughing! It was like the song of the lark. And how pretty she looked in her cotton dresses and wide-brimmed hats! Hetty knew nothing at all, but she possessed everything he had lost.

en: When he reached home, he found his servant waiting up for him. He sent him to bed, and threw himself down on the sofa in the library, and began to think over some of the things that Lord Henry had said to him.
vi: When he got home, he found the servant awake and waiting for him. He sent him to bed, threw himself onto the sofa in the library, and began to ponder some things that Lord Henry had said to him.
tr: When Dorian arrived home, he saw that his servant had not gone to bed and was waiting for him. After sending him to bed, he threw himself onto the sofa in the library and began to think about some of the things Lord Henry had said.
es: Upon arriving at his house, he found the valet waiting for him. He told him to go to bed, dropped onto a sofa in the library, and began to think about the things Lord Henry had told him.

en: Was it really true that one could never change? He felt a wild longing for the unstained purity of his boyhood—his rose-white boyhood, as Lord Henry had once called it. He knew that he had tarnished himself, filled his mind with corruption and given horror to his fancy; that he had been an evil influence to others, and had experienced a terrible joy in being so; and that of the lives that had crossed his own, it had been the fairest and the most full of promise that he had brought to shame. But was it all irretrievable? Was there no hope for him?
vi: Is it really true that people cannot change? Do you feel a maddening craving for the purity untouched by the dust of the world from your youth — your rosy-white youth, as Lord Henry once called it. You know that you have defiled yourself, have filled your soul with depravity and brought terrible visions into your imagination; that you have been a harmful influence on others, have tasted the dreadful pleasure of living like that; and that, in the lives that have encountered yours, it was the purest, most promising one that you have tainted. But can it all be restored? Is there any hope for you?
tr: Was it really true that a person could never change? Dorian's heart was overflowing with a wild longing for the unblemished purity of his youth – Lord Henry had once described it as rose-white. He had darkened his own self, filled his mind with evils, and fed his imagination with terrors; he had exerted a diabolical influence on others and derived a terrible pleasure from it; he had chosen the purest, most hopeful souls that crossed his path and driven them to shame. Dorian knew these things. And yet... Was it not possible to repair all this? Was there no hope left for Dorian?
es: Was it really true that one does not change? He felt a mad desire to regain the spotless purity of his adolescence; his pink and white adolescence, as Lord Henry had once called it. He knew that he was stained, that he had filled his spirit with corruption and fed his imagination with horrors; that he had exerted a harmful influence on others, and that he had experienced, in doing so, an indescribable joy; and that, of all the lives that had crossed paths with his, he had plunged precisely the most beautiful, the most promising ones into dishonor. But, was all that irremediable? Did he have no hope left?

en: Ah! in what a monstrous moment of pride and passion he had prayed that the portrait should bear the burden of his days, and he keep the unsullied splendour of eternal youth! All his failure had been due to that. Better for him that each sin of his life had brought its sure swift penalty along with it. There was purification in punishment. Not “Forgive us our sins” but “Smite us for our iniquities” should be the prayer of man to a most just God.
vi: Oh! In a strange moment of pride and passion, he had prayed that the portrait would bear the burden of his days, while he would retain the radiant, unblemished beauty of eternal youth! All his failures stemmed from that. It would have been better for him if every sin in his life had brought with it a sure and swift punishment. There is purification in punishment. Not "Forgive us our sins," but "Punish us for our wrongdoings" should be the prayer of man to the all-just God.
tr: Ah! How he had prayed in a moment of terrible pride and passion that his portrait might bear the burden of his days, and he himself might keep the untarnished glory of eternal youth! This had been the beginning of all his misfortunes. If only every sin he committed brought its sure, swift penalty with it, it would have been much better. There was something purifying in seeing punishment. The prayer that a man should address to a just god was not, “Forgive us our sins,” but, “Send us punishment for our mistakes.”
es: Did he have no hope left? Oh, in what monstrous moment of pride and blindness had he prayed for the portrait to bear the burden of his days and for him to retain the eternally intact splendor of youth! His failure stemmed from there. It would have been much better for him if each sin committed had been accompanied by its inevitable and immediate punishment. Instead of "forgive us our sins," the prayer of men to a God of justice should be "punish us for our iniquities."

en: The curiously carved mirror that Lord Henry had given to him, so many years ago now, was standing on the table, and the white-limbed Cupids laughed round it as of old. He took it up, as he had done on that night of horror when he had first noted the change in the fatal picture, and with wild, tear-dimmed eyes looked into its polished shield. Once, some one who had terribly loved him had written to him a mad letter, ending with these idolatrous words: “The world is changed because you are made of ivory and gold. The curves of your lips rewrite history.” The phrases came back to his memory, and he repeated them over and over to himself. Then he loathed his own beauty, and flinging the mirror on the floor, crushed it into silver splinters beneath his heel. It was his beauty that had ruined him, his beauty and the youth that he had prayed for. But for those two things, his life might have been free from stain. His beauty had been to him but a mask, his youth but a mockery. What was youth at best? A green, an unripe time, a time of shallow moods, and sickly thoughts. Why had he worn its livery? Youth had spoiled him.
vi: The intricately carved mirror that Lord Henry had given him, many years ago, stood on the table, and the ivory-limbed Cupids still laughed around it as before. He picked it up, as he had done on that dreadful night, when he first noticed the change in that disastrous picture, and with wild, tear-dimmed eyes, gazed into its polished shield. Once, someone who had loved him very much had written him a mad letter, ending with these adoring words: “The world changes because you are made of ivory and gold. The curves of your lips rewrite history.” These sentences came back to his memory, and he repeated them to himself. Then he grew to hate his own beauty, and, flinging the mirror to the floor, crushed it into silver splinters beneath his heel. It was his beauty that had ruined him, his beauty and the youth he had prayed for. Without these two things, his life might not have been soiled. To him, beauty was only a mask, youth was only a mockery. What was youth at its best? A green, unripe time, a time of shallow moods and sickly thoughts. Why had he worn its livery? Youth had spoiled him.
tr: Lord Henry's intricately carved mirror, given to him years ago, stood on the table, with the white-bodied Cupids around it still laughing as before. Just as he had done on that dreadful night when he first noticed the change in the ominous portrait, Dorian picked up the mirror and looked into its polished shield with eyes blurred by tears of madness. Once, someone who was passionately in love with him had written a frenzied letter, ending it with these words: "The world changed because you were made of ivory and gold. The curves of your lips rewrite history." Dorian remembered these sentences and began to murmur them. Then he became disgusted with his own beauty, smashing the mirror to the ground and shattering it into silver fragments under his heels. It was his beauty that had ruined him; his beauty, and the youth he had prayed to God for. If it weren't for these two things, his life would have remained unblemished. Yet his beauty had become merely a mask for him, and his youth a deception. What was youth, even in its best sense? A green, unripe age, a period filled with shallow emotions and morbid thoughts. Why had he borne the uniform of youth? Youth had been his downfall.
es: The curious carved mirror that Lord Henry had given him so many years ago was on the table, and the ivory-limbed cupids were still, as before, surrounding it with their laughter. He picked it up, as he had done on that night of horror, when he first noticed a change in the fatal portrait, and with eyes wide open, clouded by tears, he gazed at its polished surface. On one occasion, someone who had loved him passionately wrote him a letter that concluded with this declaration of idolatry: "The world has changed because you are made of ivory and gold. The curve of your lips rewrites history." Those phrases came back to his memory, and he repeated them over and over again. Then his beauty inspired in him an infinite disgust, and, throwing the mirror to the ground, he crushed it with his heel until it was reduced to silver splinters. His beauty had ruined him, his beauty and the youth for which he had prayed. Without either, perhaps his life would have remained unstained. Beauty had only been a mask, and his youth, a mockery. What was youth at best? A time of inexperience, of immaturity, a time of fleeting moods and morbid thoughts. Why had he insisted on wearing its uniform? Youth had ruined him.

en: It was better not to think of the past. Nothing could alter that. It was of himself, and of his own future, that he had to think. James Vane was hidden in a nameless grave in Selby churchyard. Alan Campbell had shot himself one night in his laboratory, but had not revealed the secret that he had been forced to know. The excitement, such as it was, over Basil Hallward’s disappearance would soon pass away. It was already waning. He was perfectly safe there. Nor, indeed, was it the death of Basil Hallward that weighed most upon his mind. It was the living death of his own soul that troubled him. Basil had painted the portrait that had marred his life. He could not forgive him that. It was the portrait that had done everything. Basil had said things to him that were unbearable, and that he had yet borne with patience. The murder had been simply the madness of a moment. As for Alan Campbell, his suicide had been his own act. He had chosen to do it. It was nothing to him.
vi: It's better not to think about the past. Nothing can change it. Yourself, your future, are what you should think about. James Vane was buried in an unmarked grave in Selby cemetery. Alan Campbell shot himself one night in his laboratory, but he did not reveal the secret he was forced to know. The pointless commotion around Basil Hallward's disappearance will soon pass. It is also fading away. You are absolutely safe. In fact, it wasn't really Basil Hallward's death that weighed most heavily on your mind. It was the half-dead state of your soul that tormented you. Basil had painted the portrait that ruined your life. You could not forgive him for that. It was that portrait that did everything. Basil had said things to you that were unbearable, and you still had to patiently endure them. The murder was simply the result of a momentary fit of rage. As for Alan Campbell, his suicide was his own act. He decided to do it. It had nothing to do with you.
tr: It was better not to think about the past. Nothing could change the past anyway! Now, he needed to think about himself, his own future. James Vane was buried in an unmarked grave in the garden of Selby Church. Alan Campbell had shot himself one night in his laboratory, yet he had not revealed the secret he had to learn. The not-so-excessive excitement caused by Basil Hallward's disappearance would soon subside. It had already begun to subside. In this regard, Dorian had nothing to fear. To tell the truth, the thing that worried him the most was not Basil Hallward's death. What truly disturbed him was that his own soul had died while he was still alive. Basil had painted the portrait that cast a shadow over his life. Dorian could not forgive this. Everything had happened because of that portrait. Basil had said things to him that were intolerable, yet Dorian had shown patience and tolerated them. The murder was nothing but a moment of madness. As for Alan Campbell; his suicide was his own doing. Alan had chosen this action himself. It had nothing to do with Dorian.
es: It was better not to think about the past. Nothing could change it. He had to think about himself, about his future. James Vane had been buried in an anonymous grave in the Selby cemetery. Alan Campbell had committed suicide one night in his laboratory, but without revealing the secret that had been imposed on him. The emotion, or curiosity, aroused by the disappearance of Basil Hallward would soon fade away. It was already starting to happen. In that regard, he had nothing to fear. And, in fact, it was not Basil Hallward's death that overwhelmed him the most. He was obsessed with the living death of his own soul. Basil had painted the portrait that ruined his life. He could not forgive him for that. The portrait was to blame for everything. Basil had said intolerable things to him, which he, however, endured with patience. The murder was simply the work of a momentary madness. As for Alan Campbell, the suicide had been his personal decision. He had chosen to act that way. It had nothing to do with him.

en: A new life! That was what he wanted. That was what he was waiting for. Surely he had begun it already. He had spared one innocent thing, at any rate. He would never again tempt innocence. He would be good.
vi: A new life! That's what you need. That's what you have been waiting for. Surely, you have already started it. After all, you have spared an innocent creature. You will never tempt the innocent again. You will be kind.
tr: A new life! This is what Dorian wanted. This is what he had been waiting for. In fact, he could already be considered to have started this new life. At least he had spared an innocent being! He would never again attempt to corrupt the innocent. He would be a good person.
es: A new life! That was what I needed. That was what I was waiting for. Without a doubt, I had already started it. I had avoided, at least, the ruin of an innocent creature. I would never again place temptation in the path of innocence. I would be good.

en: As he thought of Hetty Merton, he began to wonder if the portrait in the locked room had changed. Surely it was not still so horrible as it had been? Perhaps if his life became pure, he would be able to expel every sign of evil passion from the face. Perhaps the signs of evil had already gone away. He would go and look.
vi: When he thought about Hetty Merton, he began to wonder whether the portrait in the locked room had changed. Surely it couldn't be as horrifying as it once was? Perhaps if his life became purer, he could rid that face of all traces of sinful passion. Maybe the traces of sin had already disappeared. He would go and see.
tr: As he thought about Hetty Merton, he began to wonder if the portrait in the locked room had changed. The portrait couldn't still be as disgusting and horrible as before, could it? Perhaps if he cleansed his life, he could erase all those traces of sin and passion from the face in the portrait as well. Maybe those marks of evil had already been erased. Dorian would go and see.
es: When thinking about Hetty Merton, he began to wonder if the portrait had changed. Surely it would no longer be as horrible as before. Perhaps, if his life regained its purity, it would expel from his face every last trace of evil passions. Perhaps, even, they had already disappeared. He would go see it.

en: He took the lamp from the table and crept upstairs. As he unbarred the door, a smile of joy flitted across his strangely young-looking face and lingered for a moment about his lips. Yes, he would be good, and the hideous thing that he had hidden away would no longer be a terror to him. He felt as if the load had been lifted from him already.
vi: He took the lamp off the table and crept upstairs. As he unlatched the door, a joyful smile flashed across his strangely youthful face and lingered for a moment around his lips. Yes, he would live decently, the hideous thing he had hidden away would no longer be a terror to him. He felt as if a burden had been lifted from him.
tr: Taking the lamp from the table, he quietly went upstairs. As he pulled the door latch, a joyful smile flitted across his surprisingly youthful face and lingered on his lips for a moment. Yes, he would be a good person, and that disgusting thing he kept hidden would no longer frighten him. It already felt as if the burden on his shoulders had been lifted.
es: He took the lamp and stealthily went up the stairs. As he drew back the bolt, a smile of joy illuminated his strangely young face for an instant and lingered a few moments more around his lips. Yes, he would do good, and that dreadful portrait that had been hidden for so long would cease to terrify him. He felt as if a weight had already been lifted from his shoulders.

en: He went in quietly, locking the door behind him, as was his custom, and dragged the purple hanging from the portrait. A cry of pain and indignation broke from him. He could see no change, save that in the eyes there was a look of cunning and in the mouth the curved wrinkle of the hypocrite. The thing was still loathsome—more loathsome, if possible, than before—and the scarlet dew that spotted the hand seemed brighter, and more like blood newly spilled. Then he trembled. Had it been merely vanity that had made him do his one good deed? Or the desire for a new sensation, as Lord Henry had hinted, with his mocking laugh? Or that passion to act a part that sometimes makes us do things finer than we are ourselves? Or, perhaps, all these? And why was the red stain larger than it had been? It seemed to have crept like a horrible disease over the wrinkled fingers. There was blood on the painted feet, as though the thing had dripped—blood even on the hand that had not held the knife. Confess? Did it mean that he was to confess? To give himself up and be put to death? He laughed. He felt that the idea was monstrous. Besides, even if he did confess, who would believe him? There was no trace of the murdered man anywhere. Everything belonging to him had been destroyed. He himself had burned what had been below-stairs. The world would simply say that he was mad. They would shut him up if he persisted in his story.... Yet it was his duty to confess, to suffer public shame, and to make public atonement. There was a God who called upon men to tell their sins to earth as well as to heaven. Nothing that he could do would cleanse him till he had told his own sin. His sin? He shrugged his shoulders. The death of Basil Hallward seemed very little to him. He was thinking of Hetty Merton. For it was an unjust mirror, this mirror of his soul that he was looking at. Vanity? Curiosity? Hypocrisy? Had there been nothing more in his renunciation than that? There had been something more. At least he thought so. But who could tell? ... No. There had been nothing more. Through vanity he had spared her. In hypocrisy he had worn the mask of goodness. For curiosity’s sake he had tried the denial of self. He recognized that now.
vi: He quietly stepped in, locked the door behind him, as was his habit, and pulled the purple curtain away from the portrait. A cry of pain and anger escaped his lips. He could not see any change, except that in those eyes there was a cunning look, and on that mouth there was a hypocritical curve. It was still disgusting—more disgusting, if possible, than before—and the red dew staining the hand seemed fresher, more like newly shed blood. At that moment, he shivered. Was it only pride that had made him do his one good deed? Or was it the desire for a new sensation, as Lord Henry had hinted, with a mocking smile? Or the passion for acting a part that sometimes makes us do things finer than we are? Or, perhaps, all these things? And why was the stain larger than before? It seemed to have crept like a dreadful disease over the wrinkled fingers. There was blood on the painted feet, as though it had dripped down—blood even on the hand that had not held the knife. Confess? Did it mean that he should confess? Give himself up, and be put to death? He laughed. He felt that the idea was monstrous. Besides, even if he did confess, who would believe him? There was no trace of the murdered man anywhere. Everything belonging to him had been destroyed. He had burned what had been below stairs himself. People would simply say he was mad. They would shut him up if he persisted in his story... Yet it was his duty to confess, to suffer public shame, to make public atonement. There was God, and He required confession before men as well as before Heaven. He could do nothing that would cleanse him till he had told his own sin. His sin? He shrugged his shoulders. The death of Basil Hallward seemed very little to him. He was thinking of Hetty Merton. For it was an unjust mirror, this mirror of his soul that he was looking at. Pride? Curiosity? Hypocrisy? Had there been nothing more in his renunciation than that? There had been something more. At least he thought so. But who could say?... No. There had been nothing more. It was pride that had made him spare her. It was hypocrisy that had made him wear the mask of goodness. It was curiosity that had made him seek to deny himself. He recognized that now.
tr: He entered the room silently. As was his habit, he locked the door behind him, then pulled the purple cover off the portrait. A cry of anger and pain escaped from his lips. He could see no change. There was only an expression of cunning in the eyes and a line of hypocrisy on the mouth. The portrait was still disgusting – even more disgusting than before – the crimson dew drops that stained his hand looked more vivid than before, resembling freshly spilled blood even more. Dorian began to tremble. Had his pride made him commit the only good deed of his life? Perhaps, as Lord Henry had mockingly hinted, a search for a new excitement. Perhaps the desire to play a role that sometimes makes us perform nobler deeds than we are. Perhaps all of these. Could it be? And the red stain. Why had it expanded? It seemed to have spread over those wrinkled fingers like a vile disease. There was blood on the feet in the picture too, as if it had dripped and oozed between the toes; even the hand that had not held the knife was bloody. A confession perhaps? Was this indicating that he should confess everything? Surrender, go to the gallows? Dorian laughed. That was impossible. Besides, even if he confessed, who would believe his words? There was no trace left of the murdered man. Everything had been disposed of. Dorian himself had burned those downstairs. Everyone would look at him as if he were mad. If he insisted on his words, they would lock him up in an asylum... Gene de suçunu itiraf etmek, ele güne karşı mahcup olmak, cezasını çekmek de boynunun borcuydu. İnsanların günahlarının hesabını yalnızca öbür dünyada değil, bu dünyada da vermesini isteyen bir tanrı vardı. Günahını açığa vurmadıkça ne yaparsa yapsın, hiçbir şey onu arındıramazdı. Günahı mı? Dorian omuz silkti. Basil Hallward’ın ölümü pek umurunda değildi aslında. O Hetty Merton’u düşünüyordu, çünkü şu karşısındaki ayna, ruhunun aynası, ona haksızlık etmiyor muydu? Kibir ha? Merak? İkiyüzlülük? Bunlardan öte bir şey yok muydu, Hetty’den vazgeçmesinde? Olmaz olur muydu? Vardı; en azından o olduğunu sanıyordu. Ama kim bilebilirdi?.. Hayır. Başkaca hiçbir şey yoktu! Dorian kibri yüzünden kızı esirgemişti. İkiyüzlü olduğu için iyilik maskesi takmıştı. Merak uğruna fedakârlığı denemişti. Bunları şimdi kabul ediyordu. Now, about that murder...
es: He entered without making the slightest noise, locking the door again as was his custom, and removed the purple cloth that covered the painting. A cry of pain and indignation escaped his lips. There was no noticeable change, except for a gleam of cunning in the eyes and the sinuous wrinkles of hypocrisy around the mouth. The canvas was as hateful as ever, even more so, if that were possible; and the scarlet dew that stained the hand seemed brighter, more like freshly spilled blood. Dorian Gray then began to tremble. Had vanity alone driven him to carry out his only good deed? Or had it been the desire for a new sensation, as Lord Henry had suggested with his mocking laugh? Or perhaps the passionate desire to play a role that pushes us to do better things than we are naturally inclined to? Or maybe all of it at once? But why was the red stain larger? It seemed to have spread like a horrible disease over the wrinkled fingers. There was blood on the painted feet, as if that thing had dripped..., blood even on the hand that had not wielded the knife. A confession? Did that mean he was going to confess his crime? That he was going to turn himself in to be executed? He laughed. The idea seemed monstrous to him. Besides, even if he confessed, who would believe him? There was no trace anywhere of the murdered painter. All his belongings had been destroyed. He himself had burned the suitcase and coat. The world would simply say he was crazy. They would lock him up in an asylum if he insisted on repeating the same story... However, it was his duty to confess, to publicly endure the shame and expiate the guilt in an equally public manner. There was a God who demanded that humans confess their sins on earth as well as in heaven. Nothing he did would purify him if he didn't confess his sin. His sin? He shrugged. The death of Basil Hallward seemed very insignificant to him. He thought of Hetty Merton. Because that mirror of his soul he was gazing at was an unjust mirror. Vanity? Curiosity? Hypocrisy? Was there nothing more than that in his renunciation? There had been something more. At least that's what he believed. But how to know...? No. There was nothing more. He had only renounced the girl out of vanity. Hypocrisy had led him to don the mask of goodness. He had practiced self-denial out of curiosity. Now he acknowledged it.

en: But this murder—was it to dog him all his life? Was he always to be burdened by his past? Was he really to confess? Never. There was only one bit of evidence left against him. The picture itself—that was evidence. He would destroy it. Why had he kept it so long? Once it had given him pleasure to watch it changing and growing old. Of late he had felt no such pleasure. It had kept him awake at night. When he had been away, he had been filled with terror lest other eyes should look upon it. It had brought melancholy across his passions. Its mere memory had marred many moments of joy. It had been like conscience to him. Yes, it had been conscience. He would destroy it.
vi: But this murder — will it follow you all your life? Will you always have to bear the burden of the past? Will you really have to confess? No. There is only one piece of evidence left against you. The painting itself — that is the evidence. You will destroy it. Why have you kept it for so long? It once gave you joy to watch it change and age. Recently, you no longer find such joy. It keeps waking you up in the middle of the night. When you are away, you fear that other eyes might gaze upon it. It casts a shadow of sorrow over your passions. Just thinking about it has ruined many moments of joy. To you, it is like a conscience. Yes, it is a conscience. You must destroy it.
tr: Would it cling to him for life? Would Dorian carry the burden of his past for life? Would he really confess his crime? Never. There was only one piece of evidence left against him: the portrait itself; the only evidence. Dorian would get rid of it. Why had he kept it for so long anyway? Once, he used to take pleasure in watching the picture change and age. Lately, even that pleasure was gone. He couldn't sleep at night because of this picture. When he was away from home, he was terrified that other eyes would see the picture. His fiery emotions were overshadowed by sadness because of this picture. The mere memory of this picture had spoiled many pleasant moments. It was as if the portrait had become his conscience. Yes, it had become his conscience. Dorian had to get rid of the portrait.
es: But that murder..., was it going to haunt him all his life? Would he always have to bear the weight of his past? Should he confess? Never. There was only one piece of evidence against him. The painting itself: that was the evidence. He would destroy it. Why had he kept it for so long? Years ago, it gave him the pleasure of watching it change and grow old. In recent times, that pleasure had disappeared. The painting kept him from sleeping. When he traveled, he was horrified at the possibility of others seeing it. It tinged his passions with melancholy. Its mere memory spoiled many moments of joy. It had been something like his conscience. Yes. It had been his conscience. He would destroy it.

en: He looked round and saw the knife that had stabbed Basil Hallward. He had cleaned it many times, till there was no stain left upon it. It was bright, and glistened. As it had killed the painter, so it would kill the painter’s work, and all that that meant. It would kill the past, and when that was dead, he would be free. It would kill this monstrous soul-life, and without its hideous warnings, he would be at peace. He seized the thing, and stabbed the picture with it.
vi: He looked around and saw the knife that had once stabbed Basil Hallward. He had cleaned it many times, until there was no stain left. It gleamed brightly. Since it had killed the artist, it would also kill the artist's creation, and everything associated with it. It would kill the past, and when that past was dead, he would be free. It would kill this monstrous soul, and, without its ghastly warnings, he would be at peace. He grabbed the object and stabbed it into the painting.
tr: When he looked around, he saw the knife that killed Basil Hallward. How many times had he cleaned this knife, leaving no stain on it. The knife was sparkling, it was shining. Just as he had killed the painter, he would kill the painter's work and all its meaning. He would take the life of the past; when the past was dead, Dorian would be free. The knife would end the life of that disgusting, terrifying soul; when the portrait's warnings ceased, Dorian would find peace. He took the knife and stabbed the painting.
es: He looked around and saw the knife with which he had stabbed Basil Hallward. He had cleaned it many times, until all the stains disappeared. It shone, it sparkled. In the same way he had killed the painter, he would kill his work and everything it meant. He would kill the past and, when it was dead, he would regain his freedom. He would end that monstrous life of the soul and, without its hateful warnings, he would regain peace. He wielded the weapon and with it stabbed the portrait.

en: There was a cry heard, and a crash. The cry was so horrible in its agony that the frightened servants woke and crept out of their rooms. Two gentlemen, who were passing in the square below, stopped and looked up at the great house. They walked on till they met a policeman and brought him back. The man rang the bell several times, but there was no answer. Except for a light in one of the top windows, the house was all dark. After a time, he went away and stood in an adjoining portico and watched.
vi: Hearing a scream and a loud crash. The scream in the terrible throes of death was so horrifying that it woke the servants, who crept out of their rooms. Two gentlemen, passing through the square below, stopped and looked up at the enormous house. They continued until they met a policeman and brought him back. He rang the bell several times, but there was no response. Except for a light in one of the top-floor windows, the house was completely dark. After a while, he stepped back and stood in the adjacent gate to observe.
tr: A shout was heard, a commotion. The shout was so filled with terrible agony that the servants woke up in fright, and quietly came out of their rooms. Two gentlemen passing through the square below looked up at the large house. They went ahead and found a policeman, and brought him back. No matter how many times the policeman rang the doorbell, there was no response. Except for the light in one of the upper floor windows, the whole house was dark. After a while, the policeman walked away, went up to the porch of one of the neighboring houses, and started observing the house from there.
es: A scream was heard and the sound of a fall. The scream revealed such dreadful suffering that the servants woke up frightened and quietly left their rooms. Two gentlemen who were passing through the square stopped and looked up at the large house. Then they continued walking until they found a policeman and returned with him. They rang the bell several times, but received no response. Except for a light on one of the balconies of the upper floor, everything was dark. After a while, the policeman moved to a neighboring doorway to observe the building from there.

en: “Whose house is that, Constable?” asked the elder of the two gentlemen.
vi: "Whose house is that, officer?" the older of the two gentlemen asked.
tr: The older of the two gentlemen asked, "Whose house is this, officer?"
es: —Who lives in that house? —the older gentleman asked him.

en: “Mr. Dorian Gray’s, sir,” answered the policeman.
vi: "Mr. Dorian Gray's, sir," the policeman replied.
tr: Adam said, "Mr. Dorian Gray, sir."
es: —Mr. Dorian Gray—replied the policeman.

en: They looked at each other, as they walked away, and sneered. One of them was Sir Henry Ashton’s uncle.
vi: They looked at each other as they walked and laughed scornfully. One of the two was Sir Henry Ashton's uncle.
tr: The gentlemen exchanged glances, curling their lips in disdain as they walked away. One of them was a relative of Sir Henry Ashton.
