es: The two people who were listening to him exchanged a knowing glance and, as they walked away, there was a sneer of contempt on their faces. One of them was Sir Henry Ashton's uncle.

en: Inside, in the servants’ part of the house, the half-clad domestics were talking in low whispers to each other. Old Mrs. Leaf was crying and wringing her hands. Francis was as pale as death.
vi: Inside, in the servants' quarters of the house, the half-dressed servants were whispering to each other. Old Mrs. Leaf was crying and clenching her hands tightly. Francis was as pale as death.
tr: Inside, in the servants' quarters of the house, half-naked maids were whispering to each other. Old Ms. Leaf was crying, rubbing her hands together. Francis was as pale as a corpse.
es: Inside the house, in the area where the servants lived, the half-dressed servants spoke in low voices. The elderly Mrs. Leaf cried and wrung her hands. Francis was as pale as a dead man.

en: After about a quarter of an hour, he got the coachman and one of the footmen and crept upstairs. They knocked, but there was no reply. They called out. Everything was still. Finally, after vainly trying to force the door, they got on the roof and dropped down on to the balcony. The windows yielded easily—their bolts were old.
vi: After about a quarter of an hour, he called the coachman and a servant, then stealthily went upstairs. They knocked on the door, but there was no response. They called out loudly. Everything was as silent as the grave. Finally, after failing to break the door open, they climbed onto the roof and then descended to the balcony. The windows easily gave way; their latches were old.
tr: Fifteen minutes later, they took the coachman and one of the male servants and quietly went upstairs. They knocked on the door but received no answer. They called out. There was neither a sound nor a breath. After trying in vain to open the door, they finally climbed up to the roof and jumped onto the balcony from there. The glass door of the balcony opened easily; its bolt was worn out.
es: After approximately a quarter of an hour had passed, the valet took the coachman and one of the footmen with him and silently went up the stairs. The knocks on the door received no response. And everything remained silent when they called out to their master aloud. Finally, after trying in vain to force the door, they went out onto the roof and descended to the balcony. Once there, they entered without difficulty: the bolts were very old.

en: When they entered, they found hanging upon the wall a splendid portrait of their master as they had last seen him, in all the wonder of his exquisite youth and beauty. Lying on the floor was a dead man, in evening dress, with a knife in his heart. He was withered, wrinkled, and loathsome of visage. It was not till they had examined the rings that they recognized who it was.
vi: When they got in, they saw a magnificent portrait of the master hanging on the wall, just as they had seen him last, with all the wonderful springtime beauty. Lying on the floor was a dead man, dressed in evening clothes, with a knife in his heart. His face was haggard, wrinkled, and repulsive. It was not until they examined the rings closely that they recognized who he was.
tr: When they entered, they found a magnificent portrait of their master on the wall: Just as they had last seen him, dazzling with his unique youth and beauty, breathtaking. On the floor lay a man in a tuxedo, with a knife plunged into his heart. His face was wrinkled, sunken, extremely repulsive. It was only when they examined his rings that they could identify who he was.
es: Inside they found, hanging on the wall, a splendid portrait of their lord as they had last seen him, in all the splendor of his youth and singular beauty. On the floor, dressed in formal attire, and with a knife stuck in his heart, they found the corpse of an older man, very emaciated, full of wrinkles, and with a repugnant face. They only recognized him when they examined the rings he wore on his fingers.

en: THE END
